heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Application u/S.7 of IB Code - Limitation - Date of default by Corporate Debtor is 30.09.2014 - Copy of debit balance confirmation letter dated 07.04.2016 filed along with application - Corporate Debtor, in its reply before Adjudicating Authority, placed on record letter dated 17.11.2018, which detailed amount repaid till 30.09.2018 and acknowledged amount outstanding as on 30.09.2018 - Corporate Debtor shown to have executed various documents amounting to acknowledgement of debt even in financial year 2019-20 - Sufficient material on record to justify enlargement of extension period in accordance with S.18 of Limitation Act, considered by Adjudicating Authority before admitting application - Held, thus application u/S.7 filed on 25.04.2019, was within limitation. (Paras 22, 23, 24)

heading: Payment of gratuity
Liability
HeadNote.description:
Payment of gratuity - Liability - Act provides for complete mechanism for determination & discharge of - Same thereby discloses need for speedy disposal of matter at all stages including in appeal - Phraseology of Act thereby indicates by necessary implication exclusion of provisions to S.5 of Limitation Act - Extension of period of limitation by supplementing it with provision of S.5 of Limitation Act is impermissible.

The Act, provides for complete mechanism for determination and discharge of liability pertaining to the subject of gratuity. It is a complete code in itself. Precisely, but in its entirety the said Act deals with the process and the proceedings relating to the subject of gratuity payable by the employer to its employees. All the relevant and material provisions of law to determine the said subject covering the aspect of its determination, including the process of adjudication of all disputes relating thereto with finality attached to the decision in respect thereof with all necessary checks by authoritative review of the decision thereunder, it prescribes complete procedure for the proceedings thereunder. Besides, the scheme of the said Act reveals that the liability regarding the payment of gratuity is to be determined in accordance with the method prescribed under the said Act and should be paid as soon as it becomes payable otherwise, the employer incurs further liability of payment of interest as well being subjected to prosecution, besides penalty. The scheme, therefore, clearly indicates the intention of the Legislature to compel the employer to clear the liability regarding the gratuity as soon as it becomes due and payable, failure of which would invite penalty and prosecution for the employer. This obviously would disclose the need for speedy disposal of the matter including those at the appellate stage under the said Act and certainly in time bound framed programme. 						 [Para 16]

Considering the phraseology of Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act, undoubtedly, there is presumption about its applicability to special Acts in case of such special Act being silent about its exclusion. But the presumption would stand rebutted once the provision relating to limitation and restriction on power of extension thereof being specifically provided under a special statute. Merely because a special statute is silent on the subject, that by itself would not lead to a presumption about exclusion of Section 29(2) or for that matter Section 5 of the Limitation Act. Nevertheless, when the phraseology of the relevant provision in the special statute inevitably indicates the intention of the Legislature to exclude by necessary implication the applicability of the provisions of law contained under Section 5 of the Limitation Act, it would amount to making violence to the statutory provision to construe it to the contrary. To read the concept of unlimited extension of period of limitation by filing appeal under the said Act in the said proviso to Section 7(7) of the said Act would virtually amount to supplement the said proviso by Section 5 of the Limitation Act which is clearly impermissible.  [Para 21]

heading: Condonation of delay
Insolvency proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Insolvency proceedings - An application for condonation of delay in filing such proceedings cannot take into consideration merely the rights and liabilities of the judgment debtor and the person at whose instance the Insolvency Notice is issued, or the original and substituted petitioning creditors who are no longer interested in proceedings with the matter for any reason - Held, the court must also consider the effect of such applications being allowed on all the other creditors who are entitled to rely upon and act on the basis of the act of insolvency, for it is their rights which are invoked.

In the present case, the judgment debtors had paid the entire decretal amount with a delay of only one day. In that event there was nothing that prevented the judgment debtors from adopting proceedings under Section 9 of the said Act earlier to prevent the consequences under the said Act. The delay of almost four years in filing the present Notice of Motion is neither warranted nor justified. During this period of four years, the rights of the general body of creditors have intervened. An application for condonation of delay in filing such proceedings cannot take into consideration merely the rights and liabilities of the judgment debtor and the person at whose instance the Insolvency Notice is issued, or the original and substituted petitioning creditors who are no longer interested in proceeding with the matter for any reason. The Court must also consider the effect of such applications being allowed on all the other creditors who are entitled to rely upon and act on the basis of the act of insolvency for it is their rights which are invoked. In the present case the grant of any orders would unnecessarily protract the proceedings as far as such other parties are concerned, entirely due to the default of the judgment debtors. For instance, the intervenor viz. Kaushik Shah Shares & Securities Pvt. Ltd. has itself been prosecuting this matter after substitution for almost two years. There is no reason to exercise Court's discretion in condoning the delay. The same would only further delay the entire proceedings by compelling other creditors to adopt independent proceedings. There is also the possibility in some cases of the claims being barred by limitation. There is also the possibility of some of the creditors not being able to adopt insolvency proceedings, as they may not be maintainable. In any event, it would involve an unfair protraction of litigation and multiplicity of proceedings as far as the general body of creditors are concerned. In the circumstances, the Notice of Motion is dismissed with costs fixed at Rs.5,000/-.  [Para 9,12]

HeadNote.description:
Complaint about dishonour of cheque - Notice served beyond 15 days of intimation regarding dishonour of cheque by payee - Delay cannot be condoned either under S.473 of Cr.P.C. or under S.5 of Limitation Act - Magistrate cannot be deemed to have condoned the delay when he issued summons to petitioner.

Serving of notice within 15 days of the receipt of intimation regarding dishonour of cheque by the payee and failure to make payment within 15 days of receipt of notice issued under clause (b) of Section 138 by the drawer are to precede the filing of complaint under Section 138. In the matter of condoning delay in issuing demand notice beyond the statutory period of 15 days neither Section 473 Cr.P.C. or Section 5 of Limitation Act, 1963 would apply nor such a delay can be legally condoned. Obviously, based on said notice dated 24th September, 1994, the respondent No.2 did not have cause of action for launching the prosecution of petitioner under Section 138. Thus, being abuse of process of Court the complaint deserves to be quashed under Section 482 Cr.P.C.  [Para 8]

heading: Complaint filed beyond limitation
HeadNote.description:
Complaint filed beyond limitation - Delay cannot be condoned.

Section 142 of the NI Act prohibits the Court from taking cognizance of an offence, except where it is made within one month from the date on which the cause of action arose. The words "no Courts shall take cognizance of offence" and the non obstante clause galvanizing the proceedings under the Act from anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 in that regard, assume significance. When the Section places a complete bar on taking cognizance of an offence, except where the complaint is made within one month from the date on which the cause of action arose, the power to condone delay under Section 5 of the Limitation Act stands excluded.			   [Para 12]

heading: Dishonour of cheque
Debt liability
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Dishonour of cheque - Debt liability - Limitation - Respondent purchasing vehicle under hire purchase agreement - Issued cheque for discharging his partial liability - No evidence showing date and time of last payment - Although entire record pertaining to payment of installments and sale of vehicle was with complainant same has been withheld for reasons best known to it - Date of auction of said vehicle cannot be taken to be date of last payment on be-half of respondent - Material showing that cheque was issued by respondent when debt liability had become time barred - Provisions of S.19 of Limitation Act cannot be invoked for extending period of limitation - Acquittal of respondent, proper.

In this case according to the case of the respondent, he had paid the entire amount of debt, whereas, the case of the appellant is that only partial payment was made by the respondent. Admittedly, the entire record pertaining to the payment of installments and sale of the vehicle, which was returned to it in September, 1999, was with the appellant, but the same has been withheld for the reasons best known to the complainant appellant-Company. Moreover, the auction of the said vehicle is stated to have taken place on 18-10-2000. but that cannot be taken to be the date of last payment on behalf of the respondent, inasmuch as, at that time, the vehicle was in the possession of the appellant. Moreover, on the said date, i.e. 18-10-2000, the liability of discharging the debt had become time-barred. In this regard, it is pertinent to mention here that as per the Hire Purchase Agreement (Ex.DX), the entire debt amount to the tune of Rs.3,20,000/- was made payable in 36 monthly installments, with effect from 20-5-1996 and as such, the same had to be paid within three years i.e. on or before 20-5-1999. As stated above, the cheque dated 24-9-1999 was issued by the respondent when the debt liability had become time barred. Herein the instant case, the appellant has miserably failed to give any specific date, either in his complaint or in his examination-in-chief in respect of the last payment of instalment or interest so as to bring the claim of the appellant within time. On the other hand, under Section 19 of the Limitation Act, 1963, the payment has got to be proved in a particular way i.e. on the basis of some writing or signed acknowledgment.   [Para 9]

heading: Time barred debt
Acknowledgment
Issuance of cheques
HeadNote.description:
Contract Act (1872), S.25 - Time barred debt - Acknowledgment - Issuance of cheques - A cheque itself is a document which could fall within the scope of S.18 of the Limitation Act - Held, when a drawer revalidates cheque from time to time which is permissible, it could be said that on each occasion there was a fresh promise as envisaged by S.25 of the Contract Act as well as an acknowledgment within the meaning of S.18 of the Limitation Act if such revalidation is made within the period of limitation.

A cheque itself is a document which could fall within the scope of Section 18 of the Limitation Act.  Acknowledgment is given before the expiry of period of limitation since time was extended under the signature.

Assuming for the sake of argument that there was no acknowledgment before the expiry of period of limitation and the cheque is issued after a period of expiry of limitation, still whether there is an enforceable liability or not will have to be considered.  The cheque is issued under the signature of the debtor after putting the sum payable.  The cheque directs the bank to pay the bearer sum mentioned in the cheque.  As such it becomes the promise in favour of the payee within the meaning of Section 25(3) of the Indian Contract Act.  Once it becomes a fresh promise, fresh period of limitation of 3 years would begin to run from the date of cheque.  Hence the liability would certainly be a legally enforceable liability.

When a drawer revalidates cheque from time to time which is permissible, it could be said that on each occasion there was a fresh promise as envisaged by Section 25 of the Contract Act as well as an acknowledgment within the meaning of Section 18 of the Limitation Act if such revalidation is made within the period of limitation.  In the instant case admittedly the accused-applicant had extended the date of cheque from time to time under his own signature and had validated the cheques.  As said earlier such validation amounts to a fresh promise and therefore, he has revived a barred debt.  The proceedings have been filed within 3 years from the last such revalidation and in view of this it could not be said that under the cheque the applicant sought to recover a barred debt.  2006(3) ALL MR 673 & 2002(1) ALL MR 275 (S.C.) - Ref. to.  [Para 6,8]

heading: Dishonour of cheque
Time barred debt

ILR 2007 Karnataka 1708 Rel. on. 			(Paras 13, 14, 15)

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Application u/S.3G(5) of National Highways Act - Rejection on ground of bar of limitation being filed after 10 months of passing of award by Competent Authority - Validity - No specific period of limitation u/S.3G(5) - Also, there is no discussion in order as to what would be prescribed period of limitation for application u/S. 3G(5) - Application would be governed by Art.137 of Limitation Act and is to be filed within period of 3 years - Application was filed within period of 3 years - Order rejecting application liable to be set aside. 2016 (160) AIC 820 Rel.on.	(Paras 6, 9)

heading: Dishonor of cheque
Time barred debt
HeadNote.description: Dishonor of cheque - Time barred debt - Plea of accused that cheque issued in 2006 for time barred debt of 2002, therefore prosecution u/S.138 not maintainable - For debt of 2002 complainant filed civil suit for recovery of money in 2004 itself within limitation - Filing of suit stops period of limitation from running - Complainant wrote letter to politician to protest nomination of accused for assembly constituency - Impugned cheque issued in 2006 in order to purchase peace after complainant wrote letter, which has given fresh cause of action to complainant for prosecution u/S.138 - Cheque was not towards time barred debt but was towards live debt - Plea of accused not tenable - Prosecution u/S.138, maintainable. 	(Para 53)

heading: Civil P.C. (1908), S.100
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), S.100 - Suit for recovery of money - Question whether transaction was money lending or merely hand loan - Document in question revealing clear promise to repay amount taken without interest - Document thus falls in definition of promissory note and definition of loan under Bombay Money Lenders Act - Further, plaintiffs admission that he had lent money to many persons and civil and criminal proceedings are pending - Clearly indicates it as case of money lending without licence - Order dismissing suit on said ground, proper. 1976 Mh.L.J. Note No.10 - Rel. on.	(Para 9)

heading: Demand notice
Period of limitation
Calculation of
HeadNote.description:
Demand notice - Period of limitation - Calculation of - Held, the date on which the receipt of information from the bank regarding return of cheque as unpaid received, should be excluded while calculating period of limitation for issuance of demand notice. 

2013 ALL SCR 3090 Foll. 	(Para 4)

heading: Dishonour of cheque
HeadNote.description: Dishonour of cheque - Applicability of provisions of Limitation Act - Held, when a criminal liability is fastened in respect of civil liability under provisions in Ss.138 to 142, working of Ss.138 and 142 of NI Act excludes operation of Ss.4 to 24 of the Limitation Act. 	(Para 53)

heading: Dismissal of Criminal complaint
HeadNote.description: Dismissal of Criminal complaint - Delay of 9 months in filing revision against - Petitioner rustic woman remains out of village for harvesting purpose - Her married daughter harassed mentally and physically by in-laws - Her fetus died in womb resulting into her death without medical treatment - Delay caused is more than 6 months excluding period of limitation - Liberal view required to be adopted - Delay caused in filing revision deserves to be condoned in the interest of justice - Petitioner granted opportunity to prosecute. 	(Paras 8, 9, 11)

heading: Grant of
HeadNote.description: Specific performance of contract - Grant of - Challenge on ground that suit was barred by limitation in view of Art.54 of Limitation Act as it was filed three years after date fixed for performance of contract - Under agreement to sell it was for vendor to settle all disputes in property - Record showing that land acquisition proceedings in respect of land in question were set aside at instance of plaintiff-purchaser - Thereafter he issued legal notice to defendants for execution of sale deed and on their refusal filed suit - Considering circumstances of case Art.113 would be applicable - Cause of action to file suit arose on refusal of defendants - Plaintiff filed suit within 3 years from accrual of cause of action - He was always ready and willing to perform his part of agreement - Grant of relief of specific performance of contract, proper - However, considering fact that 40 years have elapsed since execution of agreement of sale plaintiff was directed to pay Rs.15,00,000/- to defendants towards full sale consideration including balance sale consideration.	(Paras 7.3, 7.4)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Civil P. C. (1908), O. 21, R. 95 - Suit for possession - Plea of barred by limitation - Plaintiff claiming that father of defendant forcibly took possession of suit property - Plaintiff become absolute owner of suit property in 1960 on issuance of sale certificate and possession receipt was issued in execution proceedings u/O. 21, R. 95 of CPC - Defendant claiming that their father never parted with possession of suit property after sale certificate and possession receipt was issued to plaintiff - Suit is based on title - Limitation of 12 years begin to run from date when possession of defendants become adverse - Defendants nowhere pleaded about perfecting title by adverse possession nor pleaded any dates of adverse possession - Symbolic possession delivered to plaintiff in 1960, would arrest period of limitation to file application u/O. 21, R. 95 of CPC - No question of limitation to file suit for possession, would arise unless possession of defendants become adverse to plaintiff - Suit not barred by limitation. (Paras 27, 28, 29, 31)

headline: Specific Relief Act (1963), S. 6 – Limitation Act (1963), Art. 65 – Civil P. C. (1908), O. 21, R. 95 – Suit for possession – Plea of barred by limitation – Plaintiff claiming that father of defendant forcibly took possession of suit property – Plaintiff become absolute owner of suit property in 1960 on issuance of sale certificate and possession receipt was issued in execution proceedings u/O. 21, R. 95 of CPC – Defendant claiming that their father never parted with possession of suit property after sale certificate and possession receipt was issued to plaintiff – Suit is based on title – Limitation of 12 years begin to run from date when possession of defendants become adverse – Defendants nowhere pleaded about perfecting title by adverse possession nor pleaded any dates of adverse possession – No question of limitation to file suit for possession, would arise unless possession of defendants become adverse to plaintiff – Suit not barred by limitation.

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Limitation - Plaintiff seeking specific performance of agreement of sale - Sale deed was to be executed after obtaining necessary permission from revenue authorities - Subsequently requirement of obtaining permission was not necessary - No action taken by plaintiff during lifetime of seller to get sale deed executed - Son of seller made mutation entry in his name after death of seller - Plaintiff had knowledge of said mutation entry - But he had not made any request to son of seller to execute sale deed after death of seller - Plaintiff was required to file suit within 3 years of mutation entry by son of seller as it amounts to his refusal for specific performance - Suit was not filed within period of 3 years - There is unreasonable delay in seeking relief of specific performance - Suit barred by limitation - Dismissal of suit, proper. (Paras 19, 20, 22, 24, 25)

heading: Decree
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of contract - Decree - Challenge - Execution of agreement not disputed by defendant, rather she entered in correspondence with plaintiff for incorporation of some clause - Plaintiff proved her readiness and willingness to perform her part of agreement and also her financial capacity to purchase suit property - Part payment before execution of sale deed and plaintiff's financial capacity to pay balance consideration also proved as she had arranged fund by obtaining loan from LIC - Plaintiff also filed suit immediately on expiry of period within 10 days to show her readiness and willingness to purchase suit property - Therefore, passing of decree of specific performance, held justified.	(Para 43)

heading: Application of Custodian for return of money belonging to lender from third party
HeadNote.description: Application of Custodian for return of money belonging to lender from third party - Contention that application barred by limitation - Held, application not one for recovery of money but merely bring to notice of court that third party is in possession of attached assets and are refusing to give them - As Third Parties to whom funds diverted attempt to secrete the funds - U/s. 3(3) what gets attached is the right in the money itself - Once money stands attached then no application be made by parties for recovery of money - When right in money existed on date of notification then even if right to recover gets barred by limitation the property is statutorily attached - Limitation Act not to apply to acts of court as duty of Court is to recover the properties.	(Para 19)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Suit for specific performance of contract - Limitation - Three years from date fixed for performance, or, if no such date is fixed, when the plaintiff has notice that performance is refused - Registration of a document as well as possession would constitute notice, as is evident from S.3 of Transfer of Property Act - Parties by their conduct or otherwise may also extend time for performance of contract. Transfer of Property Act (1882), S.3.

The Court, in applying the period of limitation, would first inquire as to whether any time was fixed for performance of agreement of sale.  If it is so fixed, the suit must be filed within the period of three years, failing which the same would be barred by limitation.  Here, however, no time for performance was fixed.  It was for the Courts to find out the date on which the plaintiff had notice that the performance was refused and on arriving at a finding in that behalf, to see whether the suit was filed within three years thereafter. [Para 11]

The 1st Defendant was a friend of the 2nd Defendant. Admittedly, the usual stipulations were knowingly not made in the agreement of sale dated 11-4-1983.  The 1st Defendant may or may not be aware about the agreement entered by and between the respondent herein.  But he cannot raise a plea of absence of notice of the deed of sale dated 4-9-1985, which was a registered document. Possession of the suit land by the appellant also stands admitted.  Registration of a document as well as possession would constitute notice, as is evident from Section 3 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882.   [Para 13]

Admittedly, father-in-law and wife of the Respondent No.1 had been looking after his affairs. They were, therefore, acting as his agents.  They would be deemed to have notice of the registration of the document as also the possession of the appellant herein.  If they had the requisite notice, the Respondent No.1., having regard thereto, should have filed a suit for specific performance of contract within the prescribed period. In fact they should have done so expeditiously having regard to the discretionary nature of relief he may obtain in the suit. They did not do so. They waited for more than two years from the date of execution of deed of sale.  Even if the suit was not barred by limitation on that account, it was a fit case, where the Court should have refused to exercise its discretionary jurisdiction under Section 20 of the Specific Relief Act, 1963. 2006(4) ALL MR (S.C.) 110 and 2006(3) ALL MR (S.C.) 85 - Ref to. (2006)5 SCC 340 - Followed.					        [Para 14,15]

heading: Suit for specific performance
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Whether barred by limitation - No specific date fixed for performance of agreement of sale - Second clause of Art. 54 applicable and period of limitation of three years commence to run from date on which plaintiff has knowledge that performance is refused - Plaintiff has knowledge in 1993 itself that defendant was not ready to execute sale deed as he had filed suit for possession seeking cancellation of agreement of sale - Suit for specific performance should have been filed immediately or within period of three years after such suit filed by defendant - However, suit filed by plaintiff in 2012 i.e. beyond limitation period of three years - Liable to be dismissed being barred by limitation. 	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Execution of decree
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Execution of decree - Limitation - Decree of prohibitory injunction - Execution of decree of prohibitory injunction is not subject to any period of limitation - It can be executed anytime when violation thereof takes place. (Paras 10, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - On basis of adverse possession - Suit is based on possessory title - Official record of suit land shows that it was owned by defendant and is in possession of same - Plaintiff failed to show that he is in actual possession, much less continuous possession of property for longer period which may be called settled possession or established possession - Suit liable to be dismissed. 	(Paras 7, 8, 13, 15, 16)

heading: Suit for declaration of title and perpetual injunction
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration of title and perpetual injunction - On basis of adverse possession of more than 12 years - Suit for declaration of ownership on basis of adverse possession is not maintainable - As claim of adverse possession can be made use of by way of shield and not as sword - It can be claimed as defence when arrayed as defendant in proceeding - However, as plaintiffs proved that they were in possession for more than 12 years - Plaintiffs entitled to relief of perpetual injunction to restrain defendants from disturbing their possession, otherwise than due process of law. 2014(7) ALL MR 813 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			(Paras 6, 11, 12)

heading: Right to sue on contract of indemnity
HeadNote.description:
Right to sue on contract of indemnity - Arises when contract is broken - Limitation to be counted from date when assets of company are sold and not from date of recall notice.

When the Corporation takes steps for recovery of the amount by resorting to the provisions of Section 29 of the State Financial Corporation Act, the limitation period for recovery of the balance amount would start only after adjusting the proceeds from the sale of assets of the industrial concern. As the Corporation would be in a position to know as to whether there is a shortfall or there is excess amount realised, only after the sale of the mortgage/ hypothecated assets. This is clear from the language of sub-Section (1) of Section 29 which makes the position abundantly clear. Merely because the Corporation acted under Section 29 of the Act, did not mean that the contract of indemnity came to an end. Section 29 merely enabled the Corporation to take possession and sell the assets for recovery of the dues under the main contract. It may be that only the Corporation taking action under Section 29 and on their taking possession they became deemed owners. The mortgage may have come to an end, but the contract of indemnity, which was an independent contract, did not. The right to claim for the balance arose, under the contract of indemnity, only when the sale proceeds were found to be insufficient. The right to sue on the contract of indemnity arose after the assets were sold. The present case would fall under Article 55 of the Limitation Act, 1963 which corresponds to old Articles 115 and 116 of the old Limitation Act, 1908. The right to sue on a contract of indemnity/ guarantee would arise when the contract is broken. Therefore, the period of limitation is to be counted from the date when the assets of the Company were sold and not when the recall notice was given.

2006(3) ALL MR 196 (S.C.), 2007 ALL SCR 2954 Ref.     [Para 21,22,23]

heading: Suit for specific performance of contract
HeadNote.description:
Suit for specific performance of contract - Whether barred by limitation - Time was not essence of contract - Limitation would start from date of knowledge of refusal of defendant to perform contract - Plaintiff claiming that suit was filed within three years from date of refusal of defendant to perform their part of contract - However no evidence given by plaintiff to prove that on said date defendant refused to perform their part of contract and limitation started to run from said date - In absence of any evidence it cannot be assumed that limitation started to run from said date - Further plaintiff cannot claim that matter be remanded and he should be allowed to lead evidence, as opportunity was already given to plaintiff to lead evidence - Suit held barred by limitation.

As per Art. 54 of Limitation Act, 1963 limitation period of three years to file suit for specific performance begins to run from date fixed for performance or if no such date is fixed then from date when plaintiff came to notice that defendant refused performance. In the present case there was no specific date fixed for performance of contract therefore limitation would start from date of knowledge of refusal of defendant to perform contract. Plaintiff claiming that on 14th December, 2011 he came to knowledge that defendant refused to perform their part of contract and suit is filed within three years from said date therefore is within limitation. Burden was on plaintiff to prove that defendant refused performance on 14th December, 2011 however, plaintiff given no evidence despite opportunity was given to him for leading evidence. Not having proved this fact, the Plaintiff cannot succeed on a mere assumption.Further, having failed in its attempt to proceed without evidence, the Plaintiff cannot now say as it does that the matter should be remanded and the Plaintiff should now be allowed to lead evidence only because it has failed on the issue when it consciously and deliberately chose not to do so. Rejection of suit being barred by limitation, proper. 		 [Para 14,16,18,19]

heading: Limitation for
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of contract - Limitation for - No time is fixed for performance of contract - It does not mean that agreement stipulated indefinite period for performance of contract - Engagement must be performed within a reasonable time - No refusal on part of defendant to perform his part of contract by issuing notice - No material on record to show that defendant refused to perform his part of contract - Plaintiff pleaded and proved his continuous readiness and willingness - Plaintiff made out case for specific performance - Suit is not barred by limitation. 	(Paras 17, 20, 21, 28, 31)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Respondent claiming that he has perfected title over suit property by adverse possession - Record showing that possession of respondent over suit property is permissive in character - At no stage possession was hostile to owners of property - High Court erred in accepting plea of adverse possession - Respondent not entitled to possession. (Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Application under S.31 for enforcing liabilities against sureties - Limitation - Order under S.31 not being a decree or order of court, Art.136 is not attracted - Limitation would be governed by Art.137 i.e. limitation of 3 years.

Section 31 of the Act contains special provisions for enforcement of claims by State Financial Corporations. It is by way of a legal fiction that the procedure akin to execution of decrees under the Code of Civil Procedure has been permitted to be invoked. But one cannot lose sight of the fact that there is no decree or order of a civil court when we are dealing with applications under Section 31 of the Act. The legal fiction at best refers to a procedure to be followed. It does not mean that a decree or order of a civil court is being executed, which is a sine qua non for invoking Article 136. While dealing with an application under Sections 31 and 32 of the Act there is no decree or order of a civil court being executed. It was only on the basis of a legal fiction that the proceedings under Section 31 are treated as akin to execution proceedings. There is no decree to be executed nor there is any decree-holder or judgment-debtor and, therefore, in a strict sense it cannot be said to be a case of execution of a decree. Article 136 of the Limitation Act has no application in the facts of the present case. Article 136 specifically uses the words "decree or order of any civil court". The application under Sections 31 and 32 of the State Financial Corporations Act is not by way of execution of a decree or order of any civil court.   [Para 5]

heading: Agreement of sale
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Agreement of sale - Date fixed for performance - Part first of Article 54 of Limitation Act would apply - Cause of action for filing the suit or period of limitation will begin to run from the date fixed for performance - When terms of a document are clear and not ambiguous no external evidence can be allowed to disapprove the contents of the documents. AIR 1990 SC 529 - AIR 2002 SC 960 - Followed.	(Paras 6 & 8)

heading: Applications u/Ss.228 and 276
HeadNote.description:
Applications u/Ss.228 and 276 - For grant of probate or Letter of Administration - Art.137 of Limitation Act would be applicable. 

2008 ALL SCR 1221, 2009(4) ALL MR 493 (S.C.) Rel.on. (Paras 10, 11)

heading: Application for Letter of Administration
HeadNote.description:
Application for Letter of Administration - Issue as to when ‘right to apply’ accrues - Held, after the Will is probated by any Court u/S.228, applicant has a continuous right to get the Letter of Administration - He can apply anytime, as long as the right survives and object of trust exists.

AIR 1983 Bom. 268, AIR 1991 Mad. 214 Ref.to. (Paras 17, 18)

heading: Suit for possession
Limitation to file
Not tenable
Not barred
Order decreeing suit
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Limitation to file - Plaintiff claiming ownership on basis of sale-deed - Clear recital in sale-deed that possession was delivered to plaintiff - Corroborated by entries in crop statements - Plea of non delivery of possession - Not tenable - Suit filed within 12 years of dispossession - Not barred - Further in absence of evidence about inadequacy of price - Plea that in such cases transaction should be treated as money lending transaction - Not tenable - Order decreeing suit - Proper. (Paras 10, 12, 13)

heading: Bar of limitation
Applicability
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Bar of limitation - Applicability - Pleadings and evidence of plaintiff himself shows that defendant by issuing notice on 10.1.1983 extended time to execute sale deed by 9.2.1983 - And that on failure of defendant to discharge their liability till 9.2.1983 plaintiff issued notice to defendant asking him to perform their part of contract only on 22.4.1986 - Shows that plaintiff kept silence about his part from 1983 to 1986 - Suit held time barred.		(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Limitation - As per Art. 54 period of limitation is 3 years from date fixed for performance and if no date is fixed when plaintiff has noticed that performance is refused - Material on record showing that no specific date fixed for performance of contract - Suit not covered by first part of Art. 54 - Plaintiff has filed suit after one year of getting knowledge of refusal of performance i.e. within period of 3 yeas limitation - Suit not barred by limitation. (Paras 30, 32)

heading: Suit for specific performance
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Plea as to bar of limitation - Is mixed question of law and fact - Could not be raised for first time in second appeal. 	(Para 19)

heading: Declaratory suit
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Declaratory suit - Limitation - Suit for declaration that defendant inherited suit property under Will with restriction on its transfer - Plaintiff alleged to have received knowledge about inalienability of suit property when he received copy of Will under RTI Act - Date of receipt of Will is therefore the date when cause of action to file suit first arose - Limitation would start running from that date - Suit filed beyond 3 yrs. of that date is barred by limitation. 	(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Probate of Will
Limitation for applying
HeadNote.description: Probate of Will - Limitation for applying - Right to apply is a continuing right so long as right to do so survives. 2008 ALL SCR 1221, 2009(4) ALL MR 493 (S.C.) Foll. 	(Paras 34, 36)

heading: Limitation
Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.7 R.11 - Suit for declaration, partition and possession - Limitation - Rejection of plaint - Plaintiff daughter claimed ownership of ¼ share in suit flat alongwith defendants, parents and family members - Grand father of plaintiff, original tenant of flat expired in 1989 - Landlord transferred ownership rights, for consideration, in favour of parents of plaintiff in year 1995 - Plaintiff married in 1978 and divorced in 1995 - Resided in said flat after divorce, till being restrained from entering said premises by interim order of Court in year 2001 - Plaintiff never sought declaration of her tenancy rights in flat - Nor challenged deed of Apartment registered in 1995, though she was well aware of it and allegedly paid her contribution for transfer of ownership - Earlier suit filed in 2000 by her parents denying her right, title or interest in flat decreed in their favour - Thus, right to sue accrued to her when she filed written statement in said suit in year 2002 - But she did not assert her rights in said suit - Nor filed counter claim - Therefore, separate suit filed by her in year 2011 for declaration of rights and other reliefs, against parents and others - Barred by limitation in view of Art.58 of Limitation Act - Period of limitation of 12 years u/Art.65, not attracted - Rejection of plaint under O.7 R.11, proper. 2011 ALL SCR 2540, 2018(6) ALL MR 474 (S.C.) Disting. (Paras 47, 49, 51, 54, 55, 56, 57, 70)

heading: Application for
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Revocation of probate of will - Application for - Limitation - Application for revocation has to be filed within 3 years from date of grant of probate - Application filed after 7 years from date of grant of probate - No prayer in application for condonation of delay - Application for revocation of  probate liable to be dismissed on ground of limitation.	(Para 12)

heading: Suit for declaration of title
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration of title - Plaintiff not in possession - No revenue entries produced in support - Ownership or possession of plaintiff and his vendor for a period of 12 years or more prior to the suit - Sale deed and partition deed executed hardly three years prior to suit - Held it was necessary to trace title to a point beyond minimum of 12 years before the suit.	(Para 7)

heading: Revocation of probate
Proceeding for
HeadNote.description:
Revocation of probate - Proceeding for - Time runs from date of grant of probate.

A grant of probate by a Competent Court operates as a judgment in Rem and once the probate to the Will is granted, then the said probated Will is good not only in respect of the parties to the proceedings, but against the whole world. Therefore, if the probate is granted, the same operates in Rem and time runs from the date of the grant of the probate for purposes of limitation under Article 137 of the Limitation Act in proceedings for revocation of probate.

heading: Limitation
Cause of action
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration of title - Limitation - Cause of action - Suit filed by plaintiff when Govt. was constructing road through suit property and plaintiffs learnt about erroneous entry in survey records - Cause of action arose when plaintiff learnt about erroneous entry - Mere existence of wrong entry in revenue records does not give rise to cause of action - Plaintiff's suit, not barred by limitation.		(Para 10)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Exclusion of provisions of Limitation Act - Held, if special or local law expressly excludes provisions of Limitation Act, then, recourse cannot be had to any of those Sections as they have been expressly excluded. 	(Para 23)

heading: Agreement of Sale
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Agreement of Sale - Suit for specific performance of agreement - Limitation - Agreement to sell not fixing any date for performance - Agreement denied by defendants - Suit for specific performance filed by plaintiff against defendants - Suit was filed within few months of receipt of notice about execution of sale deed in favour of third party - Held, suit is not barred by limitation.(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Suit against dispossession
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit against dispossession - Limitation - Suit premises not owned by plaintiff - It is protected slum hutment owned by Municipal Corporation - Plaintiff filed suit on basis of prior possession and not title - In such a case, Section 6 of Specific Relief Act would not apply - Rather, limitation as provided in Art.64 of Limitation Act would apply. AIR 1968 SC 1165 Ref. to.  	(Paras 12, 17)

heading: Limitation
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Specific performance of agreement - Limitation - Agreement of sale was executed wherein parties agreed that last date of performance of agreement was 30.04.1987 - Buyer did not make entire payment even after said date - Almost after 10 years, he filed suit for specific performance of agreement - Explanation given that due to civil suit filed by co-operative society against seller and undertaking given by seller not to alienate property, limitation would stop running - Not acceptable - It started running from 30.04.1987 and onwards - Therefore, suit barred by limitation. (2010) 14 SCC 596 Ref. to. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Suit for declaration
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - Limitation - It begins to run when right to sue first accrues - Right to sue accrues only on clear and unequivocal threat to infringe right of party by defendant - Plaintiff claiming declaration of her right to reside in suit property - Clear and unequivocal threat to her legal right given by defendant only in March 2014 on basis of Will executed in 2004 - Plaintiff was aware of execution of Will when she signed various documents in 2009 - Mere knowledge of execution of said Will does not give rise to right to sue - Suit filed within period of three years when right to sue first accrued in March 2014 - Not barred by limitation. (Para 11)

heading: Rejection
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of possession - Rejection - On ground that defendant is tenant and relief of possession should be claimed by filing eviction suit under rent laws - Sale deed of suit shop in favour of plaintiff nowhere recites that defendant was in possession of suit shop as tenant - Defendant also neither pleaded nor produced evidence to show that he is in possession of suit shop as tenant - Defendant claiming possession of suit shop by adverse possession - Finding of High Court that defendant is in possession of suit shop as tenant, improper - Defendant is in possession of suit shop as encroacher - Plaintiff entitled to possession of suit shop.	(Paras 26, 27, 28, 30, 31, 32, 33)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of contract - Limitation - Specific date was fixed for performance of agreement to sale - Plaintiff claiming that date fixed for performance of agreement was extended - Record showing that clauses in agreement were neither amended nor varied - Merely because defendants were pursuing application filed for permission before Land and Development Office, it cannot be said that date fixed for performance of agreement stood extended - Suit was filed 12 years after date fixed for performance - It amounts to abandonment of agreement - Suit is barred by limitation. (Paras 11, 12)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.7 R.11 - Suit for declaration and specific performance of contract - Limitation - Plaintiff executing sale deed in favour of defendant - Defendant in turn entering into agreement to sell back suit property to plaintiff by or before fixed date - Years after expiry of date fixed for resale in agreement defendant is taking action to sell suit property to third party - Suit for declaration that sale deed executed by plaintiff was nominal and for specific performance of agreement filed by plaintiff thereafter - Suit for both these reliefs is barred by limitation - Limitation for relief of declaration of sale deed as nominal started running from date of execution of sale deed itself - Similarly limitation for relief of specific performance of agreement to resale started from date fixed in agreement - Clever drafting of plaint by pleading that defendant avoided execution of sale deed on pretext of incurring liability to pay capital gain and that defendant never objected to sale made by plaintiff of part of suit property cannot extend period of limitation - Plaint liable to be dismissed at threshold under O.7 R.11 of CPC.  2017(6) ALL MR 380 Rel. on. 			(Paras 19, 20, 21)

heading: Suit for declaration
Limitation period
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - As to illegality of mortgage deed and sale deed - Limitation period - Said documents executed in Nov. 1967 and Dec. 1970 respectively - Plaintiff admitted to have gained knowledge of those documents in May 1971 - Suit however filed only in July 1978 - Much beyond limitation of 3 yrs. - Not maintainable. 	(Para 34)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of contract - Limitation - Agreements of 'Re-conveyance' were executed way back in 1963 and 1965 - Stipulated period for first agreement was 10 years - However, suit was filed 3 years after issuance of notice in 1973 - Fiding of Trial Court that as regard first agreement, suit is barred by limitation and though second transaction was within limitation, plaintiffs have failed to show their readiness and willingness to perform their part of contract - Not challenged before 1st Appellate Court - Even if same was not raised in Appeal Memo, 1st Appellate Court has also confirmed said finding - Dismissal of suit, proper. 	(Para 24)

heading: Suit for declaration and permanent injunction
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration and permanent injunction - Whether barred by limitation - Plaintiff claiming his right on basis of agreement to sale executed by defendant in 1987 - Defendant got the title of suit property from developer in 1994 - Plaintiff was also aware of the same - However, suit filed only in 2004 - No steps taken by plaintiff to get the sale deed executed in his favour - Thus, suit filed after 17 yrs. of execution of sale deed and 10 yrs. of date of execution of sale deed in favour of defendant - Suit held barred by limitation, hence dismissed. 	(Paras 7.3, 7.4)

heading: Limitation
Date of commencement
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of agreement to sale - Limitation - Date of commencement - Date for execution of sale deed mentioned in agreement - Limitation would be governed by Art.54 of Limitation Act - No document produced to show that period fixed under agreement was extended - Therefore, period of limitation would start running from date fixed in agreement - Suit filed after expiry of 3 yrs. from such date fixed in agreement - Is barred by limitation. 1965 MP.L.J. 829, AIR 2006 SC 2281, AIR 1997 SC 772, 2009 ALL SCR 1305 Ref. to. 		(Paras 12, 13, 14, 16, 17, 20)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of contract - Limitation - Specific date was fixed for performance of agreement to sale - Plaintiff claiming that date fixed for performance of agreement was extended - Record showing that clauses in agreement were neither amended nor varied - Merely because defendants were pursuing application filed for permission before Land and Development Office, it cannot be said that date fixed for performance of agreement stood extended - Suit was filed 12 years after date fixed for performance - It amounts to abandonment of agreement - Suit is barred by limitation. 			(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Suit for declaration
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - Limitation - Plaintiff sought declaration that lease of suit property granted to his father was valid and subsisting - Deed of assignment entered into between his father and defendant in 1985 - But, defendant failed to complete transaction in last 20 years - However, suit was admittedly filed in 2011 - Plaintiff himself had asserted in a suit filed in city civil court in 2007 that he continued to be lessee of suit property - Hence, suit filed in 2011 is barred by limitation. 			(Para 62)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Plea of adverse possession - Person claiming title over property by adverse possession has to admit ownership of true owner of property - Only thereafter, by adducing adequate evidence of continuous uninterrupted possession of 12 years to exclusion of true owner, title by adverse possession can be claimed - Defendant did not admit plaintiff's ownership over suit land - He cannot claim title by adverse possession. 		(Para 23)

heading: Suit for declaration and possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration and possession - Whether barred by limitation - As per Art.65 period of limitation would be 12 years from date when possession becomes adverse to that of plaintiffs - Defendants though in possession of suit property for more than 12 years, failed to prove that their possession was lawful - Plaintiffs succeeded in proving that defendants were trespassers over suit property - Fresh period of limitation begins to run on every successive day trespass continues - Suit cannot be said to be barred by limitation. 	(Paras 42, 43, 46)

heading: Limitation for filing
HeadNote.description:
Suit for cancellation of sale deed - Limitation for filing - Challenge to sale deeds, is not on ground of voidness - Sale deeds are covered by S.41 of TP Act and transactions become voidable at instance of plaintiffs - Where a written instrument operating against person is voidable, it has to be necessarily challenged within period of 3 yrs. as prescribed by Art.59 of Limitation Act.

	The filing of suit by any person for cancellation of written instrument operating against him is discretionary and depends upon the reasonable apprehension of such person that if such instrument is left outstanding, it may cause him serious injury. If a written instrument is void ab initio, a suit for getting such a declaration from the Court of competent jurisdiction is not required to be filed, and even if such instrument remains outstanding, a plea that such instrument is void can be raised anywhere in any proceedings by way of defence and the bar of limitation to raise such challenge would not arise. In a suit based on title claiming the relief of possession, any written instrument putforth in defence considered to be void, need not be challenged and the limitation for filing such a suit would be of twelve years from the date when it becomes adverse to the plaintiff and it shall be governed by Article 65 of the Limitation Act. But this is not true in a case where a written instrument operating against a person is voidable. It has to be necessarily challenged within a period of limitation of three years, as prescribed by Article 59 of the Limitation Act and the period of limitation starts running from the date when such an instrument first become known to him.

	The burden of proof that the suit filed is within a period of limitation, is upon the plaintiffs, who have come before the Court to get the same set aside or cancelled. It is not the case of plaintiffs that these sale-deeds were obtained from Laxmibai by practising misrepresentation and/or fraud. The challenge to the sale-deeds cannot be said to be on the ground of voidness. In the present case, the sale-deeds at Exhibits 74, 76 and 78 are covered by Section 41 of the Transfer of Property Act and the transactions become voidable at the instance of the plaintiffs. It is not the pleading in the plaint that the plaintiffs filed the suit challenging the sale-deeds, within a period of three years from the date of their knowledge about execution of such sale-deeds. This is also not the evidence brought on record by the plaintiffs. On the contrary, the evidence brought on record and the findings recorded in earlier paras clearly establish the knowledge of the plaintiffs about the possession of the defendants and the execution of sale-deeds on 4-6-1974, 13-4-1976 and 19-7-1976 itself. These instruments stand as insurmountable obstacle and binds them. In fact, they have made a prayer for setting aside these instruments. The limitation is, therefore, governed by Article 59 of the said Act and the suit should have been brought within a period of three years, as contemplated by Article 59 of the Limitation Act, from the date of knowledge of these sale-deeds to the plaintiffs. The suit filed on 11-2-1986 was, therefore, clearly barred by the law of limitation, as prescribed under Article 59 of the Limitation Act. 	 [Para 42,46]

heading: Special Court
HeadNote.description:
Special Court - Attachment of property of notified person - Limitation Act has no application.

The Limitation Act, 1963 is applicable only in relation to certain applications and not all applications despite the fact that the words "other proceedings" were added in the long title of the Act in 1963. The provisions of the said Act are not applicable to the proceedings before bodies other than Courts, such as quasi-judicial tribunal or even an executive authority. The Act primarily applies to the civil proceedings or some special criminal proceedings. Even in a Tribunal, where the Code of Civil Procedure or Code of Criminal Procedure is applicable; the Limitation Act, 1963 per se may not be applied to the proceedings before it. Even in relation to certain civil proceedings, the Limitation Act may not have any application. As for example, there is no bar of limitation for initiation of a final decree proceedings or to invoke the jurisdiction of the Court under Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure or for correction of accidental slip or omission in judgments, orders or decrees; the reason being that these powers can be exercised even suo motu by the Court and, thus, no question of any limitation arises.   [Para 33]

The proceedings before the Special Court are extraordinary in nature. Distribution of the assets of a notified person may take a long time but it would bear repetition to state because all the claims filed before the Special Court are disposed of, the property of the notified person stands attached. In other words, the provisions of the Limitation Act would inter alia apply only when a suit is filed or a proceeding is initiated for recovery of an amount and not where a property is required to be applied towards the claims pending before the tribunal for the purpose of discharge of the liabilities of the notified person in terms of Section 11 of the said Act.   [Para 37]

A Special Court having regard to its nature and functions may be a Court within the meaning of Section 3 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 or Section 3 of the Limitation Act, 1963 but having regard to its scope and object and in particular the fact that it is a complete code in itself; the period of limitation provided in the schedule appended to the Limitation Act, 1963, will have no application.   [Para 38]

Once the statutory operation relating to the attachment of the property belonging to a notified person comes into being, the duties and functions of the Special Court start. In relation to the duties and functions required to be performed by a Court of law, no period of limitation need be prescribed. Furthermore, Section 13 of the said Act provides for a non-obstante clause which has been used as a device to modify the ambit of provisions of law mentioned therein or to override the same in the specified circumstances. The said Act does not provide for any period of limitation, the reasons wherefor have been noticed hereinbefore and in that view of the matter. Articles 19, 28 and 55 providing for period of limitation prescribed would have no application. Section 13 of the said Act provides for a non-obstante clause which is of wide amplitude. In a case of conflict between the said Act and any other Act, the provisions of the former shall prevail. [Para 39]

A statute of limitation bars a remedy and not a right. Although a remedy is barred, a defence can be raised. In construing a special statute providing for limitation, consideration of plea of hardship is irrelevant. A special statute providing for special or no period of limitation must receive a liberal and broader construction and not a rigid or a narrow one. The intent and purport of the Parliament enacting the said Act furthermore must be given its full effect. Hence the provisions of the Limitation Act have no application, so far as directions required to be issued by the Special Court relating to the disposal of attached property; are concerned.  						 [Para 41]

heading: Limitation for
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of contract - Limitation for - No date was fixed for performance by vendor - If no such date is fixed, period of three years will begin to run when plaintiff has notice that performance is refused - Evidence on record does not show that plaintiff had notice about such refusal - Burden to prove that suit is barred by limitation was squarely on defendants - Defendants did not step into witness box - Suit not barred by limitation. (Paras 19, 20, 21, 22)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Specific performance of agreement - Limitation - Agreement did not specify a calendar date as the date fixed for its performance - Limitation of 3 years would begin when the plaintiff has notice that defendant has refused performance of agreement.

heading: Limitation
Ayodhya dispute
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration of title - Limitation - Ayodhya dispute - Suit filed on basis that interest of Idol Rama is not looked after - Parties in earlier suits were pursuing their own interest - Deity was not party to earlier proceedings - Suit filed in circumstances is not barred by limitation. 	(Paras 428, 429)

heading: Revocation of probate
Application for
Applicability of Art.137
HeadNote.description: Revocation of probate - Application for - Applicability of Art.137 - There is no provision under Limitation Act which specifies period of limitation for application seeking revocation of grant of probate - Art.137 will apply. 	(Para 11)

heading: Revocation of probate
Application for
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Revocation of probate - Application for - Limitation - Period of limitation of 3 years u/Art.137 of Limitation Act begins to run from date of grant of probate - Appellant-daughter of testator was minor at that time therefore, it will run from the date daughter attained majority - Neither proceedings filed by daughter for 31 years after attaining majority - Nor explanation offered by her to show why she did not approach Court within period of limitation - Application for revocation of probate barred by limitation - Hence, liable to be dismissed. 	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Suit for declaration
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - Suit filed against alleged encroachment by member of society - Under agreement with developer, appellants constructed disputed structure/room on portion of terrace in respect of unutilized FSI - It was before formation of society by members - Appellants, paying maintenance charges in respect of said room and terrace - Got said construction regularized from Municipal Corporation - Trial Court was under impression that common terrace of building of society was sold to appellants by agreement - Passed order in ignorance of admitted pleadings and evidence on record, declaring the said agreement as bad in law, null and void and cancelled to extent of "sale of portion of terrace" - Held, order of Trial Court was perverse being contrary to pleadings and evidence and liable to be set aside. (Paras 102, 105, 106, 111, 135, 136, 137, 139, 140, 144)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration and possession - Limitation - Evidence on record showing that suit lands were not in cultivable state being submerged with tidal water since a considerable period - Neither documentary nor oral evidence established possession or dispossession of plaintiffs of suit lands - Plea of defendants that suit instituted beyond six months of alleged dispossession on basis of possessory title, not tenable - Yet onus rests on plaintiff to establish factum of possession over and dispossession from suit land, within period of 12 years preceding institution of suit - From execution of documents in favour of builder/developer on 12-2-1984, plaintiff can be said to be in possession of suit lands - Suit for possession filed by plaintiffs on 5-11-1996 i.e. beyond period of 12 years - Further right, title and interest of builders/developers, not challenged at instance of original owners of suit lands - Therefore, claim of plaintiff, as protected tenant of suit lands who failed to establish possessory title, not tenable - Suit, held, barred by limitation. (Paras 44, 51, 59, 61)

heading: Securitization application
HeadNote.description: Securitization application - Application for condonation of delay - Jurisdiction of Debts Recovery Tribunal (DRT) - DRT has jurisdiction to not only enquire into the illegality and irregularity in the action of the Bank under S.17(1) of the Act, but also to set aside the sale and even to order restoration of status quo ante by the parties - However, it does not mean that the DRT is obliged to entertain the proceedings even after the same has become hopelessly barred by limitation and no sufficient cause for condoning delay is made out by the Applicants - Onus is on the Applicants to make out sufficient cause for condoning delay. CDJ 2009 SC 1434 - Ref. to.	(Para 5)

heading: Letter of administration
Application for revocation
HeadNote.description: Letter of administration - Application for revocation - Limitation period would be 3 yrs. as perArticle 137 of Limitation Act. 1976 ALLMR ONLINE 538 (S.C.), 2008 ALL SCR 1221, 2019 Online SCC 630 (SC), 2018 ALL SCR 192 Rel. on. 	 (Paras 12, 13)

heading: Letter of administration
Application for revocation
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Letter of administration - Application for revocation - Maintainability - Letter of administration granted to respondent on 25.11.1994 - Instead of filing application for revocation, appellant filed notice of motion in disposed of proceedings on 29.3.1997 - Same was withdrawn on 1.4.1998 - Application for revocation then filed on 29.7.1999 - Even excluding period between 29.3.1997 and 1.4.1998, application for revocation was filed beyond limitation period - Plea that limitation would start from date when appellant gained knowledge of proceedings, not tenable - Grant of letter of administration is a proceeding in rem constituting notice to all - Appellant’s application not maintainable. 	 (Para 17)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Suit barred by limitation - Suit for declaration and specific performance of agreement of sale - Failure of defendants to execute sale deed in favour of plaintiff in terms of agreement dated 25/12/2007 - Averments in plaint read with agreement shows that the plaintiff was aware about the refusal on part of predecessors of the defendants to perform their part of agreement - Yet, no steps taken by the plaintiff by issuing notice or otherwise to pursue the matter when they were alive - Thus, even if it was to be held that time was not the essence of contract, the plaintiff could not claim that cause of action accrued to him for the first time when he saw the public notice dated 23/03/2019 published in newspaper in respect of suit property - Thus, plaint liable to be rejected.  (Paras 19, 20)

heading: Amendment of plaint
HeadNote.description: Amendment of plaint - Plaintiff by way of proposed amendment seeking declaration that registered gift deeds being forged and illegal, are not binding on them - Declaration sought by plaintiff in proposed amendment on 04.12.2015, would fall u/Art.56 or 58 of Limitation Act - It would be barred by law of limitation as written objection to gift deeds raised by plaintiff on 19.02.2009, showing that he was aware of gift deeds in 2009 itself - Period of limitation of 3 years started from 2009 itself i.e. from date of knowledge - Cause set out in amendment was barred by limitation - Application cannot be allowed. 			(Paras 13, 15, 16)

heading: Determination of
HeadNote.description: Setting aside of sale - On ground of irregularity or fraud - Application whether barred by limitation or not - Determination of - Limitation for filing an application for setting aside sale in execution of decree is 60 days in terms of Art.127 of Limitation Act - S.5 of Act not applicable to proceedings under O.21 R.90 - Delay if any cannot be condoned u/S.5 of Limitation Act - Further, u/S.14 any person can only claim exclusion of time of that period for which it had been prosecuting another remedy with due diligence and in good faith - Another remedy cannot be said to be in good faith - Delay of 6 days in filing application - There is no power to condone such delay - Application liable to be dismissed. 	(Paras 9, 11, 12, 13)

(1908), O.21 R.90 – Limitation Act (1963), Art.127, Ss.5, 14 – Setting aside of sale – On ground of irregularity or fraud – Application whether barred by limitation or not – Determination of – Limitation for filing an application for setting aside sale in execution of decree is 60 days in terms of Art.127 of Limitation Act – S.5 of Act not applicable to proceedings under O.21 R.90 – Delay if any cannot be condoned u/S.5 of Limitation Act – Further, u/S.14 any person can only claim exclusion of time of that period for which it had been prosecuting another remedy with due diligence and in good faith – Another remedy cannot be said to be in good faith – Delay of 6 days in filing application – There is no power to condone such delay – Application liable to be dismissed.
