heading: In Commercial Suit
Not permissible
HeadNote.description:
Delay in filing written statement - Beyond statutory period of 120 days - In Commercial Suit - Application filed for either to condone delay or allow to treat affidavit or pleadings filed earlier as WS - Not permissible - Under Commercial Courts Act, failure to file WS within statutory period would have salutary effect of defendant forfeiting his right to file WS - Application can’t be allowed.
2004(4) Mh.L.J.739, 1971 ALLMR ONLINE 569 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 7, 9)

heading: Appeal against order of civil judge
HeadNote.description:
Appeal against order of civil judge - Delay of 182 days in filing appeal - Appeal not filed though certified copy of judgment obtained - No sufficient cause shown for condonation of delay - Delay not condoned.

The test, to decide whether or not a cause is sufficient, is to see whether it could have been avoided by the party by the exercise of due care of diligence.  In other words nothing shall be deemed to be done bonafide or in good faith which is not done with due care and diligence.  The expression sufficient cause has necessarily to be a cause which is beyond the control of the party seeking condonation of delay.  The existence of sufficient cause being a condition precedent for exercise of discretion for condonation of delay by the Court, in the absence of such sufficient cause being shown, the delay in preferring the appeal cannot be condoned.  A bald statement on the part of the applicant that he thought it fit not to file the appeal on account of comprehensive suit already filed by him cannot at all be stated to be a sufficient cause for not preferring the appeal either within the prescribed period or beyond it till he obtained legal advice.  [Para 6]

The plea that delay was due to some settlement talk between the parties could not be accepted.  Since the settlement talks had not even commenced before the expiry of the period of limitation and they were initiated only after the expiry of limitation period, the point relating to the settlement talks cannot be in a way considered to be even a cause for non-filing of the appeal before the expiry of the period of limitation.  That apart, it is the case of the applicant himself that he had filed comprehensive suit claiming several reliefs and, therefore, he thought that there was no need of filing the appeal.  [Para 6]

In the instant case, the applicant has neither shown sufficient cause for not preferring the appeal even after obtaining certified copy of order within the period of limitation prescribed for filing the appeal nor has justified the delay caused thereafter in filing the appeal.  The applicant has also stated on oath that he has already filed a comprehensive suit claiming for several reliefs and as such the applicant bonafide thought there was no need of filing an appeal against the impugned order.  In this set of facts there is no sufficient cause made out for condoning the delay of 182 days.  [Para 16]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Application for condonation of delay in bringing legal representatives of deceased on record - What is required to be seen is the averments in the application and not the length of the delay - Relevant provisions of law of Limitation are required to be interpreted liberally - Test of "sufficient cause" is purely an individualistic test. 2009(2) SCC 689 - Rel. on.	(Paras 16, 17)

heading: Partition suit
House property
Is maintainable
HeadNote.description:
Partition suit - House property - Preliminary decree declaring shares of respective parties - Application for final decree made after 48 years - Is maintainable - Arts 136, 137 are not attracted.

Held the decree dated 8th April 1930 as regards the house property being only a preliminary decree, question of its execution did not arise and there being no time limit prescribed for making the application for drawing the final decree, the application made by the present respondents on 17th November, 1978 could not have been held to be time barred. As a matter of law on passing of the preliminary decree in respect of house property declaring shares of respective parties, the suit for partition had not come to an end. The proceedings for drawing the final decree after passing of the preliminary decree in the suit for partition is continuation of suit. In a suit for partition of immoveable property or separate possession of a share therein which is not assessible to the payment of revenue, if the partition or separation cannot be conveniently made without further enquiry, the court only passes preliminary decree declaring the rights of parties and it is the duty of the Court which passes the preliminary decree to proceed for drawing the final decree. This course can be exercised by the Court either suo motu or on a application by a party. Article 137 of the Limitation Act cannot be applied to such exercise. The final decree of partition by metes and bounds having not been passed, the decree had not yet become enforceable and, therefore, Article 136 of Limitation Act has no application and the limitation prescribed under Article 136 of the Limitation Act has not even begun to run. The Appeal Court, therefore, was right and rather fully justified in holding that the application made by the respondents herein on 17th November, 1978 is an application in the nature of prayer to the Court to draw final decree and, therefore, rightly set aside the order of the Civil Judge and remanded the matter back to the said Court for proceeding further with the said application for drawing the final decree.  [Para 3]

heading: Application for rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description:
Application for rejection of plaint - For non disclosure of cause of action and suit being time barred - Suit property was sold and Rs.49,11,00,000/- had been paid on date of execution of sale-deed towards payment of part consideration - Rs.6,00,00,000/- was agreed to be paid on plaintiffs obtaining renewal of construction license from village Panchayat - Inspite of complying with said stipulation, amount was not paid and therefore, suit for recovery is filed - Application filed under O.7 R.11 that amount of Rs.6,00,00,000/- represents consideration for services rendered by plaintiffs in obtaining renewal of licence and therefore, no cause of action arose - Harmonious reading of relevant clauses prima facie shows that Rs.6,00,00,000/- was by way of additional consideration, payment of which was contingent on event of plaintiffs obtaining renewal of licence and which they did - In so far as limitation aspect, factual dispute as to what is time for completing sale or where title is accepted after time fixed for completion, date of acceptance are involved - These aspects can be gone into at trial - Rejection of application, proper.
2016(2) Goa L.R. 354, 1998(4) ALL MR 521 Ref. to. 	(Paras 19, 20, 23)

heading: Amendment of plaint
HeadNote.description: Amendment of plaint - Refusal of, on ground of delay - Suit was for possession of property on basis of agreement between parties - Plaintiffs by way of chamber summons prayed to amend plaint to include prayer for specific performance as defendants objected to suit on ground that there is no substantive prayer for specific performance - Chamber summons was not filed within period prescribed u/Art.137 of Limitation Act - Further, even fresh suit for specific performance was barred by limitation on date of filing application for amendment - Refusal of application for amendment of plaint, proper. 2012(4) ALL MR 628, 2012(6) ALL MR 268, 2009(6) ALL MR 986 (S.C.) Rel.on.			(Paras 7, 9, 10, 11)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - On ground of limitation - Suit for declaration of ownership and possession on basis of title - Plaintiff's case that suit property was entrusted with defendant no.5 (D-5) by virtue of management deed - D-5 however sold suit land by executing sale deed in favour of D-2 - Said sale deed executed on 14.5.1987 - As per Art.65 of Limitation Act period of limitation for filing suit for possession based on title is 12 yrs. from date of possession of defendant becomes adverse - Possession of defendant becomes adverse on execution of sale deed on 14.5.1987 - Suit however filed on 2.10.2012 - Contention that period of 12 yrs. would commence from date on which plaintiff got knowledge of sale deed, cannot be accepted - Suit is barred by limitation - Hence, rejection of plaint held proper. (2002) 1 SCC 90, (2000) 3 SCC 460 Ref. to.  (Paras 7, 8, 9, 10, 13)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - On ground of barred by limitation - Suit was for rendition of true and correct accounts - Suit is to be filed within period of limitation of 3 years as prescribed u/Art. 113 - Under Art. 113 what is required to be noted is when right to sue accrues and not when right to sue first accrues - Plaintiff became aware about discrepancies in July, 2000 - Plaintiff send legal notice on 28.11.2003 and again on 07.01.2005 - Cause of action arose on 07.01.2005 - Plaintiff filed suit in February, 2005 - Plaint is within period of limitation of 3 years prescribed by Art. 113 - Order rejecting plaint, liable to be set aside. (Paras 14, 20, 21)

headline: Limitation Act (1963), Art. 113 – Under Art. 113 what is required to be noted is when right to sue accrues and not when right to sue first accrues.

heading: Second appeal
Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Adverse possession - Concurrent findings of courts below as to permissive possession - Cannot be interfered with in second appeal - Permissive possession howsoever long, cannot be converted into adverse possession unless it is proved that the person in possession has been peaceably and openly using the property without any interruption to the knowledge of the true owner for the statutory period of 12 years - No substantial question of law involved in second appeal - Appeal dismissed. (2001)9 SCC 385 - Referred to.	(Para 12)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay in filing appeal against a decree for possession - Merely because there is no intentional delay cannot be a ground for condonation, because no one will intentionally cause delay. 2001(6) SCC 176 - Ref. to.	(Paras 10 to 14)

heading: Revision
HeadNote.description: Revision - Application for condonation of delay - Trial Court rejecting application seeking condonation of delay under S.5 of Limitation Act - Superior Court can scrutinize the exercise of such judicial discretion by trial Court - If Superior Court comes to conclusion that discretion is not exercised judiciously by trial Court the Superior Court can quash and set aside the order. AIR 1998 SC 3222 and AIR 1987 SC 1353 - Ref. to.	(Para 7)

heading: Delay
HeadNote.description: Application for bringing L.Rs of deceased respondent on record - Delay - Condonation and setting aside abatement - Approach of court should be pragmatic and not pedantic - Acceptability of explanation is the criterion and not length of delay - Explanation given in instant case for condonation of delay and setting aside abatement found acceptable in interest of the justice - Delay to be condoned on payment of cost of Rs.1,500/-.			(Paras 4, 7, 8)

heading: Restoration of suit
HeadNote.description: Restoration of suit - Dismissal of suit for default or non-prosecution - Is not appealable as a 'decree' - It can, however, be restored by applying under O.9, R.4 or R.3 - Court does not become functus officio on expiry of 30 days from date of dismissal of a suit for default and on the order of dismissal being drawn up, completed and filed - Time can be extended under S.5 of Limitation Act, on showing sufficient cause.	(Paras 5, 11, 12)

heading: Addition of a party after period of limitation
HeadNote.description:
Addition of a party after period of limitation - Object of Limitation Act - One of the salutary objects is to prevent plaintiff from raking up old dispute in respect of which other party would not be in a position to adduce clear cogent evidence - Whether the addition of a party after period of limitation would affect suit as regards other parties who are already on record - Held, it would depend upon whether party sought to be added is a necessary or proper party to suit.

One of the salutary objects of law of limitation is to prevent the plaintiff from raking up old dispute in respect of which other party would not be in a position to adduce clear cogent evidence. We find number of cases in which it is laid down that whenever inspite of objection by defendants on the ground of non-joinder, the period of limitation was allowed to expire, it would be too late to join such necessary parties to the suit and the only course is to dismiss the suit itself. It may be noted that it is not a case of mis-description of parties, but non-joinder of the parties and after 30 years it would be unjust and improper to allow addition of the legal representatives of Govindrao Padalkar as parties to the present suit.

The proviso to sub-section (1) of Section 21 enacts that where the court is satisfied that the omission to include a new plaintiff or defendant was due to bona fide mistake, the suit as regards such plaintiff or defendant "shall be deemed to have been instituted on any earlier date". The proviso thus mitigates the rigour of law in appropriate cases.

A further question may still arise as to whether the addition of a party after the period of limitation would affect the suit as regards other parties who are already on record. That would depend upon whether the party sought to be added is a necessary or proper party to the suit. If he is a necessary and has not been joined within the period of limitation, the suit will have to be dismissed, the reason being that the suit could be said to be a properly constituted suit only when the necessary party was joined in the suit but, by that time, the suit had already been time barred. But if the party is only a proper party, as distinguished from a necessary party, the suit as regards the other parties would not be barred since the suit which had already been instituted was legal and proper. Court is not satisfied that the mistake, in not joining Govindrao Padalkar or his legal representatives by plaintiff from 1977 till this date, is made in good faith. It is deliberate omission. There are no bona fides. The discretion given in the proviso cannot be exercised in favour of the appellant/plaintiff. AIR 1973 S.C. 2537 & AIR 1972 BOMBAY 148 - Ref. to.						 [Para 23,27,29,30]

heading: Fresh suit
What is
HeadNote.description:
Scope and applicability of S.14 of Limitation Act - Fresh suit - What is - When plaint which is returned by one court having no jurisdiction to entertain the suit is presented in the same condition to the court having the jurisdiction, it amounts to institution of fresh suit and there is no question of continuation of the earlier suit - Requirement of S.14(1) of Limitation Act indicated - Where suit is instituted after period of limitation, plaint must show the grounds upon which the exemption from such law is claimed.

The requirement of Section 14 are that the previous legal proceeding (i) must be prosecuted with due diligence in the court of first instance or of appeal or revision; (ii) should relate to the same matter in issue;  (iii) should be against the same Defendant; (iv) should be prosecuted in good faith in a court which is unable to entertain it due to want of jurisdiction or other causes of like nature.

In so far as the present suit is concerned, the matter in issue in two suits is the same. The only question, therefore, that is to be considered is whether the city civil court suit was prosecuted with due diligence and in good faith. Order VII Rule 6 of Civil Procedure Code provides that where a suit is instituted after the period of limitation, the plaint must show the grounds upon which the exemption from such law is claimed. Admittedly, when the present suit was filed the Plaintiffs did not plead any ground claiming exemption of any period in computing the period of limitation laid down by the law of limitation.

Even the plaint which is returned by one court having no jurisdiction to entertain the suit is presented in the same condition to the court having the jurisdiction, it amounts to institution of fresh suit and there is no question of continuation of the earlier suit. AIR 1958 SC 767 and 2002(4) ALL MR 549 (S.C.) - Referred to.	 [Para 11,12,13]

Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Condonation of delay - Delay of few days happened because of bonafide belief of the attorney of the petitioners that limitation for filing the appeal was 90 days - Application for condonation of delay, allowed.			(Paras 7 to 9)

Abatement of appeal

(Para 5)

heading: Amendment of pleadings
Application for
Delay

(2000) 5 SCC 458 - Ref. to.	(Para 8)

heading: Restoration of suit
Condonation of delay
Revision
HeadNote.description:
Restoration of suit - Condonation of delay - Suit for specific performance of contract - Suit dismissed in default - Counter claim proceeded though suit was dismissed - Respondent filed application for setting aside dismissal order and application for condonation of delay - Both applications dismissed in default - After lapse of 5 years and 9 months application filed under O.9 R.9 for restoration of suit and condonation of delay - Trial Court allowed application in the interest of justice - Revision - Held, trial court exceeded its jurisdiction in admitting restoration of suit by condoning 5 years and 9 months delay.

In the instant case the trial court itself had observed that the plaintiff was attending the hearing of counter claim filed by the original defendant i.e. applicants herein. Therefore, this situation also to the conclusion that when the plaintiff/respondent attended the hearing of the counter claim filed by the revision applicants herein, there was no reason in not prosecuting the suit filed by the respondent. Not only that the suit was dismissed in default but the application which was filed for restoration of the suit with a prayer for condonation of delay was also dismissed for want of prosecution and thereafter belatedly after 5 years 9 months and 18 days, another application is filed for condonation of delay and for restoration of the suit. When the court realised that there was no 'sufficient cause' disclosed in the application for condonation of delay, the court had no unlimited and unbridled discretion to condone the delay by merely observing that in the interest of justice delay deservesd to be condoned. Therefore, if the facts of the case are considered in its entirety, in the light of the provisions of Order IX rule 9 of Code of Civil Procedure and also section 141 of Code of Civil Procedure and even the provisions of section 5 of the Limitation Act, there is no doubt that Court has exceeded the jurisdiction and for unsustainable reasons in law condoned the delay. Therefore, within the scope of revisional jurisdiction under Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure, the interference in the impugned judgment and order is warranted. Accordingly judgment impugned and order set aside. 						     [Para 15,16,17]

heading: Application for setting aside execution sale
HeadNote.description:
Application for setting aside execution sale - Time limit for making deposit - Amount must be deposited within 60 days time limit and in absence of such deposit application is liable to be rejected - There is no option but to reject application.
2013 ALL SCR 141 Rel. on. 	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: First appeal
HeadNote.description: First appeal - Delay of 992 days in filing - Condonation of delay denied by appellate court - However revisional court allowed the condonation and directed appellant to deposit half of decretal amount - Said direction complied by appellant - Appellant even deposited the amount directed by Apex Court - Held, condonation of delay was justified - First appellate court shall decide appeal on merits. 	(Paras 8 to 12)

heading: Execution of decree
Legality
HeadNote.description:
Execution of decree - Dismissal of execution petition on point of limitation - Legality - Appeal filed against decree of Trial Court - Lower Appellate Court confirmed decree of Trial Court with direction to pay deficit court fees - Decree passed by Trial Court merged with decree of Lower Appellate Court - Appeal was dismissed after framing points of determination and hearing of parties - Appeal was in continuation of suit - Hence, period of limitation would start from date of dismissal of appeal and not from date of decree of Trial Court - Appeal was dismissed in January 2002 - Execution petition filed in December 2004 - Application for execution is within limitation - Dismissal not justified.

2005(5) ALL MR 339 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			 [Para 12,13]

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description:
Application under O.7 R.11 - Scope - Suit barred by limitation - Plaintiff issued notice terminating the lease in 1991 - Defendant never disputed or challenged the same till 2008 - In 2008 defendant denied termination of lease and claimed right - Though the ground that the suit was barred by limitation raised, the plaintiff not placed reliance u/S.9 and trial court did not deal with the same - Trial court should deal with the application under Order 7 Rule 11 on the basis of averments and documents of plaint - Matter to be remanded back to Trial Court.

AIR 1989 SC 997, (1977) 4 SCC 467, 2005(5) ALL MR 838 (S.C.), 2007 ALL SCR 1995, 2011 ALL SCR 2540, 2007 (6) ALL MR 953, 2005 (7) SCC 510, AIR 1980 P and H 25, AIR 1987 Delhi 165 Ref. to. 			 [Para 7,20,21]

heading: Rel.on.	(Paras 4, 5)
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay in applying for setting aside abatement - Death of respondent on 28.5.1998 reported to court on 1.8.2006 when appellant's counsel was absent - On 9.8.2007 appeal was dismissed as having abated as legal representatives were not brought on record - Held, this was a fit case where High Court ought to have set aside abatement by condoning delay. 2008 ALL SCR 1944 - Rel.on.	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Notice under S.80
Limitation
Computation of
HeadNote.description:
Notice under S.80 - Limitation - Computation of - Period of notice, provided it is given within limitation period, would be mandatorily excluded. 

Proper interpretation of Section 15(2) of the Act would be that in computing the period of limitation, the period of notice, provided notice is given within the limitation period, would be mandatorily excluded. That would mean a suit, for which period of limitation is three years, would be within limitation even if it is filed within two months after three years, provided notice has been given within the limitation period. In such a case, the period of notice cannot be counted concurrently with the period of limitation. If it is done, then period of notice is not excluded. Any other interpretation would be contrary to the express mandate of Section 15(2) of the Act. In this case construction work was completed on 30-9-2006 and balance amount remained unpaid thereafter. Notice was secured on 27-2-2009 i.e. before expiry of three years limitation on 30-9-2009. Suit was filed on 24.10.2009 i.e. within two months after 30-9-2009 was within limitation.  [Para 14,16]

heading: Rejection of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Delay for bringing legal representatives - Application for condonation of - Rejection of - Validity - Respondent landlord died during pendency of appeal - Delay of more than 7 years for bringing legal representatives of deceased on record - No sufficient cause shown for delay - Moreover, tenant/appellant is residing in the neighbourhood of the respondent/landlord - Order rejecting application for condonation of delay is proper.	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Execution of decree
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Execution of decree - Limitation - Lady purchased property from original owner, sold it to plaintiff - Suit against tenant for recovery of possession of premises by original owner was decreed - Tenant did not vacate premises - Plaintiff filed suit under Rent Control Act - Title suit was disputed on ground that original owner failed to execute decree and hence, remedy of recovery of possession is barred as time for execution has expired - Contention is liable to be rejected - Dismissal of suit liable to be set aside. 
2007(2) ALL MR 866 (S.C.), AIR 1947 PC 78, AIR 1969 SC 78, 1990 SC 540, 2012 ALL SCR 1096 Ref.to. 	(Paras 5, 8, 13)

heading: Execution of decree
HeadNote.description:
Execution of decree - Sought after lapse of 22 years - Land for which execution was sought by decree holder was assessed to land revenue - It was only a preliminary decree after a precept was issued u/S.54 of CPC to Tahasildar that was being put to execution - Period of limitation held cannot be counted from date of preliminary decree and as such execution was not barred by limitation.
2005(5) ALL MR 339 (S.C.) Ref. to. (Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Exparte decree of divorce - Appeal against - Delay of 5 years 144 days in filing appeal - Exparte decree dissolving marriage on ground that though served wife not appeared - Admittedly Bailiff was not knowing lady personally nor made any attempt to keep any witness to identify lady in house nor summons served in presence of husband - Bailiff put an endorsement of 'notice unserved' and not of service by refusal - Is not a valid service - Further facts show that husband continued to reside with wife for 18 months even after decree of divorce - Also in life insurance policy form husband shown wife as nominee - Husband had thus kept wife in dark regarding fact of divorce decree for long time - Wife has shown sufficient ground for condonation of delay - Under such facts and circumstances delay of years can be condoned. (Paras 11 to 17)

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Delay in filing appeal - Order passed during the pendency of delay condonation application would not operate in appeal proceedings. (Para 8)

heading: Counter claim
Rejection of
HeadNote.description: Counter claim - Rejection of - Plaintiff terminated development agreement with defendant by issuing letter and filed suit - Letter and suit constitute notice of refusal to perform - Defendant filed counter claim after 4 years of letter and suit - Defendant seeking declaration and specific performance as to his rights by agreement - No evidence required at this stage - Counter claim ex facie barred by limitation - Rejection of counter claim is liable to be upheld. 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 360, (2005)7 SCC 510, (2006)5 SCC 658, 2007 ALL SCR 1995, 2008 ALL SCR 1627 - Rel. on.	(Paras 8, 12)

heading: Counter claim
Filing of
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Counter claim - Filing of - Limitation - Counter-claim can be filed even subsequent to filing of written statement - Limitation not prescribed in O.8 R.6-A - Counter-claim is in the nature of cross suit and period of limitation is three years from date of accrual of cause of action as provided in Art.113 of Limitation Act. (Paras 11 to 13)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Concurrent finding on limitation - Finding is finding of fact and cannot be interfered with in Second Appeal by High Court in exercise of powers under S.100 of Civil P.C.. AIR 1986 SC 1509 - Rel. on.	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Amendment of plaint
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Amendment of plaint - Limitation - Amendment sought in suit filed in 2011 for declaration of ownership over suit property and that sale deed executed between defendants is null and void - By way of proposed amendment, plaintiffs wanted to add case in plaint that defendant had encroached suit property and constructed building over same - And therefore, sought to add prayer for mandatory injunction to demolish illegal building and claimed mesne profit from defendant - Proposed amendment sought after 43 years of alleged encroachment and construction and hence, barred by limitation - Moreover, submission made that Art.65 would not apply in absence of plea of adverse possession taken by defendant - Not tenable as it was plaintiffs case that alleged encroachment done in 1972 and construction of building done openly and continuously without obstruction for period of more than 12 years - In so far as amendment sought in respect of sale deed executed between defendants, they were clarificatory in nature - Since suit challenging said sale deed filed in 2011 and proposed amendments sought in 2015 - Amendment in this regard, not barred by limitation. AIR 1988 Bombay 94 Disting. AIR 1957 SC 357, 2007 ALL SCR 1638 Ref. to. 	(Paras 12. 13, 14, 15, 17)

heading: Ex-parte decree
Setting aside of
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Ex-parte decree - Setting aside of - Condonation of delay - Non-communication of transfer of matters from one court to another and non-communication from counsel - Is sufficient ground to condone delay and set aside ex-parte decree.

In case of application for setting aside ex-parte decree the non-communication of transfer of matters from one Court to another and further proceeding and no communication from the Advocate, if causes injustice and results into such ex-parte decree of eviction need to be considered as a sufficient ground/reason to condone the delay and to set aside the ex-parte decree in the interest of justice. In such cases, it is difficult to expect the explanation of day-by-day or month-by-month or year-by-year delays in the present case on both counts even before the passing of ex-parte decree, as well as, after passing of ex-parte decree. Therefore, the limitation of 30 days from the date of decree and/or from the date of knowledge of decree, in the present facts and circumstances of the case, as contemplated under Article 123 of the Limitation Act, 1963 need to be considered in favour of the petitioner.   [Para 15]

heading: Validity
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act (1960), S.94 - Application for restoration of dispute - Condonation of delay by Co-operative Court - Validity - Ground raised that application for condonation was not filed initially with application for restoration but it was filed only after being pointed out by other party - Held, O.9, R.4 does not require that application for condonation be filed alongwith application for restoration - No perversity in granting condonation of delay on later application. 2006(6) ALL MR 310 and 2006(4) Mh.L.J. 318 held not good law in view of 2000(7) SCC 372.	(Paras 4, 8, 13)

heading: Summary suit
HeadNote.description: Summary suit - Suit for recovery of sum with interest - Contention of defendant that suit summons not being served, decree was obtained dishonestly behind back of defendant - Period of limitation for application to set aside decree under provision of Civil P.C. is 30 days - In the circumstances, it must be held that irrespective of circumstances in which decree is passed in the suit filed under O.37, the period of limitation would be governed by Art.137 and not by Art.123 of Limitation Act - Several proceedings initiated by parties against each other including criminal proceedings - However, defendant has done nothing in the matter for about 8 years - Therefore, service of summons being doubtful, held, plaintiff is put to strict proof thereof - Hence, ex-parte decree was set aside - Parties directed to prosecute the suit on merits. AIR 1999 A.P. 427 - Ref. to.			(Paras 12, 14)

heading: Counter claim
Rejection of
HeadNote.description: Counter claim - Rejection of - For want of cause of action - Specific pleadings in counter claim that plaintiff holding suit property for benefit of and in trust for defendant - Further pleaded that suit was covered by provisions of S.10 of Act and reliefs sought are not barred by limitation - Court cannot take material beyond counter claim at this stage - Rejection of counter claim not proper. 	(Paras 22, 23)

heading: Appeal and application for condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Appeal and application for condonation of delay - Both appellants and their Advocates absent - Court cannot dismiss appeal on merits after hearing Advocate for respondent - Court could have either dismissed appeal for want of prosecution or adjourn it to future date.
2006(6) ALL MR 541 Ref. to. (Paras 11, 12, 13)

heading: Ex-parte decree
Delay in filing
Condonation of
HeadNote.description:
Ex-parte decree - Application for setting aside - Delay in filing - Condonation of - Decree passed ex-parte as appellant has no knowledge of proceedings initiated by respondents - Appellant came to know about award after receipt of notice in mutation proceedings - No malafides attributed to appellant - Delay condoned.

While examining the Application for condonation of delay, there can always be element of negligence on the part of such Applicant. What is material in such circumstance is to examine whether there was any gross delay with malafide intention on the part of such Applicant to deliberately approach the Court belatedly. In fact, on perusal of the reply filed by the Respondents, there are no malafides attributed to the Appellant. There is no cogent evidence on record to show that the Appellant had knowledge of the proceedings initiated by the Respondents before the learned Lower Appellate Court. In such circumstances and in the interest of justice, the learned Judge was not justified to dismiss the Application for condonation of delay and set aside the ex-parte decree passed in the Appeal preferred by the Respondents. No doubt, Article 11 of the Code of Communidade permits the summons to the Administrator of the Comunidade but in the peculiar facts and circumstances of the case and taking note of the fact that the Respondents themselves chose to serve the attorney of the Communidade before the Trial Court which was stated to be registered address of the Appellant before the Trial Court, it was not open to the Respondents to change such address and serve the Administrator in the Appeal preferred against the Appellant herein.   [Para 8,10]

heading: Second appeal
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Second appeal - Condonation of delay - Length of delay itself is not only criteria or relevant factor while considering the prayer for condonation of delay - What matters is sufficient cause disclosed in the application for condonation of delay. 
AIR 1987 SC 1353 - Rel. on.  (Para 7)

heading: Enlargement of time
Maintainability
Not justified
HeadNote.description: Enlargement of time - Application for, after expiry of fixed time - Maintainability - Court ordered deposit of cost within 10 days - Extension of time to make such deposit however sought after expiry of 10 days but within a period of 30 days - Denial of extension solely on ground that period of 10 days has already expired - Not justified - Court ought to have exercised its discretion u/s.148 considering that applicant is an old ailing retired Govt. servant unable to make deposit within 10 days.	(Para 7)

heading: Impleadment of parties
HeadNote.description: Impleadment of parties - Suit for specific performance - Agreement for sale of immovable property - Agreement executed in favour of "M" and her husband "V" - Suit filed only in name of "M" in 1997 - In 2005 name of "V" was added as plaintiff - Held, two plaintiffs in this suit have different cases and if examined independently, they appear to be barred by law - Even otherwise, taken together, it would appear to be barred by both O.1 R.1 of CPC and the Limitation Act. 	(Paras 2, 3)

heading: Rejection of plaint
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Claim for - Ground of bar of limitation and non-disclosure of cause of action - For determining whether plaint should be rejected or not, pleadings in plaint should be looked into as whole and not in disjunctive manner - Pleadings are about continuing breach and obtuse attitude in committing wrong de die diem - S.22 of Limitation Act provides that in case of continuing wrong, fresh period of limitation begins to run every time wrong is committed - Plaint is not barred by limitation - Further argument that plaintiff being stranger to suit cannot have cause of action to file suit - Belongs to category of plea of absence of cause of action and not to non-disclosure of cause of action - It can be considered only at time of trial - Plaint not liable to be rejected.	(Paras 20, 24, 26, 27)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - On ground of limitation - Suit for specific performance of contract dated 26.04.1985, filed in June 2016 - Pleadings in plaint themselves showed that stipulated time for performance of contract was up to 31.03.1989 - Limitation began to run from 31.03.1989 - Suit filed beyond period of 3 years, barred by limitation - Plaint stands rejected. (2005) SCC 510 Disting. 			(Paras 11, 12, 18)

heading: Revision application
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Revision application - Condonation of delay - Revision filed on 21.11.2014 with delay of 92 days - Due to office objection being raised, application for condonation of delay filed on 27.05.2015 - Submission that delay has to be computed up to date of filing of condonation application, cannot be accepted - Merely because revision application was not registered due to office objection, would not make any difference - Though petitioner could have filed condonation application promptly on objection being raised, considering delay of short duration in filing revision application, delay is condoned subject to costs. 	(Paras 10, 12)

heading: First Appeal
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: First Appeal - Condonation of delay - Appellate Court dismissed appeal only on point of delay - Final Court of facts needs to administer substantial justice on merit - For that purpose liberal justice oriented approach is needed in matter of condonation of delay - Delay condoned.(Para 4)

heading: Whether condonable
HeadNote.description: Order of "No written statement" - Application for setting it aside - Delay of 2200 days - Whether condonable - Condonation sought at stage when suit was posted for pronouncing judgment - Applicant/Defendant pleaded ignorance of proceedings - However, perusal of roznama shows presence of representative of defendants at initial stage of suit - Plea of ignorance not acceptable - Despite repeated intimation to defendants, they did not contact their advocate to give instructions - Another plea of old age of defendant/applicant, also not acceptable as he was 52 years at time of 'No W.S.' order - One more ground raised that defendant who was looking after matter died and other defendants/trustees were not aware of stages of matter - But no explanation given regarding steps taken by deceased defendant - Application made at belated stage without even enclosing W.S. - Inaction of defendants disentitles them from protection of S.5 of Limitation Act - Condonation declined. (1981) 2 SCC 788, 2014(3) ALL MR 965 (S.C.), 2012(1) ALL MR 968 (S.C.), (1993) 2 SCC 185 Ref. to. (Paras 7, 8, 9, 10, 12, 15)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Refusal to condone delay in filing application for restoration of execution application on ground that it was not filed within 30 days of dismissal of execution application - Execution application dismissed on ground that no steps were taken by decree holder - Execution application was not dismissed under O.21, R.105 therefore, period of 30 days prescribed in R.106(3) of O.21 will not attract - Provisions of S.5 of Limitation Act, will also not attract as O.21, R.106(3) not attracted - Further, no specific period prescribed for making application for restoration of execution application - Decree holder submits that delay caused in filing restoration application as person-in-charge of all 45 execution proceedings had left services without handing over all 45 proceedings which includes present execution proceeding - Record shows that decree holder filed restoration application immediately after getting knowledge of dismissal of execution proceedings - Decree-holder sufficiently explained delay in filing restoration application - Order refusing to condone delay liable to be set aside. 	(Paras 13, 14, 17, 18, 19)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Application for setting aside of ex-parte decree - Condonation of delay - Ex-parte decree passed in suit for permanent injunction - Applicant-corporation was not following suit before Trial Court as appeal filed by it against order granting temporary injunction in said suit was pending - Considering that applicant is public sector undertaking providing money for development of industries in State and huge public money is involved in case and that suit was for permanent injunction - Opportunity granted to applicant to put forth their defence and contest suit in accordance with law - Delay condoned with cost of Rs.50,000/-. 	(Paras 12, 13, 14)

heading: Second appeal
Dismissal for non-prosecution
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Dismissal for non-prosecution - Application for its restoration - And also for setting aside abatement of appeal and bringing LRs. on record - Huge delay in filing said applications - Ground that counsel representing appellants, applicants did not remain present before High Court when appeal was fixed for hearing - Applicants- LRs. came to know about dismissal of said second appeal only when decree sought to be executed against them by respondents - Thus, delay caused in filing said applications, does not smack malafide or any deliberate intention - Sufficient cause shown by applicants in justification of delay in filing applications - Therefore, abatement of second appeal set aside and LRs. permitted to be brought on record - Second appeal restored to original position. 	(Paras 28, 31, 33)

heading: Ex-parte decree
Revision against
HeadNote.description: Ex-parte decree - Setting aside of by condoning delay of more than 2 years - Revision against - Ex-parte decree was passed as defendant was not appearing in suit after filing of written statement - Plea of defendant that he was not appearing as he shifted his residence to other State due to personal and family health problems - It was further contended that his advocate did not contact him to remain present for adducing his evidence or for cross-examination of plaintiff - No evidence to show that defendant and his family were suffering from health problems and that he shifted to another State - Also, defendant has not informed to Court or his advocate about his shifting and change in his address - Defendant cannot put entire blame on his advocate when he himself was not diligent - Record showing that plaintiff has issued notice to defendant about date of hearing on address given in suit which returned as unclaimed - Plaintiff took every effort to serve defendant notice about date of hearing - No sufficient cause made out by defendant to set aside ex-parte decree by condoning delay - Ex-parte decree cannot be set aside. (Paras 14, 15, 16, 18, 19, 22, 24, 25)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - On ground that suit is barred by limitation - Suit was for specific performance of agreement to sale - Time was not essence of contract - As per Art.54 of Limitation Act, when no date is fixed for performance of agreement, suit is to be filed within three years from date of knowledge of refusal - Plaintiff claiming that he came to know of refusal when he visited suit land on 25.05.2017 - Correctness of such averments made in plaint is matter of trial and cannot be considered in application u/O.7 R.11(d) - While deciding application u/O.7 R.11 plain averments in plaint are to be looked into - From prima facie reading of averments in plaint, it cannot be said that suit is barred by limitation - Plaint cannot be rejected. 	(Paras 10, 11, 12, 15)

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Relevant date for computation of period of limitation - Judgment and order impugned under appeal passed on 11/11/2011 - Decree was not drawn because plaintiffs did not make payment of requisite Court fee stamps for decided decretal amount - Instead, they applied for correction in the judgment - Corrected judgement and order came into existence on 18/4/2014 - Plaintiffs thereafter deposited requisite court fee stamps in terms of corrected judgment and order - Decree thereafter drawn on 7/11/2014 - As per O.41 R.1 CPC (Bombay Amendment), memorandum of appeal mandatorily required to be accompanied by decree appealed from - Thus, appellant could not have filed appeal until decree was drawn in terms of corrected judgment - Therefore, period of limitation commenced from 7/11/2014 when decree was eventually drawn. AIR 1961 SC 832, AIR 1977 SC 2319 Rel.on.	(Paras 23, 24, 25)

heading: Application for setting aside auction sale
HeadNote.description: Application for setting aside auction sale - Rejection on ground of delay - Auction took place on 23.4.2012 - Application filed on 26.6.2012 with delay of 3 days - Limitation prescribed u/Art.127 of Limitation Act is 60 days - Executing Court has no jurisdiction to entertain the application purportedly filed under O.21 R.89 beyond period of 60 days - Delay also cannot be condoned on strength of S.5 of Limitation Act as the same is not applicable to provision of O.21 R.89 - Therefore, rejection of application held, proper. AIR 1926 Bombay 335(2), 2008 ALL SCR 1365 Ref. to. 	(Paras 10, 11, 12, 15)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Claim for mesne profit - Limitation - Mesne profit claimed as consequence of decree passed in rent suit - It is claim for damages or compensation for continued possession of premises after decree of possession is passed - Therefore, accrual of cause of action is defining aspect - Claim is to be filed within 3 years from date of cause of action in terms of Art.113 of Limitation Act - Cause of action for filing claim arises on 03.09.2002 when possession of defendant becomes wrongful - Claim filed on 06.09.2004 i.e. within 3 years - Is not barred by limitation - However, in terms of Art.113 same should be granted for preceding 3 years from date of cause of action i.e. from 03.09.1999 to 03.09.2002 and not from year 1991. 			(Paras 17, 18, 22, 24)

heading: Application for
HeadNote.description: Order of no written statement - Setting aside of and grant of permission to file written statement by condoning delay - Application for - Order of 'No W. S.' was passed as defendant's application for stay of suit with prayer that he should not be asked to file written statement till criminal case filed by plaintiff against him in respect of same incident is decided as it will disclose his defence, was rejected - Thereafter matter proceeded without written statement and evidence of plaintiff and his witnesses was over - Defendant seeking permission to file written statement on ground that criminal case was decided - There was delay of 2 years in filing application after decision of criminal case - No explanation offered for said delay - Defendant took civil proceedings lightly and filed application without sufficient cause for delay of 6 years since filing of suit - Delay cannot be condoned and permission cannot be granted to file written statement.			(Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Ground of barred by limitation - Suit for cancellation of sale deed on ground of part payment of sale consideration - Plaintiffs claiming that only 6 cheques were encashed and remaining 40 cheques were bogus cheques - Cause of action to file suit arose in 2009 when last cheque was delivered to plaintiffs - Suit was filed 5 and ½ years after cause of action arose in 2009 - As per Art. 59 suit is to be filed within three years when cause of action arose - Suit barred by limitation - Rejection of plaint, proper. (Para 15.8)

headline: Civil P.C. (1908), O. 7, R. 11(d) - Limitation Act (1963), Art. 59 - Where suit for cancellation of sale deed is not filed within three years when cause of action arose, same is liable to be rejected being barred by Art. 59 of Limitation Act.

heading: Amendment of plaint
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Amendment of plaint - Limitation - Applicability of doctrine of relation back.

In the original written statement dated 16th May, 1990, the defendant had clearly put the plaintiff on notice that it had denied the plaintiff's title to the suit property. A reading of an isolated para in the written statement, by the trial court on the facts of this case has been correctly commented upon adversely by the High Court in the judgment under appeal. The original written statement read as a whole unmistakably indicated that the defendant had not accepted the plaintiff's title. Secondly, while allowing the amendment, the High Court in its earlier judgment dated 28th March, 2002 had expressly remanded the matter to the trial court, allowing the defendant to raise the plea of limitation. The right to sue for declaration of title first arose on the facts of the present case on 16th May, 1990 when the original written statement clearly denied the plaintiff's title. By 16th May, 1993 therefore a suit based on declaration of title would have become time-barred. It is clear that the doctrine of relation back would not apply to the facts of this case for the reason that the court which allowed the amendment expressly allowed it subject to the plea of limitation, indicating thereby that there are no special or extraordinary circumstances in the present case to warrant the doctrine of relation back applying so that a legal right that had accrued in favour of the defendant should be taken away.

2011 ALL SCR 2540 Rel.on. 	     [Para 29]

heading: Would be barred
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition and separate possession filed by plaintiff father - Death of father during pendency of suit - Plaintiffs on attaining majority not electing to continue previous suit - But second suit filed beyond elongated period of three years - Would be barred - Order dismissing suit, held proper.	(Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Against order decreeing suit for declaration as to title by adverse possession - No specific pleadings by plaintiffs that suit property was used by them as matter of right - However, plaintiffs have pleaded about continuous and uninterrupted use and enjoyment of suit property “as of theirs” for period more than 55 years - It cannot be said that there are no pleadings sufficient to make out case of adverse possession/by law of prescription - Further, defendants have not stepped into witness box or lead any evidence in matter - Two Courts considered documentary as well as oral evidence on record and returned concurrent findings that plaintiffs were in adverse possession of suit property and acquired title by adverse possession - Finding of facts recorded by Courts, does not suffer from any perversity - Second appeal dismissed. 	(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13, 22)

heading: Appeal
Refusal to condone
Validity
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Delay of 235 days in filing - Refusal to condone - Validity - Appellant claiming that delay occurred as he had been suffering from serious health ailments due to which he could not contact his counsel and could not file appeal in time - Material on record showing that appellant was visiting his doctor which is at distance of 1 and ½ Km from office of his counsel - It shows appellant is ignorant about his proceedings - Contention of appellant seeking condonation of delay was falsified by material on record - Refusal to condone delay, proper. 	(Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Restoration of appeal
Condonation of delay
Application for
HeadNote.description: Restoration of appeal - Condonation of delay - Application for - Applicants found to have acted in most negligent manner - Earlier appeal was restored in year 2006, still applicants were not diligent in prosecuting appeal - Orders passed in 2014 and 2015 reflecting that applicants have not contacted their Advocate in spite of efforts made - So also they have not deposited costs imposed - In facts, no case can be said to be made out to condone delay and recall order dismissing the appeal - Furthermore no case of serious prejudice made out to entertain the application - Application rejected.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Abatement of suit
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Abatement of suit - Delay in filing application for setting it aside - Condonation of - Claim by applicants that they were unaware of assertion of rights over suit land by respondent and institution of suit itself by their late father - Found not tenable as not only co-applicant had instituted suit earlier for partition against late father, but petitioner also had earlier instituted suit for partition, which was eventually dismissed - Therefore, rejection of application by applicants for condonation of delay, was proper as reason sought to be ascribed by them was not "sufficient". (Paras 15, 16, 20, 21)

heading: Ex parte decree
HeadNote.description:
Ex parte decree - Application for setting aside ex parte decree filed under O.9, R.13 - During pendency of the application, Appeal also filed - Dismissed as barred by limitation - Pending application is also liable to be dismissed notwithstanding the fact that application was filed first and appeal was filed thereafter.

An appeal filed along with an application for condoning the delay in filing that appeal when dismissed on the refusal to condone the delay is nevertheless a decision in the appeal. Therefore when an appeal against ex parte decree was dismissed as time barred by rejecting application for condonation of delay the petition under O.9, R.13 of the Code would not lie in view of the filing of an appeal against the decree by the appellant and the dismissal of the appeal though for default, since a dismissal for default or on the ground of it being barred by limitation cannot be equated with a withdrawal of the appeal. The fact that the appeal was filed subsequent to application under O.9, R.13 would be of no consequence as Explanation to O.9, R.13 applies to cases where appeal was filed subsequent to application under O.9, R.13 also. Hence, the trial court, the appellate court and the High Court have rightly held that the petition under Order IX, Rule 13 of the Code would not lie in view of the filing of an appeal against the decree by the appellant and the dismissal of the appeal though for default, since a dismissal for default or on the ground of it being barred by limitation cannot be equated with a withdrawal of the appeal. AIR 1976 Cal. 415 (FB) Held not good law in view of 1956 SCR 166.  [Para 13,16]

heading: Bombay Public Trusts Act (1950) , S.50(A)(1)
HeadNote.description: Bombay Public Trusts Act (1950) , S.50(A)(1) - Application for setting aside abatement - Delay of 10 months in filing application - Due to misconception of law, application for condonation of delay, not filed - Question involved was whether appointment of trustees as fit persons, was proper - Held, District Judge should have allowed applicants to file an application for setting aside abatement - Therefore, appellant/applicant needs to be allowed to file application for condonation of delay before District Judge - However, same shall be considered on its own merits, after hearing the parties.	(Paras 11 to 13)

heading: Rejection of plaint
Plea of limitation
HeadNote.description:
Rejection of plaint - Plea of limitation - Where, a plea of limitation is raised, the Court cannot reject the plaint but may dismiss it on framing a preliminary issue.

If law of limitation, which is a substantive law, speaks as to how a suit barred by limitation should be dealt with, then the mandate in the substantive law has to be followed. The Legislation in its wisdom has mandated dismissal of the suit. It could have also said that in such cases plaint be rejected. The fact that it makes use of the word dismiss is by itself eloquent. Necessarily, therefore, if the suit is apparently barred by limitation, the suit has to be dismissed. This is necessary because the rejection of plaint does not prohibit a party from filing a fresh suit as envisaged by rule 13 of Order 7 of C.P.C. Therefore, when once court records a finding that suit is barred by limitation and dismisses it, the lis comes to an end while where a plaint is rejected the lis does not come to an end. Where, therefore, a plea of limitation is raised, the court cannot reject the plaint but may dismiss it on framing a preliminary issue. The judge of the trial court has rightly rejected the application under Order 7, Rule 11 of C.P.C. There is, therefore, no substance in the revision and the same is dismissed.  [Para 10,11]

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description:
Scope of Limitation Act - Rejection of plaint - Where, a mere plea of limitation is raised; it could not be said that the suit is barred by law - The law of limitation cannot prevent a party from instituting a suit in Civil Court - But there are certain laws which prevent the suit being instituted in the Civil Court, for that law, makes a provision of alternate remedy and forum.

The words used in clause (d) of rule 11 of C.P.C. are to the effect that the plaint can be rejected when suit appears from the statement in the plaint to be barred by law. The important words in the said clause are "barred by law". The words barred by law have to be interpreted in the sense the suit itself could not be filed in the civil court i.e. where the civil court inherently lacks jurisdiction and certain law prohibits it from taking cognizance of the suit. Where, therefore, a mere plea of limitation is raised; it could not be said that the suit is barred by law. The law of limitation cannot prevent a party from instituting a suit in civil court. But there are certain laws which prevent the suit being instituted in the civil court, for that law, makes a provision of alternate remedy and forum. If a person wants to get an industrial dispute resolved, which is essentially a civil dispute, such a person cannot approach civil court, since Industrial Disputes Act makes remedy and forum available and therefore, civil court in such cases will inherently lack jurisdiction. The law of limitation, therefore, does not prohibit a party from approaching the civil court and filing a suit even though it may be barred by limitation. While dealing with the question, Court has to bear in mind the difference between rejection of a plaint and the dismissal of a suit. The plaint is rejected because it is found to be defective for the reasons mentioned in Rule 11. Though not in every case, generally the defective plaint is rejected by the court at the threshold. The court refusing to take cognizance can reject the plaint. Where plaint is rejected, a party has a right to present a fresh plaint but where a suit is dismissed, no party has a right to present a fresh suit on the same cause of action.

heading: New plea of limitation in second appeal
HeadNote.description:
New plea of limitation in second appeal - Can be raised.

As per the mandate of S. 3 of the Limitation Act it is the duty of the Court to see and go into the question of limitation. It is irrespective of the fact that defendant in the suit has not taken the defence of limitation. While in second appeal High Court is within its jurisdiction to consider the plea of limitation set up by the appellant and for that purpose it is necessary to appreciate the evidence on record.   [Para 29]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Application for restoration of suit - Condonation of delay - Application filed belatedly because wrong advise was inadvertently given by Advocate to file fresh suit - Delay condoned.	(Para 7)

heading: Consent decree
Execution of
HeadNote.description:
Consent decree - Execution of - Suit for specific performance of agreement of sale - Parties entered into compromise and recorded consent terms - Consent decree reflects agreement which was arrived at between parties - However said agreement cannot be equated to agreement of which enforcement is sought in suit - Agreement in question has translated itself into decree - Decree was enforceable from day one - Court was not required to do anything for making decree enforceable - Decree is executable in terms of Art.136.

AIR 1999 SC 3421, 2001(4) ALL MR 521 (S.C.) Ref.to. 	 [Para 12]

heading: Application for execution of decree
HeadNote.description: Application for execution of decree - Applicability of S.18(1) of Limitation Act - Application for execution shall not be deemed to be an application in respect of any property or right - Hence S.18(1) would have no application to execution of decree. 			(Para 17)

heading: Amendment of plaint
HeadNote.description:
Specific Relief Act (1963), Ss.21(5), 22(2) - Amendment of plaint - Plaintiff by amendment seeks to claim damages with interest in addition to specific performance - Application for amendment was filed much after 3 years when right to apply accrued - Amendment as per proviso to Ss.21(5), 22(2) can be made at any stage of proceedings - Application for amendment must be distinguished from cause of action, which is sought to be set up by amendment - Though application for amendment is allowed, question that if cause of action is within limitation would have to be determined and adjudicated upon - Application for amendment is not barred by limitation.

While allowing amendment, it is always open to Civil Court to direct that amendment shall not relate back to institution of proceeding. Court would therefore have to determine at trial whether cause of action is within limitation or is barred. Where legislature has contemplated that plaint can be amended at any stage of proceedings as stipulated in provisos to S. 21(5), 21(2). Such amendment of nature contemplated by those provisions can indeed be brought about at any stage of proceedings.

Application for amendment filed by plaintiffs is not barred by limitation. Judgement of Single Judge allowing amendment would not operate to cause any prejudice to Appellant so as to constitute judgment within meaning of Cl. 15 of Letters Patent.Necessary consequence would be that appeal against order of Learned Single Judge would not constitute judgment under Cl.15 of Letters Patent.

2012(4) ALL MR 628, 2004 (8) SCC 569, AIR 1982 SC 818, AIR 1992 SC 1604, 1983 Mh.L.J. 369, 1981 (4) SCC 8, 1974 (2) SCC 387 Ref. to. 		 	   [Para 11]

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Execution of foreign decree - Limitation - Word 'application' u/S.3 of Limitation Act, is wide enough to include application for execution of decree and even foreign decree - Principles of delay and latches which may be applicable to writ proceedings cannot be applied to civil proceedings - And also not at all attracted in proceedings filed under CPC which must be filed within prescribed period of limitation. 	(Para 13)

headline:
(A) Civil P.C. (1908), S.44A, O.21 R.3 – Limitation Act (1963), S.3, Art.136 – Execution of foreign decree – Limitation – Word 'application' u/S.3 of Limitation Act, is wide enough to include application for execution of decree and even foreign decree – Principles of delay and latches which may be applicable to writ proceedings cannot be applied to civil proceedings – And also not at all attracted in proceedings filed under CPC which must be filed within prescribed period of limitation. 	(Para 13)

(B) Civil P.C. (1908), S.44A, O.21 R.3 – Limitation Act (1963), S.3, Art.136 – Execution of foreign decree – Limitation – Plea that limitation will start running only after petition u/S.44A is filed – Plea raised on ground that cause of action for executing decree in India arises only after application u/S.44A is filed – Cause of action is concept relating to civil suits and not to execution petitions – Cause of action is bundle of facts which gives rise to legal right enabling plaintiff to file suit – Whereas decree is determination already made by court on basis of reasoned judgment – Decree becomes enforceable from day it is passed – Further, S.44A does not deal with period of limitation – It only enables District Court to execute decree – Filing of application u/S.44A will not create fresh period for enforcing decree – Plea not tenable.			(Paras 15, 17, 19, 21)

(C) Civil P.C. (1908), Ss.44A, 13, O.21 R.3 – Execution of foreign decree – Limitation – Limitation period for executing decree passed by foreign court from reciprocating country in India will be limitation prescribed in reciprocating foreign country – This will be subject to decree being executable in terms of S.13 of CPC. 	(Para 35)

(D) Civil P.C. (1908), S.44A, O.21 R.3 – Limitation Act (1963), S.3, Arts.136, 137 – Execution of foreign decree – Applicability of Art.136 – Determination – Art.136 clearly states that decree or order should be of civil court – Civil court as defined in India, may not be same as in foreign jurisdiction – Further, when dealing with application for execution of decrees, law makers have not said including foreign decrees – It appears that intention of legislature was that Art. 136 would be confined to decrees of Indian courts – Art.136 is applicable only to decrees passed by Indian civil courts – Application for execution of foreign decree would be covered by Art.137 of Limitation Act. 	(Paras 37, 39)

(E) Civil P.C. (1908), Ss.44A, 13, O.21 R.3 – Limitation Act (1963), Art.137 – Execution of foreign decree – Limitation – Limitation would start running from date when decree was passed in foreign country – However, if decree holder first takes steps to execute decree in foreign country and decree is not fully satisfied – He can file petition for execution in India within period of 3 years from finalization of execution proceedings in foreign country. 	(Paras 40, 43)

heading: First appeal
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
First appeal - Condonation of delay - One of the appellants suffering from serious ailment hence failed to act promptly - However, no reason given by other appellants as to why they could not file appeal in time - In view of ailment of one, it was expected of others to take prompt steps and avoid negligence - Absence of due diligence - Delay not condoned. 
2011 ALL SCR 487 Rel.on.(Paras 8, 13)

heading: Amendment of decree
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Amendment of decree - Limitation - Amendment sought to correct place of suit premises mentioned in decree beyond period specified u/Art.137 of Limitation Act - However, S.152, CPC permits such correction at any point of time - Therefore, Art.137 would have no application. 	(Para 9)

heading: Cannot be entertained
HeadNote.description: Chamber summons for cancellation of decree - Filed beyond period of three years - Cannot be entertained - It cannot also be entertained as review petition for correcting mistake or error in decree because limitation for such petition is only 30 days from date of decree.	 (Para 13)

heading: Abatement of appeal
Setting aside of
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Abatement of appeal - Setting aside of - Condonation of delay - Appellants rustic and illiterate villagers belonging to different families, different villages - Delay not a result of any dilatory tactic but genuine one - Liable to be condoned.	(Para 12)

heading: Framing of Issues
Acknowledgement of liability
HeadNote.description: Framing of Issues - Acknowledgement of liability - Suit for recovery of dues - Plaint specifically alleged that acknowledgement was given by defendant on specified date - Such allegation not denied in written Statement - No issue need be framed as to proof of acknowledgment - Issues can be framed only on disputed and not on admitted facts.

heading: Counter claim
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Counter claim - Limitation - Counter claim seeking mandatory injunction based on partition deed - No period of limitation provided under O.8 R.6A of CPC and therefore, Art.113 of Limitation Act would apply - Counter claim filed 3 years after accrual of cause of action when deed was executed - Hence, barred by limitation. 2012(7) ALL MR 169 Rel. on. (Para 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
Exparte proceedings ordered
HeadNote.description: Appeal against exparte decree - Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Suit for possession, filed by landlord against tenant - Tenant, absconding since more than one year prior to filing of suit - Summons sent to him, returned unserved as not claimed - Exparte proceedings ordered - Suit decreed in favour of landlord on 3rd January, 1994 - Wife of tenant aware of exparte decree only on 29th August, 1994 when it was sought to be executed - Wife being occupant of suit premises, rushing to appellate court on 5th September, 1994 and took necessary steps including filing of application for permission to file appeal as well as another application for condonation of delay in filing appeal against exparte decree - Sufficient cause and good reason which prevented the wife from filing appeal within limitation, made out - Delay ought to be condoned - Question as to whether summons of suit was sent and was duly served or not - Is relevant only while considering merits of grounds of appeal - Wife claiming right in respect of suit property through original tenant - She being aggrieved person by the exparte decree held, is competent to maintain an appeal against the said decree.1981 M.L.J. 355 - Followed.			(Paras 5,6 & 7)

heading: Proceedings under O.21
HeadNote.description: Proceedings under O.21 - Application of S.5 of Limitation Act stands excluded - For the said purpose inherent power cannot be invoked.	(Paras 14 to 17)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Issue of limitation, held, basically is a mixed issue of law and fact.	(Para 17)

heading: Abatement of suit
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908). S.151, O.1, R.10 - Abatement of suit - Suit pending for final decree - Cannot abate merely because Defendant had died in the intervening period after making of preliminary decree - Application seeking permission to amend plaint and proceedings as per schedule appended and also permission to bring respondents and applicant on record of suit - Though filed after 17 years but before passing of final decree - Not barred by limitation. 	(Paras 10, 11, 14)

heading: Setting aside abatement
Delay in applying
HeadNote.description:
Setting aside abatement - Delay in applying - Principles applicable in considering application stated.

The principles applicable in considering applications for setting aside abatement may thus be summarized as follows :

(i)	The words "sufficient cause for not making the application within the period of limitation" should be understood and applied in a reasonable, pragmatic, practical and liberal manner, depending upon the facts and circumstances of the case, and the type of case. The words 'sufficient cause' in section 5 of Limitation Act should receive a liberal construction so as to advance substantial justice, when the delay is not on account of any dilatory tactics, want of bonafides, deliberate inaction or negligence on the part of the appellant.

(ii)	In considering the reasons for condonation of delay, the courts are more liberal with reference to applications for setting aside abatement, than other cases. While the court will have to keep in view that a valuable right accrues to the legal representatives of the deceased respondent when the appeal abates, it will not punish an appellant with foreclosure of the appeal, for unintended lapses. The courts tend to set aside abatement and decide the matter on merits, rather than terminate the appeal on the ground of abatement.

(iii)	The decisive factor in condonation of delay, is not the length of delay, but sufficiency of a satisfactory explanation.

(iv) The extent or degree of leniency to be shown by a court depends on the nature of application and facts and circumstances of the case. For example, courts view delays in making applications in a pending appeal more leniently than delays in the institution of an appeal. The courts view applications relating to lawyer's lapses more leniently than applications relating to litigant's lapses. The classic example is the difference in approach of courts to applications for condonation of delay in filing an appeal and applications for condonation of delay in refiling the appeal after rectification of defects.

(v)	Want of 'diligence' or 'inaction' can be attributed to an appellant only when something required to be done by him, is not done. When nothing is required to be done, courts do not expect the appellant to be diligent. Where an appeal is admitted by the High Court and is not expected to be listed for final hearing for a few years, an appellant is not expected to visit the court or his lawyer every few weeks to ascertain the position nor keep checking whether the contesting respondent is alive. He merely awaits the call or information from his counsel about the listing of the appeal.  [Para 8]

heading: Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay in applying for setting aside abatement - Sufficient cause - How to determine.

If the following three conditions exist, the courts will usually condone the delay, and set aside the abatement (even though the period of delay is considerable and a valuable right might have accrued to the opposite party - LRs of the deceased - on account of the abatement):

(i)	The respondent had died during the period when the appeal had been pending without any hearing dates being fixed;

(ii)	Neither the counsel for the deceased respondent nor the Legal Representatives of the deceased respondent had reported the death of the respondent to the court and the court has not given notice of such death to the appellant.

(iii)	The appellant avers that he was unaware of the death of the respondent and there is no material to doubt or contradict his claim. 						 [Para 13]

heading: Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Delay in applying for setting aside abatement - Condonation of - Appeal by Managing Committee of Institution admitted in 1993 in High Court where regular and periodical dates of hearing are not fixed - Appeal came up for hearing in 2005 - Meanwhile New Managing Committee had come into existence and it was not aware of the death of respondent - New Committee had no way of knowing that appeal was pending, that LR's of deceased respondent were not brought on record - Held delay was satisfactorily explained and ought to have been condoned.	(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Preliminary issue
HeadNote.description: Preliminary issue - Suit for specific performance of agreement to sell and for perpetual injunction restraining defendant from interfering with suit property - Suit filed 29 years after date of agreement - No time limit prescribed in agreement for its performance - Suit for injunction would be governed by residuary Art.113 and cause of action would depend upon Court deciding when the right accrued, on the pleadings and evidence in the case - Hence suit in so far as it relates to prayer for a decree for perpetual injunction cannot be held to be barred by limitation at the preliminary stage.			(Para 14)

heading: Application for restoration
HeadNote.description: Dismissal of suit for default - Application for restoration - Application to be filed within 30 days of date of dismissal and not from date of knowledge.		(Para 3)

heading: Interpretation of Statutes
Procedural laws
HeadNote.description: Interpretation of Statutes - Procedural laws - Courts are required to take a pragmatic approach and not be hypertechnical as regards the procedural laws - Courts are no doubt burdened with huge arrears and suits are required to be disposed of with desirable speed - However, held, there should not be any haste to dispose of matters at the cost of being just and fair, and to avoid any miscarriage of justice. (2001)6 SCC 176 & (1987)2 SCC 107 - Ref. to.	(Para 10)

heading: Procedural laws
Abatement of suit
Delay
Suit abates
HeadNote.description:
Procedural laws - Abatement of suit - Delay - Failure to file condonation application - Suit abates - Valuable right accrues to other party - Cannot be lightly interfered with.

Procedural laws are as valid as any other law and are not meant to be brushed aside by the Court.  The provision fixing a particular time for making an application for bringing legal representatives on record with the consequence of the suit or appeal abating if no application is made within time, have been enacted for expeditious disposal of cases in the interest of proper administration of justice.  It is further to be borne in mind that when a suit or an appeal abates, a very valuable right accrues to the other party and such a right is not to be ignored or interfered with lightly in the name of doing substantial justice to the party, as depriving a party of a lawful right created in the interest of administration of justice in the absence of good grounds results in injustice to the party concerned.  [Para 20]

heading: Premature suit
Dismissal
Propriety
Not mandatory
HeadNote.description:
Premature suit - Dismissal - Propriety - Court entertaining such suit and passing decree therein - Not mandatory - Issue does not go to the root of jurisdiction - Not act without jurisdiction - It is in the discretion of court whether to grant decree or not.

A suit of a civil nature disclosing a cause of action even if filed before the date on which the plaintiff became actually entitled to sue and claim the relief founded on such cause of action is not to be necessarily dismissed for such reason. The question of suit being premature does not go to the root of jurisdiction of the Court; the Court entertaining such a suit and passing decree therein is not acting without jurisdiction but it is in the judicial discretion of the Court to grant decree or not. The Court would examine whether any irreparable prejudice was caused to the defendant on account of the suit having been filed a little before the date on which the plaintiff's entitlement to relief became due and whether by granting the relief in such suit a manifest injustice would be caused, to the defendant. Taking into consideration the explanation offered by the plaintiff for filing the suit before the date of maturity of cause of action, the Court may deny the plaintiff his costs or may make such other order adjusting equities and satisfying the ends of justice as it may deem fit in its discretion. The conduct of the parties and unmerited advantage to plaintiff or disadvantage amounting to prejudice to the defendant, if any, would be relevant factors.   [Para 22]

heading: Suit based on premature cause of action
HeadNote.description:
Suit based on premature cause of action - Plea as to non-maintainability of suit should be promptly raised by defendant and pressed for decision - Circumstances indicated in which court shall not exercise its discretion in favour of decreeing a premature suit.

A plea as to non-maintainability of the suit on the ground of its being premature should be promptly raised by the defendant and pressed for decision.
