It will equally be the responsibility of the Court to examine and promptly dispose of such a plea. The plea may not be permitted to be raised at a belated stage of the suit. However, the Court shall not exercise its discretion in favour of decreeing a premature suit in the following cases:  (i) When there is a mandatory bar created by a statute which disables the plaintiff from filing the suit on or before a particular date or the occurrence of a particular event; (ii) when the institution of the suit before the lapse of a particular time or occurrence of a particular event would have the effect of defeating a public policy or public purpose; (iii) if such premature institution renders the presentation itself patently void and the invalidity is incurable such as when it goes to the root of the Court's jurisdiction, and (iv) where the lis is not confined to parties alone and affects and involves persons other than those arrayed as parties, such as in an election petition which affects and involves the entire constituency. (See: Samar Singh Vs. Kedar Nath and others, (1987) Supp. SCC 663). One more category of suits which may be added to - where leave of the Court or some authority is mandatorily required to be obtained before the institution and was not so obtained. [Para 22]

heading: Amendment of plaint
HeadNote.description: Amendment of plaint - Amendment pertaining to certain facts newly emerged in suit - Provisions of S.3 and Art.137 of Limitation Act would not apply. 	(Para 29)

heading: Execution proceedings
Order not sustainable
HeadNote.description:
Execution proceedings - Correction in property details - Petitioner bank itself purchased property mortgaged with it in case of loan recovery - Executing Court issued sale certificate - Application for delivery of possession by petitioner in Executing Court - Objection by respondent that boundaries of property described in said application are incorrect - Application to correct description of property by petitioner - Application rejected on ground of delay and in view of O.6 R.17 - Order not sustainable - O.6 R.17 applies to amendment of pleading and cannot apply to execution proceedings.

Petitioner bank itself was permitted to purchase property mortgaged to it. Sale Certificate was issued shows boundaries of property. Said sale was preceded by auction notice in which also boundaries were mentioned. Parties were therefore very well aware as to property in respect of which application for possession has been filed by petitioner under O.21 R.95.  Omission to mention boundaries of Western and Southern Side can only be attributed to inadvertence on part of petitioner. In view of fact that parties were well aware as to in respect of which property execution proceedings were filed as also application for handing over possession, amendment of description of property in said application can therefore hardly cause any prejudice to Respondents. It is further required to be noted that respondents have also raised objection as regards description of property only in year 2012. Executing Court has proceeded on premise that provisions of O.6 R.17 would be applicable. Further held that application for amendment filed in year 2012 was filed beyond limitation and therefore could not be allowed.

Executing Court has erred in proceeding on premise that O.6 R.17 of C.P.C. would be applicable. O.6 R.17 applies to amendment of pleading, and cannot apply to execution proceedings and more so in respect of application for possession which has been filed in which through inadvertence description of property in so far as 2 boundaries are concerned is omitted.  Power that is to be exercised by Executing Court is inherent power under S.151 and power to permit amendment under S.153 of C.P.C. Power under S.153 to permit petitioner to correct boundaries in application for possession of property required to be exercised as it would lead to travesty of justice as petitioner who has decree in favour passed as long back as in year 1974 and also Sale Certificate dated 10/3/1980 would be deprived of possession of property on ground of mere technicality. 		     [Para 16]

heading: Summary suit
Summons for judgment
Limitation
Acknowledgment of liability
HeadNote.description: Summary suit - Summons for judgment - Limitation - Acknowledgment of liability - Last invoice is dated March 2006 and payment of Rs.5,00,000/- is made in November 2006 - Defendant did not acknowledge alleged liability on statement of accounts - Statement of accounts and ledger account only bears rubber stamp of defendant Company - It cannot be construed as acknowledgement of alleged liability or implied or express promise to pay - These two documents would not extend period of limitation under S.18 of Limitation Act - Issue of limitation is triable issue - Defendant is entitled to unconditional leave to defend.	(Para 18)

heading: Summary suit
Summons for judgment
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Summary suit - Summons for judgment - Limitation - On perusal of pleadings filed by plaintiff, it is clear that no such plea for seeking exclusion of time under S.14 of Limitation Act is pleaded - Burden to prove good faith and due diligence is on plaintiff - Finding of existence of good faith would be finding of fact - Whether plaintiff is entitled to exclusion of time under S.14 and as to whether plaintiff has satisfied all conditions for applicability of S.14 itself is triable issue - Defendants are entitled to unconditional leave to defend.

AIR 1998 SC 2476 Ref. to. 	 [Para 20]

heading: Appeal against preliminary decree
HeadNote.description: Appeal against preliminary decree - Contention that appeal is admitted for final hearing without condoning delay and without considering sufficient cause - No review or recall of order admitting appeal filed by respondent - Order not challenged in appeal either - Question of delay cannot be re-agitated - Contention of respondents is liable to be rejected.			(Para 3)

heading: Judgment on admission
HeadNote.description: Judgment on admission - Suit whether barred by law of Limitation - Refund on part of defendant was due from 4/12/2009 - Suit filed beyond period of 3 years i.e. 4/4/2013 - However, defendant acknowledged his liability up to 31/3/2012 - He even made part payment on 26/5/2011 - Held, suit is within time. (Paras 6, 10)

heading: Appeal
Cross-objection
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Cross-objection - Delay in filing cross-objection - Held, sufficient cause need not be shown - Appellate Court has wide power to extend time to file cross-objection - The power to extend time under O.41 R.22(1) has to be liberally exercised in case where a cross-objection is sought to be filed before the appeal is heard for final hearing. 			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Counter claim
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Counter claim - Limitation - It bars remedy and not a right - Though period of limitation prescribed in Limitation Act precludes plaintiff from bringing suit which is barred by limitation, there is no such limitation so far as any defence is concerned. (Para 7)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Specific Relief Act (1963), S.4 - Rejection of plaint - Limitation, whether a preliminary issue - Suit for specific performance of contract - In view of observation made in AIR 2006 SC 1556, when no date is fixed for performance of contract, matter falls under second limb of Art.54 of Limitation Act - In such case issue of limitation cannot be taken as preliminary issue for dismissal of suit. (Para 6)

heading: Framing of issues
HeadNote.description: Framing of issues - Suit based on title - Defendant pleading adverse possession - Limitation would start from date when possession of defendant becomes adverse - Hence, question of framing issue of limitation does not arise. 	(Para 8)

heading: Summary suit
HeadNote.description: Summary suit - For price of goods sold - Limitation period expired during Chrismas vacation - Suit filed on the court opening day, held to be within limitation. (Para 5)

heading: Summary suit
HeadNote.description: Summary suit - For price of goods sold - Acknowledgment of liability by defendent is sufficient - It is not necessary that there should be a promise to pay either express or implied. (Para 4)

heading: Summary suit
Plea of limitation
HeadNote.description: Summary suit - Plea of limitation - Cause of action started after 29th March, 2006 i.e. on due date when defendant failed to pay invoice amount - On day of expiry of limitation period i.e. on 29th March 2009, court was closed - Therefore, suit filed on 30th March, 2009, not barred by limitation.               (Para 4)

heading: Rejection of plaint
Application for
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Application for - On ground that suit is barred by limitation - First suit was withdrawn with liberty granted on ground of defect of jurisdiction - However, second suit being fresh suit is filed after expiry of period of limitation - Not barred by limitation since same is saved by leave so granted - Application rejected. (Paras 12, 13, 16)

heading: Ex parte decree
Limitation to file
HeadNote.description: Ex parte decree - Application to set aside - Limitation to file - It has to be filed within 30 days from date of decree. (Para 11)

heading: Period of limitation
HeadNote.description: Period of limitation - The issue of limitation is a mixed question of law and fact - The trial Court shall frame the issue of limitation and decide the same after giving opportunity to the parties.			(Para 15)

heading: Rejection of plaint
Application for
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Application for - Defendant sought rejection on ground that it was barred by limitation - Plaintiff claims exclusion of time spent in earlier proceedings - As per S.14 time has been excluded if earlier proceedings failed due to defect of jurisdiction or other cause of like nature - Earlier proceedings failed on ground of delay - Period spent in earlier proceedings cannot be excluded - Plaint is hopelessly barred by limitation - Plaint liable to be rejected.	(Paras 13)

heading: Execution
Obstructionist proceedings
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Execution - Obstructionist proceedings - Limitation - Application under O.21 R.97 not filed within 30 days of obstruction raised by obstructionists - However, application filed by obstructionists and reply filed by decree holders were considered as an application under O.21 R.97 and tried as suit - In such situation, Art.129 of Schedule to Limitation Act, would not be attracted. 	(Para 24)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Claim for, on ground of bar of limitation - Suit against hospital and its doctors for recovery of money and compensation for fraud and misrepresentation - Plaintiff was advised to go for urgent open heart surgery - She was also asked to carry demand draft of Rs.4 lakhs in favour of hospital though she was covered by Goa Medical Claim Scheme - Cause of action for suit arose on date when plaintiff was consulted and alleged fraud and misrepresentation was practiced - Suit however filed beyond period of 3 years from that date - Therefore barred by limitation - Plaint liable to be rejected.	(Para 19)

heading: Second appeal
Availability of remedy
HeadNote.description:
Second appeal - Availability of remedy - Application for condonation of delay in filing first appeal was dismissed - Same amounts to dismissal of appeal itself - Order so dismissing the appeal, is a decree - Can be subject matter of second appeal - Hence, remedy of second appeal is available against such order. 

AIR 2004 Karnataka 75 Held not a good law in view 2005(5) ALL MR 152 (S.C.).     (Para 5)

heading: First appeal
Delay in filing
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: First appeal - Delay in filing - Condonation of - Hyper technical approach should not be adopted while deciding delay condonation application - Conscious application of judicial mind is must to record findings upon all issues and contentions. 			(Para 7)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - Application for, on ground of limitation - Last date for filing of suit was 31/12/2010, the last day of winter vacation - 1/1/2011 was a non-working Saturday - But a working day for Registry - However, such confusion cannot save limitation to file a suit - Application allowed. 			(Paras 3, 7)

heading: Amendment of plaint
Chamber summons for
HeadNote.description: Amendment of plaint - Chamber summons for - Filed after 27 years of filing of suit - Though delay is not a ground for rejecting amendment, in the instant case parties are not rustic litigants - All plaintiffs are companies and dispute between parties is a commercial litigation - In such facts and circumstances, amendment not allowed.  (Para 16)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - On ground of suit barred by limitation and principles of res-judicata - Issue of res-judicata and limitation being mixed question of facts and law cannot be decided in application u/O.7 R.11(d) - Whether suit is barred by limitation or not will have to be decided on basis of evidence led by parties after framing of issue as to limitation - On plain reading of plaint, it cannot be said that suit is barred by limitation - Also issue relating to possession was not directly and substantially in question before Co-operative Court in earlier proceedings as alleged by petitioner - It cannot be said that suit is barred by res-judicata - Application for rejection of plaint liable to be dismissed. 	(Paras 13, 14, 15, 17)

heading: Second appeal
Issue of limitation
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Issue of limitation - Is mixed question of law and facts - Party cannot be permitted to raise it in second appeal, if not framed by Trial Court nor pressed before First Appellate Court. (1976) 1 SCC 863 Ref. to. 	(Para 15)

heading: Ex-parte decree
Permissibility
HeadNote.description: Ex-parte decree - Delay in filing regular appeal u/S.96(2), CPC - Condonation, by excluding time spent in pursuing application under O.9 R.13 - Permissibility - Held, only where defendant has adopted dilatory tactics or lack bonafide in pursuing two remedies consecutively, Court may decline to condone delay - Otherwise depriving defendant from his statutory right of appeal would not be appropriate - Rules of limitation are not meant to destroy rights of parties. 2005(5) ALL MR 257 (S.C.), (2012) 12 SCC 693 Ref.to. 	(Paras 14, 16)

heading: Ex-parte decree
HeadNote.description: Ex-parte decree - Delay of 4 yrs. in filing regular appeal u/S.96(2), due to pendency of application under O.9 R.13 for more than 3 yrs. - Defendants pursued said application diligently - In the interest of justice, defendants may be permitted to challenge ex-parte decree on merits notwithstanding dismissal of their application under O.9 R.13 - Time spent in earlier application is to be taken as "sufficient cause" for condoning delay. 			(Paras 17, 18, 19)

heading: Cross-objection to appeal
HeadNote.description: Cross-objection to appeal - Powers of Court to extend time or condone delay in filing of - Not similar to power of Court to condone delay under Limitation Act - Principles governing discretion of Court under Limitation Act do not apply - While extending time or condoning delay under O.41 R.22(1) CPC, principle of fitness of case, depending on fact and situations of cases should always be applied in liberal and pragmatic way. 2013(5) ALL MR 934 (S.C.), (2014) 14 SCC 133, (2014)14 SCC 127, AIR 1963 SC 1516, 2011(6) ALL MR 242 Ref. to. 			(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Death of appellant
HeadNote.description: Death of appellant - Consequent abatement of appeal - Appellant died in the year 1996 - Order that 'appeal abates' passed in 2011 while rejecting application for bringing LRs on record - This does not mean that appeal stood abated only in 2011 and applicability of Arts.120 and 121 of Limitation Act stood nullified in the facts of case - Said limitation is applicable. 	(Para 13)

heading: Rejection of application
Legality
HeadNote.description:
Bringing LRs on record - Rejection of application - Legality - Appellant died in the September 1996 - Application to bring LRs on record filed in September 2009 - Contention of applicant LRs that they came to know about pendency of appeal only in April 2009 - Not acceptable, as the dispute is of partition among the parties who are inter se related - Further, the applicants had also appeared in Darkhast proceedings filed by the other party in 2008 - Even if it is accepted that applicants came to know about appeal only in April 2009, their application in September 2009 is still unexplained - In the instant case 'sufficient cause' is far from satisfaction - Rejection proper.

AIR 2002 SC 1201 Disting.			 [Para 11,13,14]

heading: Auction sale
HeadNote.description: Auction sale - Application under O.21 R.95 by purchaser, for delivery of possession of property - Limitation of one year - Starts from date when sale becomes absolute and not from date when sale is confirmed - In instant case, after order of confirmation, judgment debtor challenged valuation of auctioned property - Unless said challenge is finally decided, held, sale cannot be said to have become absolute - Challenge of judgment debtor finally decided on 9.7.2003 - Application under O.21 R.95 filed on 30.8.2003 - Not barred by limitation. AIR 1934 PC 134, AIR 1953 SC 425 Ref. to.  (Para 17)

heading: Auction sale
Period of limitation
HeadNote.description: Auction sale - Application under O.21 R.95 by purchaser, for delivery of possession of property - Period of limitation - Issue as to applicability of S.15(1) of Limitation Act in said application so as to exclude the time for which matter was stayed by Court - Said larger issue not looked into by Court in view of narrow compass of instant case - Issue left open.  (Para 15)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Ex-parte decree of divorce - Application for setting aside of - Limitation - Time for computing period of limitation would start from date of decree - However, where summons or notice was not duly served limitation would start when applicant had knowledge of decree. 	(Para 5)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Rejection of plaint - On ground of limitation - Challenge by contending that limitation being mixed question of law and fact, plaint cannot be rejected - Not acceptable, as not in every case, it is question involving disputed facts - There may be cases where facts on basis of which, issue of limitation has to be decided are either admitted or undisputed or are clearly borne out of record. 2000(2) Mh.L.J. 570 Rel. on. 	(Para 14)

heading: Rejection of plaint
HeadNote.description: Specific Relief Act (1963) - Rejection of plaint - On ground of limitation - Suit filed for declaration of ownership as also declaration about Certificate of Sale dated 30.06.1973 in execution proceedings as being null and void - Denial/infringement of title may not necessarily require interference with actual possession of property - By way of setting up of rival title based on document, which was Sale Certificate, issued in auction proceedings, would also amount to clear denial or cloud on title of plaintiff - As per plaintiff, he learnt about said purchase on 22.02.2001 - However, Judgment of inquiry officer placed on record was of 08.01.1985, proving that plaintiff was aware of purchase certificate at least from 1985 - Therefore, suit filed in 2004 was clearly barred by limitation. 2011 ALL SCR 2540, AIR 1961 SC 808, 2010(2) ALL MR 461 (S.C.), (1991) 4 SCC 1 Ref. to. 	(Paras 17, 18, 19)

heading: Exparte order
HeadNote.description:
Exparte order - Application for permission to file written statement after quashing exparte order, made after expiry of period of three years - Bar of Art.137 would apply - In application u/O.9 R.7 defendant sought to give reason for their non appearance - However, no pleading made as regards delay in moving application and reason for said delay - In absence of application for condonation of delay, consideration of application u/O.9 R.7 would be without jurisdiction - Defendants are at liberty to seek condonation of delay in moving application u/O.9 R.7.
2003 (3) Mh.L.J. 238, 2005 (1) Mh.L.J. 1147, 2006 (6) BCR 500, 1997(1) ALL MR 149 Rel. on. (Para 10)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Formulation of issue of limitation, for first time - Just because Courts below did not frame said issue or it was not raised by parties, framing of such issue in second appeal would not be barred. 2005(1) ALL MR 390, 2016 ALL SCR 857 Ref. to. 	(Paras 23, 24)

heading: Compromise decree
HeadNote.description:
Compromise decree - Allegation that it was void - Still for setting aside the same law of limitation applies - It is not the law that when decree is void no period of limitation shall be attracted at all.

If the compromise has been accepted in absence of all the parties, the same would be void. But if the same having resulted in grant of a decree, the decree based on compromise is required to be set aside. The compromise may be void or voidable but it is required to be set aside by filing a suit within the period of limitation. Limitation is a statute of repose. If a suit is not filed within the period of limitation, the remedy would be barred.    [Para 45]

Thus, a compromise decree even if void was required to be set aside. A consent decree, as is well known, is as good as a contested decree. Such a decree must be set aside if it has been passed in violation of law. For the said purpose, the provisions contained in the Limitation Act, 1963 would be applicable. It is not the law that where the decree is void, no period of limitation shall be attracted at all.						 [Para 48]

heading: Amendment of plaint
Not maintainable
HeadNote.description: Amendment of plaint - Original suit for injunction was filed in year 2008 - Amendment application seeking declaratory relief of title filed in year 2016 - Said application altering the entire nature of suit filed after a period of 8 years from date of cause of action - Not maintainable - Moreover, said application being filed far beyond the allowable limitation period - Liable to be dismissed. (Paras 13, 15)

heading: Suit for recovery of money
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of money - Whether barred by limitation - Appellate Court held that suit is barred by limitation as it was not filed within period of three years from date of order for supply of material placed by defendant - Date for supply of material cannot be starting point for computing period of limitation - Invoices which were raised on defendant had to be settled by defendant within 90 days, from date on which same were raised - In case of failure to pay within 90 days defendant will be obliged to pay interest at 18% p.a. - Defendant failed to settle invoices within 90 days - Cause of action to file suit arose when period of 90 days expired - Suit was instituted within period of 3 years from date of expiry of period of 90 days - Suit is within period of limitation - Appellate Court erred in holding suit barred by limitation.	(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13)

heading: First appeal
Condonation
Appellant not diligent
HeadNote.description:
First appeal - Delay of 3 yrs. - Condonation - Appellant purchased a property of joint family - Vendor’s family members obtained ex-parte decree that sale deed was not binding on them - Appellant did not appear before trial court - He did not even engage a lawyer - He relied on oral promise of vendor that he would solve family problem - Reasons of ill-health also given - However, no documentary evidence produced in support of it - Appellant not diligent - Delay cannot be condoned.
(2001) 6 SCC 176, 2018 SCC OnLine Bom 6482 Disting. 	(Para 8)

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description:
Appeal - Scope and applicability of S.5 of Limitation Act - Applicability of S.5 of Limitation Act is not excluded in case of an appeal preferred under Clause No.21.

Maharashtra Rent Control Act (1999), S.43.

Mere provision of period of limitation in howsoever peremptory language is not sufficient to displace the applicability of Section 5 of the said Act of 1963.  It is also clear that unless applicability of Section 5 of the said Act of 1963 is expressly excluded, it cannot be said that Section 5 will not have any application.  It is no doubt true as held by the Apex Court in the recent case of Union of India Vs. M/s. Popular Construction Co., express exclusion may follow from the scheme and objects of the special or local law.  In case of Prakash Jain relied upon by the learned counsel for the Petitioner, while considering the scheme of Section 43 of the Maharashtra Rent Control Act, 1999 and especially the consequences prescribed by the Section itself for not making application for leave to defend within a period of 30 days, the Apex Court has taken view that applicability of Section 5 of the said Act of 1963 is excluded.  However, on the basis of the view taken by the Apex Court after examining the scheme of Section 43 of the Act of 1999, one cannot jump to the conclusion that applicability of Section 5 of the said Act of 1963 is excluded in so far clause 21 of the Rent Control Order is concerned.  If the entire scheme of the Rent Control Order is examined there is nothing to show that the applicability of Section 5 of the said Act of 1963 is intended to be excluded.  Infact, in sub-clause (i) of Clause 21 a provision has been made for excluding time required for obtaining copy of the Order of the Rent Controller.  In the case of Prakash Jain relied upon by the learned counsel for the petitioner, the Apex Court was considering the scheme and scope of a provision which is altogether of a different nature.  In the present matter the question is as regards the Appeal under Clause 21 of the Rent Control Order.  Considering the scheme of the Rent Control Order the Division Bench of this Court in the case reported in Babasaheb Kedar Vs. Additional Collector has come to the conclusion that applicability of Section 5 of the said Act of 1963 is not excluded in case an appeal is preferred under Clause No.21. Court does not agree with the submissions of the learned counsel for the Petitioner that the law laid down by the Division Bench of this Court is no longer a good law in the light of the case of Prakash Jain.  Therefore, the said argument advanced by the learned counsel for the Petitioner is rejected. 2004(5) ALL MR 1 (S.C.) - Distinguished. 2000(3) ALL MR 90 - Rel. on.	 [Para 11]

heading: It is court
HeadNote.description:
Appellate Authority under S. 21 - It is court - It can condone delay by invoking S.5.

1996 (2) Mh. L.J. 240 overruled.

The Additional Collector exercising appellate powers under the Rent Control Order is a "court" and therefore, he has jurisdiction under S. 5 of the Limitation Act to consider and decide the application for condonation of delay in filing the appeal.

1996(2) Mh LJ 240 overruled.   [Para 23]

The Reviewing or the Appellate Authority exercising powers under the C.P. & Berar Rent Control Order, 1949 are exercising judicial functions and, therefore, they have all essential attributes of a Court and, therefore, they are Courts. The C.P. & Berar Rent Control Order, 1949 though provides Limitation for filing review or appeal against the order of the Rent Controller, it does not expressly exclude the application of the provisions of Sections 4 to 24 (both inclusive) of the Limitation Act. As such, the provisions of Sections 4 to 24 of the Limitation Act would automatically apply to the proceedings before the Reviewing or the Appellate Authority exercising powers under the C. P. & Berar Rent Control Order, 1949 and thus, they have jurisdiction under section 5 of the Limitation Act to consider and decide the application for condonation of delay in filing review or appeal against the order of the Controller within the prescribed period.  [Para 12,17,21]

Further, it is the Collector who is authorised to exercise the powers. At some places, it is the Additional Collector who is authorised to exercise the appellate power. But in any eventuality, it is by designation and not by name. Therefore,e the Authority appointed to exercise the appellate power cannot be said to be persona designata.  [Para 19]

heading: Plea of Limitation
Cannot be rejected
HeadNote.description:
Specific performance of the contract - Plea of Limitation - Agreement executed in favour of plaintiff - Defendant failed to perform his part of agreement when notice served on him - Claim by plaintiff for specific performance - Cannot be rejected - Furthermore no date of sale deed mentioned in agreement - Suit would be within limitation u/s.54 of Limitation Act. 

In the instant case, Defendant executed an Agreement in favour of the plaintiff and failed to perform his part of the agreement when called upon by the plaintiff by serving notice on him, besides the plaintiff's claim for specific performance of the agreement cannot be rejected, furthermore on date on which the sale deed was to be executed by the defendant in favour of the plaintiff was mentioned in Agreement, therefore from the date on which the defendant when called upon to perform his part of the Agreement, refused to perform his part, the cause of action to seek specific performance of the agreement has arisen and from that date, the suit is within limitation as per the provisions of Sec.54. 						       [Para 9,10,11]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Delay of more than three years in filing revision against order of appellate court - Appeal was dismissed for continuous non-appearance of petitioner - Though delay explained in the application, no explanation given as to non-appearance of petitioner on as many as 21 consecutive dates - Held, expression "sufficient cause" cannot be erased from S.5 of Limitation Act by adopting excessive liberal approach defeating very purpose of S.5 of Limitation Act and Consumer Act - No discretion can be used in such a huge delay - Delay not condoned. 
IV (2011) CPJ 63 (SC), 2009 ALL SCR 508, AIR 1962 SC 361, 1993 (1) RLR 68, 1997 (2) Raj LW 845 Ref. to.(Para 2)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Complaint regarding insurance claim - Cause of action commences from date on which complainant suffers loss and not from date on which insurance claim was repudiated - Ar.44 of Limitation Act which provides to the contrary is not applicable to consumer complaints.

The whole difficulty is that Section 24-A of the Consumer Protection Act, 1986 speaks about 'cause of action' but, does not specify that the cause of action arises on rejection or repudiation of the insurance claim. The date on which the Complainant becomes eligible to get the amount of insurance policy is the date on which the cause of action commences i.e. the date on which he suffered loss. It is well-settled principle of law that cause of action once commences to run, it never stops. No doubt Limitation Act, 1963 contains the provisions which provide for stopping of cause of action even though it commenced when the person who is supposed to file a suit suffers from a disability, namely, minority and/or mental disability. However, in that event also the cause of action starts to run from the date on which disability is removed. However, said provision has not been incorporated under the Consumer Protection Act, 1986.  [Para 7]

Clause (b) of Article-44 of the Limitation Act, 1963 provides for period of limitation of three years and in last column it states when the period of limitation starts to run. As per this article period of limitation starts to run from the date of occurrence causing the loss, or where the claim on the policy is denied, either partly or wholly, the date of such denial. Therefore, this provision provides that the limitation starts from the date of denial of the claim by the Insurance Company. However, this Article is not applicable to Section 24- A of the Consumer Protection Act, 1986. It is applicable to the civil suits to be filed in the Civil Court. No doubt Section-3 of the Consumer Protection Act, 1986 specifically states that provisions of the said Act are not in derogation of but are in addition to the provisions of existing laws but it is to be noted that the remedy available under this Act is a summary remedy. A full-fledged remedy of the Civil Court is available under the law to the Complainant instead of choosing the remedy under the Consumer Protection Act, 1986.

III (2009) CPJ 75 (SC) Ref. to.  [Para 9]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - In filing appeal under Companies Act 2013 - Limitation Act whether applicable - Appellant has crossed even second time limit for filing appeal - S.433 cannot come into aid of appellant as provisions of Limitation Act only apply "as far as may be" - Special provision is contained u/S.421(3) Proviso, hence Limitation Act cannot apply. (1976) 1 SCC 392 Disting. 	(Paras 4, 5, 13)

heading: Contempt petition
Delay
HeadNote.description: Contempt petition - Delay - Scope and applicability of S.5 of Limitation Act - Held, S.5 of Limitation Act is applicable to petitions under Contempt of Courts Act. 2003 (Supp) Bom.C.R. (S.C.) 51 - Rel. on.			(Para 16)

heading: Contempt petition
HeadNote.description: Contempt petition - Delay in filing of contempt petition - Act allegedly committed by contemnor admittedly a continuing wrong - Hence, held, no need to condone the delay. 2003(4) ALL MR 3 - Rel. on.	(Para 19)

heading: Company petition
HeadNote.description: Company petition - Petition for rectification of register of members - Ground of misuse of company's funds to purchase its own shares in violation of S.77 - Eight other shareholders also filing company petition - Limitation for filing petition would begin to run from date petitioners came to know about fraud - Finding on point of knowledge could not have been recorded until parties are given opportunity to lead evidence and as such dismissal of petition as barred by limitation at the preliminary stage itself would be erroneous in law.	(Paras 17, 20)

heading: Suit for compensation
HeadNote.description: Suit for compensation - On account of breach of contract - Limitation of 3 yrs. - Contract was to be completed in four seasons - On each season, defendant caused delay in handing over site due to which cost of labour increased - Held, it is not a case of continuous breach but multiple breaches on part of defendant - Cause of action for plaintiff arose on each breach of contract and not at completion of contract - Plaintiff filed suit after completion of contract when cause of action even for the last breach was lapsed - Plaintiff's suit barred by limitation.	(Paras 9, 10, 14)

heading: Applicability of S.19
HeadNote.description:
Extension of period of limitation on certain payment - Applicability of S.19 - Plaintiff filed suit for compensation on account of additional cost incurred by him in performance of contract - Held, a claim for damages does not give rise to a 'debt' in terms of S.19 - Further, S.19 does not apply to any amount not accepted by the other party - Defendant never accepted/acknowledged claim of plaintiff - Payment of Final Bill and return of Security Deposit by defendant cannot be construed as acknowledgement of damages raised by plaintiff - S.19 would not extend period of limitation as it does not apply to plaintiff's case.
(1858) 27 L.J.Q.B. 234, (2008) 2 SCC 444 Rel. on. 	(Para 12)

heading: Winding up petition
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Winding up petition - Limitation - Suit for recovery based upon cause of action i.e. within limitation - Cannot impact separate and independent remedy of winding up proceedings.
	A suit for recovery based upon a cause of action that is within limitation cannot in any manner impact the separate and independent remedy of a winding up proceeding. In law, when time begins to run, it can only be extended in the manner provided in the Limitation Act. For example, an acknowledgement of liability under Section 18 of the Limitation Act would certainly extend the limitation period, but a suit for recovery, which is a separate and independent proceeding distinct from the remedy of winding up would, in no manner, impact the limitation within which the winding up proceeding is to be filed, by somehow keeping the debt alive for the purpose of the winding up proceeding.	(Para 19)

heading: Claims before Regulatory Commission
HeadNote.description:
Claims before Regulatory Commission - Applicability of Limitation Act - Commission is not a court stricto-sensu - Limitation Act by itself is inapplicable to proceedings before Commission - Claim barred by limitation cannot be entertained by Commission but in appropriate case specified period may be excluded by applying principles underlying Section 5 or 14 of Limitation Act.

By itself the Limitation Act will not be applicable to the Commission under Indian Electricity Act 2003 as the Commission is not a Court stricto sensu. The Commission being a statutory tribunal, cannot act beyond the four walls of the Electricity Act also does not brook any exception. However, the Electricity Act 2003 requires a further scrutiny to find out whether by virtue of Section 175 of the Electricity Act or otherwise it can be inferred that the provisions of Limitation Act will govern or curtail the powers of the Commission in entertaining a claim under Section 86(1) (f) of the Electricity Act. [Para 32]

A statutory authority like the Commission is also required to determine or decide a claim or dispute either by itself or by referring it to arbitration only in accordance with law and thus Section 174 and 175 of the Electricity Act assume relevance. Since no separate limitation has been prescribed for exercise of power under Section 86(1)f) nor this adjudicatory power of the Commission has been enlarged to entertain even the time barred claims, there is no conflict between the provisions of the Electricity Act and Limitation Act to attract the provisions of Section 174 of the Electricity Act. In such a situation on account of provisions in Section 175 of the Electricity Act or even otherwise the power of adjudication and determination or even the power of deciding whether a case requires reference to arbitration must be exercised in a fair manner and in accordance with law. In the absence of any provision in the Electricity Act creating a new right upon a claimant to claim even monies barred by law of limitation, or taking away a right of the other side to take a lawful defence of limitation, in the light of nature of judicial power conferred on the Commission, claims coming for adjudication before it cannot be entertained or allowed if it is found legally not recoverable in a regular suit or any other regular proceeding such as arbitration, on account of law of limitation. Have taken this view not only because it appears to be more just but also because unlike Labour laws and Industrial Disputes Act, the Electricity Act has no peculiar philosophy or inherent underlying reasons requiring adherence to a contrary view. Evidently, in absence of any reason or justification the legislature did not contemplate to enable a creditor who has allowed the period of limitation to set in, to recover such delayed claims through the Commission. Hence a claim coming before the Commission cannot be entertained or allowed if it is barred by limitation prescribed for an ordinary suit before the civil court. But in appropriate case, a specified period may be excluded on account of principle underlying salutary provisions like Section 5 or 14 of the Limitation Act. Such limitation upon Commission on account of this decision would be only in respect of its judicial power under clause (f) of sub-section (1) of Section 86 of the Electricity Act, 2003 and not in respect of its other powers or functions which may be administrative or regulatory. [Para 29,30]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Appeal u/S.127 of Electricity Act - Condonation of delay - S.29(2) of Limitation Act, whether applicable - S.29(2) becomes applicable in two contingencies - Firstly that there must be a provision for period of limitation under any special or local law in connection with any suit, appeal or application - Secondly that when said special or local law prescribes period of limitation for an appeal or application for which there is no provision in Schedule to Limitation Act - Language of S.127 satisfies said tests - Hence, S.29(2) would be applicable to proceeding u/S.127 of Electricity Act.

	Section 29 of the Limitation Act becomes applicable in two contingencies that there must be a provision for period of limitation under any special or local law in connection with any suit, appeal or application; and secondly when the said special or local law prescribes the period of limitation for an appeal or application for which there is no provision in the Schedule to the Limitation Act. In such cases all the provisions of Sections 4 to 24 of the Limitation Act would become applicable.

	The special laws can be carved out into two categories, one category of special laws are those where the Appeal provision lays down a period of limitation couched in a peremptory or imperative language which as held by the Apex Court is not sufficient to displace the applicability of Section 5 of the Limitation Act and the 2nd category is of those special laws where on account of the language used in the Appeal provision the applicability of the limitation Act is ruled out or are those special laws where the applicability of Section 5 of the Limitation Act is specifically excluded.

	In the instant case, the Appeal is under a provision namely Section 127 of the Electricity Act. The said Appeal lies against the final assessment order passed by the Assessing Officer. The language of Section 127 of the Electricity Act stands in contradistinction to the language of Section 125 of the Electricity Act. The scheme encompassed within the said two provisions is therefore different. Though Section 127 is couched in a peremptory or imperative manner, Sections 5 to 24 of the Limitation Act would have to be applied for determining the period of limitation to file an Appeal under the said provision, though the Electricity Act is held to be a special law. Having regard to the tests laid down for applicability of Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act which have already been adverted to herein above, the said tests can be said to have been satisfied in so far as the applicability of Section 29(2) to a proceeding under Section 127 of the Electricity Act is concerned.

	By holding that Section 29(2) would be application to a proceeding under Section 127 of the Electricity Act, the Court has construed Section 127 of the Electricity Act is different than Section 125, though both are part of the same special law. Support for the same can be drawn from the judgment of the Apex Court in The Member, Board of Revenue's case [AIR 1956 SC 35].

	In the said case, the Apex Court was concerned with the provisions of the Indian Stamp Act and especially the issue as to under which provision the document in question therein was exigible to stamp duty. The provisions in question were Sections 4 to 6 of the Indian Stamp Act. The Apex Court held that the topics dealt with by the 3 Sections above being different no useful purpose would be served by referring to Section 4 or Section 6 of the Indian Stamp Act for determining the scope of Section 5 or for construing its terms, as in the said case, the legislature has used three different words in relation to the three sections "transaction" in Section 4, "matter" in Section 5, and "description" in Section 6. Same is the case with Section 125 and Section 127 of the Electricity Act. The language of the said provisions is different and they provide for an Appeal against different orders. Therefore, the applicability of Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act to a proceeding under Section 127 of the Electricity Act cannot be ruled out and the period applicable for filing an Appeal would therefore have to be necessarily construed keeping in mind Sections 5 to 24 of the Limitation Act.	 [Para 8,14]

heading: Acknowledgement in writing
Are relevant
HeadNote.description: Acknowledgement in writing - Entries in books of account regularly kept in course of business - Are relevant - Entries alone are not sufficient to charge any person with liability - However, if there is a cogent and reliable evidence to show genuineness of the accounts, then the liability can be fastened on defendant.			(Para 13)

heading: Disconnection
Applicability
HeadNote.description: Disconnection - Time limit of 2 yrs. - Applicability - Due to mistake of billing, electricity charges recovered at lower rate - Mistake discovered after about 3 yrs. - Held, after lapse of said time limit, electricity supply cannot be disconnected in terms of S.56(2) - However, for recovery of supplementary charges, limitation would begin from date of discovery of mistake as per S.17(1)(c) of Limitation Act. (Para 9)

headline:
Electricity Act, 2003 - S.56 - Disconnection of supply in default of payment - 

(1) Meaning to be ascribed to the term “first due” - Word “due” used u/S.56(1) as well as u/S.56(2) - Term “due” refers to amount for which the demand is raised by way of a bill - Term “first due” therefore implies when the demand is raised for the first time - Bill raised by the licensee company would be the starting point for the exercise of power u/sub-section (1) of S.56

(2) Period of limitation u/S.56(2) cannot be extended by raising a supplementary bill - “Sum due” raised in original bill, unpaid, must be continuously shown as arrears of charges in subsequent bills, within period of limitation of two years from date of additional bill, for said amount to become recoverable by coercive mode of disconnection of electricity supply

(3) Statutory right of licensee company to disconnect the supply of electricity u/S.56 of 2003 Act, if consumer neglects to pay the electricity dues, subject to the period of limitation of two years provided u/S.56(2) of 2003 Act - Bar of limitation extends to 

(4) As per S.17(1)(c) of Limitation Act,1963, in case of a mistake, limitation period begins to run from the date when the mistake is discovered for the first time.

(5) After expiry of limitation period of two years, licensee company free to take recourse to any other lawful remedy for recovery of additional demand but  barred from taking recourse to disconnection of supply of electricity due to non-payment of electricity dues u/S.56(2), as coercive measure for realizing payment for said additional demand.

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Scope and applicability of S.14 of Limitation Act - Appeal against an order passed by authority under Employees' Provident Funds Act - Period of limitation of 60 days prescribed by R.7(2) for filing appeal to Tribunal - It is a special law of limitation - Held, provision of S.14 of Limitation Act would apply also to special law of limitation.	(Paras 6 to 9)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Appeal to Supreme Court - Appeal against decision or order of Tribunal - Condonation of delay - S.5 of Limitation Act cannot be invoked in view of Proviso to S.125.

Section 5 of the Limitation Act cannot be invoked by this Court for entertaining an appeal filed against the decision or order of the Tribunal beyond the period of 120 days specified in Section 125 of the Electricity Act and its proviso. Any interpretation of Section 125 of the Electricity Act which may attract applicability of Section 5 of the Limitation Act read with Section 29(2) thereof will defeat the object of the legislation, namely, to provide special limitation for filing an appeal against the decision or order of the Tribunal and proviso to Section 125 will become nugatory.  (1995)5 SCC 5 - Distinguished.   [Para 16]

heading: Suit for possession on basis of title
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession on basis of title - Question whether amendment to raise claim as reversioner would relate back to date of institution of suit - Title to suit property acquired by virtue of will and plea of reversion not inconsistent with plea of will at all - More over by amendment neither claim of plaintiff as owner is changed nor it has caused any prejudice to defendant - Defendant not claiming title by adverse possession - Since suit even after amendment would remain suit for possession - Amendment to raise claim as reversioner - Would relate back to date of institution of suit.	(Para 6)

heading: Delay in filing claim petition
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing claim petition - Due to earlier petition filed before Accident Claim Tribunal (MACT) - Benefit of exclusion of time u/S.14 of Limitation Act cannot be given - Said benefit available only in cases where earlier remedy pursued before a wrong forum - Case covered by S.10 of WC Act and not by S.14 of Limitation Act. 	(Para 31)

heading: Condonation of delay in filing appeal
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay in filing appeal - S.5 of Limitation Act is applicable - Held, sufficient cause for condonation of delay existed and appeal was required to be heard on merits. (Paras 17, 20)

heading: Filing of suit
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.7 R.11 - Filing of suit - Limitation - Order dismissing appeal u/S.14(3) of Goa Land Revenue Code passed on 12.5.2011 in open Court - Both parties or their representatives present when said order was passed - There was corrigendum to said order on 20.5.2011 for correction of typographical errors - Certified copy issued on 23.5.2011 - Suit against said order filed on 23-5-2012 - Held, barred by limitation being filed beyond one year as prescribed u/S.14(5) - Provision as to exclusion of time required for obtaining certified copy, not attracted - Rejection of plaint, being barred by limitation, was proper. (Paras 19, 21)

heading: Revision application u/S.201B
HeadNote.description: Revision application u/S.201B - Whether, S.5 of Limitation Act would apply - For condoning delay of 29 days in filing revision - No provision in entire Act of 1994 for condonation of delay - Scheme of Act of 1994 as whole and S.201-B do not show that provisions of Limitation Act are either expressly or implicitly excluded - Use of word "shall" in S.201-B is not sufficient to hold that it excludes provisions as to condonation of delay - Reading of provisions for condonation of delay in filing revision u/S.201-B would not defeat object of deciding revision application expeditiously as is required u/S.201-B(4) - On taking recourse to S.29(2) of Limitation Act, provisions of S.5 of Limitation Act will be applicable to revision application. 2002(4) ALL MR 605 (S.C.), 2007(5) ALL MR 436 (S.C.), (2004) 4 SCC 252, (1997) 1 SCC 373 Disting. (Paras 9, 10, 19, 22, 24, 25)

heading: Not acceptable
HeadNote.description:
Civil suit against order under Art.14(3) - Limitation of one year - Impugned order passed on 24.10.2002 and civil suit filed on 24.10.2003 - Section 12(1) of Limitation Act will come into play i.e. date on which order was passed, would be excluded for computing limitation - Civil suit filed within limitation - Contention that Land Revenue Code is a complete Code in itself and provisions of Limitation Act shall not apply - Not acceptable - No provision in Land Revenue Code excludes applicability of Limitation Act. 
AIR 1961 SC 1500, (2009) 5 SCC 791, AIR 1989 SC 1477 Ref. to. 	(Para 9)

heading: Condonation of delay
Appeal
Exparte decree
Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Appeal - Suit in respect of land acquired under provisions of MIDC Act - Exparte decree - Appeal against - Delay of four years and one month in filing the appeal - Held, ends of justice will be met if the appellants are called upon to pay the cost to the original plaintiffs quantified at the sum of Rs.15,000/-. (1998)7 SCC 123 and 2002(2) ALL MR 588 (S.C.) - Referred to.	(Paras 3, 4, 5)

heading: Appeal
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Condonation of delay - From order of Tribunal till filing of appeal, there is gap of 262 days - On what basis appellant calculated delay of 107 days, not explained - Carelessness of appellant is evident from pleadings wherein date of obtaining certified copies mentioned as December 2013 whereas order of Tribunal passed only in May 2015 - Cause for delay stated to be departmental formalities - It only reflects lackadaisical attitude of appellant - Condonation not allowed. 2013 ALL SCR 3236 Ref.to.			(Paras 9, 10, 12)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Appeal against order of supersession before School Tribunal - Limitation - Condonation of delay of 9 years and 11 months - Though no limitation is provided, petition must be filed within reasonable time - Delay of 9 years and 11 months without submitting any cogent reason cannot be condoned.	(Para 7)

heading: Recovery of possession
HeadNote.description: Recovery of possession - Applicability of Limitation Act - C.P. and Berar Rent Control Order not prescribing any limitation for issuing quit notice after permission was granted - General law under Limitation Act, held, would not apply. 1973 Mh.L.J. 72 and 1992 Mh.L.J. 1620 - Ref. to.		(Para 10)

heading: Right of Muslim woman under S.3
HeadNote.description:
Right of Muslim woman under S.3 - Applicability of Limitation Act - Right of future maintenance to a wife who has not re-married and is not able to maintain herself and is otherwise not disentitled for claiming maintenance - Right, held, is a right in continuity and recurrence - Bar of limitation has no application to the right of a Muslim woman filing an application under S.3(1) of the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Divorce) Act (1986). Criminal P.C. (1973), S.125.

Right of future maintenance to a wife who has not re-married and is not able to maintain herself and is otherwise not dis-entitled for claiming maintenance, or to have a fair provision is a right in continuity and recurrence.

In absence of any express provision of law to the contrary, the nature of this right is such that it does not extinguish.

If the law intends not to prescribe limitation, it means so, and this omission will have to be respected as conscious omission and there are no grounds coming forward permitting to fill in the alleged omission taking shelter of Article 137 of the Limitation Act.

In these premises, held that the Law of Limitation has no application to the right of a Muslim woman filing an application under Section 3(1)(a) of the Muslim Women (Protection of Rights on Divorce) Act, 1986, it being a right of recurring nature, and bar of limitation is not laid down.						 [Para 22,23,26,27]

heading: Scope and applicability of S.280
HeadNote.description: Scope and applicability of S.280 - Held, S.280 is not a Code in itself and therefore S.280 does not exclude or supersede the provisions of Limitation Act. AIR 1974 SC 480 and AIR 1975 SC 763 - Referred to.	(Para 14)

heading: Appeal
Delay in filing
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Delay in filing - Condonation of - Appeal filed against order rejecting to enroll as member of society - Delay of 614 days in filing appeal - No period prescribed for filing appeal - When period of limitation has not been prescribed then what is reasonable or not depends on facts and circumstances of each case and is discretionary order - It cannot be interfered with unless there is any arbitrariness or malafides or perversity - Order condoning delay in filing appeal, proper. 	(Para 9)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Application before School Tribunal by a peon whose services were terminated - Delay was condoned and oral termination of services was set aside and he was directed to be reinstated - School management reinstated him but he was not being paid salary - He was also told not to complain because application of school for grant in aid was under consideration - As such there was delay of 18 months in starting second round of litigation - Held applicant who was constantly pursuing respondent to allow him to resume duties cannot be said to have deliberately delayed filing appeal - Delay deserves to the condoned. 	(Para 20)

heading: ULP complaint
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: ULP complaint - Condonation of delay - Delay of more than 5 years caused in filing complaint against order passed in departmental proceedings - Pendency of criminal case based on same incident and awaiting of decision were stated to be reason for causing delay - Standard of proof in both criminal and departmental proceedings are different as no strict proof of case required in departmental enquiry as is required in criminal case - Therefore, pendency of criminal case and consequent acquittal cannot be good and sufficient cause - Delay cannot be condoned. 2012 ALL SCR 460, (1992) 4 SCC 711, 2004(5) ALL MR 1115 (S.C.), (2005) 7 SCC 764 Ref. to. 	(Paras 11, 15, 19, 21, 22)

heading: Disqualification
HeadNote.description: Disqualification - Failure to submit accounts of election expenses within 30 days - Out of 2996 candidates, 2096 candidates disqualified for period of 5 years - Minor delay of 2 days and 16 days in filing accounts of expenses by petitioners - First petitioner explained that though they had submitted accounts to Mamidwar within time, it was received by concerned authority on 33rd day from election result - Second petitioner stated that she being illiterate person, had no knowledge about introducing limitation of 30 days u/S.14B - After getting knowledge from Talathi, she had submitted accounts of expenses on 46th day - Disqualification on such ground can't be compared with grounds of disqualification like having more than two children, not having toilet, encroachment on Govt. land etc - Therefore, explanation offered for delay has to be tested with reference to length of delay - Such minor delay would not be inordinate so as to disqualify petitioners - Refusing to condone minor delay would not only result in ousting these petitioners from their elected positions, but also disqualified them for five years - Hence, impugned order quashed. 2013 ALL SCR 3236 Ref. to. 			(Paras 17, 18, 19, 23, 24, 28, 31, 34)

heading: Appeal
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Delay of 2523 days in filing - Condonation of - Applicant was diligently pursuing remedy of review for correction of inadvertent delay crept in common judgment and award - Serious question of quantification of contributory negligence is involved in main appeals - Tribunal also did not address said issue and dismissed review - Therefore, delay condoned, though conditionally. 			(Paras 3, 7, 8)

heading: Appeal to Commissioner
Dismissal
HeadNote.description: Appeal to Commissioner - Dismissal - On ground of delay in filing appeal and as there is no specific provision u/S.16 of Village Panchayats Act for condonation of delay - Held, though there is no specific provision for condonation of delay, Commissioner has power to condone delay in filing appeal - Order dismissing appeal liable to be set aside. 2018(2) ALL MR 703 Rel. on. 	(Para 7)

heading: Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Application u/S.5(3) M.P.I.D. Act - Applicability of Limitation Act - Designated Court condoned delay of 25 days for filing application u/S.5(3) M.P.I.D. Act - Submission raised that M.P.I.D. Act, being special Statute having overriding effect, Limitation Act would not be applicable - Not acceptable - No provision at all in M.P.I.D. Act, empowering Designated Court to condone delay and therefore, no question of prevailing provisions of M.P.I.D. Act on count of being inconsistent - In absence of any bar express or by necessary implication in M.P.I.D. Act, S.5 of Limitation Act would be applicable for filing application u/S.5(3), M.P.I.D. Act. 2007(3) Mh.L.J. 241 Ref. to. (Paras 18, 19, 26)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Appeal u/S.9 of MEPS Act - Condonation of delay - Delay of 57 months in challenging dismissal order before School Tribunal - Though in first petition filed within two months of dismissal order, appellant made statement that he would challenge his dismissal from service, no challenge was put forth - Even in second writ petition, appellant had stated that he was dismissed from service, yet he pursued several other remedies pertaining to infighting in management of Education society - Thus, appellant knowingly and consciously did not challenge dismissal order - Stand of appellant that he would not waive any monetary benefit and does not desire salary paid to him for such period to be adjusted against legal dues if he succeeds in appeal - He himself disentitled for any relief due to such adamant stand - Order refusing to condone delay, proper. 1987 ALLMR ONLINE 164 (S.C.), 2013 ALL SCR 3236 Ref. to. (Paras 22, 23, 24, 25, 29)

heading: Revision
Filing of
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Revision - Filing of - Condonation of delay - Respondent failed to repay loan amount - Auction sale of mortgaged property - Sale deed executed in favour of auction purchaser - Mutation also effected in his name - Auction sale notice published in newspaper widely circulated in region - Therefore, plea by respondent that he had no knowledge of auction sale, was disbelieved - Respondent failed to give “sufficient cause” which prevented him to approach the authority within limitation - Respondent not found to have approached authority bonafidely - Thus condonation of delay, in filing revision by respondent before Authority, by taking liberal view, without any justifiable grounds, illegal. 	(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Limitation period
Contention not tenable
HeadNote.description: Suit for renewal of lease - Limitation period - Whether general law i.e. Art.58 of Limitation Act or special law i.e. S.120 of MPT Act would apply - Contention that execution of lease is not a part of administration, management or control of Ports for which MPT Act is enacted, therefore limitation under general law would apply - Contention not tenable - Leased properties would generate income - It is a "matter connected with" administration of Port - Hence, limitation period u/s.120 would apply. (Paras 28, 29, 32)

heading: Suit for eviction
Determination
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Whether, barred by limitation - Determination - Submission of defendants that cause of action i.e. non user of premises, arose more than 12 years prior to date of suit - However, no certainty as to on which particular date defendant stopped using premises and on which particular date landlord came to know about such non user - No specific case as required by Limitation Act - It cannot be inferred that suit was filed after period prescribed by Art.66 of Limitation Act - Suit, not barred by limitation. 2010 ALL MR (Supp.) 869, (2008) 12 SCC 577 Disting.	(Para 17)

heading: Suit for Possession
Limitation
Date of commencement
Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for Possession - Limitation - Date of commencement - Bank in possession under Collector's certificate - Possession transferred to Transferee under auction sale - Suit for possession - Limitation  commences from date of transferee's possession - Art.64 and not Art.65, is applicable. (Para 11)

heading: Appeal
Sufficient cause for
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Delay of 430 days in filing - Sufficient cause for - Delay neither explained nor any convincing grounds mentioned in condonation application - Simply by mentioning in one line that no guidance was there for filing of appeal - Is not sufficient ground to condone delay. 2012 (5) SCC 157, 2010(6) ALL MR 480 (S.C.), 2013(5) ALL MR 934 (S.C.), 2008 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 65 Ref.to.	(Para 15)

heading: Starting point of limitation
HeadNote.description: Starting point of limitation - There are two starting points of limitation under Art.54 - First, the time begins to run from the date on or by which the contract is required to be performed and secondly if no time is fixed, from the date of refusal - Unless there is specific denial the time would not run - The postponement does not and cannot amount to refusal at all - It at the most may amount to avoidance but not refusal. AIR 2001 A.P. 425 - Ref. to.	(Para 15)

heading: Limitation commencement of
HeadNote.description:
Suit for recovery of deficit in port trust charges - Limitation commencement of - Period of limitation would begin from date of sale of cargo and would be of three years as per Art.113 - Suit filed within three years from date of sale of cargo - Not barred by limitation.

In the present case, the Port Trust has an authority to sell the goods which are unclaimed for a period of two months after the agent of the vessel delivered the goods to the Port Trust. If these goods are not cleared by the purchaser/owner/consignee, the Port Trust can sell the goods and recover port trust charges. Sections 61 and 62 of the Major Port Trusts Act lay down the procedure for sale of the cargo. It is also laid down that in the event of the amount recovered from the sale of cargo is not sufficient to recover the port trust charges, in that event the Port Trust has a right to recover the said amount by filing a suit. It is evident, therefore, that as long as the goods are not actually sold the Trust would not be in a position to calculate the exact deficit which has to be recovered from the owner. It is possible that after selling the cargo, the entire amount may be recovered towards the port trust charges in which event there would be no necessity for the Port Trust to file a suit for recovery of any amount from the owner. However, it is found that even after the cargo, the sale proceeds of the cargo may not be sufficient for the purpose of making payment of the port trust charges. It is only at that time the Port Trust would be in a position to know the exact deficit which has to be recovered from the owner. The date on which, therefore, in this case, the Port Trust became aware of the deficit is the date of sale viz. 08/12/1986. In the present case, suit is filed on 07/12/1989 i.e within three years from the date of sale of the cargo which took place on 8/12/1986 is thus not barred. AIR 1979 Bombay 12 - Rel. on.  [Para 23,24,25]

heading: Suit for mandatory relief directing promoter to convey title to suit property to society and for declaration that promoter is not entitled to carry on further construction on the property
HeadNote.description: Suit for mandatory relief directing promoter to convey title to suit property to society and for declaration that promoter is not entitled to carry on further construction on the property - Scheme for ownership flats started in 1985 and completed in 1989 - Society registered in 1993 - Promoter not taking steps to convey title to society within four months - Suit filed in 1997 - Suit is not time barred because breach of statutory obligation gives continuing cause of action to Society against the promoter - Further there was absolutely no reason for the trial Judge to have granted three years time to promoter for conveying title and for executing necessary documents in favour of society.	(Paras 47, 49)

heading: Election petition
HeadNote.description: Election petition - Scope and applicability of S.5 of Limitation Act - Provisions of S.5 do not apply to election petition filed under S.33 of Mumbai Municipal Corporation Act - By necessary implication the applicability of S.5 has been excluded qua the election petitions under the Mumbai Municipal Corporation Act.	(Para 12)

heading: Revision against order u/s.101
HeadNote.description: Revision against order u/s.101 - Application for condonation of delay - Rejected by Revisional Authority - Reasonable opportunity not given to Respondent/member before issuing Recovery certificate - Petitioner already depositing 50% of recoverable dues - Application for condonation of delay granted, as delay was not deliberate.  (Paras 5, 6)

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Relationship of landlord and tenant not established - Title of the plaintiff based on sale deed or title of defendant by way of assertion of long possession need not be looked into - Plaintiff is entitled to file fresh suit for title and recovery of possession and such other reliefs as law permits - By institution of suit for eviction time for acquiring title by adverse possession stands arrested till proceedings arising out of suit are terminated. 		 	(Paras 22, 23, 24, 34)

heading: Declaration of ownership
Suit for
Limitation period

heading: Revision against order of maintenance under S.125
HeadNote.description:
Revision against order of maintenance under S.125 - Delay in filing revision - S.5 Limitation Act applies - Delay can be condoned for sufficient reason.

Section 397 vests with the High Court or any Sessions Judge, power of revision and for which the said court may call for records to exercise the powers of revision.  None of the provisions relating to the exercise of powers of revision i.e. from Section 405 specifically provide for any period of limitation within which such an application is required to be made.  In so far as the Sessions Judge's powers of revision are concerned, the same are provided under section 399 of the code, which are coextensive with those of High Court, and it does not provide for any period of limitation, and therefore one should have no doubt in his mind that the prescribed period of limitation for filing a Criminal Revision Application will be governed by Article 131 of the Limitation Act, and Section 5 of the said Act will enable the court to admit the application after the expiry of period of limitation on sufficient cause being shown for condonation of delay.  As the bar of limitation provided under section 3 of the Limitation Act is to be exercised subject to the provisions contained in sections 4 to 24 (inclusive) and therefore the contrary view taken by the Sessions Judge is without application of mind and contrary to law. [Para 7]

In the application, the revisionist stated that upon receipt of the certified copy, the applicant has handed over the certified copy to the clerk of the counsel, under an impression that it will be handed over to the counsel representing him for preferring the revision.  But the said clerk did not do so, which resulted in non filing of the revision.  The applicant did make queries with the counsel, but he was informed that the certified copy was not traceable and it is only when the certified copy is traced out he filed a revision application which was after delay of 19 days.  In the circumstances it could not be said that the delay was due to negligence or inaction on the part of the applicant, and therefore, the High Court is inclined to condone the delay on imposing certain conditions.			 [Para 18]

heading: Limitation for filing

(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Period of limitation
HeadNote.description:
Appeal against acquittal by victim - Period of limitation - Held, in a police case, limitation for filing appeal would be 90 days - Whereas in a complaint case, limitation period would be 60 days from grant of leave by Court.

	The right to appeal conferred upon the victim by adding proviso to the substantive provision of Section 372 of CrPC, clearly provides that no appeal shall lie from any judgment and order to a Court except as provided for by the CrPC. The right of the victim, therefore, is subject to the limitation and leave of the Court provided under Section 378 against acquittal.	 [Para 25]

	Section 378, does not use the word 'victim'. Sub-sections (4) and (5) thereof, deal with a right of appeal against the order of acquittal on behalf of the complainant and, that too, on an application made to the High Court seeking special leave to appeal and once the leave is granted, the complainant can present the appeal to the High Court. The application seeking leave, as provided for under sub-section (5), insofar as the complainant as defined under Section 2(d), has to be filed within a period of 60 days from the date of the order of acquittal. Sub-sections (1), (2) and (3) of Section 378, speak only about the right of the State Government or the Central Government to file an appeal against the order of acquittal, with the leave of the High Court. Thus, it is clear that Section 378, though directly does not confer any right on the victim, the Supreme Court in Satya Pal Singh [2015 ALL SCR 3523], held, in view of the peculiar language employed in Section 372, that even if the victim, when files appeal against the order of acquittal in State prosecution case, requires to make an application to seek the leave of the High Court to file an appeal. Similarly, since it is not in dispute that the State can file an appeal with the leave of the High Court against the order of acquittal within a period of 90 days, the same limitation would apply in case of appeal by the victim arising from State prosecution, obviously taking recourse to Article 114 of the Limitation Act.

	Thus, from the scheme of the provisions of Section 378, it is clear that two streams of appeals against acquittals are provided. The first stream of appeals is against the order of acquittals to be preferred by the State Government/Central Government and the same would be under sub-sections (1) and (2) of Section 378 and before such an appeal is entertained, a leave of the High Court requires to be taken, as provided for under sub-section (3) of Section 378. The other stream of appeals is against the order acquittals in the complaint case, wherein, by virtue of Section 378 (4), the complainant has to seek special leave to appeal from the High Court under sub-section (5). Further, the application for grant of special leave to appeal must be filed if the complainant is a public servant within 6 months from the date of order of acquittal and in all other cases, within 60 days from the date of order of acquittal. For the first stream of appeals under sub-sections (1) and (2) read with sub-section (3) of Section 378, no limitation is provided under Section 378 or any other Section of CrPC and, hence, the period of limitation for filing the appeal under Section 378(1) and (2) of CrPC is 90 days from the date of the order appealed from, as provided for in Article 114(a) of the Limitation Act. Though it is with reference to Section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, that equally applies to Section 378 (1) and (2), as has been held by the Supreme Court in Dharam Pal Singh's case [AIR 2001 SC 2924]. In that case, the Supreme Court observed that appeals by the State Government or the Central Government continue to be governed by Article 114 (a) of the Limitation Act. In other words, those appeals must be filed within 90 days from the date of the order appealed from. It is needless to state that if there is a delay in filing an appeal by the State Government or the Central Government, it would be open to them to file an application under Section 5 of the Limitation Act for condonation of such delay. Thus, that period can be extended if the Court is satisfied that there was sufficient cause for not preferring the appeal within a period of 90 days. In this backdrop, when we have a close look at the provisions contained in Section 372, it leaves no manner of doubt that the limitation as provided for the State Government/Central Government appeals under Section 114(a) of the Limitation Act would apply for filing of an appeal by the victim. In any case, the limitation provided under sub-section (5) of Section 378 has no application when the appeal is filed by the victim being his substantive right after the proviso came to be added to Section 372 by Act 5 of 2009 with effect from 31.12.2009. Sub-section (4) and sub-section (5) do not deal with the right of the victim in a State prosecution.

	Therefore, the limitation for preferring an appeal against the order of acquittal by the victim would be 90 days in all cases, other than the cases instituted upon complaint, and 60 days for any case instituted upon complaint against the order of acquittal after the High Court grants special leave to appeal. 2014 CrLJ 1046 Held Not Good Law in view of 2015 ALL SCR 3523. 2002 ALL MR (Cri) 185 (S.C.), 2010 ALL SCR 1085, 2015 ALL SCR 3523 Rel. on.  [Para 21,22,26]

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description:
Suit for possession - Suit filed by landlord against Petitioner No.1 who acquired suitable residential premises and started residing therein from the year 1970-71 - Suit filed under S.13(1)(l) governed by Art.66 of Limitation Act - Suit filed on 29th April, 1987, held, was clearly barred by Limitation.

In the case at hand, the respondent no.1 in the plaint had stated that the petitioner no.1 had acquired the alternate premises and started residing therein from 1970-71. Section 13(1)(l) of the Bombay Rent Act provides that a landlord shall be entitled to recover possession of any premises if the Court is satisfied that a tenant after coming into operation of the Bombay Rent Act, has built acquired vacant possession of or being allotted a suitable residence. Under section 13(1)(l) of the Bombay Rent Act, a tenant forfeits his protection and the right to remain in possession of the tenanted premises if he acquires suitable residence. The forfeiture takes place on the date on which the tenant acquires suitable residential premises. Consequently, the period of limitation would be required to be counted from the date of forfeiture, i.e. the date of acquisition of the suitable residential premises. That would be the starting point for computing the period of limitation for filing of the suit for possession. As the petitioner forfeited his right to remain in possession of the suit premises in the year 1970-71 when he acquired the suitable residential premises, the suit filed on 29th April 1987 was clearly barred by limitation.  AIR 1979 SC 1745 and (1987)3 SCC 576 - Rel. on. 			 [Para 10]
