On the advice of the advocate the party in the instant case preferred are appeal before the High Court within a period of 90 days i.e. within the period of limitation prescribed for preferring appeal to the High Court and it was only on the return of the said Memo of Appeal by the High Court for filing the same in the Court of competent jurisdiction that same was filed before the lower appellate Court. These facts sufficiently disclose the bona fide on the part of the party in prosecuting the matter before a wrong forum. This finding has been arrived at on the basis of analysis of the materials placed before the lower appellate Court and being the finding of fact which unless is shown to be perverse or arbitrary, cannot be ignored. The finding is neither arbitrary nor perverse, nor can it be so, since the same has been arrived on the basis of the materials placed on record which are sufficient to arrive at such finding.  There was no jurisdictional error on the part of the lower appellate Court in condoning the delay and no interference is called for in the discretionary order passed by the lower appellate Court, wherein the discretion has been judiciously exercised.  [Para 4,7]

heading: Condonation of delay
Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Suit seeking perpetual injunction decreed - Appeal against - Delay of 14 days in filing - Condonation cannot be refused on ground that period prior to those 14 days which falls within limitation has not been explained.(Para 5)

heading: Condonation of delay
Application for
Appeal
Rel on.
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Application for - Appeal - Ground pleaded that applicant was ill and unable to move for a long time and therefore could not contact her Advocate - Such ground found satisfactory - No deliberate inaction on part of Applicant found - Held, in circumstances, delay required to be condoned in interest of justice - Term "sufficient cause" in S.5 must receive liberal construction and so as to advance substantial justice - Generally delay in appeals required to be condoned in interest of justice where no negligence or deliberate inaction or lack of baonafides imputable to party seeking condonation.	(Para 11)

AIR 1998 SC 3222 - Rel on.

heading: Exclusion of time
Appointment of Receiver
HeadNote.description:
Exclusion of time - Appointment of Receiver - Suit filed by Receiver who has powers to institute the suit - Provisions of S.15 would not be attracted - Period during which Receiver was appointed, cannot be excluded.

Civil P.C. (1908), O.40, R.1.

In the instant case, it is not plaintiff who instituted the suit.  The suit was instituted by the Receiver after having been conferred such powers.  There was no bar on the Receiver in instituting the suits.  Once that be the case, section 15 would not be attracted.  In the instant case, present Plaintiff has now been substituted in place of the Receiver.  It is not a case where Plaintiff independently had filed the suit and contended that the period during which Receiver was appointed has to be excluded.  If that had been position, the matter would have been examined in a different context.  On the facts as now they stand, the suit having been instituted by the Receiver who had powers to institute the suit, provisions of Section 15 would not be attracted and time could not be excluded.				 [Para 4]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Land in scheduled area belonging to Scheduled tribe - Non-tribal cannot acquire right and title on the basis of adverse possession because transfer to non-tribal is prohibited.	(Paras 7, 9)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Plea of adverse possession by defendant - Suit filed by plaintiff within 12 years from date of knowledge - Defendant never adduced any evidence to prove that they ever asserted their right of ownership over specific portion of suit land as belonging to them openly and with assertion of hostility to knowledge of plaintiff - Plea of adverse possession not available to defendant against plaintiff - Suit liable to be allowed.	(Paras 21, 22, 23, 24, 25)

HeadNote.sub_clause: Art.137- Letters of Administration of a Will
heading: Overruled; AIR 1983 Bom. 268
HeadNote.description: Overruled; AIR 1983 Bom. 268 - Partly Overruled.   [Para 4,12,14,16]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of about 300 days in filing change report - Delay occurred as order by which two trustees were removed was challenged by said trustees and those proceedings were pending - Delay caused was not deliberate - Condonation of delay with cost of Rs.1,000/- proper. 	(Para 4)

heading: Redemption of mortgage
HeadNote.description:
Redemption of mortgage - Right of redemption starts from the date of mortgage, unless there is a restriction imposed in the mortgage deed - Any acknowledgment of existence of mortgage after the period of limitation does not revive limitation - Land mortgaged on 21-3-1893 for Rs. 53/- and possession delivered to mortgagee - Appellant purchased the said land in the year 1959 from the original mortgagor - On 11-1-1960 the mortgagee sold his mortgage rights under a registered deed to the respondents under which the mortgagee acknowledged the mortgage - The appellant filed a suit in 1980 for possession by way of redemption against the respondents - Held, the suit is barred by limitation.

Transfer of Property Act (1882), S.59 and 60.

Section 18, sub-section (1), itself starts with the words "Where, before the expiration of the prescribed period for a suit or application in respect of any property or right, an acknowledgment of liability in respect of such property or right has been made .......". Thus, the acknowledgment, if any, has to be prior to the expiration of the prescribed period for filing the suit, in other words, if the limitation has already expired, it would not revive under this Section. It is only during subsistence of a period of limitation, if any, such document is executed, the limitation would be revived fresh from the said date of acknowledgment. In the present case, admittedly, the oral mortgage deed is in March 1893. If the period of limitation for filing suit for redemption is 60 years then limitation for filing a suit would expire in the year 1953. Thus, by the execution of this document dated 11th January, 1960 it cannot be held by virtue of section 18 that the period of limitation is revived afresh from this date.

heading: Condoned
HeadNote.description:
Application for condonation of delay - Would apply in case of an application of setting aside ex parte decree u/O.9, Rule 13 of C.P.C. 1908 - Delay of six days in filing application under O.9, R.13 on the part of the petitioners - Sufficient cause for the same having been established - Condoned - Order rejecting application seeking condonation set aside. 1998(1) Mah.L.R. 722 held per incuriam and not good law in view of AIR 1980 Bom 250, (1996)5 SCC 529 and 1996(11) SCC 353.

Civil P.C. (1908), O.9, R.13.	(Paras 22, 23)

heading: Execution of decree
Limitation
Starting point
Doctrine of merger
HeadNote.description: Execution of decree - Limitation - Starting point - Doctrine of merger - When an appellate Court passes a decree, decree of the trial Court merges with decree of appellate Court and even if and subject to any modification that may be made in the appellate decree, decree of appellate Court supercedes decree of the trial Court - In other words merger of a decree takes places irrespective of fact whether appellate Court affirms, modifies or reverses the decree passed by trial Court - However, when an appeal is dismissed on the ground that delay in filing the same is not condoned, doctrine of merger shall not apply.(Paras 20 to 24)

heading: Period of limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for administration of property of deceased - Period of limitation - Suit for administration of both movable and immovable properties of deceased father of the parties - Suit required to be filed within 3 years from accrual of right to sue - Deceased expired on 29-06-1975 - Suit for administration of property of deceased filed on 21-11-1980 - Right to sue accrued on date of death of deceased - Held, suit is barred by law of limitation. 2007(6) BCR 180 & AIR 1979 Delhi 240 - Ref. to.	(Paras 17, 30)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Ex Parte decree passed by Debt Recovery Tribunal on 7.9.2001 for Rs.1.18 Crores - Demand notice issued on 28.2.2002 - Petitioner applying for certified copy on 10.4.2002 and it was ready on 9.5.2002 - Application for setting aside ex parte decree made on 13.5.2002 - Delay condoned and petitioner directed to deposit rupees fifty lakhs in a separate account without prejudice to its contentions. (Para 8,11)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Delay caused in government departments on account of technical difficulties in processing - Respondents acquiring vested right on account of inordinate delay on part of government - Delay cannot be condoned.

Though Government Machinery suffers from matter moving from one table to another, the delay is caused in government departments on account of technical difficulties in processing.  But there has to be reasonableness in it.  Like any other litigant, Government is also obliged to take necessary steps for the purpose of taking legal action.  The delay of some days can be considered and can be condoned.  Of course, there has to be justification for that.  In the present case, the respondents have acquired a vested right on account of the said inordinate delay on the part of the Government.  That cannot be toppled easily and without sufficient justification.  Thus, delay condonation application was dismissed.

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - In matters of land acquisition - Reference Court enhanced compensation ranging between Rs.520/- and Rs.7670/- to land-losers in 1997-98 - State filed appeals in 1999 and application for condonation of delay to set aside abatement and leave to bring LRs of deceased land-losers on record, almost after 2 years in 2001 - Matters are pending for last 20 years in Court from date of acquisition in 1974-75, due to lack of diligence of State in effecting service or in taking steps to bring on record LRs of land-losers - Only to deprive land-losers of meager compensation, State and Court have spent enormous amount of money and time - Applications for condonation of delay and consequently appeals themselves are liable to be dismissed.			(Paras 16, 17)

heading: Suit against trustees and their representatives
HeadNote.description: Suit against trustees and their representatives - Merely because same money has been deposited with bank an account of auction of goods, by Court it cannot be said that trust is created - Suit with regard to said money against bank filed beyond period of three years, would not be saved by applying S.10 of Limitation Act - No fiduciary relationship with bank was created to attract S.88 of Trusts Act - Limitation under Art.113 would not also apply as basis of the fact that statement of account was tendered by bank; as it would not amount to acknowledgement to save limitation which had long expired. 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 547 - Disting.			(Paras 6 to 11, 13, 15, 18, 20)

heading: Mixed question of law and fact
HeadNote.description:
Mixed question of law and fact - Whether settlement was for consideration to the trust as understood under S.10 - Issue pertains to fact and law and cannot be adjudicated as a preliminary issue. 
2006(6) ALL MR 56 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Para 19)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Liberal and justice oriented approach is required to be adopted - If, however, explanation offered is found to be concocted and if applicant is found to be thoroughly negligent in presenting its cause, delay cannot be condoned. 

Even though a liberal and justice oriented approach is required to be adopted in the exercise of power under Section 5 of the Limitation Act and other similar statutes, the Courts can neither become oblivious of the fact that the successful litigant has acquired certain rights on the basis of the judgment under challenge and a lot of time is consumed at various stages of litigation apart from the cost. What colour the expression 'sufficient cause' would get in the factual matrix of a given case would largely depend on bona fide nature of the explanation. If the Court finds that there has been no negligence on the part of the applicant and the cause shown for the delay does not lack bona fides, then it may condone the delay. If, on the other hand, the explanation given by the applicant is found to be concocted or he is thoroughly negligent in prosecuting his cause, then it would be a legitimate exercise of discretion not to condone the delay. In cases involving the State and its agencies/instrumentalities, the Court can take note of the fact that sufficient time is taken in the decision making process but no premium can be given for total lethargy or utter negligence on the part of the officers of the State and / or its agencies / instrumentalities and the applications filed by them for condonation of delay cannot be allowed as a matter of course by accepting the plea that dismissal of the matter on the ground of bar of limitation will cause injury to the public interest.   [Para 18]

In this case, unfortunately the learned Single Judge of the High Court altogether ignored the gapping holes in the story concocted by the Corporation about misplacement of the papers and total absence of any explanation as to why nobody even bothered to file applications for issue of certified copies of judgment for more than 7 years. The cause shown by the Corporation for delayed filing of the appeals was, to say the least, wholly unsatisfactory and the reasons assigned by the learned Single Judge for condoning more than 7 years delay cannot but be treated as poor apology for the exercise of discretion by the Court under Section 5 of the Limitation Act.  [Para 22]

heading: Adverse possession
Meaning of
Permissive possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Meaning of - Permissive possession - When can be converted into adverse possession.

Adverse possession means possession of the land or interest in the land by a wrong man against the will of the right man.  Adverse possession, as its words imply, must be actual possession of another's land with intention to hold it and claim it as of his own, to the exclusion of the rightful owner.  It must commence with the wrongful possession of the rightful owner at some particular time and must commence, in wrong against right.  It must be actual, open notorious and hostile under claim of right, continuous and exclusive and maintained for the statutory period.  Possession and adverse possession do not mean the same thing.  Mere user of the property cannot be taken as a definite assertion of the proprietary rights, there must be definite quality in the possession before it can be called adverse and some act of unequivocal character to put the owner on guard.  There cannot be adverse possession if the claimant himself does not know that he was occupying somebody's land. However, cannot be converted into adverse possession unless it is proved that the person in possession asserted as adverse title to the property, to the knowledge of the true owners for a period of 12 years or more.	  [Para 14]

In instant case the possession of the defendants was permissive. Their plea reveals that they did not claim that they have perfected their title to the suit house by virtue of adverse possession and what has been pleaded is that defendant No.1 acquired and completed his right of management over the property in the suit house which is private trust property by open, peaceful possession thereof for the last more than 30 years. In the circumstances it could not be said that the defendants became owner of the suit house by adverse possession.	 [Para 17]

heading: Setting aside award
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Setting aside award - Limitation - Limitation starts from date of service of notice of filing of award and not date of knowledge of filing of award.

(2008) 8 SCC 626 Rel. on. (Paras 6, 7)

heading: Suit for damages
For malicious prosecution
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for damages - For malicious prosecution - Limitation - Respondent had filed criminal case against applicant - Trial Court quashed FIR and charge-sheet on 5.11.2003 - SLP against, filed before Supreme Court, dismissed on 3.9.2004 - Suit for damages for malicious prosecution filed by applicant on 24.11.2004 i.e. beyond period of limitation starting from date 5.11.2003 - Contention that prosecution against applicant could not stand terminated during period when SLP was pending, but period of limitation started from 03.09.2004, when SLP was dismissed - Not acceptable, as it would amount to reading something more in Art.74 than what is plainly stated therein - Once plaintiff is acquitted or prosecution is otherwise terminated, period of limitation is triggered and time begins to run - Merely because order of acquittal or otherwise terminating prosecution has been made subject matter of challenge before Higher Court, it cannot be held in abeyance or suspended - Since period of limitation started to run from date 05.11.2003, suit was barred by limitation. AIR 1930 Allahabad 326, AIR (33) 1946 Nagpur 46, 1966 ALLMR ONLINE 242, 1989 ALLMR ONLINE 418, 2007(1) ALL MR 102 Ref. to. 	(Paras 16, 22, 23)

heading: Expression "right to apply"
HeadNote.description: Expression "right to apply" - Application for grant of probate or letters of administration - Is covered by Art.137. 1976(4) SCC 634, 2008 ALL SCR 1221 - Foll. AIR 1991 Mad 214 - Overruled.	(Paras 5, 7, 8)

heading: Condonation of delay
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Delay of six years in bringing legal heirs on record - Single Judge dismissed petition holding it to be abated - Validity - Appellants had no knowledge of the death of Respondent - Delay in taking out the application for inclusion of legal heirs - Delay to be computed from the date of knowledge of death of party - Court has ample powers to set aside the abatement and condone delay to bring legal heirs on record.

The delay in taking out the application has to be computed from the date of knowledge of the death of a party.  In the instant case, the appellants had no knowledge as to the death of the Respondent and as soon as they acquired knowledge, they took out application for bringing legal heirs on record.  Moreso, this aspect as regards knowledge is not seriously disputed by the respondent.

Moreover, the provisions of O.22, R.1, C.P.C. are not penal in nature.  It is a rule of procedure and substantial rights of the parties cannot be defeated by pedantic approach by observing strict adherence to the procedural aspect of law.

Hence, the Single Judge was in error in refusing to use discretion vested in him for condoning delay in taking out application for bringing legal heirs on record.  Even if proceeding abates, the Court has ample powers to set aside the abatement, and condone the delay to bring legal heirs on record.	 [Para 8]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Possession, howsoever, long cannot mature into adverse possession at all unless it is shown that the dispute with regard to possession and ownership had arisen and such a specific time of such dispute is pleaded and made out. 2007 ALL SCR 2816 & 2007 ALL SCR 1582 - Ref. to.		(Para 11)

heading: Appeal allowed
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay-Rustic illiterate agricultural labourers, no economic support, did not comprehend legal procedures and only few days before second appeal was filed came to know that they should challenge judgment dt. 21.3.2003 and had taken steps to file second appeal- Held, explanation satisfactory and sufficient to condone delay, High Court ought to have condoned delay - Appeal allowed - Order of the High Court dated 14.2.2006 rejected - Second appeal stands restored to be disposed of in accordance with law.	(Paras 3, 4, 5)

heading: Application for condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Application for condonation of delay - Order refusing to condone delay - Material relevant for deciding the issue not considered and irrelevant material looked into for refusing to condone the delay - Held, order suffers from non-application of mind- Order liable to be quashed and set aside. 1998(1) ALL MR 688 - Distinguished.	(Para 8)

heading: Land acquisition proceedings
Limitation
Reference
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition proceedings - Limitation - Reference - Limitation is mixed question of law and fact - For this purpose, evidence has to be furnished by both parties in support of their respective contentions. (2005)6 SCC 614 - Ref. to.	(Para 7)

heading: Application dismissed
HeadNote.description: Dismissal of application for condonation of delay for default - Filing of application for restoration of application for condonation of delay - Such application filed beyond limitation and without application for delay condonation - Application dismissed - Challenge in writ petition - Held, such application filed under O.9, R. 9 of C.P.C. either in the original court or appellate court having been covered under Art.122, the provisions of Art. 137 of Limitation Act will not be attracted.

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Possession under settlement deed only permissive - Plea of adverse possession not tenable - For claiming title by adverse possession, it was necessary for the plaintiff to plead and prove animus possidendi - Long possession by itself would not be sufficient to prove adverse possession. 2007 ALL SCR 1582 - Ref. to.	(Para 23)

heading: Applicability of S.14 to arbitration proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Applicability of S.14 to arbitration proceedings - By virtue of S.29(2) provisions of Limitation Act stand excluded to proceedings under Arbitration Act to the extent area is covered by Arbitration Act - No provision in Arbitration Act excludes operation of S.14 of Limitation Act - Hence applicability of S.14 cannot be excluded.

The prohibitory provision has to be construed strictly. It is true that the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 intended to expedite the commercial issue expeditiously. It is also clear from the statement of objects and reasons that in order to recognize economic reforms the settlement of both of domestic & international commercial disputes should be disposed of quickly so that country's economic progress be expedited. The statement of objects and reasons also nowhere indicate that Section 14 of the Limitation Act shall be excluded. But on the contrary intendment of legislature is apparent in the present case as Section 43 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996 applies the Limitation Act, 1963 as a whole. It is only by virtue of sub-section (2) of section 29 of the Limitation Act, its operation is excluded to that extent of the area which is covered under the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996. By virtue of sub-section (2) of section 29 of the Limitation Act that the provisions of Limitation Act shall stand excluded in Act of 1996 to the extent area which is covered by the Act of 1996. In the present case under section 34 by virtue of sub-section 3 only the application for filing and setting aside the award a period has been prescribed as 3 months and delay can be condoned to the extent of 30 days. To this extent the applicability of section 5 of Limitation will stand excluded but there is no provision in the Act of 1996 which excludes operation of section 14 of the Limitation Act. If two Acts can be read harmoniously without doing violation to the words used therein, then there is no prohibition in doing so. The view taken by the court below excluding the applicability of Section 14 in this proceeding is not correct. 		 [Para 27]

heading: Suit for malicious prosecution
HeadNote.description: Suit for malicious prosecution - Limitation begins to run from date of acquittal or discharge - It does not stop running - These is no scheme under Limitation Act for exclusion of any period from computation of limitation the time spent in defending any appeal or revision etc. against the order of acquittal or discharge.	(Paras 11 & 12)

heading: Execution proceedings
HeadNote.description: Execution proceedings - Proceedings stayed at the instance of a third person - Appellant unable to take any steps for setting aside sale by application under O.21, R.89 - Held, whether stay of execution proceedings was obtained by judgment debtor or by a third person was hardly relevant, appellant would be entitled to benefit of such period under Art.127 of Limitation Act.	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Delay
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Delay - Condonation of - Defendants seeking appointment of a Court Commissioner during course of recording of oral evidence - Order passed in favour of defendants for said appointment - Defendants not complying with said order within time stipulated - Extension of time ought not to be granted.	(Para 4)

heading: Dishonour of cheque
Condonation of delay
Application for
HeadNote.description: Criminal P.C. (1973), S.397 - Dishonour of cheque - Condonation of delay - Application for - A liberal approach is required to be adopted in dealing with cases u/s.5 of Limitation Act - Delay not occasioned due to negligence on part of applicant - Court should view it liberally and allow the application with costs.		(Paras 4 to 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Government filing LPA after a delay of 97 days - Reason for delay was that the file had to go through different departments of the State which required some time to take decision about filing of LPA - Delay condoned.	(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Ground based on alleged concession by Advocate at the Bar - Recording of such concession in Roznama of Court - Grievance about the recording made by appellant - Grievance ought to have been raised before Single Judge - This not being done, ground of limitation cannot be pressed in the appeal.

If a party thinks that the happenings in Court have been wrongly recorded in a judgment, it is incumbent upon a party, while the matter is still fresh in the minds of the Judges, to call the attention of the very Judges who made the record.  That is the only way to have the record corrected.  If no such step is taken, the matter must necessarily end there.  It is not open for the party to contend before the superior Court to the contrary.  If the appellant was having any grievance about the recording of concession made by the appellant in the judgment, he ought to have approached the learned Single Judge.  This not having been done the ground of limitation cannot be pressed in the appeal. 2003(3) ALL MR 1120 (S.C.) - Followed.  [Para 6,7]

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Power of Reference court - Claim of appellant that there was no delay in making application under S.18 of the Act accepted by Division Bench of High Court - Finding in earlier proceedings between the same parties in relation to the same award will be binding on the respondents - It was therefore, not open to Reference Court to hold to the contrary. 1996 Mh.L.J. 609 - Referred to.	(Para 8)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - If defendant is not sure who is true owner, question of there being in hostile possession and denying title of true owner does not arise.

It is well recognized proposition in law that mere possession however long does not necessarily means that it is adverse to the true owner. Adverse possession really means the hostile possession which is expressly or impliedly in denial of title of the true owner and in order to constitute adverse possession the possession proved must be adequate in continuity, in publicity and in extent so as to show that it is adverse to the true owner. The classical requirements of acquisition of title by adverse possession are that such possession in denial of the true owner's title must be peaceful, open and continuous. The possession must be open and hostile enough to be capable of being known by the parties interested in the property, though it is not necessary that there should be evidence of the adverse possessor actually informing the real owner of the former's hostile action.   [Para 22]

In this case the High Court has erred in holding that even if the defendants claim adverse possession, they do not have to prove who is the true owner and even if they had believed that the Government was the owner and not the plaintiffs, the same was inconsequential. Obviously, the requirements of proving adverse possession have not been established. If the defendants are not sure who is the true owner the question of their being in hostile possession and the question of denying title of the true owner do not arise. Above being the position the High Court's judgment was clearly unsustainable.   [Para 23]

heading: Leave to appeal
intentional or otherwise
HeadNote.description:
Leave to appeal - 57 days delay in filing application for grant of leave to appeal against acquittal of accused by condoning delay - In view of slow motion of wheels in working of the Government delay condoned and leave to appeal granted.

It is axiomatic that decisions are taken by officers/agencies proverbially at slow pace and encumbered process of pushing the files from table to table and keeping it on table for considerable time causing delay - intentional or otherwise - is a routine. Considerable delay of procedural red-tape in the process of their making decision is a common feature. Therefore, certain amount of latitude is not impermissible. If the appeals brought by the State are lost for such default no person is individually affected but what in the ultimate analysis suffers, is public interest. The expression "sufficient cause" should, therefore, be considered with pragmatism in justice-oriented approach rather than the technical detection of sufficient cause for explaining every day's delay. The factors which are peculiar to and characteristic of the functioning of the governmental conditions would be cognizant to and requires adoption of pragmatic approach in justice-oriented process. The court should decide the matters on merits unless the case is hopelessly without merit. No separate standards to determine the cause laid by the State vis-a-vis private litigant could be laid to prove strict standards of sufficient cause. The Government at appropriate level should constitute legal cells to examine the cases whether any legal principles are involved for decision by the courts or whether cases require adjustment and should authorise the officers to take a decision or give appropriate permission for settlement. In the event of decision to file appeal needed prompt action should be pursued by the officer responsible to file the appeal and he should be made personally responsible for lapses, if any. Equally, the State cannot be put on the same footing as an individual. The individual would always be quick in taking the decision whether he would pursue the remedy by way of an appeal or application since he is a person legally injured while State is an impersonal machinery working through its officers or servants. When the factual background is considered in the light of legal principles as noted above the inevitable conclusion is that the delay of 57 days deserved condonation. Therefore, the order of the High Court refusing to condone the delay is set aside. 1996(3) SCC 132 and 1996(10) SCC 634 Ref.	 [Para 17,19]

heading: Scope and applicability of
HeadNote.description: Scope and applicability of - Suit to enforce payment of money secured by a charge upon immovable property - Suit is covered by Art.62 of Limitation Act, if the recovery is sought against the charged properties - Prescribed period of limitation would be twelve years. AIR 1962 SC 633 - Referred to.	(Para 13)

heading: Limitation
Adverse Possession
Plea of
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Adverse Possession - Plea of - Burden of proof - Pleading as to ouster - Onus to prove adverse possession would be on one who raises such a plea - Plaintiff did not specifically plead ouster - Moffusil pleadings must be construed liberally - Non use of terminology, ipso facto, would not mean that ingredients for satisfying requirements of statute are absent.

The factual aspects are neither denied nor disputed. Admittedly, the plaintiff respondent had remained in possession for a long time i.e. since 1953.  It may be true that in his plaint, plaintiff did not specifically plead ouster but moffusil pleadings, as is well known, must be construed liberally.  Pleadings must be construed as a whole. Only because the parties did not use the terminology which they should have, ipso facto, would not mean that the ingredients for satisfying the requirements of statute are absent.  There cannot be any doubt whatsoever that having regard to the changes brought about by Articles 64 and 65 of the Limitation Act, 1963 vis-a-vis Articles 142 and 144 of the Limitation Act, 1908, the onus to prove adverse possession would be on the person who raises such a plea. It is also furthermore not in dispute that the possession of a co-sharer is presumed to be possession of the other co-sharers unless contrary is proved. A plea of adverse possession or a plea of ouster would indisputably be governed by Articles 64 and 65 of the Limitation Act.  Mere assertion of title by itself may not be sufficient unless plaintiff proves animus possidendi.  The plaintiff's intention to possess properties in suit exclusively and not for and on behalf of other co-owners is evident from the fact that defendants appellants themselves had earlier filed two suits. Such suits were filed for partition.  In those suits defendants-appellants claimed themselves to be co-owners of the plaintiff.  A bare perusal of judgments of the courts below clearly demonstrates that plaintiff had even therein asserted hostile title claiming ownership in himself.  The claim of hostile title by plaintiff over suit land, therefore, was, thus, known to appellants.  Express denial of title was made by plaintiff-respondent in the said suit in his written statements. The plaintiff made his hostile declaration claiming title for property at least in his written statement in the suit filed in 1968.  Thus, at least from 1968 onwards, plaintiff continued to exclusively possess suit land with knowledge of defendants-appellants. The parties went to trial fully knowing their respective cases, fact that they had been co-owners was not an issue.  The parties proceeded to adduce evidences in support of their respective cases. Article 65 of Limitation Act, 1963, therefore, would in a case of this nature have its role to play, if not from 1953, but at least from 1968.  If that be so, finding of High Court that respondent perfected his title by adverse possession and ouster cannot be said to be vitiated in law. In this case, however, a finding of fact has been arrived at by all the three courts. They have analysed the evidences on record.  They have taken into consideration the correct legal position operating in the field as also conduct of the parties.  They applied correct principles of law as regards 'burden of proof'.  There is no infirmity in the impugned judgment.	 [Para 18,19,21,22,23,24,25,26,27,28,32,33,34]

heading: Limitation for suit
HeadNote.description: Limitation for suit - Sale and purchase of goods - Suit to recover balance amount - Period of limitation will commence from the date of the transaction lastly entered into between the parties.	(Paras 3, 5)

heading: Adverse possession
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Burden of proof - Once plaintiff proves his title, burden shifts on defendant to establish that he has perfected his title by adverse possession.

The change in the position in law as regards the burden of proof as was obtaining in the Limitation Act, 1908 vis-a-vis Limitation Act, 1963 is evident.  Whereas in terms of Articles 142 and 144 of the old Limitation Act, the plaintiff was bound to prove his title as also possession within twelve years preceding the date of institution of the suit under the Limitation Act, 1963, once the plaintiff proves his title, the burden shifts to the defendant to establish that he has perfected his title by adverse possession.  (2005)8 SCC 330 and 2007(2) ALL MR 866 (S.C.) - Followed.						     [Para 6]

heading: Delay
Condonation of
Order condoning delay
HeadNote.description: Delay - Condonation of - Challenged on ground that delay has not been explained day to day by Respondent Govt. Dept. - Fact that parties left it to Court to decide matter by oral submissions - Court was not assisted by proof of facts which would have resulted in attributing particular date of knowledge in contract with date of knowledge pleaded by respondent (applicant) - Order condoning delay - No interference.	(Paras 9, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Appeals
HeadNote.description:
Scope and applicability of S.5 of Limitation Act - Appeals - Tribunal whose function is quasi judicial in nature need not necessarily be a Court - The Forum which functions as a Court shall have the trappings of the Court - Commissioner of Central Excise (Appeals) empowered to hear appeals u/s.35 of Central Excise and Salt Act - Cannot be treated as forum functioning as a Court nor the said Authority can be said to have trappings of the Court - S.5 of Limitation Act would not be applicable to such appeals.

The Tribunal whose function is quasi judicial in nature need not necessarily be a Court.  The forum which functions as a Court shall have the trappings of the Court.

For appreciating as to whether the provisions of section 5 of the Indian Limitation Act apply to the proceedings before the Court, the scheme of the enactment will have to be looked into minutely.  If it is found that the provisions of the Limitation Act are specifically excluded from its application to the proceedings of the Court then it would not be permissible to apply the provisions of the Limitation Act.

The relevant provisions for the purpose of the present petition demonstrate that the limitation for filing appeals was provided under section 35 of the Central Excise and Salt Act, 1994.  The provisions of section 35 provides that any person being aggrieved by any decision or order passed by the Central Excise Officer may within three months from the date of such decision may appeal to the appellate authority.

The Commissioner of Central Excise (Appeals) empowered to hear appeals under section 35 of the Central Excise and Salt Act, cannot be treated as forum functioning as a Court nor the said authority can be said to have trappings of the Court.  Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act is not attracted to the appeals preferred under section 35 of the Act and, consequently, section 5 of the Limitation Act would not be applicable to such appeals.  2005(1) Bom.C.R. 58 - Rel. on. [Para 3,4,6,7]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Adverse possession or ouster is an inference to be drawn from facts proved - It is a mixed question of law or fact.

Section 27 of the Limitation Act, 1963 operates to extinguish the right to property of a person who does not sue for its possession within the time allowed by law. The right extinguished is the right which the lawful owner has and against whom a claim for adverse possession is made, therefore, the plaintiff who makes a claim for adverse possession has to plead and prove the date on and from which he claims to be in exclusive, continuous and undisturbed possession. The question whether possession is adverse or not is often one of simple fact but it may also be a conclusion of law or a mixed question of law and fact. The facts found must be accepted, but the conclusion drawn from them, namely, ouster or adverse possession is a question of law and has to be considered by the Court.   [Para 12]

In the matter of adverse possession, the Court have to find out the plea taken by the plaintiff in the plaint. In the plaint, the plaintiff who claims to be owner by adverse possession has to plead actual possession. He has to plead the period and the date from which he claims to be in possession. The plaintiff has to plead and prove that his possession was continuous, exclusive and undisturbed to the knowledge of the real owner of the land. He has to show a hostile title. He has to communicate his hostility to the real owner. None or these aspects have been considered by the High Court in its impugned judgments stated above, the impugned judgment is under section 96, Civil Procedure Code, it is not a judgment under section 100, Civil Procedure Code. As stated above, adverse possession or ouster is an inference to be drawn from the facts proved  (and) that work is of the first Appellate Court.		   [Para 13]

heading: Recovery of Port Trust Charges
HeadNote.description: Recovery of Port Trust Charges - Right of Port Trust - Confiscation of cargo by Customs Authorities detained for Import Trade Control formalities upon its non-clearance by importer - Right to sue would accrue to Port Trust upon order of confiscation when exact liability of importer for the payment of confiscation charges is ascertained and crystallised.	(Para 16)

heading: Delay
HeadNote.description: Restoration of execution application - Delay - Restoration application can be filed within thirty days - S.5 of Limitation Act not applicable to execution proceedings - Hence, delay in filing restoration application cannot be condoned.	(Para 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - High Court while declining to entertain appeal on ground of delay making a passing observation that there was also no merit in the appeal - Not proper.			(Para 4)

heading: Execution
HeadNote.description:
Decree in partition suit - Execution - Commencement of period of limitation - Commences from date of decree and not from engrossment of decree on stamp paper.

A decree in a suit for partition declares the rights of the parties in the immovable properties and divides the shares by metes and bounds. Since a decree in a suit for partition creates rights and liabilities of the  parties with respect to the immovable properties, it is considered as an instrument liable for the payment of stamp duty under the Indian Stamp Act. The object of the Stamp Act being securing the revenue for the State, the scheme of the Stamp Act provides that a decree of partition not duly stamped can be impounded and once the requisite stamp duty along with penalty, if any, is paid the decree can be acted upon. The engrossment of the final decree in a suit for partition would relate back to the date of the decree. The beginning of the period of limitation for executing such a decree cannot be made to depend upon date of the engrossment of such a decree on the stamp paper. The date of furnishing of stamp paper is an uncertain act, within the domain purview and control of a party. No date or period is fixed for furnishing stamp papers. No rule has been shown to us requiring the Court to call upon or give any time for furnishing of stamp paper. A party by his own act of not furnishing stamp paper cannot stop the running of period of limitation. None can take advantage of his own wrong. The proposition that period of limitation would remain suspended till stamp paper is furnished and decree engrossed thereupon and only thereafter the period of twelve years will begin to run would lead to absurdity.   [Para 25,26]

In the present case the Court has not passed an order directing the parties to furnish the stamp papers for the purpose of engrossing the decree.  Merely because there is no direction by the Court to furnish the stamp papers for engrossing of the decree or there is no time limit fixed by law, does not mean that the party can furnish stamp papers at its sweet will and claim that the period of limitation provided under Article 136 of the Act would start only thereafter as and when the decree is engrossed thereupon. The starting of period of limitation for execution of a partition decree cannot be made contingent upon the engrossment of the decree on the stamp paper. The engrossment of the decree on stamp paper would relate back to the date of the decree, namely, 7th August, 1981, in the present case. In this view the execution application filed on 21st March, 1994 was time barred having been filed beyond the period of twelve years prescribed under Article 136 of the Act. The High Court committed illegality in coming to the conclusion that it was not barred by limitation.   [Para 27]

heading: Claim petition
HeadNote.description:
Application for condonation of delay - Claim petition - Petition dismissed for negligence of Advocate - Petitioners could not be penalised for the default of advocate - Petitioners have shown sufficient cause for condoning the delay and restoring the claim application to file.

The Tribunal has, erred in dismissing the application. The Tribunal ought to have considered the fact that the petitioners had entrusted their matter to an advocate who was not diligent. The petitioners, therefore, could not have been penalised for the default of the advocate engaged by them. The negligence of an advocate should not jeopardise the interests of a litigant who has been diligent. There is material on record to indicate that the Petitioners had, through their constituted attorney, enquired from their advocate the adjourned dates of hearing as well as whether the certified copy of the judgment was available. Despite these circumstances, the Tribunal has dismissed the application. Held, he petitioners have shown sufficient cause for condoning the delay and restoring the claim application to file.  [Para 6]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay in filing appeal against order of eviction of tenant - Certified copy obtained from Rent Controller after prolonged period of time - No malafide attributable to applicant and dispute was to be decided on merits - Delay condoned subject to payment of cost of Rs.10,000/-. 			(Paras 7, 9)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Party bona fide prosecuting first and second appeal before wrong forum - Though S.14(2) per se is not applicable principles akin thereto would apply and also provisions of S.5 would apply.			(Paras 12 to 15)

heading: Condonation of delay
Revision before M.R.T.
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Revision before M.R.T. - Consideration of merits as also consideration of prayer for condonation of delay was simultaneous - Order unsustainable.

When there is delay, the Tribunal has to first proceed to consider its condonation. It gets jurisdiction to consider the controversy on merits only after such delay is condoned, Here consideration of merits as also consideration of the prayer for condonation of delay is simultaneous. The Tribunal has to first consider prayer for condonation of delay and for that to give opportunity of hearing to the present Petitioners. After passing necessary orders and if delay is condoned, the M.R.T. shall then look into the controversy in both Revisions on merits. 	          [Para 8,10]

heading: Exclusion of time spent in wrong forum
HeadNote.description:
Exclusion of time spent in wrong forum - Entitlement only to bonafide and diligent litigant - Earlier proceedings filed before Consumer Forum without taking any legal opinion that too with a delay of 1 year - After its dismissal for want of jurisdiction, appellant filed arbitration petition but with a delay of almost 3 years - Appellant found to have deliberately approached wrong forum without due care and diligence - Not entitled to benefit of exclusion u/s.14.

In order to get benefit of Section 14 of the Limitation Act, it is required to be proved before the Court that appellant was prosecuting the remedy in a wrong forum in a bona fide manner. It is an admitted fact that the appellant has not led any evidence before the Arbitrator to point out that he was prosecuting the remedy before the Consumer Forum in good faith and under genuine belief that it had jurisdiction to decide the dispute. If a party in a negligent manner and without verifying as to whether the claim is maintainable before the appropriate Court and without good faith and due diligence prosecute such proceedings, such party naturally is not entitled to the benefit under Section 14 of the Limitation Act. Appellant is also not in a position to point out as to why and under what circumstances the appellant approached the National Forum.  [Para 9]

The benefit of Section 14 of the Limitation Act cannot be given to the appellant as it is found that the appellant has deliberately approached a wrong forum without due care and diligence. Even otherwise, if the said period is to be excluded then also the claim before the Consumer Forum is beyond limitation as the appellant had approached the Consumer Forum after one year from accruing the cause of action and after the order of Consumer Forum, the appellant remained silent for more than two years and eight months.  [Para 10]

heading: Consideration
HeadNote.description: Application for condonation of delay - Consideration - Application for condonation of delay, whether it be of 10 days or 14 days, does not deserve evidence to be led, issues to be framed, precedents to be considered, reasons to be given and judgment to be pronounced in detailed manner.	(Para 5)

heading: Condonation of delay
Application for
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Application for - Averments made in the application sufficiently explaining reasons for delay - Court is not supposed to go into merits of the case while deciding application for condonation of delay - Order refusing to condone delay set aside.			(Paras 2, 3)

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Plea of adverse possession - Plea raised and proved before trial Court - Conclusions drawn by Trial Court and confirmed by Appellate Court cannot be faulted - Conclusions based on cogent evidence - There is no need therefore, to take a different view - Second appeal dismissed. 1996(1) S.C.C. 639 and 2000(3) S.C.C. 708 - Ref. to.	(Para 21)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 1306 days in filing appeal - Wife did not receive notice after remand of case in matrimonial matter - Court below had observed in its judgment that wife had lived in adultery - After that her application for maintenance was also rejected on ground that she had lived in adultery - Held, if respondent wife is not heard on merits after condoning delay she will suffer irreparable loss and observations that she lived in adultery will remain without opportunity to redress her grievance - Fact that husband has performed second marriage cannot be a ground to confirm decree of dissolution of marriage. 	(Paras 9-11)

heading: Condonation of delay
Application by State
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Application by State - Liberal approach does not mean that delay can be condoned even in absence of sufficient cause. 	(Para 10)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Delay of 253 days in preferring revision against order of trial court - Condonation sought on ground that applicants (Corporation) not informed by their attorney regarding date of judgment - Office note-sheet and reply of attorney to notice for not intimating date of judgment to Corporation was filed - Considering peculiar position of applicants i.e. corporate body, it is difficult to perceive that without receiving information about date of judgment, applicants could have taken proceeding early - Hence, applicants have made out sufficient cause for condoning delay - As result, delay stands condoned. 

(1998) 7 SCC 123 Ref. on.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Condonation of delay in first appeal
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay in first appeal - Recording of evidence oral or on affidavit is necessary - Order of refusal to condone delay without recording evidence - Order liable to be set aside. 2007(1) Bom.C.R. 506 : 2006(5) Mh.L.J. 80 - Foll. AIR 1987 SC 1353 and 1999(2) Mh.L.J. 272 - Ref. to.	(Para 10)

heading: Delay
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Delay - Condonation of - Delay of 178 days in filing appeal - Court while deciding application for condonation of delay ought not to enter into merits of the case and should only consider whether sufficient cause had been shown by the appellant for condoning delay in filing appeal - Delay condoned and High Court directed to decide appeal on merits.(Para 3)

heading: Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing appeal - Condonation of - Plea that delay was caused due to ill health of appellant - Facts on record show that every attempt was made by appellant to protract things, to delay execution and to defeat claim of respondents - No sufficient cause was made out to condone delay - Delay cannot be condoned. 	(Para 6)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Bharad and Rocky land having no houses and trees - Pleading silent on the point of area of Land, overt acts of possession and manner which was hostile - Finding about failure to establish title cannot be interfered with. 	(Para 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Appeal against order of termination of Assistant teacher dismissed - Delay in filing review petition - Application for condonation rejected - Roznama does not disclose presence of parties on date of pronouncement of judgment - Reason that petitioner had no knowledge of pronouncement of judgment is believable - Delay is not willful or inordinate - To enable petitioner to contest matter on merit delay is liable to be condoned.	(Para 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Delay of 1373 days in filing second appeal - Delay occasioned only on account of deliberate lapses on the part of Executive Officer of the Panchayat at relevant time - Court can take lenient view in such case and condone delay.
2005 ALL MR (Cri) 1570 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Paras 3, 4, 5)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Judgment and decree passed in March 2008 - Respondents approached their Advocate in June 2008 - Respondents presumed that their Advocate must have filed appeal as instructed - Advocate did not file appeal in time - Held, for the lapse on part of Advocate, respondent cannot be said to have acted with malafides - Sufficient cause has been shown by respondents - Delay condoned. 
2014(5) ALL MR 751, 2014(5) ALL M R 609 Ref. to.(Para 10)

heading: Eviction petition
HeadNote.description: Eviction petition - Dismissal of petition holding it to be barred by limitation is improper - Arts.66, 67, 113 of Limitation Act (1963), are not applicable to rent proceedings in Himachal Pradesh. (Paras 4, 7, 8)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of seven years in preferring application for substitution of heirs and for setting aside order dismissing appeal in default - Original plaintiff died pending second appeal and his widow had knowledge of pendency of second appeal - Mere fact that her husband had stated that according to their counsel second appeal was not likely to be taken up for the next 20 years cannot be a ground to entertain application for condonation of delay of 7 years. (Para 14)

heading: Bar of limitation
HeadNote.description: Bar of limitation - Larger interests would always out weigh individual claims such as bar of limitation - Bar may take away the remedy, but shall not extinguish a right - Individual interest and a right allegedly accrued due to bar of limitation would never result in defeating and destroying rights of community. 2007(2) ALL MR 608; 1998(1) ALL MR 688 and A.I.R. 1998 SC 2276 - Ref. to.	(Paras 6 & 8)

heading: Delay in filing
HeadNote.description:
Appeal against award for land acquisition - Delay in filing - Application for certified copy of award filed ten years after date of award - Appeal was filed after lapse of one and half year after obtaining certified copy - Held, delay of nearly eleven years in filing appeal, cannot be condoned.
2013 ALL SCR 3236, 2013 ALL SCR 1340 Rel. on. (Paras 8, 9, 12)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay in filling revision challenging order of Deputy Collector - Petitioner filed writ petition challenging said order - Writ petition disposed of as petitioner had an efficacious remedy by way of filing revision before Administrative Tribunal - While disposing of petition right of petitioner to avail alternate remedy was reserved - Petitioner learnt about order passed in writ petition only after 50 days from passing of said order - No malafides attributed to petitioner - Delay condoned subject to payment of costs. 	(Paras 7, 9)

heading: Delay in filing appeal
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing appeal - Appeal filed before Division Bench of High Court after inordinate delay of 239 days - It was fully justified in rejecting appeal on ground of delay in filing as no sufficient cause was shown for condoning it - Appeal against their order also filed after a delay of 114 days - Union of India ought to have been more careful in avoiding delay but it is a matter of deep anguish and distress that majority of the matters filed by the Union of India are hopelessly barred by limitation and no satisfactory explanations exist for condoning inordinate delay in filing those cases.	 (Para 6)

heading: Cause of action
When arises
Services terminated
HeadNote.description: Cause of action - When arises - Respondent unauthorisedly remaining absent from duty - Services terminated - He was re-employed on temporary basis subsequently - He made representation about his seniority and other things after more than a decade - Submission that limitation would commence from date on which his last submission was made, cannot be accepted, moreso in absence of any provision for statutory appeal. 	(Para 13)

heading: Condonation of delay
Application for
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Application for - It is true that it will be a hyper-technical view to say that, day to day delay should be explained by the party - However, it is also equally true that sufficient cause should be disclosed by the party who is approaching the court with prayer for Condonation of delay.

In the present case, there was delay of about 1144 days. It is true that, it will be a hyper-technical view to say that, day to day delay should be explained by the party. However, it is also equally true that, 'sufficient cause' should be disclosed by the party who is approaching the Court with prayer for condonation of delay. It will depend upon the facts of each case. It is also necessary to see that, the delay in filing the appeal is intentional or the party has gained some benefit out of it. In the present case, admittedly, the appellant is in possession of the suit property and therefore, there is every reason to believe that, since the appellant is in possession of the suit property, he has delayed filing the appeal though he was aware about judgment and decree passed by the trial Court.
AIR 1987 SC 1353 - Ref. to.   [Para 7]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Application filed on 1-8-2007 - Appeal actually filed on 30-8-2007 - Sufficient cause for delay after filing application for condonation and actual filing of appeal subsequently remaining unexplained - Without noticing this discrepancy Tribunal condoning delay for entire period by treating it as technical mistake - Held order suffers from error of law apparent on the face of record and is liable to be set aside.			(Paras 2, 3)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Suit property gifted to original plaintiff by his father - Defendant i.e. brother of plaintiff who has been residing in suit property since birth, claiming to have perfected his title by adverse possession - In some earlier proceedings he had raised plea of tenancy as well as co-ownership wherein he failed - In instant case he failed to point out any date or event from which he is claiming adverse possession - He in fact admitted that he used to collect rent on behalf of plaintiff - Held, this destroys plea of adverse possession - Defendant was imposed exemplary cost for vexatiously contesting the suit by raising the false pleas one after another. 	(Paras 17 to 22)

heading: Limitation period
HeadNote.description: Limitation period - Exclusion of consumed time in earlier proceedings before Court - Time consumed in proceedings before Labour Court, though not in Civil proceedings such time can be excluded in terms of S.14 - Since Section 14 of the Limitation Act speaks only of a "Court", any authority or Tribunal having the trappings of the Court would be a "Court" within the meaning of the said section. (2000)5 SCC 355 - Rel. on.			(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Defence of limitation
HeadNote.description:
Defence of limitation - To set up the defence of limitation, ouster is to be specifically pleaded and proved. 

2008(5) ALL MR 110, 1989 Supp.(1) SCC 246 - Ref. to.  (Para 6)

heading: Adverse possession
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Limitation - Grant for possession of land by way of cultivation for a limited period of 15 years - Transferee thereby not acquiring absolute title from State Government - Period of limitation to claim title by adverse possession in such a case would be 30 years and not 12 years. 

(1994) 3 SCC 536 Rel.on.  (Para 11)

heading: Abatement of suit
Death of defendant
HeadNote.description: Abatement of suit - Death of defendant - If the heirs of a deceased defendant are not brought on record within the statutory period of 90 days from the date of death, the suit abates automatically and no order of the Court is necessary - The Court may pass a formal order noting abatement on the death but that is in law not necessary and the suit abates automatically on expiry of statutory period of limitation.	(Para 6)

heading: Exclusion of time
HeadNote.description: Exclusion of time - Time spent in wrong forum - Instead of approaching Collector, petitioner approached Deputy Collector for filing revision application - Such application was filed on advise of Lawyer and under a bonafide belief that it was maintainable - Such application before wrong forum was filed within time and thus due diligence was exercised by petitioner - Allegation of respondent that petitioner is adopting tricks to harass him and that petitioner is in habit of filing false complaints, not substantiated - Petitioner entitled to benefit of S.14(2) of Limitation Act. 			(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Delay of 4 years in filing appeal
HeadNote.description: Delay of 4 years in filing appeal - Appellant also not approaching High Court with clean hands - High Court committed grave error by condoning more than four years' delay in filing of appeal ignoring the judicially accepted parameters for exercise of discretion under Section 5.	(Paras 2, 10, 13)

heading: Not provided for
HeadNote.description:
Computation of two years period - Exclusion of time taken to obtain certified copy of judgment or order in respect of stay order - Not provided for - In absence of any ambiguity or apparent omission doctrine of casus omissus cannot be invoked.

Section 11-A in terms does not provide for exclusion of the time taken to obtain a certified copy of the Judgment or order by which the stay order was either granted or vacated. Section 12 of the Limitation Act has no application to the making of an Award under the Land Acquisition Act. In the absence of any enabling provision either in Section 11-A of the Land Acquisition Act or in the Limitation Act, there is no room for borrowing the principles underlying Section 12 of the Limitation Act for computing the period or determining the validity of an Award by reference to Section 11-A of the Land Acquisition Act.		 [Para 15]

In the present case there is no ambiguity or any apparent omission in Section 11-A to justify application of the doctrine of casus omissus and by that route re-write 11-A providing for exclusion of time taken for obtaining a copy of the order which exclusion is not currently provided by the said provision. The omission of a provision under Section 11-A analogous to the proviso under Section 28A is obviously not unintended or inadvertent which is the very essence of the doctrine of casus omissus. 			 [Para 22]

heading: Period of limitation
Extension of
Execution of will
HeadNote.description: Period of limitation - Extension of - Execution of will - Date of gaining knowledge in respect of execution of will deed - Cannot be considered as circumstance extending period of limitation - Suit presented by plaintiff within three years from the date of gaining knowledge in respect of execution of will deed, therefore, held, cannot be held to be presented within prescribed period of limitation. 2001(4) ALL MR 287 (S.C.) - Ref. to.	(Para 14)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Plaintiff's father leased out suit land to defendant's father - After case before Tahasildar defendant's father gave possession only in writing - However, actual possession was never handed over - Now specific plea is taken that defendant is owner by adverse possession - Further, that there is bar of limitation under Art.65 - Defendant never entered witness box to prove his adverse uninterrupted possession - In absence of any evidence finding that defendant is owner by adverse possession cannot sustain. 	              (Para 5)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - No negligence, in action or mala fides can be imputed to party - Condonation cannot be refused.

It is true that even upon showing a sufficient cause, a party is not entitled to the condonation of delay as a matter of right, yet it is trite that in construing sufficient cause, the Courts generally follow a liberal approach particularly when no negligence, inaction or mala fides can be imputed to the party. It is manifest that though Section 5 of the Limitation Act, 1963 envisages the explanation of delay to the satisfaction of the Court, and makes no distinction between the State and the citizen, nonetheless adoption of a strict standard of proof in case of the Government, which is dependant on the actions of its officials, who often do not have any personal interest in its transactions, may lead to grave miscarriage of justice and therefore, certain amount of latitude is permissible in such cases.  [Para 7,11]

In the present case, the conduct of the appellants in late filing of appeal does not indicate inaction, negligence or mala fides. The explanation furnished for the marginal delay of 59 days viz. the delay had occasioned because of the time taken by the company's consultant mainly on account of summer vacation. Constitutes a sufficient cause and therefore, deserves to be accepted.  [Para 4,12]

heading: Limitation
Bar of
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession of land - Limitation - Bar of - Alienation of undivided Hindu Family property through a registered sale deed - Respondent's right to declare such alienation as non binding accrues the moment such alienation was executed - Suit filed not within three years but after 19 years of alienation - Hence barred.			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Government should not take possession of somebody's land without following due process of law and try to take advantage of such possession at the time of giving compensation when said land is acquired. 	(Para 7)

heading: Suit for declaration
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - Wrong entry in revenue records - Defendants not admitting claim made by plaintiffs - Defendants asserting that suit was filed 18 years after alleged compromise between the parties - Plaintiff stating that they came to know about wrong entries in the record of rights about eight days before filing suit - Cause of action according to plaintiffs arose because defendants refused to agree to correct wrong entries - Held, suit having been filed within three years from such refusal was within time.	(Para 10)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Permissive possession can never be perfected into adverse possession without necessary animus possidendi or without hostile animus, continuity and extent in view of Art.65 of Limitation Act. 2004(3) Bom.C.R. 408 and 2004(2) ALL MR 368 (Bom.) - Ref. to.	(Para 15)

heading: Adverse possession
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Limitation - Evidence to the effect that property was encroached upon sometime around May 2000 - Defendants were trespassers having no title or interest in suit property - Further, they did not claim to be in adverse possession - Plea of limitation not even raised by defendants in written statement - Limitation for filing suit for possession is 12 years and suit filed within twelve years, is not barred by limitation. (Paras 16, 17)

heading: Condonation of delay
Rejection of
Sustainability
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Rejection of - Sustainability - Delay of 1410 days - Allegedly, revisional court did not consider plea of ill-health of father of petitioner - Counsel for respondent also supported petitioner's plea - Only aspect of pendency of matter was considered - It was expected from revisional court to decide issue in accordance with law - Non consideration of said issue resulted in miscarriage of justice - Hence, delay needs to be condoned. (Paras 6, 7)

heading: Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Sufficient cause - Proceedings taken to set aside an ex parte decree do not constitute "sufficient cause", so as to extend period of limitation of an appeal against ex-parte decree.			(Paras 10, 11, 15)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay in filing revision u/S.201B of Goa Panchayat Raj Act - Refusal to condone on ground of negligence, lack of due diligence and bona fide on part of petitioner - Revision filed against order passed in appeal - Order was passed in appeal 11 months after it was closed for order - When any matter is closed for order, there remains nothing for parties to do and keep on contacting Advocate - Petitioner's contacting his advocate twice at intervals of 6 to 10 months cannot be seen as sheer indolence of petitioner - Nor failure to give explanation for not contacting Advocate for period of 6 months shows lack of diligence and bona fide on part of petitioner - Further, one and half months period taken by petitioner in filing revision after getting knowledge of order in appeal is reasonable, considering controversy involved in matter - Refusal to condone delay, improper. 			(Paras 13, 14, 15, 16, 17)

heading: Condonation
Reason satisfactory
HeadNote.description: Delay of 6-1/2 months in filing of appeal - Condonation - Time consumed in securing approval of each appellant residing at different and distant places - Reason satisfactory - Delay is not too much to throw out the matter without deciding the same on merits - Condonation granted.	(Para 5)

heading: Suit for possession
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Suit for possession - Rejection, on ground that it was barred by limitation - Validity - Plaintiff had proved her title over suit property - On contrary defendants failed to prove that they were in adverse possession - Once defendants failed to prove that they were in adverse possession, plaintiff cannot be non-suited - Rejection of suit, not proper.
(1998) 1 SCC 614, 2007 ALL SCR 2816 Foll. (Paras 11, 14)

heading: Condonation
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing appeal - Condonation - Delay caused due to mistaken impression that advocate has already applied for certified copies of impugned order - Fact of non-application revealed only after expiry of limitation - Explanation sufficient for Condonation - Fact that applicant continued to appeal before court, does not lead to conclusion that he was aware of Advocate's inaction - Litigants should not suffer due to fault of advocates.	(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Suit for recovery of loan - Last receipts/acknowledgment of collecting money are not proved according to law - Those acknowledgments cannot be treated as valid - As per date of valid acknowledgment suit is not filed within period of 3 years - Decree of recovery of money is liable to be set aside.		(Para 8)

heading: Ex parte decree
Setting aside of
HeadNote.description: Ex parte decree - Setting aside of - Date of knowledge of decree - Decree passed in 1986 while application for setting aside filed almost after eleven years - Defendant for getting it set aside was required to establish that either no summons was served on him or he had sufficient cause for remaining absent on date fixed for hearing suit ex parte - Defendant admitting that he had approached plaintiff for not giving effect to decree one and half year prior to filing of application - Period of limitation would run from that day and was thus barred by limitation.	(Paras 6, 8, 9)

heading: Merger of decree
HeadNote.description: Merger of decree - Starting point of limitation - When decree of trial Court merges with decree of Appellate Court, the starting point of limitation is the date of the decree of the Appellate Court. 1990 Mh.L.J. 897 - Rel. on. (Paras 6, 7, 8)

heading: Suit for compensation based on defamatory article
HeadNote.description:
Suit for compensation based on defamatory article - Complaint before Press Council of India - Time spent cannot be excluded.

Subhash Babbar filed the suit for compensation against Sanjha Jansatta and others wherein he averred that by publishing of the article viz. 'Parde Ke Peechhe Kya Hai' in the issue of Hindi Newspaper dt.13.1.1994 he was defamed.  It was contended by defendant that present suit filed on 14.12.1995 beyond the period of one year was barred.  The plaintiff contended that time taken in prosecuting the complaint before the Press Council of India should be excluded.

Held under S.12 the date on which the present suit was filed has to be excluded but that does not help the plaintiff. Sub sections (2), (3) and (4) on its face have no application to the suits.  As regards Section 14 of the Limitation Act, it may be observed that it provides exclusion of time taken in bonafide prosecuting proceedings in Court without jurisdiction.  The proceedings by way of complaint filed by the plaintiff before Press Council of India under the Press Council Act is a proceeding of entirely different nature having no semblance of 'civil proceeding' as contemplated under Section 14.  The damages sought by the plaintiff in the suit could not have been claimed in the complaint filed by him before Press Council of India nor was complaint filed for the said purpose.  The complaint filed by the plaintiff was not 'another civil proceeding' prosecuted by the plaintiff, even if be assumed with due diligence and in good faith, relating to the same matter in issue before the Court.  The Press Council of India is neither court nor the complaint is a civil proceeding as contemplated under Section 14 of the Limitation Act and, therefore, the plaintiff cannot derive any advantage of the time consumed in prosecuting complaint before the Press Council of India.  In other words, the plaintiff is not entitled to the time from 24.1.1994 to 4.8.1995 during which the complaint remained pending before Press Council of India.	  [Para 8]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Matter of land acquisition - Review against rejection of appellant's claim for enhancement of compensation - Delay of 706 days in filing - Further, delay of 1705 days before Supreme Court - On remand, High Court allowed review by fixing compensation at appropriate rate - However, looking to delay, appellant held not entitled to any statutory benefit for total period of delay i.e. 2411 days.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing appeal - Condonation of - Appellant by way of appeal challenging his order of termination - Service of appellant terminated with retrospective effect - Record showing that during concerned years appellant was constantly in correspondence with institution - Also his appointment as Lab attendant and promotion as Junior Clerk was approved by District Education Officer - Opportunity must be given to appellant to challenge order of termination - Delay condoned. 	(Paras 10, 11)

headline: Limitation Act (1963), S. 5 – Constitution of India, Art. 16 – Delay in filing appeal – Condonation of – Appellant challenging order of termination – His appointment and promotion was approved by District Education Officer – Delay condoned to give opportunity to challenge order of termination.

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - In filing review petition before High Court - Delay occurred on account of prosecution of special leave petition before Supreme Court in earlier round - Delay in filing review petition, condoned. 		(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Delay of 1 year and 2 months in filing appeal - Case of appellant that his advocate did not inform him about decision in suit - Appellant is an educated person staying in an up market area in Mumbai - Standard applicable to him would be different than lay villager - Appellant did not take step in filing written statement in suit when pending in Trial Court nor made any inquiries with his advocate about suit - Conduct of appellant is one of gross negligence and also indolence - Explanation put forth by appellant does not constitute sufficient cause - Payment of cost cannot be panacea for such unexplained delay - Hence, delay cannot be condoned. 

2013(5) ALL MR 934 (S.C.) Ref. to.			(Para 11)

heading: Condonation of delay
Application for
