HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Application for - Delay of 884 days in filing appeal against award of Reference Court under Land Acquisition Act - Applicant claiming that they were not aware of making of award therefore, applied for certified copy only after 9 months of passing of award - However, award shows that it was passed in open Court in presence of advocates of applicants - There was no explanation for delay of more than 9 months in applying for certified copy of award - Further, statement of applicants that they are Govt. institutions and they have to take approval from Govt. before filing appeal is not sufficient to condone delay of 884 days - Explanation given by applicants for delay was quite casual, unverifiable and hardly constitutes sufficient cause - Delay cannot be condoned. 	(Paras 5, 7, 10, 18)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Delay of approximately 95 days in filing appeal - On account of some inadvertent mistake that counsel was instructed and has assured to file appeal, but failed to do so - Even petitioner was also not found diligent enough to contract counsel and to see that indeed appeal is filed - Another ground of delay that counsel being appointed as President of Administrative Tribunal, is found incorrect - Hence delay cannot be condoned. 
2013 ALL SCR 3236 Ref.to.(Para 12)

heading: Exclusion of time
HeadNote.description:
Exclusion of time - Applicability of S.14 of Haryana Panchayati Raj Act in election petition - To be tested not from provisions of Limitation Act but that of relevant election law - No provision in relevant election law for condonation of delay - S.14, therefore, not applicable - Election petition liable to be dismissed. 

(1974) 2 SCC 133, (1973) 2 SCC 530, (1999) 8 SCC 532 Rel. on. 	(Para 9)

heading: Limitation
Exclusion of time
HeadNote.description:
Suit for specific performance - Limitation - Exclusion of time - Delay of more than 5 years caused in filing civil suit - However, out of such delay, more than 4 years consumed in pursuing claim before consumer forum - No malafide in filing consumer complaint - Hence, time taken by Consumer Forum liable to be excluded - Civil suit not barred by limitation.

2001(3) ALL MR 1, AIR 1995 SC 1428, (1998) 8 SCC 357 Rel. on. 			(Paras 10, 12)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 148 days in filing revision application - Petitioner aged about 90 years is staying abroad - Power of attorney given to 'C' had also proceeded to U.K. sometimes in August 2013 - Further delegation made to one 'A' who was required to wait as 'C' had carried power of attorney with her - 'A' was instructed to file revision application in beginning of November 2013 - Thereafter on account of alleged sickness of 'A', revision application filed on 18.1.2014 - No lack of diligence can be attributed - Delay condoned subject to costs of Rs.25,000/-. 	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Suit for recovery of possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of possession - Is to be filed within 12 years from date of termination of tenancy - Suit filed after period of 12 years of arising of cause of action - Suit is barred by limitation - Also there is no pleadings showing that respondent prosecuting earlier proceedings with due diligence - Benefit of S.14 could not be granted to respondent. 	(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 233 days in filing appeal - Delay caused as appellants were not parties to writ petitions in which impugned order was passed - Delay in filing appeal against order passed in writ petitions, condoned. 	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
Application for
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Application for - Delay of 1590 days in filing appeal against order enhancing amount of compensation in land acquisition matter - Applicant-State Govt. submitted that it being impersonal agency and decisions are required to be taken at different levels 'some delay' was caused - Delay of more than three years in obtaining certified copy of judgment was not explained - There was delay of more than one year in filing appeal even after receipt of certified copy - Vague statements like opinion was to be obtained from various authorities, documents were incomplete, typed copies were not available, etc. were made to explain said delay - No sufficient cause made out for condonation of delay - Inordinate delay of more than 1590 days cannot be condoned on basis of vague statements merely because applicant is impersonal agency - Law of limitation is similar for citizens as well as for Govt. authorities. (Paras 6, 7, 9, 15)

heading: Railway claim
Condonation of delay
Not justified
HeadNote.description: Railway claim - Condonation of delay - Delay of 4 and ½ years in filing application - Condonation sought on ground of illiteracy, poverty, lack of communication between claimants and their advocate and that claimants faced lots of difficulties in collecting police papers and getting them translated for purpose of filing petition - Adverse inference drawn for reason that claimants did not provide particulars as which police station they had visited for getting documents and that who was advocate who kept pending file with him for 2 years - Not justified - Delay caused was not deliberate or intentional - Claimants were not going to be benefitted by such delay - Materials on record prima facie show that deceased was bona fide passenger and that he suffered death in untoward incident - Delay in such cases has to be liberally condoned. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Order is illegal
HeadNote.description: Suit against one defendant - Plaintiff omitting to include names of two other defendants, in good faith - Application for impleading such defendants - Rejection of application on ground that claim had become time barred against those defendants - Order is illegal - In view of Proviso to S.21(1) suit against such defendants would be deemed to have been instituted on date of presentation of plaint as against one defendant - Court is under obligation to direct to that effect - Order of court is liable to be quashed. (Para 4)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 807 days in filing application for restoring the restoration application - Delay alleged to be occurred due to lack of knowledge of dismissal of application for restoration of suit for possession in default - Restoration application was filed by petitioner along with his brothers - Petitioner submitted that his brothers did not attend proceedings as during pendency of restoration application, suit property came to his share in pursuance of family arrangement - No documents produced by petitioner to show any family arrangement between brothers - Further pleadings of petitioner that he could not attend proceedings in restoration application as he was suffering from serious ailments like heart trouble, kidney stone and other mental ailments which put restrictions on his movements, could not be accepted - Evidence of doctor showing that ailments from which petitioner was suffering were not that serious which make him bedridden - Evidence of wife of petitioner also shows that he was looking after shop of pharmacy - Moreover, petitioner has not examined himself to prove reasons given by him for not pursuing restoration application - No sufficient reasons given by petitioner for condonation of delay - Delay cannot be condoned. 			(Paras 7, 8, 10, 11)

heading: Condonation of delay in filing appeal
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay in filing appeal - Exclusion of period spent in other proceedings - Suit was decreed on 16.02.2008 - Appellant appeared on 29.07.2008 only after filing of execution proceedings and filed objection which was rejected on 28.03.2014 - Thereafter, writ petition challenging said order filed but same was dismissed on 27.11.2015 - Then on 18.12.2015, appeal filed along with application for condonation of delay - Period from 29.7.2008 till 27.11.2015 spent in prosecuting other proceedings and therefore, can be excluded as per S.14 of Limitation Act - However, period of delay from 16.02.2008 till 29.07.2008 remained unexplained - Said delay cannot be condoned.  (2015) 7 SCC 58, (1975) 4 SCC 628 Ref. to. 	(Paras 7, 10)

heading: Condonation of delay
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Prayer for Rejection for want of authority - Challenge - Contention that S.29(2) of Limitation Act makes S.24(4) applicable for computing limitation under special law and therefore, would also apply to proceedings under Maharashtra Police Act being special law - However, S.29(2) would not apply to proceedings before Tribunal since Limitation Act prescribes period of limitation only to proceedings in courts - Though Maharashtra Police Act is special Act, since Appellate Authority is not Court, provision of S.5 of Limitation Act cannot be applied to appeal - No error in rejecting application for condonation of delay for want of powers of appellate authority.  2016 ALL MR (Cri) 4453, 2008(6) ALL MR 423 (S.C.), 1996 (1) Mh.L.J. 609, AIR 1985 SC 1279 Rel. on.  (Paras 10, 11, 12, 13, 14)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Delay of more than 5 years in filing appeal against order enhancing amount of compensation in land acquisition matter - Applicant-State Govt. stated that delay caused as files had to move from table of various authorities for taking decision of filing appeal - There was no explanation for delay of more than one year in applying for certified copy of judgment - Statement that some time was spent in obtaining opinion from various authorities is vague and backed by no particulars - Decision to file appeal was taken in 2015 and draft of appeal was also prepared in 2015 - However, appeal along with application for condonation of delay was filed in 2017 - There was no explanation for delay of two years in filing appeal after taking decision to file appeal - Vague statement that memos of appeal were incomplete or demand draft for payment of court fees and legal expenses was not enclosed with proposal - Does not constitute sufficient cause - On basis of vague pleadings of procedural delay, inordinate delay of more than 5 years cannot be condoned. (Para 7, 8, 9, 10, 12, 19)

heading: Condonation of delay
Land dispute
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Land dispute - Writ Petition filed against order of Minister, dismissed - Filing of review with delay condonation application - Defects in filing of review and direction issued by Registry to cure the same - Non-compliance with order of Registry, consequently review application rejected - Application for restoration of review application, dismissed essentially on ground of delay - Challenge - Held, in view of Apex Court Judgment in Sangram Singh [AIR 1955 SC 425] procedural laws should not be construed like a penal provision to punish parties as far as possible - High Court should have been liberal in taking a view in matter and condoned delay and granted one more opportunity to appellants to cure defects - Ordered accordingly. 			(Paras 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 16, 17)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 370 days in filing second appeal against decree of recovery of money - Delay alleged to have been caused due to advice of advocate of applicant not to file appeal - No affidavit of advocate who gave such advice - Submission of applicant that advocate gave such advice, is not acceptable - Further, applicant has issued cheque to bailiff who had come to his office for attachment of property, despite knowing that he is not having sufficient amount in his bank account - Applicant issued cheque to avoid course of law - Applicant is not bona fide litigant - Delay in filing second appeal cannot be condoned. 			(Paras 4, 6, 7)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Delay of seven days in filing appeal - Appeal filed during illness - Delay in filing appeal ought to have been condoned.

In exercising discretion under S. 5 of the Limitation Act the Courts should adopt a pragmatic approach. A distinction must be made between a case where the delay is inordinate and a case where the delay is of a few days. Whereas in the former case the consideration of prejudice to the other side will be.a relevant factor so the case calls for a more cautious approach but in the latter case no such consideration may arise and such a case deserves a liberal approach. No hard and fast rule can be laid down in this regard. The Court has to exercise the discretion on the facts of each case keeping in mind that in construing the expression 'sufficient cause,' the principle of advancing substantial justice is of prime importance.				 [Para 5]

heading: Bar of limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of possession - Bar of limitation - Defendant was in possession of suit property since 1931 i.e. for more than 12 years prior to coming into force of Act of 1963 - Plaintiff was required to file suit for recovery of possession within period of 12 years from discontinuance of his possession as per Art. 142 of Limitation Act, 1908 - Suit filed in 1980, was beyond period of limitation as prescribed u/Art.142 of Act of 1908 - Further, suit would not be governed by Act, 1963 as period of limitation prescribed under Act, 1908 was expired prior to coming into force of Act, 1963 - Suit barred by limitation. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Plaintiff has to stand on his own legs by proving his case - High Court wrongly shifting burden of proof on defendant - Plaintiffs ought to prove as to when adverse possession started and when it was perfected. 	(Paras 10, 14)

heading: Suit for recovery of money
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of money - Whether barred by limitation - Suit was for recovery of excess amount paid to defendant on basis of misrepresentation - Amount was paid by plaintiff to defendant under impression that he is authorized to receive amount payable by plaintiff to third party, in whose favour decree was also passed by Civil Court - Suit not covered by provisions of Art.23 of Limitation Act nor by any other provisions - Provisions of Art.113 are attracted - Cause of action to file suit accrued when right of parties were crystallized - Suit not filed within period of 3 years from accrual of cause of action - Hence, barred by limitation. 			(Paras 8, 9, 10, 11)

heading: Fraudulent award/order
Application for review
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Fraudulent award/order - Application for review - Condonation of delay - Award of compensation in accident case obtained by respondent in year 2010 by relying on GD Entries of Police Station - Insurance Company came to know of fake entries only in year 2014 - Rejection of review application by Court below for non-explanation of delay, erroneous - Particularly when Insurance Company was able to show prima facie fraudulent entries - Decision of Court below is contrary to principles u/S.17 of Limitation Act - Liable to be set aside. 2014 ALL SCR (O.C.C.) 129, (2002) 9 SCC 764 Ref. to. 	(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Delay of 11 months in filing revision application - Applicants pleading that delay caused due to administrative exigencies arising from need to take decision to challenge order - However, no material on record showing that difficulties faced by applicants were really of administrative nature - No sufficient cause shown to condone delay - Application liable to be rejected. 			(Paras 5, 6, 7)

heading: Refusal to condone
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing written statement - Refusal to condone - On ground that there is no justification for not filing written statement (W.S.) when suit is filed in 1997 and no specific prayer made for setting aside no W.S. order - Suit though filed in 1997, it was dismissed in 2004 and restored in 2015 - Record also does not indicate that summons were really served in 2018 - Application cannot be rejected on ground that delay is not explained - Further, even though there is no specific prayer for recall of order, in substance petitioner prayed for recalling of order and to grant leave to file W.S. - Order refusing to condone delay in filing W.S., improper. 	(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 90 days in second appeal - Applicant is poor and illiterate old woman who is suffering from various ailments - Considering old age of applicant, delay condoned.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 349 days in filing appeal against ex-parte order - Applicant claiming that delay occurred as he has no knowledge of proceedings and order passed in it - Order sheet of Trial Court shows that both parties were present on date of framing of issues and on said date case was put up for recording evidence of plaintiff - Order sheet shows that applicant had full knowledge of proceedings of suit - Record shows that despite giving ample opportunities, applicant has not filed written statement in suit - Applicant was not vigilant in pursuing matter - Delay in filing appeal cannot be condoned.	 (Paras 16, 17, 18, 19)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 2074 days in filing application for bringing LRs on record and setting aside abatement of second appeal - Delay occurred as LRs of appellant were not having knowledge of filing of second appeal - Wife of appellant was illiterate and his kids were minor at time of filing second appeal - Application for bringing LRs was filed immediately on getting knowledge of abatement of appeal - Sufficient cause for delay - Delay in filing application condoned by imposing cost of Rs.5,000/-.  1996 (10) SCC 253 Rel. on. 			(Paras 12, 20, 22, 25, 27)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay in filing appeal against order passed in mutation proceedings - Delay of 3 years, 11 months and 7 days in filing appeal - Delay occurred as petitioner had no knowledge of order passed by Mamlatdar, because he was not made party to proceedings - Order was obtained behind back of petitioner - Sufficient cause made out by petitioner for delay - Delay condoned. 	(Paras 8, 9, 11)

heading: Enforcement of
Period of Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Decree for recovery of possession and mandatory injunction - Enforcement of - Period of Limitation - Would be the time prescribed for the main relief, i.e. Decree for recovery of possession - The second relief of mandatory injunction being inseparable from the main relief - Enforcement of decree of mandatory injunction can be made within the time prescribed for main relief of possession.

In the instant case, the decree for mandatory injunction is inseparable from the decree for possession and since the decree for possession is the main decree which prescribes 12 years limitation for enforcement, the decree for mandatory injunction merges with that relief and decree holder can enforce the degree for possession alongwith mandatory injunction within the time limits prescribed for possession.	 [Para 8,12,13]

heading: Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing second appeal - Condonation of - There was inordinate delay of 1942 days in filing appeal - Appellants claiming that delay caused as their lawyer did not take timely steps - It was not sufficient cause within meaning of S.5 for condoning delay - Delay being not properly explained, cannot be condoned. 	(Paras 15, 18, 21)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Exclusion of period of proceedings before Civil Court - Application for, by insurance company - In petition filed for setting aside arbitral award - Petition initially filed by insurance company before Civil Court was within period prescribed u/S.34(3) of Arbitration Act - However, it was dismissed by Civil Court holding that it was not maintainable before it and returned it u/O.7 Rr.10, 10-A for its re-presentation before proper Court by fixing time and date - Respondent claiming that application u/S.14 of Limitation Act could be allowed only if it was bona-fidely presented before wrong Court - However, while returning petition, Civil Court has not recorded finding that petition was filed before it with mala fide intention - There was delay of only 8 days in re-presentation before proper Court without seeking extension of time for re-presentation - Re-examination of matter to consider entire period spent before Civil Court as malafide, so as to non-suit insurance company and deny consideration of proceedings u/S.34 of Arbitration Act, not justified - Application u/S.14, allowed. 			(Paras 11, 13, 14)

heading: Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing appeal - Condonation of - Delay of 4 years and 30 days in filing appeal against partition decree enhancing share of respondents in suit property - Delay occurred due to pendency of review petition which was dismissed being not maintainable - Review petition was filed by appellant on advice of his advocate - Appellant was litigating its cause before wrong forum under bona fide belief as per legal advice of his advocate - Delay occurred in such proceedings has to be taken into consideration for condonation of delay in preferring appeal - No delay in preferring appeal if period of pendency of review petition was deducted - Delay condoned. 	(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay in filing appeal - Delay occurred as applicant was under wrong impression that period of limitation is 90 days to challenge judgment - He was also poor person not having funds to even pay fees of advocate - Poverty can never be impediment for litigant to seek justice from Court of law - Even delay was not so enormous - Delay liable to be condoned. 	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 128 days in filing miscellaneous appeal against order granting temporary injunction - Petitioner claiming that he was not aware of passing of temporary injunction as his counsel did not give information - Roznama of proceedings showing that petitioner and his counsel were present in Court on day of granting temporary injunction - Caveat filed by plaintiff is also duly served on petitioner - Record showing that there was lack of diligence on part of petitioner - Rejection of application for condonation of delay, proper. 	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Rejection of application for - Challenge - Delay of 121 days in filing appeal against ex-parte decree - Defendant was residing at Pune and matter was pending in Court at Aurangabad - He had engaged lawyer who did not communicate stages and about disposal - He had no knowledge about judgment and therefore there was delay - Observing that defendant was coming to Aurangabad every week for his official work, First Appellate Court refused to condone delay - Before proceeding ex-parte or dismissing matter for default, Court should always ask itself whether this is matter in which absent party should be penalized with dismissal for non-appearance or whether party deserves last chance of intimation of notice - Particularly when litigant is from outstation, his advocate and Court should be cautious to see that principles of natural justice are followed - Client has been given warning that if he would not attend matter, it would proceed in his absence - Since engaged advocate did not issue any notice of withdrawal of his appearance, defendant could not attend matter - First Appellate Court did not properly follow principles and arrived at wrong conclusion - Delay condoned by imposing exemplary cost. (2011) 12 SCC 600, 2011(4) Mh.L.J. 104, (2009) 2 SCC 689, AIR 2001 SC 2497 Ref. to. 	(Para 17)

heading: Condonation of delay
Refusal to condone
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 3286 days in filing appeal - Refusal to condone - Applicant in appeal challenging his order of termination - Applicant received order of termination on 19 March, 2011 - Applicant claiming that delay occurred as he was continuously writing to respondent school and Education Officer regarding his grievances - Record showing that in 2014 itself Education Officer informed applicant that he has to approach School Tribunal for redressal of grievances - However, he has not done anything till 2016 - No other sufficient explanation given by applicant for such long delay - Refusal to condone delay, proper. 1984 ALLMR ONLINE 585 (S.C.), (1998) 7 SCC 123 Disting. 	(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay in filing revision application - Deputy Collector passed order on 01.02.2016 and petitioners collected copy of it on 24.02.2016 - Revision application along with application for condonation of delay was filed in August, 2016, much beyond period of limitation - Reason for delay stated that petitioner no.1 was suffering from Acute Asthmatic Bronchitis coupled with fever from 14.06.2016 and was advised rest for about 10 to 15 days - However, no account given for period of July and August till date when revision filed - Petitioner No.2 also failed to give explanation for such delay - Therefore, rejection of application for condonation of delay, held proper - Challenge, on count that no opportunity of hearing is given - Not tenable, as record shows that petitioners have sought umpteen adjournment and even on date they moved for adjournment - No cause shown for such inordinate delay - Rejection of application is proper.  2013 ALL SCR 3236, 2008(6) ALL MR 954 (S.C.), 1998(3) ALL MR 393, 1981 ALLMR ONLINE 277 (S.C.), 1999(2) ALL MR 507 Ref. to. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Refusal to condone
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing appeal - Refusal to condone - On ground that no sufficient cause made out - Delay occurred as appellant-old man was hospitalized during relevant period, suffering from heart disease and dengue fever - He was also mentally disturbed due to disputes going on in his family - Genuineness of documents filed by appellant in support of his cause was not disputed - Cause shown by appellant for delay in filing appeal before High Court sufficient - Refusal to condone delay, not proper. 	(Paras 14, 16, 19)

heading: Adverse possession
Plea of
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Plea of - Must be established by positive evidence - Mere assertion, of no avail - Plea of adverse possession, predominantly, one of fact - It acquires legal significance, only after basic factual foundation is laid through pleadings and evidence - Open, continuous and uninterrupted possession to the knowledge of owner of property for over statutory period of 12 years has to be proved - Party seeking recovery of possession not required to plead, as to when he lost possession.

The appellant sought to assert his possession over the suit schedule property, on the strength of Ex.A-9 and the entries in various pahanies.  It has come in the evidence that when the appellant started construction in the plaint schedule land, on the strength of the permission obtained under Ex.A-9, DWs.1 and 2 and others, on behalf of D-1, had obstructed; and in fact, cut away the steel rods, used for raising pillars.  The fact that, for the past more than a decade, the same condition subsists on the ground, discloses that the appellant did not exercise rights of possession over it.  The pahanies are hardly of any use to it.  The reason is that the land became part of the municipality and revenue records maintained in respect of agricultural land, do not have any bearing on such lands.  Except making an assertion himself, the appellant did not examine anyone, in support of his claim, that he is in possession of the suit schedule property.	 [Para 16]

heading: Suit for compensation
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Suit for compensation - Limitation - Suit instituted jointly which includes minors - As per Art.72 limitation for filing suit for compensation on account of doing or for omitting to do any act is one year from date of act or omission - However, Ss.6 and 7 provides that period of limitation would not start where proceedings are to be jointly instituted and plaintiffs are minor at time of filing of suit and discharge cannot be given by other plaintiffs - At time of filing of suit four out of five plaintiffs were minor - Suit was filed by mother of plaintiffs who could not give them valid discharge as contemplated by S.7 - Plaintiffs entitled for benefit of provisions of Ss.6 and 7 for extending period of limitation - Suit is within limitation.

	Under the provisions of Art.72 of the said Act, the limitation for claiming compensation on account of doing or for omitting to do an act is a period of one year from the date the actor omission takes place. The accident in question having occurred on 9.6.1990,the suit was liable to be filed within a period of one year from said date. It is however not in dispute that four of the plaintiffs were minors when the suit was filed on 27.10.1994.Under S. 6 (1) of the said Act, if a plaintiff is a minor at the time when the suit is sought to be instituted, he is permitted to institute such suit within the same period as prescribed after the disability as regards minority has ceased. Under S. 7 of the said Act where several persons are jointly entitled to institute a suitand one of them is under disability due to which the suit cannot be instituted, unless a discharge can be given without the concurrence of such person, time would not run against all the said persons.From the aforesaid provisions, it is clear that firstly if a plaintiff is a minor he is entitled to the benefit of the period till he attains the majority. Similarly, where a proceeding can be jointly instituted, even if one of the plaintiffs is a minor and discharge cannot be given by the other plaintiffs the time would not run against all of them. In present case as the plaintiff nos.1 and 2 were under a legal disability as they were minors when the period of limitation of one year after the incident in question expired, they were entitled to file the suit within a period of one year after attaining the age of majority. The suit thus having been filed by their mother who could not givethem valid discharge as contemplated by S. 7 of the said Act was within limitation.The plaintiffs are entitled for the benefit of provisions of Ss. 6 and 7 of the said Act for extending the period of limitation. AIR 1983 All. 27, AIR 2009 J & K 56 Ref. to. 	 [Para 8,11]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Whether delay of 427 days in filing SLP by office of the Post Master General can be condoned - Delay attributable to impersonal machinery and bureaucratic methodology - Delay cannot be condoned in view of modern technology being used and available - Limitation law binds everybody including the Government.

It is the right time to inform all the government bodies, their agencies and instrumentalities that unless they have reasonable and acceptable explanation for the delay and there was bonafide effort, there is no need to accept the usual explanation that the file was kept pending for several months/years due to considerable degree of procedural red-tape in the process. The government departments are under a special obligation to ensure that they perform their duties with diligence and commitment. Condonation of delay is an exception and should not be used as an anticipated benefit for government departments. The law shelters everyone under the same light and should not be swirled for the benefit of a few. Considering the fact that there was no proper explanation offered by the Department for the delay except mentioning of various dates, the Department has miserably failed to give any acceptable and cogent reasons sufficient to condone such a huge delay of 427 days.

2008(6) ALL MR 954 (S.C.), 1994 Supp (2) SCC 603, 2005 ALL MR (Cri) 1570 (S.C.) - Rel. on.  [Para 12,13]

heading: Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of possession - Burden of proof - To prove that plaintiff has title, she has been in possession and she was dispossessed within 12 years from date of filing of suit, is on plaintiff in view of Art.142 of Limitation Act - Plaintiff failed to discharge said burden - Dismissal of suit, proper. 	(Para 10)

heading: Refusal to condone
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing appeal - Refusal to condone - Delay occurred in filing appeal against order dtd. 20.09.2016 as copy of said order was received by petitioner in March 2017 - Also by impugned order, sale deed standing in favour of petitioner was invalidated - Considering these circumstances petitioner held entitled to opportunity for pursuing appeal on merits - Order refusing to condone delay set aside with direction to petitioner to pay cost of Rs.2,500/- to respondent. 	(Para 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - 24 days delay in filing appeal - Petitioner producing medical certificate that he was advised bed rest as he had accute attack of phalsiparam Malaria - Blood test report, however, not produced even during hearing of writ petition - Respondent producing photographs showing petitioner supervising construction work during alleged period of sickness - Held explanation for delay was not bonafide and no sufficient cause for condonation of delay was made out.

AIR 1987 SC 1353, (1998) 7 SCC 123, AIR 1981 SC 733. Rel. on. (Para 13)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 3015 and 3166 days in filing cross objection in two appeals - Suit for specific performance of contract was filed against defendant and subsequent buyer - Applicant who was brother of defendant had filed separate suit for declaration and perpetual injunction claiming himself to be exclusive owner under partition - Said suit was dismissed and order had attained finality in absence of challenge - Although applicant was also made party to main suit, neither specific prayer was made nor was any Judgment passed against him - Decree for specific performance was made only against his brother and subsequent buyer - Three defendants had preferred three different appeals which were dismissed - After long gap, applicant filed cross objection in second appeals preferred by other two defendants - Not maintainable under O.41 R.22, as dispute between parties related to right of plaintiff to obtain specific performance of contract - In such suit, issue of ownership cannot be gone into - Moreover, applicant failed to prove his title to obstruct sale transaction - In view of huge and unexplained delay, cross objection not maintainable - Even on merit, delay could not be condoned. 2015 (1) SCC (Civil) 236, 2003(2) ALL MR 333 (S.C.), 2011(4) ALL MR 858 (S.C.), 2011(6) ALL MR 242 Rel. on. 			(Paras 14, 18, 19, 20, 22, 25)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of amount of excise duty - Limitation - Prayer to alter or set aside orders passed by revisional authority by an Officer of Government in his official capacity - Held, the suit ought to have been filed within one year - Suit as filed by the respondent, held, was time barred in view of Art.100 of Limitation Act.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 10 months in filing first appeal - Suit decreed on 23.03.2010 - Defendants claiming that they came to know about decree in December, 2010 - Defendants residing at Mumbai and suit pending at Islampur - Defendants would not go on each and every date to Islampur - Though defendants had engaged three Advocates, none of them followed the proceeding - They did not inform defendants nor were asked to issue intimation to their client by registered post A.D. and thereafter withdrew from suit - Sufficient cause for condonation of delay - However, there is some negligence on part of defedants - Therefore, delay condoned by imposing some exemplary costs. 2013 ALL SCR 3236, AIR 2001 SC 2497 Ref. to. 	(Paras 17, 26, 27, 28)

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Rejection, on ground of bar of limitation - Applicant received notice u/S.12(2) of LA Act on 21.06.2004 - Reference filed on 07.08.2004 which is beyond prescribed period of six weeks from receipt of notice u/S.12(2) - Applicant seeking direction to be issued to Reference Court to decide belated reference by requiring applicant to forgo amount of statutory interest - Delay in reference proceedings cannot be condoned u/S.5 of Limitation Act - Direction as sought by applicant cannot be given to Reference Court - Rejection of reference, proper. 	(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Suit against Municipal Council for recovery of amount with interest on completion of road repair work
HeadNote.description: Suit against Municipal Council for recovery of amount with interest on completion of road repair work - Work completed on 22-5-1990 - Limitation of three years from this date came to an end on 22-5-1993 - Even if one month's statutory notice period is allowed suit ought to have been filed on 8-5-1993 because notice was given on 8-4-1993 - Hence suit filed on 14-7-93 was clearly barred by limitation.	(Paras 2, 3)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Partition took place in 1928 between predecessors of plaintiff and defendants - House came in the share of plaintiff but was taken in forcible possession by defendants in 1928 itself - Defendants were in continuous possession thereafter - Documentary as well as oral evidence supporting defendants - Suit for possession by plaintiffs filed in 1955 is barred by limitation.	(Paras 4, 6)

heading: Suit claiming compensation
HeadNote.description: "Price of work done" - Term not applicable to professionals who merely provide service for a "fee" - Suit claiming compensation - Defendant trust engaging plaintiff Architect for providing professional consultancy services as an architect for various projects at different sites in Jammu-Fee of 2.5% of total project cost was fixed for providing such services - Said trust terminating services of Architect who filed suit claiming compensation - Held, case is not governed by Art.56 of J&K Act or Art.18 of 1963 Act - It is governed by residuary Article 119 of J&K Act and 113 of Limitation Act (1963). AIR 1931 All 752 and AIR 1973 Gauhati 27 - Foll.	(Paras 11 to 16)

heading: Legality
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Title by adverse possession - Legality - Two lands Gut nos.31 and 55 bequeathed to two brothers plaintiff and defendant no.1 - As per plaintiff, Gut no.31 and Gut no.55 were given for cultivation to him and defendant no.1 respectively under arrangement - Whereas defendants' case that Gut no.55 was sold to defendant no.2 with consent of plaintiff - Plaintiff sought partition and separate possession while defendant no.2 sought title by adverse possession of Gut No.55 - Court below decreed in favour of defendant no.2 on finding of continuous possession of 12 yrs. with knowledge of plaintiff - Not proper - Defendants themselves stated that sale agreement was with consent of plaintiff and thus, admitted title of plaintiff over suit land - Even defendant no.2 had not sought specific performance of sale agreement - On defendants' own saying that possession of defendant no.2 was permissive, it would not pass title to him - Plaintiff's claim for partition and separate possession needs to be considered.	(Paras 21, 22, 28, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37, 38)

heading: Bar of limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for compensation for breach of contract - Bar of limitation - Finance agreement between plaintiff and defendant for purchase of vehicle - Default in payment of installments by defendant on 20/5/1984 - Plaintiff exercised his right as per agreement and seized vehicle and sold it on 30/5/1985 - Suit for recovery of balance amount filed on 25/5/1988 - Held, default in payment of installment, constitutes breach of contract - Plaintiff's right to sue accrues on date of breach of contract i.e. 20/5/1984 and not on date of sale of vehicle - Suit filed beyond 3 yrs. from date of breach of contract - Barred by limitation.	(Paras 12, 15, 21)

heading: Suit for administration of estate of deceased
HeadNote.description:
Suit for administration of estate of deceased - Period of limitation for filing - Determination.

No straitjacket formula to ascertain period of limitation for filing administration suit. Limitation Act does not prescribe any specific Article for determining period of limitation in such suit. An administration suit could be by creditor for recovery of his debt or legal heirs. Therefore, period of limitation applicable to such suit would depend on who plaintiff is and what his specific cause of action is. It is for that reason that Limitation Act has not explicitly provided period of limitation for such suit. If suit is by creditor, cause of action is to recover debt, appropriate Article residuary Art.113 will be applicable and period of limitation would be three years. Whereas suit is by legal heir for legacy or for share of residue bequeathed by testator or for distributive share of property of an intestate, Article 106 will be applicable. Thus, pleadings and prayers of suit for administration would have to be analysed and thereafter, relevant Article is to be made applicable. Onus will be on party claiming benefit of shorter period of limitation to establish that case fell within special rule limiting period of shorter time. If in situation two articles of law may be wide enough to cover given right of suit and Court is unable to come to a conclusion that one applies more specifically than other, then it should lean in favour of application which would keep the right of suit alive in preference to that which would destroy it.  AIR 2006 HP 103, AIR 1955 Madras 369, 1902 (25) I.L.R. 361 (Madras), AIR 1953 SC 125, AIR 1964 MP 207, AIR 1962 Rajasthan 83 Ref. to.   [Para 12,17,21,22,23,25]

heading: Period of limitation
HeadNote.description:
Period of limitation - Once period of limitation starts, then it continues to run till the period is over.

In the present case, the cause of action for filing suit arose on 22-5-1990. Once period of limitation starts, then it continues to run till the period is over.  Issuing notice under Section 304 of Maharashtra Municipal Council Act enables the plaintiff to file the suit, but it does not extend the period of limitation excepting for the period of statutory notice.  It is not the cause of action in that sense of word that could enable the plaintiff to seek extension of three years limitation from the date of the notice or from the date of service of notice.  Therefore, the suit should have been filed on or before 22-5-1993 and even if the plaintiff was entitled to one month period for the notice under Section 304, one month's period expires on 8-5-1993 because the plaintiff had given notice under Section 304 on 8-4-1993. The suit should have been filed on the opening day after the Summer Vacation of 1993. The suit was filed on 14-7-1993 and, admittedly, therefore, the suit was barred by limitation.   [Para 6]

heading: Starting point
HeadNote.description:
Limitation for execution of decree - Computation of twelve years period - Starting point - Time would run from date decree becomes enforceable and not when decree becomes executable - Decree passed on 20.11.70 on receipt of commissioner's report - Petition for execution filed twelve years after 20.11.1970 is not maintainable - Fact that notice to furnish stamp papers was issued on 28.2.1972 and time was granted upto 17.3.1972 would not save limitation.

Art 136 of the Act of 1963 prescribes a twelve years period certain and what is relevant for Article 136 is, as to when the decree became enforceable and not when the decree became executable. The word 'enforceable' should be read in its literal sense. In the contextual facts, the final decree upon acceptance of the report of the Commissioner was passed on 20-11-1970, while it is true that notice to furnish stamp paper was issued on 28-2-1972 and the time granted was up to 17-3-1972 but that by itself will not take it out of the purview of Article 136 as regards the enforceability of the decree. Furnishing of stamped paper was an act entirely within the domain and control of the appellant and any delay in the matter of furnishing of the same cannot possibly be said to be putting a stop to the period of limitation being run - no one can take advantage of his own wrong : As a matter of fact, in the contextual facts no stamp paper was filed until 26-3-1984 - Does that mean and imply that the period of limitation as prescribed under Article 136 stands extended for a period of twelve years from 26th March, 1984? The answer if it be stated to be in the affirmative, would lead to an utter absurdity and a mockery of the provisions of the statute. Suspension of the period of limitation by reason of one's own failure cannot but be said to be a fallacious argument: though however suspension can be had when the decree is a conditional one in the sense that some extraneous events have to happen on the fulfilment of which alone it could be enforced - furnishing of stamped paper was entirely in the domain and power of the decree-holder and there was nothing to prevent him from acting in terms therewith and thus it cannot but be said that the decree was capable of being enforced on and from 20th November, 1970 and the twelve years period ought to be counted therefrom. Case law discussed. [Para 13]

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Plaintiffs claiming their right over suit property through an agreement entered with vendors in 2003 - Facts however show that even before selling suit property to vendors, original owners had sold it in 1989 to a society by registered conveyance deed - Even though the conveyance was cancelled in 1995 such cancellation was not valid being unilateral and not accorded by court - Further, both the plaintiffs and their vendors had knowledge of conveyance of 1989 when they purchased the suit property - Limitation period for original owners to seek declaration of title and setting aside of conveyance deed arose in 1989 and remained for 3 years in view of Art.58, Limitation Act - Same would also apply to plaintiffs being successors-in-title - Fact that plaintiffs entered agreement in 2003 and their rights interfered in 2007, notwithstanding - Suit filed by plaintiffs not maintainable - Fact that they had asked for injunction and specific performance and not for declaration, would also not save them as the reliefs claimed by them are consequential to declaratory relief. 			(Paras 25 to 31)

heading: No sale thereafter
HeadNote.description:
Suit for price of goods sold on credit - Last sale on 15-3-1975 - No sale thereafter - Part of price paid on 21-2-1979 and suit filed in 1981 - Held suit was for recovery of price of goods and not for accounts - Relevant date was date of last sale i.e. 15-3-1975 and not 21-2-1979 and as such suit filed in 1981 was barred by Art 14 and S.20 had no application.

AIR 1940 Bom 158 Relied on. (Para 3 ,7)

heading: Expression "date fixed for the performance"
HeadNote.description:
Expression "date fixed for the performance" - Is a crystallized notion - When date is fixed it means that there is a definite date for doing a particular act - 'Date' is suggestive of a specified date in the calender.

'Fixed' in essence means having final or crystallized form or character not subject to change or fluctuation. The expression 'date fixed for the performance' is a crystallized notion. This is clear from the fact that the second part "time from which period begins to run" refers to a case where no such date is fixed. To put it differently, when date is fixed it means that there is a definite date fixed for doing a particular act. Even in the second part the stress is on 'when the plaintiff has notice that performance is refused'. Here again, there is a definite point of time, when the plaintiff notices the refusal. In that sense both the parts refer to definite dates. So, there is no question of finding out an intention from other circumstances. Whether the date was fixed or not the plaintiff had notice that performance is refused and the date thereof are to be established with reference to materials and evidence to be brought on record. The expression 'date' used in Article 54 of the Schedule to the Act definitely is suggestive of a specified date in the calendar.   [Para 6,7]

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Generally speaking courts adopt a liberal approach for condonation of delay - High Court noticing that delay was result of inefficiency and ineptitude of government pleaders - It then graphically narrated clear dereliction of duty in not pursuing appeal deligently - Having so observed it inexplicably proceeded to condone unconscionable delay (of 3703 days) - Held, approach adopted by the High Court tends to show the absence of judicial balance and restraint, which a Judge is required to maintain whilst adjudicating any lis between the parties - Given the pathetic explanation by respondents in the application seeking condonation of delay High Court ought not to have condoned the delay. 2010(6) ALL MR 480 (S.C.) - Rel. on. (1964)2 SCR 363 - Ref. to.	(Paras 18, 24-26)

heading: Special Leave Petition
Delay in filing
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Special Leave Petition - Delay in filing - Condonation of - Petition filed by State Govt. - Delay of 663 days in filing petition - Delay sought to be condoned on ground of unavailability of documents and process of arranging documents - Object of causing delay is to obtain certificate of dismissal from Supreme Court to put quietus to issue and say that nothing could be done because highest Court has dismissed appeal - Such process is followed to save skin of officers who may be at default - Though on earlier occasions such practice and process was strongly deprecated, there seems to be no improvement - In none of cases any action is taken against officers, who sit on file and do nothing - It is time when concerned officer responsible for same, bears consequences - It is proposed that where there are inordinate delay that Government or state authorities coming to Apex Court must pay for wastage of judicial time which has its own value and it can be recovered from officers responsible - Looking to period of delay and casual manner in which delay application has been worded, delay cannot be condoned and costs of Rs.25,000/- imposed on State. (Paras 4, 5, 6, 7, 8)

heading: Condonation of delay
Prayer for
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Prayer for - Suit filed for declaration that deceased had worked with defendants till retirement - Delay of 380 days in filing written statement - Explanation given that office of defendants was undergoing renovation work - In process of shifting and rearranging files, it seems that due to oversight, papers of matter were kept in another file and hence, could not be traced - Delay is condoned by imposing exemplary cost. (Para 5)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 3778 days in filing application for recall of order passed in first appeal - Applicant claiming that delay occurred as her advocate was elevated as Hon’ble Judge of High Court and after another advocate engaged by her she came to know that appeal was dismissed for non-appearance of advocate - Applicant has not specifically stated that she got no communication from advocate before his elevation as Judge of High Court - Cause assigned by applicant appears to be after thought, concocted and is not sufficient - Delay cannot be condoned. (Paras 5, 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
Validity
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - In filing application u/S.340 of Cr.P.C. - Issuance of notice to person against whom complaint is proposed to be filed u/S.340 of Cr.P.C. - Validity - Plea of applicant that person is not entitled to notice in application for condonation of delay in filing complaint u/S.340 of Cr.P.C. as preliminary inquiry u/S.340(1) is  merely to form opinion whether complaint needs to be made u/S.340 - Expiry of period of limitation creates valuable right in favour of adversary to treat judgment and order or matter as case may be, having concluded and attained finality - Such right cannot be disturbed or interfered with without concerned party being heard after issuance of notice - Further, impugned order does not result into any manifest injustice on applicant as it only issued notice - Plea of applicant not tenable - Order issuing notice, proper. 	(Paras 15, 16, 17)

heading: Suit for eviction
HeadNote.description: Suit for eviction - Plea of bar of limitation - Plaintiff claiming that defendant unauthorisedly occupied suit hut by staking her claim to be mundkar - Period of limitation to file suit commenced from date when possession of defendant becomes adverse to plaintiff - Possession of defendant becomes adverse to plaintiff in 1996 when defendant took step to claim her right as mundkar in property of plaintiff - Defendant’s attempt to stake claim of mundkar failed before two revenue authorities and when it failed before Deputy Collector, plaintiff filed suit for eviction in 2006 - It is within period of limitation of 12 years prescribed under Limitation Act - Suit is not barred by limitation. 	(Para 9)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 2919 days in filing application to bring on record LR’s of deceased- respondent - Petitioners claiming that delay occurred as they were not aware about death of respondent and were not aware about details of family of deceased - Averments in application for condonation of delay were found to be incorrect - However, as petitioners were poor, illiterate tribals and if application is not allowed, it may result in miscarriage of justice since right to immovable property is involved in suit - Delay condoned with cost. (Paras 11, 12, 15)

(1908), O. 22, R. 3 – Condonation of delay – Delay of 2919 days in filing application to bring on record LR’s of deceased- respondent – Petitioners claiming that delay occurred as they were not aware about death of respondent – Averments in application for condonation of delay were found to be incorrect – However, as petitioners were poor, illiterate tribals and if application is not allowed, it may result in miscarriage of justice since right to immovable property is involved in suit – Delay condoned with cost.

heading: Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing written statement - Condonation of - Defendant claiming that delay occurred as writ of summons was not served upon him - Record not showing that writ of summons was served upon defendant through Court - Considering ambiguity about service of writ of summons upon defendant and to advance cause of justice - Delay condoned. 	(Paras 5, 7)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 433 days in filing appeal for enhancement of compensation - Delay occurred as applicant could not arrange funds to file appeal - If delay not condoned, grave prejudice would be caused to applicant - Further, applicant stated that he will not claim interest for period of delay, if compensation is enhanced - Delay condoned. 	(Para 5)

heading: Dismissal of suit
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Dismissal of suit - Application for setting aside order - Delay of 266 days in filing - Condonation of - Suit dismissed due to failure of petitioner to file affidavit of evidence for almost two years - Also delay condonation application filed belatedly after eight months - No sufficient cause shown in application for condonation of delay - Application is bereft of details - Considering conduct of petitioner and for failure to show sufficient cause to condone delay, delay cannot be condoned - Rejection of application, proper. 			(Para 6)

heading: Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing written statement - Condonation of - Delay of 185 days - Delay occurred due to indifferent health of petitioner - Nothing on record to indicate that delay was for any mala fide reasons or to intentionally delay proceedings - Delay condoned on payment of costs of Rs.15,000/-. 	(Paras 10, 14, 15)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Proof of “actual possession” - As per plaintiffs, while taking possession of land under development agreement, they also took possession of adjacent land of 799 sq.m. - Adverse possession claimed over said adjacent land - No positive evidence of possession brought on record - Plaintiffs only relied on defendant’s failure to challenge certain images and documents - Besides, possession of plaintiffs traceable to ‘encroachment’ - Injunction sought against defendants, cannot be allowed.
(2019) 11 SC 309, (1993) 3 SCC 161 Rel. on. (Paras 21, 23, 24, 26)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description:
Suit for possession - Limitation of 12 yrs. - Defendants entered suit flat in Dec. 1987 - Instant suit filed in Nov. 2012 - However, before said suit, defendants had also filed a suit claiming title on basis of sale deed which was dismissed in Nov. 2000 - Thus, possession of defendants became illegal in Nov. 2000 only - Suit filed by plaintiff in Nov. 2012 is well within limitation. 
AIR 2020 SC 4321, (2018) 1 SCC 610 Ref. to. (Paras 17, 18, 19, 20)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Delay of 2 years, 8 months and 16 days in filing appeal - Condonation sought on ground that delay occurred because of administrative reasons - No attempt made to explain delay, except stating that officer was transferred and post was vacant for long time and work was looked after by other in-charge officer - Govt. and its authorities must be treated as any other ordinary litigant and due diligence on part of individuals to approach court would apply with equal force to Govt. and its officers - No sufficient cause shown by respondent-corporation - Order condoning delay liable to be quashed and set aside. (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Condo nation of delay - Sufficient cause - Appeal filed with delay of 1 year and 7 months - Five medical certificates produced - However, authenticity of those certificates doubted as all of them were in same format with only change in dates - Correct and true facts not disclosed before appellate authority - Appellant even avoided to produce those certificates before writ court - Held, party who does not approach court with clean hands, not entitled for discretionary relief - Condonation denied. 		(Paras 19, 28)

heading: Adverse possession
Hindu Law
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Respondent took possession of suit property in 1960 - Respondent also claimed adoption as son by plaintiff's father in 1951 - Respondent mutated revenue record in 1960 immediately on death of plaintiff's father - Plaintiff filed suit for possession in 1975 - On facts of case respondent held to be in adverse possession - Law of limitation held applicable to debar plaintiff's suit - Adoption acted upon for a long period and all acted as if adoption is valid and proper - Adoption therefore could not be questioned - Evidence Act (1872) S.3, 101, 114 - Hindu Law - Adoption.

From the year 1960, the respondent had admittedly got his name mutated in the land revenue record and to the knowledge of the Appellant, Respondent continued in possession claiming to be the owner as clearly indicated in the "Mutation Entry" i.e.obviously the respondent was in possession hostile to the interest of Appellant and ever since 1960, the Respondent has been proclaiming that he is the owner of the said property and in any event, after the adoption, the share of the sister also devolved on him. The appellant all through out was aware of the mutation entry but the Appellant never took any steps to challenge the mutation entry, which, in fact, the Appellant ought to have done on or before 7th December, 1961.  Respondent had been holding the property in possession adverse to the interest of the Appellant openly and in a hostile manner and by getting the mutation entry changed as early as on 8th December, 1960 which was also never challenged.  Admittedly, the respondent has been claiming to be the owner ever since 8th December, 1960 to the knowledge of Appellant, whereas the suit was filed in the year 1975, which is clearly barred by the law of limitation.  The adoption has been acted upon for a long period cannot now be negatived. Both the lower Courts have erred in holding that the adoption was not proved. Long period of recognition as an adopted son raised a presumption in favour of valid adoption. (1870-72) 14 Moo Ind App67 (PC) Foll.		 [Para 27,28,31,32]

heading: Condonation of delay
Legality
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Rejection of application for - Legality - Delay in filing RTS appeal against order setting aside mutation entry standing in name of petitioner in appeal by Sub-Divisional Officer (SDO) on 4th July, 2012 - No intimation about said order given to petitioner though specific instruction given in order - Petitioner came to know about said order only on 4th Dec., 2012, he then applied for certified copy of order and preferred appeal on 22nd May, 2013 - Thus, cause of action would arise from date of knowledge on 4th December, 2012 - Petitioner failed to explain subsequent delay after date of knowledge - Therefore, SDO could not have declared registered deed of conveyance as illegal, fraudulent and could not have declared execution of various documents including rent receipt as fraudulent - However, gross injustice would be caused to petitioner if delay is not condoned - Therefore, delay condoned by imposing exemptionary cost. 2013 ALL SCR 3236 Ref. to. 			(Paras 23, 24, 25, 27, 28)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Delay of 546 days in filing appeal against ex-parte decree - Appeal filed after dismissal of application u/O.9 R.13 CPC - Appellant claiming that delay occurred as summons of case was not served on him and he pursued remedy u/O.9 R.13 - Delay can be condoned if appellant has bona fidely pursued remedy u/O.9 R.13 - Appellant has shown his bona fide by depositing Rs.25 lakhs in compliance with order of Court - Delay condoned on condition that appellant shall deposit Rs.20 lakhs.

	In present case, issue is whether time spent in pursuing remedy u/O.9, R.13 is to be considered while condoning delay in filing appeal u/S.96(2). If court is satisfied that defendant has adopted dilatory tactics or where there is lack of bona fide, court may decline to condone delay in filing appeal u/S.96(2). Whether the defendant has adopted dilatory tactics or where there is lack of bona fide in pursuing the remedy of appeal under S. 96(2) of the code after the dismissal of the application under O. 9, R. 13 CPC, is a question of fact and the same has to be considered depending upon the facts and circumstances of each case. 

	In the present case, the respondent-plaintiff has filed the Money Suit being for recovery of Rs.46,98,500/- together with interest and the said suit was decreed ex-parte. Appellant-defendant has filed application to condone the delay of 276 days in filing the application to set aside the ex-parte decree. In the said application, the appellant has stated that he has been residing at Chennai; whereas the notice was served at Trichy and therefore, he did not have knowledge about the filing of the said suit and the ex-parte decree was passed. The said application u/O.9, R. 13 was dismissed. Thereafter, the appellant has preferred the first appeal with the application to condone the delay of 546 days in filing the first appeal. There was already delay of 276 days in filing the application to set aside the ex-parte decree. Pursuing the proceedings in the application filed under O. 9, R. 13 CPC has caused further delay of 270 days. Thus, there has been a total delay of about 546 days in filing the first appeal. The appellant has shown his bona fide by depositing Rs.25,00,000/- in compliance with the orders of this Court. The said amount of Rs.25,00,000/- was permitted to be withdrawn by the respondent-plaintiff. Considering the facts and circumstances of the case and in the interest of justice, the appellant deserves an opportunity to put forth his defence in the suit for recovery of money. But to avail this opportunity, he must deposit the balance amount of Rs.20,00,000/- as a condition precedent for condonation of delay. Delay condoned on condition that appellant deposit Rs.20,00,000/-.	 [Para 15,17,18,19,20]

heading: Applicability
namely
HeadNote.description:
Applicability - Suit for declaration of vested rights in trust property i.e. Temple - Plaintiffs claim based on Grant/Sanad issued by Ruler, Adilshah Nizam in favour of ancestors - Allegation that ancestors of defendants had illegally taken over control of suit Temple somewhere in 1950 - Held, in the instant case, plaintiffs themselves having contended that suit temple never vested in defendants S.10 could not be invoked - That apart, trust suit was filed for relief of declaration and injunction but not for possession - Exemption u/s.10 was not available and Limitation Act would apply.

On bare reading of section 10 of the Limitation Act, it is clear that the provisions of this Act can be invoked against any person in whom the property has become vested for a specific purpose or his legal representatives or assigns not being assigns for valuable consideration. It applies to 3 categories of reliefs - namely - to follow the Trust property or its proceeds or for account of the Trust property or its proceeds. Thus, these provisions apply only against a person on whom the property has become vested for any specific purpose. From the facts pleaded in the plaint by the appellant, it is clear that the property of the said Temple has not become vested with the original defendants/respondents for any specific purpose or so. This fact is further clear from the prayer clauses (a) to (c) of the plaint. The relief claimed by the appellants is for the declaration of assertion of their vested rights and for consequential reliefs of injunction and not for the possession. In such circumstances, it cannot be accepted that the provisions of section 10 of the Limitation Act will be applicable to the suit instituted in the Court and exempted from the operation of Limitation Act, 1963, as urged.  [Para 6,7]

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration and injunction - Plaintiffs claimed right to manage suit Temple and to collect offerings by devotees - Such claim was based on vested rights of their ancestors - It was alleged that ancestors of defendants had illegally taken over control of suit Temple in 1950 - Ancestors of plaintiffs took no action thereafter - However, plaintiffs when came to know about their rights in 1971, filed a suit seeking abovesaid reliefs - Limitation - Suit not being for possession, Art.107 would not apply - Art.58 would apply under which suit had to be filed within 3 years of the date on which right to sue accrued to plaintiffs or their ancestors - Suit for declaration in 1971 was therefore time barred - Being so, claim as to consequential relief of injunction also did not survive. AIR 1959 SC 798 - Rel. on. AIR 2005 SC 1556 - Disting.	(Paras 15 to 18)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of money - Limitation - Suit filed against Government Officer for work performed by him in his official capacity - Period of notice issued under S.80 of Civil P.C. can be deducted in calculating period of limitation - Held, application under S.5 for condonation of delay is not necessary for that purpose. 1973(1) S.C.C. 115 - Ref. to.		(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Limitation
Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Suit for possession - Contention that defendants are in possession of suit property since 1961 - Suit should have been filed within 12 years from 1961 - There is no averment in this regard by defendants - Therefore issue of limitation was not framed by Trial Court - Further plaintiff's contention was accepted that cause of action arose in 2002 when defendants refused to vacate premises - Contention regarding limitation liable to be rejected.  (Para 8)

heading: Suit for declaration that plaintiff is tenant and for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration that plaintiff is tenant and for possession - Relationship governed by Rent Act - Time will begin to run only from express denial of tenancy rights even in respect of relief of declaration - Suit was not barred by limitation as defendant was not denying tenancy rights even after suit was filed. (Para 19)

heading: Evidence Act (1872), Ss.62, 64
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), Ss.62, 64 - Suit for possession by landlord - Whether barred by limitation - Tenant claiming that suit is barred on basis of notice served by landlord in proceedings before reference court - Said notice was never produced in evidence in suit for possession either in form of primary or secondary evidence - Reference to such notice as starting point of limitation is clearly erroneous - Landlord has filed suit for possession on basis of determination of tenancy - Suit is governed by Art.67 - Landlord has filed suit within 12 years of determination of lease by efflux of time - Suit not barred by limitation. 	(Paras 28, 38, 39)

heading: Dismissal
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), Ss.62, 64 - Suit for possession by landlord - Dismissal - On ground of bar of limitation u/Arts.65, 66 - Tenant claiming adverse possession over suit property - However, failed to lead any evidence of hostile possession to knowledge of true owner - Tenant failed to prove adverse possession - Further, tenant has not proved forfeiture of tenancy prior to expiry of lease period - Dismissal of suit being barred by limitation u/Arts.65, 66, improper. 	(Paras 39, 41, 42)

heading: Condonation of delay
Land acquisition case
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Land acquisition case - Delay in filing appeal against award - Incorrect statement made in application that applicant was not aware about stand taken by S.L.A.O. and about judgment and award - Held a party taking a false stand to get rid of the bar of limitation could not be encouraged to get any premium on the falsehood on his part by condoning delay. (1993)1 SCC 572 - Rel. on.	(Para 11)

heading: Condonation of delay
Discretion of Court
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Discretion of Court - High Court finding that applicant had made incorrect statement that it had no knowledge about award passed by Reference Court in land acquisition case - Held High Court ought not to have exercised its discretion in favour of condoning delay of 1724 days.	(Para 13)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Delay of 1724 days in filing appeal against award in land acquisition case - No acceptable reason given - Application based on incorrect statement that applicant was not aware of judgment and award - Dragging land losers to Court years after termination of legal proceedings without proper explanation for delay serves no public interest - Delay ought not to be condoned.	(Para 22)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Limitation law is same for both citizen and governmental authorities - Government would be entitled to certain amount of latitude if acts of collusion or fraud on the part of its officers or agents is pleaded and proved.	(Para 24)

heading: Acknowledgement
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.137 - Acknowledgement - No specific pleadings by plaintiffs claiming any benefit of S.19 to start fresh period of limitation - Nor necessary facts brought on record to enable Court to consider claim u/S.19 of Limitation Act - No error on part of Supreme Court holding that suit of plaintiff was barred by time - Review petition dismissed. 			(Para 19)

heading: Applicability
Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Applicability - Ingredients of two sections are different - Power to excuse delay under S.5 is discretionary while exclusion of time under S.14 is mandatory.

There is fundamental distinction between the discretion to be exercised under Section 5 of the Limitation Act and exclusion of the time provided in Section 14 of the said Act.  The power to excuse delay and grant an extension of time under Section 5 is discretionary whereas under Section 14, exclusion of time is mandatory, if the requisite conditions are satisfied.  Section 5 is broader in its sweep, than Section 14 in the sense that a number of widely different reasons can be advanced and established to show that there was sufficient cause in not filing the appeal or the application within time.  The ingredients in respect of Section 5 and 14 are different.  The effect of Section 14 is that in order to ascertain what is the date of expiration of the "prescribed period", the days excluded from operating by way of limitation, have to be added to what is primarily the period of limitation prescribed.   [Para 32]

heading: Pleadings and proof
Adverse possession

Two articles are different from each other.

Art.96 of 1963 Act and Art.134-B of the 1908 Act are different from each other in so far as while under the 1908 Act, 12 years was to run from the death, resignation or removal of the transferor, under the 1963 Act, the said period of 12 years was to run from the date of death, resignation or removal of the transferor or the date of appointment of the plaintiff as manager of the endowment, whichever was later.   [Para 19]

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Period of limitation for suits under 1908 Act already expired before commencement of 1963 Act - Suits cannot be instituted by taking the plea that the same was within limitation under 1963 Act.			(Para 19)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Plea of adverse possession cannot be said to be a pure question of law - It can be said to be a mixed question of law and fact - A party setting up such plea must plead and establish that its possession was adequate in publicity, in continuity and for the statutory period of 12 years - It is sufficient that the possession to be overt and without any attempt at concealment so that a person against whom time is running ought if he exercises due vigilance to be aware of what is happening.

For application of doctrine of adverse possession, it is to be clarified that doctrine of adverse possession essentially operates by default. When the property is sought to be claimed by third party, ordinarily the third party would not have any right to that property. However, it is only on the ground that third party has set up a title to the knowledge of the true owner and continued in uninterrupted possession or in hostile possession of that property for over 12 years. Thus, law takes into account the fact that true owner has by virtue of his in-action, lack of action during the entire period of 12 years time, does nothing to reclaim the property and has allowed a right to accrue to the party in possession. These are factors usually that confer benefit of the right of adverse possession. This principle chiefly presupposes the fact that there is no other right available to the party claiming adverse possession. Thus, absence of no better rights in relation to such property in favour of the party, setting up a plea of adverse possession, is significant. Such plea of adverse possession has to be pleaded sufficiently and clearly by the party concerned. All facts need to be pleaded by the party concerned, if such party seeks benefit of doctrine of adverse possession and acquisition of title to such property, which undisputedly not owned by such party and to which no better right stands with party claiming benefit of such plea of adverse possession. The plea of adverse possession cannot be said to be a pure question of law. It can be said to be a mixed question of law and fact. A party setting up such plea must plead and establish that its possession was adequate in publicity, in continuity and for the statutory period of 12 years. It is sufficient that the possession to be overt and without any attempt at concealment so that a person against whom time is running ought if he exercises due vigilance to be aware of what is happening. Thus, there must be evidence of open assertion of hostile title occupied with exclusive possession and enjoyment to the knowledge of the other, i.e. true owner of the property. Such party, setting up plea of adverse possession must establish that it's possession was adverse to the knowledge of the real owner and denying the title of the real owner. Commencement of such adverse possession that is pointed out must be pleaded and proved for counting such statutory period of 12 years. It is thus clear that the person, who enters permissive possession, cannot plead acquisition of such title by principles of adverse possession. Facts may differ from case to case. 2007 ALL SCR 2209 - Ref. to.  [Para 8,9]

heading: Plea of adverse possession and tenancy
HeadNote.description: Plea of adverse possession and tenancy - These two pleas cannot go hand in hand unless it is pleaded and proved by the defendants as to when they surrendered possession as tenant and commencement of date of possession by principles of adverse possession.	(Para 9)

heading: Setting aside of ex parte decree
HeadNote.description:
Setting aside of ex parte decree - Limitation of 30 days for filing application - Service of summons by substituted service - Limitation commences from date of knowledge of decree.

In terms of Section 123 of the Limitation Act an application for setting aside the exparte decree can be filed within 30 days from the date of the decree, but where the summons or notice was not duly served, it can be filed within 30 days from the date of knowledge of the decree to the applicant. The explanation to Section 123 further clearly provides that substituted service under Order V, Rule 20 shall not be deemed to be due service. In other words, in case of service of summons by substituted service under Order V, Rule 20 of C.P.C. the period of 30 days for setting aside the exparte decree is to be counted only from the date of acquisition of knowledge of the decree by the applicant. In the instant case the application was filed within 30 days of knowledge of decree and hence it was within time.  [Para 6]

heading: Partition suit
