HeadNote.description: Partition suit - Prayer therein that will executed by deceased predecessor be declared  null and void found unnecessary - Suit filed beyond three years of knowledge of execution of will to plaintiffs - Not barred by limitation. (Para 14)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Suit seeking declaration that agreement stood abdicated or given up or is void or voidable - Agreement expired more than three years before filing of suit - It is barred by limitation - Art.65 has no application since prayer for possession is only a consequential relief in a suit for declaration that agreement for sale is void. (Paras 5,7)

heading: Exclusion of time taken by plaintiff in proceeding bona fide in court without jurisdiction
HeadNote.description: Exclusion of time taken by plaintiff in proceeding bona fide in court without jurisdiction - Material facts necessary for exclusion must be specifically pleaded - Reliefs in two proceedings distinct and based on different causes of action - Prior proceedings not in good faith or bona fide - S.14 benefit cannot be granted. (Para 8)

heading: Suit for cancellation or setting aside of instrument
HeadNote.description: Suit for cancellation or setting aside of instrument - Limitation would not be more than 3 years - Inordinate delay on part of petitioner, held, is an additional factor to refuse to exercise discretion in favour of the petitioner. AIR 1964 SC 1006 and 2008(10) SCALE 449 - Rel. on.	(Paras 39, 41, 69)

heading: Suit for specific performance of agreement to sale
HeadNote.description:
Suit for specific performance of agreement to sale - Filed after 15 yrs. of agreement of sale - Liable to be dismissed as time barred.

Under the provisions of Section 46 of the Contract Act no time is specified for performance of promise, but the contract must be performed within a reasonable time. What is the reasonable time is to be seen in Article 54 of the Limitation Act. For specific performance of contract three years time is prescribed under the said Article and, therefore, reasonable time means three years. Therefore, in the instant case, the sale deed should have been executed by the respondent/plaintiff within one month from the date of agreement of sale by obtaining permission from the authority. There was no such attempt to obtain permission. It is clear that from the date of agreement till enforcement of Maharashtra Act 41 of 1977, there was restriction on sale or transfer without prior permission of the Collector. After introduction of Section 31-AB by way of said Act of 41 of 1977, the said restriction was removed and, therefore, the sale deed should have been executed within one month. Even if the reasonable time is taken into consideration to execute the sale deed, from the date of introduction of Section 31-AB in the Maharashtra Act 41 of 1977, reasonable time of three years will expire in 1980. However, the suit is filed in 1981. Therefore, the trial Court was absolutely right in holding that the suit was time barred as the same was not filed within reasonable time.  Thus order of lower appellate Court holding suit was within limitation, liable to be set aside.							 [Para 25,26,27]

heading: Acknowledgement
Agreement to sell
HeadNote.description: Acknowledgement - Agreement to sell - Suit for specific performance - Endorsement about receipt of payment, not saying anything about liability or responsibility of defendants to execute sale deed - Alleged payments will not extend period of limitation for plaintiffs - Moreover, all those five endorsements allegedly signed by only one defendant without acknowledgement for and on behalf of others.	(Para 15)

heading: Acknowledgement
HeadNote.description: Acknowledgement - Extension of period of limitation - Acknowledgement should be made before expiration of period of limitation for suit.	(Para 16)

heading: Suit for declaration of title to suit property
HeadNote.description:
Suit for declaration of title to suit property - Time runs from date when right to sue first accrues.

Article 58 being a residuary article relating to declaratory suit, it will now govern all suits for declaration which were not covered by any other article and covered by article 120 of Limitation Act of 1908. The language of third column of Article 58 makes it clear that time runs from the date when right to sue first accrues.  [Para 54]

The suit land was purchased by defendant on request of plaintiff and from amount recovered from the plaintiff. Since the plaintiff was in military service the land was purchased in the name of defendant his uncle as Benami. His title was threatened by the behaviour of defendant and he filed suit for declaration of title within period of limitation after accrual of cause of action for first time. Consequently the suit was not barred.	  [Para 56]

Every threat during the earlier period of plaintiff's right, however, ineffective and innocuous it was, could not be considered to be a clear and unequivocal threat so as to compell plaintiff to file suit till the year 1973. It was in the year 1973 defendant made an attempt to occupy the suit plot to establish his possession over it by erecting fencing around the suit plot. This attempt on the part of the defendant was thwarted by the interruption by the Watchman of plaintiff. It is also significant to note that defendant made this attempt very clandestinely in the sense knowing that plaintiff was away from the town. Then plaintiff realised that all silence till 1973 on the part of defendant was not innocuous and intention to infringe plaintiff's right over the suit plot was hidden or persisting in the mind of defendant. The attempt on the part of the defendant in the month of May 1973 was the outcome of that intention of the defendant to infringe plaintiff's right and title over the suit plot. In substance it was only in the year 1973 that plaintiff realised unequivocal interruption, infringement to the title over the suit property by the defendant and that is the time when the right to sue accrued and as such plaintiff filed in fact the suit in the year 1974. Therefore, the suit filed by the plaintiff was well within the limitation. The contention raised by learned counsel for appellant that suit is barred by limitation is absolutely incorrect. Therefore, the suit filed by plaintiff in 1974 was well within time.  [Para 56]

heading: Adverse possession
Permissive possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Permissive possession - Can not be converted into an adverse possession unless it is proved that the person in possession asserted an adverse title to the property to the knowledge of true owners for a period of 12 years or more.

Adverse possession means possession of the land or interest in the land by a wrong man against the will of the right man. Adverse possession, as its words imply, must be actual possession of another's land with intention to hold it and claim it as of his own, to the exclusion of the rightful owner.  It must commence with the wrongful possession of the rightful owner at some particular time and must commence, in wrong against right.  It must be actual, open, notorious and hostile under claim of right, continuous and exclusive and maintained for the statutory period.  Possession and adverse possession do not mean the same thing.  Mere user of the property cannot be taken as a definite assertion of the proprietory rights, there must be definite quality in the possession before it can be called adverse and some act of unequivocal character to put the owner on guard. There cannot be adverse possession if the claimant himself do not know that he was occupying somebody's land. However, permissive possession cannot be converted into adverse possession unless it is proved that the person in possession asserted an adverse title to the property, to the knowledge of the true owners for a period of 12 years or more.   [Para 17,18]

heading: Ex parte decree
Setting aside of
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Ex parte decree - Setting aside of - Delay in filing application - Caused due to negligence of lawyer/his clerk - Sufficient cause - Delay condoned. Civil P.C. (1908), O.9, R.13.			(Para 11)

heading: Suit for recovery of money
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of money - Deficiency in Court fee - Suit would be deemed to have been instituted on date deficiency was made good - Limitation would run from that date. (Para 9)

heading: Period for setting aside ex parte decree
HeadNote.description: Period for setting aside ex parte decree - Application to set aside ex parte decree filed immediately after acquiring knowledge of passing of said decree - Cannot be barred by Limitation. 2001(2) Mh.L.J. 955 - Distinguished.	(Para 4)

heading: Condonation of delay
Expression "sufficient cause"
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Expression "sufficient cause" - Expression is adequately elastic to enable the court to apply the law in meaningful manner which subserves the ends of justice. 2005 ALL MR (Cri) 1570 (S.C.) - Ref. to.			(Para 22)

heading: Title by adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Title by adverse possession - One co-owner claiming perfection of title by adverse possession against other co-owner by virtue of being in exclusive possession and cultivation of joint-ownership of suit land for more than 12 years - Held, since there was absolutely no evidence to prove ouster, Courts below have committed no error of law in holding that defendant had perfected his title by adverse possession.

Where co-owners, the possession of one being in law, the possession of all, it will not be possible for one co-owner to put an end to that possession by any secret intention in his mind.  So long as possession is that of a joint co-owner no question of any bar of limitation would arise during that period, and in the absence of ouster or exclusion the possession of one co-owner is not adverse to the other co-owner.  Whether ouster is proved depends upon the facts of each case.  The burden of proving ouster is on the person who claims to have ousted the others.  To establish ouster, it is necessary to prove the requisite animus, to prescribe title adversely to the other co-sharer.  There must be positive evidence of possession hostile to the other co-owners and this hostile animus must be brought to the knowledge of the co-owner against whom ouster is claimed.  Ouster is a positive matter; and the hostile animus necessary to constitute ouster must also be a positive matter.  It is a matter involving action, it cannot be mere inaction.  If the co-owner in possession did not give a share of the income to the co-owner out of possession merely because the latter did not ask for it, then such animus may be only a negative animus.  On the other hand, if the evidence shows that even if the co-owner out of possession demanded his share, the co-owner in possession would not have given him a share , then the animus is positive, in the sense that it is indicative of an animus to exclude.  For entertaining a hostile animus to ouster the real owner, the person in possession need not know who the real owner is, if he has the animus to hold the property as his against whole world including the real owner, whoever he be, known or unknown, the animus is sufficiently hostile to exclude the real owner also.

The test is whether the co-owner in possession has openly and unequivocally and to the knowledge of the other co-owners denied their title to the property.  A party who sets up a hostile title to the exclusion of co-heirs must be definite and unequivocal in his assertion.  When the assertions are in the nature of 'hide and seek', that is to say, mutually contradictory and merely intended for the purpose of taking a tractical advantage out of a litiguous situation, it cannot be considered as an assertion of hostile title adequate for the purpose of becoming the starting point in the acquisition of title by adverse possession.  In the present case, there is absolutely no evidence to prove the ouster and both the Courts below have committed an error of law in coming to the conclusion that the defendant has perfected his title by adverse possession resulting into miscarriage of justice. 	         [Para 21,22]

heading: Followed.	 [Para 23]
HeadNote.description:
Jurisdiction of High Court to interfere in finding of fact by Courts below - Both Courts below recording concurrent finding of perfection of title to suit land by defendent by adverse possession - Held, where finding is recorded without any legal evidence on record, or on misreading of evidence, or suffers from any legal infirmity which materially prejudices case of one of the parties, or finding is perverse, High Court can set aside such finding and take a different view.

It is not possible to accept the contention the defendant that the concurrent finding recorded by both the Courts below on the issue of adverse possession needs no interference and this Court cannot exercise jurisdiction under Section 100 of the Code of Civil Procedure for setting aside the judgment and decree passed by both the Courts below dismissing the suit.  This Court can definitely interfere if it is shown that the findings of the Courts below have no basis in any legal evidence on record or is based on misreading of evidence or suffers from legal infirmity which materially prejudices the case of one of the parties or the finding is perverse.  It is held that it is well settled that the High Court while considering the matter in exercise of its jurisdiction in second appeal or civil revision would not reverse the finding of fact as recorded by both the courts below but it is not an absolute proposition; in a case where the finding is recorded without any legal evidence on record, or on misreading of evidence, or suffers from any legal infirmity which materially prejudices the case of one of the parties or the finding is perverse, it would be open for the High Court to set aside such a finding and to take a different view.  In the present case, the concurrent finding recorded by both the Courts below appears to have been recorded without any legal evidence on record, on misreading of evidence and suffers from legal infirmity when there is no evidence to prove the ouster and, therefore, cannot be sustained in law.  Thus, the co-owner cannot claim title to the joint ownership property by way of adverse possession as against other co-owner without an overt denial of title of the latter by the person in possession.  (2002)2 SCC 440 - Followed.	 [Para 23]

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Whether governed by Art.64 or 65 - To be decided on basis of pleadings - In earlier title suit defendant admitted that he was in possession till 1971 - Present suit filed in 1984 by him for possession on discontinuance of possession would be governed by Art.64 - Said suit having been filed 13 years after dispossession would be barred by limitation - Defendant appellant was not entitled to benefit of S.14.			(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Art.65 is residuary article - Applies to suits for possession not otherwise provided for - Suit based on title in which there is no allegation of prior possession and subsequent dispossession alone can fall within scope of Art.65.	(Para 9)

heading: Scope and applicability of S.43 of Limitation Act
HeadNote.description:
Scope and applicability of S.43 of Limitation Act - S.43 applicable to arbitrations and not to proceedings under S.34(3) of Arbitration and Conciliation Act - Proceedings before Arbitrator and proceedings before Court under S.34(3) cannot be equated.

Section 43 of the Act will be applicable to the arbitrations and not to the proceedings before the Court taken u/s.34 of the Act.  An useful reference can be made to the scope of Indian Limitation Act.  This (Act) primarily applies to suits, appeals and applications and it has in term no application to the "arbitration proceedings" as it is not a suit. Section 3 of the Limitation Act provides that subject to the provisions contained in Sections 4 to 24 (inclusive) every suit instituted, appeal preferred, and applications made after the prescribed period shall be dismissed although the limitation has not been set up as defence.  The proceeding before the Arbitrator/s is not a suit, appeal or application and in terms of Section 3 can have no application thereto. To overcome this aspect, Section 43 is incorporated in the Act. Expiry of the period of limitation prescribed for a suit does not destroy the right : it only bars the remedy for enforcement of a right in a Court of law.  It cannot, therefore, be said that the provisions of the Limitation Act prevent an arbitrator/s or Arbitral Tribunal from adjudicating upon the claim which if brought before the Court of law may be barred by limitation, but it may proceed to consider at times even to entertain a claim which is barred by period of limitation.  Therefore, the arbitral proceedings are not suit and the arbitral Tribunal is not a Court.  By Section 43 of the Act, the provisions of Limitation Act are made applicable to the arbitrations. The proceedings before the Arbitrator and the proceedings before the Court u/s.34 cannot be equated and, therefore, Section 43 cannot be taken help of in construing Section 34 (3) of the Act.  [Para 20,21]

The provisions of Section 43 of the Act are only attracted to the proceedings before the arbitrators and the proceedings under section 34 of the Act are not the proceedings which are referred to under Section 43 of the Act. The Arbitrator before whom the proceedings were brought the claims which were barred by limitation have to be dismissed and for that purpose section 43 is to be construed and interpreted.  Therefore, the contention of Shri. Vayal that by virtue of Section 43 of the Act, the provisions of the Limitation Act are attracted in the application u/s.34, being without any substance, has to be rejected. [Para 22]

heading: Partnership at Will
Notice of dissolution
HeadNote.description: Partnership at Will - Notice of dissolution - Refusal to accept notice - Limitation for filing suit - Time starts running from such date - Suit filed beyond three years of that date is barred by limitation.	(Para 15)

heading: Appeal filed against order which was alleged to be null and void
HeadNote.description: Appeal filed against order which was alleged to be null and void - Appeal filed after 24 years without citing any cause, good, bad or indifferent, much less sufficient cause - Is not maintainable. (Para 6)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Person occupying premises being permitted by landlord - They cannot claim title to property by adverse possession.

It is well settled law that if once possession is permissive possession, then it cannot be converted into adverse possession unless the person in possession first surrenders the possession to the owner of the property and then reenters into the property to claim hostile title.  [Para 21,33]

It is found that when the two defendants came into possession of the property because of the permission given by land lady and they had not surrendered the possession to her and had not reentered into the property, they cannot claim title by adverse possession. They have utterly failed to prove that they have acquired title by adverse possession.  [Para 52,53]

heading: Insurance claim
HeadNote.description: Exclusion of time in pursuing bona fide remedy - Insurance claim - Fire occurred on 10.2.90 - Insurance Company informed orally immediately and in writing on 17.2.90 - Claim declined on 18.4.90 - Owner approached National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission on 20.8.91 - Commission rejected claim on 23.3.92 on ground that there was no deficiency in service and hence it had no jurisdiction - Supreme Court declined to interfere in appeal by order dt.29.1.93 - Held that resort by appellant to NCDRC was bona fide and in good faith - Appellant entitled to exclusion of period from 24.8.91 to 30.9.92 - Hence suit before civil Court filed on 29.4.93 was within limitation.(1998) 8 SCC 357 relied upon.	(Para 10)

heading: Title by adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Title by adverse possession - Respondent and his father were managing properties and were in position of Mutawallis - They cannot claim title by adverse possession. (Paras 30-32)

heading: Explanation
HeadNote.description: Explanation - Respondent a donee from his father and not a transferee for valuable consideration - Suit for recovery of possession from him - Can be filed without any limitation as to time in view of S.10. (Para 40)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Undertaking owned by large corporations or by Union or State Governments - Decision making process is proverbially slow - Court should wait and not proceed to pass ex parte decree immediately on expiry of ten days from service of writ of summons.

The period of ten days is a very short period particularly for the undertakings which are owned by large Corporations or State Governments or Union of India. In the large organisations decisions are not taken as quickly as they perhaps are taken by Proprietary or Partnership firms or Small Private Organisations. It takes more than ten days to move the papers from even the despatch department to the appropriate table. The State machinery, as is well known, moves like a royal elephant. It is therefore, unrealistic to expect a Vakalatnama to be filed in a Court of law within such a short period of ten days. According to me, it is rather too early to give an ex-parte decree immediately after expiry of ten days from the date of the service of the Writ of Summons. It would be always advisable to wait for a reasonable period.  [Para 6]

heading: Applicability
Transposition of parties
HeadNote.description:
Applicability - Transposition of parties - Section has no application.

Section 21 has no application to cases of transposition of parties. Since transposition also involves addition of a plaintiff or a defendant as the case may be, into the suit as originally filed, sub-sec. (2) of S. 21 of the Limitation Act applies only to those cases where the claim of the person transposed as plaintiff can be sustained on the plaintiff as originally filed or where person remaining as a plaintiff after the said transposition can sustain his claim against the transposed defendant on the basis of the plaint as originally filed. For sub-sec. (2) to apply all that is necessary is that suit as filed originally should remain the same after the transposition of the plaintiff and there should be no addition to its subject matter. Where a suit as originally filed is properly framed with the proper parties on record the mere change of a party from array of defendants to that of plaintiff under Order 1 Rule 10 of the Civil Procedure Code will not make him a new plaintiff and will not bring the case within this Section and in such a case sub-section (2) will not apply.  [Para 9]

heading: Possession of co-owners
HeadNote.description:
Possession of co-owners - Co-owner or co-sharer of property can never claim ownership by adverse possession of the other share.  AIR 1956 SC 548 and AIR 1984 Gujrat 32 foll.

Adverse possession - Possession of co-owners. (Para 10)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Single appeal filed against decreeing of suit and dismissal of counter claims - Counter claims were tried alongwith suit - Common judgment was passed - Appeal memo contains common grounds of challenge for both decree, counter claims - Question of limitation does not arise while filing appeal. (Para 13)

heading: Delay and laches
HeadNote.description: Delay and laches - Delay is different from laches - Laches is not simply running of time - Laches give rise to equities - Petitioners themselves acknowledged delay in challenging recovery proceedings - But, considering that number of their properties have already been sold by the bank and that petitioners were not totally indolent rather pursued their remedies before revenue authorities, held, petition cannot be dismissed on ground of laches.  (Paras 12, 13)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Suit for partition and separate possession - Defendant no.3 admitted that at time of death of deceased, deceased was possessing suit properties - Only after death of deceased defendant no.3 became owner - Cause of action arose for filing suit after death of deceased on 10-2-1995 - Suit filed in year 1995 is not barred by limitation. 			(Para 32)

heading: Application for condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Application for condonation of delay - Condition precedents for condonation of delay, stated. 

In Section 5 at two places the word "may" is used. This shows that the Court has discretionary power in this regard. Section 5 further shows that the party seeking extension of prescribed period is required to satisfy the Court that he had sufficient cause for not preferring the appeal/application and that arose within such period and continued thereafter. Thus, existence of sufficient cause is a condition for use of discretion by the Court.     [Para 12]

heading: Condonation of delay
Expression "sufficient cause"
Meaning of
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Expression "sufficient cause" - Meaning of - It means a cause which is beyond control of party invoking Section - Any cause which prevents parties approaching court within time, is sufficient.		 (Para 14)

heading: Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Delay in filing appeal - Condonation of - Suit was decided by holding that there was no cause of action for suit - In such case delay does not deserve to be condoned - No arguable case was made out - Also no sufficient cause was shown - Delay could not be condoned.		 (Paras 16, 18)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Suit for correction of revenue entries - However, as defendant disputed title of plaintiff and claimed Communidade as owner - Suit would be governed by Art.58 of Act - Communidade, an institution under control of State Govt. produced its record to support plea of its ownership - Record of Communidade held to be very old and even general survey was started in 1974-75 - Suit filed by plaintiff for correction of revenue entries after lapse of more than 20 yrs. - Held, barred by limitation.(Para 34)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - To file suit for recovery of money - On basis of dishonored cheque - Period of limitation to file suit commences from date of cheque and not from date of lending of money. 

	Art. 19 of the Act, 1963 applies to suits laid on the strength of original consideration and cannot be imported to a suit filed on a cheque issued by a borrower in discharge of debt incurred and which is later dishonoured. 
	Cause of action for a suit for money based on a dishonoured cheque cannot be said to be the same for a suit based on original consideration. Both are different since the sources determining the right and obligations of the parties to such suits are not at all the same. Right of a person to sue on original consideration accrues when there is commission of breach of promise. On the other hand, the position in the case of a suit filed on a dishonoured cheque stands, however, on a totally different footing. In order for a cause of action based on a dishonoured cheque to arise, the cheque must have been presented before the drawee Bank and the same got dishonoured. Therefore, a suit for money on a dishonoured cheque drawn by a borrower cannot be held to be governed by Art. 19 of the Act, 1963.
	Appropriate provision that applies to a suit instituted on dishonour of cheques can legally be Art. 35 alone wherein limitation commences from the date of the cheque.
	In the present case suit is filed within period of three years from date mentioned in cheques, suit is within period of limitation. 
2017 (4) KHC 601 Overruled.				(Paras 12, 13, 14, 15)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Difference between Arts.35 and 40 - Explained.

	Under S. 2(c) of the Act, 1963, a Bill of Exchange is defined as inclusive of a cheque also. The period of limitation for a suit on a dishonoured cheque ought to be traced from Art. 35 wherein limitation commences from the date of the cheque as distinct from Art. 40 where the commencement is from the date of dishonour. There appears to be an apparent distinction between Arts.35 and 40 though as per the definition of “Bill of Exchange” in S. 2(c) of the Act, 1963 and definition of ‘cheque’ in S. 6 of the N.I.Act, either of the instruments embraces the other. The cheque by all means is an order issued by the drawer thereof directing his banker for payment of money to a specific or definite individual or entity. A cheque cannot be drawn on a person other than a Banker. This is what mainly distinguishes a cheque from a Bill of Exchange. A Bill of Exchange as defined by S. 5 of the N.I.Act is an instrument in writing containing an unconditional order, directing a certain person who may not be a Banker to make payment of certain sum of money to a certain person or bearer of the instrument.
	Under the scheme of the N.I. Act, a Bill of Exchange is considered to be an instrument addressed to persons in general whereas a cheque could be drawn only on a specified banker. Unless this distinction maintained by the N.I.Act is perceived, suits embraced by Art. 40 are likely to be mistaken for those based on dishonoured cheques also. The expression “refusal to accept” in Art. 40 can naturally refer only to persons other than a bank since the act of refusing to accept a Bill of Exchange does not associate with a banker, though he may for various reasons refuse to honour a cheque. On the other hand, what we understand from the scheme of provisions in the N.I.Act is that the words ‘refusal to accept’ could fit in only with the context of Bills of Exchange refused to be honoured by the drawees. In view of this position, the appropriate provision that applies to a suit instituted on dishonour of cheques can legally be Art. 35 alone.				(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description:
Suit for possession - Concurrent finding recorded by courts below that plaintiffs established their title - Yet, the relief of possession not granted to plaintiffs on ground that plaintiffs could not prove permissive user of entire premises by defendant - Rather, there appears joint tenancy of parties in respect of one block of suit property - Held, as per Art.65 once the plaintiff establishes his title, he cannot be non-suited unless a better title is set up by defendants - No finding that defendants are having better title - Plaintiff therefore, entitled to relief of possession.

(1998) 1 SCC 614 Rel. on. 			 [Para 15,17,18]

heading: Adverse possession
Trustee
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Trustee - D was guardian of plaintiff and looked after her property since she was four years old - On D's death his son defendant got his name entered in Record of Rights in place of D and also got name of plaintiff deleted and this change was made even without any notice to plaintiff - Held, possession of defendant with respect to suit property was that of trustee and in such situation defendant could never claim adverse possession in respect of suit property. Trusts Act (1882), S.14. (Para 5)

heading: Adverse possession between co-sharers
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession between co-sharers - Mere non-participation in rent and profits of land of co-sharer does not amount to ouster so as to give title by adverse possession to other co-sharer in possession.
AIR 1981 S.C. 77 Referred. (Para 5)

heading: Application for removal of obstruction
HeadNote.description:
Application for removal of obstruction - Limitation.

It is now well settled that although an application for removal of obstruction is required to be taken within thirty days, there is nothing to prevent the decree-holder from making a successive application for possession and in case such an application is resisted, the limitation for filing the application for removal of the obstructions starts from the date of the second obstruction and not from the date of the initial obstruction. 1978 Mh.L.J. 519. Relied on.  [Para 16]

heading:
Limitation of 30 days -Not-applicable where neither any application under S.14(2) of the Arbitration Act is made or any application filed for making the award a rule of the court.
JT 1996(1) SC 265 Distinguished. (Para 7)
HeadNote.description:
Limitation of 30 days -Not-applicable where neither any application under S.14(2) of the Arbitration Act is made or any application filed for making the award a rule of the court.
JT 1996(1) SC 265 Distinguished. (Para 7)

heading: Delay in filing application for bringing heirs on record immediately after knowledge of death
HeadNote.description:
Delay in filing application for bringing heirs on record immediately after knowledge of death - Time spent in making enquiries to find out legal heirs - Respondent not disputing this position by filing affidavit - Delay ought to be condoned.
AIR 1987 SC 1353 Rel. On. (Para 3)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Appellant was prevented from filing appeal in time because of legal advice received by him - Differing legal advice could be a sufficient cause in a given case if appellant's conduct was otherwise bona fide.    (Para 40)

heading: Adverse possession
Claim of
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Claim of - Government does not enjoy any immunity or privilege.

The law of adverse possession branches out of the law of limitation. Article 65 states that if the possession for immovable property or any interest therein based on title is of 12 years, then the possession of the defendant becomes adverse to the plaintiff. A title by adverse possession can be prescribed also against the Government, so the Government does not enjoy any immunity or privilege where the adverse possession is claimed. However, some concession of longer period of claiming adverse possession is given in favour of the Government under Article 112 of the Limitation Act where the period of limitation to run is for 30 years. In the corresponding Article 149 of the Limitation Act of 1908 (old), it is made clear that the Article applies also to Government like a private person. The concept of adverse possession is borrowed from British Law. The common law recognizes the theory earlier of "nullum tempus occurrit regi", which means, no time affects the Crown. The reason for this was that the State should not suffer for the negligence of its officers or for their fraudulent hand-in-glove transactions with the adverse party. However, common law fixed a period of 60 years limitation in respect of suits on behalf of or against the Crown and the same was adopted by the Indian Law under Article 149 (Old) and subsequently by way of amendment period is reduced from 60 to 30 years under Article 112 (new). However, the reason for giving a longer period to the Government when a party claims adverse possession is obvious; because the Government is not one person but is a body of persons taking decisions following procedural wrangles and moving like a python who is very slow in its action. 			 [Para 14]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Cannot be proved piecemeal - It is to be pleaded with certainty and to the hilt.

There is no dispute that adverse possession must be proved for the whole period which is claimed. It cannot be proved piecemeal. There must be proof as to the date, time and manner in which the possession became open and adverse and the owner is out of the possession. It is to be remembered that a person pleading adverse possession cannot claim equity in his favour since he is trying to defeat the rights of the true owner. The acquisition by adverse possession is an exception to law of acquisition of title through lawful means and therefore, it is to be pleaded with certainty and to be proved to the hilt. Thus, for the claim of adverse possession, a person should be in continuous, exclusive, open and peaceful possession for 12 years when he claims against the private parties and for 30 years, when he claims against the Government. 	 [Para 14]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Is not a pure question of law but blended with facts.

A person who claims adverse possession against a private person and the Government has to establish his claim by adducing sufficient evidence on the point that he was enjoying continuous, uninterrupted, peaceful possession for a period of 12 and 30 years respectively. Thus, the adverse possession is not a pure question of law but blended with facts. On this background, as First Appeal is a continuation of the suit, the documentary as well as oral evidence adduced by the plaintiffs as well as the defendants is required to be looked into.   [Para 26]

heading: Suit for adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Suit for adverse possession - Proof of documents relied on - Strict proof is not required in civil suit.

A person who relies on document has to prove the contents therein. Unless the contents in the documents are proved, it cannot be admitted and read in the evidence. In admitting or exhibiting the document, parties are made aware that the court is going to take into account the contents therein for the purpose of determining the issues before the Court. It is a responsibility of the Court while accepting the document in the evidence, i.e., admitting the same in the evidence, to exhibit it so that the evidence is identified. Thus, the parties are aware that they must meet that evidence. This basic procedure of proving the documents thus ensures fair trial to the parties. No strict proof of the facts is required in civil trial. On the basis of preponderance of probabilities which are brought before the Court, the parties can prove their assertions. However, a party who asserts a case has to prove it. In a civil suit also, the initial burden is on the plaintiff and never on the defendants but onus shifts after plaintiff discharges his burden to prove his case and then the defendants' evidence can be looked into. 	 [Para 27]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Tacking of periods of possession by two successive trespassers is permissible when one derives title from the other. AIR 1965 SC 1553, (1920) Vol XL III 165 (All), (1976) 1 MLJ 1288, AIR 1926 All 697 Rel. on. 	(Para 31)

heading: Adverse possession of Govt. land
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession of Govt. land - Proof of.

A person who claims adverse possession has to show the exclusion of the possession of the owner. In the present case, the Government was throughout in the possession, however, the appellants oft and on might have been in possession of some portion of land by way of encroachment, but the Government did not lose its possession. To claim adverse possession, it is necessary to establish that the Government was excluded from the possession. 	 [Para 46]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Suit for declaration of suit property - Plaintiff purchasing suit property from original owner - Defendant purchasing suit property from son of original owner and claiming title to suit property by adverse possession - Held, purchase of suit land by defendant by itself destroyed his claim as by the purchase he admitted that he had no title to suit property. (Para 7)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Wrong fixation of pay - Limitation - Order wrongly fixing pay of petitioner passed on 1st December, 1997 - But, it was challenged only on 16th June, 1999 - Barred by limitation. (Para 5)

heading: Adverse possession
Means hostile assertion
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Means hostile assertion - possession expressly or impliedly in denial of title of true ownr - Possession which can be referred to lawful title not considered adverse possession of a member of a Joint Family cannot be adverse to other members - Mere mutation not sufficient. (Para 12,13,14)

heading: Condonation of delay
Discretionary powers u/s.5
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Discretionary powers u/s.5 - Not to be exercised by court so as to help a party which is negligent and does not present a bona fide case.
2012(2) ALL MR 505, 2011 ALL SCR 487, (1972) 1 SCC 366 Ref. to. (Para 12)

heading: Suit by minor born in 1976 through his mother, challenging sale of property made by father on 6-5-1978, on ground that there was no legal necessity
HeadNote.description: Suit by minor born in 1976 through his mother, challenging sale of property made by father on 6-5-1978, on ground that there was no legal necessity - Suit filed on 29-9-1983 - Held, trial judge committed error in holding that suit was barred by limitation - Plaintiff being minor right to sue remains postponed and suit even after period of three years from date of execution of sale deed was perfectly within limitation. (Para 3)

heading: Restitution of possession
Jurisdiction to order
HeadNote.description: Restitution of possession - Jurisdiction to order - Restitution cannot be granted by Supreme Court - It is for executing court to decide whether restitution petition, if any filed, is within limitation or not - It is only the court which passed original decree, can order restitution.	(Para 22)

heading: Application
Starting point

Applicability of S.14.

Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Application - Order of removal from Government service - Appeal against said order rejected by Government - Subsequent suit for wrongful removal from service - Starting point - Applicability of S.14.

Limitation - Suit for removal from Government service - Whether right of appeal to Government keeps order of removal in abeyance until decision of appeal - Applicability of S.14 of Limitation Act, (1963)

Limitation Act (1963), Ss.14, 9.

In the present case, the order of removal from Government service was passed on 8-10-1965 the appeal against the order of removal was rejected by the Government on 4-11-1967.  Thereafter, the writ petition filed by the plaintiff was withdrawn by him on 27-11-1968.  Then the present suit for wrongful removal from service was filed by the plaintiff on 1-9-1969.

Held that the suit was barred by limitation .  The right of appeal did not involve the consequence that the order of removal could not be operative by its own force but would continue in abeyance until the decision of the appeal. With regard to S.14 of the Limitation Act,1963, it could not come to the reserve of the plaintiff. By invoking S.14 it cannot be said that the period from 8.10.1965 till the withdrawal of the writ petition on 27.11.1968 was to be excluded, what the plaintiff was prosecuting was merely the departmental appeal, the expression, "a Court of first instance or of appeal" appearing in S.14 refers to judicial Court i.e. Courts established by the law of the land and not courts in the wider sense of domestic forums or tribunals.  AIR 1958 SC 1036 Applied. 56 Bom.L.R.214 foll.  [Para 7,9]

heading: Expression "sufficient cause"
HeadNote.description:
Expression "sufficient cause" - Should receive a liberal interpretation - Belated application for setting aside abatement of appeal - Condonation of delay.

The expression "sufficient cause" within the meaning of Section 5 of the Act or Order 22 Rule Q of the Code or any other similar provision should receive a liberal construction so as to advance substantial justice when no negligence or inaction or want of bona fide is imputable to a party. In a particular case whether explanation furnished would constitute "sufficient cause" or not will be dependant upon facts of each case. There cannot be a straitjacket formula for accepting or rejecting explanation furnished for the delay caused in taking steps. But one thing is clear that the Courts should not proceed with the tendency of finding fault with the cause shown and reject the petition by a slipshod order in over jubilation of disposal drive. Acceptance of explanation furnished should be the rule and refusal an exception more so when no negligence or inaction or want of bona fide can be imputed to the defaulting party. On the other hand, while considering the matter the Courts should not lose sight of the fact that by not taking steps within the time prescribed a valuable right has accrued to the other party which should not be lightly defeated by condoning delay In a routine like manner. However, by taking a pedantic and hyper technical view of the matter the explanation furnished should not be rejected when stakes are high and/or arguable points of facts and law are involved in the case, causing enormous loss and irreparable injury to the party against whom the lis terminates either by default or inaction and defeating valuable right of such a party to have the decision on merit. While considering the matter, Courts have to strike a balance between resultant effect of the order it is going to pass upon the parties either way.					 [Para 11]

heading: Suit for declaration that sale deed is not binding
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration that sale deed is not binding - Point of limitation not considered by trial court - Being a question of law and fact trial court directed to reconsider issue of limitation afresh. 	(Para 7)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay occurred in filing application for restoration of application filed under O.9 R.13 by predecessor-in-interest of appellants - Application under O.9 R.13 was dismissed in default on 19/10/2001 - Predecessor of appellant-legal heirs died on 20.11.2001 - Restoration application filed by legal heirs on 21.8.2002 - Delay explained as deceased could not recover from illness and legal heirs were not aware of application under O.9 R.13 - Same held to be sufficient cause for restoration - S.5 of Limitation Act attracted in application filed for restoration - Delay condoned. 			(Paras 61, 62)

heading: Restoration application
HeadNote.description: Restoration application - Whether barred by limitation - ULP complaint of applicants dismissed by order dt.21/8/2004 - Applicants got knowledge of the same on 24/9/2004 - Restoration application filed within hardly 4 days of date of such knowledge - In fact, certified copy of order was received by applicants on 25/9/2004 - From that date restoration application virtually filed within 3 days - Simply because application filed on 37th day, it cannot be said that it was barred by limitation. 	(Para 30)

heading: Bar of limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for cancellation of sale deed - Bar of limitation - Plaintiff challenging execution of sale deed which was executed on basis of compromise decree passed by Lok Adalat - Plaintiff thus challenging compromise decree passed on 16.10.2005 - Suit filed in 2010 - As per Art.59 suit should be filed within 3 years from accrual of cause of action - Suit filed 5 years after accrual of cause of action - Suit is barred by limitation. 	(Para 25)

heading: Execution of decree
Barred by limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for mandatory injunction filed under substantive Portuguese law on 14-6-66 - Appeal against decree passed in suit also filed under Portuguese law - Decree passed in favour of plaintiffs - Execution of decree - Portuguese law not providing any limitation for execution of decree - Limitation under Limitation Act (1963) governs case - Execution application filed beyond the limits under Act - Barred by limitation - Art. 535 of Portuguese Civil Code which prescribes limitation of 30 years has no application.	(Paras 14, 20)

heading: Breach of contract
HeadNote.description: Breach of contract - Supply of imported Brazilian cotton by plaintiff to defendant Mill - Consignment of cotton arriving in Port of Cochin on 31-10-1977 - Defendants conveyed to take delivery of cotton bales within 15 days - Defendants conveying denial of their liability to take delivery by letter dt. 8-11-77 - Suit filed on 28-8-1980 is within 3 years of breach of contract - It is within time.	(Para 7)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause shown
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act (1958), S.111 - Application for joining LRs as party non-applicant - Condonation of delay - Delay of 2 years and 8 months caused in filing application under O.22 R.9 - Application under O.22 R.9 was filed without delay condonation application - During period from 2000 to 2010, Tribunal was not functioning - Therefore, application for condonation of delay was filed on 5.3.2010 - During this period one of LRs also expired - Delay of 98 days also caused in filing application for bringing his LRs on record - Applicants filed application under O.22 R.9 as soon as they came to know about death of non-applicant - Sufficient cause shown - Sole non-applicant died even prior to filing revision - By treating application under O.22 R.9 as application under O.1 R.10, delay condoned by imposing fine. (Para 4)

heading: Cause of action
Starting point
HeadNote.description: Cause of action - Starting point - Demand for development fee from life members made in 1986 and 1989 - No action taken to collect the same till 1995 when protest by life members was ignored and they were threatened with action and subsequently Club refused to issue duplicate card without first clearing dues - Held cause of action arose not in 1986 but in 1995 and suit filed within three years was within limitation both under Art.58 and 113 whichever Article applied. (Paras 23 to 25)

heading: Limitation for
HeadNote.description: Continuing cause of action - Limitation for - To be termed as continuing cause of action, breach of contract must be continuing - However, non-performance of obligation of opponent based on contract between parties cannot be said to be continuing breach - Liability to perform obligation begins when contract is made - At that point of time, cause of action accrues to claimant. (Para 7)

heading: Unpaid salary
Recovery of
HeadNote.description:
Unpaid salary - Recovery of - Governed by Art. 113.

In respect of denial of payment of salary or wages or proper time scale resulting in lower pay would amount to denial of property as money includes property. No person can be deprived of property as envisaged under Art. 300-A of the Constitution of India without due authority of law. Therefore, deprivation can only be by authority of law. By giving wrong time scale and because workman accepted the said time scale would not mean that the workmen's right to payment has been ousted by acceptance of wrong time scale and as such the act is complete. In such case what is barred is relief and not the remedy. Where an employee is not given proper pay scale resulting in lower pay, he is entitled to difference in pay for the period of three years preceding the initiation of proceedings in court for recovery of salary.  [Para 11]

heading: Suit for partition
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Limitation will start from date of demanding partition and its refusal. (Para 18)

heading: Meaning of
HeadNote.description:
Expression "defect of jurisdiction" - Meaning of - Suit decided after adjudication on merits - S.14 does not apply.

The expression "defect of jurisdiction" on a plain reading means the Court must lack jurisdiction to entertain the suit or proceeding. The circumstances in which or the grounds on which, lack of jurisdiction of the Court may be found are not enumerated in the section. It is to be kept in mind that there is a distinction between granting permission to the plaintiff to withdraw the suit with leave to file a fresh suit for the same relief under O.23, R. 1 and exclusion of the period of pendency of that suit for the purpose of computation of limitation in the subsequent suit under S.14 of the Limitation Act. The words "or other cause of a like nature" are to be construed ejusdem generis with the words 'defect of jurisdiction,' that is to say, the defect must be of such a character as to make it impossible for the Court to entertain the suit or application and to decide it on merits. Obviously S.14 will have no application in a case where the suit is dismissed after adjudication on its merits and not because the Court was unable to entertain it.  [Para 16]

heading: Withdrawal of suit
HeadNote.description: Withdrawal of suit - With liberty to file fresh suit for same relief - Defendant taking objection regarding non-joinder of necessary party since initial stage - Yet plaintiff prosecuting suit without impleading necessary party - Plaintiff cannot be said to be prosecuting previous suit in good faith - Hence not entitled to exclusion of period of pendency of previous suit.	(Paras 17, 18)

heading: Exclusion of period of pending proceeding
HeadNote.description:
Exclusion of period of pending proceeding - Conditions to be satisfied before S.14 is pressed in service.

Section 14 is in the nature of a proviso to O.23, R.2. The non obstante clause provides that notwithstanding any thing contained in sub-rule (2) of O.23 of the Code of Civil Procedure the provisions of sub-section (1) of S.14 shall apply in relation to a fresh suit instituted on permission granted by the Court under R.1 of O.23. For applicability of the provision in sub-section (3) of S.14 certain conditions are to be satisfied. Before S.14 can be pressed into service, the conditions to be satisfied are : (1) Both the prior and subsequent proceedings are civil proceedings prosecuted by the same party; (2) the prior proceeding had been prosecuted with due diligence and good faith; (3) the failure of the prior proceeding was due to defect of jurisdiction or other cause of like nature; (4) the earlier proceeding and the later proceeding must relate to the same matter in issue, and (5) both the proceedings are in a Court.

The main factor which would influence the Court in extending the benefit of S.14 to a litigant is whether the prior proceeding had been prosecuted with due diligence and good faith. The party prosecuting the suit in good faith in the Court having no jurisdiction is entitled to exclusion of that period. The expression 'good faith' as used in S.14 means "exercise of due care and attention." In the context of S.14 expression 'good faith' qualifies prosecuting the proceeding in the Court which ultimately is found to have no jurisdiction. The finding as to good faith or the absence of it is a finding of fact. [Para 14,15]

heading: Right of pre-emption
Suit for
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Right of pre-emption - Suit for - Limitation - Period of limitation of one year shall commence from first sale deed after coming into force of Act of 1966 and not from any other subsequent sale - As S.9 of Rajasthan Pre-emption Act (1966), bars exercise of right of pre-emption on subsequent transaction relating to same immovable property - Plaintiff chosen not to file suit on basis of sale effected in 1966 and filed suit on basis of subsequent sale deed - Suit liable to be dismissed being barred by limitation - Rajasthan Pre-emption Act (1966), Ss.6, 21, 9. (Paras 16, 22, 23)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of agreement - Limitation - Appellant was put in possession of suit premises as tenant by agreement dt.6/10/1997 with an option to purchase suit property during subsistence of tenancy - No specific date fixed for performance of contract - Therefore, case falls under second part of Art.54 of Limitation Act prescribing limitation of 3 yrs. from date of refusal of performance - Cause of action arose when notice dated 10/12/2003 sent by appellant showing his intention to purchase suit premises, was refused by respondent - Suit however filed on 14/7/2007 i.e. 4 yrs. after refusal of notice - Suit therefore barred by limitation. 	(Paras 21, 22, 23)

heading: Plea of limitation
HeadNote.description: Plea of limitation - No issue as to whether application was barred by limitation, framed by Trial Court - Consideration of question of limitation by Appellate Court - Not without jurisdiction. 2015(3) ALL MR 951 (S.C.) Rel.on.			(Para 27)

heading: Scope
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Scope - Condonation of delay - Suit filed under local law beyond prescribed limitation period - S.5 does not apply to suits - Merely by reason of s. 29 (2) its applicability cannot be extended to such a suit - Suit barred by limitation. (Para 4)

heading: Execution of decree
HeadNote.description:
Execution of decree - Starting point for limitation - Time runs from date decree becomes enforceable i.e. from any future date or on happening of specified events - Filing of appeal is not a bar to enforceability unless stay is obtained.

Art. 136 of the Schedule to the Limitation Act, 1963 provides 12 years for execution of any decree or order of any Civil Court (other than a decree granting a mandatory injunction). The third column in the article which indicates the time from which period begins to run, states that "when the decree or order becomes enforceable.........."  [Para 6]

When is a decree becoming enforceable? Normally a decree or order becomes enforceable from its date. But cases are not unknown when the decree becomes enforceable on some future date or on the happening of certain specified events. The expression "enforceable" has been used to cover such decrees or orders also which become enforceable subsequently.  [Para 8]

Filing of an appeal would not affect the enforceability of the decree, unless the appellate Court stays its operation. But if the appeal results in a decree that would supersede the decree passed by the lower Court and it is the appellate Court decree which becomes enforceable. When the appellate Order does not amount to a decree there would be no supersession and hence the lower Court decree continues to be enforceable.  [Para 9]

Held the decree became enforceable on 1-8-1973 when the Appellate Court passed the decree which superseded the decree of the trial Court. As no decree was passed by the High Court in the second appeal the decree of the first Appellate Court remained unaffected and the enforceability once commenced remained undisturbed for a period of 12 years therefrom. The execution process initiated by the appellant long after the expiry of 12 years from 1-8-1973 is thus irretrievably barred.   [Para 16]

heading: Suit for recovery of money
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of money - Deficiency in Court fee - Suit would be deemed to have been instituted on date deficiency was made good - Limitation would run from that date. (Para 9)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Applicability - Agricultural land belonging to ex-Jahagirdar - Defendants claiming prescription of title to suit land in their favour long prior to coming into force of 1963 Act. - Evidence of witness not supporting their plea - Pleadings in written statement not giving material particulars of adverse possession - Suit by permanent tenant for possession after commencement of 1963 Act. - Not barred.

In the instant case the defendants claimed that their father was cultivating the suit land belonging to ex-Jahagirdar since 1934 and after his decease the defendants continued cultivating the land and alleged that they have prescribed title by adverse possession prior to commencement of the Limitation Act (1963). The evidence of a witness, an owner of adjoining land, revealed that the defendants were paying rent and land revenue to Jahagirdar. His evidence did not point out adverse interest and/or hostility on the part of the defendants to claim possession as owner. The plaintiffs became permanent tenant in the year 1945, it could not be said that the possession of the respondents was adverse to the plaintiffs from 1934. Further, it could not be said to be adverse to Jahagirdar when the evidence is to the effect that the rent and land revenue was being paid to Jahagirdar by the defendants. The witness, has expressed ignorance as to how defendant or his father had got the suit land. There is no pleading and evidence as to when the possession of the defendant became adverse to the plaintiffs. Not only that, but the fact of discontinuance or date of dispossession of the plaintiff is not accepted by the defendants. On the contrary, the defendants are coming with a came that they are continuously in possession of the property and, therefore, there is no dispossession or discontinuance of the defendants, possession. What is important to be taken into consideration while scrutinising the case of the tenants claiming adverse possession is that the said tenants/defendants are under obligation to point out as to at what point of time, they started claiming possession adverse to the knowledge of the true owner. Pleading and evidence in this respect is absent. Therefore, it could not be said that suit which has been filed by permanent tenant after coming into force of the Act of 1963 is not tenable in law in view of the provisions of Section 31 thereof.  [Para 13]

heading: Limitation
Article applies
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Revision under Criminal P.C. or Civil P.C. - Article applies - Period of limitation is 90 days and time begins to run from date of decree or order or sentence sought to be revised.

Criminal P.C. (1973), S.397.

Civil P.C. (1908), S.115. (Para 6) (Para 16)

heading: Adverse possession and constructive res judicata
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession and constructive res judicata - Question whether land in dispute could be allotted depended on whether displaced person died heirless - Not raised before revenue authorities - Would be barred by principle of constructive res judicata - Plea of adverse possession would also not be available where appellant admits to be tenant of displaced person.	(Paras 31, 32)

heading: Starting point
HeadNote.description:
Limitation of one year - Starting point - Limitation starts from date of confirmation of sale under O.21, R.64 CPC and is not postponed to issue of sale certificate.

The sale becomes absolute on confirmation under Order XXI, Rule 92 of the Code effectively passing title. It cannot be said to attain finality only when sale certificate is issued under Order XXI, Rule 94.  There can be variety of factors conceivable for which delay can be caused in issuing a sale certificate. The period of one year limitation now prescribed under Article 134 of the Limitation Act in substitution of a three year period prescribed under Article 180 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908 is reflective of the legislative policy of finalizing proceedings in execution as quickly as possible by providing a quick forum to the auction purchaser to ask for the delivery of possession of the property purchased within that period from the date of the sale becoming absolute rather than from the date of issuance of the sale certificate.  On his failure to avail such a quick remedy the law relegates him to the remedy of a regular suit for possession based on title, subject again to limitation.	 [Para 14]

heading: Suit for possession of immovable property
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession of immovable property - Suit not filed within 12 years from the date when the possession of the defendant became adverse to plaintiffs - Suit barred by law of limitation. 1991(2) GLT 153 and 1973 Bom. C.R. 321 - Referred to.	(Paras 14, 16)

heading: "Works contract"
What constitutes
HeadNote.description:
"Works contract" - What constitutes - Claim of price for work done under plumbing contract - Contract constitutes a work contract - Contract covered by Art. 18 and not by Art. 7.

AIR 1997 SC 1505, AIR 1969 SC 1245 - Rel. on. (Paras 7, 10)

heading: "Works contract"
Unsustainable
HeadNote.description:
"Works contract" - Claim of price for work done under plumbing contract - Final bill raised on 19-2-1975 - Cause of action arose on raising of final bill - Contention that cause of action arose when architect certified the work - In absence of any such stipulation in writing - Unsustainable - Suit filed on 28-11-1978 - Barred by limitation.

AIR 1984 P & H 185 - Rel. on. (Paras 7, 12)

heading: Suit for possession of land on basis of adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Suit for possession of land on basis of adverse possession - Specific plea has to be taken - Mere suggestion in prayer clause that there was uninterrupted possession for several years is not enough - Long possession is not necessarily adverse possession.

Civil P.C. (1908), O.6, R.5.

Adverse possession has to be specifically pleaded and proved.  A mere suggestion in the relief clause that there was uninterrupted possession for "several 12 years" or that the plaintiff had acquired "an absolute title" is not enough to raise such a plea.  Long possession is not necessarily adverse possession and the prayer clause in not a substitute for a plea.  [Para 7]

In the present case, it would clearly reveal that the parties themselves were not knowing as to how much area of the land was in their possession till the date of the measurement, and it would also clearly reveal from the evidence that the defendant did not specifically plead as to on what date he came into possession of the land and what was the nature of his possession and whether the fact of his adverse possession was known to the plaintiff and what was the period of such adverse possession.  In such circumstances, it is not possible to accept the contention that the possession of the defendant was adequate in continuity, in publicity and in extent to show that it is adverse to the knowledge of the true owner, i.e. the plaintiff.  [Para 10]

heading: Mutation on basis of Will
HeadNote.description: Mutation on basis of Will - Neither pleadings nor evidence as to the date on which the plaintiff had derived the knowledge about the mutation and/or the Will - Suit Rightly held as barred by limitation.	(Paras 37, 38)

heading: Suit for compensation from medical practitioner
HeadNote.description:
Suit for compensation from medical practitioner - Limitation runs not from date of misfeasance or malfeasance but from time the injury results - Suit filed five years thereafter is barred.

AIR 1932 All 256, AIR 1929 Pat. 245, 1992 (4) SCC 1 Rel. on. (Para 62)

heading: Period spent in obtaining stay orders by plaintiffs, their assignees or nominees cannot be excluded. (Para 5)
HeadNote.description: Period spent in obtaining stay orders by plaintiffs, their assignees or nominees cannot be excluded. (Para 5)

heading: Adverse possession
Suit for possession
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Suit for possession - Limitation - Specific case of plaintiff that the defendant's possession on the suit land is for more than 12 years - Under such circumstances, held, the suit filed by the plaintiff was time barred and therefore the suit should have been dismissed on the ground of limitation.	(Para 9)

heading: Acknowledgement in writing
HeadNote.description:
Acknowledgement in writing - Must involve admission of a subsisting jural relationship between parties - It need not be in regard to any precise amount nor by expressed words - It should, however, consciously admit liability to pay or admit his intention to pay debt - What can be acknowledged is a present subsisting liability and not for a new additional claim for damages.

A writing to be an acknowledgement of liability must involve an admission of a subsisting jural relationship between the parties and a conscious affirmation of an intention of continuing such relationship in regard to an existing liability.  The admission need not be in regard to any precise amount nor by expressed words.  If a defendant writes to the plaintiff requesting him to send his claim for verification and payment, it amounts to an acknowledgement.  But if the defendant merely says without admitting liability, it would like to examine the claim or the accounts, it may not amount to acknowledgement.  In other words, a writing, to be treated as an acknowledgement of liability should consciously admit his liability to pay or admit his intention to pay the debt.  What can be acknowledged is a present subsisting liability.  An acknowledgement made with reference to a liability, cannot extend limitation for a time barred liability or a claim that was not made at the time of acknowledgement or some other liability relating to other transactions.  Any admission of jural relationship in regard to the ascertained sum due or a pending claim, cannot be an acknowledgement for a new additional claim for damages.   [Para 15]

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for compromise decree - Limitation - Agreement in minutes of meeting executed between parties on 8th Nov, 2011 - In said agreement, parties agreed to resolve their disputes amicably and in terms respondents agreed to vacate suit premises on or before 31st Dec, 2014 - Cause of action to seek enforcement of agreement would arise with effect from 31st December, 2014 - No need to relate back cause of action to date on which agreement was executed - Therefore, application filed on 10th July 2015, is fully within limitation.	(Para 21)

heading: Suit against
Limitation for
HeadNote.description: Exclusion from joint family - Suit against - Limitation for - Held, if an heir is excluded from the joint family property, he could file a suit within 12 years of such exclusion. 2004(2) ALL MR 416 - Ref. to.	(Para 32)

heading: "Administration suits"
Rel.on.						 [Para 35]
HeadNote.description:
"Administration suits" - Scope and applicability of Limitation Act - Held, Limitation Act makes no separate provision for limitation with regard to "administration suits" as they are dependent upon the special reliefs claimed - Plaintiff claiming half share in movable estate of his deceased mother - Plaintiff claiming accounts as well as administration - Held, since there is no provision for such suit in Schedule I to Limitation Act, Art.113 applies - He has to sue within three years when the right to sue accrues suit filed beyond three years of death, is barred by l.

The Limitation Act makes no separate provision for limitation with regard to "administration suits" as they are dependent upon the special reliefs claimed.  The plaintiff herein claims his half share in the movable estate of his mother.  He claims accounts as well as administration.  His half share accrued to him upon the death of his mother.  It is entirely in movable estate.  He has to claim that share within the period of limitation.  Since there is no provision for such a suit in Schedule-1 to the Limitation Act, Article 113 applies.  He has to sue within three years when the right to sue accrues.  The right to sue accrues upon the death of his mother.  He should have filed his suit, whether or not his sister, the defendant made any claim thereto.  He should have, therefore, sued within three years from 23rd May, 1978.  He having not sued within the period of limitation, his suit is now barred by the Law of Limitation.  2007(6) Bom.C.R. 180 - Rel.on.						 [Para 35]

heading: Petition for probate
HeadNote.description:
Petition for probate - Can be filed when the need arises - Right to file is a continuing right which can be exercised at any time after death of testator - Limitation would begin to run only when situation warranted a petition - Argument that limitation would run from date of death of deceased cannot be accepted - Undue delay would be a suspicious circumstance and will be considered by the court of probate.

AIR 1983 Bombay 268, 2008 ALL SCR 1221, (1976) 4 SCC 634 Ref. 	 [Para 126,128]

heading: Limitation under
HeadNote.description: Limitation under - Limitation commences when right to apply and not right to sue accrues. 	(Para 65)

heading: Limitation
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Condonation of delay - Hardship or injustice not a ground for extending period of limitation.

The principles underlying the provisions prescribing limitation are based on public policy aiming at justice, the principles of repose and peace and intended to induce claimants to be prompt in claiming relief.

Hardship or injustice may be a relevant consideration in applying the principles of interpretation of statute, but cannot be a ground for extending the period of limitation.	 [Para 20,21]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Starting point of limitation.

In cases of adverse possession, the starting point of limitation does not commence from the date when the right of ownership arises to the plaintiff but it commences from the date when the defendants' possession  became adverse.   [Para 6]

heading: Starting point of limitation
HeadNote.description:
Starting point of limitation - Co-sharer getting possession of property by partition.

Partition is really a process by which a joint enjoyment of the property is transformed into an enjoyment severally. In the case of partition, each co-sharer has an antecedent title and, therefore, there is no conferment of a new title.   [Para 6]

heading: Acknowledgment of liability
HeadNote.description: Acknowledgment of liability - Defendant acknowledging liability to pay amount due calculated on basis of enhanced rate of interest as per terms of agreement - Unqualified acknowledgment not only saves the period of limitation but also gives a cause of action to the plaintiff Bank to base its claim.	(Para 8)

heading: Agreement of sale
HeadNote.description: Agreement of sale - Suit for specific performance of agreement - Notice issued by appellant asking the respondent purchaser to perform his part of the agreement within 15 days from the receipt of the notice - Held, suit should be filed within a period of three years from the date of expiry of fifteen days of receipt of notice of deposit of the amount.	(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Scope and applicability of
HeadNote.description:
Scope and applicability of - For applicability of Art.64, plaintiff should have been dispossessed - If plaintiff voluntarily handed over his property, his case would not come within the ambit of expression "dispossession" - Held, Art.64 would not be applicable to such cases.

The suit under Article 64 must be brought within 12 years from the date of dispossession. As such, for applicability of Article 64 of the Limitation Act, the prima donna requirement is that the plaintiff should be dispossessed, or should discontinue possession. The expression "dispossession" applies when a person comes in and drives out another from possession. It imports ouster, i.e. driving out of possession against the will of a person in actual possession. This driving out cannot take place when the transfer of possession was voluntary i.e. to say not against the will of person in possession, but in accordance with his wishes and active consent. Dispossession implies some amount of force or fraud. As such, unless it is shown that the plaintiff was dispossessed by force or by fraud. Article 64 of the Limitation Act would not be applicable. If the plaintiff on his own volition and voluntarily handed over his property, that would not come within the ambit and purview of the expression "dispossession" inter-alia Article 64 would not be applicable in such a case.				  [Para 10]

heading: Claim of
HeadNote.description: Title by adverse possession - Claim of - Property entrusted with defendant by plaintiff - Defendant neither claiming adverse possession nor had shown animus to hold the property as owner - Held, the defendant is not entitled to claim title by adverse possession. AIR 2004 SC 4261 - Ref. to.			(Paras 16, 17)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
Appeal
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Appeal - Necessity of certified copy of judgment and decree for entertaining and disposing of appeal - Cannot be considered as a mere formality but has to be considered as mandatory requirement - Sufficient cause for not preferring appeal would also include sufficient cause for not preferring application for certified copy of decree within period of limitation.

The appeal cannot be filed without the certified copy of the Judgment and decree.  Undoubtedly, in view of he amendment to the provision of order 41 Rule 1 w.e.f. 1-7-2002 the requirement of accompaniment of the certified copy of the decree at the time of presentation of Memorandum of Appeal though excluded, the necessity of the certified copy of the decree for disposing the appeal cannot be ruled out as various other factors like valuation of the Appeal, the court fee payable thereon would depend upon the bill of cost prepared by the Registry on disposal of the suit on the basis of the valuation of the court fee paid in the suit.  Being so the necessity of the certified copy of the Judgment as well as of the decree for entertaining and disposal of the appeal cannot be considered as mere formality but has to be considered as mandatory requirement.  Being so any step in the direction of collecting the legally required material necessary for the purpose of preferring the appeal would amount to taking steps for preferring the appeal within the meaning of the said expression under section 5 of the said Act.  Being so, "sufficient cause for not preferring" would also include sufficient cause for not preferring the application for certified copy of the decree within the period of limitation.	 [Para 18]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - It is not something like exclusion of time under Ss.12 or 14 - It is rather extention to time which is a matter of concession or indulgence to the applicant which cannot be claimed as a matter of absolute right.

There can be cases where a party may be totally unaware of the pronouncement of Judgment for a period more than one prescribed for preferring the appeal and on having learnt of such Judgment after the expiry of such period desires to file the appeal, is such person to be considered to be totally debarred from preferring the appeal?  Any such interpretation would virtually defeat the very purpose of section 5 of the Limitation Act.  It is well settled that condonation of delay is not the same thing like exclusion of time under Section 12 or 14 of the Act.  It is rather extension of time which is a matter of concession or indulgence to the applicant which can not be claimed as a matter of absolute right; however, section 5 has to receive a legal construction so as to advance substantial justice when no negligence or want of bonafide is imputable to the applicant.	 [Para 19]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Order condoning delay has to be judicious order - It should disclose application of mind of Judge and facts disclosed should constitute sufficient cause for purpose of condonation of delay and more particularly when it is a contested matter.

The extension of time to enable the petitioners to place on record certified copy of the decree, by itself does not amount to condonation of the delay in filing the appeal.  It is not mere lodging of the appeal that is sufficient but the lodging has to be in accordance with the provisions of law and by following the procedure prescribed by the law and not otherwise.
