HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Liberal approach - Purpose of introducing liberal construction is to introduce concept of "reasonableness" - Once a valuable right accrues in favour of one party as a result of delay by other, it will be unreasonable to take away that right on mere asking of applicant - This is also because justice must be done to both parties equally and then alone ends of justice can be achieved.	(Para 11)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Expression "sufficient cause" must be given pragmatic justice oriented approach in considering the matter on merits.	(Para 3)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Revenue records revealing that disputed property stood in the name of defendants - Superintendent of Police making repeated attempts to grab property by filing repeated appeal before different forums by claiming adverse possession - Such an action by police who are protectors of property is most reprehensible - No government department should be permitted to perfect title to land or building by invoking provisions of adverse possession.

2008 ALL SCR 2222 - Rel. on. (Para 50)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Parliament must seriously consider at least to abolish "bad faith" adverse possession i.e. adverse possession achieved through intentional trespassing. 

The Parliament must seriously consider at least to abolish "bad faith" adverse possession, i.e., adverse possession achieved through intentional trespassing. Actually believing it to be their own could receive title through adverse possession sends a wrong signal to the society at large. Such a change would ensure that only those who had established attachments to the land through honest means would be entitled to legal relief.

2008 ALL SCR 2222 - Rel. on.  [Para 43]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Change in law is necessary - Atleast a longer statutory period of 30 to 50 years instead of 12 years must be effected. 

In case, the Parliament decides to retain the law of adverse possession, the Parliament might simply require adverse possession claimants to possess the property in question for a period of 30 to 50 years, rather than a mere 12. Such an extension would help to ensure that successful claimants have lived on the land for generations, and are therefore less likely to be individually culpable for the trespass (although their forebears might). A longer statutory period would also decrease the frequency of adverse possession suits and ensure that only those claimants most intimately connected with the land acquire it, while only the most passive and unprotective owners lose title.  [Para 44]

heading: Law about adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Law about adverse possession - If Parliament decides to retain the law at least title owners should be compensated according to prevalent market rate of land or building. 

If this law is to be retained, according to the wisdom of the Parliament, then at least the law must require those who adversely possess land to compensate title owners according to the prevalent market rate of the land or property in question. This alternative would provide some semblance of justice to those who have done nothing other than sitting on their rights for the statutory period, while allowing the adverse possessor to remain on property. While it may be indefensible to require all adverse possessors - some of whom may be poor - to pay market rates for the land they possess, perhaps some lesser amount would be realistic in most of the cases. The Parliament may either fix a set range of rates or to leave it to the judiciary with the option of choosing from within a set range of rates so as to tailor the compensation to the equities of a given case.  [Para 42]

heading: Suit for possession
Limitation for
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Limitation for - It is to be filed within period of 12 years when tenancy is determined - Tenancy came to be determined by efflux of time on 9.4.1988 - Suit was filed on 11.7.2003 - Suit was not filed within period of 12 years - Suit barred by limitation. (Paras 9, 10)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - None appears for claimant respondents - No reply to application for condonation of delay is filed - Delay in filing appeals by acquiring body is liable to be condoned.	(Para 2)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Unless and until delay is first condoned, court does not get jurisdiction to embark upon enquiry on merits.	(Para 10)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Based on title from a party in illegal occupation - Suit is governed by Art.65 - Plaintiff's half share in property was not defined in 1958 when property was purchased in auction sale - Physical separation was effected by compromise decree in 1988 - Suit filed in 1990 is well within limitation of 12 years. (Para 40)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Clandestine removal of excisable goods - Period of limitation will start from date of knowledge arrived at upon raids on the premises. (Para 27)

heading: Suit for possession and mandatory injunction
HeadNote.description:
Suit for possession and mandatory injunction - Suit land was in possession of defendants but no evidence to show that their possession became adverse - Hence suit decreed.

The suit based upon title is governed by article 65 of the Limitation Act. Limitation of 12 years commences from the date, possession of the defendant becomes adverse to the plaintiff. Onus is entirely on the party who sets up a title on the basis of adverse possession. Presumptions and probabilities cannot be substituted for evidence. It must be shown by clear and unequivocal evidence that possession was hostile to its true owner and amounted to a denial of his title to the property claimed. Mere long possession for a period of more than 12 years cannot result in acquisition of title by adverse possession. What is material is 'animus possidendi'. It seems that the learned trial court could not distinguish between the 'possession simplicitor' and 'adverse possession' and therefore fallen in error while recording the finding that the suit is barred by limitation and defendants have perfected title to it by adverse possession.	    [Para 12]

heading: Plea of limitation
HeadNote.description: Recovery of adverse possession - Plea of limitation - Possession of suit property by defendants commenced from 1976 - Suit for recovery of possession filed in 1996 - Time from which period of 12 years begins to run is when possession of defendant becomes adverse to plaintiff - Proof of mere possession from 1976 not sufficient to prove adverse possession - Question of limitation for filing suit, does not arise. 	(Para 14)

heading: Counter claim to
HeadNote.description: Recovery of adverse possession - Counter claim to - Defendents claiming to be owner of suit property by virtue of a sale deed - No evidence to prove that property described in sale deed corresponds to suit property - Defendents failed to prove their title - Even adverse possession of suit property was not proved - Hence, counter claim of defendent liable to be rejected.         (Para 19)

heading: Condonation of delay
Term "sufficient cause"
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Term "sufficient cause" - Even if it is to receive liberal construction it must comply with concept of reasonable time and proper conduct of concerned party.

The purpose of introducing liberal construction normally is to introduce the concept of 'reasonableness' as it is understood in its general connotation. The law of limitation is a substantive law and has definite consequences on the right and obligation of a party to arise. These principles should be adhered to and applied appropriately depending on the facts and circumstances of a given case. Once a valuable right, as accrued in favour of one party as a result of the failure of the other party to explain the delay by showing sufficient cause and its own conduct, it will be unreasonable to take away that right on the mere asking of the applicant, particularly when the delay is directly a result of negligence, default or inaction of that party. Justice must be done to both parties equally. Then alone the ends of justice can be achieved. If a party has been thoroughly negligent in implementing its rights and remedies, it will be equally unfair to deprive the other party of a valuable right that has accrued to it in law as a result of his acting vigilantly. The application filed by the applicants lack in details. Even the averments made are not correct and ex-facie lack bona fide. The explanation has to be reasonable or plausible, so as to persuade the Court to believe that the explanation rendered is not only true, but is worthy of exercising judicial discretion in favour of the applicant. If it does not specify any of the enunciated ingredients of judicial pronouncements, then the application should be dismissed. On the other hand, if the application is bona fide and based upon true and plausible explanations, as well as reflect normal behaviour of a common prudent person on the part of the applicant, the Court would normally tilt the judicial discretion in favour of such an applicant. Liberal construction cannot be equated with doing injustice to the other party. 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 1101 - Held per incurium.  							 [Para 13]

heading: Term "sufficient cause"
HeadNote.description:
Term "sufficient cause" - Implies presence of legal and adequate reasons.

The word 'sufficient' means adequate enough, as much as may be necessary to answer the purpose intended. It embraces no more than that which provides a plentitude which, when done, suffices to accomplish the purpose intended in the light of existing circumstances and when viewed from the reasonable standard of practical and cautious men. The sufficient cause should be such as it would persuade the Court, in exercise of its judicial discretion, to treat the delay as an excusable one. These provisions give the Courts enough power and discretion to apply a law in a meaningful manner, while assuring that the purpose of enacting such a law does not stand frustrated. The party should show that besides acting bona fide, it had taken all possible steps within its power and control and had approached the Court without any unnecessary delay. The test is whether or not a cause is sufficient to see whether it could have been avoided by the party by the exercise of due care and attention.   [Para 14]

heading: Defendant displaying their advertisements on hoarding erected by plaintiff
HeadNote.description: Defendant displaying their advertisements on hoarding erected by plaintiff - Plaintiff were tenants of lands owned by third party - Contract between plaintiff and defendant coming to an end by eflux of time - Defendant continuing to use hoardings for display of advertisements and paying licence fees to corporation - Licence standing in name of plaintiff - Defendant can be said to be tenant holding over after expiry of lease - Limitation for recovery of rent is 3 yrs. - Suit filed beyond that period is barred by limitation.	(Para 26)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay in applying for correction of notional and deemed date of promotion - Delay not solely attributable to petitioner - Held in such case liberal, reasonable and justice oriented approach is necessary in considering application for condonation of delay. 	(Para 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
Application for
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Application for - Considerations to be kept in mind while dealing with such application.

The principles that can broadly be stated are:

(i) There should be a liberal, pragmatic, justice oriented, non-pedantic approach while dealing with an application for condonation of delay, for the courts are not supposed to legalise injustice but are obliged to remove injustice.

(ii) The terms "sufficient cause" should be understood in their proper spirit, philosophy and purpose regard being had to the fact that these terms are basically elastic and are to be applied in proper perspective to the obtaining fact-situation.

(iii) Substantial justice being paramount and pivotal the technical considerations should not be given undue and uncalled for emphasis.

(iv) No presumption can be attached to deliberate causation of delay but, gross negligence on the part of the counsel or litigant is to be taken note of.

(v)Lack of bona fides imputable to a party seeking condonation of delay is a significant and relevant fact.

(vi)It is to be kept in mind that adherence to strict proof should not affect public justice and cause public mischief because the courts are required to be vigilant so that in the ultimate eventuate there is no real failure of justice.

(vii)The concept of liberal approach has to encapsule the conception of reasonableness and it cannot be allowed a totally unfettered free play.

(viii)There is a distinction between inordinate delay and a delay of short duration or few days, for to the former doctrine of prejudice is attracted whereas to the latter it may not be attracted. That apart, the first one warrants strict approach whereas the second calls for a liberal delineation.

(ix)The conduct, behaviour and attitude of a party relating to its inaction or negligence are relevant factors to be taken into consideration. It is so as the fundamental principle is that the courts are required to weigh the scale of balance of justice in respect of both parties and the said principle cannot be given a total go by in the name of liberal approach.

(x)If the explanation offered is concocted or the grounds urged in the application are fanciful, the courts should be vigilant not to expose the other side unnecessarily to face such a litigation. (xi) It is to be borne in mind that no one gets away with fraud, misrepresentation or interpolation by taking recourse to the technicalities of law of limitation.

(xii) The entire gamut of facts are to be carefully scrutinized and the approach should be based on the paradigm of judicial discretion which is founded on objective reasoning and not on individual perception.

(xiii) The State or a public body or an entity representing a collective cause should be given some acceptable latitude. 

To the aforesaid principles we may add some more guidelines taking note of the present day scenario. They are: -

(a) An application for condonation of delay should be drafted with careful concern and not in a half hazard manner harbouring the notion that the courts are required to condone delay on the bedrock of the principle that adjudication of a lis on merits is seminal to justice dispensation system.

(b) An application for condonation of delay should not be dealt with in a routine manner on the base of individual philosophy which is basically subjective.

(c) Though no precise formula can be laid down regard being had to the concept of judicial discretion, yet a conscious effort for achieving consistency and collegiality of the adjudicatory system should be made as that is the ultimate institutional motto.

(d) The increasing tendency to perceive delay as a non-serious matter and, hence, lackadaisical propensity can be exhibited in a non-challant manner requires to be curbed, of course, within legal parameters.

To the aforesaid culled from case law some more guidelines taking of the present day scenario can be added as under"

(a) An application for condonation of delay should be drafted with careful concern and not in a half hazard manner harbouring the notion that the courts are required to condone delay on the bedrock of the principle that adjudication of a lis on merits is seminal to justice dispensation system.

(b) An application for condonation of delay should not be dealt with in a routine manner on the base of individual philosophy which is basically subjective.

(c) Though no precise formula can be laid down regard being had to the concept of judicial discretion, yet a conscious effort for achieving consistency and collegiality of the adjudicatory system should be made as that is the ultimate institutional motto.

(d) The increasing tendency to perceive delay as a non-serious matter and, hence, lackadaisical propensity can be exhibited in a non-challant manner requires to be curbed, of course, within legal parameters.          [Para 15,16]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of almost seven years on ground of lack of knowledge by succeeding Managing Committee - Despite High Court order appellant was not allowed to join duty as teacher in school - After contempt petition filed by her she was allowed to join duty but was not permitted to sign muster, was not allotted any work nor salary was paid - In the next contempt petition Single Judge directed personal presence of Secretary and Principal of the school - Managing Committee and Secretary filed appeal along with application for condonation of delay of 2449 days in filing appeal - Division Bench condoning delay - Held, Division Bench erred in relying on plea of lack of knowledge which lacked bona fide, order condoning delay set aside. (Paras 22, 23)

heading: Limitation for
HeadNote.description:
Suit for specific performance - Limitation for - Agreement not stipulating date for performance - Suit filed within three years from date of refusal, held, is within time.
AIR 1985 AP 393 Ref. to. (Para 27)

heading: Suit for declaration
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - Right to sue when accrues - Plaintiff asking Government to correct wrong entries in survey records by sending a letter - Government did not reply - Held suit filed within three years thereafter was within limitation.	(Para 27)

heading: Suit for possession
Bar of limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Bar of limitation - Defendant claiming that second suit for possession was barred by limitation as cause of action for it arose when first suit was filed by father of plaintiff - First suit was filed on ground that there is landlord-tenant relationship between plaintiff's father and defendant and defendant has not paid rent - Court denied existence of any such relationship in first suit - Second suit filed by plaintiffs on ground that after death of their father, they became owner of suit property and defendant is in adverse possession of suit property - Cause of action for both suits, is different - Cause of action for second suit arose when Court denied tenant-landlord relationship and it was based on Art.65 - Though defendant denied adverse possession, but failed to prove that he had mortgaged suit property to father of plaintiffs - Suit filed within 12 years court denying tenant-landlord relationship, not barred by limitation. 	(Paras 35, 36)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Suit for specific performance of contract - Limitation - Agreement to sell property executed on 25-11-94 Notice dt.6-1-96 and 10-11-97 issued to execute sale deed, not complied - According to plaintiff on 17-5-2006 defendant attempted to plough suit field, hence she filed suit - Held, non compliance of notice dt.10-11-97 and to execute sale deed on 17-11-97 amounted to refusal by defendant - Suit barred by limitation.
2009(1) ALL MR 235 Disting.(Para 17)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Even though S.5 may be impliedly inapplicable, principle of S.14 can be held to be applicable even if S.29(2) does not apply. 2008(6) ALL MR 423 (S.C.), (2015) 5 SCALE 505 Rel.on.	 (Para 14)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit by trustees for benefit of minor - Limitation - Minor entitled to institute suit within three years after attaining majority - Suit filed before minor attaining majority - Suit not barred by limitation. (Paras 15, 16, 17)

heading: Suit alleging fraud
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit alleging fraud - Limitation - Suspension about fraud arose when bank stopped giving inspection - Suit filed within three years of knowing about fraud - Suit is within limitation. (Para 14)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Plaintiffs claiming to be lawful owners of property by inheritance or sale instruments in their favour - They claimed relief of permanent injunction restraining Bangalore Development Authority from disturbing their possession by claiming ignorance about acquisition proceedings - However, on date of suit, properties stood cleared of any structures by demolition of whatever stood on the same - Held, High Court was justified in setting aside decree passed by trial court and dismissing the suit filed by plaintiffs claiming adverse possession. (Paras 8, 12)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Plaintiff claiming to be in possession of property in terms of sale deed executed long after property was acquired by Development Authorities and possession was taken by drawing Panchnama - Held, sale in such cases is void and non-est giving vendees limited right to claim compensation and no more. (Paras 13, 14, 15)

heading: Plea of adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Plea of adverse possession - Inconsistent with the plea as to title - Once the plea of adverse possession is projected, defendant has to admit that true owner was somebody else - Claim as to title over suit property on plea of adverse possession as well as on the basis of execution of some document, not permissible.

In the instant matter, defendant claims his title to the suit property on the basis of an unregistered gift deed executed by plaintiff community.  At the same time, defendant has claimed his adverse possession saying that his possession is open to the knowledge of the members of plaintiff community.  Both the pleas raised by defendant are mutually inconsistent and cannot be entertained.

That apart, it is not known as to from what point of time possession of defendant became adverse to the real owner.  Defendant has neither pleaded the date or period of commencement of his adverse possession nor has led and any evidence to show that there was any animus or intention made known to the plaintiffs that the possession of defendant is adverse to the owner.  Apart from the actual and continuous possession which are amongst other ingredients of adverse possession, there should be necessary animus on the part of person who intends to perfect his title by adverse possession.  It is also necessary for the person who claims adverse possession to set up title hostile to the title of the true owner.

In the instant matter it cannot be said that defendants have substantiated their case in respect of perfection of their title by virtue of adverse possession. AIR 1964 SC 1254, 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 432, 2004(1) SCC 271, 2003(3) BCR 150, (1997)7 SCC 567 & (1995)2 SCC 543 - Rel. on.  [Para 9]

heading: Adverse possession
Proof
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Proof - Person must show possession was hostile to real owner and amounted to denial of his right to property claimed.1995(1) ALL MR 352 (S.C.), AIR 1964 SC 1254 Ref. to. 	(Paras 22, 25)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description:
Suit for possession - On basis of title - Limitation prescribed for filling, stated.

So far as Article 65 is concerned, it covers the cases where the possession is sought on the basis of title and the limitation prescribed is 12 years when the possession of the Defendant becomes adverse to the Plaintiff. The limitation under Article 65 therefore starts from the point when the possession of the Defendant becomes adverse to the Plaintiff. Hence in so far as Article 65 is concerned, the onus is on the Defendant to prove that he is in adverse possession, as that is the only ground on which the Plaintiff can be nonsuited, on the ground of limitation if the suit is filed 12 years after the Defendant's possession becomes adverse to the Plaintiff. In so far as adverse possession is concerned, one of the requirements is that it has to be claimed and has to be put in issue and that there has to be proof of hostile possession which is open and continuous and to the knowledge of the public at large. If one comes to the facts of the instant case, the written statement does not contain any such averment. In fact the Petitioner was required to file a counter claim if it was its case that it was claiming a right on the basis of adverse possession. No such counter claim was filed, neither is any averment appearing in the written statement. The sine qua non if one can say of adverse possession is hostility to the title of the true owner, no such fact is pleaded nor brought on record to prove such hostility though the Petitioner herein claims to be in possession since the year 1976. Hence the Petitioner has not satisfied the test of adverse possession and therefore the finding of the Co-operative Appellate Court that in view of the fact that the Petitioner is in unauthorized possession meaning thereby a trespasser the cause of action was continuous and the Dispute therefore filed in the year 1993 was within limitation cannot be faulted with. 				 [Para 22]

heading: Approach of court
HeadNote.description:
Application for condonation of delay - Approach of court - Court should not condone delay on sympathetic grounds alone. 

The courts should not adopt an injustice-oriented approach in rejecting the application for condonation of delay. However the court while allowing such application has to draw a distinction between delay and inordinate delay for want of bona fides of an inaction or negligence would deprive a party of the protection of Section 5 of the Limitation Act, 1963. Sufficient cause is a condition precedent for exercise of discretion by the Court for condoning the delay. This Court has time and again held that when mandatory provision is not complied with and that delay is not properly, satisfactorily and convincingly explained, the court cannot condone the delay on sympathetic grounds alone. if some person has taken a relief approaching the Court just or immediately after the cause of action had arisen, other persons cannot take benefit thereof approaching the court at a belated stage for the reason that they cannot be permitted to take the impetus of the order passed at the behest of some diligent person.  [Para 11,12]

heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Appeal filed after inordinate delay of 10 years 2 months and 29 days - Sufficient grounds to condone delay not cited - Held, High Court was justified in not condoning delay. (Paras 16, 17)

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description: Plea of adverse possession - Scope - There can be no adverse possession among members of one family for want of any animus among them over land belonging to their family. 	(Para 19)

heading: Computation of period of three years
HeadNote.description: Computation of period of three years - Appeal challenging dismissal from service - Zilla Parishad (Z.P.) employees dismissed on 19.1.1976 - High Court permitting withdrawal of Spl Civil Application filed on 29.7.1981 and permitting filing of civil suit - Civil suit filed on 16.4.1982 - Held, suit filed within three years from 29-7-1981 when cause of action arose, was maintainable.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of possession - Limitation - Plaintiff Manager of Deosthan claiming that suit land is trust property of Deosthan which was illegally sold by erstwhile manager - When erstwhile Manager died, Deosthan was looked after by his widow as plaintiff-son was minor - After attaining majority, plaintiff took up charge of Deosthan and filed instant suit - Suit claimed to be filed within 12 yrs of attaining majority - However, plaintiff failed to prove that suit land was dedicated for religious and charitable purposes and that Deosthan was managed out of income from suit land - Hence, Art.96 of Limitation Act would not apply - Sale deed executed in 1953 and 1956 - Case would be governed by Art.144 of old Act and/or Art.65 of New Act - Period of limitation would start when possession of defendant became adverse to plaintiff i.e. when sale deed executed - Suit filed in 1971 barred by limitation. (Para 21)

heading: Exclusion of time
HeadNote.description: Exclusion of time - Suit challenging sale of land allegedly belonging to Deosthan, a family deity - Plaintiff claimed that he was minor when he succeeded to Shebaitship of Deosthan upon death of his father - Therefore, Deosthan was managed by his mother till he attained majority - Since plaintiff could not file suit till he became major, he sought exclusion of said intervening period from computation of limitation period - Held, Hindu widow is class-I heir - She herself succeeded to shebaitship - Not that she was managing Deosthan on plaintiff's behalf - No question of exclusion as sought by plaintiff. (Paras 19, 20)

heading: Limitation
Suit for recovery
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Suit for recovery - Mortgage by deposit of title deeds by respondent guarantors, proved - Provisions of Art.62 of Limitation Act read with S.96 of T. P. Act would be applicable.	(Para 35)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Suit by appellant flat purchaser against builder for performance of contract - No specific agreement executed except receipt of payment of earnest money - Receipt issued in 1979 and suit filed in 1986 - No other legal proceedings were initiated in between this period - Merely sending notice by appellant to execute sale deed in 1986 would not save suit - Suit filed beyond limitation, liable to be dismissed. 

Appellant agreed for terms and conditions which provide that possession would be given in 2 years and later refused to accept modified terms and conditions as admittedly opposed by communication / telegram and still waited for more than 3 years to file suit cannot get any relief.

2000(4) ALL MR 285 (S.C.) Disting.  [Para 7]

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage - Limitation - There was period of 30 yrs. for filing suit for redemption.(Para 18)

heading: Computation
HeadNote.description: Goa, Daman and Diu Land Revenue Code (1968), Art.14(4) - Limitation period of "one year" - Computation - Day on which impugned order was passed, has to be excluded - Construing of "one year" as defined under General Clauses Act cannot take away right of plaintiff to avail benefit of S.12(1) of Limitation Act. 	(Para 10)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for damages for breach of contract - Limitation - Agreement entered into between FCI and plaintiff for the latter constructing plinths and leasing them out to FCI initially for three years - FCI vacated premises before expiry of three years - Plaintiff filed suit for damages within three years of date of vacating the premises - Held, suit not barred by time.	(Para 13)

heading: Adverse possession
Proof
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Proof - Case of defendants that their predecessors came in possession of suit property consequent to partition in joint family - Plea of adverse possession also raised - Said two pleas are inconsistent - If defendant got suit property after partition, it indicates his permissive possession - Title of plaintiffs' predecessor was not challenged during his life time - Title of plaintiff was disputed by defendant in a rent control suit - However, possession of defendant does not cease to be permissive for that reason - Rent control suit is based on different cause of action - Long standing possession of defendant is permissive and not adverse - Decree directing possession of suit property to plaintiffs is justified.	(Paras 10, 13)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - From 1930 onwards name of K was recorded in revenue records as full owner - in 1942 K as absolute owner sold property to L - Plaintiff was attesting witness to sale deed - Held this conduct of plaintiff and fact that he filed suit only in 1972 were tell-tale circumstances to indicate that defendants had perfected title by adverse possession even if it is presumed that K was not absolute owner. (Para 7)

heading: Review petition
Delay in filing
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Review petition - Delay in filing - Condonation of - Writ petition disposed of on 6.8.2013 - Review petition filed on 15.11.2014 - Special leave petition disposed of on 10.11.2014 - Filing and pendency of special leave petition is only ground for condonation of delay - No explanation for not filing review petition simultaneously or prior to filing of special leave petition - Held, inordinate delay of 469 days in filing review petition cannot be condoned. (Para 11)

heading: Adverse possession
Claim for
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Claim for - Person inducted by limited owner accepting title of reversioner after death of such limited owner - Such person never claiming title by adverse possession against deceased during her lifetime - Reversioner under circumstances would have no cause to treat his possession as adverse - Art.65, Expln.(b) not relevant in such cases.

Where original defendant claimed to have entered possession with consent of female heir in 1948-49 and thereafter claimed irrevocable license as she permitted him to construct house, it is obvious that till her death in 1951 he never claimed suit property adversely to her.  His possession was therefore not adverse to said female heir.  Because of explanation (b) such possession of defendant during lifetime of such woman is excluded for the purposes of computing limitation and hence, by deeming fiction, only after death of such limited owner, legislature has recognised it as becoming adverse to the plaintiff thereby requiring filing of suit within twelve years from the date of death of such woman.  There was no cause for Plaintiff to file any suit.  If a person inducted by limited owner accepts title of reversioner after death of such limited owner, revisioner will have no cause to treat his possession as adverse to him.  Hence, explanation (b) of Article 65 is not at all relevant here and defendant has to demonstrate that he was in adverse possession as against present Plaintiff for twelve years.  Article 65 of present Limitation Act have no application in the facts of this case and Suit as filed by original Plaintiff in 1982 cannot be said to be barred by limitation insofar as his claim as revisioner is concerned.  Further the plea and claim as reversioner raised by Appellant Plaintiff for the first time in Second Appeal, and present Respondent/original Defendant did not get opportunity to point out facts negating it.  Matter restored back to the file of said court only to consider the issue of reversion arising from amended pleadings of parties and to answer it in accordance with law after giving them reasonable opportunity.	 [Para 8,9]

heading: Delay in filing proceedings
Permissibility
HeadNote.description: Filing application beyond stipulated maximum time limit - Permissibility - Special statute prescribed certain period of limitation for filing particular application thereunder - Provided that such period may be extended, on sufficient cause being shown, in maximum only up to a specified time limit and no further - Application filed before tribunal beyond such maximum limit - Cannot be treated to be within limitation.	(Para 41)

heading: Condonation of delay
Application for
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Application for - Approach to be adopted by Court - In matters of condonation of delay, liberal approach is warranted - Overall conduct of party has to be examined - Unless it is established that a litigant has been irresponsible or grossly negligent, Courts must show utmost consideration to the suitors.

	In matters of condonation of delay, a liberal approach is warranted. In most cases, involving condonation of delay, it is possible that there is some amount of negligence on the part of the litigants. However, that by itself, is not enough to turn down the plea of such litigants and to shut the door against them. If the explanation does not smack of malafides or is not put forth as part of dilatory tactic, the Court must show utmost consideration to the suitors. However, whilst condoning the delay, the Court should not forget the opposite part altogether. It must be borne in mind that the opposite party is also a looser and the opposite party too, would have to incur quite a large litigation expense. Therefore, it would be a salutary guideline that when, the court condones the delay, the Court must compensate the opposite party for its loss. 	 [Para 13]

	The Court must be more discerning and considerate particularly when delay is not inordinate and explanation, not malafide. The litigants usually rely upon their lawyers for such procedural compliances. The lawyers in turn entrust such matters to their juniors or clerks. These are some of the practical issues, which, though cannot be granted some blanket judicial sanction, cannot be altogether ignored either. Further, in the instant case, the appellants/petitioners had nothing to gain by delaying their own appeal. The primary function of the Court is to adjudicate the dispute between the parties and to advance substantial justice. Such procedural requirements are basically required to ensure that there is compliance with natural justice and the parties do not resort to dilatory tactics. In dealing with applications for condonation of delay the overall conduct of the party has to examined. Unless it is established that a litigant has been irresponsible or grossly negligent, the Courts must show utmost consideration to the suitors.		 [Para 14]

heading: Condonation of delay
Application for
Dismissal
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Application for - Dismissal - Challenge - Delay of 120 days occurred in filing application for readmission of appeal and for recall of order dismissing appeal - Reason for delay stated that due to deaths of several respondents number of respondents increased manifold - Number of respondents being very large, despite efforts it was not possible to trace their addresses - Petitioners regularly attending and following up matter - They also took steps from time to time to serve notices upon respondents - Further, when application was taken for lodging, the registry raised objection that entire cause title was necessary to be stated in application - On returning with corrected application petitioners were informed that a delay condonation application is required to be filed with said application - Delay was not inordinate and sufficient explanation given as regards delay - Therefore, dismissal of delay condonation application, held not proper. 			(Paras 10, 14, 17)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Mere possession however long does not necessarily mean that it is adverse to the true owner.

Mere possession does not ripen into possessory title until possessor holds property adverse to the title of the true owner for the said purpose. The person who claims adverse possession is required to establish the date on which he came in possession, nature of possession, the factum of possession, knowledge to the true owner, duration of possession and possession was open and undisturbed. A person pleading adverse possession has no equities in his favour as he is trying to defeat the rights of the true owner and, hence, it is for him to clearly plead and establish all facts necessary to establish adverse possession. The courts always take unkind view towards statutes of limitation overriding property rights. Plea of adverse possession is not a pure question of law but a blended one of fact and law. 2007(2) ALL MR 866 (S.C.), (2004)10 SCC 779 - Rel.on.   [Para 14]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Initial plea of appellant was that he purchased property from original owner - Alternatively agreement of sale was pleaded - Both pleas not substantiated - It was then pleaded that appellant paid some money to tenant to relinquish his tenancy rights - But such relinquishment will not enure to the benefit of appellant against true owner - Held, Division Bench was justified in rejecting plea of adverse possession.(Para 15)

heading: Adverse Possession
What amounts to
HeadNote.description: Adverse Possession - What amounts to - Where a person possesses an immovable property in a manner in which he is not entitled to possess it - And there being nothing to that he possesses it otherwise than as an owner, his possession can be termed as adverse possession. (Para 9)

heading: Adverse Possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse Possession - Defendant was in uninterrupted possession of suit land since 1952 till date of filing of suit in 1978 - Both the courts below admitted the same - However, declined to accept defendant's case of adverse possession - Firstly, on ground that defendant had not pleaded and proved date on which he came into such possession - Secondly, he did not plead or establish nature of his possession or the fact of plaintiff's knowledge of his adverse possession - Nobody's case that defendant had a permissive possession - Unless there is something to show that his possession is consistent with recognition of true owner's title, the possession will be adverse possession - As regards knowledge of true owner, law does not require any specific notice or proof for that matter - Thus, Courts below erred in applying the law of adverse possession to the facts of the case - Impugned order set aside. (Paras 8, 9, 10, 11)

heading: Adverse Possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse Possession - Knowledge of true owner as to - The possession should be open and not concealed - It should be effective so as to impute knowledge on the part of true owner - However, it is not for the adverse possessor to establish specific knowledge of true owner in all cases of adverse possession.	 (Para 11)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 9 years in filing appeal - Defendant came to know about suit when bailiff came to serve summons of execution proceeding - Original record of trial court shows entry of issuance of summons - Summons served or not mentioned in roznama - Defendant resident of Osmanpura but address given in suit summons of village Satara - Condonation of delay by appellate court, proper. 	(Para 15)

heading: Suit for recovery of pledged jewellery
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of pledged jewellery - Filed within three years from date of demand - Suit is within limitation.	(Para 23)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Scope and applicability of - Adverse possession - Art.65 would have been applicable only in case the defendants had set up a plea of adverse possession and proved it. 1998(1) SCC 614 - Ref. to.	(Para 12)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Court should refrain from highly pedantic approach in matters of Condonation - Approach which furthers the cause of substantial justice be adopted.  (Para 6)

heading: Condonation of delay
Challenge against
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Challenge against - Respondent contended that petitioner had acquiesced in the impugned order - Relied on the stand taken by petitioner in a subsequent litigation that proceedings have not abated - Fact also brought to the notice of Court that instant petition is filed by petitioner only after the petition filed by respondent - Held, acquiescence of petitioner cannot be inferred on such grounds - In order to bring home ground of acquiescence, a strong case has to be made out as it results in non-suiting a party. (Para 7)

heading: Plea of adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Plea of adverse possession - Not available to pendente lite purchaser - Because, to avail said plea, possession of party should be peaceful - If proceeding is pending, possession cannot be peaceful. (2004) 10 SCC 779 Ref. to. 	(Paras 41, 42)

heading: Suit for
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Specific performance of agreement - Suit for - Limitation - It is to be filed within period of 3 years from date fixed for execution of sale deed - Suit not filed within period of 3 years - Suit barred by limitation. 			(Para 15)

heading: Suit for partition
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Plea as to limitation - Plaintiff claimed 1/5th share in suit property devolved upon him on account of death of his father - Not a case where partition has already taken place and plaintiff is excluded from joint family property - Defendants had not raised plea of adverse possession in written statement - In absence of any such plea, plea of limitation was not available to defendants. AIR 1965 SC 271, (2004) 1 SCC 271, (2004) 13 SCC 385 Disting. 	(Paras 16, 17, 18)

heading: Condonation of delay
Costs
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Costs - By imposition of costs requirements of furnishing sufficient cause cannot be dispensed with - Costs cannot be a substitute for absence of reasons to condone delay. 	(Para 13)

heading: Civil P.C. (1908)
Restoration of appeal
Condonation of delay
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908) - Restoration of appeal - Condonation of delay - Dismissal of appeal initially in default - It was restored on application of respondents, stating reason for default that earlier counsel had not given no objection along with record of case - It was again dismissed on 23.11.2011 - Application for restoration was filed on 15.02.2012, stating same reason along with application for condonation of delay - No reason was given for delay - Appellate Court misdirected itself when it considered dismissal to be fault of counsel and reason for delay - Not proper - In absence of any proper explanation for delay, delay could not be condoned. 2010(6) ALL MR 480 (S.C.), AIR 1998 SC 2276, 2012(3) ALL MR 450 (S.C.) Rel. on. 		(Paras 9, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Delay of 54 days in filing revision - Reason stated that matter was entrusted to advocate 'M' who caused delay - Whereas record shows that matter was entrusted to advocate 'T' - Even if advocate 'M' was stated to be engaged only to instruct advocate 'T', such fact should have been reflected in condonation application - As explanation is plausible and applicant has not gained substantially by omitting reference to advocate 'T', condonation application is considerable - Prejudice suffered by non-applicant is required to be compensated - Delay condoned subject to payment of costs of Rs.1 lacs.  (1998) 7 SCC 123 Ref. to.			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Length of delay is no matter, acceptability of explanation is only criterion. (1998) 7 SCC 123 Rel. on. 	(Para 9)

heading: Regularisation of service
HeadNote.description: Regularisation of service - Delay of 8 years in challenging order - Court found reasons cited as fanciful, lackadaisical approach of the petitioner apparent on the face of the records - Reasons cited did not appear acceptable, much less convincing - Delay not condoned. 	(Paras 21, 22, 23)

heading: Limitation
Suit for possession
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Suit for possession - Whether falls under Art.58 or Art.65 of Limitation Act - Plaintiffs filed suit on basis of their title on suit structure - Defence that since plaintiff sought declaration that defendants have no right, title or interest on suit structure and on that basis plaintiffs claimed possession, suit falls under Art.58 - Not acceptable - Held, when possession is sought on basis of title, there is no need for plaintiff to seek such declaration - Suit must fall within Art.65. AIT 2000 SC 1099 Rel. on. 	(Para 7)

heading: Adverse possession
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Limitation - Plaintiffs claimed possession of suit premises through agreement of sale dated 24th July, 1997 with original owner - Defendant claimed adverse possession through agreement of sale entered in 1984 between it and one 'G' which was based on agreement of sale in year 1980 between 'G' and developer who entered into agreement of sale with original owner in 1979 - Agreement between developer and original owner was breached by developer and accordingly, notice of termination was sent to developer and therefore, possession of defendant is unauthorized and illegal - Agreement of sale between plaintiff and original owner was on "as is where is" basis and subject to occupation of third parties - Plaintiffs knew in month of July, 1997 that developer had not only breached agreement of sale with original owner but also inducted defendant illegally in suit premises - Since plaintiffs claimed possession through original owner, limitation period begins to run from date when original owner became aware of hostile possession of defendant - That was more than 12 years prior to filing of suit by plaintiffs in year 2009 - Submission made that unauthorized possession is continuing wrong - Not acceptable, neither S.27 nor Art.65 would make any sense, if adverse possession were to be treated as continuing wrong - Suit barred by limitation. 			(Paras 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17)

heading: Adverse possession
Claim of title
Maintainability
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Claim of title - Maintainability - Suit land was acquired by notifications in 1984 and 1986 - However, actual possession remained with original owner who sold it to plaintiff in 1994 - Plaintiff filed suit for declaration of title in year 2001 on basis of her possession for 7 yrs. plus previous possession of original owner totaling more than 12 yrs. - Plaintiff's claim of title on basis of adverse possession, held, not maintainable - Firstly because, purchase of land by her after notification of acquisition, is void - Secondly, possession of original owner cannot be counted while computing 12 yrs. period of adverse possession - Thirdly, even if plaintiff claims actual possession, paper possession was already taken by Authorities by drawing panchanama which is a valid mode - Fourthly, plaintiff's possession cannot be said to be open and peaceful in view of her own assertion that defendants had come to suit property in 2001 and demolished the structure on suit land.

2016 ALL SCR 320 Foll.

2007 ALL SCR 1582, (2013) 6 ADJ 119 Ref. to. 	(Paras 18, 22)

heading: Adverse possession
Not permissible
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Computation of 12 yrs period - Plaintiff purchased suit property after its acquisition - Plaintiff filed suit for declaration of title on basis of her possession for 7 yrs. plus previous possession of original owner totaling more than 12 yrs. - Not permissible - Plaintiff could count the period of adverse possession only from date she purchased the property - Period for which the original vendor held the property, cannot be counted. 	(Para 18)

heading: Limitation for
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration of title - Limitation for - Suit for declaration of title is continuous and, as such, a suit can be filed as long as title to property subsists - Unless and until respondents establish that they have become owners by adverse possession, suit cannot be said to be barred by limitation. 	(Para 5)

heading: Extension of period of limitation
HeadNote.description: Extension of period of limitation - Applies only to appeals or application and not to suit - No court or Tribunal can extend period of limitation for filing a suit - Even if any cause, beyond control of plaintiff is shown also - The only extension is what is permitted u/S.4 the period coming under court holiday.	(Para 6)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage - Limitation - Art.61(a) provides limitation of 30 years when right to redeem or recover possession accrues to mortgagor - Plaintiff executed mortgage deed in favour of defendant as security for loan and put him in possession of suit property for five years - Suit for redemption filed within 30 years after expiry of period of five years - Suit is not barred by limitation. 	(Para 34)

heading: Condonation of delay
Hence, delay condoned
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 604 days in filing appeal against decree of eviction - Decree passed on basis of compromise deed allegedly entered into between parties - Appellants tenants contending that compromise deed was signed by them under pressure exerted by Police - In cases where there is reasonable doubt that police may have forced a party to enter into compromise, process of court ought to weigh in favour of party alleging to be victim of such pressure - Hence, delay condoned - However, looking to fact that delay is of more than 600 days, appellants directed to pay cost of Rs.50,000/- to respondent.	(Paras 7, 15)

heading: Adverse possession
Plea as to
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Plea as to - Suit land was mortgaged to mortgagee by way of conditional sale - Mortgagee claiming adverse possession on ground that he was in possession of suit property even after repayment of mortgaged amount by mortgagor - Facts constituting adverse possession must be such that intention to hold property adversely to true owner must be manifest and open - Mortgagee in his evidence stated that mortgagor accepted his condition of reconveyance of land only on payment of market price prevailing at relevant time which is more than mortgaged amount - Mortgagee further deposed that however mortgagor paid only mortgaged debt and did not pay market price - Deposition of mortgagee itself shows continuation of jural relationship of mortgagor and mortgagee and not independent assertion of title adverse to mortgagor - Plea of adverse possession not sustainable. 			(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Legality
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration, injunction and possession - Dismissal on ground of limitation - Legality - High court observed that suit was filed for declaration and injunction only and not for possession therefore suit would be governed by limitation of 3 yrs. - Pleadings in the plaint showing that suit property was subject matter of proceedings u/S.145 Cr.P.C. between parties before Magistrate wherein parties were claiming their possession over suit property against each other - Said proceedings culminated in order of attachment dt.23/12/1966 - Plaintiff therefore filed suit on 19/12/1978 claiming declaration, injunction and possession - Thus, suit would be governed by limitation of 12 yrs. as per Art.65 of Limitation Act - Suit filed within limitation - Dismissal not proper. 	(Paras 15, 16, 17, 18)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration, injunction and possession - Limitation - Plaintiffs alleging in plaint that defendant's possession became adverse to the knowledge of plaintiffs for the first time when they asserted their right, title and interest over suit property in proceedings u/S.145 Cr.P.C. - Said proceedings culminated in order of attachment dt.23/12/1966 - Same furnished a cause of action to plaintiff for claiming declaration of their ownership over suit property and other consequential reliefs - Suit filed within 12 yrs. from date of attachment order, not barred by limitation. 	(Paras 19, 20)

heading: Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Sufficient cause - There is no set definition of expression 'Sufficient cause' - Whether explanation given constitutes sufficient cause or not, would depend on factual matrix of each case. 	(Para 16)

heading: Tenancy appeal
Delay in filing
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Tenancy appeal - Delay in filing - Condonation of - On ground that petitioner has no knowledge of passing of judgment and order by ALT, since it was not communicated to him - Delay of 11 years and 9 months - Nothing on record to indicate that decision were communicated to petitioner - However, in proceeding filed by petitioner under Forest Act, respondent intervened and disclosed that he was declared as tenant and also annexed copy of order of ALT - It shows that petitioners were aware about the order of ALT - Explanation given by petitioner is ex-facie not plausible - Further, petitioner has not explained its inaction for 11 years and 9 months - Delay cannot be condoned. 			(Paras 19, 20, 21, 22, 24)

heading: Suit for recovery of possession of ancestral house
HeadNote.description:
Suit for recovery of possession of ancestral house - Plea of adverse possession taken in written Statement - Except for bare statement no evidence produced by defendants - Decree passed by court in his favour cannot be sustained.

The defence in the case of adverse possession has definitely to indicate that the said possession of the defendants is with the knowledge of the plaintiffs or to the knowledge of the plaintiffs adverse to the possession of the plaintiffs and even adverse to the whole world. In the instant case, but for a bare statement in the written statement, which is a plea taken by way of an alternative plea, there is nothing which really can be said to have complied with the necessary ingredients of adverse possession. The plea taken is that "in the alternative, the defendants claim their ownership on the basis of adverse possession and that too of more than twelve years". This defence of adverse possession, is not sufficient.  [Para 8,9,10]

heading: Suit for recovery
Period of limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery - Period of limitation - Determination of starting point - Plaintiff claiming money under contract entered into with defendant - Limitation normally starts from date of payment of final bill - However, after date of final payment plaintiff made correspondences to defendant claiming additional payment - Said claim of plaintiff was entertained by defendant and kept pending - Hence, cause of action for suit would be date of rejection of claim by defendant - Suit filed prior to expiry of period of 3 years from said date - Not barred by limitation. (Para 11)

heading: Sustainability
Not permissible
HeadNote.description: Civil P.C. (1908), O.8 R.6A(4) - Plea of adverse possession - Sustainability - Plea raised by defendant in counter claim filed against plaintiff, claiming declaration of ownership over suit land - Not permissible - Counter claim is treated as plaint u/O.8 R.6-A(4) CPC - Status of defendant in counter claim is that of plaintiff because he seeks relief of passing decree in his favour against plaintiff - And a plaintiff cannot raise plea of adverse possession to claim ownership over suit property - Hence, plea not sustainable. 2014(7) ALL MR 813 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 32, 33)

heading: Sustainability
HeadNote.description: Wakf (Amendment) Act (1984), S.66G - Plea of adverse possession - Sustainability - Mere possession, however long does not necessarily mean it is adverse to true owner - Possession should be in denial of true owner's title - No pleadings as to from which date his possession became adverse to plaintiff - Also not clear when his adverse possession was completed and ripened into full ownership - Defendant failed to establish 30 years continuous possession adverse to plaintiff which is necessary under S.66G of Wakf Act, 1984 - Defendant failed to prove his adverse possession over suit property - Plea liable to be rejected. 2007(2) ALL MR 866 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			(Paras 36, 39, 40, 41)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Counsel for the Road Transport Corporation not informing it that writ petition filed against award of Labour Court was decided by High Court against it - Name of counsel removed from the panel and another counsel engaged through whom writ appeal was filed - Held, Division Bench was justified in condoning the delay in filing writ appeal after placing reasons on record.	(Para 5)

heading: Limitation for
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession and declaration - Limitation for - Is of 12 years - Merely because one of reliefs sought is of declaration that will not mean that outer limitation of 12 years is lost - Suit filed within period of 12 years - Suit is within limitation. 	(Para 9)

heading: Land acquisition
Determination
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Delay in filing application u/S.28A of LA Act - Whether, Limitation Act would apply - Determination - Land Acquisition Officer is not a 'Court' - Limitation Act would not apply. 	(Para 5)

heading: Land acquisition
Not tenable
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Delay in filing application u/S.28A - Application for condonation of delay - Not tenable - Application has to be filed within 3 months - Limitation u/S.28A would commence from date of award of court and only period in obtaining certified copy would be excluded - Question of getting knowledge of award would not arise. 2013(5) ALL MR 907 (S.C.), 2010 ALL SCR 778, (1997) 6 SCC 280 Rel. on. (Paras 5, 6, 7, 9)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition and separate possession - Limitation - Predecessor of appellants and predecessor of respondents were brothers who had jointly purchased suit property - Appellant filed said suit contending that in 1995 after demise of their predecessor, respondents refused their claim of half share in property - While, as per respondents, cause of action arose in 1974, when their predecessor constructed house and his name was reflected in Corporation records as owner of house - Not acceptable, as it was not event to demonstrate that rights of predecessor of appellants were being refuted by predecessor of respondents - Even no evidence to show that house was constructed exclusively by either of parties or expenses were borne by them jointly - Further, Authorities had issued notices and recovered non-agricultural assessment tax even from respondents and at best such documents demonstrated that both parties were jointly in ownership and possession of suit property - Therefore, recording of name in Corporation record would be of no avail - Claim that cause of action arose in 1995 is accepted and hence, suit not barred by limitation. 	(Para 18)

heading: Scope
Suit for possession
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Suit for possession - Defendants claiming to be in possession of land since 1934 as tenants of ex-Jahagirdar - No proof of dispossession of plaintiffs and at what point of time - Plaintiffs becoming permanent tenants in 1945 i.e. within 12 years from 1934 - filing suit for possession after commencement of 1963 Act. - Not barred under S.31.

In the instant case the defendants claimed adverse possession of the agricultural lands since 1934 as tenants of the ex-Jahagirdar and that the suit for possession filed by the plaintiffs who were declared as permanent tenants, after commencement of the limitation Act (1963) was barred under S.31 of the 1963 Act, since the period of 12 years under the 1908 limitation Act had already expire before the commencement of the 1963 Act.

Rejecting the contention of the defendants it was held

(i) that the defendant was paying rent to the Jahagirdar since 1934 did not prove adverse possession since there was no proof that any dispute existed between the Jahagirdar and the defendants.

(ii) Even assuming adverse possession the plaintiffs are the permanent tenant of the suit land as a result of registered deed dated 20th June 1945. Not only that, but in 1946 Reg.C.S. No.24-A of 1946 for possession came to be filed which was decreed in favour of plaintiffs and therefore the adverse possession did not get ripen.

(iii) The defendants claimed to be tenants. Thus the entry in the land itself is permissible and referable to the lawful title. Therefore adverse possession could not be claimed by the defendants. There is no pleading and evidence as to when the possession of the defendants became adverse to the plaintiffs. Not only that, but the fact of discontinuance or date of dispossession of the plaintiffs is not accepted by the defendants. On the contrary, the defendants are coming with a case that they are continuously in possession of the property and, therefore, there is no dispossession or discontinuance of the plaintiffs' possession. The defendants were under obligation to point out as to at what point of time, they started claiming possession adverse to the knowledge of the true owner. Pleading and evidence in this respect is absent and further-more, Articles 141, 142 and 144 of the Limitation Act, 1908 will have no application in the facts and circumstances of the case, because civil suit came to be filed in the year 1946 and decree for possession came to be passed in the said suit which, according to the plaintiffs, was executed in the year 1950-51. The cause of action if at all as contemplated under Article 142 or Article 144, has never taken place so as to hold that the period of limitation provided under these two Articles has expired prior to the coming into force the Limitation Act, 1963. Therefore, it could not be said that the suit for possession filed after commencement of the 1963 Act was not tenable in view of S.31 of that Act.  [Para 11,15]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 5 years and 75 days in filing appeal against ex-parte decree - Applicant claiming that by applying provisions of S.14 of Limitation Act, time spent in pursuing proceedings u/O.9 R.13 is to be excluded while considering period of delay in filing appeal u/S.96 CPC - Proceedings u/O.9 R.13 yet not attained finality and are still being prosecuted by applicant - Provisions of S.14 cannot be applied - No other sufficient cause shown by applicant for condoning delay in filing appeal - Delay cannot be condoned. 2015(2) ALL MR 321 Rel.on.			(Paras 6, 7, 9)

heading: Applicability of S.14
HeadNote.description:
Applicability of S.14 - Conditions to be satisfied - Stated.

	For the purposes of applying the provisions of S.14 of the Act of 1963, the conditions that are required to be satisfied are that the prior and subsequent proceedings are civil proceedings prosecuted by the same party, the prior proceeding had been prosecuted with due diligence and in good faith, the failure of the prior proceeding was due to defect of jurisdiction or other cause of a like nature, the earlier proceeding and the later proceeding must relate to the same matter in issue and both the proceedings must be in a Court. It is only after the aforesaid conditions are satisfied that the provisions of S.14 of the Act of 1963 or principles analogous thereto can be applied. 2008(6) ALL MR 423 (S.C.) Rel. on. 				 [Para 6]

heading: Appeal
Delay in filing
Condonation of
Application
HeadNote.description:
Appeal - Delay in filing - Condonation of - Application - Commissioner while hearing application not entitled to condone said delay, since S.5 of Limitation Act 1963, shall not be attracted in view of S.29(2) of Limitation Act - Tamil Nadu Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act (1959), S.69.

	The applicability of Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act 1963 is with regard to different limitations prescribed for any suit, appeal or application when to be filed in a Court.

	Section 29(2) cannot be pressed in service with regard to filing of suits, appeals and applications before the statutory authorities and tribunals provided in a special or local law. There The Commissioner while hearing of the appeal under Section 69 of the Act, 1959 is not entitled to condone the delay in filing appeal, since, provision of Section 5 of Limitation Act 1963 shall not be attracted by strength of Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act.

1975 ALLMR ONLINE 105 (S.C.) Foll. 				 [Para 58,59]

heading: Appeal
Delay in filing
Condonation
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Delay in filing - Condonation - Application u/S.5 of Limitation Act - S.115 of Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, indicates that provision for only computation of Limitation, made applicable to proceedings under said Act - It cannot be read in a manner as to providing for applicability of S.5 - Fact that suo motu power is given to commissioner u/S.69(2) to call for and examine record with object to ensure that order passed by Joint Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner may be corrected when appeal is not filed u/S.69(1) - Shows that applicability of S.5 of Limitation Act, never contemplated by Legislature in S.69(1) for condoning delay in filing appeal by applying S.5 of Limitation Act - Mere fact that statutory authority is empowered to follow procedure under Civil P.C. to trial of suits or hearing of appeals - Would not make statutory authority a "Court" - Nothing in S.110 to indicate applicability of Limitation Act in hearing of appeal - Tamil Nadu Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act (1959), Ss.69, 115, 110, 6(7).			(Paras 62, 63, 64, 65, 66, 67)

heading: Suit for specific performance of sale of land
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of sale of land - Case is governed by Art.54 and period of limitation is 3 years - Defendant to obtain permission of authorities as pre-condition - It indicates that time was not essence of contract - Plaintiff dispossessed from lands who was is possession in terms of agreement - It was an act of hostility by defendant against agreement of sale and cause of action arises on that date.	(Para 11)

HeadNote.sub_clause: S.14- Complaint for dishonour of cheque
heading: Limitation for filing complaint in proper forum
HeadNote.description: Limitation for filing complaint in proper forum - Period from the date of return, inclusive of the same, till the date of presentation of complaint before appropriate forum cannot be excluded - Court has no power to extend time. Negotiable Instruments Act (1881), S.138.			(Para 13)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay of 106 days in filing appeal - Delay occurred due to transfer of Chief Officer of Municipal Council - Said cause is sufficient to condone delay of 106 days in filing appeal - Further, if delay is condoned no serious prejudice would cause to respondent - Order refusing to condone delay on ground that there is no sufficient cause, improper - Delay condoned with cost of Rs.25,000/-. 	(Paras 7, 9)

heading: Condonation of delay
Application for
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Application for - While dealing with such application, Appellate Court is expected to have confined its enquiry to satisfy as to whether sufficient cause to condone delay has been assigned or not - Merit of matter could not have been looked into while deciding application for condonation of delay.  2013 ALL SCR 3236 Rel. on. 	(Para 7)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Suit for declaration that Will was null and void - Plea of defendants that suit is barred by limitation being not filed within three years when right to sue first accrued - At time of filing of suit which was instituted jointly one of plaintiff was minor - Other plaintiffs were not in position to give valid discharge to minor plaintiff as contemplated by S.7 of Limitation Act - Limitation for suit challenging Will would commence when plaintiff became major - Suit filed prior to expiry of period of limitation - Is not barred by limitation. (Para 15)

heading: Suit for declaration
Applicability of Art.58
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - Applicability of Art.58 - Claim for declaration that Will was null and void and defendants were not owners of suit property on basis of Will - No claim for relief of cancellation of Will - Provisions of Art.58 and not Art.59 would apply. 	 (Paras 17, 18)

heading: Suit for declaration
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - Claiming relief that Will was null and void and defendants were not owners of suit property on basis of Will - Limitation - As per Art. 58 limitation would start from date when right to sue first accrues - Actual threat to legal rights of plaintiffs surfaced when public notice was issued inviting objections in mutation proceedings - Cause of action to file suit accrued for first time when public notice was issued - Suit filed within period of three years from date of issuance of public notice - Not barred by limitation. 	(Paras 17, 18)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Delay in filing revision against order of issuance of process - Offence of dishonour of cheque by company - Process was issued against petitioner, director of company - Revision was filed by petitioner after six months from date of issuance of process - No sufficient cause disclosed to condone delay - Rejection of application for condonation of delay is proper. 	(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Adverse possession
Claim of
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Claim of - Watchman of society working on a petty monthly salary allowed to stay in suit property - Only by obtaining ration card and house tax receipts he cannot support his claim of adverse possession.  (Para 20)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Watchman, caretaker or a servant employed to look after property can never acquire interest in property - Courts are not justified in protecting their possession on grounds of justice, equity and good conscience - Courts must take notice of attempts to introduce untenable pleas and irrelevant documents while imposing costs. 

The plea of adverse possession which has no foundation or basis in the facts and circumstances of the case was introduced to gain undue benefit. The Court must be cautious in granting relief to a party guilty of deliberately introducing irrelevant and untenable pleas responsible for creating unnecessary confusion by introducing such documents and pleas. These factors must be taken into consideration while granting relief and/or imposing the costs.   [Para 41]

Watchman, caretaker or a servant employed to look after the property can never acquire interest in the property irrespective of his long possession. The watchman, caretaker or a servant is under an obligation to hand over the possession forthwith on demand. According to the principles of justice, equity and good conscience, Courts are not justified in protecting the possession of a watchman, caretaker or servant who was only allowed to live into the premises to look after the same. The watchman, caretaker or agent holds the property of the principal only on behalf the principal. He acquires no right or interest whatsoever in such property irrespective of his long stay or possession. The protection of the Court can be granted or extended to the person who has valid subsisting rent agreement, lease agreement or licence agreement in his favour.  [Para 42]

heading: Period of limitation for filing suit
HeadNote.description: Period of limitation for filing suit - No date fixed in agreement for its performance - Case would be governed by second category i.e. when plaintiff has a notice that performance is refused. 	(Para 50)

heading: Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Defendant claiming adverse possession contending that suit is barred by limitation - Held, it is incumbent on plaintiff to file suit within 12 yrs. from date when possession of defendant became adverse to plaintiff - Article 65 pre-supposes that limitation starts only if defendant proved factum of adverse possession affirmatively from particular time - Defendant failed to prove his adverse possession affirmatively - Mere contention that since 1979-80, plaintiff never objected to his possession over suit house, is not sufficient to hold that defendant became owner by adverse possession - Therefore, contention as to bar of limitation deserves no consideration. 2018 (10) Scale 630  Ref.to.			(Paras 19, 20)

heading: Suit for declaration
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - Limitation - Plaintiff sought declaration that sale deed dt.08.06.1977 was illegal as execution of sale deed was outcome of loan transaction and that upon repayment of loan, suit field would be re-conveyed -Defendant allegedly refused to accept amount when repayed and threatened plaintiff that he would take possession - Cause of action as pleaded to have arisen when name of defendant was mutated in revenue records on 21.07.1985 - Suit filed on 29.07.1985 would be within limitation even if Art.54 were to be applied - Suit is within limitation.	(Para 13)

heading: Adverse possession
Co-owners
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Co-owners - No adverse possession of one co-owner against others under denial of title and ouster of other co-owners is proved - Mere uninterrupted possessiion by a co-owner however long is not enough.  (Para 9)

heading: Bank guarantee
HeadNote.description: Bank guarantee - Limitation for suit against guarantor - In case of continuing bank guarantee, the limitation against the guarantor starts running from the date of default. AIR 1979 SC 102 - Rel. on.			(Paras 22, 23)

heading: Suit for declaration and possession
HeadNote.description:
Suit for declaration and possession - Limitation whether governed by Art.60 or 65 - Registered sale deeds of suit property was conveyed by father of minor - When sale deed was executed by father, he purported to convey right of minor also - Sale deeds being voidable and not void, plaintiffs cannot rely on Art.65 - Limitation for suit would be governed by Art.60.

	Article 60(b)(ii) refers to a suit when a ward dies before attaining majority. The present is a case where 'P' died on 11.02.1986 before attaining majority, his date of birth being 16.07.1978, the limitation to avoid instrument made by guardian of the ward is 03 years from the death of ward when he dies before attaining majority.

	Limitation under Art.65 is available when suit is filed for possession of immovable property on any interest therein based on title. The present is a case where by registered sale deeds the property was conveyed by the father of the minor was eonominee party. Thus, when sale deed was executed by 'B' he purported to convey the right of the minor also. The sale deeds being voidable and not void, plaintiffs cannot rely on Article 65. First Appellate Court and the High Court has rightly held that limitation for suit was governed by Article 60 and the suit was clearly barred by time.

(1999) 9 SCC 446, (2016) 6 SCC 725 Rel.on.	 [Para 9,11]

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - To file suit for possession of ancestral property, on basis of declaratory decree that its sale was illegal - Limitation of 3 yrs. to start from date on which declaratory decree is obtained - Decree passed in year 1963 but prepared and drawn only in Aug. 1972 - Expression "obtained" would pre-suppose securing a certified copy - Hence, date on which a formal decree is drawn would be relevant and not merely date of passing - Suit for possession filed in June 1974, is within limitation. 1975 ALLMR ONLINE 177 (S.C.) Rel. on. 	(Paras 16, 17, 20, 28)

heading: Exclusion of time
Applicability
