HeadNote.description: Exclusion of time - Applicability - Suit for possession of ancestral property, after obtaining declaratory decree that its alienation was illegal - Limitation of 3 yrs. (as per State Act) to start from "date on which right to sue accrued" - Right accrued on death of vendor in Jan. 1971 - However, instead of filing suit for possession, plaintiff applied for execution of declaratory decree in Feb. 1971 - Execution petition dismissed and plaintiff directed to file suit for possession only in Feb. 1974 - Finding that plaintiff was pursuing wrong remedy in good faith, not disputed - Time of 3 yrs. consumed before wrong forum, has to be excluded - Suit for possession filed in June 1974 is within limitation. 	(Paras 21, 22, 23)

heading: Applicability of S.14 of Limitation Act
HeadNote.description: Applicability of S.14 of Limitation Act - In view of special law of a State - Provisions u/Ss.4 to 24 shall apply unless expressly excluded by special Act - No indication in State Act i.e. Punjab Limitation (Customs) Act, excluding applicability of S.14 - In fact, S.5 of State Act uses expression "Subject to provision contained in Ss. 4 to 25 of Limitation Act" - S.14 would apply.	(Paras 24, 26)

heading: Limitation period
HeadNote.description: Bringing LRs on record - Limitation period - Appellant died in the year 1996 - First time, steps were taken in 2009 for bringing legal heirs on record and for setting aside abatement order in year 2011 - Held, applications deserve no consideration - As per Art.120 of Act legal heirs of deceased Appellant are bound to take steps in first place within 90 days to bring themselves on record - Moreover, Article 121 of Act provides that after expiry of said period of 90 days, on abatement of appeal, applicants should file application for setting aside abatement order within 60 days - However, no such steps were taken by Applicants - Their application liable to be dismissed. 			(Para 15)

heading: Suit instituted for recovery of hand loan given by defendant
HeadNote.description: Suit instituted for recovery of hand loan given by defendant - Period of limitation is three years - Suit instituted after period of three years would be barred under Art.19.			(Para 8)

heading: Exclusion of time
HeadNote.description: Exclusion of time - Proceedings in Court not having jurisdiction - Time can be excluded only if the proceeding is prosecuted bona fide in Court not having jurisdiction - Bona fide means honestly. AIR 1985 SC 1669 and (2008)7 SCC 169 - Ref. to. 			(Paras 27 and 28)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - In filing complaint for offence u/S.138 - Delay of three months - Complainant claiming that delay occurred as accused has not replied to first notice nor postal department furnished acknowledgment of first notice and therefore he has to issue second notice after which he filed complaint - High Court rejected application merely on presumption that first notice would be deemed to have been served if it was dispatched in ordinary course - But complainant shown sufficient cause for condonation of delay in filing complaint - Delay condoned. 	(Para 11)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Corporate insolvency resolution process - Application for initiation of - Limitation - Application u/S.7 of Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, would be governed by Art.137 and not by Art.62 - As Art.62 applies only to suits. 	(Para 6)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Corporate insolvency resolution process - Application for initiation of - Limitation - Right to sue accrues on 21.07.2011 - Application filed in 2017 i.e. after period of limitation of 3 years as provided in Art.137 is lapsed - Application barred by limitation. 		(Para 6)

heading: Entertainable
HeadNote.description:
Plea as to bar of limitation - Raised for the first time in appeal - Entertainable - Held, question of limitation is a mandate for forum and irrespective of fact whether it was raised or not, forum must consider and apply it - Parties entitled to raise plea of limitation in appeal or successive appeal or even in court of last resort. 

(2003) 9 SCC 505, AIR 1944 Privy Council 24 Rel. on. 	(Para 6)

heading: Suit for enhanced compensation
HeadNote.description:
Suit for enhanced compensation - On ground that defendant caused delay in handing over site which led to increased cost of contract for plaintiff - Claim of plaintiff cannot be said to have arisen outside the contract - Change in circumstances directly attributable to breaches committed by defendant - Suit would therefore fall within ambit of Art.55 of Limitation Act - Art.311 is a residuary provision, cannot be resorted to. 

(1969) 3 SCC 607 Disting. 	(Para 8)

heading: Suit for partition
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Limitation - Plaintiff and defendant are co-owners of suit property after death of their father - Consent award was declared on 15th April 1986 wherein property dispute between them was settled on certain terms - Decree in terms of consent award was passed in 1991 - If case of plaintiff is that he is deprived of his father's property, Art.106 would be attracted - Time begins u/Art.106 when legacy and share become payable or deliverable - Suit filed in 2011 is beyond period of 12 years - Hence, barred by limitation. 	(Paras 63, 64)

heading: Suit seeking true and correct accounts from defendant
HeadNote.description: Suit seeking true and correct accounts from defendant - Time commences when right to sue first accrues - Consent award between parties were made in 1986 - Decree was passed in 1991 - Right to sue for said relief arose in 1991 - Suit filed in 2011, barred by limitation. 	(Para 66)

heading: Suit for declaration
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - To the effect that documents executed by and between defendants, were illegal - Other reliefs of seeking delivery of documents and their cancellation also sought - For relief of declaration, Art.58 would be applicable - Whereas for delivery of documents, Art.113 would be applicable - Plaintiff was aware of such documents as the long registration of documents itself amounts to constructive notice - Right to sue accrued to plaintiff much prior to 3 years before filing of suit - Suit barred by limitation. 	(Para 67)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates (Control) Act (1947), S.13 - Limitation - Suit for recovery of possession - Application for condonation of delay and setting aside abatement by legal heirs of plaintiff - Pleading by legal heirs that they got knowledge of proceedings when all family members assembled after death of father of plaintiff in December 2011 - Thereafter applications were filed in January 2012 and delay was not occasioned deliberately - Sufficient cause for delay shown - Rejection to condone delay is liable to be set aside.

Court are required to adopt liberal approach while acceptance of 'sufficient cause' and normally explanation should be accepted as Rule and rejection thereof  should be in exceptional cases.

Words 'Sufficient cause' in S.5 of Limitation Act should receive liberal construction so as to advance substantial justice, when delay is not on account of any dilatory tactics, want of bona fides, deliberate inaction or negligence on part of appellant. Courts while dealing with this kind of application will have to keep in mind that valuable right accrues to legal representatives of deceased respondent when appeal abates. In this case defendant no.1 cannot claim that valuable rights have accrued in its favour by demise of some of plaintiffs and failure to bring their legal representatives on record. Delay is liable to be condoned.

1987(2) SCC 107, 1996 (2) SCC 568, 2002(2) ALL MR 588 (S.C.), 2005(2) ALL MR 268, 2010(6) ALL MR 480 (S.C.), AIR 1965 SC 1794 Referred. 		           [Para 12,13]

heading: Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Plea of adverse possession - Burden of proof - Is on person who is raising it to prove same by proper pleadings and evidence. 			(Para 18)

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Rejection of plaint on ground of bar of limitation - Challenge - Agreement for sale entered into on 20/2/1988 - No date fixed for performance, therefore limitation would be reckoned from date of refusal to perform - Averments in plaint showing that heirs of vendor executed development agreement dt.31/12/2007 and also a power of attorney in favour of D-1 in respect of suit land - Further averment that heirs of vendor also applied for survey of suit land to which plaintiff objected by letter dt.7/5/2008 to Survey Officer - Said development agreement and application was therefore an affront to plaintiff's right he claimed under agreement dt.20/2/1988 - Hence, development agreement and application for survey, would have to be construed as refusal on part of heirs to complete transaction which their father had entered into - Therefore, suit ought to have been filed within 3 yrs. of 1/3/2008 or at least within 3 yrs. of 7/5/2008 when plaintiff objected the survey - Same being not done by plaintiff, suit barred by limitation - Rejection of plaint held proper. 	(Para 17)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Limitation - Suit filed beyond 3 yrs. from date of refusal to perform - Contention that in the suit, recovery of possession is also sought therefore limitation would be 12 yrs. - Cannot be accepted as suit was essentially filed for specific performance - Other reliefs are only offshoot of said principal relief - Moreover, no whisper in the plaint as to when plaintiff has lost possession and as to who dispossessed him - Conduct of plaintiff belies plaintiff's case of any such dispossession - Therefore, period of limitation would be 3 yrs from date of refusal as no date of performance mentioned in agreement. (Para 17)

heading: Suit for specific performance
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance - Whether barred by limitation - Agreement for sale entered into on 20/2/1988 - No date fixed for performance, therefore limitation would be reckoned from date of refusal to perform - Averments in plaint showing that heirs of vendor executed development agreement dt.31/12/2007 and also a power of attorney in favour of D-1 in respect of suit land - Document in question i.e. agreement dt.31/12/2007 being registered, would constitute notice in terms of S.3 of TP Act - Thus, plaintiff had a notice of document being executed and consequentially refusal on part of heirs to complete transaction - Suit however filed in June 2011, barred by limitation.  2007 ALL SCR 1430 Rel. on. 	(Para 20)

heading: Time barred debt
HeadNote.description: Time barred debt - Contract as to payment of time barred debt - Debtor can always agree to pay time barred debt for which no consideration is required and promise to pay time barred debt can always be considered as a valid contract.	(Para 10)

heading: Condonation of delay
Sufficient cause
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Sufficient cause - Delay of 4 years and 10 days in filing appeal - Appellant submits that delay occurred due to delay in receiving confirmation from higher authority to file appeal, which alleged to be received in November 2010 - Evidence of witness does not show on which date proposal was sent to Higher Authority for its opinion on filing of appeal - Nor copy of said proposal was produced by appellant despite submitting that it was available in office - No steps taken to file appeal despite receiving knowledge of decision of trial court on same day on which it was rendered - Letter by which permission alleged to be received from head office, does not speak of any approval for filing appeal - Further, submission of appellant that Advocate could not file appeal immediately as he has to shift his office and in meanwhile case papers were also misplaced, is not believable - As appellant has not examined advocate - Appellant failed to give sufficient cause for delay in filing appeal - Delay cannot be condoned. 			(Paras 16, 17, 18, 20, 21, 23)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Proof of sufficient cause - Is pre-condition for exercise of discretion in favour of applicant for condoning delay. 

2012(3) ALL MR 450 (S.C.) Rel. on.			(Para 23)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Claim for possession of property pursuant to partition in joint family and at same time claim for property by adverse possession - Is not permissible. 2014(6) ALL MR 1 Rel. on. 			(Paras 37, 38)

heading: Plea of adverse possession by co-heir
HeadNote.description: Plea of adverse possession by co-heir - Possession of one co-heir did not render its possession adverse to other co-heirs who are not in possession - Ouster of other co-heirs must be evident by open assertion of hostile title, coupled with exclusive possession and enjoyment by one of them to knowledge of other - Co-heir failed to prove exclusive possession of suit property - Co-heir cannot claim possession of suit property by adverse possession. 2015 ALL SCR 3381 Rel. on. 	(Para 35)

heading: Partition suit
HeadNote.description: Partition suit - Plaintiff failed to prove that he was in cultivating possession of suit field till he fell ill - Plaintiff also failed to prove that original holder was his great grand father and that suit land was his ancestral property - Moreover mutation in name of three defendants as owners after death of their father, was never challenged by plaintiff or his father - Plaintiff also failed to prove his title - Further change in onus about adverse possession due to Limitation Act, 1963, of no relevance - Order dismissing suit for partition and separate possession - Proper.	(Paras 20, 21, 22, 23)

heading: Cross-objection
Delay in filing
HeadNote.description: Cross-objection - Against order passed in reference proceeding - Delay in filing - Application for condonation of - On ground that same could not be filed for want of funds - Claimants have withdrawn entire amount of enhanced compensation passed in reference proceeding - Now they cannot contend that cross-objection could not be filed for want of funds - Delay cannot be condoned. 	(Para 7)

heading: Suit for specific performance of an agreement to reconvey property executed in 1951
HeadNote.description: Suit for specific performance of an agreement to reconvey property executed in 1951 - Agreement not providing any definite time for reconveyance - Suit for reconveyance filed in 1981 after demanding reconveyance in same year - Plaintiff deposing to have made a demand in 1961 which he did not pursue - Suit in 1981 held barred by limitation - When no definite time provided for reconveyance demand for reconveyance must be made within reasonable time. (Para 9)

heading: Suit for damages
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act (1989), Ss.22, 3(1)(x) - Malicious prosecution under SC/ST Act - Suit for damages - Limitation - Suit filed on 25.09.2006 - Acquittal order passed on 23.9.2005 - That day would have to be excluded as per S.9 of General Clauses Act and thus, period of one year would commence from 24.9.2005 - 23.9.2006 was Saturday on which Court was closed, so also 24.9.2006 which was Sunday - Suit has been filed on 25.9.2006, which is next working day and therefore, is within limitation.  1956 ALLMR ONLINE 241 (S.C.), 2001(1) ALL MR 543 (S.C.), 1999(2) ALL MR 265 (S.C.) : 1999 ALL MR (Cri) 521 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Para 12)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Suit for declaration of ownership by respondent lessee - By taking plea of sham transaction (sale deed in favour of appellants) - Plea not only prohibited by Benami Transactions (Prohibition) Act, but makes appellants absolute owner - Plea not tenable. (Para 18)

heading: Delay of 305 days in filing special leave petition by the State
HeadNote.description:
Delay of 305 days in filing special leave petition by the State - Circumstances mentioned in the application not showing sufficient cause to condone the delay - Application can be dismissed without issuing notice to the other side - Only when the Court is prima facie of the view that there could be sufficient cause, notice is required to be issued.

It is, therefore, only when this Court from the facts stated in the application seeking condonation of delay is prima facie of the view that there could be sufficient cause that notice is required to the issued. If the application does not make out any such cause there is no bar dismissing the application without notice to the other party. Since no sufficient cause was shown by the petitioner the petition was dismissed on the ground of delay.  [Para 23]

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Applicability - Preconditions for.

For the applicability of Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act, the following requirements must be satisfied by the Court invoking the said provision : (1)  There must be a provision for period of limitation under any special or local law in connection with any suit, appeal or application. (2)  Such prescription of the period of limitation under such special or local law should be different from the period of limitation prescribed by the Schedule to the Limitation Act, 1963. [Para 38]

heading: Suit by person excluded from joint family property to enforce share in property
HeadNote.description: Suit by person excluded from joint family property to enforce share in property - Limitation of 12 years - Positive act of exclusion must become known to plaintiff.			(Para 17)

heading: Exclusion of period of appeal
HeadNote.description: Exclusion of period of appeal - Railway Tribunal declaring revision of railway freight as unreasonable - Special leave petition against decision of Tribunal granted - S.46-A of Railways Act though grants finality to decision of Tribunal cannot exclude jurisdiction of Supreme Court to hear appeal by special leave - Once leave to appeal is granted correctness of Tribunal's decision is wide open - Hence limitation for filing suit to claim refund of excess amount of freight illegally realised would run from date of order in SLP.	(Paras 13 to 17)

heading: Starting point of limitation under the two Articles
HeadNote.description:
Starting point of limitation under the two Articles - Distinction between.

A distinction, which is required to be noticed is that whereas in terms of Article 58 the period of three years is to be counted from the date when 'the right to sue first accrues'; in terms of Article 113 thereof, the period of limitation would be counted from the date 'when the right to sue accrues'. The distinction between Article 58 and Article 113 is, thus, apparent inasmuch as the right to sue may accrue to a suitor in a given case at different points of time and, thus, whereas in terms of Article 58 the period of limitation would be reckoned from the date on which the cause of action arose first, whereas, in the latter the period of limitation would be differently computed depending upon the last day when the cause of action therefor arose.   [Para 21]

heading: Land acquisition appeal
Delay in filing
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition appeal - Delay in filing - Condonation of - In matters of compensation for land acquisition, approach of Court has to be pragmatic and liberal on aspect of condonation of delay - For purpose of balancing equities, applicants can be denied interest for period for which they did not approach Court - Such course would enable applicants to receive similar compensation as that received by adjoining land owners whose lands were acquired under same notification and granted enhanced compensation - State would also not be burdened by amount of interest as no interest would be payable for period of delay - Delay liable to be condoned. 			(Para 6)

heading: Claim for stridhana
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Claim for stridhana - Limitation - Claim for stridhana denied by administrator of estate in 1955 - Claim for movable properties are required to be made and filed within 3 years of denial of those claims - Claim barred by limitation as not brought within 3 years of denial - Order of lower Court that claim for Stridhana was not sustainable was proper.	(Para 152)

heading: Execution of decree
Limitation
Contract of sale
Specific performance
HeadNote.description:
Execution of decree - Limitation - Contract of sale - Specific performance - Judgment debtor and decree holder directed to demarcate land and deposit balance consideration by specified date - Judgment debtor failing to demarcate land by specified date - Decree will become executable from specified date.

If the direction given in the decree to the judgment-debtor to measure and demarcate the land by that date (23-9-1966) was not complied with the decree-holder was free to execute the decree. The steps to be taken by the decree-holder in this regard are provided in O.21, R.34(1) CPC. A specified date was mentioned in the decree for the judgment-debtor to carry out the aforementioned direction i.e. 23-9-1966 and if he failed to carry out the direction it was open to the decree-holder to seek help of the executing Court for measurement and demarcation of the land, and thereafter, to get the sale deed executed by the judgment-debtor if possible or by the Court if necessary. The decree-holder for reasons best known to him did not choose to execute the decree till April 1980. On a fair reading of the decree in the context of the provisions of Art.136 of the Limitation Act the conclusion is inescapable that the execution petition was filed after expiry of the period of limitation prescribed under the Act.	   [Para 16,17]

heading: Period of limitation
HeadNote.description:
Period of limitation - Fixation of.

The fixation of periods of limitation are bound to be to some extent arbitrary and may at times result in hardship. But in construing such provisions equitable considerations are out of place and the strict grammatical meaning of the words is the only safe guide.AIR 1932 PC 165 Ref.	 [Para 16]

heading: Knowledge
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description:
Knowledge - Burden of proof - Plaintiff must establish, at any rate prima facie, that the suit is within time.

A person having the right to the possession of a property wrongfully taken from him by another can file a suit to recover the said specific movable property or for compensation therefor within three years from the date when he first learns in whose possession it is. Obviously where a person has a right to sue within three years from the date of his coming to know of a certain fact, it is for him to prove that he had the knowledge of the said fact on a particular date, for the said fact would be within his peculiar knowledge. That apart, S. 3 of the Limitation Act makes it obligatory on a court to dismiss a suit barred by limitation, although limitation has not been set up as a defence, indicating thereby that it is the duty of a plaintiff to establish, at any rate prima facie, that the suit is within time. It is the obligation of the plaintiff to satisfy the court that his action is not barred by lapse of time. ILR 5 Pat 312 and ILR 60 Bom 848 - Foll.  [Para 11]

The burden of proof is on a plaintiff who asserts a right, and it may be, having regard to the circumstances of each case, that the onus of proof may shift to the defendant. But to say that no duty is cast upon the plaintiff even to allege the date when they had knowledge of the defendant's possession of the converted property and that the entire burden is on the defendant is contrary to the tenor of the article in the Limitation Act and also to the rules of evidence. ILR 13 Pat 752 - Overruled.  [Para 12]

heading: Suit for cancellation of transaction
HeadNote.description: Suit for cancellation of transaction - On ground of being void or voidable - Suit ought to be filed within three years from date of knowledge of the fact that the transaction which according to the plaintiff was void or voidable had taken place. 1996(7) SCC 767, 2009 ALL SCR 786 - Rel.on.	(Para 19)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Urbanisation of rural area and land vested in Central Government - Appellants running restaurant on land - Appellants one after other filed 3 suits pleading different causes of action on different dates - As per 1st suit cause of action accrued in 1990 when respondents authority threatened to demolish restaurant structure - Therefore suit filed for injunction in year 2000 is beyond period of limitation. Constitution of India, Art.136. 			(Paras 27, 28, 29)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Title to schedule property - Not found to have been acquired by appellant by sale deed of year 1915 and settlement deed of 1919 - Thus, no finding can be recorded as regards adverse possession or ouster.	(Para 68)

heading: Provisions of Limitation Act
HeadNote.description:
Provisions of Limitation Act - Do not apply to quasi judicial proceedings.
AIR 1980 MP 106, 2005(5) ALL MR 232 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Paras 16, 17)

heading: Movable property
HeadNote.description: Movable property - Everything that is not immovable is movable - Suit bonds, held, are specific moveable property to which Art.91(1) applied. 	(Para 16)

heading: Term "first learns"
HeadNote.description:
Term "first learns" - Implies knowledge on part of plaintiff of specific person in whose possession bonds are - Mere suspicion is not enough for limitation to start running.

A perusal of Article 91(a) of the Limitation Act shows that it is meant to apply to specific movable property. It further stipulates that the period of limitation shall start running from the date when the person 'first learns' about the conversion of the moveable property. While it is true that the word used in the said Article is "first learns" and not knowledge, it is difficult to construe the word "first learns" without attributing to it certain degree of knowledge. The provision of Article 91 (a) of the Limitation Act thus demands two things. First is knowledge on the part of the plaintiff, and second, that the said fact be within his peculiar knowledge. The term "first learns" places a burden of knowledge which is rather specific in nature. Thus, the knowledge must be of the identity of a specific person in whose possession the bonds are and that he acquired the possession of the said bonds under an arrangement, which in law would constitute wrongful conversion. The knowledge of a specific person against whom the suit can be instituted is what is crucial here. A mere suspicion or a whisper of knowledge is not enough for the period of limitation to start running. 				    [Para 18]

heading: Second appeal
HeadNote.description: Second appeal - Substantial question of law - Attraction of bar of limitation - It is to be considered as a substantial question of law. (2005)10 SCC 455 - Rel. on.	(Para 37)

heading: Ownership
HeadNote.description:
Ownership - Mere possession for long many years will not ripe into ownership unless element of hostility is proved.

Mere possession for long many years will not ripe into ownership unless element of hostility is proved.

In case of joint Hindu Family, there is commonness of interest and unity of possession amongst all members of joint family and every co-parcener is entitled to joint possession and enjoyment of co-parcenery property. The mere fact that one of the co-parceners is not in joint possession does not mean that he has been ousted. The possession of the family property by a family must be held to be on behalf of himself and other members and possession of one is possession of all.  AIR 1995 SC 895 - Rel. on.	 [Para 23]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - There can be no adverse possession without hostile animus.

There is a real distinction between adverse possession and possession simplicitor. Possession in order to be adverse must be hostile to that of true owner. Fundamental principle of law is that there can be no adverse possession without hostile animus. The starting point of limitation begins from the expression of hostile animus amounting to denial of title of the real owner to his knowledge. This must continue for uninterrupted period of 12 years. 						    [Para 13]

heading: Ayodhya dispute
HeadNote.description:
Ayodhya dispute - Applicability of Limitation Act - Fiction that deity is perpetual minor - Does not exempt it from law of limitation.

	The legal fiction of a deity as a minor has been evolved to obviate the inability of the deity to institute legal proceedings on its own. A human agent must institute legal proceedings on behalf of the deity to overcome the disability. However, the fiction has not been extended to exempt the deity from the applicability of the law of limitation. 	 [Para 421,425]

heading: Adverse possession
Claim by defendant
Sustainability
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Claim by defendant - Sustainability - Previous ownership of plaintiff must be admitted - In instant case, defendants nowhere admitted ownership of plaintiff - They only claimed possession since last 40 yrs. - There is concurrent findings of Courts below that plaintiff received possession of suit land in year 1979 under decree of Court - No specific date given by defendant as to when they came into possession - Claim of adverse possession not sustainable. 2017(4) ALL MR 448 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Para 26)

heading: Exclusion of time
HeadNote.description:
Exclusion of time - Compromise decree passed was as good as final decree - Appellant filing partition suit and for declaring exparte compromise decree as null and void - Suit remained pending for more than 21 years - There was no stay of earlier judgment - In absence of any interdiction by any court decree holders were entitled to execute decree - Held as compromise decree was immediately executable period spent in subsequent suit cannot be excluded and execution proceeding was barred by limitation.
AIR 2010 Jhar 10 Disting.  (Para 35)

heading: Specific performance
Relief
HeadNote.description:
Specific performance - Relief - Period of three years mentioned in Art.54 will start to run from the date of cause of action which can be ascertained on the basis of two circumstances that can arise in this Article.

There are two parts, the circumstances, on the basis of which the cause of action can arise in Article 54 of the Limitation Act, 1963 and they are: (i) when the date of performance is fixed and the promisor has not performed his part of contract within prescribed period, and (ii) when the date, time is not fixed, but the plaintiff can gather that the performance is refused by the promissor. Thus, the period of limitation of three years mentioned in Article 54 will start to run from the date of cause of action which can be ascertained on the basis of aforesaid two circumstances. In this case, even after it is presumed that time was not essence of contract, the plaintiff ought to have filed suit within reasonable time from the date of agreement. It ought to have presumed by plaintiff that the promisor had refused to perform her part of the contract. However, the pleadings and the contents of the agreement shows that the time of four months was fixed and no explanation is given by the plaintiff as to why there was such mention in the agreement. In view of these circumstances, for the present matter, it can be said that the time started to run after expiry of four months, which need to be counted from the date of agreement. 		 [Para 9,13]

heading: Suit for recovery of possession by reversioner
HeadNote.description: Suit for recovery of possession by reversioner - Period of limitation would commence from death of widow who inherited property of her husband - Death of widow in year 1938 - Very right of alleged reversioner 'J' for filing suit for possession ran out in 1950 with running out period of limitation of 12 years u/Arts.140, 141 - Thus, when 'J' executed sale in favour of appellants in year 1955 she could not convey any right - Even taken that period of limitation would start from 12 years from 1955, the said period ran out in 1967 - Suit for possession filed by appellants even several years after 1967 would not also be maintainable in view of S.31 of 1963 Act.			(Paras 26, 28)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Depends upon the question as to whether document was required to be set aside - Deed of partition dt.5.8.1983 - In the fact situation found to be only voidable and not void - Hence it was required to be set aside and suit filed long after in 1990 was barred by limitation.			(Para 57)

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - A person pleading adverse possession has no equity in his favour since he tries to defeat rights of true owner - It is for him to clearly plead and establish all facts necessary to establish adverse possession - It is high time for law makers to consider at least abolition of "bad faith" adverse possession. (Paras 8, 9)

heading: Legality
HeadNote.description: Title by adverse possession - Decree in favour of State Govt. - Legality - Wire fencing on open land by Govt. - Plaintiff complained encroachment on his land and sent letters and notices to Govt. - Ownership of plaintiff not disputed - Vague statement made by Govt. that suit land was acquired but no evidence produced to that effect - Court below erroneously threw burden on plaintiff to prove that suit land was not acquired - Besides, State Govt. pleaded adverse possession only in one line without any foundation or evidence - Decree in favour of State Govt. is wholly illegal and unsustainable - Plaintiff entitled to compensatory cost of Rs.5000/- in view of unlawful encroachment on his property for several years. (Paras 10, 11, 12, 14)

heading: Suit for partition
HeadNote.description: Suit for partition - Applicability of Art.65(b) of Limitation Act - Art.65(b) is applicable only where property is not claimed through female but independently of woman who has died -Plaintiff-legal heir claiming property from Hindu female who was full owner - It could not be said that plaintiffs would be entitled to property independently of rights of female - Also defendant failed to prove adverse possession - Art.65(b) would not be applicable to plaintiffs. AIR 1916 Oudh 50, AIR 1918 Oudh 32, AIR 1923 Oudh 185 Rel. on. 2006 (4) SCC 482 Disting. 	(Paras 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13)

heading: Word 'entitled'
HeadNote.description: Word 'entitled' - Contained in explanation (b) to Art.65 of Limitation Act, means person is entitled independently of right of Hindu or Mohammedan female. 	(Para 8)

heading: Adverse possession
Plea by State
HeadNote.description: Adverse possession - Plea by State - Not permissible, it being welfare State. (Para 10)

heading: Cross-objections
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Cross-objections - Limitation - Delay of just over two months in filing cross-objections - Initially, appellants suffered ex parte decrees before both Trial Court and First Appellate Court - Once Appellate Court restored appeal, appellants filed their cross-objections - Neither delay condonation application filed nor any discussion by First Appellate Court as to whether delay deserved to be condoned or not - First Appellate Court has simply ruled that cross-objections were presented beyond 30 days and considered crossob crossobjections on merits - No occasion for First Appellate Court to examine whether appellants had shown sufficient cause for presenting cross-objections belatedly - Considering circumstances, one chance in interest of justice is to be given to apply for delay condonation - Matter remanded back to be considered afresh. (Paras 39, 40)

heading: Suit for declaration
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for declaration - Limitation - Suit was filed in 2009 against agreement executed in 1993 - Would be barred by limitation - Fact that suit was filed on granting liberty by High Court to initiate appropriate proceedings - Would not result in commencement of fresh cause of action since suit already became time barred on that date - Suit before trial court thus was ex facie barred by limitation - Finding that limitation is saved, since no limitation is prescribed for possession unless adverse possession is shown or suit is filed for enforcement of statutory obligation under MOFA Act 1963 is ex facie perverse and liable to be set aside. 	(Paras 102, 105, 106, 111, 135, 136, 137, 139, 140, 144)

heading: Limitation
Exclusion of period
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Exclusion of period - Absence of specific pleading making out a case for exclusion - Does not preclude High Court from exercising power u/S.14 of Limitation Act - Moreso when institution of original petition before the National Commission and its disposal, are beyond pale of controversy and plaint makes a specific reference to said order. (Para 21)

heading: Limitation
Exclusion of period
HeadNote.description:
Institution of fresh suit - Limitation - Exclusion of period - S.14(3) of Limitation Act operates as proviso to R.2 O.23 CPC.

Sub-section (3) of section 14 of the Limitation Act professes to relieve a plaintiff from the rigour of Rule 2 of Order XXIII in the matter of limitation. It provides that notwithstanding anything contained in Rule (2) of Order XXIII of the Code, the provisions of sub-section (1) of section 14 shall apply in relation to a fresh suit instituted on a permission granted by the court under Rule 1 of that Order, where such permission is granted on the ground that the first suit must fail by reason of a defect in the jurisdiction of the court or other cause of a like nature. Sub-section (3) of section 14 thus operates as a proviso to Rule 2 of Order XXIII. (Para 26)

heading: Limitation
Exclusion of time
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Exclusion of time - Fact that defendant was not impleaded as party opponent to original petition before National Commission - Disentitles plaintiff from claiming benefit of exclusion of time spent in said petition, u/S.14(1) of Limitation Act qua said defendant - Therefore, institution of suit for recovery of specific movable property, jewellery or value thereof after three years of knowledge of unlawful conversion, against said defendant - Held, barred by limitation.

In the instant case, where it is alleged that the defendant had wrongfully converted the movables and a decree for those specific movables or the value thereof is sought, the non-impleadment of such defendant in the previous proceeding implies that the plaintiff allowed the period of limitation to lapse qua the said defendant to his own peril.

For the foregoing reasons, in the peculiar facts of the case, the fact that defendant was not impleaded as a party opponent to the original petition before the National Commission, which was withdrawn, disentitles the plaintiff from claiming the benefit of the exclusion of the time spent in the said petition, under section 14(1) of the Limitation Act, 1963, qua the said defendant and the institution of the suit for recovery of the specific movable property or value thereof after three years of the knowledge of unlawful conversion must be held to be barred by limitation.

The matter can be looked at from a slightly different angle. If it is held that the non-impleadment of a defendant in the previous proceedings does not matter at all if some of the co-defendants only were parties in the previous proceedings, it may lead to serious prejudice in some cases. Under some of the enactments, a shorter period of limitation is provided for institution of the proceedings than the one provided by the Schedule to the Limitation Act, 1963. For example, the Major Port Trusts Act, 1963 provides a shorter period of limitation for institution of the proceedings against a Port Trust. If in respect of cause of action against a Port Trust and a private party, a proceeding is instituted against a private party and later on withdrawn with liberty to institute a fresh proceeding on the same cause of action and, in the meanwhile, the period of limitation prescribed by the statute against the Port Trust expires, the grant of benefit of section 14 of the Limitation Act, 1963, despite the Port Trust being not a party to the previous proceeding, would run counter to the statutory scheme under the special enactment. (Paras 30, 31, 32, 33)

heading: On fresh payment
HeadNote.description:
Fresh period of limitation - On fresh payment - For availing benefit of S.19, mere payment is not sufficient - Two conditions must be satisfied - First, payment must be made within limitation - Second, it must be acknowledged in writing.
(2020) 2 SCC 677 Rel. on. (Paras 20, 22)

heading: Condonation of delay
Exclusion of time
Appeal
Followed.	 [Para 16]
HeadNote.description:
Condonation of delay - Exclusion of time - Appeal - Application for certified copy of judgment and order - Application not made within period of limitation - Appellant cannot claim benefit of exclusion of time required for obtaining certified copy of judgment and decree.

Question of giving benefit of exclusion of a period required for obtaining certified copy of the Judgment and decree while filing the appeal can arise only in cases where the party applies for certified copy of the Judgment and decree within the period of limitation and not otherwise.  A party sleeping over his right for the entire period of limitation and thereafter asking for the certified copy of the Judgment and decree cannot claim benefit of exclusion of the said period while computing period of limitation which he would have otherwise been entitled to under Section 12, had he filed application for certified copy within the period of limitation.  Learned Advocate for the Respondents is therefore justified in contending that in case where application for certified copy of the Judgment and decree is filed beyond the period of limitation prescribed for filing of the appeal the party cannot avail the benefit of exclusion of period under section 12 of the Limitation Act.  AIR 1977 SC 2319 and AIR 1979 Bom. 33(DB) - Followed.	 [Para 16]

heading: Civil P.C. (1908), O.34, R.7(2)
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), O.34, R.7(2) - Mortgage by conditional sale - Deposit of amount after period stipulated in preliminary decree has expired - Held, in any eventuality, the Court could not have extended time for depositing the amount beyond the period of limitation prescribed under the Statute.

In the present case, considering the nature of transaction and considering the finding recorded by the trial court, while passing preliminary decree it cannot be said that the character of transaction as contended by the applicants is         of "usufructuary mortgage." However, the same has been construed as mortgage by conditional sale as defined in section 58(c) of Transfer of Properties Act. It was not open for the trial court to grant leave to the applicants to deposit the amount even after the period stipulated in the preliminary decree has expired. Exercise of powers under Order 34, Rule 7(2) by the executing court in accepting the amount was clearly arbitrary. There does not appear to be any good ground for extending the time for depositing the amount. Even otherwise, by harmoniously reading the provisions of Article 137 of the Limitation Act, in any eventuality, the court could not have extended time for depositing the amount beyond the period of limitation prescribed under the Statute.  AIR 1994 SC 191 - Ref. to.  [Para 8]

heading: Extinguishment of right to property
HeadNote.description: Extinguishment of right to property - Notice of termination of tenancy - Suit for recovery of possession filed after 12 years dismissed - There is no bar under T.P. Act which can prevent or prohibit the landlord from filing successive suits on the basis of termination of notice because if the earlier notice is not legal and valid and has not legally terminated the tenancy as required by S.106 of T.P. Act, then the right of landlord is not lost for ever and he will give fresh notice and terminate the tenancy and file a suit - Right of plaintiff to institute the second suit is nowhere extinguished u/s.27 of Limitation Act - Even if purposes of the first suit and the second suit are common and the reliefs claimed are identical what makes a difference is the cause of action - Cause of action in second suit is fresh notice.			(Paras 13, 15, 16)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Recovery of mortgaged property - Limitation - As per decision of full Bench of High Court in Ram Kishan’s case, which was upheld by Supreme Court in Singh Ram [2014 ALL SCR 3747], there is no limitation period in case of usufructuary mortgage - “Once a mortgage always a mortgage” was the principle applied. 2014 ALL SCR 3747 Foll.	(Para 3)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Appellant using "Kundan" trade mark since 1980 - He was also supplying goods with this trade mark to respondent - In 1994 appellant came to know that respondent was using this trade mark - He immediately filed a suit - During pendency of suit respondent obtained registration of trade mark "Kundan" in its favour - Writ petition was immediately filed in Delhi High Court and in 2001 Delhi High Court held that writ petition ought to have been filed in Madras High Court - Registrar handed it over to counsel on 2.11.2004 for filing before Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB) - IPAB on 9.3.2012 dismissed it as belated - Held, appellant was pursuing its remedy with due diligence or bona fide and IPAB ought not to have dismissed it as time barred in view of S.14 of Limitation Act. 	(Para 12)

heading: Usufructuary mortgage
HeadNote.description:
Usufructuary mortgage - Right to redeem and recover possession - Commences when mortgage money is paid out of rents and profits or partly out of rents and profit and partly by payment or deposit by mortgagor - Until then limitation does not start - Mortgagee is not entitled to file suit merely on expiry of 30 years from date of mortgage.

In a usufructuary mortgage, right to recover possession continues till the money is paid from the rents and profits or where it is partly paid out of rents and profits when the balance is paid by the mortgagor or deposited in Court as provided under Section 62 of the T.P. Act.

Article 61 refers to right to redeem or recover possession. While right of mortgagor to redeem is dealt with under Section 60 of the T.P. Act, the right of usufructuary mortgagor to recover possession is specially dealt with under Section 62. Section 62 is applicable only to usufructuary mortgages and not to any other mortgage. The said right of usufructuary mortgagor though styled as 'right to recover possession' is for all purposes, right to redeem and to recover possession. Thus, while in case of any other mortgage, right to redeem is covered under Section 60, in case of usufructuary mortgage, right to recover possession is dealt with under Section 62 and commences on payment of mortgage money out of the usufructs or partly out of the usufructs and partly on payment or deposit by the mortgagor. This distinction in a usufructuary mortgage and any other mortgage is clearly borne out from provisions of Sections 58, 60 and 62 of the T.P. Act read with Article 61 of the Schedule to the Limitation Act. Usufructuary mortgage cannot be treated at par with any other mortgage, as doing so will defeat the scheme of Section 62 of the T.P. Act and the equity. This right of the usufructuary mortgagor is not only an equitable right, it has statutory recognition under Section 62 of the T.P. Act. There is no principle of law on which this right can be defeated. Any contrary view, which does not take into account the special right of usufructuary mortgagor under Section 62 of the T.P. Act, has to be held to be erroneous on this ground or has to be limited to a mortgage other than a usufructuary mortgage.

1985 (4) SCC 162 Disting.

2006(3) ALL MR 175 (S.C.), AIR 2012 (HP) 1 (FB) Overruled. [Para 10,12,15,16]

heading: Specific Relief Act (1963), S.27A
Suit for possession
HeadNote.description: Suit for possession - Plaintiff alleging forcible dispossession in 1975 - No evidence produced to show his dispossession or that of his tenant - Letters produced only spoke about compensation after resumption of leased land - Lands were resumed several years prior to 1975 without any protest and the suit was filed only in 1987 - Held apart from merits claim was also barred by limitation.		(Para 17)

heading: Infringement of trademark
Delay and latches
HeadNote.description: Infringement of trademark - Delay and latches - Plaintiffs opposed immediately to use of said mark by defendants in India and abroad - In criminal case against appellants goods were returned to defendants with condition that they would not sell it - Case was dismissed due to non service to accused - Plaintiffs opposed two applications for registration of trade mark by defendant - One application for registration was not opposed as it escaped plaintiff's attention - There is valid explanation to delay - Plaintiffs has not acquiescenced or waived their rights towards their marks. 2005(30) PTC 14, 1994 IPLR 1 - Referred. 	(Paras 30, 33C, 35, 40, 41)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit for redemption of mortgage - Limitation - Issue is not about calculation of period, but determination of starting point - Deed of re-conveyance provides that amount was to be repaid within 5 years, but by end of phalgun months, which is year-end of phalgun calendar from 1964 - Thus, initial payment became due by end of phalgun of 1969 - No pleading and evidence to show that subsequent period of extension of 5 years was claimed and granted - Even if it is considered, still mortgage amount becomes due and payable by end of phalgun in 1974 - If suit for redemption was to be filed within 30 years, it should have been filed in month of phalgun which ended on 20th March, 2004 - However, suit was filed on 06.04.2004 - No provision for condonation of delay of single day - Hence, suit barred by limitation. 1925 Allahabad 138 Ref. to. 			(Paras 15, 17, 20, 21)

heading: Adverse possession
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Evidence Act (1872), S.101 - Adverse possession - Burden of proof - Burden to prove ouster by adverse possession lies on defendant in given facts - Mere statement that defendant did not allow plaintiff or his mother to plough field for about 25 years, cannot lead to ouster of plaintiffs from land, because plaintiff then was a minor - Held, contention that defendant's right had perfected into title by adverse possession cannot be accepted.			(Paras 11 to 14)

heading: Hindu Law
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Hindu Law - Suit for administration of estate - Limitation - Property is claimed to be estate of deceased father of parties upon succession - Devolution of property is complete on date of death of father - Suit for administration of estate of deceased upon such succession has to be filed within 3 years from date of death - Suit filed after 12 years of death of father is beyond limitation. 

Case of plaintiff that he has sued only when he learnt that defendant no. 1 sought to appropriate entire suit property to himself to exclusion of other co owners , would not start period of limitation. Plaintiff must have filed suit within 3 years of death of father when cause of action to sue accrued to plaintiff upon succession. 

2013(2) ALL MR 497, AIR 1987 SC 558, AIR 1971 SC 2184, 2009(4) ALL MR 358, 2009(2) ALL MR 718 Ref. to.           [Para 31,34]

heading: Adverse possession
HeadNote.description: Hyderabad Abolition of Inams and Cash Grants Act (1954) - Adverse possession - An assertion of hostile title necessarily means denying title of the true owner and asserting one's own title openly without attempt at concealment. 1977 Mh.L.J. 485 - Ref. to.			(Para 8)

heading: Suit by quondam minor
HeadNote.description: Suit by quondam minor - To set aside alienation of his property by his guardian in contravention of S.8(2) of Hindu Minority Act - Limitation prescribed u/Art.60 of Limitation Act, would apply - Arts.109, 110 or 113, would have no application in such case.			(Para 29)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Suit against alienation of property by guardian - Limitation - Several plaintiffs entitled to file suit - Property alienated in year 1982 - Suit filed in 1989 - One of plaintiffs is 20 yrs. old and other one was still minor on date of institution of suit - Other two plaintiffs though majors, not Manager or karta of joint family - They will not fall under Explanation 2 of S.7 of Limitation Act, could not give discharge without concurrence of such minor person - Hence, suit so filed held well within three year from date of attaining majority.			(Para 82)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Property of minor plaintiff no. 1 and 2 was sold by de facto guardian step mother without permission - Real mother of plaintiff was alive at that time - Suit is within limitation as per S.65 - Concurrent finding of both courts below that suit is within limitation - Contention in this regard liable to be rejected. 
1986(0) BCI 39 - Ref. to. (Paras 30 to 32)

heading: Appeal under
HeadNote.description:
Appeal under - Limitation of 30 days provided under S.30 - Court cannot condone delay in its inherent powers by invoking S.5 of Limitation Act. 

Section 30 (which is an exception to Section 29) of the RDDBFI Act provides for an appeal against the order of Recovery officer within 30 days from the date the copy of the order of the Recovery officer is issued to an aggrieved person who wants to prefer appeal to the Tribunal and when there is no provision made for condonation of delay the court/ Tribunal can not have power to condone delay in absence of such specific provision because the power of the court flows from provision of the relevant special statute. If the relevant special statute provides for the specific period of limitation to prefer appeal without any specific provision for the court to condone delay, then inherent power of the court to condone delay under the general law i.e. Limitation Act , 1963 can not apply and delay can not be condoned on the ground of equity and hardship. Order of the Recovery officer under Chapter V of the RDDBFI Act would become absolute and binding if no appeal is preferred within specified limitation of 30 days as provided for under section 30 of the Act.

2007 (3) Mh.L.J. 241 Held no longer good law in view of (2008) 3SCC 70.  [Para 13,14]

The primary function of a court of law is  to do justice according to law. Where the legislature clearly declares its intent to lay down the scheme and use or omit specific words in a statute, it becomes the duty of the court to give full effect to the same. Perusal of sub-section (2) of Section 30 of the RDDBFI Act, indicate that for the Debts Recovery Appellate Tribunal, entertaining appeal against the order of the Recovery Officer, the only precaution seems to observe the principle of natural justice, while Tribunal can expeditiously inquire and dispose of the appeal by passing an appropriate order after examining the validity of the order passed by the Recovery officer following the procedure contained in section 25 to 28 (both inclusive).
2008(2) ALL MR 512 Disting.   [Para 9]

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Delay of 336 days in filing election petition - Application for condonation of delay means acceptance of fact of delay - Ss.4 to 24 of Limitation Act are not applicable to filing of election petition - Equity does not find place in filing of said petitions - Ground for delay is that petitioner was pursuing with authorities and had also filed PIL is liable to be rejected - Petition was filed beyond period prescribed in S.81 - Petition liable to be dismissed under provisions of S.86.

1974 (2) SCC 113, 1993 (1) SCC 636, 1999 (8) SCC 532 Ref. to. (Paras 19, 20)

heading: Proceeding by DRT
HeadNote.description: Proceeding by DRT - Provision of Limitation Act are applicable in view of S.24 of Recovery of Debts Act.  (Para 16)

heading: Appeal before DRT
Condonation of delay
Powers of Tribunal
HeadNote.description: Appeal before DRT - Condonation of delay - Powers of Tribunal - Pre-requisite for applicability of S.5 of Limitation Act, is pendency of proceedings before a Court - Proceedings under RDB Act being before a statutory Tribunal, it cannot be placed at par with proceedings before a Court - Hence, Tribunal shall have no power to condone delay, unless expressly conferred by the statute creating it. 	(Para 11)

heading: Appeal before DRT
Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description:
Appeal before DRT - Against order of Recovery Officer - Condonation of delay - S.5 of Limitation Act, whether applicable - Scheme of RDB Act manifestly provides that Legislature has provided for application of Limitation Act to original proceedings before Tribunal u/S.19 only - Therefore, delay in preferring appeal against order of Recovery Officer cannot be condoned by application of S.5 of Limitation Act.

	The RDB Act is a special law. The proceedings are before a statutory Tribunal. The scheme of the Act manifestly provides that the Legislature has provided for application of the Limitation Act to original proceedings before the Tribunal under Section 19 only. The appellate tribunal has been conferred the power to condone delay beyond 45 days under Section 20(3) of the Act. The proceedings before the Recovery officer are not before a Tribunal. Section 24 is limited in its application to proceedings before the Tribunal originating under Section 19 only. The exclusion of any provision for extension of time by the Tribunal in preferring an appeal under Section 30 of the Act makes it manifest that the legislative intent for exclusion was express. The application of Section 5 of the Limitation Act by resort to Section 29(2) of the Limitation Act, 1963 therefore does not arise. The prescribed period of 30 days under Section 30(1) of the RDB Act for preferring an appeal against the order of the Recovery officer therefore cannot be condoned by application of Section 5 of the Limitation Act.	                                        [Para 14]

HeadNote.act_name: Liquified Petroleum Gas (Regulation of Supply and Distribution) Order (1993)
heading: Discharge of accused
HeadNote.description: Gas Cylinder Rules (1981) - Criminal P.C. (1973), S.245 - Discharge of accused - Prosecution against accused under E.C. Act - Absence of any contraventions or breaches of any orders by accused - In absence there of, there is nothing to justify that the petitioners/accused should face criminal trial and/or such proceedings - Application for discharge, allowed. 2004 ALL MR (Cri) 3473 (S.C.) - Rel. on.	(Para 11)

heading: Offence by company
Compounding
HeadNote.description:
Offence by company - Compounding - Liability of directors to pay compounding fee - Nomination already made u/S.49(2) and certified by Directors of Legal Metrology - Hence, only nominated directors u/S.49(2) and company could be proceeded against and punished - No propriety in directing all directors to pay compounding fees. 

Under Section 49(1) of the Legal Metrology Act, only the nominated Director and the Company is deemed to be guilty of the offence and is liable to be proceeded against and punished. Since, the petitioner-company had nominated the Director under Section 49(2) and since, the nomination was certified by the Director of the Legal Metrology, only the nominated Director and the Company could have been proceeded against and punished. If, the other Directors could not have been proceeded against under Section 49(1) after the nomination of the Director under Section 49(2), the imposition of the compounding charges on the other Directors of the Company was not justified. The Appellate Authority-Deputy Controller of Legal Metrology could not not have held that all the Directors of the petitioner-company were liable to pay the compounding fees, as the provisions of Sections 48 and 49 of the Legal Metrology Act, 2009 are distinct and separate. If only the nominated Director of the Company and the Company could have been proceeded against and punished, the other Directors of the Company could not have been directed to pay compounding fees.

The provisions of Section 49(4) of the Act cannot be relied on, for supporting the impugned order, as it is not the case of the respondents that the offence was committed with the consent or connivance of, or is attributable to the neglect on the part of, any director, manager, secretary or other officer, not being a person nominated under sub-section (2) of Section 49 of the Act. In the absence of any allegation in regard to the commission of the offence by any director, manager, secretary or other officer, not being the person nominated under Section 49(2) of the Act, it cannot be said that the compounding charges should have been paid by all the Directors of the Company. Also, if compounding is permissible after the institution of the prosecution and if the prosecution could have been instituted only against the nominated Director, there was no propriety in directing all the Directors of the Company to pay the compounding fees. 				 [Para 8]

heading: Maintainability
HeadNote.description:
Rule making power of Central Govt. - Challenge on ground of excessive delegation - Maintainability - Held, policy stated in the Preamble of Amendment Act offers sufficient guidelines to the Central Govt. for exercising rule making power - Further, requirement of laying down Rules before Parliament ensures strict vigilance and control over the delegate - Hence, challenge on ground of excessive delegation is not maintainable.

In the instant case the policy as stated in the preamble of the Amendment Act is that "for securing the interests of the Life Insurance Corporation of India and its policy-holders and to control the cost of administration, it is necessary that revision of the terms and conditions of service applicable to the employees and agents of the Corporation should be undertaken expeditiously". The policy stated here is at least as clear as the one held in Harishanker Bagla's case offering sufficient guidance to the Central Government in exercising its powers under that Act. Further, S. 48 (3) of the Life Insurance Corporation Act requires that every rule made by the Central Government under this Act shall be laid before each House of Parliament and that if both Houses agree in making any modification in the rule or both Houses agree that the rule should not be made, the rule shall thereafter have effect only in such modified form or be of no effect, as the case may be. This makes it perfectly clear that Parliament has in no way abdicated its authority, but is keeping strict vigilance and control over its delegate. Therefore the Amendment Act of 1981 and the Rules framed by Central Govt. subsequent to such Amendment cannot be held to be invalid on the ground of excessive delegation of legislative functions.     [Para 11]

heading: Divorce suits
Counter Claim
HeadNote.description:
Civil P.C. (1908), O.19, R.1 - Divorce suits - Counter Claim - Separation of the properties between the spouses is necessary fall out of the grant of divorce and adjudication of a counter-claim in divorce suits warrants an answer as to who amongst the warring spouses was innocent person as envisaged under Art.27 of Portuguese Civil Code for the purposes of dealing with benefits received or to be received from other spouse - Art.15 of Portuguese Civil Code has been made to avoid multiplicity of the proceedings and ought not to be read to render the other legal provision i.e. Art.26 of the code nugatory.

Separation of the properties between the spouses is necessary fall out of the grant of divorce and adjudication of a counter-claim in divorce suits warrants an answer as to who amongst the warring spouses was innocent person as envisaged under Article 27 of the Portuguese Civil Code for the purposes of dealing with the benefits received or to be received from other spouse. Article 26 of the Portuguese Civil Code stipulates the manner in which the rights of the parties to the properties belonging to them are to be settled and the said property divided amongst them accordingly. One of the mode of settling such rights is by way of public deed made by the parties/spouses amicably i.e. by amicable settlement between the spouses. The other mode which is open to the Court in absence of such amicable settlement is by way of inventory in accordance with general law. This has been so specifically incorporated in the law governing separation of properties between the spouses in order to ensure equitable distribution of assets/properties between the spouses at the hands of the Court. Article 15 of the Portuguese Civil Code has been made to avoid multiplicity of the proceedings and ought not to be read to render the other legal provision i.e. Article 26 of the Code nugatory. 2000(2) Goa Law Times 539 and AIR 1992 Bombay 422 - Ref. to.  [Para 12,13]

heading: Suit for divorce
Referred.	 [Para 8,9]
HeadNote.description:
Suit for divorce - Suit filed on ground of incurable disease involving sexual aberration - Suit filed without verifying the nature and characteristics of such disease by previous examination - Procedure set out in Para 4 of Article 4 is mandatory and not just salutary - Suit for divorce liable to be dismissed.

In the instant case the suit for divorce is not maintainable on account of the non-compliance of the mandatory provisions of Para 4 of Article 4 of the Law of Divorce.  The verification of nature and characteristics of incurable disease in accordance with Articles 247 and 260 of the Portuguese Civil Procedure Code is a pre-condition to institution of a suit for divorce under Sub-clause (10) of Article 4.  Since there are no corresponding provisions in the Civil Procedure Code, 1908, which has been made applicable to Goa, it is clear that Articles 247 and 260 of the Portuguese Civil Procedure Code are in force and require compliance before any suit for divorce is filed under Article 4(10).  Admittedly, in the present case, no such examination has been done.  Para 4 of Article 4 of the Law of Divorce is not just salutary but in terms mandatory.  Failure to comply with the said provisions of Para 4 would, therefore, make the suit not maintainable.

1989(2) Goa L.T. 238 - Referred.	 [Para 8,9]

heading: Paper lottery and online lottery
HeadNote.description:
Paper lottery and online lottery - State of Kerala prohibiting sale of online or internet lotteries - It can do so if it is not running that form of lottery, even if it is running other types of lotteries. 

If the State Government has to prohibit any lottery organized, conducted or promoted by every other State, it has to prohibit the sale of its own lottery also. Meaning thereby, if a paper lottery is being prohibited by a particular State then that paper lottery has to be prohibited as a whole. Likewise, if online or internet lottery is to be prohibited by a State then that online lottery or internet lottery of all States including that State also has to be prohibited. Viewed from this angle, State of Kerala was well within its rights to prohibit the sale of online or internet lotteries in its State and there is no fault in it. It is well within the powers conferred on it under Section 5 of the Act. A State Government can organize, conduct or promote a lottery subject to conditions mentioned in Section 4 and if there is any violation of the conditions mentioned in Section 4, it would be always open to the State Government to prohibit such lottery and that would be within the legislative power vested with the State under Section 5 of the Act as in that case the State would be only complying with the provisions of the Act made by the Parliament.

The State can prohibit any form of lottery, if only it is not running any lottery at all. The second interpretation is that the State can prohibit a particular form of lottery, if it is not running that form of lottery, even if it is running other types of lotteries. The Act has been designedly made to suppress the mischief of lottery. Therefore, an interpretation, which advances the object of the Act, should be favoured. That means, the State can prohibit online lotteries, if it is not running the said type of lotteries.

(1999) 9 SCC 700 Rel.on.        [Para 38,39]
