heading: Compensation
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination - Large tract of land acquired for sugar factory - Acquired land having potentiality for being used as commercial, industrial and residential purposes - Exemplars of small plots - Held, when land is acquired for a sugar factory yielding good profit a deduction of more than 10% would not be justified.

The question to be considered is whether in the present case those factors exist which warrant a deduction by way of allowance from the price exhibited by the exemplars of small plots which have been filed by the parties. The land has not been acquired for a Housing Colony or Government Office or an Institution. The land has been acquired for setting up a sugar factory. The factory would produce goods worth many crores in a year. A sugar factory apart from producing sugar also produces many by-product in the same process. One of the by-products is molasses, which is produced in huge quantity. Earlier, it had no utility and its disposal used to be a big problem. But now molasses is used for production of alcohol and ethanol which yield lot of revenue. Another by-product begasse is now used for generation of power and press mud is utilized in manure. Therefore, the profit from a sugar factory is substantial. Moreover, it is not confined to one year but will accrue every year so long as the factory runs. A Housing Board does not run on business lines. Once plots are carved out after acquisition of land and are sold to public, there is no scope for earning any money in future. An industry established on acquired land, if run efficiently, earns money or makes profit every year. The return from the land acquired for the purpose of Housing Colony, or Offices, or Institution cannot even remotely be compared with the land which has been acquired for the purpose of setting up a factory or industry. After all the factory cannot be set up without land and if such land is giving substantial return, there is no justification for making any deduction from the price exhibited by the exemplars even if they are of small plots. It is possible that a part of the acquired land might be used for construction of residential colony for the staff working in the factory. Nevertheless where the remaining part of the acquired land is contributing to production of goods yielding good profit, it would not be proper to make a deduction in the price of land shown by the exemplars of small plots as the reasons for doing so assigned in various decisions of this Court are not applicable in the case under consideration. Hence, having regard to the entire facts and circumstances of the case, a deduction of 10% from the market value of the land, which has been arrived at by the High Court would meet the ends of justice.  [Para 14,15]

HeadNote.description:

Therefore, for that reason alone we are not inclined to allow the application for producing additional evidence in this case.

heading: Provision not retrospective in its operation
HeadNote.description:
Provision not retrospective in its operation - Award and decree passed by reference Court in year 1975 - Provision introduced during pendency of appeals filed against - No question of petitioners claiming any right of re-determination - Application under Section 28-A has to be made only on basis of award and decree of reference Court on a reference under Section 18, within limitation period of 3 months.

Admittedly, the reference Court passed its award and decree in the year 1975. Significantly, at that time Section 28-A was not in existence as the same was introduced in the year 1984 by the Amendment Act 68 of 1984. There is nothing, which suggests that the said provision is retrospective in its operation or that it applies to appeals pending at the time of coming into force of the said provision. It is only during the pendency of the appeals filed against the award of the reference Court that the said provision was introduced. Therefore, there was no question of the petitioners claiming any right of re-determination.  (1996)1 SCC 85, AIR 1997 SC 1793 - Rel. on.   [Para 10]

The conclusion is inevitable that the petitioners are not entitled to seek re-determination of compensation under Section 28-A of the Act, as they did not and could not have filed their applications within the period of three months from the date of the award of the reference Court. As their applications were beyond the time limit of three months from the date of the award of the reference Court, they are barred by limitation.   [Para 16]

Assuming that the limitation for applying for re-determination will not start to run till the disposal of the appeals filed against the award of the reference Court, on the facts pleaded by the petitioners, they are barred by limitation. Even according to the petitioners, the appeals were disposed of by Court on 4.3.1986. They claim to have applied for certified copies of the judgment on 5.11.1988, obtained the same on 7.11.1988 and sent representations on 28.11.1988. The very fact that more than 2 1/2 years elapsed from the date of disposal of the appeals even by the time they applied for certified copies completely exposes the hollowness of the petitioners' claim that they filed their applications within the period of limitation, if date of disposal of the appeal is reckoned for the purpose of computing the period of three months prescribed in proviso to Section 28-A of the Act. In the said provision the time taken for the certified copy alone is required to be excluded while computing the period of 90 days. The petitioners cannot sleep over the matter without even applying for a certified copy for more than 2-1/2 years and still claim that they filed their applications within time. Apart from the fact that they could not file their applications within the prescribed time limit even after disposal of the appeals, the petitioners have gone in hibernation after they made their representations on 1.12.1988 and 16.9.1988 till the year 2004 when they approached the Lokayukta and they leisurely filed the present writ petition in the year 2005.  						 [Para 17]

The law is well settled that High Court, which exercises discretionary jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution, does not come to the aid of those who sleep over their rights, if any, for unduly long periods.  (1975)4 SCC 714; (1998)6 SCC 720; (2006)4 SCC 322 - Rel. on.   [Para 18]

heading: Scope and applicability of
HeadNote.description:
Scope and applicability of - Inconsistency between provisions of Acquisition Act and Urban Land Ceiling Act - Inconsistency arises only in the eventuality that the same land is covered under the S.4 notification, S.6 declaration of Acquisition Act and the statement u/s.9 of Urban Land Ceiling Act - Only in that eventuality, the provisions of S.42 will come into play and that provisions of Urban Land Ceiling Act will have overriding effect over the provisions of any other law for the time being in force.

Inconsistency between the provisions of the Acquisition Act and the U.L.C. Act arises only in the eventuality that the same land is covered under the Section 4 notification, Section 6 declaration of the Acquisition Act and the statement u/s.9 of the U.L.C. Act.  Only in that eventuality the provisions of Section 42 will come into play and that the provisions of the U.L.C. Act will have overriding effect over the provisions of any other law for the time being in force.  If a part of land covered u/ss.4 and 6 notification of the Land Acquisition Act is acquired under the provisions of Section 10 of the U.L.C. Act, there is nothing which precludes acquisition of the remaining part of the land under the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act. 1979 Mh.L.J. 787, AIR 1988 Bombay 188 and AIR 1982 Bom. 22 - Referred to. 				 [Para 18]

heading: Acquisition of land dispensing with S.5-A enquiry
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land dispensing with S.5-A enquiry - Mere existence of urgency or unforeseen emergency under S.17(2) would not be sufficient for dispensing with enquiry - Govt. must apply its mind and come to conclusion that such an urgency is inherent in the two types of urgencies contemplated under Ss.17(1) and (2) - Dropping enquiry is not automatic or follows ipso facto in every case of urgency.

Section 17(4) provides that in cases where the appropriate Government has come to the conclusion that there exists an urgency or unforeseen emergency as required under sub-section (1) or (2) of Section 17 it may direct that the provisions of Section 5A shall not apply and if such direction is given then 5A inquiry can be dispensed with and a declaration may be made under Section 6 on publication of 4(1) notification, possession can be made. A careful perusal of this provision which is an exception to the normal mode of acquisition contemplated under the Act shows mere existence of urgency or unforeseen emergency though is a condition precedent for invoking Section 17(4) that by itself is not sufficient to direct the dispensation of 5A inquiry. It requires an opinion to be formed by the concerned government that along with the existence of such urgency or unforeseen emergency there is also a need for dispensing with 5A inquiry which indicates that the Legislature intended that the appropriate government to apply its mind before dispensing with 5A inquiry. It also indicates the mere existence of an urgency under Section 17(1) or unforeseen emergency under Section 17(2) would not by themselves be sufficient for dispensing with 5A inquiry. If that was not the intention of the Legislature then the latter part of sub-section (4) of Section 17 would not have been necessary and the Legislature in Section 17(1) and (2) itself could have incorporated that in such situation of existence of urgency or unforeseen emergency automatically 5A inquiry will be dispensed with. But then that is not language of the Section which in our opinion requires the appropriate Government to further consider the need for dispensing with 5A inquiry in spite of the existence of unforeseen emergency. The requirement of an application of mind by the appropriate Government while dispensing with 5A inquiry does not mean that in and every case when there is an urgency contemplated under Section 17(1) and unforeseen emergency contemplated under Section 17(2) exists that by itself would not contain the need for dispensing with 5A inquiry. It is possible in a given case the urgency noticed by the appropriate Government under Section 17(1) or the unforeseen emergency under Section 17(2) itself may be of such degree that it could require the appropriate Government on that very basis to dispense with the inquiry under Section 5A but then there is a need for application of mind by the appropriate Government that such an urgency for dispensation of the 5A inquiry is inherent in the two types of urgencies contemplated under Section 17(1) and (2) of the Act. Sub-section (4) of Section 17 itself indicates that the "government may direct that provisions of Section 5A shall not apply" which makes it clear that not in every case where the appropriate Government has come to the conclusion that there is urgency and under sub-section (1) or unforeseen emergency under sub-section (2) of Section 17 the Government will ipso facto have to direct the dispensation of inquiry.					 [Para 31,32,33]

There should be an application of mind to the facts of the case with special reference to this concession of 5A inquiry under the Act. At this stage, it is relevant to notice that the limited right given to an owner/person interested under Section 5A of the Act to object to the acquisition proceedings is not an empty formality and is a substantive right, which can be taken away for good and valid reason and within the limitations prescribed under Section 17(4) of the Act. The right of representation and hearing contemplated under Section 5A of the Act is a very valuable right of a person whose property is sought to be acquired and he should have appropriate and reasonable opportunity of persuading the authorities concerned that the acquisition of the property belonging to that person should not be made. Therefore, if the appropriate Government decides to take away this minimal right then its decision to do so must be based on materials on record to support the same and bearing in mind the object of Section 5A. 	 [Para 34,36]

heading: Market value
Determination
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination - Cannot be fixed on basis of a basic valuation register maintained by registering authority for collection of stamp duty - Market Value has to be based on comparable sale deeds - Land owner of a comparable sale deed cannot urge that though sale deed showed a price of Rs.15.40 per sq. yard the real market value was Rs.120 per sq. yard - To permit party to so urge would be to give a premium to dishonesty.

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation awarded
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Compensation awarded - Reference for enhancement of amount of compensation - Amount of compensation must have been received by owner under protest - It is pre-condition for seeking reference.

A reference under S.18 is not tenable when compensation is received without protest. The decisions in this regard do not support the proposition that the requirement of making a protest contained in second proviso to sub-section (2) of Section 31 of the Land Acquisition Act as a pre-condition for making a reference under Section 18 has in any way been diluted by these judgments.  It is manifest that when the Legislature had specifically provided in the second proviso to sub-section (2) of Section 31 of the Act that no person, who has received the amount otherwise than under protest, would be entitled to make any application under Section 18, no Court would be able to hold otherwise.   [Para 9,14]

heading: Reference
Enhancement of compensation
Order attaining finality
HeadNote.description: Reference - Enhancement of compensation - Similarly situated land granted enhanced compensation by Reference Court - Order attaining finality - Same enhancement granted to other land - No interference required. 2002(4) ALL MR 242 (S.C.) - Rel. on.	(Para 8)

heading: Acquisition of land
Notification under S.6
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Notification under S.6 - Award not made within two years from date of publication - No stay of proceedings by High Court - Hence finding by High Court that Explanation to S.11-A had no application and since award was not made within two years from date of publication of final notification under S.6, the proceedings lapsed, could not be interfered with.			(Paras 32-35)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Determination of market value - Based on value of land paid in neighbouring villages at time of acquisition of land is fair and reasonable.			(Para 1)

heading: Acquisition of land
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Determination of market value - Burden of proof - Entire burden of establishing market value of the land is on claimant - It is the duty of the claimant to bring on record the evidence to show that sale instances on which reliance is placed by him are comparable and are similar to the land of the claimant which has been acquired.	(Para 10)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - Vast tracks of land acquired for planned development of Delhi - Market value cannot be more than what was directed to be paid by Supreme Court for comparable land covered by same Notification - Value in respect of similar land acquired after three months raised by 5% and that for land acquired after one year by 10%.			(Paras 5, 6, 7)

heading: Award passed before amendment
HeadNote.description:
Award passed before amendment - Application filed for correction in amount of compensation consequent on change in law with retrospective effect - No limitation is prescribed for such application and hence it cannot be dismissed as barred by limitation.

In this case, applications were made under Section 151, CPC and they were not made for correction of any atithmectical or clerical errors; they were made only for amending the awards in view of the change brought about by law. Hence the applications were not barred by time. It may also be noticed that the respondents could not have filed appeals against the original orders passed by the reference Court seeking additional market value and interest for the simple reason that the amendment to the Act was brought into force giving additional benefits subsequently but with retrospective effect from the given date.  [Para 5]

heading: Whether mandatory
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for company - Nature of enquiry to be conducted - Notice of enquiry to land owners - Whether mandatory - Matter referred to a larger Bench in view of doubt entertained by a Division Bench about view taken by three - Judge Bench decision without noticing contrary view held in earlier five Judge Bench decision.			(Para 6)

heading: Award u/S.11
HeadNote.description:
Award u/S.11 - Is to be made within a period of two years from publication of declaration u/S.6 - Publication of any corrigendum to the said declaration cannot have the effect of extending the period.

Under Section 11-A what has to be seen is the date of last publication of the declaration under Section 6, and not any subsequent corrigendum to the said declaration.  The only circumstance under which the period between the declaration under Section 6 and the award can be extended is mentioned in the explanation to Section 11-A.  There is no mention in Section 11-A that the period after the publication of the declaration under Section 6 and the publication of any corrigendum to the said declaration has also to be excluded.  We will be adding words to the statute if we put such interpretation to Section 11-A, and it is well settled the Court should not add or delete words in a statute. Failure to adhere to this time frame is fatal to the award, as the provision is mandatory.  [Para 6,9,10]

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description: Scope - Application by claimant under S.18 for reference - Dismissed as barred by limitation - Application by him under S.28-A is maintainable.	(Para 7)

heading: Land acquision
HeadNote.description:
Land acquision - Lapsing of, on failure to make award within time - Explanation enjoins exclusion of entire period during which any action to be taken pursuant to declaration under S.6 is stayed by order of court.

The Explanation is not confined to the stage of making of the award pursuant to section 6 of the notification, but it is widely worded and covers in its sweep the entire period during which any action or proceedings to be taken in pursuance of the declaration under section 6 is stayed by a competent Court.  Explanation to section 11A clearly enjoins exclusion of the entire period during which any action or proceedings to be taken pursuant to declaration under section 6 is stayed by an order of the competent Court.  The explanation is in the widest possible terms and therefore there is no warrant for limiting the actions or proceedings referred to in the explanation to actions or proceedings  the making of the award under section 11 of the Act AIR 1991 SC 2153 Rel. on.    [Para 6]

heading: Acquisition of land for public purpose-Land admeasuring 9600 sq.mtrs. and categorised in Zone I
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for public purpose-Land admeasuring 9600 sq.mtrs. and categorised in Zone I - Held, claimants were entitled to get compensation at rate of Rs.18/- per sq.mtr. with 10 percent deduction thereon and also entitled to get 30 percent solatium and benefit of S.23 (1-A) and S.28. (Para 5)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - S.12(2) notice served on petitioner on 15-3-88 - Application for certified copy of award made by petitioner on 23-3-88 - Certified copy received by petitioner on 13-4-88 - Application under S.18 submitted with court fee stamp in favour of L.A.O on 17-5-88 - Order of L.A.O. rejecting s.18 application set aside and direction given to him to make reference.
Limitation Act (1963), S.5 (Paras 3, 10)

heading:
Evidence and proof.

It is necessary that when a party relies upon the sale instances, as an evidence in the claim, presented under S.18, claiming higher compensation, then it is incumbent upon such party to adduce the evidence by examining vendors or vendees and if not available, the attesting witnesses in such sale transactions, who have personal knowledge thereof to prove that such transactions were genuine and bonafide. Furthermore, it is also imperative that the evidence should be made available to prove and establish that the plot of lands, under the sale instances were comparable to the land under acquisition. The evidence has to be led with regard to similar and dis-similar features, as also the advantages and disadvantages vis-a-vis both the plots of lands.  [Para 9]

The same principles would apply in the case of a certificate issued by the comunidade or a judgment of the High Court. Mere production of the certificate or the judgment, as base, for determining the market value of land is not enough. 1990(2) Goa LT 225 Relied on.  [Para 10,11]

heading: Compensation
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination - Relevant date is date of notification.

The only question is : whether the High Court would be justified in enhancing the compensation to Rs.12/- per sq.yd. in other words, Rs. 58,000/- per acre.  Admittedly, the land is dry land and the Land Acquisition Officer had pointed out in his award that the converted lands for which he had awarded compensation at the rate of Rs.9,000/- and Rs.10,000/- per acre, bear different connotation to the actual dry land existing as on that date.  The potential value shall be determined for the land existing as on the date of the notification and not after subsequent developments have taken place. The value of the developed land bears no relevance to further enhancement of the value. Under these circumstances, the High Court was wholly incorrect in enhancing the compensation to Rs.12/- per sq.yd. i.e., Rupees 58,000/- per acre.  [Para 5]

heading: Reference Court gets jurisdiction only if matter is referred to it
HeadNote.description: Reference Court gets jurisdiction only if matter is referred to it - It cannot widen the scope of its jurisdiction or decide matters which are not referred to it - When issue referred was only about apportionment of compensation court could not decide the question of enhancement of compensation.		(Paras 7,11)

heading: Reference under
HeadNote.description:
Reference under - Reference not an appeal against award of Collector - Court cannot take into account the material relied upon by Land Acquisition Officer in his award unless that material is produced and proved before Court.

A reference under Section 18 of the Act is not an appeal against the award of the Collector. The Court cannot take into account the material relied upon by the Land Acquisition Officer in his award unless that material is produced and proved before the Court.  In the present case, the instance relating to Survey No.15/2 or, for that matter, of Survey No 9/1, was not relied upon in the reference proceedings.  The award of the Land Acquisition Officer, it is equally well settled, is not to be regarded as if it were a judgment of the Trial Court subject to appeal and it would not in that sense be open to challenge before the Court hearing the reference.  The award is merely an offer made by the Land Acquisition Officer and even material utilised by him for making the offer cannot be utilised by the court unless it is produced and proved before it.  The reference is an original proceeding and the reference court has to determine the market value afresh on the basis of the material produced before the Court.	 [Para 10]

1998 (3) SCC 751 -Referred to.

heading: Term "an appeal" in S.54
HeadNote.description:
Term "an appeal" in S.54 - Does not restrict it to only one appeal in High Court - It would take in its sweep a Letters Patent Appeal - Letters Patent is not an enactment but a charter of High Court - Non-obstante clause in S.54 would not cover charter of High Court.

A Letters Patent is the charter under which the High Court is established. The powers given to a High Court under the Letters Patent are akin .to the constitutional powers of a High Court. Thus when a Letters Patent grants to the High Court a power of Appeal, against a judgment of a single Judge, the right to entertain the appeal would not get excluded unless the concerned statutory enactment excludes an appeal under the Letters Patent.					 [Para 9]

A Letters Patent is not an enactment. It is the charter of the High Court. A non-obstante clause of this nature in S.54 cannot cover the charter of the High Court.  [Para 1]

By virtue of the Letters Patent "an appeal" against the judgment of a single Judge of the High Court would lie to a Division Bench. Section 54 of the said Act does not exclude an Appeal under the Letters Patent. The -word 'only' occurring immediately after the non-obstante clause in Section 54 refers to the forum of appeal. In other words it provides that the appeal will be to the High Court and not any other Court e.g. the District Court. The term "an appeal" does not restrict it to only one Appeal in the High Court. The term "an appeal" would take within its sweep even a Letters Patent Appeal. The decision of the Division Bench rendered in a Letters Patent Appeal will then be subject to appeal to the Supreme Court. Read in any other manner there would be a conflict between Section 54 and the provision of a Letters Patent. It is settled law that if there is a conflict, attempt should be made to harmoniously construe the provisions.	 [Para 14]

Validity

Land Acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - Validity - Sale instances in neighbouring villages - No evidence adduced to establish similarity between land acquired and land under sale instances - Moreover sale instances were of small pieces of land as compared to vast area of acquired land - Enhancement based merely on sale deeds cannot be justified - Enhancement set aside.AIR 1998 SC 2470, AIR 1999 SC 317 - Rel on. Hearing of objection
Non-compliance of S.5A
Acquisition proceedings, vitiated
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition - Hearing of objection - Land acquired for extension of road - Petitioner-landowner submitted his objections which were allegedly not considered - Respondent-authority claiming that petitioner in his objection shown inclination to receive compensation - However, it would not mean that petitioner did not intend to pursue his objection and had given up same - No material to indicate that petitioner was duly heard on objections raised by him or those objections were adjudicated upon - Nothing on record to indicate application of mind by SLAO to those objections - SLAO proceeded with acquisition proceedings without adverting to objections - Non-compliance of S.5A - Acquisition proceedings, vitiated - Hence, set aside. heading: Compensation
Enhancement
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Enhancement - Challenge, on ground of being exorbitant and non- reliance upon sale instance - Rate of compensation enhanced from Rs.3/- to Rs.36/- per sq.m. and from Rs.4/- to Rs.40/- and other consequential and statutory reliefs granted - Reference Court considered distinguishable factors that land from sale deed was a smaller plot, while land acquired is a bigger one - Court also considered locations of both lands in same village in respect of boundaries of river/bank and development expenditure - Land in sale instance was purchased for Rs.90/- per sq.m. but considering distinguishable factors, Reference Court deducted price by 65% and also then added 10% the sale instance pertained to pre-notification period - Price fixed at Rs.36/- and Rs.40/- per sq.m. is approximate and not exorbitant - No interference. 	(Para 9)

heading: Report of Valuer
HeadNote.description:
Determination of market value - Agricultural land with building potentiality - Report of Valuer - It must be based on conditions prevailing at time of S.4 Notification - Award declared on 26-10-1981 - Benefit of S.23 (1A) not available.

	 The Valuer must indicate the prices available of the lands in the vicinity on the date of notification under S.4 of the Act, and not with reference to the date on which the Valuer visited the site. Notification was published in June 1978 and it was futile to refer to the condition prevailing in year 1986 for determination of market price of the acquired land. The same error was committed by the trial Judge who visited the site at the time of hearing of Reference in year 1986 and felt that the land was valuable.There is no evidence on record to indicate as to where these lands covered by Exhs. 17 to 21 are situated and what is the rate of development. The trial Court overlooked that the area under acquisition is 60.8 Ares and the land was used for the purpose of agriculture. The trial Judge was clearly in error in holding that the maximum price of Rs.25/- per sq.mtr. paid for small plot of 484 sq. mtrs. should be considered as the prevailing market price for determining the compensation of the acquired land. The trial Judge overlooked that the sale deed providing for the rate of Rs.25/- per sq. mtr. is of October 1977 while the latter two sale deeds of January 1979 and August 1979 indicate the price of Rs.19.76 and Rs.17.66 respectively, and, therefore, it was erroneous to assume that even the price of the developed plots was in the vicinity of Rs.25/- per sq. mtr. at the time of notification under S.4. It also cannot be overlooked that the prices of the agricultural lands with a building potentiality cannot be determined without taking into consideration the area which is required to be excluded for internal roads etc. at the time of developing property. The normal rule of excluding 1/3 rd area has to be applied in case there is no evidence as to what area would be required to be excluded from consideration while developing the land. The trial Judge  instead of excluding 1/3rd land, proceeded to deduct 1/3rd of the price of Rs.25/-. The trial Judge also overlooked that apart from spending considerable amount for developing the land and for advertising the plots for sale, the plots will not be sold over night and some deduction is required to be made by taking into consideration the time required for the disposal of the plots. The trial Judge without applying this well settled principle, arbitrarily felt that Rs.13/- per sq. mtr. should be adequate compensation. The claimants did not lead any evidence as to what is the demand for developed plots in this area and what time would be required for the disposal of the plots after developing the land. In these circumstances, the trial Judge was clearly in error in determining the compensation payable at the rate of Rs.13/- per sq. mtr.  [Para 4]

The counsel for the respondents (claimants) submitted that the compensation offered by the Land Acquisition Officer at the rate of Rs.3/- per sq. mtr. is inadequate even though the land is an agricultural land, because of the potentiality existing on the date of notification. There is considerable merit in this submission. The instances of sale deeds of agricultural lands on which reliance was placed, indicate that the rate prevalent in year 1968 was Rs.20,000/- per Hectare for agricultural land in village Bhisegaon. The prices of the agricultural land are also on increase and if 10% increase is granted per year, then the price of agricultural land in year 1978 would be Rs.40,000/- per Hectare. Though the evidence on record is not very clear, a judicial notice can be taken that the area around Karjat Railway Station and the Karjat Town has building potentiality. The land is situated hardly at a distance of 10 minutes walk from Karjat Railway Station. The time required for development of the land cannot be too distant. It would be proper to add Rs.10,000/- per Hectare while determining the compensation of the acquired land on the basis of building potentiality. The compensation payable, therefore, would be at the rate of Rs.50,000/- per Hectare and which comes to Rs.5/- per sq. mtr. This amount of compensation would adequately compensate the Respondents.  [Para 5]

The grievance of the Appellant that the trial Judge was in error in awarding compensation under S.23(1-A) of the Act deserves acceptance. The award in this case was declared on October 26, 1981 and, therefore, the benefit of S.23(1-A) is not available.

1994(5) S.C.C.   593  Followed.  [Para 6]

The Respondents would be entitled to solatium at the rate of 30% on the additional compensation payable. The appeal preferred by the State Government is, therefore, required to be partly allowed and the following order is passed :-

The Respondents would be entitled to additional compensation of Rs.12,160/-, plus solatium at the rate of 30% of Rs.3,648/-, plus interest of Rs.19,139/- and thus the total amount payable is Rs.34,947/-.  [Para 6]

heading: Acquisition of land urgently for public purpose
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land urgently for public purpose - Subjective satisfaction of authority not vitiated by mala fide or oblique motive - Dispensation with enquiry under S.5A - Court will not enquire into sufficiency of grounds for subjective satisfaction - Slight slackness on part of Acquisition Officer - Will not undo invocation of urgency clause.

Whether the land needs to be acquired urgently or not, depends upon the subjective satisfaction of the appropriate Government or the competent authority having power to acquire the land and ordinarily the courts do not interfere with such subjective satisfaction of the Competent Authority competent to acquire unless such subjective satisfaction is vitiated by malafides or suffers from oblique motive. The court cannot ordinarily enquire whether there were sufficient grounds to form opinion by the Government under sub-section (4) of section 17 and once on the material available with the Government an opinion has been formed that there was sufficient ground for invoking the power under sub-section (4) of section 17 and in dispensing with the enquiry under section 5A of the Act, the court of law would not interfere with such subjective satisfaction unless it is unequivocally demonstrated that the appropriate Government or for that matter, the acquiring authority had not applied its mind to the matter or that such action was malafide or actuated with ulterior motive.  [Para 5]

Where the competent authority was satisfied that the land was needed for public purpose i.e. for research and development area of Defence Department and the need was urgent and there was no mala fide or obique motive, the competent authority was justified in invoking urgency provision under the Act.  [Para 5,6,8]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - On basis of comparable sale deeds - Compensation of acquired land given at Rs.306/- per sq.m. - Whereas land in comparable instance sold at Rs.567/- per sq.m. - Deduction made on account of development and dissimilarities between two lands - Though another comparable land was sold at Rs.400/- per sq.m., there was dissimilarity as to largeness of land - Deduction of 25% on that count and fixation of award at Rs.306/- for present land, fair and reasonable - Rate of compensation in present case can also be justified in view of Rs.300/- per sq.m. awarded for another land in same notification - Compensation of present land is slightly high as it is closer to city and has better facility - No interference with compensation so fixed. (Paras 11, 12, 14, 16)

heading: Redetermination of compensation
Application u/s.28A(1)
HeadNote.description:
Redetermination of compensation - Application u/s.28A(1) - Whether maintainable in respect of award of court passed u/s.28A(3) - Held, award made by Collector under sub-s.(2) of S.28A is on per with award u/s.11 - Against such award, remedy is provided under sub-s.(3) - Once such application under sub-s.(3) is made, it is governed by Ss.18 to 28 - Even though sub-s.(1) of S.28A does not make reference to award under sub-s.(3), it is an award of court under Part III of Act -Hence, even in respect of award under sub-s.(3), an application under sub-s.(1) will lie.

The object of 28-A seems to be to help a person interested, who for the various reasons was unable to file an application for Reference under Section 18 of the said Act. The object seems to be to pay the compensation to the person interested to which in law he was entitled by way of an award under Section 11 of the said Act. The object is to pay compensation to him to which he was legitimately entitled to on the date of passing an award under Section 11 of the said Act. If Sub-sections (2) and (3) of Section 28A are read together, it appears that an Award under Sub-section (2) is on par with an Award under Section 11 of the said Act in so far as the provisions of reference under Section 18 of the said Act are concerned. Once an Award under Sub-section (2) of Section 28A is made, it replaces an Award under Section 11 for all purposes as it becomes an offer of the Appropriate Government.

Under sub-section 3 of section 28-A, a remedy is provided to a person who has not accepted the Award under sub-section 2 of section 28-A to apply for a reference to the Court. Once such application is made, for all purposes, it becomes an application under sub-section (1) of section 18 of the said Act and it will be governed by the provisions of sections 18 to 28 of the said Act. It is contended that sub-section 1 of section 28-A does not make a specific reference to the Award made on a reference under sub-section 3 of section 28-A. In fact, sub-section 1 of section 28-A provides that "Where in an award under this Part, the Court allows to the applicant any amount of compensation in excess of the amount awarded by the Collector under Section 11", a person aggrieved may apply for re-determination of compensation. Sub-section 1 applies when the Award of the Court allows the applicant any amount of compensation in excess of the amount awarded by the Collector by an Award under section 11 of the said Act. The Award made on a reference under sub-section 3 of section 28-A of the said Act will be an Award of the Court under part III which is specifically referred to in sub-section 1 of section 28-A of the said Act. Thus, when such Award of the Court allows an amount in excess of the amount provided in the Award under section 11, an application under sub-section 1 of section 28 will lie. Thus, an application will lie under said sub-section even on the basis of the Award made by the Court on a reference made in accordance with sub-section 3 of section 28-A of the said Act.           [Para 11,12]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of market value - Acquired land within 10 meters distance from railway tack - No construction was possible on the acquired land - Whether floor Area Ratio could be utilized or granted was for the Authorities to decide - Market value at Rs.40/- per sq.m. by reference court, held, proper and further reduction of 10% on noise pollution ground, was not necessary. HeadNote.description: Withdrawal from acquisition - Compensation in terms of S.48(2) to land owners - Such compensation cannot be determined without notice being served to the local authority for whose benefit land was sought to be acquired and ultimately at whose instance the Govt. withdrew  from acquisition - Such local authority is the "person interested" - Non service of notice would cause prejudice to it - Order of compensation u/s.48(2) without such notice, violates principle of natural justice - Not sustainable in law. heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Petitioner not present when award was passed - Petition for setting aside award within six months from date of award is within time. (Para 4)

heading: Compensation
Apportionment of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Apportionment of - Part of ancestral property acquired - Death of one brother without leaving issues - Widow selling her undivided rights in ancestral property along with acquired land to third party - Right of deceased brother would devolve on his three brothers and their descendants - Hence finding that widow of deceased brother would get ½ compensation cannot be sustained - Her share would be restricted to 1/4th share in acquired land - Finding arrived at in reference proceedings is restricted only to acquired land and would not influence the court in other proceedings in respect of remaining property. heading: Acquisition of land
Acquisition in 1987

heading: Refund of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Refund of compensation - Appellants allowed to withdraw the amount of compensation deposited along with interest accrued thereon subject to the condition that in case the dispute pending in the civil suit is finally decided in favour of the respondent, the appellants would be liable to refund the said amount or part thereof, in accordance with law. 

Under the provisions of Section 31 of the Land Acquisition Act, the persons who have received the compensation, shall be bound to refund the said amount to the person who is lawfully entitled to such amount. In the facts and circumstances of the case, in the interest of justice, court held that it would be appropriate that a direction be given to the effect that the Appellants be allowed to withdraw the amount of compensation deposited along with interest accrued thereon subject to the condition that in case the dispute pending in the Civil Suit is finally decided in favour of the Respondents, the Appellants would be liable to refund the said amount or part thereof, in accordance with law.
2003(2) ALL MR 319 (S.C.) Ref. to.             [Para 12]

heading: Reference
Limitation

Reference - Limitation - It would start from date of knowledge of contents of award to applicants - Applicants came to know about contents of award on date of payment of compensation - Reference filed within six days from date of knowledge of contents of award - Reference was within period of limitation - Rejection of reference on ground of delay, not proper.

2012(3) ALL MR 434 (S.C.) Foll. 			 [Para 6,9]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Sale instance given is of post notification sale hence 25% amount is deducted - Further land in sale instance is situated within village therefore deduction of 25% is proper - 30% would have to be reduced towards development - However acquired land was irrigated, adjoining to State Highway, near petrol pump - Claimant is also entitled to Rs.50,000/- compensation for well - Compensation to be enhanced than what was awarded by Reference Court. heading: Acquisition of land
Proceedings challenged
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Proceedings challenged - Petition filed over a year after the entire proceedings concluded - Petitioners plea that he was unaware of the acquisition proceedings - Factually at the time the notices issued u/Ss.4 and 6 he was a tenant having continuous possession of said land - He also not established contents of award and certificate to be false - It cannot be believed that he did not notice all the procedure - The activities unlike the issuance/publication of notices carried out physically at site and award made and entire proceedings stood concluded - Petitioner unable to establish any cogent reason for the delay in filing petition in question - Petition liable to be dismissed on the ground of latches and delay.

1975 (4) SCC 285 Disting.

(1996) 11 SCC 501, 2000(2) ALL MR 438 (S.C.), (2003) 1 SCC 335, 2004 Goa LR 389, 2012 ALL SCR 745, (2008) 4 SCC 695, (1996) 6 SCC 445 Ref. to.			 [Para 32,33,34,35]

heading: Declaration under S.6
HeadNote.description:
Declaration under S.6 - Declaration is complete for purpose of proviso to S.6(1) (ii) only when it is published in gazette - Hence date of publication in gazette is relevant date for computation of limitation and not the date of last publication in the series prescribed under S.6(2).

AIR 1993 Raj 157 overruled.

The making of declaration under S.6 is complete for the purpose of proviso to S.6(1)(i) & (ii) when it is published in the official gazette. Hence for the purpose of calculating the limitation prescribed under proviso to S.6(1)(ii), it is not the last of the publication in the series that should be taken into account, but the publication that was made in the first instance under S.6.  [Para 18,19]

This construction is supported by the language employed in Section 6(2) of the Act. In particular, the word "hereinafter" used in Section 6(2) will amply prove that the last of the series of the publication referred to under Section 6(2) is relevant for the purposes coming thereafter, namely, for making award under Section 11-A. The language employed in second proviso to Section 6(1) also supports this construction.  [Para 10]

heading: Personal hearing
HeadNote.description:
Enquiry under S. 5A - Personal hearing - Not obligatory to give personal hearing when petitioner only files his objections in pursuance of notice under S. 4(1) without demanding personal hearing.

AIR 1995 SC 1549 Rel. on. (Paras 12, 13)

heading: Section 6 declaration
HeadNote.description:
Section 6 declaration - Quashing of on ground that enquiry under S. 5A was vitiated - Objections not filed by all owners - quashing will be limited - Quashing in the cases of individual writ petitions cannot be treated as quashing the whole of it.

In connection with owners or persons interested who have not filed objections under S.5A, in principle, it must be accepted that they had no objection to S. 4 notification operating in respect of their property. On the other hand, in respect of those who filed objections they might have locus standi to contend that S. 5 A inquiry was not conducted properly, therefore, those who have not filed objections under S. 5A, could not be allowed to contend that the S .5 A inquiry was bad and that consequently S. 6 declaration must be struck down and that then the S. 4 notification would lapse. If, therefore, no objections were filed by the respondents logically the S.6 declaration must be deemed to be in force so far as they are concerned.  [Para 7]

Quashing the notification in the cases of individual writ petitions cannot be treated as quashing the whole of it. (1991)45 Delhi L T 602 Not followed in view of three Judge Bench decision in 1997 AIR SCW 2513.  [Para 10]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Land acquired with residential structure on it - Reference Court relied on evidence of expert witness - Reading between lines, Court arrived at conclusion that house was constructed in year 1973-74 - Reference Court considered depreciation @ of 13% and fixed cost of construction - Reference Court adopted lowest possible rate - Appeal by State is liable to be dismissed. 	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Land was valued at Rs. 520/- per sq. yard in 1993 - Land acquired in the year 2001 - During this period from 1993 to 2001 there was attrition in the land rates - Hence, land value can be enhanced by 12% per annum for only four years instead of entire period of eight years from 1993 - Valuation in 2001 would be Rs.770 per sq. yard and after making deduction of one third net valuation would be Rs.514/- - Held, Rs.514 per sq. yard would be quite reasonable price. 			(Para 11)

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
Sale deed
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Compensation - Sale deed - Normally sale instances which are around five years prior to the S.4 Notification are acceptable pieces of evidence for the purpose of fixing the market value of the acquired land in cases in which such sale instances are available.
2009(5) ALL MR 1022 (S.C.) Ref. to.             (Para 9)

heading: Compensation
Withdrawal of amount
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Withdrawal of amount - Condition to furnish bank guarantee in execution proceedings by petitioner - Despite issuing notices no reply was filed by respondents - No document filed to show that award is challenged and stay order granted by High Court - Order to furnish bank guarantee as condition for permitting withdrawal of amount deposited is liable to be set aside.

2012(4) ALL MR 747 Rel. on. 			 [Para 11,12]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Land in rural area - Stone quarries only acquired land - Needed filling up to make land fit for construction purpose - While making deduction of 50% reference court only took into consideration presence of stone quarries by ignoring that land was in rural area - Held, deduction ought to have been 60% and escalation 7% and not 10% - Compensation @ Rs. 36/- per sq. meter awarded. 	(Paras 13, 16)

heading: Acquisition of Land
Payment of compensation
Apportionment
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of Land - Payment of compensation - Apportionment - Party raising plea that he had tenancy right over acquired Land - Authority under Land Acquisition Act cannot decide issue of tenancy - Matter has to be referred to be decided by authority under Tenancy Act.

Goa, Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964), S.58. (Para 4 )

heading: Market rate
Determination
Awards passed earlier
HeadNote.description:
Market rate - Determination - Awards passed earlier - Relevant only in cases of comparable lands - Land acquired subsequently being of inferior quality than lands covered under earlier awards - Potential for construction or industrial activity absent - Rate under earlier awards cannot be granted.

The acquired land in instant case is in the interior and on account of the fact that the landholder did not obtain any conversion in respect of that land which was subject to tenancy, there was no feasibility for development of the land for industrial or construction activity. The evidence on record clearly showed that the land in question is low lying paddy field. The claimants have not brought on record any cogent and material evidence to establish that the land in question was of a suitable and potential nature for construction and industrial activity therein. The nature of the land in question is different from the lands referred to in the Awards passed earlier and the location and surroundings in case of land in question are different from those in case of lands in the Awards. The rate awarded in those Awards could not be accepted for fixation of market value of the land in question.  The rates in the earlier Awards in respect of lands in the vicinity of the land of subject matter is not to be accepted blindly without even comparing the land acquired subsequently with that of the one acquired earlier. Though the Awards passed in earlier acquisitions can be relevant for the purpose of comparing the rates awarded while fixing the rate for subsequent acquisition, this is possible only in cases of comparable lands in reasonable proximity of the acquired land and not otherwise.  [Para 10,11,12]

heading: Acquisition proceedings dropped under the Act
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition proceedings dropped under the Act - Claimant entitled to compensation - S.42 of Ceiling Act has no bearing in such case.

Urban Land (Ceiling and Regulation) Act (1976), S.42.

Certain land was sought to be acquired and Notification under S.4 followed by Notification under S.6 were issued. Thereafter the proceedings were dropped under the Land Acquisition Act and not because of the Ceiling Act. Therefore, the owner was entitled to compensation under S.48(2) of the Land Acquisition Act. So far as the right available to the owner of the land under Section 48 of the Act is concerned, there cannot be any impact on the said Ceiling Act inspite of there being Section 42 and code thereunder. Section 42 gives overriding effect to the provisions of Ceiling Act but it can have no bearing on the right given to the owner of the land who had to prosecute the acquisition proceedings till they were dropped, for which Section 48 has been specifically enacted.  [Para 4]

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Acquisition in 1994
Assessment of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Enhancement of compensation - Acquisition in 1994 - Reference Court enhancing compensation considering rates fixed by Apex Court in 1975 - No evidence on record for showing astronomical rise in land prices and for comparing land in question with land acquired in 1975 - Sale deeds relied upon by expert valuer not proved and neither vendor nor vendee examined - Held, claim for enhancement was not established.

Land acquisition case - Assessment of compensation - Claim for enhancement of compensation. (Paras 4,5,6)

heading: Reference
Notice
HeadNote.description: Reference - Notice - Acquiring body was neither issued with any notice of reference proceedings nor it was a party thereto - Award was passed in absence of acquiring body - It is essential for Reference Court to issue notice to acquiring body so that evidence may be adduced by acquiring body so as to determine amount of compensation to be awarded in reference proceedings - Proceedings remitted back to Reference Court. AIR 1995 SC 724 Ref. to. 	(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
Grant of
Validity
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - Grant of - Validity - 5 Hectare land was acquired - Reference Court enhanced compensation from Rs.14,500/- per Hectare to Rs.6,00,000/- per Hectare - Initially claimant sought compensation @ Rs.50,000/- per acre - Subsequently claimant dishonestly and fraudulently sought exorbitant compensation at rate which never existed at time of issuance of S.4 notification by seeking amendment to reference - Reference Court enhanced compensation by relying upon sale instance of house property and judgment passed in other land acquisition proceedings - Sale instance of house property on an extremely small plot cannot be considered for deciding price of large tract of land situated outside village - Market value of the land of the claimant would have been only 70,000/- per Hectare at the time of issuance of S.4 notification - Therefore, compensation reduced to Rs.70,000/- per Hectare. 	(Paras 8, 9, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Rejection
Challenge
Same attained finality
HeadNote.description: Order as to recovery of interest - Application for recalling of - Rejection - Challenge - Main order against state for recovery of interest dt.15/9/1997, was not challenged - Same attained finality - Same was also not an ex-parte order, hence binding on State - Moreover, order of recovery of interest was passed due to delayed payment of decreetal amount - State however took such petty matter upto Apex Court in appeal - Appeal held totally misconceived, hence dismissed. 		(Paras 12, 13, 15)

heading: Compensation
Determination
Legality
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination - On basis of sale instance of similarly situated land - Legality - Sale instance land is at distance of 3 minutes walk from acquired land - Both lands are similar and suitable for construction - Sale instance land was developed plot which was purchased at rate of Rs.30/- sq. mtr. - Considering deduction towards development and propriety, etc. compensation at rate of Rs.86.40/- per sq. mtr. is just and reasonable. 	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Acquisition proceedings
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Acquisition proceedings - Challenge - On ground that dispensation of S.5A inquiry was unjustified and unwarranted - High Court declined to interfere with acquisition and held appellant entitled to a plot as per Rehabilitation and Resettlement Policy of Govt. - In view of efflux of time and intervening developments, matter not considered on merits - Order of High Court upheld. 	(Paras 2, 4)

heading: Acquisition of land
Petition against
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Petition against - Petitioner seeking declaration that acquisition proceedings u/S.6 have lapsed and land be released in name of petitioner - High Court held that acquisition was made more than 37 years ago and no ground for interference made out as the proceedings already complete - Held, approach of High Court not proper in facts and circumstances of the case - High Court should have addressed the issues and passed orders on main reliefs - Matter remanded to be considered on merits. (Paras 4, 5)

heading: Land value
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Land value - Fixed by Reference Court - Interference by High Court on ground that Requisitioning Authority was not put to notice - Challenge - Contention that Authority may not have any difficulty in accepting the land value fixed as same value awarded to adjoining land - Held, same being matter to be considered by Reference Court, parties directed to appear before Reference Court. 	(Paras 2, 3, 4)

heading: Land Acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition - Compensation for fruit bearing trees standing on acquired land - Claimant claimed that 396 fruit bearing trees were standing on acquired land - Whereas as per his deposition they were 250 fruit bearing trees - Total area of acquired land is 7 kanals 2 marlas - Expert relied by claimant admitted that there was tank for storing water and buckets were lying, meaning thereby there was no perennial source of water and claimant was watering trees with help of buckets - Further, he deposed that there could be 90 fruit trees in one killa (equal to one acre) - Not clear as to how there could be 250 trees or 396 trees in 7 kanals and 2 marlas of land (less than one acre) that too of B category - High Court has over looked certain material aspects of evidence while awarding compensation - Matter remitted back for fresh consideration. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Award under
Review
Referred.			 [Para 15,16]
HeadNote.description:
Award under - Review - Award obtained by fraud - Person in whose favour the award was passed, not an interested person in the land acquired - Held, award can be reviewed or recalled either suo motu or on an application made by any person, either by Land Acquisition Officer or the Commissioner.

Every Court has inherent power to act ex debito justitiae-to do that real and substantial justice for the administration of which alone it exists or to prevent abuse of the process of the Court.  When the law gives anything to any one, it also gives all those things without which the thing itself would be unavailable and this principle appears in the maxim "Quando lex aliquid alicuiconcedit, concedere videtur id quo res ipsa esse non potest."  On the touchstone of these well settled principles, an award passed under section 28A of the Act can be reviewed or recalled either suo motu or on an application made by any person, either by the Land Acquisition Officer or the Commissioner in case it is subsequently noticed that the same was obtained by fraud and the person in whose favour the award was passed was not an interested person in the land acquired.

AIR 2000 SC 1165 and AIR 1994 SC 853 - Referred.			 [Para 15,16]

heading: Market Value
HeadNote.description: Market Value - Land acquired in this case and in another First Appeal was pursuant to same notification for same purpose - Both were tenanted lands - Said judgment must be taken as basis for fixing compensation of land acquired herein - Land being at lower level, uneven deductions has to be made - Appellants are entitled to enhancement of compensation - Rejection of Reference not liable to sustain. 	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Market value of respondent's land fixed by placing reliance on award in respect of adjoining property - Subsequently however, the award on which reliance was placed, came to be reduced in appeal - Hence, compensation awarded to respondent also ordered to be reduced - Additionally, deduction of 25% also directed on account of disadvantages of respondent's land vis-a-vis adjoining land. 			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Lapse of proceedings
HeadNote.description: Lapse of proceedings - Land Acquisition Officer failed to pass award within 2 years of publication of declaration under S.6 of Act - Land acquisition proceedings relating to land of petitioners are liable to be quashed. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Acquisition of half portion of shop
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of half portion of shop - Premises consisting of two storeys - Tenant doing business for last several years - Construction of supporting wall absolutely necessary for dividing premises in two parts - Compensation offered to landlord - Landlord directed to construct dividing wall as per plan of Land Acquisition officer. (Para 1)

heading: Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description: Determination of compensation - Reasonable deduction towards development charges - High Court rightly taking size of plots acquired and size of plots exhibited for purpose of comparison into account but reducing compensation by 40%, though acquired lands were within developed municipal limits with all amenities - Held, deduction of 1/4th the market value made by Reference Court was proper - Restored accordingly. 	(Para 7)

heading: Apportionment of compensation
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Apportionment of compensation - Challenge - Respondent alone held entitled to compensation - Reliance placed only on decree dismissing appellants' suit for declaration in respect of suit property - Reference Court did not look for any specific document showing title of respondent - Whereas partition deed of 1913 produced by appellants through which they claimed to have inherited suit property, not at all considered - Reason given that issue of title having already been decided by Civil Court, reconsideration of same would be barred by res judicata - Reference court failed in its duty to examine evidence and documents independently - Decree of Civil Court also misconstrued - Respondent's claim in that case was limited only to a portion of property and not entire property - Apportionment in favour of respondent was illegal - Direction issued for re-apportionment in favour of appellants. 	(Paras 22, 23)

heading: Compensation
Award
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Award - Enhancement by Reference Court - Held justified in facts of the case.

The land acquired in the instant case is in the neighbourhood of the land which is divided in plots and sold.  Also a police station and staff quarters are constructed on that land.  Central market place is about 1 1/2 kms from the acquired land and also all facilities such as school, market, pharmacy and shops are available at that distance.  The neighboring land was sold for Rs.49/-.  However, the Reference Court has taken Rs.45/- as basis.  From Rs.45/-, the Court has reduced 25% for development charges for the land and reached at a figure of Rs.30/- per sq. metre.  Another deduction of Rs.4/- per sq. metre being conversion charges has also been provided for and the Court has thus arrived at Rs.30/- per metre for the land.  In respect of other place of land eventhough it is the bharad land and in same level besides being adjoning land, still the Court has reduced Rs.10/- from Rs.30/- and awarded Rs.20/- per sq. metre.  Held that the award given by the Reference Court did not warrant any interference.  [Para 6,7]

heading: Representations made by the owners of the land proposed to be acquired that pucca residential buildings and commercial complexes are existing on lands and so they may be exempted from acquisition
HeadNote.description: Representations made by the owners of the land proposed to be acquired that pucca residential buildings and commercial complexes are existing on lands and so they may be exempted from acquisition - Rejection of said representations, while allowing some similar objections in other cases is arbitrary and discriminatory.			(Para 11)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Quashing of notification u/S. 4 - Ground of land acquired by invoking urgency clause without necessity - Out of 99 landowners affected by land acquisition only 2 land owners have challenged notification and acquisition of land - Compensation amount was already disbursed to many landowners - Also crores of rupees were spent by respondent on development of infrastructures on acquired land - Court refused to quash notification. 2010 ALL SCR 1898, (2005) 13 SCC 477 Rel. on. 	 (Paras 6, 9, 12)

heading: Market Value
Determination of
HeadNote.description:
Market Value - Determination of - Expenditure likely to be incurred for development of land sought to be acquired - Ought not to be taken into consideration.

The potentiality of the acquired land should be considered neither with reference to the purpose to which it may be put to use in future nor the nature of development to be brought in the acquired land is a material factor to be considered for fixing the market value of the land under Section 23 of the Land Acquisition Act.  Where the land sought to be acquired is in more advantageous position as compared to the land which is already acquired, at least the rate awarded to the earlier acquired land should be awarded to the land sought to be acquired and the fact that it is 1.5 metres below the road level is no ground to award lesser rate.  The rate enhanced from Rs.15/- per sq. metre to Rs.30/-.  The possible or likely expenditure to be incurred for the development of the land, cannot be the basis for deciding the market value of the land.  [Para 2]

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Compensation - In view of bar under S.50(2) compensation awarded by Collector cannot be challenged by writ petition in absence of any allegation that award is fraudulently or collusively passed.

AIR 1986 SC 1164 Rel. on. (Para 9)

heading: Rental compensation
Entitlement to
Illegal
Unsustainable
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition Act (1894), S.30 - Maharashtra Govt. Resolution dt: 1-12-1972 - Rental compensation - Entitlement to - Possession taken by Government by private negotiations before issuance of notice U/s. 4(1) - Govt. entitled to take possession before acquisition only U/S. 31(2) - Taking of possession by Govt. - Illegal - Contention that Govt. not liable to pay rental compensation and interest thereupon - Unsustainable - Govt. estopped from going back from grant of rental compensation and interest as provided.

heading: Reference
Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Acquisition of land - Dispute pertaining to area of land acquired - It forms the subject matter of disputes which have to be referred under S.18.

In the instant case the land acquired by the Government is of the total area of 9700 sq. metres and the appellants are entitled to receive compensation in respect of the entire land admeasuring 9700 sq. metres.  Since it is established that possession of an extra area of 3971 sq. metres has been taken possession of by the Government pursuant to the acquisition proceedings for the River Zuari project, the Reference Court ought to have decided on the question of payment of compensation for the said land and the question of driving the appellants to file Civil Suit for recovery of the land which is in possession of the respondent for which compensation has not been paid does not arise.  Since the dispute pertains to the area of land acquired, it forms the subject matter of disputes which have to be referred under Section 18.				 [Para 27]

heading: First Proviso
Draft award
Approval of Government
HeadNote.description: First Proviso - Draft award - Approval of Government - After considering the detailed note the commissioner granting approval to draft award subject to certain observations recorded therein - Award made after taking into consideration those observations - Held, the note and the endorsement by Commissioner constituted approval.	(Para 10)

heading: Land acquisition
Award of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Award of compensation - Court to award just and fair compensation - Court is not powerless to grant compensation exceeding the amount claimed by landowner. 

	The duty of the Court determining the compensation under the Act is to determine just and fair compensation and to award compensation less than just and fair compensation on the premise that the Court is powerless to grant compensation exceeding the amount claimed would be doing disservice to the statutory duty.	(Paras 41, 42)

	The scheme of the Act mandates that the compensation shall be fair and just and based on the market value and other relevant considerations statutorily prescribed. It would be a travesty of justice, if the Courts, despite concluding that the true market value of the land is more than that claimed by the land owner, are precluded from awarding compensation higher than that claimed on the premise that the claimant himself assessed the market value of the land. Such a view, would not accord either with the Constitutional philosophy underlying Article 300-A of the Constitution of India nor with the statutory scheme of the Act.	 (Para 36)

heading: Reference to Civil Court
HeadNote.description:
Reference to Civil Court - Whether it can be dismissed for default.

The Civil Court has to pass an award in answer to the reference made by the Collector under S.18 of the Act.  If any party to whom notice has been served by the Civil Court did not participate in the inquiry it would only be at his risk because an award would be passed perhaps to the detriment of the concerned party.  But non-participation of any party would not confer jurisdiction on the Civil Court to dismiss the reference for default.

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Limitation - Notice of award served - Time for making reference would run from date of service of notice u/s 12(2) and not from receipt of certified copy of award - Delay in filing reference application cannot be condoned under S.5 of Limitation Act.

AIR 1961 SC 1500, AIR 1989 SC 239, (1995) 3 SCC 330 and (1996) 9 SCC 414 Rel. on. (Para 7)

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - Challenge by acquiring authority - Land acquired for construction of market bypass - Compensation fixed @ Rs.59.58 per sq. mt. sought to be enhanced @ Rs.2000/- per sq. mt. - Reference court considered sale instance of 1993 whereby a plot of paddy field situated close to acquired land, sold @ Rs.1235/- per sq. mt. and awarded compensation at same rate - Reference court ignored fact that sale transaction was of 1993 and land owner was entitled to a fair increase of 10% per annum since then till notification u/S.4 - Reference court ought to have fixed compensation much higher than Rs.1235/- per sq. mt. - However, since no cross appeal or objection filed by land owner, no interference can be made in quantum of compensation - Appeal by acquiring department, dismissed.	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
Necessary parties
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - Necessary parties - Land acquired for public purpose - Held, post-acquisition allottee of the land, is not necessary or proper party or has no locus to be heard in the proceeding for enhancement of compensation.

	To determine the question whether the post-acquisition allottee of land is necessary or proper party or has any locus to be heard in the matter of determination of compensation, The scheme of the Act may be refered The acquisition may either be for a "public purpose" as defined under Section 3(f) or for a company under Part-VII of the Act. If the acquisition is for a public purpose (as the present case), the land vests in the State after the Collector makes an award and the possession is taken. Till the award is made, no person other than State comes into the picture. Once the land vests in the State, the acquisition is complete. Any transferee from the State is not concerned with the process of acquisition. The State may transfer the land by public auction or by allotment at any price with which the person whose land is acquired has no concern. The mere fact that the Government chooses to determine the allotment price with reference to compensation price determined by the Court does not provide any locus to an allottee to contest the claim for enhancement of compensation. 

(1995) 2 SCC 326 Disting. 	 [Para 9]

heading: Acquisition of land
Award of Compensation
Reference under S.18
Compensation enhanced
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Award of Compensation - Reference under S.18 - Compensation enhanced - Person who was not party to reference - Cannot apply for apportionment of enhanced compensation in execution petition pending before court.

A person who is not a party to the reference made under S.18 of the Act for enhancement of compensation, cannot file application for apportionment of the enhanced amount of compensation in an execution petition pending before court.

No doubt the Civil Court gets the jurisdiction as a result of the reference being made by the Collector and/or the Acquisition Officer either as. provided under section 18 or under section 30 of the Land Acquisition Act and even though to the proceeding which are referred to the Civil Court, the procedure applicable is that of Code of Civil Procedure, still the same will not be applicable when the court is considering the issue of addition of parties either Under Order 1 Rule 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure or for any other purpose. AIR 1996 SC 1513 AND 1986 Mh. L.J. 844 Rel.  [Para 6]

those who are parties to the original proceedings before the Civil Court which passed the decree, their legal representatives and the purchasers of the said property as defined in .Section 47 are only entitled to appear while the question of discharge, satisfaction etc. of the decree is to be considered.   [Para 7]

heading: Land acquisition
Declaration of award
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Declaration of award - Award shall be declared within a period of two years from the date of publication of the declaration - If no such award is made, the entire proceedings for the acquisition would lapse.

Normal rule is that an Award must be declared within a period of two years from the date of publication of the declaration, and if no such Award is made the entire proceedings for the acquisition would lapse.  The proviso, however, is in the nature of exception to the rule and clarifies that where the said declaration had been published before the commencement of the Amendment Act of 1984, then the Award shall be made within a period of two years from such commencement.

Now, when the amendment was made effective and brought into force with effect from 24th September, 1984, the last date for making an Award was 23rd September, 1986.  It is not in dispute that on 23rd September, 1986, an Award was made which was within time.  Therefore, it cannot be said that any illegality had been committed by the respondents and the Award was not passed within two years.   [Para 7,8]

heading: Compensation
Entitlement
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Entitlement - Possession of land given to Government on understanding that government will pay compensation - Proceeding initiated under Daman (Abolition of Proprietorship of Villages) Regulation (1962) dropped on finding that land was under cultivation and was not a grass land - Order dropping proceedings becoming final - Claimant cannot be deprived of compensation on ground that land was grass land. (Para 3)

heading: Person not party to land acquisition proceedings before Collector
HeadNote.description:
Person not party to land acquisition proceedings before Collector - Cannot be impleaded as party before District Court in reference under S.30.

A person who has not been a party to the land acquisition proceedings before the Collector cannot seek impleadment as a party to the proceedings before the District Court in a reference under s. 30 of the Act.   [Para 11]

The scope of reference is limited to the terms of reference. The terms of reference would depend upon the objections by the claimants. The objections can be in relation to those subjects which are specified under section 18 or section 30 of the said Act. It is only after the valid reference that the Court has to inquire into the matter and for that purpose follow the procedure prescribed under the Code of Civil Procedure, subject to that it shall not be inconsistent to the provisions of the Act. S. 32 (2) Proviso provides that nothing contained therein shall affect the liability of any person who may receive the whole or any part of the compensation awarded under the said Act, to pay the same to the person lawfully entitled thereto eventhough such person may not have appeared before the Collector under the said Act.  [Para 8,9]

In the instant case the intervenors whose applications are rejected by the Reference Court were not parties to the proceedings before the Land Acquisition Officer. None of them had filed any application for reference either under section 18 or 30 of the Act in the matter. The intervenors are seeking impleadment much after the reference was made by the Collector to the Reference Court. In the circumstances, no fault can be found with the final decision of the reference Court in rejecting the applications of the petitioners.  [Para 11]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - On assessment of evidence and by giving cogent reasons High Court enhancing compensation to Rs. 5/- per Sq.Ft. while the Collector had granted compensation at Rs. 1.35 per Sq. Ft. which was enhanced to Rs. 3.20 per Sq.Ft. by Tribunal - Held that mathematical precision cannot be expected and some amount of guess work would always be involved in determining compensation.	(Paras 4,5)

heading: Market value of acquired land
HeadNote.description:
Market value of acquired land - Prices fetched by properties in the neighbouring area - Certified copies of sale deeds - Can be considered without examining persons connected with the transactions mentioned therein.

The State has the burden to prove the market value of the lands acquired by it for which the State may have to depend upon the prices of lands similarly situated which were transacted or sold in the recent past, particularly those lands situated in the neighbouring areas.  The practice had shown that for the State officials it was a burden to trace out the persons connected with such transaction mentioned in the sale deeds and then to examine them in Court for the purpose of proving such transactions.  It was in the wake of the aforesaid practical difficulties that the new S.51A was introduced in the L.A. Act.  When the Section says the certified copy of a registered document "may be accepted as evidence of the transaction recorded in such document" it enables the Court to treat what is recorded in the document, in respect of the transactions referred to therein, as evidence. [Para 13]
