The words "may be accepted as evidence" in the section indicate that there is no compulsion on the Court to accept such transaction as evidence, but it is open to the Court to treat them as evidence.  Merely accepting them as evidence does not mean that the Court is bound to treat them as reliable evidence.  What is sought to be achieved is that the transactions recorded in the documents may be treated as evidence, just like any other evidence, and it is for the Court to weigh all the pros and cons to decide whether such transaction can be relied on for understanding the real price of the land concerned. [Para 14]

In the case of S.51A of the LA Act also the position cannot be different, as it is open to the Court to act on the documents regarding the transaction recorded in such documents.  However, this will not prevent any party who supports or opposes the said document or the transaction recorded therein to adduce other evidence to substantiate their stand regarding such transactions.  But it is not possible to hold that even after the introduction of S.51A the position would remain the same as before (1993) 3 SCC 240 and (1995) 2 SCC 205 overruled.				 [Para 16]

heading: Market value
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination of - Potentiality, topography and advantages attached to land in adjacent village almost similar to land in question - Market value - Claimants also not producing any evidence to support any enhanced value - High Court adopting that value as basis and granting escalation at 6% for years 1963-1965, 10% for per year from 1966 to 1973 and 12% per annum from 1975 - Market value of Rs.16,750/- per bigha arrived at being for agricultural land, amount raised to Rs.82,255/- per bigha in view of developed commercial potentiality by High Court approved of.			(Paras 10 to 12)

heading: Assessment of compensation
HeadNote.description: Assessment of compensation - Property in question having perennial potentiality with regard to agricultural operation and irrigation - Residential houses and village road situated nearby - Held, compensation for area covered by coconut plants can be fixed at rate of Rs.1.50 per sq.mtr. and for remaining extent of land at rate of Re.1/- per sq.mtr. (Para 7)

heading: Acquisition of land
Urgency clause
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Urgency clause - Notification invoking urgency clause in respect of 14 properties - Notification quashed in respect of property belonging to one of the persons on ground that opinion expressed in notification was insufficient for invoking provisions of S.17(1) - Held expression of urgency being one cannot be partly good and partly bad and as such notification was liable to be quashed.			(Para 15)

heading: Redetermination of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Redetermination of compensation - Right to make application under S.28-A is not confined to earliest award that is made by the Court.

The decision in Pradeep Kumari (1995) 2 SCC 736 categorically held that "the right to make the application under S.28-A of the Act arises from the award of the Court on the basis of which the person making the application, is seeking redetermination of the compensation. There is nothing in sub-sec. (1) of S.28-A to indicate that this right is confined in respect of the earliest award that is made by the Court after the coming into force of S.28-A." Any construction to the contra introducing such words, not found engrafted in the very provision would amount to curtailing the amplitude of the provision resulting virtually in restricting a benefit conferred, particularly of a beneficent provision normally not permissible by judicial interpretation. It was also held therein that there is nothing in the wordings of S.28-A to indicate that the legislature intended to confer any such limited benefit thereunder which would have the inevitable consequence of denying the benefit of higher amount on the basis of the subsequent award. Such an interpretation as would restrict the benefit of S.28-A to the first of the Award in the series and in point of time, was also considered to result more in the perpetuation of the inequality in the payment of compensation, which the legislature specifically intended to remove by enacting the provision and that, therefore, the object underlying S.28-A would be better served and achieved by giving the word "an award" in S.28-A its natural meaning, as meaning any one of the award(s) made by the Court under Part-III, after the coming into force of S.28-A. That apart, even the latter part of S.28-A which stipulates, "require that the amount of compensation payable to them may be re-determined on the basis of the amount of compensation awarded by the Court," leaves the choice to the person making such an application for redetermination, without confining or restricting the area of choice of such person to any one or the other, though it could be availed of only once and not as many number of times as there are so many awards.

(1995) 2 SCC 736 Followed.	  [Para 4]

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Right of expropriated owner - Once the land is vested in State free from all encumbrances, such land of government if not used for the purposes for which the land was acquired or for any other public purpose or has not at all been used, should be sold through public auction - Expropriated owner cannot have any right to restoration of such land.

Once the land has been acquired and acquisition has become final, the expropriated owner ceases to have any right, title and interest in the property and pre-existing right, title and interest held by the erstwhile owner ceases to exist and is divested.  Once the land is vested in the State free from all encumbrances, obviously such land of the government if not used for the purposes for which the land was acquired or for any other public purpose or has not at all been used, should be sold through public auction and the expropriated owner cannot have any right to restoration of such land.  AIR 1999 SC 3667 - Followed.  [Para 5]

heading: Award contemplated by S.11-A not made within two years provided by that Section
HeadNote.description: Award contemplated by S.11-A not made within two years provided by that Section - Proceedings commenced for acquisition of land liable to be quashed. 	(Para 2)

heading: Comparable sales method
Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Determination of market value - Comparable sales method - Applicability - Land covered by comparable sale better situated and having better facilities - High Court may reduce value of land to be acquired keeping this aspect in view.

While fixing the market value of the acquired land, Comparable Sales Method of valuation is preferred than other methods of valuation of land such as Capitalisation of Net Income Method or Expert Opinion Method. Comparable Sales Method of valuation is preferred because it famishes the evidence for determination of the market value of the acquired land at which a willing purchaser would pay for the acquired land if it has been sold in open market at the time of issue of notification under Section 4 of the Act.   However, Comparable Sales Method of valuation of land for fixing the market value of the acquired land is not always conclusive. There are certain factors which are required to be fulfilled and on fulfillment of those factors the compensation can be awarded, according to the value of the land reflected in the  sales.  The factors laid down inter alia are : (1) the sale must be a genuine transaction, that (2) the sale deed must have been executed at the time proximate to the date of issue of notification under Section 4 of the Act, that (3) the land covered by the sale must be in the vicinity of the acquired land, that (4) the land covered by the sales must be similar to the acquired land and that (5) the size of plot of the land covered by the sales be comparable to the land acquired. If all these factors are satisfied, then there is no reason why the sale value of the land covered by the sales be not given for the acquired land.   However, if there is a dissimilarity in regard to locality, shape, site or nature of land between land covered by sales and land acquired, it is open to Court to proportionately reduce the compensation for acquired land than what is reflected in the sales depending upon the disadvantages attached with the  acquired land.		 [Para 3]

heading: Reference
Rejection of
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Rejection of - On ground of absence of claimant - Validity - Reference was filed claiming enhancement of compensation - However, claimant remained absent and failed to adduce evidence to prove his claim - Even then Reference Court cannot dismiss reference on ground of absence of claimant - Adjudication of reference is award within meaning of S.26 - Reference Court has to pass award after considering material and documents available on record.

The adjudication of reference petition by the Civil Court has to be regarded as an award within the meaning of S. 26 of the Land Acquisition Act irrespective of the fact that enhancement of compensation came to beawarded or not. It is incumbent on the part of Civil Court to consider the material on record, even if the party is absent and has failed to adduce evidence. It is to be noted that unless the material on record is considered and appreciated the amount determined being market value would not be specified in the award of Reference Court as envisaged under clause First of section (1) of S. 23 of the Act of 1894. It must include the amount awarded under respective clauses of sub section of S.23 of the Act of 1894 together with grounds of award. The order passed by the Civil Judge comprising specific market value determined after due exercise as prescribed under S. 23 of the Act of 1894, only would be regarded as an award under S. 26 of the Act of 1894. In the present case, the learned Reference Court failed to consider the material whatever available on record to determine the fair, correct and genuine market value of the acquired land. The Civil Court should have undertaken exercise to arrive at the conclusion that the amount determined by the SLAO would be just, proper and reasonable value for the land under acquisition. The Reference Court did not painstake to elucidate as to how the compensation awarded by SLAO was just, proper and reasonable. In such circumstances, the impugned judgment and award would not be construed as adjudication of dispute within ambit of law. It cannot be treated as an award under S. 26 of the Act of 1894. Albeit, the Court has no jurisdiction to refuse for determination of the amount of compensation even where the claimant remains absent or where he is present, but fails to adduce evidence. It is mandatory for the Civil Court to apply its judicious mind and make an award under S. 26 of the Act of 1894.		 [Para 12,13,14,16]

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - Compensation enhanced by Reference Court by reproducing facts of award which was cited as evidence by claimant - It shows non-application of mind on part of Reference Court - Order enhancing compensation passed by Reference Court on basis of completely wrong facts - Same is liable to be set aside. 		(Paras 4, 5, 6)

heading: Market value
Determination
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination - Land situated near market place - In earlier case 10 years back Rs.6/- per sq. meter awarded - Acquisition of land situated near land required in earlier case - Award of Rs.2/- per sq. meter is unjustified - Rs.6/- may be held to be adequate compensation. (Para 3)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Claimants' land had advantages over adjoining land - Claimants' land had direct access to Peddar Road, had a better shape for residential use and half of land was levelled - Both lands acquired under same notification - Willing buyer would give better value to claimants' land on these three counts - Hence considering superiority of claimants' land 8% increase allowed over the adjoining land and 30% solatium over the enhanced market value - Interest at 9% for period of one year from date of possession and thereafter at 15 % till payment also granted. (Paras 12, 13)

heading: Acquisition of land
Payment of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Payment of compensation - Court enhancing market value in reference - Landowner is entitled to simple interest on amount of difference.

Where Land is acquired and the compensation is quantified by the Land Acquisition officer and such compensation is enhanced by the court in reference, the landowner is entitled to claim simple interest on amount of difference between the market value calculated by the court less the market value calculated by the Land Acquisition officer which has remained unpaid.  [Para 11]

Neither the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act, nor the Award passed by the Civil Judge, provide for compound interest. If compound interest is payable then, there must be specific directions to that effect; otherwise, the interest is always simple interest. That means the interest on the principal amount and not on the principal amount plus amount of interest accrued on the principal amount. The Award passed by the learned Civil Judge does not indicate as to whether interest should be compound or simple interest; and, in such circumstances, the interest has to be calculated as simple interest under S.28.

heading: Notice
HeadNote.description:
Notice - Personal notice to owners of land is not contemplated by S.4 - Under S.5A notice is required to be issued to objector alone and not to all those persons brought to the notice of the officer by the objector - Other persons interested would get notice under S.9 while determining entitlement to compensation amount.

Section 4 does not contemplate any personal notice.  So far as Section 5A is concerned, the notice is required to be issued to the objector, as, it is strictly meant for the objectors who raise the same.  However this does not mean that persons who have not raised the objection shall not be called at all by the Officer concerned for making the necessary enquiry.  The intention of issuance of preliminary notification i.e. notification u/s 4(1) itself is to give a chance to all those interested in whatsoever manner they may be in the land to raise an objection.  In our opinion, therefore, it is not contemplated in sub-section (2) of section 5A that if anybody's name comes to the notice of the Officer concerned through the objection raised by the objector, he should go on issuing notices to all such persons at all such stages and particularly when such person though had an enough opportunity but failed to have raised the objection on the basis of the notification issued u/s 4 of the Act.  [Para 15]

The Collector or the Land Acquisition Officer could not expand the scope of his inquiry by calling everyone to whom a reference is made by the objectors and particularly when such persons had an opportunity to raise objection on the basis of notification under Section 4(1) of the Act. [Para 26]

Section 9 definitely contemplates a notice to be given to the interested persons as it is made incumbent on the Collector to affix public notice at a convenient place or near the land to be taken indicating the intention of the Government to take possession of the said land and call upon all the persons interested in such land to make claims as to the compensation.  Sub-section (2) of Section 9 calls upon all the persons interested in land to appear in person or through agent before the Collector at the time and place mentioned in the notice and to state the nature of their respective interests in the land, the amount and the shares in the compensation amount.  Sub-section (3) of Section 9 of the Act makes it incumbent on the Collector concerned to serve a notice to the same effect on the occupier, if any, of such land and all such persons known or believed to be interested therein or to be entitled to act for the persons so interested or for agents authorised to receive service on their behalf within the local district in which the land is situated.  In pursuance of sub-section (4) of Section 9 of the Act, in appropriate cases as are mentioned therein the Collector has to send notices by post to the interested persons.  This is for the first time that the Act requires a notice to be issued to the party concerned or persons interested in the land.  Neither Section 4 nor Section 6 contemplate any personal notice either to the owners or the persons interested in the land to be acquired.

1975 Mah.LJ 1035 and 1981 Mah.LJ 511 Rel. on.			 [Para 18,19]

heading: Land acquisition
Rejection
Improper
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Cross-objection by claimant against order passed by Reference Court - Rejection - Merely because appeal filed by opposite parties against order of Reference Court was dismissed on merit - Improper - Dismissal of appeal would not result in dismissal of cross-objection - Cross-objection had to be disposed of on its merits by assigning reasons - No such reasons were also assigned by High Court - Matter remanded to High Court for deciding cross-objection afresh. 	(Paras 18, 20, 21, 22, 23)

heading: Acquisition of Land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of Land - Objections filed by the owner - No opportunity of being heard given to objector - Issue of declaration without complying with S.5A which is mandatory requirement - Order is vitiated and deserved to be quashed and set aside.

Section 5A clearly indicates that it is obligatory on the part of the Collector or the Land Acquisition Officer to give the objector an opportunity of being heard and it is only after hearing all such objections and after making such further inquiry if any, as he thinks necessary, that he can make a report and unless the persons interested in the land which has been notified under section 4(1) has been given an opportunity of being heard, the authority concerned can not proceed further.  [Para 10]

Since the authorities in the case failed to comply with the mandatory provisions of section 5-A of the Act by not affording an opportunity of being heard to the Petitioners though objections were filed and having proceeded further by issuing declaration that the land of the petitioners is required for public purpose as required under section 6, the said declaration under section 6 is vitiated and deserves to be quashed and set aside. [Para 15]

heading: Reference application
Validity
HeadNote.description: Reference application - Rejection of, by Additional Collector - On ground of non-payment of court fees - Validity - Amount of Court fees could be remitted even before reference court - Additional Collector should have forwarded reference application to civil court by passing conditional order - Order rejecting reference application for non-payment of court fees liable to be quashed. 	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Reference
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Limitation - Limitation begins to operate from the moment the notice under S.12(2) is received or as envisaged by S.18(2) - It is not necessary that notice under S.12(2) should contain all details of the award including its consideration and manner of determination - S.5 of Limitation Act does not apply to the application under S.18 of the Act.

Limitation Act (1963), S.5.

It is not necessary that the notice under Section 12(2) of the Land Acquisition Act should contain all the details of the award including its consideration and manner of determination. Limitation begins to operate from the moment the notice under Section 12(2) is received or as envisaged by Section 18(2).  The Division Bench judgment of this Court in Mangilal cannot be said to be good law on the face of the Supreme Court Judgment in Satinder Bir Singh.  Section 5 of the Limitation Act does not apply to the application under Section 18 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 and if the application for a reference under Section 18 is made beyond the period of limitation prescribed for that purpose, the only consequence that would follow is rejection of such application being barred by limitation and that is what has been done by the Special Land Acquisition Officer in the present case. 1997(2) Mh.L.J. 353 and (1995)3 SCC 330 - Followed.  AIR 1978 Bombay 325 No longer good law.  [Para 11,12]

heading: Notification under S.6(2)
HeadNote.description:
Notification under S.6(2) - Words "publish" and "from the date of publication of the notification" occurring in 6(1) Proviso (ii) - Refer to S.4 notification and not to S.6 notification - Notification under S.6(2) is not required to be published within time stipulated in proviso (ii) to S.6(1).

Sub-section (2) of S.6 does not prescribe any time limit within which the declaration made under Section 6(1) is to be published. It is well known that after an order or declaration is made there can be a time gap between the making of the order or a declaration and its publication in the Official Gazette. Whereas the time limit for the making of an order is provided under Section 6(1), the legislature advisedly did not provide for any time limit in respect of the steps required to be taken under sub-section (2) of Section 6. The purpose of Section 6 notification being to give a final declaration with regard to the need of the land for public purpose, the interest of the land owners was sufficiently safeguarded with the requirement of the making of the declaration under Section 6(1) within a prescribed period. It is difficult for us to read into sub-section (2) the provisions of the proviso to Section 6(1) which relate to the time limit for issuance of the notification under Section 6(1). (1976) 1 SC 843 Rel.on. (1996) 3 SCC 600 Held obitar. [Para 7]

heading: Dispute regarding apportionment
HeadNote.description:
Apportionment of compensation between landlord and tenant - Dispute regarding apportionment - Tenant claiming right of tenancy in terms of Agricultural Tenancy Act - Held, before proceeding with matter of apportionment, issue of tenancy should be framed and referred to concerned Mamlatdar for decision and his finding thereon should be obtained.

JT 1996(7) SC 639 and AIR 1993 SC 1766 foll.

Land acquisition - Apportionment of compensation between landlord and tenant - Dispute as to apportionment - Right of tenancy claimed by tenant - Procedure to be followed by Court. (Paras 3, 4, 5)

heading: Reference
Dismissal
HeadNote.description: Reference - Claiming enhancement of compensation - Dismissal - On ground that claimant has no right to claim compensation as area was shown as reserved for Development Plan road in sanctioned lay-out - In case of reservations for Development Plan road, acquiring body has to pay compensation at market value of said portion - Further, there is no law which empowers planning authority to impose condition while sanctioning lay-out that land reserved for public purpose would vest in planning authority or municipality free of cost - Order dismissing reference application liable to be set aside. 1994 ALLMR ONLINE 1955 (S.C.) Rel.on. 2009(4) ALL MR 333, 2003(4) ALL MR 299 Ref. to. 	(Paras 12, 14, 15, 16, 17)

heading: Acquisition of land
Determination of compensation
Reference
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Determination of compensation - Reference - Enhancement of compensation - Evidence produced by claimant insufficient to arrive at any conclusion about valuation of land - Enhancement of compensation is not justified.

In a case where the claimant wants to rely upon the already executed sale deed to prove his claim for enhancement of compensation, based on such sale deed, it is necessary for him to lead necessary evidence regarding the location, size, shape, tenure, user and potentiality of the land sold to be compared with the acquired land.  A perusal of the evidence on record in the case in hand discloses that the respondents Claimants have not taken any pains to lead any evidence for the purpose of comparision of the said land with the acquired land.  There is absolutely no evidence regarding the prevailing market price of the land in the locality in the year 1972.  Merely on the basis of revenue assessment, it is not possible to jump to the conclusion about the value of the acquired land should be similar to the land which was subject matter of the sale deed.					 [Para 13]

Once it is clear that the evidence in relation to the comparability of the land acquired with the land which was the subject matter of sale deed produced by the claimant was insufficient to arrive at any conclusion about the valuation of the acquired land, and there being no other evidence on record, to justify the claim for enhancement of compensation for the acquired land, the Reference Court is not justified in enhancing the compensation from Rs.1800/- to Rs.5000/- per acre for Bagayat land and Rs.1500/- to Rs.3500/- per acre for dry land.   [Para 15]

heading: Compensation
Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Acquisition of land - 84 acres of land acquired - Land having commercial and residenticial potential but entirely undeveloped - One side abutted main road but remaining large area where planned development was required needing internal roads, drainage, sewer, water, electricity lines, and other civic amenities - Cut of 20% on rate of compensation as against 1/3 normal deduction was proper taking into consideration potential for development - Price fetched by small plot cannot be accepted so also the argument that the land was adjacent to development area.

The land proposed to be the acquired was a large area of 84 acres. In order to develop this land, roads were to be laid, provisions for drainage was to be made and certain area was to be earmarked for other civic amenities. Thus, after leaving the area in the land required for the purposes mentioned above, plots were to be made for residential and commercial purposes by incurring expenditure for other developmental works, such as providing electricity, water, etc. The acquired land is not small plot located in such a way that no other development was required at all and it could be utilized as it is as a developed building site. It is well-settled that in respect of agricultural land or undeveloped land which has potential value for housing or commercial purposes, normally 1/3 amount of compensation has to be deducted out of the amount of compensation payable on the acquired land subject to certain variations depending on its nature, location, extent of expenditure involved for development and the area required for roads and other civic amenities to develop the land so as to make the plots for the residential or commercial purposes. A land may be plain or uneven, the soil of the land may be soft or hard bearing on the foundation for the purpose of making construction; may be the land is situated in the midst of a developed area all around but that land may have a hillock or may be low-lying or may be having deep ditches. So the amount of expenses that may be incurred in developing the area also varies. A claimant who claims that his land is fully developed and nothing more is required to be done for developmental purposes, must show on the basis of evidence that it is such a land and it is so located. In the absence of such evidence, merely saying that area adjoining his land is developed area, is not enough particularly when the extent of the acquired land is large and even if a small portion of the land is abutting the main road in the developed area, does not give the land character of a developed area. In 84 acres of land acquired even if one portion on one side abuts the main road, the remaining large area where planned development is required, needs laying of internal roads, drainage, sewer, water, electricity lines, providing civic amenities etc. However, in cases of some land where there are certain advantages by virtue of the developed area around, may help in reducing the percentage of cut to be applied, as the developmental charges required may be less on that account. There may be various factual factors which may have to be taken into consideration while applying the cut in payment of compensation towards developmental charges, may be in some cases it is more than 1/3 and in some cases less than 1/3. It must be remembered that there is difference between a developed area and an area having potential value, which is yet to be developed. The fact that an area is developed or adjacent to a developed area will not ipso facto make every land situated in the area also developed to be valued as a building site or plot, particularly when vast tracts are acquired, as in this case, for development purposes.		 [Para 7]

heading: Reference under
Application for
"Person interested"
HeadNote.description:
Reference under - Application for - "Person interested" - Application can be made by legal representatives of land owner - Application for substitution of legal representatives of original land owner made after his death - Land Acquisition Officer duty bound to decide that application first and then proceed to forward the reference to appropriate Court mentioned in S.18.

Civil P.C. (1908), O.1, R.10 & O.22, Rr.3,4.

An application for reference may be made by any person interested who has not accepted the award.  An application for reference, therefore, could be made by the legal representatives of the land owner.   Sub-section (2) of Section 18 provides for the limitation within which it has to be made.  Factually, in the present case such application was made by the land owner himself.  An application for substitution of the legal representatives of Janglu, who was the original owner' after his death was made before the Land Acquisition Officer.  It was, therefore, necessary for the Land Acquisition Officer to decide that application and then proceed to forward the reference to the appropriate Court mentioned in Section 18.  Section 19 enjoins upon the Collector the duty to state certain information in the reference and it requires that he shall state the names of persons whom he has reasons to think are interested in such land.  It is, therefore, a statutory duty of the Special Land Acquisition Officer to inform the names of the persons whom he has reasons to believe are interested in the land.  Consequently, when an application for substitution of the applicants as legal representatives of deceased Janglu was pending before him, it was his duty under Section 19 to decide that application and inform their names to the Court as contemplated by Section 19.  Failure on the part of the Collector to do his duty cannot result in depriving the applicants of their right to claim enhanced compensation under Section 18 of the Act.		 [Para 9]

It will be seen from the provisions of O.1, R.10 that the Court may even suo motu add parties in the interest of justice.  It is, therefore, a power of the Court to add parties to a suit either at the instance of the party already appearing before the Court or suo motu.  This power of the Court is entirely different than the power vested in the Court under Order 22 which deals with death, marriage and insolvency of parties.  Rule 1 provides that the death of the plaintiff and defendant shall not cause the suit to abate if the right to sue survives.  In this case, right to sue survives on the death of the original landholder.  Rules 3 & 4 of Order 22 then provide for making of an application for substitution by the legal representatives of the party dying as the right to sue or be sued survives under Rule 1.   Thus, it is a statutory right of the legal representatives of a party dying during the pendency of a lis that is conferred by the provisions of Order 22.  It is entirely different statutory right than the right conferred on the Court by Order 1 Rule 10 C.P.C.  These two are distinct powers and proceedings are required to be taken for exercise of that power.	 [Para 10]

heading: Acquisition of land for Mumbai-Pune Express Highway
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for Mumbai-Pune Express Highway - Changes in alignment of road alleged to have been made to favour a particular person - His house and portion of land was saved though he too lost three acres of land - Over 84 Kms. stretch of High way only six local changes were made the disputed being one of them - Petitioner not able to make out that Government acted malafide or in inappropriate exercise of its power - Held conclusive presumption under S. 6(3) was not displaced by the petitioners and in the circumstances order of status quo has to be vacated. (Para 50)

heading: Acquisition proceedings
Validity
HeadNote.description: Acquisition proceedings - Validity - No hearing U/S.5A given to owner before acquisition - Moreover two notices U/S. 4(1) issued - No evidence that notices served - In circumstances, acquisition proceedings set aside.	(Paras 4,6,7)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Appellant seeking to quash S.4(1) notification published on 29.12.1989 filing Civil Suit - S.C. by a decision given on 27.4.1995 holding that notification can be challenged only by filing a Writ Petition and not by Civil suit - Inspite of this decision appellant pursued Civil Suit - When district Judge held that Civil Suit was not maintainable appellant filed Writ Petition after a long delay of eleven years - Held both the learned Single Judge and Division Bench were justified in dismissing the Writ Petition but in view of fact that appellant was not in a position to seek reference for enhancement of compensation pending litigation Court directed payment of Rs.12 lakhs to the landowner to put an end to litigation.	(Paras 4,6)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Objections filed by land owners - Objector has to be heard personally or through his authorised person - Acquisition without hearing objection is illegal.

Section 5-A(2) shows that an opportunity should be given to the objector of being heard in person or by any person authorised in his behalf and only after hearing all such objections and making such further inquiry, as he thinks fit, make a report to the appropriate Government.	 [Para 9]

The note-sheet in the instant case, does indicate that on the relevant date the land owner was present and that he had submitted his objection, but does not indicate that any personal hearing was given to him.  Its also does not indicate as to whether the Special Land Acquisition Officer had informed him that on that date he was deciding his objection, the note-sheet, therefore, is rather vague and does not  clearly indicate whether an opportunity of personal hearing has been given to him or not.  In the circumstances the matter has to be remanded to the Land Acquisition officer to give hearing to the petitioner-owner. [Para 10]

heading: Acquisition of land for Indian Oil Corporation for the purpose of setting up LPG Bottling plant
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for Indian Oil Corporation for the purpose of setting up LPG Bottling plant - Ministry of Industry, Bureau of Public Enterprises laying down certain guidelines to be followed by such corporation - Guidelines essentially for providing preference in employment to those whose lands were to be acquired - Marking and ranking to the persons who are all similarly situated and affected in acquisition of the lands - Petitioners found not eligible to the employment as per the policy - Marking and ranking given by officers of corporation after application of mind - Cannot be interfered with.			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Acquisition of land
Market value
Standard deduction
Followed.	 [Para 8]
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Market value - Standard deduction - Land acquired for development of Industrial Estate - 30% deductions are just and proper but at the same time deductions could go even upto 60%. depending upon facts of each case.

As far as standard deductions are concerned, it is well established that about 30% deductions are found to be just and proper but at the same time the deductions could go even upto 60% depending upon the facts of each case. The Industrial Development Corporation has the liberty to bring on record such evidence as to demonstrate a deduction permissible beyond 30%. This has not been done.  There is also no evidence to accept the contentions that the subject land is located in one of the most backward areas. Notwithstanding the failure on the part of the acquiring body to bring on record this evidence to justify more than 30% deduction, admittedly the subject land was being acquired for development of Industrial Estate, which development process would also take into consideration construction of roads, drainage, common amenities, water supply, electricity supply including building sub-stations, etc. The plot of land would not be sold unless all these developments were to be physically available and therefore there would be a gestation period.  This would certainly justify a deduction of 30%.  (1998)2 SCC 385 and (1988)3 SCC 751 - Followed.	 [Para 8]

heading: Market value
HeadNote.description: Market value - Status of the land as non-agricultural or agricultural - Grant of non-agricultural permission - Permission granted on condition that grantee shall commence Non-agricultural use of the land within period of one year from date of order unless the period is extended from time to time failing which permission shall be deemed to have been cancelled - Held, the non-agricultural permission cannot be the sole basis to treat the entire land as non-agricultural or being used for commercial purposes. AIR 1996 SC 981 and 1996(2) SCC 583 - Followed.	(Para 12)

heading: Compensation
Redetermination
Application for
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Redetermination - Application for - Limitation - Starts from date of passing of award and not from date of knowledge of passing of the award.

Plain language of S.28-A would only mean that the period of limitation is three months from the date of the award of the Court. It is also provided that in computing the period of three months, the day on which the award was pronounced and the time requisite for obtaining the copy of the award is to be excluded. Therefore, the aforesaid provision crystallizes that application under S.28-A is to be filed within three months from the date of the award by the Court by only excluding the time requisite for obtaining copy. Hence, it is difficult to infer further exclusion of time on the ground of acquisition of knowledge by the applicant.  	 [Para 7]

Though Section 28-A is a beneficial provision, the advantage of the benefit which is conferred is required to be taken within the stipulated time. A landowner may be poor or illiterate and because of that he might not have filed reference application but that would not mean that he could be negligent in not finding out whether other landowners have filed such applications. Whosoever wants to take advantage of the beneficial legislation has to be vigilant and has to take appropriate action within prescribed time. He must at least be vigilant in making efforts to find out whether other landowner has filed any reference application and if so what is the result. If that is not done then law cannot help him. Admittedly, in the present case, award enhancing the compensation was pronounced by the Civil Court by order dated 29th November, 1984 and applications were filed on 27th November, 1989 i.e. after lapse of 5 years. In such case, as the applicant was having an opportunity of knowing the award and/or he was required to make efforts of knowing about such proceedings, he must be presumed to have had knowledge of the award. If such delayed applications are entertained, there may not be any finality to the award and payment of compensation. Result may be that such proceedings may adversely affect where land is acquired by the Government for a project which is to be carried out by local bodies. [Para 10]

The award passed by the Court cannot be termed as an offer for market price for purchase of the land. There is no duty cast upon the Court to issue notice to the landowners who have not initiated proceedings for enhancement of compensation by filing reference applications; may be that their lands are acquired by a common notification issued under S.4 of the Act. As against this, under S.18 it is the duty of the Collector to issue notice either under S.12(2) of the Act at the time of passing of the award or in any case the date to be pronounced before passing of the award and if this is not done then the period prescribed for filing application under S.18 is six months from the date of the Collector's award.   [Para 12]

heading: Reference
Acquisition of land
Compensation
Deduction towards development
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Acquisition of land - Compensation - Deduction towards development - Deduction depends on facts of each case and there cannot be any rule of universal application.

The deduction towards development depends on the facts of each case and there cannot be any rule of universal application. Considering that the acquired plot in this case was situated in a populous locality and was otherwise suitable for construction with water and electricity facilities being available, the deduction of 1/3 + 10% towards conversion charges (more than 43%) could not be stated to be on the lower side.  (1995)5 SCC 426,  (1996)9 SCC 640 - Referred to.  [Para 15]

heading: Acquisition of land
Public purpose
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Public purpose - Broadly speaking it means general interest of community as opposed to interest of an individual - Land and premises were in possession of the State Government for more than 60 years and was used for office of the Dy. Commissioner of Police (Security Control) - Held, it could not be said by any stretch of imagination that no public purpose was involved in acquiring the said premises.

Ambiguity, indefiniteness and vagueness of public purpose are usually the grounds on which notifications under Section 4(1) of the Land Acquisition Act are assailed.

Public purpose cannot and should not be precisely defined and its scope and ambit be limited as far as acquisition of land for the public purpose is concerned.  Public purpose is not static.  It also changes with the passage of time, need and requirements of the community.  Broadly speaking, public purpose means the general interest of the community as opposed to the interest of an individual.

The power of compulsory acquisition as described by the term 'eminent domain' can be exercised only in the interest and for the welfare of the people.  The concept of public purpose should include the matters, such as, safety, security, health, welfare and prosperity of the community or public at large.

The concept of 'eminent domain' is an essential attribute of every State.  This concept is based on the fundamental principle that the interest and claim of the whole community is always superior to the interest of an individual.

Public purpose for which the premises was required in the instant case was not questioned seriously.  As a matter of fact, the State of West Bengal has been using the premises in question for more than six decades for the safety and security of the people by having an office of the Deputy Commissioner of Police (Security Control).  Therefore, by no stretch of imagination, it can be said that the premises was not required by the State Government for the interest and welfare of the people or there was no public purpose involved in acquiring the premises in question. [Para 68,72]

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Compensation - Order of Reference Court enhancing compensation - State seeking reduction of - Maintainability - Onus to justify higher compensation is on claimants - Claimants failing to discharge said onus - State also failing to lead adequate evidence to seek reduction of compensation awarded - Under the circumstances order of Reference Court not interfered with.	(Paras 11, 12, 13)

heading: Compensation
Determination
Comparable sales
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination - Comparable sales - Acquired land more than nine times larger than plot of comparable sale deed - Acquired property was much in the interior at a distance of about 400 to 500 meters away from Kaccha road while comparable sale deed plot was only 100 meters from main road - Acquired property was not developed land while plot of the sale deed was developed plot - Held a total deduction of at least 40% ought to have been made by the Reference Court.			(Para 13)

heading: Compensation
Comparable sales method
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Comparable sales method - Applicant's property was in low lying paddy field situated about 1/2 km. from church and school - No evidence about the depth of the paddy field in relation to property of the sale deed or the road - No evidence as to whether acquired paddy field was capable of development for construction of houses - Held, applicant not having led any cogent and reliable evidence that plot of the sale deed could be compared in any respect with acquired land Reference Court ought to have rejected the reference.		(Para 13)

heading: Acquisition proceedings
Enhancement of compensation
Validity
Upheld.	(Para 6,7,8)
HeadNote.description: Acquisition proceedings - Enhancement of compensation - Validity - Sale instance proximate to time of notification and in respect of land situated one furlong from acquired land - Held, sale instance can be safely relied upon - Enhancement on basis of such sale instance and evidence that lands irrigated, situated in close proximity to road, having lift irrigation facility, having double crop lands - In circumstances, enhancement proper - Upheld.	(Para 6,7,8)

heading: Application for enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Application for enhancement of compensation - Application filed in view of award of Civil Court - Applicant need not file a copy of the award along with the application filed under S.28-A.

Merely because the petitioner has not annexed a copy of the Court award along with his application under section 28A, that by itself cannot be a justification for rejection of his application.  Besides, if such an award is required for perusal by the Collector or necessary for inquiry under sub-section (2) of section 28A, then certainly the Collector could call upon the applicant to produce the copy thereof.  But, merely because the copy of such Court award is not filed along with the application under section 28A, the same cannot be rejected.  The provisions of law contained in section 28A nowhere make it compulsory for the applicant to file any such copy of Court award along with the application itself.			 [Para 7]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of market value - Court has to consider increase in sale price of land in and around acquired land - Development activity around acquired land was going on and there was no evidence to show that there was reduction in price of land - On the contrary evidence showed that there was increasing trend in market value of land in question - Under the circumstance plea raised by State Govt. that Award by Reference Court is based on no evidence - Not tenable more so when Collector himself has assessed market value of land in question.		(Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Acquisition of land
Award of compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Award of compensation - Deduction towards development charges - There cannot be any fixed amount of deduction towards development charges - There cannot be any hard and fast rule as to how much deduction has to be made to account for this factor - It is essentially question of fact depending on the facts and circumstances of each case - It does not involve drawing upon any principle of law. (1988)3 SCC 751 - Rel. on.	(Paras 7, 10)

heading: Reference
Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Reference - Acquisition of land - Determination of market value - Notification issued on 30th April, 1977 - Market value existing at that time will have to be considered for the purpose of assessing market value of acquired area - Claimant is a plaintiff and the Reference is an original proceeding to determine market value afresh - It is for the claimant to produce material evidence for enhancement of the price of acquired land. AIR 1988 SC 1652 and AIR 1984 Orissa 86 - Referred to.			(Paras 10, 12)

heading: Is mandatory
HeadNote.description:
Making of award within two years from last declaration of S.6 notification - Is mandatory - Failure to comply renders acquisition proceedings ab initio void - Reference under S.18 itself cannot be construed as waiver of mandatory requirement under S.11-A.

Section 11-A clearly mandates that the award has necessarily to be passed within a period of two years from the date of publication of the declaration of the notification under Section 6.  This provision is a mandatory provision.  Once requirement of law clearly mandates the authorities to perform any particular act within the specified period and further provides for consequences in case of failure to comply with such mandate, any failure on the part of the authorities to ensure due compliance of the mandate of such provision is bound to result the act done in contravention of such provision to be ab initio void.  When a duty is cast on the public body to perform an act within the specified period, such duty has to be performed within the specified period and such provision is to be construed as mandatory, and more so when the consequences for failure to comply such duty are also provided under the provision of law.  (2003)10 SCC 1 Rel. on.  [Para 11]

Undoubtedly, the general rule that the non-compliance of mandatory requirements results in nullification of the act is subject to one exception and the exception is that the requirement or conditions of that mandate may be waived by the person for whose interest the condition or requirement is provided for. It is primarily the duty of the Land Acquisition Officer to ensure strict compliance of the period of two years for the purpose of making of award under Section 11 from the date of last declaration of notification under Section 6.  Undoubtedly, such obligation is cast upon the Land Acquisition Officer from the point of view of protecting the interest of the parties whose land is sought to be acquired.  Being so, though it could be argued that the persons for whose benefit the mandatory limit of two years is prescribed under Section 11-A would be entitled to waive such requirement or condition prescribed under Section 11-A, it is difficult to accept the contention on behalf of the Government that the reference under Section 18 itself would amount to such a waiver.  [Para 12,13]

The scope of the reference being limited, to the four grounds specified in Section 18, and upon mere invocation of right to challenge the award on those four grounds, certainly, it cannot be said that a party seeking to exercise it's right under Section 18 would waive his rights under Section 11-A.  It is well settled law that waiver has to be clear and specific.  It cannot be by mere implication.  Besides, there is no estoppel against law.  Considering all these aspects, the contention that, reference under Section 18 would amount to waiver of right under Section 11-A, cannot be accepted.  [Para 14]

heading: Word "Protest" found in second proviso to S.31(2)
HeadNote.description:
Word "Protest" found in second proviso to S.31(2) - A wider meaning will have to be given to the word "Protest" - It can be lodged in different forms either by specifically recording such protest at the time of acceptance of money or even by lodging an application for enhancement of compensation under S.18 or even orally intimating the authorities that he is not satisfied with the compensation awarded at the time of disbursement of the amount by the Collector under S.31(1) of the said Act.

The second proviso to Section 31(2) uses the expression "who has received the amount otherwise than under protest".  Admittedly, the word "protest" has not been defined in the said Act. Undisputedly, the statutory provisions do not prescribe any specific mode of lodging the protest at the time of collecting the compensation awarded by the Land Acquisition Officer. Therefore, it cannot be said that the protest contemplated under the said proviso is necessarily by way of specific recording in writing about the protest in the receipt issued by the interested person while accepting the compensation. Considering the phraseology of Section 18 and 28-A of the said Act, a wider meaning will have to be given to the word "protest" to be found in the second proviso to sub-section (2) of Section 31.  Being so, the protest will have to be understood to be an act on the part of the interested person which will disclose his dissatisfaction about the compensation awarded by the Land Acquisition Officer.  It can be lodged in different forms either by specifically recording such protest at the time of acceptance of money or even by lodging an application for enhancement of compensation under Section 18 or even orally intimating the authorities that he is not satisfied with the compensation awarded at the time of disbursement of the amount by the Collector under Section 31(1) of the said Act.  In case of such an oral intimation, it will be the duty of the compensation disbursing officer to note such protest in the records relating to the payment of compensation for the land acquired.  Bearing in mind the number of illiterate people in the country and taking judicial notice of the bureaucratic red-tapism and carelessness prevailing almost in every public office, the principle that ignorance of law is no excuse should not be allowed to be stretched to such an extent that it can be a tool in the hands of the authorities to deny the statutory right in relation to the compensation to the owners whose properties are acquired. Otherwise, it may result in encouraging the acts to defeat the very purpose of Article 300-A of the Constitution of India. The provisions of the Act cannot be read and understood by ignoring the mandate of Article 300-A of the Constitution of India.  Viewed from this angle, therefore, merely because in the records of the Government there does not find any endorsement by the interested parties that they had received the amount of compensation under protest, it cannot be presumed that the interested parties were satisfied or were not aggrieved by the compensation awarded by the Land Acquisition Officer even though they had filed their application expressing desire for enhancement of the compensation, and it could have been concluded by the Collector that the Collector was entitled to reject the application under Section 18. 1986 Mh.L.J.181 and 2002(1) ALL MR 27 - Referred to.   [Para 12]

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - In matters of land acquisition - Reference Court enhanced compensation ranging between Rs.520/- and Rs.7670/- to land-losers in 1997-98 - State filed appeals in 1999 and application for condonation of delay to set aside abatement and leave to bring LRs of deceased land-losers on record, almost after 2 years in 2001 - Matters are pending for last 20 years in Court from date of acquisition in 1974-75, due to lack of diligence of State in effecting service or in taking steps to bring on record LRs of land-losers - Only to deprive land-losers of meager compensation, State and Court have spent enormous amount of money and time - Applications for condonation of delay and consequently appeals themselves are liable to be dismissed.			(Paras 16, 17)

heading: Reference
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Reference - Enhancement of compensation - Right of acquiring body - Acquiring body is certainly entitled to notice and right to participate in proceedings before the reference court leading to enhancement of compensation. AIR 2002 SC 817 - Followed.		(Para 7)

heading: Claim for enhancement
HeadNote.description: Claim for enhancement - Land falling in command area - Acquiring Society itself purchasing land at only a furlong away at higher rate - Land having non-agricultural potentially - Reasons given by Trial Court for refusing enhancement, not proper - Enhancement granted.	(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: District Judge enhancing compensation to Rs.150/- per sq. mtr. relying on sale deed dated 8-2-1989 of a plot of land in nearby survey number
HeadNote.description:
District Judge enhancing compensation to Rs.150/- per sq. mtr. relying on sale deed dated 8-2-1989 of a plot of land in nearby survey number - Appeals filed by both parties - Held, where evidence of value of acquired land itself is available on record, it is unnecessary to travel beyond that evidence and consider market value prevalent in adjacent lands - When owner himself has purchased the land under acquisition, consideration mentioned in the sale deed would form basis to determine market value.

The need to take into consideration the value of the land adjacent to the acquired land or near about the area which possessed the same potentiality to work out the prices fetched therein for determination of market value of the acquired land would arise only when there is no evidence of the value of the acquired land.  In a case where the evidence of the value of the acquired land itself is available on record, it is unnecessary to travel beyond that evidence and consider the market value prevailing in the adjacent lands.  When the owner himself had purchased the land under acquisition, the consideration mentioned in the sale deed would form the basis to determine the market value.  The market price of the land of the applicant was available on record and not only that the said applicant had even put up its land for sale and being so the Reference Court ought to have assessed the market value of the acquired land based on the price mentioned in the sale deed by which the applicant had purchased the same and then by giving consequential increase which is now widely accepted to be 10% per year.  The said increase at 10% over Rs.32/- works out to Rs.44/- per sq.m.  This shall now be the compensation payable to the said applicant with other consequential statutory benefits.	 [Para 10,11]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Large extent of land notified for acquisition for planned development of industries - Rate of Rs.2/- per square yard fixed by LAO - Even after noticing the potentialities LAO fixed price treating land as agricultural - Held having regard to facts found and reasons recorded High Court could not be said to have erred in fixing enhancement to Rs.8/- and 9/- per sq. yard considering nature and location of land.	(Para 5)

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Compensation - Land acquired may be having high potential or may be proximate to developed land - But that by itself cannot be claimed to be a developed land - Lot of development activities would be required to be undertaken like laying of roads, sewerage facility, water supply etc. which may require enormous amount of expenditure - Hence deduction of development charges would be necessary.	(Para 7)

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Compensation agreed upon between parties - No necessity for Collector to hold enquiry as to market value of acquired land - Collector entitled to award compensation as per agreement - No necessity to make reference - Same can be declined.

Holding of an enquiry under sub-section (1) of section 11 is dispensed with if the parties have agreed to the matters which are required to be decided by the Collector after holding enquiry under sub-section (1) of Section 11 and enter into a written agreement to that effect.  One of the things which is required to be agreed by the parties is the compensation to be paid for the acquired land.  If the compensation is agreed upon by the parties, it is not necessary for the Collector to hold an enquiry as to what would be the market value of the land on the date of issuance of notification, but the Collector would be entitled to award compensation in accordance with the agreement between the parties.  Consequently, there would be no necessity of making a reference to the District Court under S.18 for determination of the compensation for the acquired lands where the award is passed on the basis of an agreement passed under sub-section (2) of section 11 of the Act.  When a person enters into an agreement under section 11(2), the award cannot be regarded as an offer which may or may not be accepted by the person whose land is acquired because he has entered into an agreement regarding the amount of compensation.  The Collector would therefore be right in declining to make a reference under S.18 of the Act where the award is based upon an agreement made under S.11(2) of the Act.  [Para 7]

heading: Compensation
Comparable sale-deeds
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Comparable sale-deeds - One sale-deed of a small plot but nearer in time and the other sale-deed nearly three years prior to preliminary notification - Both the sale-deeds can be taken into consideration by making appropriate adjustments.	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Acquisition of land for benefit of school - Tenant in possession of part of said land raising objection to acquisition - State Government issued Notification denotifying part of land in possession of tenant from acquisition - Notification in respect of rest of the land remains intact - Order of High Court quashing acquisition in respect of remaining land is liable to be set-aside.			(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Acquisition of land
Application seeking reference
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Application seeking reference - Court fee not paid alongwith reference - It is not fatal - Time could be granted to owner to pay Court fee - Rejection of application by Collector on that ground is unfair and liable to be quashed.

Where the petitioners land owners have shown their willingness to pay the Court fee and are not disputing their liability to pay the Court fee, it would be just and fair to grant the petitioners some time to pay the Court fees as the Reference Applications cannot be rejected by the Collector without granting reasonable time to the petitioners to pay the Court fees.  In the facts and circumstances of the present cases, the order passed by the Collector rejecting the reference applications on the ground that the Court fees has not been paid along with the application under Section 18, is unjust and unfair and hence, it is required to be quashed and set aside.  1996(1) Mh.L.J. 652, 2003(1) ALL MR 27 - Relied on.  [Para 6]

heading: Land acquisition
Comparable sale instance
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Fixation of market value - Comparable sale instance - Claimant himself selling adjacent plot just about a year before the date of notification under S.4 of the Act issued in respect of the subject land - Such a sale instance being a comparable sale instance, cannot be discarded while fixing market value of the acquired land.	(Para 12)

heading: Interference with
HeadNote.description: Companies Act (1956), Ss.591, 617 - Authority to initiate proposal for acquisition of land - Interference with - Existence of public purpose for acquisition of land - Absence of serious prejudice caused to the petitioner/owner of the land - The acquisition proceedings could not be said to have been vitiated - Held, no interference is warranted in exercise of extraordinary writ jurisdiction under Art.226 of the Constitution of India. Constitution of India, Art.226. 2009(5) SCC 242, 2003 AIR SCW 4372 and 2009 ALL SCR 731 - Ref. to.	(Paras 46 and 47)

heading: Proceedings under Act
HeadNote.description: Proceedings under Act - Provisions of Civil P.C. apply to proceedings before court under Act in terms of S.53 of Act - Reference under S.18 to civil court - On date fixed for hearing applicant and counsel absent - Reference dismissed by judgment and order - Dismissal is for failure to adduce evidence - Order cannot be taken to be an adjudication and hence cannot be treated to be award - Dismissal also cannot be treated as dismissal in default - Appeal against such order does not lie under S.54 of Act - Hence remedy of revision is available to claimant - Revision is maintainable in the case. 	(Paras 7, 9)

heading: Market value
Determination of
Agricultural land
Acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Determination of - Agricultural land - Acquisition - Claimant not producing sale deeds of sale instances which would be nearer and earlier to date of publication of S.4 notification - Adverse inference can be drawn against him - Award passed by Reference court in instant case held perfectly legal and correct.

Evidence Act (1872), S.114(g). (Para 8)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Suit for partition decreed - Land Acquisition Officer including the land of the petitioner in acquisition proceedings even though his land was less than eight acres - Authorities directed to delete holding of the petitioner after partition from acquisition proceedings as his land was less than eight acres.			(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Notification for acquisition
HeadNote.description: Notification for acquisition - Subsequent compromise between parties stipulating conditions in Memorandum of Settlement one of them being deposit of compensation within time schedule - Failure to deposit compensation by State due to intervening circumstances viz. stay for execution by High Court etc. - Acquisition cannot be set aside in terms of Memorandum of Settlement - Extension of time for deposit of compensation granted by High Court not improper.	(Paras 12, 13, 14)

heading: Declaration for acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Declaration for acquisition - Report of LAO in favour of land owner - Land owner had already built residence, swimming pool and boundary wall prior to notification under S.4 - Government acquiring land without considering the report of Collector - Process of acquisition, held tainted with malefides and liable to be set aside. 
2012 ALL SCR 370, 2013 ALL SCR 1689, 2013 ALL SCR 1689 Rel.on.(Para 11)

heading: Award passed relying on judgment of Apex Court not interfered with by High Court
HeadNote.description: Award passed relying on judgment of Apex Court not interfered with by High Court - Relied on judgment subsequently set aside by Apex Court - Order of High Court set aside and matter remanded for fresh disposal.	(Para 3)

heading: Benefit of S.28-A
HeadNote.description:
Re-determination of amount of compensation - Benefit of S.28-A - who can claim.

The benefit of Section 28-A is available only to the parties who had not sought reference under Section 18 of the Act for enhancement of the compensation. This provision is not available to persons who seek for reference under Section 18 of the Act for enhancement of the compensation and do not challenge judgment of the reference Court or the judgment of the High Court thereafter. (1991)1 SCC 174 Rel.on.	  [Para 12]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - On relevant date acquired land had wide frontage of highway - Land was in close proximity of National Highway - Land was situated in Municipal Corporation limits - As per development plan land is in residential zone - Lands in sale instances are not close to highway, lacking basic amenities - Acquired land, lands in sale instances must be treated as urban lands - Escalation must be calculated on cumulative basis at rate of 15% per annum - Portion of acquired land abutting highway has to be kept open - Market value of acquired land cannot be doubled than lands in sale instances - 50% of market value of lands in sale instance must be added - Deduction on account of development cost, would be 20%. 
2011 ALL SCR 1526, 2008(6) ALL MR 491 (S.C.), 1997 (6) SCC 59 Ref. to. 			(Paras 13, 16, 18, 19)

heading: Acquisition of land
Public purpose
What is
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Public purpose - What is - Constructing memorials of national heroes - Is undoubtedly a public purpose.

In the instant case, the contention is that land to be acquired for erecting memorial of Dr. Kotnis is not public purpose.  The great deeds of the great Doctor are well known throughout the country.  To say erection of a memorial of such a great man is not a public purpose is in fact, an insult to great memories of the Doctor.  Constructing memorials of National Heroes is undoubtedly a public purpose and this contention also is therefore rejected.

Then it is the contention of the learned counsel for the petitioner that in Solapur there already exist four memorials of Dr. Kotnis, creating fifth one is not necessary no can it be a public purpose.  The four memorials that exist are in the name of Dr. Kotnis created by someone else.  If the municipal corporation itself was to create memorial for Dr. Kotnis it cannot be said that it is not necessary.  There is therefore no substance in the contention of the petitioner that the acquisition proceedings are liable to be quashed.  [Para 2,4]

heading: Reference
Enhanced compensation
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Reference - Enhanced compensation - Claim for - Co-owner is entitled to benefit of enhanced compensation given to other co-owners though was barred by limitation. AIR 1991 SC 1966 Rel.on.	(Para 5)

heading: Scope
Enhanced interest
Entitlement
HeadNote.description: Scope - Enhanced interest - Entitlement - Award passed after Amendment Act, 1984 came into force - Claimant whether disentitled to enhanced interest - In 1995(1) SCC 367 a three Judge Bench taking a view contrary to Constitution Bench case in 1989(2) SCC 754 - Matter directed to be referred to a larger Bench.			(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Necessary and proper party
HeadNote.description: Necessary and proper party - Impleadment for complete adjudication of claim - Procedure prescribed under the Act is inconsistent with procedure under O.1, R.10 - Order allowing application of respondent to allow him as a party as he had some interest in property acquired set aside - He can pursue independent remedies if his rights are affected.	(Paras 5, 7)

heading: Compensation
Market value
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Market value - Determination of - Acquired plot was purchased by claimant for Rs.45,000/- a year earlier - State had offered compensation of Rs.1,30,680/- which the reference Court enhanced to Rs.2,17,800/- - Held there was no basis whatsoever to enhance compensation to Rs.2,17,800/-. (1975)2 SCC 730, (2005)12 SCC 59, (1994)2 SCC 133, (1991)4 SCC 195 - Rel. on.	(Para 12)

heading: Determination of Compensation
Agricultural tenanted lands
HeadNote.description:
Goa Land Use (Regulation) Act (1991) - Goa, Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964) - Determination of Compensation - Agricultural tenanted lands - Held, compensation in respect of agricultural tenanted lands cannot be fixed on the basis of building potential of such lands - It can only be valued on the basis of the yield.

2005(3) ALL MR 824 - Rel. On. (Para 8)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Determination of market value of acquired land - Increase in value of land - Application of principle of 12 percent increase per year in the land value by taking recourse to scheme of S.23(1-A) of the Act - Held, no reason to take a different view, more so when instant appeals also arise from the very same notification and also the land in the very same gat number.	(Para 5)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of market value of acquired land - Assistance of valuer can be sought therefor - Alternatively, sale instances of comparable lands in the neighbourhood at or about the date of notification u/s.4 can be taken into consideration. 2005 AIR SCW 2107 - Rel. on.	(Paras 6, 9, 11, 12)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Acquired land forming part and parcel of the land allotted to the Respondents - Respondents, therefore, entitled to receive compensation. (Paras 6, 7)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Section is enacted for benefit of poor, illiterate, ignorant and inarticulate people - Benefit of section cannot be extended to a person who prefers S.18 reference. (1995)2 SCC 733, AIR 1995 SC 2259, (1995)2 SCC 766, 2009 ALL SCR 674 - Rel. on.	(Para 14)

heading: Land acquisition proceedings
Compensation
Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition proceedings - Compensation - Enhancement of - Reference Court recording positive findings in favour of the claimants - However, compensation was not enhanced sufficiently - In appeal, court directed for enhancement of compensation along with interest and other consequential benefits as granted by the reference court.		(Paras 17, 18)

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Structures on land to be acquired - Appellant contending that lands of others with similar structures were left out - High Court not finding merit in the case - Appeal - Supreme Court directing respondent State to exclude land with structures unless required for purposes of road, hospital and other civic amenities and also make available more land if possible on payment of price and development charges as is charged from other allottees.	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Land Acquisition
Urgency
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition - Urgency - Time elapsed between publication of S.4(1) and S.17 notifications was more than one year - Invoking urgency clause under S.17(4) was improper - Supreme Court directed that if so advised, Government can initiate acquisition proceeding by following the provision of Section 5-A - Impugned notifications of acquisition quashed.			(Paras 37 to 41)

heading: Compensation
Foll.		(Paras 6, 7)
HeadNote.description: Compensation - High Court enhancing compensation from Rs.23/- per sq. ft. to Rs.32/- per sq. ft. - Same cannot be denied to claimants on the mere technical ground that claimants had restricted their claim to Rs.23/- due to their inability to pay Court fee - Opportunity must be given to pay deficit Court Fee. (1985)3 SCC 737 - Foll.		(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Determination of compensation
Sale deed
HeadNote.description:
Determination of compensation - Best evidence of value of property - Sale deed - In absence of sale deed relating to acquired land, sale transactions relating to neighbouring lands have to be taken into consideration - Undoubtedly, such transactions must be within a reasonable time of the date of notification and preferably before such date, transactions must be bona fide and it should be a sale of land similar to the land acquired or land adjacent to land acquired.

The best evidence of the value of property are the sale transactions in respect of the acquired land or the neighbouring land; the time at which the property comes to be sold; the purpose for which it is sold; nature of the consideration; and the manner in which the transaction came to be brought out, are also relevant factors. In the absence of sale deed relating to the acquired land, the sale transactions relating to the neighbouring lands have to be taken into consideration. Undoubtedly, such transactions must be within a reasonable time of the date of the notification and preferably before such date, the transactions must be bona fide and it should be a sale of the land similar to the land acquired or land adjacent to the land acquired.  [Para 8]

heading: Market value
Comparable sale instances
HeadNote.description: Market value - Comparable sale instances - High Court taking into consideration five sale instances cited by claimants but not two instances cited by acquiring authority wherein they themselves had offered Rs.80,000/- per bigha - This offer was for consolidated amount and was refused by claimants - Held all instances ought to have been taken into consideration and deduction of 33-1/3 % ought to have been made because sale instances were for small pieces of lands.	(Para 5)

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Compensation - Acquisition proceedings not pending before Collector on 30-4-1982 since award was made on 7-4-1981 - Claimants not entitled to additional compensation as entitlement of additional amount provided under S.23(1-A) depends upon pendency of acquisition proceedings as on 30-4-1982 or commencement of acquisition proceedings after that date. (1990)1 SCC 277 and (2002)2 SCC 605 - Followed.			(Para 3)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Additional amount under S.23(1-A) - Cannot be calculated on solatium payable under S.23(2).

While market value and compensation are factors to be assessed and determined by the court, no such judicial exercise is involved in regard to additional amount payable under Section 23(1-A) and solatium payable under Section 23(2) as they are statutory benefits payable automatically at the rates specified in those sub-sections, qua the market price. No reasons need be assigned for grant of additional amount or solatium. Hence additional amount under Section 23(1-A) is awardable only on the market value determined under the first factor of Section 23(1) of the Act and cannot be calculated on the solatium payable under Section 23(2) of the Act.   [Para 4,9]

heading: Market value
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination of - Three sale deeds from same locality but in respect of bagayat land - Dates of sale deeds were near about the date of S.4 notification - Market value of bagayat land is generally double than that of jirayat land also depending upon other factors like location near to highway or to the Gavthan - Compensation awarded at the rate of Rs.25,000/- per Hector raised to Rs.40,000/- per Hector. 2006(5) ALL MR 491 - Ref. to.	(Paras 6, 7, 8)

heading: Acquisition of land
Bar under S.2
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Bar under S.2 - Acquired land tenanted and agricultural - Compensation payable in respect of the acquired land - No cogent evidence led by the appellant in respect of income from agriculture - Held, in view of bar created under S.2 of the Goa Land Use (Regulation) Act, building potential of acquired land cannot be considered for determining the compensation. AIR 1988 SC 1652 and AIR 1998 SC 700 - Referred to.	(Para 8)

heading: Challenge as to
Not justified
