HeadNote.description: Compulsory acquisition of Land - Challenge as to - Reason given for compulsory acquisition becoming non-existant - Development plan modified and appropriate authority changed from respondent trust to petitioner trust and thus reason for compulsory acquisition for benefit of respondent trust ceased to exist - Secondary as result of cancellation of grant, no grant for purpose of building is paid by Govt. to Respondent trust - Therefore no part of compensation to be paid for acquiring land is going to be paid from public fund and there will be no public purpose for acquiring land - Petitioner itself being public trust running school on adjacent site to suit site - Acquisition of suit site for establishing another school - Not justified - Compulsory acquisition of land - Set aside.			(Paras 4, 5, 6)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Market value determined by reference Court held improper by High Court - Landowners offering to accept reduction of 75% of said market value - Considering long lapse of time of about 20 years Court directed to accept said offer.			(Paras 10, 13)

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Compensation - Acquiring body sending a proposal to Government that on negotiation the price is settled at Rs.50,000/- per acre and that Government should make a provision for that - The acquiring body thereafter cannot resile from this position, consequently the Government cannot resile from it - Claimant agreeing not to claim any compensation in respect of well - Held, no separate compensation was payable to claimant in respect of the well.	(Para 9)

heading: Land acquisition
Dereservation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Dereservation - Until Notification under S.6 is issued within six months, it could not be said that any step is taken towards acquisition.	(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Proviso is mandatory
HeadNote.description:
Proviso is mandatory - Declaration made after expiry of one year from date of publication of S.4(1) notification would be void and of no effect.

The proviso appended to sub-section (1) of Section 6 is in the negative term.  It is, therefore, mandatory in nature.  Any declaration made after the expiry of one year from the date of the publication of the notification under sub-section (1) of Section 4 would be void and of no effect.  An enabling provision has been made  by reason of the explanation appended thereto, but the same was done only for the purpose of extending the period of limitation and not for any other purpose.  The purport and object of the provisions of the Act and in particular the proviso which had been inserted by Act 68 of 1984 and which came into force w.e.f. 24.09.1984 must be given its full effect.  The said provision was inserted for the benefit of the owners of land. The period which is required to be excluded would be one,  during which the action or proceeding taken was subjected to any order of stay passed by a competent court of law.  [Para 14,17]

heading: Market value
Determination
Rel. on.			(Paras 8-11)
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination - Factors to be considered - Appellant not producing even a single sale instance in support but relying on judgments in LARs. - In these LARs. lands were acquired for National Highway and for canal - In this case acquisition is for Sub-Market Yard - Further material relied on in LARs. is required to be produced and proved - Damages for crops for three years could not be allowed as appellant has not produced any evidence in support - Held, no interference was required with award passed. A.I.R. 1988 S.C. 1652 - Rel. on.			(Paras 8-11)

heading: Entitlement
HeadNote.description: Solatium and additional benefits - Entitlement - Relevant date is date of award by Collector - Award passed on 7.11.1972 i.e. earlier to relevant date viz. 30.4.1982 - No enhancement of compensation made in reference in excess of award by collector - Awardee is not entitled to additional compensation and benefits under Ss.23(1-A) and 28. (1990)1 SCC 277, 2002(2) ALL MR 630 (S.C.), JT 1995(9) SC 1 - Foll.	(Para 9)

heading: Acquisition of land
Claim of compensation
Parity
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Claim of compensation - Parity - Lands situated in same village, acquired for same purpose under same notification - Claimants are entitled to compensation at the same rate on ground of parity. 2003 AIR SCW 5188 - Ref. to. 			(Para 5)

heading: Acquisition of land
Parity
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Determination of market value for acquired land - Parity - Lands situated in same village, acquired for same purpose under same notification - Claimants entitled to compensation at the same rate on ground of parity - Perennial irrigated land has more market value than seasonally irrigated land. 2007(2) ALL MR 316 - Ref. to.	(Paras 10, 14, 15)

heading: Market value
Determination
Agricultural land
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination - Agricultural land - Factors to be taken into consideration - Transactions immediately preceeding or succeeding would afford a good guidance - In view such sale deeds produced and proved compensation awarded at Rs.150 per guntha raised to Rs.10,000/- per acre along with statutory benefits as per Amended provisions of the Act. AIR 1988 S.C. 1652 - Rel. on.	(Paras 8, 10)

heading: Reference
Adjudication of calculation
HeadNote.description: Reference - Adjudication of calculation - Remand of matter to trial Court - Dispute as to calculation - Held, the proper adjudication of dispute can only be made by remanding the matter to the District Court, who will give opportunity to both the sides to put up their respective cases with regard to the modalities and methodology, regarding calculations and objections raised by respective parties in that regard.			(Para 6)

heading: Application u/s. 28A(1)
Limitation
Application for redetermination
HeadNote.description: Application u/s. 28A(1) - Limitation - Application for redetermination - Benefit of redetermination can be availed of on basis of any one of the awards made by the court after coming into force of S.28-A - Right to apply for re-determination is not confined to the earliest award made by the court - Contention that period of limitation for filing an application u/s.28-A(1) has to be computed from the Award which is earliest in point of time cannot be accepted. (1995) 2 SCC 689 Overruled by and (1995) 2 SCC 736.	(Paras 8 & 4)

heading: Land acquisition proceedings
Limitation
Reference
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition proceedings - Limitation - Reference - Limitation is mixed question of law and fact - For this purpose, evidence has to be furnished by both parties in support of their respective contentions. (2005)6 SCC 614 - Ref. to.	(Para 7)

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Non-payment of court fees - Petitioner claimant complied with conditions under S.18 - SLAO to pass conditional order by granting time to pay court fees and forward Reference to Civil Court - Order rejecting Reference for non-payment of court fees is liable to be set aside. 1996(1) Mh.L.J. 652, 2003(2) Mh.L.J. 661 - Rel. on. 2004(1) LACC 326 - Ref. to.	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Vesting of acquired land in Government
HeadNote.description: Vesting of acquired land in Government - Vesting takes place as soon as possession is taken by Collector after passing an award under S.11 - Vesting of land under S.16 of the Act presupposes actual taking of possession and till that is done, legal presumption of vesting enshrined in S.16 cannot be raised in favour of the acquiring authority. (1976)1 SCC 700 and (2005)12 SCC 489 - Ref. to.	(Para 11)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Award passed relying upon agreement entered into prior to Section 4 notification cannot be treated as a consent award under Section 11(2) - Owners of land if not satisfied with quantum of compensation awarded can seek reference to Civil Court under Section 18.

A consent award under Section 11(2) of the Act can be made by the Collector on being satisfied that all the persons interested in the land who appeared before him have agreed in writing on the matters to be included in the award only where such agreement has been entered into by the persons interested in the land after the proceedings are initiated under the Land Acquisition Act i.e., after the notification under Section 4(1) of the Act is published.   [Para 11]

In the case on hand, admittedly the petitioners agreed to receive the compensation at the rate of Rs.90,000/- per acre when the advance possession of the land was taken on 10.12.2003. Long thereafter the notification under Section 4(1) of the Act was published on 18.4.2005. Hence, it is not open to the Collector to rely upon such agreement entered into prior to notification while passing the impugned award.   [Para 12]

Consequently, the impugned award cannot be treated as a consent award under sub-section (2) of Section 11 of the Act. Hence, the petitioners if not satisfied with the quantum of compensation awarded can seek reference to Civil Court under Section 18 of the Act.						 [Para 13]

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
Comparable sale instances
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Compensation - Comparable sale instances - Sale instance taken into consideration was for a period before issue of notice u/s.4 - State leading no cogent evidence to differentiate compensation either on ground of comparability or admissibility of sale instances - Grant of compensation @ Rs.10/- per sq. mt. by Reference Court, held, proper.

In the instance case, relying on an earlier sale instance the Reference Court granted Rs.10/- per sq. mt. as compensation payable to claimants.  The said sale instance was prior to the date of S.4 notification.

Moreover, the State did not lead any cogent evidence before the Reference Court so as to differentiate the compensation either on the ground of comparability or admissibility of the sale instances as well as the judgments of other Reference Courts during the trial of present land acquisition reference.

Hence, the State now cannot take advantage of its own errors and claim that the evidence has not been correctly appreciated by the Reference Court.

It is settled principle of law and statutory obligation is placed on the Reference Court to determine adequate and fair market value of the acquired land in terms of Section 23 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894. The Court cannot also lose sight of the fact that these are compulsive acquisitions of lands and not voluntary sale of lands effected by the owners in favour of the State. Certain amount of latitude is to be given without imbalancing the settled principles of law.  [Para 2,3,5,7]

heading: Rejection of
HeadNote.description: Reference made by Collector under S.18 - Rejection of - A reference can be rejected not only on point of limitation set out under S.18(2) of the Act, but also if it is not in accordance with S.18(1) of the Act.  2009(1) Mh.L.J. 856 and AIR 1979 SC 404 - Ref. to. 		(Para 18)

heading: Compensation
Comparable instances
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of market value - Comparable instances - Held, comparable instances have to be identified on the following considerations (i) proximity from time angle, (ii) proximity from situation angle. AIR 1992 S.C. 2298 - Ref. to. 	(Para 5)

heading: Acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition - Non-passing of award within limitation of two years under S.11-A - Only if any action or proceedings is stayed the period of stay would extend said period of limitation - However, time taken in supply of copy of judgment cannot extend said period of limitation under S.11A.

1996 (3) SCC 88 and (2002) 3 SCC 533 Foll.		(Paras 10 to 12)

heading: Government exempting petitioner's land from acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Government exempting petitioner's land from acquisition - Any withdrawal of such exemption cannot be effected without giving opportunity of hearing to the petitioner.

Section 48 of the Act confers powers on State Government to withdraw from acquisition of any land of which possession has not been taken.  Sub-section (2) of S.48 of the Act provides for compensation for damage suffered by land owner on ground of any notice or proceeding under the Act and sub-section (3) thereof provides for determination of compensation.  Undoubtedly land acquisition relates to taking over land of land owner.  It relates to immovable property and it also provides for payment of compensation with regard to acquired land.  In the circumstances any proceeding relating to title of land and its compensation would have civil consequences as it would relate to rights of the parties.  In that view of the matter opportunity is a must.  						 [Para 14]

heading: Determination of compensation
Development charges
Deduction for
HeadNote.description: Determination of compensation - Development charges - Deduction for - Land sought to be acquired was within municipal limits - Deduction at the rate of 53% would be on the higher side and it should not be more than 33-1/3%. (1996)2 SCC 62, 2003(1) ALL MR 755 (S.C.), 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 369 - Rel. on.	(Para 12)

heading: Determination of market value of acquired land
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value of acquired land - Award of compensation passed in respect of acquisition of lands made in same village and/or neighbouring villages - Award could be relied upon in absence of any other evidence like deed of sale, report of expert and other relevant evidence - However, the same would have only evidentiary value. (2005)6 SCC 454 - Ref. to. 	(Para 10)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of market value - Proximity of land near Highway, assumes importance in deciding market value of the land.	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Reference
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Reference - Limitation - Has to be computed having regard to date on which claimants get knowledge of declaration of award either actual or constructive - Claimants coming to know of declaration of award only when compensation was being paid to them - Application filed within six months from date of knowledge - Is not barred by limitation.	(Para 7)

heading: Interest on solatium
HeadNote.description: Interest on solatium - Payability is to be considered based on decision in Gurpreet Singh Vs. Union of India, 2007(5) ALL MR 475 (S.C.) - Matter remitted to High Court.		(Para 6)

heading: Valuable right
HeadNote.description:
Right to file objection under Section 5-A - Valuable right - Dispensation of, by invoking power u/S.17(4), for dire need of decongestion of traffic - Master Plan already prepared, approved by Planning Board and out of a sum of Rs.20.65 crores sanctioned for widening of National Highway into four lanes, Rs.17.42 crores already spent - In light of facts, it cannot be said that invoking power was for ulterior purpose or was arbitrary exercise of power - No reason to interfere with order passed by Division Bench of High Court - Appeal dismissed.

There is no gainsaying the fact that this right to file objection under Section 5-A is a valuable right and the Governments are not given a free hand to dispense with Section 5-A.  Section 5-A is only a safeguard against the arbitrary exercise of the power by the State.  But one should also not lose sight of the fact that invocation of such a provision is also sometimes imperative as in order to meet the urgency of the situation it needs to be invoked in public interest.  It depends upon case to case.  Sometimes it may not be necessary at all and the State functionaries may sometimes out of over zealousness may invoke this provision which would seriously jeopardize the interest of the people.  Therefore, it depends upon case to case whether in a given situation Section 5-A has been correctly invoked and the authorities were satisfied in an objective manner.  In the present case, there are no two opinions that because of the globalization of economy Indian economy is progressing with fast speed, therefore in order to keep pace with the speed, invocation of Section 5-A has become imperative.  Traffic congestion is a common experience of one and all and it is very difficult to negotiate with the traffic congestion in Delhi and National Capital region.  Therefore, in the present situation, it cannot be said that the invocation of Section 5-A was for ulterior purpose or was arbitrary exercise of the power.  Since the Master Plan has already been prepared and it has been approved by the Planning Board and they have sanctioned a sum of Rs.20.65 crores for the development of this Transport Nagar and widening of the National Highway No.91 into four lanes.  Therefore, the proposal was approved by the Board and it got the sanction from the National Capital Region Planning Board and ultimately the Government invoked the power under Section 17(4) read with Section 5-A of the Act dispensing with the objections.  In the light of these facts it cannot be said that invoking of power was in any way improper exercise.  There is need for decongestion of the traffic and it is really the dire need of the hour and earliest it is implemented, better for the people at large.  (1997)9 SCC 78, (1993)2 SCC 84 - Rel. on.						 [Para 4]

heading: Acquisition of land
Inquiry under S.5-A
Objections
Personal hearing
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Inquiry under S.5-A - Objections - Personal hearing - An inquiry under S.5-A without hearing the objectors, in case where the objections are filed within the period of limitation, would be bad-in-law and would vitiate the proceedings - However, when the objections are filed beyond the period of limitation prescribed under the statute, there is no obligation upon the authorities to grant personal hearing to such objector.

Certainly an inquiry under Section 5-A without hearing the objectors, in case where the objections are filed within the period of limitation, would be bad-in-law and would vitiate the proceedings.  However, when the objectors are filed beyond the period of limitation prescribed under the statute, there is no obligation upon the authorities to grant personal hearing to such objections.  As regards the second contention that even though the objections were filed beyond the period of limitation, it was necessary for the authorities to consider the same before submitting the report, even without giving personal hearing to the parties, it is to be seen that in such cases it would be entirely in the discretion of the concerned authorities to consider such objections.  Only in a case when the objections are relevant to decide the issue as to whether the acquisition is for the public purpose or not, certainly the authorities would be empowered to consider such objections in their discretion but not as an obligation. Assuming that there is any lapse on the part of the authorities in considering such objections, that cannot create any right in favour of the party, whose objections filed beyond the period of limitation are not considered, to seek a writ of mandamus directing the authorities to consider his objection.  In other to seek such a direction, the party seeking such a relief must have right in his favour and there must be failure on the part of the authorities in performance of their obligation.  As already seen above, there is no obligation cast upon the authorities to consider such objections once they are found to have been filed beyond the period of limitation.	 [Para 3,4]

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Power of Reference court - Claim of appellant that there was no delay in making application under S.18 of the Act accepted by Division Bench of High Court - Finding in earlier proceedings between the same parties in relation to the same award will be binding on the respondents - It was therefore, not open to Reference Court to hold to the contrary. 1996 Mh.L.J. 609 - Referred to.	(Para 8)

heading: Acquisition of land
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Challenge to - Land reserved for public amenity - Land acquired after following procedure under the Land Acquisition Act - Belated challenge to the acquisition proceedings cannot be accepted in exercise of discretionary jurisdiction under Art.226 of Constitution of India.	(Para 7)

heading: Acquisition of rights
HeadNote.description: Urban Land (Ceiling and Regulation) Act (1976) - Transfer of excess lands - Acquisition of rights - Permissions from Urban Land Ceiling Authorities - Permissions required to be taken only with regard to transfer of excess lands under Urban Land Ceiling and (Regulation) Act - This has nothing to do with the authorities under Land Revenue Code which entitles the State Government itself to be reported of the acquisition of rights.	(Para 10)

heading: Prayer for denotifying land
HeadNote.description:
Prayer for denotifying land - Lands acquired for housing purposes - No progress made even after lapse of 21 years - Petitioners in possession despite acquisition - State contending that housing sceme was very much alive and delay was only because of pending litigations - Possession of land was also taken and handed over to Tamil Nadu Housing Board - Writ petitioners not basing their claim on S.48-B as amended in the state of Tamil Nadu - In fact earlier request made to Government under S.48-B was rejected and there was no challenge to such rejection in the writ petition - Held, mere claim of possession by writ petitioners was not a foundation on which relief could have been rested either by the learned Single Judge or by Division Bench of High Court.

Once a piece of land has been duly acquired under the Land Acquisition Act, the land becomes the property of the State.  The State can dispose of the property thereafter or convey it to anyone, if the land is not needed for the purpose for which it was acquired, only for the market value that may be fetched for the property as on the date of conveyance.  The doctrine of public trust would disable the State from giving back the property for anything less than the market value.   [Para 11]

If the request of the writ petitioners for re-conveyance in terms of Section 48-B of the Act stood rejected as apparently conceded by them before learned single judge, one finds it difficult to see how a second direction can be issued even in the absence of a challenge in the writ petition to the order of rejection and without examining the reasons contained therein.  That order was also binding on the writ petitioners, so long as it was not got rid of.  The order rejecting the request had become final and in a sense, it was not open to the learned single judge to issue the direction to consider an identical representation all over again.  The Division Bench went one step further, we regret to say, without a proper consideration of the relevant aspects.  The Division Bench apparently, even without giving the Tamil Nadu Housing Board an opportunity of being heard, proceeded at the stage of admission itself to direct re-conveyance of the lands to the writ petitioners. If the Division Bench felt that there was a case to be looked into, it should have admitted the writ appeal, issued rule nisi to the parties and thereafter heard the matter and disposed it of in the light of the relevant provisions of the Act, the law bearing on the subject and the facts obtaining.  Even when the Division Bench got an opportunity to correct itself on being approached by way of review, it did not utilise that opportunity.  In the Writ Petition, there were no sufficient allegations justifying interference by the Court.  Mere claim of possession by the writ petitioners is not a foundation on which the relief now granted could have been rested either by the learned single judge or by the Division Bench of the High Court.  On the materials, no right to relief had been established by the writ petitioners.	   [Para 8,10]

heading: Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Notification under S.4(1) of Land Acquisition Act - Challenge to - Jurisdiction of Civil Court - Civil Court has no jurisdiction to go into the question of validity or regularity of notification u/s.4(1) or declaration u/s.6 of the Land Acquisition Act - That enquiry can be done only by way of Writ Petition under Article 226 of the Constitution of India. (1995)4 SCC 229 - Rel. on.	(Paras 10 & 11)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description: Applicability - Section can be invoked only in unforeseen emergency cases - 145 families were required to be immediately rehabilitated bacause the land was going to be sub-merged after construction of barrage - Barrage was already completed and was going to be commissioned - Entire project was held up on account of challenge to Panchayat Resolution before High Court and huge expenditure already incurred on providing civic amenities for construction of rehabilitation centre would go waste - Held this was an exceptional case where invoking emergency power S.17 was justified.			(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Reference
Dismissal of
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Reference - Dismissal of - Challenge to - References cannot be dismissed merely on ground of technicalities - Rejection of references on ground of failure of petitioner to adduce evidence, held, not proper - The Court below, should have given sufficient and full opportunity to the petitioner to put-forth his case through his duly instructed lawyer and after appreciating his contentions at length, the references should have been decided. 2004(1) ALL MR 651 - Rel. on.	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Writ Petitions filed long after notification under S.4 was issued and declaration made under S.6
HeadNote.description: Writ Petitions filed long after notification under S.4 was issued and declaration made under S.6 - Reference under S.18 was also pending when petitions were filed - Petitions cannot be entertained. Constitution of India, Art.226.	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Scope and applicability of
HeadNote.description:
Scope and applicability of - Total amount of compensation granted by Collector, not reduced - S.25 will not have any application in the instant case - Furthermore, S.25 being a substantive provision will have no retrospective effect - Original award passed on 08-02-1981, S.25, as it stands now, may, therefore, not have any application in the instant case.

Section 25 of the Act merely prohibits that total amount of the award granted by the Collector cannot be reduced.  Section 25 which has undergone an amendment in the year 1984, thus, merely lays down that the amount of compensation awarded by the reference court shall not be less than the amount awarded by the Collector, and in no circumstances the amount awarded by the Collector can be reduced.  What is an award is a total sum and not the ingredients contained therein.  An award made by the Collector is in the form of an offer.  It is in that sense only that the amount contained therein cannot be reduced.

It is not the case of the appellants that the total amount of compensation stands reduced.  If it had not been, Section 25 will not have any application in the instant case.  Furthermore, Section 25 being a substantive provision will have no retrospective effect.  The original award was passed on 08.02.1981, Section 25, as it stands now, may, therefore, not have any application in the instant case.  (2002)3 SCC 463 & 2004(5) ALL MR 19 (S.C.) - Ref. to.  [Para 21]

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Colourable exercise of powers - Acquisition found to be totally mala fide and not for bona fide purpose, ground of delay and acquiescence has no substance - When whole acquisition emanates from tainted notifications any settlement on basis of that notification cannot be validated.

Lands on basis of notifications issued u/Ss.4(1), 6(1) of the Land Acquisition Act, had been acquired for the petitioner-House Building Society, treating the said acquisition to be for a public purpose. No order of the State Government as required by Section 3(f)(vi) granting prior approval for acquisition of the lands in question for the housing scheme of the petitioner-society has been produced.  In this background, when the acquisition has been found to be totally mala fide and not for bona fide purpose, the ground of delay and acquiescence in the present case has no substance.  It may be that appellant might have tried to settle out acquisition but when whole acquisition emanates from aforesaid tainted notification any settlement on basis of that notification cannot be validated. The fact remains that when basic notification under which present land is sought to be acquired stood vitiated then whatever money  that appellant has paid, is at its own risk.  Once notification goes no benefit could be derived by appellant. The issue of notification was mala fide and it was not for public purpose, nothing turns on the question of delay and acquiescence.						 [Para 9,10]

heading: Acquisition of land
Reversed.		 [Para 33,44,47,51]
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - For providing housing accommodation for Dalits/Tribals - Is of urgent nature under S.17(1) - However, even in such cases procedure under S.5-A cannot be dispensed with unless notification under sub.S.(4) of S.17 is issued.

When preliminary notification under Section 4 was issued in 2001, and as early as in 1982 proceedings were initiated for acquisition of land but they were allowed to be lapsed in spite of final notification under Section 6 of the Act by not taking appropriate actions in time the authorities could not have invoked 'urgency clause' by scuttling enquiry and dispensing with hearing of objections under Section 5-A of the Land Acquisition Act. The scheme of the Act is clear which provides for issuance of preliminary notification under sub-section (1) of Section 4 of the Act empowering the appropriate Government to issue such notification for acquisition of land needed or likely to be needed for any public purpose. Since the property belongs to a private individual, unless there is a 'public purpose' as defined in clause (f) of Section 3 of the Act, no acquisition of land can be made. It is in exercise of power of eminent domain that a sovereign may acquire property which does not belong to him. In the circumstances, as a general rule, before exercise of power of eminent domain, law must provide an opportunity of hearing against the proposed acquisition.   [Para 26,27]

Further, even in cases falling under or covered by sub-sections (1) and (2) of Section 17 of the Act and the Government intends to acquire land in cases of 'urgency' or 'unforeseen emergency', it is still required to follow procedure under Section 5-A of the Act before issuance of final notification under Section 6 of the Act. It is only when the Government also makes a declaration under sub-section (4) of Section 17 that it becomes unnecessary to take recourse to procedure under Section 5-A of the Act. Thus, though acquisition of land for housing accommodation or for construction of residential quarters for dalits and tribals can be said to be of an urgent nature falling under Section 17(1) of the Act. But even in such cases, procedure required to be followed under Section 5-A cannot be dispensed with unless notification under sub-section (4) of Section 17 is issued. Also, the provision cannot be pressed in service by officers who were negligent and due to their lethargy, proceedings could not be initiated for a quite long time.  2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 1170 and (1964)3 SCR 425 - Expl. and Applied.  C.W.P. No.1853 of 2003, Dt.2-4-2004 (P & H) - Reversed.		 [Para 33,44,47,51]

heading: Letters Patent (Bihar)
Foll.		 [Para 13,19]
HeadNote.description:
Letters Patent (Bihar) - Appeal to High Court from award - Letters Patent Appeal to Division Bench from order passed by Single Judge - Division Bench ought not have dismissed appeal in limine - It should have passed reasoned order after considering the merits.

An appeal before the learned Single Judge was Appeal from Original Decree, i.e. First Appeal, the Division Bench ought to have considered the correctness or otherwise of the order passed by the learned Single Judge by exercising same powers as exercised by the learned single Judge in the appeal from original decree. The Letters Patent before the Division Bench was not in the nature of appeal from an appellate decree, i.e. Second Appeal, but it was continuation of appeal from original decree, i.e. First Appeal. In the circumstances, the Division Bench committed an error of law in dismissing the appeal in limine by a brief order without considering the merits.  AIR 1974 SC 2048, 2008(1) ALL MR 909 (S.C.) - Foll.		 [Para 13,19]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Appeals by several landholders and by union of India - All appeals decided by a short and cryptic common order by stating that it would be appropriate to end litigation in the spirit of "let be gones be gones" because adverting to issues to each case would open Pandora's Box - It did not refer to even an iota of evidence adduced by parties - Landholders had filed separate appeals and had filed separate objections before reference Court - When a host of factors bearing on valuation of land in every individual case is required to be examined disposal by a common order not in accordance with O.41, R.31 - Matter remanded for fresh consideration.	(Paras 8-10)

heading: Reference
Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Reference - Acquisition of land - Determination of market value of acquired property - Sale instances in respect of properties situated in different areas - Reference court holding that such sale instances are not any way helpful to determine the real market price of the property - View taken by reference court was proper.	(Para 8)

heading: Acquisition of land
Challenge to
Award of compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Challenge to - Acquisition as per the procedure contemplated in the Act - Award of compensation - After passing of the award, the claimant can only ask for enhancement of compensation if he is not satisfied with the amount under the award - In the absence of challenge to the validity of the award by the petitioner, the land which is acquired under the land acquisition proceedings, cannot be divested till such time the award is in force.	(Para 5)

heading: Acquisition of land
Allowed
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Award of interest on solatium - Reference decided on basis of law laid down by Supreme Court - Decision of Supreme Court changing law given on the day on which High Court dismissed appeals of Land Acquisition Officer - Payment of interest allowable on solatium due to Supreme Court decision - Special Leave Petition before Supreme Court - Allowed - Claimants granted interest on amount envisaged by Ss. 23(1-A), 23(2) of the Act - Directions to Collector without remanding matter to High Court.

Reference Court did not award interest on amount payable by way of additional amount and solatium by following Supreme Court judgment in Prem Nath Kapoor, (1996)2 SCC 71.  Aggrieved by enhancement, Land Acquisition Officer filed First Appeals. High Court did not interfere and dismissed appeals.  Special Leave Petitions filed in Supreme Court by claimant contending that High Court ought to have awarded interest on amounts payable u/secs.23(1-A) and 23(2) of the Act   After narrating developments in case law, Supreme Court noted that in Sunder Vs. Union of India, 2001(4) ALL MR 550 (S.C.) it has pronounced that interest was payable on amount envisaged by Ss.23(1-A) and 23(2).  Appellant contended that when reference was decided by the Court, judgment in Prem Nath Kapoor held the field and it was not considered advisable to appeal against part of order rejecting interest on those amounts. Unfortunately, even till High Court decided appeal, judgment of Supreme Court in Sunder's had not been pronounced.  It is only accidental that judgments were pronounced on same day and, therefore, claimants invoked special jurisdiction under Article 136 of the Constitution. Supreme Court instead of remanding the matter to High Court allowed Special Leave Petition and granted interest to the claimants by directions to the Collector. [Para 17]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Land situated on National Highway of Banglore-Madras near railway line and in industrial area - Corporation limits were about two furlongs from acquired land - Apart from New Aero Engine Factory there were other factories also near about acquired land - Held compensation at Rs.20/- per square yard was justified - Land, however, not having been converted to non-agricultural use amount payable would be reduced by Rs.3,000/- per acre.	(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Jurisdiction of District Court - Legality of Judgment passed by Mamlatdar - District Judge aware of the fact that he has no jurisdiction nor any power to test the legality of the judgment passed by Mamlatdar - However, District Judge Predetermining the issue that judgment of Mamlatdar is illegal or else without giving any opportunity to the concerned revenue authority to justify the said order - Held, observations made by the District Judge were totally unfair - Matter remanded to District Judge with an advice to give notice to both sides to decide the issue afresh within the four corners of his jurisdiction which is limited to S.30 of Land Acquisition Act.			 (Para 4)

heading: Determination of
HeadNote.description: Market value of land - Determination of - Judgment and award passed by Reference Court in relation to the land acquired under the same notification and from vicinity of the land under the judgment can be considered to be evidence in relation to market value of the land in question.	(Para 5)

heading: Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Award of Reference Court - Appeal against - High Court directing appellant to deposit 50% of enhanced amount along with proportionate amounts towards solatium, additional market value and interest - Claimant allowed to withdraw it - Direction modified to extent that claimants would withdraw 25% of enhanced amount without furnishing any security.	(Para 5)

heading: Compensation
Entitlement of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Additional compensation of 12% - Entitlement of - Award of compensation passed prior to 30-04-1982 - Held, additional compensation of 12% would not be available to the claimant where the award was made prior to 30-04-1982. 2002(2) ALL MR 630 (S.C.) - Rel. on.	(Paras 5, 6)

heading: Land acquisition
S.4(1) notification
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - S.4(1) notification - Legality and validity of - Power of reference Court to decide - Reference Court can only determine objections as to measurements of acquired land, amount of compensation payable for it or apportionment of compensation among various claimants - Reference Court cannot decide legality or validity of notification under Section 4(1).

This revision arises out of a reference under Section 18 of the Act. It is a matter of record that the notification under Section 4(1) of the Act was issued on 18-4-1980 and it was followed by a declaration under Section 6 of the Act on 16-5-1980. The petitioner passed an award, dated 15-5-1985. Not being satisfied with the market value fixed by the petitioner, the respondents sought for reference. The petitioner acceded to the same and referred the matter to the Trial Court. The parameters of adjudication by a Civil Court in a reference under Section 18 of the Act are very limited. The reference can be only for determination of the objections as to the measurement of land, the amount of compensation payable for it, or the apportionment of compensation among the various persons, interested in the land. Beyond that, the Civil Court cannot address itself to the question of the very validity of notification. The reason is that the award came to be passed after the stage of notifications and with the active participation of the owners of the land.  In a way, it can be said that even where the notifications under Section 4(1) of the Act and Section 6 are defective, the landowners are deemed to have waived their objections by participating in the award enquiry. Therefore, even where an objection is raised touching on the legality and validity of the notifications, while participating in reference under Section 18 of the Act, the Court cannot deal with the same. Such matters are clearly outside the scope of reference.			       [Para 5]

heading: Determination of
Agricultural lands
HeadNote.description:
Market value of land - Determination of - Agricultural lands - Market price of agricultural lands can be considered on the basis of nature of the land whether an irrigated land or non-irrigated land/ dry crop/ jirayat land and its productivity - However, assessment of land revenue cannot be the basis of classification, especially when evidence about when survey was taken, what was basis of assessment etc..

The market price of the agricultural lands can be considered on the basis of nature of the land whether an irrigated land or non-irrigated land/dry crop/jirayat land and its productivity.  So far as the irrigation is concerned, it may be seasonal or perennial source of water to the land concerned.  Apart from these two categories/classes of lands, potkharaba land/non-cultivable land can be considered by the Special Land Acquisition Officer while determining the market value of the land concerned.  For classification, the quality, fertility with other factors of jirayat land can be considered.  However, it does not stand to reason as to how the assessment of land can be made a basis for grouping of the agricultural lands.  Here one more aspect requires consideration.  Use of the mannure, chemical or otherwise, is the order of the day.  Such use of the mannure undoubtedly improves the fertility of the agricultural land.  Therefore, grouping of lands made by the Special Land Acquisition Officer on the basis of assessment and accepted by the Reference Court is not legal, proper and in accordance with the provisions of law.  AIR 1995 SC 1012 - Ref. to.  [Para 13,14]

heading: Acquisition of land
Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Determination of compensation - Future potential of the acquired land - Cannot per-se be equated to a developed land and thus being granted similar compensation. 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 176 - Ref. to.	(Para 13)

heading: Meaning of
HeadNote.description: Expression "the date of award" - Meaning of - Held, the expression "the date of the award" must mean the date when the award is either communicated to the party or is known by him either actually or constructively. A.I.R. 1961 SC 1500 - Rel. on.	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Compensation
Enhancement of
Rejection of
Appeal against
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Enhancement of - Rejection of - Appeal against - District Judge failing to consider non-agricultural potential of land in question - Appeal filed by acquiring body challenging enhancement granted to landlords allowed and matter remanded for determination of compensation - Since there cannot be any contradictory computation of compensation to be granted for same land in different proceedings, appeal allowed and matter remanded.	(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Redetermination of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Redetermination of compensation - Amount payable to applicant - Is amount determined by Reference Court as modified in appeal by higher courts.

The amount payable under Section 28-A of the Act is the amount which is finally payable by way of compensation to the owners of the land who challenged the award of the Collector and claimed reference under Section 18 of the Act. The said provision seeks to confer the benefit of enhanced compensation even on those owners who did not seek a reference under Section 18. It cannot be that those who secure a certain benefit by reason of others getting such benefit should retain that benefit, even though the others on the basis of whose claim compensation was enhanced are deprived of the enhanced compensation to an extent. This would be rather inequitable and unfair. Moreover, even if it be that the compensation payable to claimants who have applied under Section 28-A of the Act, is the enhanced compensation decreed by the Reference Court, we must understand the decree to mean the decree of the Reference Court as modified in appeal by higher Courts. Otherwise, an incongruous position may emerge that a person who did not challenge the award of the Collector and did not claim a reference under Section 18 of the Act would get a higher compensation than one who challenged the award of the Collector and claimed a reference, but in whose case a higher compensation determined by the Reference Court was subsequently reduced by superior court.						      [Para 7]

heading: Land acquisition
Expression "land"
Meaning of
Dual ownership
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Expression "land" - Meaning of - It has to be whole of land including things attached or permanently fastened thereto as well as benefits arising therefrom - "Part of building" specified u/s.49 would not lead to conclusion that it excludes land underneath such building - Dual ownership - Does not imply that acquisition could be limited to interest in land. AIR 2004 SC 2006 - Referred to.	(Paras 20, 42 to 46)

heading: Factors to be considered in fixing compensation
HeadNote.description:
Factors to be considered in fixing compensation - District Court enhancing compensation of Rs.40/- per sq.mtr. awarded by L.A.O. for acquired land to Rs.133/- per sq. mtr. using a pre-acquisition plot of sale deed dated 28-05-1988 and deducting 1/3 towards cost of development - Held, in addition to 1/3 deductions towards development charges, minus points such as smallness of plot, gradient and sloppiness, waiting period to sell small plots to willing purchasers need to be considered in fixing market value.

In the case at hand deduction of 1/3 considering that basic amenities like water and electricity were available closeby, could not be faulted.  However, it appears that the learned Reference Court did not consider smallness of the plot of sale deed as one of the minus factors as compared to the acquired property which was more than seven times larger than the plot of sale deed.  Likewise, the learned Reference Court also appears not to have considered that acquired property was having a gradient and was otherwise slopy but proceeded to adjust this minus factor against the said deduction of 1/3.  When the market value is to be determined on the basis of small plots of land the same price cannot be expected to be realised when a larger track of land is offered to a willing purchaser by a willing vendor.  In case more plots like the one in question were to be carved out by the appellants, the appellants would have certainly to wait for some time to sell the same to willing purchasers and on that count also a further deduction ought to have been made by the Reference Court.  Therefore, in addition to 1/3 deduction made further deductions ought to have been made for the minus points referred to hereinabove and considering the totality of the facts of the case, the learned Reference Court ought to have made a total deduction of at least 40% and having made the same, market value ought to have been fixed for the acquired property at Rs.120/- per sq.m. which is hereby done.  2003(10) SCC 525, (1996)7 SCC 3 - Referred to.	 [Para 10]

heading: Provisions of S.11-A are intended to benefit land owner and ensure that the Award is made within a period of two years from the date of declaration under S.6 of the Act
HeadNote.description:
Provisions of S.11-A are intended to benefit land owner and ensure that the Award is made within a period of two years from the date of declaration under S.6 of the Act - If statutory provision provides a particular manner for doing a particular act, then, that thing or act must be done in accordance with manner prescribed therefor in the Act.

Where any statutory provision provides a particular manner for doing a particular act, then, that thing or act must be done in accordance with the manner prescribed therefor in the Act. The provisions of Section 11-A are intended to benefit the land owner and ensure that the Award is made within a period of two years from the date of the declaration under Section 6. In ordinary course, therefore, when the Government fails to make an Award within two years of the declaration under Section 6, the land has still not vested in the Government and its title remains with the owner, the acquisition proceedings are still pending and, by virtue of the provisions of Section 11-A, the proceedings will elapse. The period of two years referred to in Section 11-A shall be computed by counting from the last of the publication dates, as per the prescribed modes of publication. 1998(1) ALL MR 161 (S.C.) and (1995)2 SCC 497 - Ref. to.  [Para 15,16]

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Compensation - Lands abutting Kurukshetra Town and having a great potential - Applicants produced two judgments in which higher compensation was awarded though acquisition proceedings were completed much earlier than present acquision proceedings - High Court vaguely mentioning that present lands were situated at some distance away and the price of land in the villages in which land was situate had not shown any upward trend - Held such a casual approach was not justified and it would be better for the High Court to reconsider the matter on remand. (1997)11 SCC 218 and (2005)12 SCC 564 - Rel. on.			(Paras 9, 12, 13)

heading: Application for enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Application for enhancement of compensation - CIDCO acting as agent of the State Government and not as acquiring body - It cannot insist for being impleaded as party to reference. 		(Para 18)

heading: Compulsory acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Compulsory acquisition of land - Plaintiff not raising any issue as regards measurement of land acquired or amount of compensation paid to her or defendants - Plaintiff accepted award and compensation without protest - Not entitled to make application under S.18 and remedy provided by statute is barred - Consequently general remedy by recourse to Civil Court is also barred.	(Paras, 21, 22)

heading: Notification under
HeadNote.description: Notification under - Land acquired for establishing a School and Hospital - Notification challenged as mala fide on ground that land which was only half an acre was not sufficient to satisfy requirement of a School, a play ground and hospital - Single Judge of High Court quashed notification - Appeal to Division Bench - Division Bench upholding notification and pointing out that land though not sufficient to satisfy all the three purposes can be utilised for one of them - Moreover fact that resolution of Municipal Corporation was earlier challenged on this very ground by writ petition was suppressed while challenging S.4(1) notification - Hence appeal dismissed.	(Para 6)

heading: Claim for
Foll.	 [Para 10,12]
HeadNote.description:
Re-determination of compensation on basis of award of court - Claim for - Claimant's Land need not be exactly identical to land for which award has been passed by court - A close proximity and similarity is enough for an application for re-determination under S.28-A.

Section 28-A provides a right to the expropriated owner to claim re-determination of the amount of compensation on the basis of the award of the court.  The award that has been passed by the court in excess of the amount awarded by the collector under S.11 is the basis on which the interested person  moves the application under S.28-A and seeks re-determination.  It is not necessary for claiming re-determination under S.28-A that the land in case of a person claiming re-determination of compensation awarded under S.11 is exactly identical to the land for which the award has been passed by the court. A close similarity and proximity to the award passed by the court is sufficient to entitle a person interested in the land covered by the same notification under S.4(1) to which the said award relates, to apply for re-determination, S.28-A postulates re-determination of the amount of compensation on the basis of the award of the court made in favour of another. But that does not mean that factually and actually the land must be exactly similar.

Therefore, where the land of the expropriated owner was similarly situated to that of another person's land which came to be acquired under the same proceedings and only the trees standing thereon were somewhat different, it was held that merely because the trees standing thereon were somewhat different, that would not mean that the land was dis-similar, incapable for re-determination under S.28-A of the Land Acquisition Act. (1995)2 SCC 689 - Foll.	 [Para 10,12]

heading: Land acquisition proceedings
Payment of interest
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition proceedings - Payment of interest - Act is a complete code - High Court cannot in its writ jurisdiction direct payment of interest in a manner not contemplated by either S.28 or 34. 1996(5) SCC 44, 1997(10) SCC 77, 1995(5) SCC 683, 1995(6) SCC 233 - Rel. on.	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Award of compensation
Interest
HeadNote.description:
Award of compensation - Interest - Failure of Collector to deposit compensation payable to petitioners - Petitioners would be entitled to interest @ 15% p.a. one year after the Award under S.11 of the Act.

Under Section 31 of the said Act, the Collector is expected to tender payment of the compensation awarded once an Award under Section 11 of the said Act is passed, except where certain contingencies mentioned in the Section arise. One such contingency is where there is a dispute regarding apportionment of the compensation. The Collector is then expected to deposit the amount of compensation in the court to which the Reference under Section 18 could be submitted. In the present case, admittedly, there was a dispute regarding apportionment. However, that should not have deterred the Collector from depositing the amount as required under Section 31 of the said Act. Not having done so, the interest payable to the petitioners, one year after the amount of compensation was expected to be deposited, would be payable @ 15% p.a.. Although the Award has been modified and the Reference Court has granted an enhancement of the amount, in any event, the petitioners would be entitled to interest @ 15% p.a., one year after the Award under Section 11 of the said Act was made, on account of the failure to deposit the compensation payable to the petitioners.  [Para 7,8]

heading: Reference for enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Reference for enhancement of compensation - Reliance on post notification sale deed executed four years after 5.4 notification - Reference court, held, was justified in discarding said sale deed for enhancing compensation. 	(Para 5)

heading: Land acquisition
Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Determination of compensation - Binding effect of judgments on State - Once the Award is in respect of a portion of the same property, the market value fixed therein having been accepted by the State, cannot be thereafter disputed as being not acceptable for the purpose of determining compensation in subsequent acquisition since judgments are also relevant for determining the market value of the land acquired, since, the judgments are binding on the State, they can form the basis for determining the market value of the land acquired. 	(Para 16)

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Deduction from sale deed plot - Sale deed plot having advantage of road on southern side which advantage the acquired land did not have - Held, it would be appropriate to make deduction of 10% on this count. 	(Para 11)

heading: Standard deductions
HeadNote.description: Compensation for land acquired - Assessment based on comparable sale transactions - Statutory restriction on use of land - Standard deductions - Just and proper, extent of deductions - Land acquired not a freehold, its free use is not permissible as it suffers from statutory restrictions - Its market value could not be compared with other sale instances in respect of the freehold land - Deduction of 40% given due to vastness of land but no deduction given for development and statutory restrictions - About 30% deductions are found to be just and proper but the same could go even up to 60% depending upon facts of each case - High Court gave deduction of 45% and reduced the compensation from Rs.80/- per sq. mtr. to Rs.55/- per sq. mtr. with all consequential statutory benefits.	 (Paras 10, 12, 13)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Determination of market value - Sale deed of undivided rights - Such undivided rights which are appurtaining to the flat premises cannot be a basis for determining the market value of open land - Also, a forest area cannot be compared to the land which was converted for non-agricultural purpose as such area has its own peculiar advantages.

Dealing with the sale instances produced by the Applicants, Court held that the Sale Deed of an undivided right cannot be a basis for the purpose of determining the market value of land as on the date of Section 4 Notification, as such undivided right has been sold in view of the existence of a constructed premises in a residential building. The price fixed therein, cannot be a price offered by a willing purchaser in the open market. Such undivided rights, which are appurtaining to the flat premises cannot be a basis for determining the market value of open land. Apart from that, the land which was subject matter of the said Sale Deed which is dated 11th November, 1996, is at a distance of about 1.5 kilometres from the Mapusa market and about 1 kilometre from the Highway. The said Sale Deed as such cannot be a comparable sale instance. The Sale Deeds produced with regard to the plots located at Xelpem are at a distance of 5 kilometres from the acquired land and, as such, the same cannot be compared to the land acquired. It is also admitted that the said land is a forest area and there is no dispute that the land acquired in the present proceedings was not a forest area. A forest area cannot be compared to the land which was converted for non agricultural purpose as such area has its own peculiar advantages.

The Sale Deed produced by the Applicants in respect of the properties located in Mapusa City and which are at a distance of nearly 3 kilometres from the acquired land are also not comparable Sale instances. In the heart of a city the prices can differ considering its respective location. In cities, when the properties are located close to the market, they fetch a higher commercial value considering that such land can be used for business activity. As land located in the outskirts of the city cannot be compared to lands located in the heart of the city unless material is produced to value the demerits and merits of such land. The commercial value of such lands will be much less than the value of Sale Deeds located in the heart of City. No evidence has been adduced by the Applicants to establish such differentiation in the land value between such two locations. On that count, the Sale Deed produced by the Applicants of land sold to Kamat Construction, cannot be considered to be a comparable Sale Deed for considering the basis for determining the market value of land. As such, the said sale instance at exhibit 31, cannot be considered for the purpose of determining the market value of land. The sale instances produced by the Respondents are stated to be more than 2 kilometres from the acquired land besides that the same are not adjoining the Highway nor has evidence been recorded to establish that such land could be used for non agricultural purpose or are in the vicinity of the acquired land. In view of the above, the only sale instance which remains for consideration is the award of the Land acquisition Officer which took place in the year 1980 in respect of the portion of the same property belonging to the Applicants for the purpose of National Highway 17. The said land admittedly is part of the same survey number, which is the subject matter in the present proceedings. When no comparable sale instance is available for determining the market value of land, there is no bar to rely on such award to determine the market value of land as on the date of Section 4 notification after giving appropriate escalation on account of appreciation considering the surrounding circumstances. The previous acquisition took place in the year 1980 and the price was fixed at Rs. 40/- per square metre. The notification in the present case was issued in 21st August, 1997.  2008(17) SCC 133 and 2009(5) ALL MR 1022 (S.C.) - Ref. to.	  [Para 14,15]

heading: Interest on compensation
Liability to pay
HeadNote.description:
Interest on compensation - Liability to pay - Dispossession prior to issuance of S.4 notification - Interest under S.23 would be payable from date of passing of award and not from date of dispossession - Petitioners would not be entitled to interest on rental compensation as the same is not paid under the provisions of L.A. Act.

2009(3) ALL MR 779 Held not good law in view of 2004(5) ALL MR 435 (S.C.) and 2004(5) ALL MR 19 (S.C.). (Paras 13, 14)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Land acquired for tourism place - Land converted into non-agriculture land - High Court reducing compensation of Rs. 650/- per aar to Rs. 500/- per aar - Though hotel businesses was not started on the land there was some structure on the land - Land was adjacent to Highway and about 6 to 8 kms away from ajantha caves - Very great potential for development ought to have been taken consideration by High Court but it failed to do so - Award of reference court restored.  (Paras 13, 14)

heading: Acquisition of land by Govt.
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land by Govt. - Enquiry under S.5-A by Special Land Acquisition Officer - He has to follow rules of natural justice before preparing report - Constitution of India, Art.14.

It is true that the State Government is entitled to acquire the land for public purpose.  However, for safeguarding the interest of the land holders, inquiry under Section 5-A is required to be conducted by the Special Land Acquisition Officer.  It is incumbent on the Special Land Acquisition Officer to follow the rules of natural justice before preparing the report under Section 5-A of the Land Acquisition Act by giving reasonable opportunity of hearing to the land holders whose lands are being acquired under the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act and who have raised objections.  The inquiry under Section 5-A though is summary in nature, however, is not the empty formality and therefore, the same should not be conducted in a casual manner and without following rules of natural justice. The Report prepared by officer without following there principles is violative of principles of nature justice and cannot be sustained.	 [Para 5,6]

heading: Interest on compensation
HeadNote.description: Interest on compensation - S.4 notification issued on 24.2.2000 - Land acquired on 1.12.1999 i.e. before issuance of  S.4 notification - Petitioners would be entitled to claim benefits only from date of notification - Claimants were paid advance compensation to the extent of 80% - Hence, they would be entitled to claim benefits under S.34 from date of notification till date of payment of advance compensation and interest under S.34 on the balance amount of compensation till payment of balance amount.              (Para 4)

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Rejection of review application - Order of rejection is not made appealable - However, in case review application is allowed by the court or earlier decree or order is modified, in that contingency, appeal is made available under R.7(1) of order 47 of Civil P.C. (2005)3 SCC 427 and AIR 1995 SC 1012 - Ref. to.			(Para 9)

heading: Reference
Market value
Determination
HeadNote.description: Reference - Market value - Determination - Land acquired for widening of road - Acquired land comes under settlement zone - Evidence on record proves that acquired land was served with electricity, telephone, tap water, well water, transport, temple, dispensaries, high school, market, play ground, primary school, chapel, bus stop, police station - Sale instances are 500 meters from acquired land and similar to acquired land - Sale instance plot admeasuring 1200 sq. mtr. sold for Rs.125/- per sq. mtr. - Acquired land was 1400 sq. mtr. - Sale instance executed subsequent to publication of Notification - However nothing on record showing that on account of acquisition, price of sale deed plot had increased - Market value of Rs.100/- per sq. mtr. proper. 	(Paras 11, 13, 14)

heading: Limitation period
HeadNote.description:
Application for reference by landowner - Limitation period - Commences from date of receipt of notice from collector - Time spent in obtaining certified copy of award cannot be excluded.

The period of limitation for filing application for reference to court u/S.18(2) would be for six weeks starting from the date of receipt of notice from the collector u/S.12(2) of the Act.  Hence once the notice is received the period starts from that date.  The period required for obtaining certified copy cannot be excluded while computing period of limitation under S.18(2) of the Act.  AIR 1978 Bom 325 and 1981 Mh.L.J. 49 - Not followed.						      [Para 17,19]

heading: Land acquisition proceedings
Discrimination
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition proceedings - Discrimination - Exclusion of lands from acquisition - Facts placed on record indicating that though petitioner's land was similarly situated was not excluded from land acquisition proceedings despite recommendation of Special Land Acquisition Officer - Order is discriminatory and liable to be set aside - Order quashing S.4 notification not interfered with.	(Para 7)

heading: Additional compensation
HeadNote.description: Additional compensation - Huge chunk of land acquired - No amount paid to respondent land owner though other land owners were paid compensation even without examining their entitlement to additional compensation - Matter remitted to High Court for fresh disposal of writ petition.			(Para 7)

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation awarded
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Compensation awarded - Reference for enhancement of amount - Pre-condition of accepting amount under protest - Acceptance of application for enhancement and reference of case for enhancement - Court cannot reject it on ground that claimant has not recorded his protest while receiving amount.

The claimant is entitled to enhanced compensation by making a reference u/s.18 of the Land Acquisition Act and the Court cannot deny enhancement of compensation merely on the ground that the claimant has failed to record protest while receiving the amount under the Award.  In view of this it has to be said that the trial Court has committed an error in rejecting the claim of the appellant for enhancement of compensation merely on technical ground that the appellant has not recorded his protest while receiving the amount of compensation.  The protest required to be recorded by the claimant while receiving the amount of compensation need not be expressed in writing.  That apart, the Land Acquisition Officer, who has paid the amount of compensation, accepts and refers the petition filed by the claimant to the Court for deciding enhancement of compensation, as claimed by the claimant, does imply that the claimant has received the amount of compensation under protest.  If that is so, then it was not within the powers of the Civil Court to reject the application or reference on technical ground that the claimant has not expressed or recorded his protest while receiving the amount.  That is much more so as in the instant case the Civil Court, considering the merits of the matter, has recorded a finding that the enhanced amount of compensation of Rs.1,00,000/- as claimed by the appellant was reasonable and that he is entitled for the same.  Not only that, but the Court has recorded a finding that the compensation fixed in the Award was inadequate.  In the circumstances the claimant is entitled to enhanced amount of compensation.  [Para 7,8]

heading: Reference under
HeadNote.description:
Reference under - Compromise between parties before Lok Adalat - Practice of obtaining signatures on blank forms shall not be adopted.

Before the Lok Adalat whenever there is a compromise between the parties in References under Section 18 of the said Act, care shall be taken to ensure that agreed calculations of compensation amount payable as per the compromise are incorporated in the consent Awards. If for some reasons, after arriving at settlement, the calculations are not ready, the references shall be kept before the next Lok Adalat. The practice of obtaining signatures on blank forms shall not be adopted. 				      [Para 7]

heading: Acquisition proceeding
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition proceeding - Limitation - Last publication of declaration was on 10th June 2010 - Notification under S.48(1) was issued on 16th March 2011 withdrawing from acquisition of said land - Period of 2 years prescribed in S.11A for making award expired on 10th June 2012 without making award - However period between date of notification under S.48(1) till date on which it was set aside cannot be excluded in computing period of 2 years prescribed in S.11A - Extension of limitation under S.11A would be contrary to statutory provision.

Consequences may not be drastic. Property could be acquired by initiating acquisition proceedings afresh. Indeed compensation may well be enhanced if there is escalation of price thereof. If withdrawal of acquisition proceedings is found to be fraudulent, Government would be entitled to adopt proceedings to recover damages in accordance with law, including by seeking appropriate reliefs, inter alia, qua compensation payable in respect of property in fresh acquisition proceedings.	          [Para 23,27]

heading: Remained uncontroverted
Proper.	(Paras 8, 9)
HeadNote.description: Dispute over apportionment of compensation - Parties to dispute were uncle and nephew and were joint tenants of acquired land - Averments in written statement submitted by respondent nephew that occupancy price was paid by both appellant and respondent, promise given by appellant to mutate half land in favour of respondent and about subsequently executing partition deed - Remained uncontroverted - Under circumstances it can be inferred that sale certificate issued in name of appellant was obtained for himself and his nephew - Thus finding that appellant and respondent were each entitled to half share in compensation awarded - Proper.	(Paras 8, 9)

HeadNote.sub_clause: S.25 (as it existed before its amendment w.e.f. 24-5.1984)
heading: Award of compensation by Collector
HeadNote.description: Award of compensation by Collector - Both award and Notification under S.4 issued prior to said amendment - Reduction of compensation awarding compensation of lesser rate than the one awarded by Collector cannot be interfered with.	(Para 11)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Enhancement by High Court from Rs.10,000/- per acre to Rs.75,000/- per acre - Enhancement done without considering oral and documentary evidence - How findings of Reference Court are unjustified by which compensation is fixed at Rs.10,000/- is not shown - High Court proceeded on wrong notion that sale deeds of tiny pieces of land could be determining factor as acquired land in this case is Ac. 4.98 decimals - Judgment of High Court liable to be set aside. 2009 ALL SCR 1029 Rel.on.	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Land reserved for industrial zone
HeadNote.description: Land reserved for industrial zone - Proposal of industrial co-operative society for acquisition of land rejected by Government - Writ petition against by respondent - High Court deciding petition as if respondent society and one another were the only two aspirants entitled to acquire land - Compromise arrived at between the two respondent societies as suggested by High Court - High Court directing acquisition on basis of such settlement arrived at though there was no reservation in favour of respondents in the regional plan and no contribution was made by Govt. - Held direction to issue S.4 notification was improper and it was also not correct to hold that concerns of other aspirants could be taken care of in S.5-A enquiry and they could be allotted plots by society after acquisition was completed.			(Paras 25-30)

heading: Declaration under S.6(1)
HeadNote.description: Declaration under S.6(1) - Collector shall give hearing to objector and then make report to Government - Declaration under S.6(1) can be made only after applying mind to collector's report, to objections of landowner and other interested persons.  (Para 33)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Acquisition for defence purposes under Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act, 1952 - Award of solatium and interest is permissible even in such cases.

A large extent of land was acquired for defence purposes under the provisions of Requisitioning and Acquisition of Immovable Property Act, 1952. Failure of the parties to arrive at an agreement as to the amount of compensation payable to the expropriated owners of the land in question led the owners to seek appointment of an Arbitrator for determination of the amount payable to them. The Government did not respond to the said request for a long time which forced the land-owners to approach the High Court to appoint an arbitrator.

Held that, having regard to the fact that there was an inordinate delay of 16 years in the appointment of an Arbitrator in the present cases the land owners would be entitled to the benefit of solatium and interest especially when the owners who have lost land in similar circumstances and for the same purpose have been given such a benefit.  2009(3) ALL MR 961 (S.C.) - Rel.on.   [Para 7,8,11]

heading: Apportionment of compensation
Dispute over ownership
HeadNote.description: Apportionment of compensation - Dispute over ownership - Reliance placed by Reference Court on judgment of HC in another land acquisition appeal to conclude that a particular party is sole owner of acquired land - Taking judicial notice of judgment is permissible u/Ss.56 and 57 of Evidence Act - Keeping in view that said judgment is confirmed in LPA and though challenged in SLP, Apex Court has not ordered the stay, held, Reference Court is bound by said judgment - Placing reliance on said judgment for the purpose of S.30, justified. 	(Paras 27, 28)

heading: Interest on solatium
HeadNote.description: Interest on solatium - Can be granted by execution Court if it is not expressly denied by reference or appellate Court. 2006(8) SCC 457 - Foll.	(Para 6)

heading: Acquisition of lands
Compensation
Deductions
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of lands - Compensation - When large tracts of lands are acquired by the same Notification, held, the compensation payable in respect of all the lands may not be the same - Determination of market value - Deductions - Held, deduction varies depending upon various factors - There cannot be straight jacket formula for determining the percentage of deduction. 2007 ALL SCR 2267 and 2008(6) ALL MR 493 (S.C.) - Ref. to.	(Para 7)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Land acquired in close proximity of the land purchased by claimant - Consideration paid by such claimant is the best evidence of market value. 

In case the land of the claimant has been acquired in close vicinity of the purchase, the consideration paid by such claimant to the vendor is the best evidence of the market value of the land. The court should not award more unless it is possible to reach a different conclusion. Even the appellate court should not interfere in such a fact situation unless the judgment is based on wrong application of principle or because some important point affecting valuation has been overlooked or misapplied. The consideration paid by the owner only a few months ago presents bonafide evidence of value subject to certain exceptions such as relationship of the parties, market conditions and terms of sale and the date of sale. In case a purchaser has not shown the exact amount of consideration paid by him in the sale deed to save the stamp duty such dishonest vendee is not required to be protected by the court. A cumulative increase of 10 to 15 per cent per year in the market value of the land may be accepted unless the State agencies or acquiring authority prove otherwise.

2008 ALL SCR 1228, 2008(6) ALL MR 491 (S.C.), (2008) 17 SCC 133, 2009 ALL SCR 2400 Rel. on.     [Para 13,14,15]

heading: Compensation
Sale Deed
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Sale Deed - Land in question in the said Sale-Deed and acquired land are from the same village - Though land covered by the Sale-Deed is developed plot, the said Sale-Deed can be taken into consideration in fixing the rate of compensation as the said Sale-Deed was of the same contemporaneous period as the Notification under S.4 of the Act.	(Para 4)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Notification for acquisition of land - Compensation - Government will have to determine the compensation of the land as on date of issuance of S.4 Notification - Public money cannot be spent as per whims of concerned officers - Inaction in this regard amounts to dereliction of duty and misconduct.	(Paras 7 and 8)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Acquisition of identically situated lands from same village - Compensation at the rate of Rs.2,20,000/- per acre awarded in the first case - Two years after further land acquired from the same village from the appellant - Held appellant was entitled to compensation @ Rs.2,20,000/- plus benefit of escalation of 10% increase for two years.

2008(6) ALL MR 491 (S.C.) Rel.on. 			 [Para 10,11]

heading: Compensation
Severance charges
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Severance charges - Acquisition divided property into 2 parcels - Eastern portion of 5 plots has become inaccessible - Though issue as to 'damage sustained' is not framed, evidence is led in this regard - Damage should be compensated with reference to date of taking possession - Damage liable to be compensated under clause thirdly - Award by Reference Court under clause fourthly is liable to be modified - Order accordingly. 2005(1) ALL MR 797 - Rel. on. AIR 1968 SC 1425, 2005(4) ALL MR 708 - Referred. 		(Paras 15, 16, 18)

heading: Reference
Dismissal of
Challenge to
