HeadNote.description: Reference - Dismissal of - Challenge to - References cannot be dismissed merely on ground of technicalities - Rejection of references on ground of failure of petitioner to adduce evidence, not proper - Held, the Court below, should have given sufficient and full opportunity to the petitioner to put-forth his case through his duly instructed lawyer and after appreciating his contentions at length, the references should have been decided. 2004(1) ALL MR 651 - Rel. on.	(Paras 9 and 10)

heading: Acquisition of land
Effect
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Landlord receiving 80% of compensation from Government - Effect - Land will be deemed to have vested in the State absolutely free from all encumbrances - Government cannot be compelled to withdraw from acquisition even if petitioner is ready and willing to return compensation received along with interest.		(Paras 11, 13)

heading: Exparte award
Setting aside of
HeadNote.description: Exparte award - Setting aside of - Petitioner not aware of date of hearing - He was absent when award was passed - He could not lead evidence or cross-examine witnesses - On such a case even assuming that court proceeded under O.17 R.2 application under O.9 R.13 would be very much maintainable - Petitioner taking appropriate steps to recall exparte award within seven days - Held, court was not justified in refusing to condone delay. 			(Paras 6, 8)

heading: Compensation
Reduction of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Reduction of - Non-speaking order by High Court - Order liable to be set aside - Reference court awarded compensation by well reasoned order - Order of reference Court liable to be restored. (Para 7)

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Compensation - Is to be paid from date of S.4 notification upto date of award. 
2004(5) ALL MR 435 (S.C.), 2002(1) ALL MR 262 (S.C.) Foll. (Para 8)

heading: Challenge to acquisition proceedings
HeadNote.description: Challenge to acquisition proceedings - No evidence that possession of land and house was taken after award was passed and before writ petition was filed - Moreover, acquisition of land was vitiated by colourable exercise of power by State Government because land was not acquired for any public purpose but to benefit a coloniser who had undertaken to develop the area into a residential colony - Further State Policy also required release of land on which construction was made before S.4 notification - Hence, acquisition of land was illegal and as such quashed.  (Paras 8, 14, 15, 18)

heading: Acquisition of land
Claim of compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Claim of compensation - Once the land is treated as Bagayat for determining the market value of the land then claimant is not entitled to separate compensation towards well. (1996)6 SCC 124 - Rel. on.	(Para 11)

heading: Possession of land taken long back for constitution of percolation tank
HeadNote.description:
Possession of land taken long back for constitution of percolation tank - Also notification under S.4 issued even after expiry of period of 7 years - Directions given for taking prompt action.

In the instant case, the possession of the subject lands  was taken in the year 2001 for construction of the percolation tank. Since then the Petitioners have been requesting the authorities for initiating acquisition proceedings.  The High Court observed that it was necessary and incumbent on the part of the concerned authorities to take appropriate and prompt actions when the Petitioners land was subjected to acquisition and they were dispossessed in the year 2001. In the process the Petitioners had lost possession of the land and were deprived of the payment of compensation in accordance with law consequent to dispossession.  The High Court directed the Collector, Ahmednagar to verify, whether there are such identical cases pending in Ahmednagar District and if such cases are noticed, earliest action shall be taken and if such directions are not complied with, responsible officers shall be dealt with in accordance with the provisions of Maharashtra Government Servants Regulation of Transfers, Prevention of Delay in Discharge of Official Duties Act, 2005.  Petition was disposed of with cost of Rs.5000/-.

heading: Interim relief
Refusal to grant
HeadNote.description: Interim relief - Refusal to grant - Special Leave Petition filed against refusal to grant interim relief - Writ petition filed against acquisition of land pending - Notice of motion seeking some reliefs rejected by High Court - Another notice of motion for relief and seeking expeditious hearing of petition also was dismissed by the High Court - S.L.P. filed against order passed in the notice of motion dt.21.3.2005 - Matter pertaining to acquisition of property for Respondent No.2 - Award passed under S.11 of the Act - Possession was taken under S.16 of the Act by Collector on 16.2.2004 handed over to R-2 immediately thereafter - Appellant as also owner filed references against the award and the same are pending - In given facts and circumstances of the case, held, Court is not inclined to interfere with order passed by High Court except to extent that High Court dispose of the petition as expeditiously as possible preferably within 3 months from date - The appellant may persue his remedy before Reference Court or other forum as available.			(Paras 6 to 10)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - By Govt. for a Trust for promoting Ayurvedic education - Land allotted to Trust under Agreement in 1952 - Trust constructed various buildings for conduct of Ayurvedic Medical Courses - Trust felt need of independent ladies hostel in 1987 - Alienating a portion of land in lieu of construction of ladies hostel without permission of Govt. - Erstwhile land owner applying to Minister (Revenue) for restoration of portion of land on ground that Trust has not used entire land - Minister condoning alienation of land by Trust without permission, with penalty - Minister also directing restoration of portion of land to erstwhile land owner as "special case" - Held, order condoning alienation with penalty, was proper - However, direction by Minister to restore portion of land to erstwhile land owner - Not sustainable as acquired lands cannot be returned to erstwhile land owner - Constitution of India, Art.14.(Paras 28, 30, 31, 32, 34, 36)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of market value - There cannot be a straight jacket formula for determining market rate of acquired land - Some kind of guess work can be done in arriving at the market rate of the acquired land and the same cannot be fixed by resorting to a mathematical formula. 	(Para 17)

heading: Redetermination of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Redetermination of compensation - Circulars dt. 20.10.98, 25.3.98 provide that even if appeals against awards u/S.18 are pending - Applications u/S.28A(1) should be decided subject to claimants furnishing bank guarantee for amount of compensation - Circulars are contrary to Apex Court decision 1995 (2) SCC 689 - Petition is liable to be rejected. 

If Appeal against award in Reference under S.18 is pending in higher court and if Appellate Court has stayed execution and operation of award, Land Acquisition Officer or Collector cannot proceed with hearing of application under S.28A(1) filed on basis of said award.

However, in those limited cases where Appeals are pending, but Appellate Court has not stayed operation and execution of award made in Reference under S.18, Collector or Land Acquisition Officer can consider of proceedings with inquiry in accordance with S.28A(2) provided claimant gives undertaking not to claim amount payable under award under S.28A(2) unless he furnishes bank guarantee of any nationalized bank for entire amount payable under award under S.28A(2). In such case claimant will have to furnish bank guarantee of any nationalised bank which shall be valid till disposal of Appeal as condition precedent for withdrawal of compensation amount payable as per Award under S.28A(2).

1995 (2) SCC 689 Rel. on. 1995 (2) SCC 736, 2009 ALL SCR 674 Ref. to.   [Para 15,18,19]

heading: Successive notifications under
HeadNote.description:
Successive notifications under - Effects.

Successive Notifications under Section 4 or successive Declarations under Section 6 of the Act can be made, however, the effect of the same would be that earlier notification/declaration stands obliterated/ superseded and in such a fact-situation, it would not be permissible for either of the parties to make any reference to the said notifications/ declarations which stood superseded.

(1969) 3 SCC 675, 2011(2) ALL MR 470 (S.C.), (2000) 4 SCC 357 Rel. on.     [Para 6]

The appellant is entitled for restoration of possession of the land in dispute. However, considering the fact that the possession of the land was taken over about half a century ago and stood completely developed and a full-fledged residential colony of employees of DESU has been constructed thereon, therefore, it would be difficult for respondent no.1 to restore the possession. In such a fact-situation, the only option left out to the respondents is to make the award treating Section 4 notification as, on this date, i.e. 12.2.2013 and to make the award after hearing the parties within a period of four months from today. The appellant is at liberty to file a reference under Section 18 of the Act and to pursue the remedies available to him under the Act. 	         [Para 11,12]

heading: Is mandatory requirement
HeadNote.description:
Publication of notification in public place - Is mandatory requirement - That interested persons had knowledge of acquisition proceedings is of no help to the respondent State - Acquisition Proceedings are null and void.

(1985) 3 SCC 1, (2011) 10 SCC 714 - Rel. on.  (Para 12)

heading: Allotment of land to project affected person
HeadNote.description: Allotment of land to project affected person - Circle inspector handing over wrong agricultural land which was not at all acquired - Owner of that land complaining about wrong allotment of his land - High Court Directing grant of alternate agricultural land to allottee and Government was also directed to decide claim of allottee for compensation though he was reaping benefits from land since 1982 - Held no interference with order of high court was required. 	(Paras 5, 7)

heading: Belated award
HeadNote.description: Belated award - Not a ground to revert possession to owner of land which was acquired by final notification by invoking urgency clause when land has already vested in Government.	(Para 8)

heading: Compensation
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination - No sales of comparable lands - Method is to assess annual income.

Where there are no sales of comparable land, one of the methods which may be used is to assess the annual income from the land which the owner has been deriving or is expected to derive and then capitalise such income by adopting a multiplier. The net annual income from a land is arrived at by deducting from the gross annual income all outgoings such as expenditure on cultivation, land revenue, etc. 			     [Para 15]

heading: Report under S.5A
HeadNote.description:
Report under S.5A - Land acquired for constructing road in village - Petitioners contending that acquisition is only for benefit of 2 houses - Report of Collector merely states that acquisition would improve accessibility in village - Reason for reaching to this conclusion is not stated - Nothing in report indicates application of mind by Collector to rival contentions - Nature of objections is such that they require consideration and further inquiry by authorities - Report under S.5A is set aside in respect of lands of petitioners only.

1995 (3) SCC 752, 1975 (4) SCC 298 Ref. to. 	 [Para 15,17]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Acquisition of agricultural land for irrigation project - Documents reveal that lands were under cultivation and crops like cotton, toor, jawar were grown - Evidence was led to show per year profit from each acre of land was Rs. 5000/- - Reference Court assumed it at Rs. 2000/- per acre - Considering all minus factors, and considering cost of cultivation income from each acre of land cannot be less than Rs.2000/- to Rs.2500/- - Reference Court was right in choosing multiplier of 10 - Award is not liable to be interfered with. 			(Para 7)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Acquired land is a strip of land - No construction possible on it - No definite answer by witnesses as to the distance between main road and acquired land - Contention of applicant that due to acquisition of only a portion, rest of his property rendered useless - Not supported by evidence - Sale instances also produced by interested witnesses, hence not reliable - However keeping in view that acquired land is situated in vicinity of various houses having various facilities and having coconut trees on it out of which applicant was getting some income, compensation enhanced from Rs. 7 to Rs. 14 per sq. m. of land. 			(Paras 14 to 18)

heading: Award
HeadNote.description: Award - No communication of award under S.11 within a period of two years from date of publication of the declaration under S.6 - As such no award can be said to have been made by Collector as envisaged under S.11A - Entire proceedings for a acquisition stand lapsed. 	(Para 11)

heading: Redetermination of compensation
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Redetermination of compensation - Successive application for, u/s.28A - Maintainability - Application u/s.28A(1) has to be made within three months from date of first award - Any further award with respect to same acquisition - Would not give concerned agriculturist a fresh cause of action to move successive application u/s.28A, in view of the law laid down by Apex Court in (1995) 2 SCC 689. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12, 13, 14)

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description: Appeal - Application for substitution to bring on record the heirs and legal representatives of deceased appellant - While allowing appeal, a question raised as to whether in fact the claimant-appellant had filed an application for reference under S.18 of the Act - Records showing that an application under S.18, in fact, was filed by appellant - Such being the position, held, Court has no other alternative but to set aside the order impugned in this appeal and send the case back to Reference Court to decide the said application under S.18 of the Act in accordance with law after giving hearing to the parties.	(Para 3)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - Agricultural land acquired for setting up a grain market - Acquired land adjacent to already developed village - Deduction of 70% towards developed charges being on the higher side reduced to 60%.	(Para 30)

heading: Reference
Question of limitation
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Question of limitation - It is mixed question of law and fact and it is required to be pleaded and proved.

The question of limitation is mixed question of law and fact and it is required to be pleaded and proved. The contention of the respondents is that the notice under Section 12(2) of the said Act was served upon the petitioner on 18.1.2007, whereas the contention of the petitioner is that for the first time, the said notice came to the knowledge of the petitioner on 17.9.2008 when the reply was filed in Writ Petition No.2773 of 2008 by the respondents. The Special Land Acquisition Officer has not adjudicated upon this disputed question of fact. At any rate, this question can be gone into by the Civil Court and the Special Land Acquisition Officer could not have rejected the application under Section 18, for reference.				 [Para 3]

heading: Compensation for acquired land
HeadNote.description: Compensation for acquired land - Production of sale instance relied upon by parties - Held, in a given case it may not be possible for a party to produce before the Court the sale instance of the very year in which the suit land became subject matter of acquisition - Court will have to consider whether effort was made by the party to place before the Court the rate in respect of a particular land, may be in the year in which the land is sought to be acquired or near about time when the land is sought to be acquired.	(Para 7)

heading: Reference
Award under S.11
Challenge to
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Award under S.11 - Challenge to - Award under S.11 is in the nature of an offer - The claimant who does not accept the award can seek a reference under S.18 of the Act - After reference under S.18 of the Act is made, the claimant is in a position of the plaintiff who has to discharge the initial burden of proving that the market value offered by Special Land Acquisition officer is inadequate.

Award under section 11 of the said Act is in the nature of an offer. The claimant who does not accept the award can seek a reference under section 18 of the said Act. After reference under section 18 of the said Act is made, the claimant is in a position of the plaintiff who has to discharge the initial burden of proving that the market value offered by the Special Land Acquisition Officer is inadequate. After the said burden is discharged, for establishing the correct market value on the relevant date, the claimant is duty bound to adduce evidence. The well accepted method which is normally adopted in such matters is comparison method by producing and proving the comparable sale instances or Awards made under sections 11 or 18 of the said Act in respect of comparable lands. In the present case, it is an admitted position that the claimants have not relied upon any comparable sale instances or any awards in land acquisition cases. The claimants have stepped into witness box and have deposed regarding the area of the acquired land and the claim made by them. The perusal of the Roznama of the proceedings shows that no document of sale instance has been exhibited. Thus, in short, the claimants have not adduced any evidence in the form of comparable sale instances. There is no evidence adduced to show that the market value offered under the Award made by the Special Land Acquisition Officer is inadequate. The impugned awards under section 18 of the said Act are based only on the draft award prepared by the Special Land Acquisition Officer. In the draft award prepared by the Special Land Acquisition Officer, there is an observation made that the market value of Rs.85/- per sq. meter is quite fair and reasonable. There is a similar statement found in the award published under section 11 of the said Act. However, the said observation is to the effect that he had made valuation at the rate of Rs.85/- per sq. meter. Under the proviso to sub section 1 of section 11, the Collector/Special Land Acquisition Officer cannot make an award without prior approval of the officer appointed by appropriate Government. 	 [Para 4,5]

heading: Award
HeadNote.description: Award - Recovery of amount paid by mistake - Not possible once reference is made to civil court by Land Acquisition officer. 	(Para 7)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination of market value - How to be assessed. 

The market value of the land is to be assessed keeping in mind the limitation prescribed in certain exceptional circumstances under Section 23 of the Act. A guess work, though allowed, is permissible only to a limited extent. The market value of the land is to be determined taking into consideration the existing use of the land, geographical situation/location of the land alongwith the advantages/disadvantages i.e. distance from the National or State Highway or a road situated within a developed area etc. In urban area even a small distance makes a considerable difference in the price of land. However, the court should not take into consideration the use for which the land is sought to be acquired and its remote potential value in future. In arriving at the market value, it is the duty of the party to lead evidence in support of its case, in absence of which the court is not under a legal obligation to determine the market value merely as per the prayer of the claimant.

There may be a case where a huge tract of land is acquired which runs though continuous, but to the whole revenue estate of a village or to various revenue villages or even in two or more states. Someone's land may be adjacent to the main road, others' land may be far away, there may be persons having land abounding the main road but the frontage may be varied. Therefore, the market value of the land is to be determined taking into consideration the geographical situation and in such cases belting system may be applied. In such a fact-situation every claimant cannot claim the same rate of compensation.      [Para 15]

heading: Reference
Validity
HeadNote.description: Reference - Rejection on ground of limitation - Validity - Alongwith notice u/s.12(2) of Act copy of award not supplied to claimant - Claimant applied for copy of award and after knowing contents of it immediately within one month filed reference - Reference is within period of limitation - Rejection of reference, not proper. 	(Para 3)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Possession of land taken much prior to notification u/s.4(1) - Land owner can initiate legal proceeding for recovery of possession - In case possession is not recovered, he would be entitled to rent and damage for the period during which Govt. retained the possession of property.
2004(5) ALL MR 435 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Para 3)

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Determination of disputes by Civil Court - There are 4 types of disputes that can be referred to Civil Court for determination - They are (i) as to the measurement of the land, (ii) as to the amount of compensation, (iii) as to the person to whom the compensation is payable, or (iv) as to the apportionment of the compensation among the persons interested.	(Para 12)

heading: Objection for acquisition
HeadNote.description: Objection for acquisition - Procedure under R.4 not followed - Land Acquisition Officer completely ignored specific objection that land in question is not suitable for developing playground viz. purpose for acquisition and there is alternative barren land - Enquiry by Land Acquisition Officer being farce, it impaired decision making process of State Government in issuing notification under S.6 - Report under S.5-A cannot be sustained - Notification under S.6 set aside. 	(Paras 12, 16, 17, 18, 20, 22, 23, 31, 33)

heading: Natural Justice
Land Acquisition Reference
HeadNote.description: Natural Justice - Land Acquisition Reference - No opportunity given to claimant to adduce/produce evidence in the Reference - If the opportunity is not given to claimant to adduce and produce evidence in the said Land Acusition Reference, held, it would result into miscarriage of justice - Claimant should get an opportunity to contest/prosecute the said Land Acquisition Reference on merits with the view to do the substantial justice to the parties.			(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Compensation disbursement
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Compensation disbursement - Challenge to - Amicable settlement between plaintiff and defendant as to sharing of compensation amount by 40% and 60% respectively - Record reveals that plaintiff had given suit land to his abandoned wife towards her life-time maintenance - Wife entitled to entire amount of compensation - Since in pursuance of amicable settlement she has received 60% compensation, plaintiff is estopped from challenging the same - Suit by husband for recovery of compensation fallen to the share of wife, rightly dismissed.		(Para 5)

heading: Acquisition of land
Hearing of objection
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Hearing of objection - Collector's report that property in dispute was acquired for construction of garbage treatment plant in view of several notices by Pollution Control Board and directions by Supreme Court - Collector had inspected site personally, found it away from Churches and other historical monuments - Application of mind not lacking - Decision to acquire land was duly taken in Cabinet Meeting and communicated to Collector who then communicated to Acquisition Officer - S.7 also substantially complied with - Interference with acquisition, not warranted.	(Paras 23 to 29)

heading: Notional income
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value of acquired property - Evidence of agricultural expert - Notional income - Held, the Reference Court was justified to discard the evidence of agricultural expert on the ground that the same has not been evaluated on the basis of the actual yeild, but only on the basis of notional income which is without any basis. 2010 ALL SCR 2152 - Ref. to.			(Para 14)

heading: Consequence
Not considered
HeadNote.description:
Report of LAO recommending acquisition - Without considering objections raised - Consequence - Petitioners raised specific objections that an application for putting up SEZ in properties is already pending before State Govt. - Also, that acquisition would gravely affect working of educational institution in vicinity - Some alternative site for proposed acquisition also suggested - That apart, petitioners also brought on record that no public purpose is involved in proposed acquisition - Not considered - Except holding a site inspection to find out nature of land and existence of trees, no application of mind by LAO while submitting his report - Both report u/S.5A and consequent notification u/S.6 vitiated - Liable to be quashed. 
2013 ALL SCR 2381, 2013(1) ALL MR 817 Rel. on. 	(Paras 12, 13, 15)

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Acquired land purchased by land owner as a means of access to his house property at the rate of Rs.125/- per sq.m. - Held, the said price cannot be the market value of the land in the open market - The Court in such circumstances would have to determine the price which a willing purchaser would offer to such acquired land. (Para 13)

heading: Withdrawal from acquisition
HeadNote.description: Withdrawal from acquisition - Direction sought by way of writ of mandamus - On the basis of internal correspondences between Development Authority and State Govt. whereby Development Authority communicated its decision to withdraw from acquisition and sought approval of State Govt. - Held, on basis of such communications mandamus cannot be issued - When acquisition is made by following due process of law, land vests in Govt. and cannot be reconveyed to the owners merely because some land was left unutilized. 	(Paras 15, 16, 18)

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Compensation - Determination of market value - Factors to be considered. 

Comparable instances of sale of lands which have proximity from time angle as well as situation angle, can be considered and suitable adjustments can be made having regard to various positive and negative factors. In case of acquisition of a large area for a specific purpose, deductions can be made by way of development charges and also deductions can be made for largeness of the land. However, in the instant case The notification under Section 4(1) of the Act was published in the official Gazette dated 13/2/1986 i.e. more than 5 years prior to that published in respect of the land with which Reference court was concerned in the instant case. The applicant has also not produced any cogent evidence on the similarity of the nature of the acquired land as compared to the land of the said award. Hence the applicant cannot claim that the market value of the acquired land can be determined on the basis of the said two sale deeds.          [Para 23,27,28,32]

heading: Market value
Determination of
Its location irrelevant
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination of - Acquired land is tenanted paddy land - Its location irrelevant - Government had offered Rs. 150/- per sq. meter for such lands in other villages - No evidence to support extraction of salt - Tenants held entitled to Rs. 150/- per square meter. 	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Application for reference
Limitation, when starts
HeadNote.description:
Application for reference - Limitation, when starts - Expression "from date of Collector's award" under proviso to S.18 means date on which award is communicated to party - Award declared in 1990 - Case of applicants that they came to know about award only in 2012 - Acceptable, in view of fact that their predecessor lived in one place whereas disputed land situated in another place - That being so, application for reference filed in 2012 itself not barred by limitation - Rejection on ground of delay of more than 20 years, not sustainable. 
AIR 1961 SC 1500 Rel. on. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Application under
Limitation for
HeadNote.description: Application under - Limitation for - An application under S.28-A of the Act seeking enhanced compensation on basis of another award in respect of the lands covered under the same notification is to be filed within a period of three months from the date of award - Neither the Land Acquisition Officer nor the Reference Court has the power to condone the delay under the Act. 2003(4) ALL MR 347 (S.C.) - Ref. to.			(Para 10)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Land acquired for establishment of Amravati University - Higher compensation was awarded in similar judgment in which land was acquired under S.4 notification for establishment of Amravati University - Same rate of compensation liable to be awarded in this case.  (Para 2)

heading: Interest
HeadNote.description: Interest - Land acquired for housing scheme by state housing board - Allottees of plots liable to pay interest to board on differential amount between tentative price and final price @ 8% from date of deposit or payment of enhanced compensation by board till payment of differential amounts by said allottees. W.A. No.1760 of 2004 Dt. 28-2-2006 (Ker.) Partly Reversed.			(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Reference
Not justified
HeadNote.description: Reference - Refusal to register without giving opportunity of hearing to applicant - Not justified - Order of refusal, liable to be set aside. 	(Para 6)

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Compensation - Determination of - Reliance on sale instances - Sale instances should be bona fide transactions for its reliance - If sale instances are not bonafide, reference court can refuse to use sale instances of higher value for fixing market value. 
2012 ALL SCR 159 Foll. 	(Paras 18, 19)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - Large area of land of forty guntas sought to be acquired for establishment of Medical Research Centre - Factors to determine fair market value are location of land, potentialities, surroundings, condition of acquired undeveloped lands, expenditure required to develop acquired land, its proximity to various places in the town - High Court relying on solitary instance of small piece of land of four guntas awarding Rs.99,000/- per gunta - Apex Court taking into consideration various factors for determining fair market value reducing valuation to Rs.70,000/- per gunta as just and reasonable - Award of High Court set aside. 	(Paras 20, 21, 22, 23)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Comparable awards and sale instances - Acquisition of land from four villages for establishing a university - Compensation in case of one village determined on basis of award made in respect of adjoining village - However compensation of same amount was not awarded - Rather, a reduction of 12% applied in view of fact that acquisition in instant case was notified in 1983 whereas acquisition in the other village was notified in 1984 - Held, such reduction is not justified as in the comparable case of adjoining village - Sale instances of 1982 and 1983 were relied by court - Such sale instances will also be relevant for acquisition notified in 1983 - Compensation enhanced to make the same as in case of adjoining village.

50 (1993) DLT 40, 93 (2001) DLT 150 Ref. to. 	 [Para 12,15]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Judgement and award referred, is regarding acquisition of land in same village for same project - Reference Court justified in relying on said judgment while awarding compensation. 	(Para 7)

heading: Compensation
Comparable sale instance
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Comparable sale instance - Reference Court relied upon four sale deeds, by which some of co-owners had sold their undivided right to purchasers - Pursuant to such sale deeds, possessions of specific portions of land had been given to purchasers, not considered by Reference Court - Whereas lease deed relied upon by claimants were rejected on ground which was factually incorrect - Even though nature of acquired land was disclosed by witness of respondents, Reference Court did not compare it with the land in award relied by claimants - Reference Court failed to consider several relevant aspects - Matter liable to be remanded back for fresh consideration. 	(Paras 13 to 17)

heading: Reference
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Reference - Limitation - Notices under S.12(2) of the Act issued to petitioners on 13-10-2003 - Petitioners receiving copy of contents of the award on 09-12-2003 and on the very same day they filed the reference under S.18 of the Act - Reference filed by the Petitioners, held, was within the period of limitation. 2010 ALL SCR 778 - Rel. on.	(Para 6)

heading: Practice and procedure
Absence of advocate
HeadNote.description: Practice and procedure - Absence of advocate - After entrusting the matter to an Advocate, appellant under bonafide belief that Advocate would attend and communicate what steps are to be taken - However, Advocate never attended the matter - For fault of the Advocate, the litigant should not suffer - Held, it would be appropriate to accord one more opportunity to the appellant to adduce his evidence.	(Para 4)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Enhancement of compensation - Application by petitioner to produce certified copies of settlement reports, letter from the Bank about landing rates and extract of notification of the Government of India under S.48 of Income Tax Act - Petitioners claiming that these documents supported their claim for enhanced compensation - Held relevancy of these documents can be considered only at time of appreciating the evidence and hence permission could not have been refused at the admission stage.

2009 ALL SCR 2400 - Rel. on. (Paras 8 to 10)

heading: Award
HeadNote.description: Award - Reference seeking enhancement of compensation - Dismissal of reference application - On ground that application filed beyond prescribed period of limitation - Is an award within meaning of Act - And reasons recorded by Reference Court is a judgment within meaning of S.2(9) of Civil P.C. - Against such an award appeal u/s.54 shall lie, irrespective of fact whether enhancement in compensation awarded or not. (Para 8)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Reliance placed on sale deed of land not similar to land in present case - Acquired land is admittedly tenanted agricultural land - Land in sale deed relied is not so - 50% deduction for purpose of fixing market value as per sale deed not sustainable - Compensation awarded by relying on sale deed not liable to be upheld.

2005 (3) ALL M.R. 824, 2011 ALL SCR 2723 Ref. to. (Para 16)

heading: Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Award of reference court - Challenge to - Market rate fixed by reference court of the acquired land appearing to be just and proper - Therefore, held, no interference is called for with the impugned judgment and award. (Para 7)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Sale instances cited must be comparable to land under acquisition - Without producing evidence about comparability said instances cannot be relied upon.	(Para 6)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Substantial area of property of appellant lost in acquisition - No evidence produced before Reference Court about nature of sale deed land and whether it is comparable with acquired land - In the interest of justice Reference Court directed to decide reference afresh after hearing parties on the question of nature of land.	(Para 8)

heading: Delay in filing
HeadNote.description:
Appeal against award for land acquisition - Delay in filing - Application for certified copy of award filed ten years after date of award - Appeal was filed after lapse of one and half year after obtaining certified copy - Held, delay of nearly eleven years in filing appeal, cannot be condoned.
2013 ALL SCR 3236, 2013 ALL SCR 1340 Rel. on. (Paras 8, 9, 12)

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
Entitlement to receive
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Compensation - Entitlement to receive - Dispute between appellant and respondent regarding ownership of acquired land - Respondent produced sale deed on record to prove his ownership - On contrary appellant did not produce any title document to support his claim - Promulgated survey record shows name of respondent and there is no other name figuring in it - On contrary appellants produced matriz document which did not confer title - Once survey records under Land Revenue Code came into force, matriz records lost their value - None of witnesses of appellant say that possession of acquired land was taken from them - However respondent in his written statement as well as oral evidence stated that possession of acquired land was taken from him - Respondent is entitled to receive compensation. 	(Paras 13, 14, 15)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Acquisition of land of project affected persons - Alternate land allotted and given possession of - Government cannot thereafter withdraw from acquisition - Whether notice of hearing was given or not is of a little consequence.	(Para 6)

heading: Reference under
HeadNote.description: Reference under - Execution of award in reference - Court need not impose condition of furnishing bank guarantee from decree-holders. (Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Reference Court considered compensation for land, things attached to land - Reference Court was well within its power to consider compensation for irrigable land valued on basis of Sale statistics in respect of lands in vicinity - Further considered value of standing Orange trees which were required to be valued separately - Award of Reference Court is to be upheld.

Sale instances were 2 years prior to date of notification under S. 4. Thus, on this basis since market value of land in vicinity was about Rs.18,000/- per hector, that too prior to two years to notification under S. 4 of Act, Reference Court considered acquired land as irrigated land, of which advantageous H. 3.57 R. was perennially irrigated, 0.80 R. Cultivable but fallow land and Pot Kharab land 0.20 R. were differently assessed for computing market value thereof. Separate compensation was not awarded for cattle shed as it was easily removable shed and capable of being taken away. Reference Court in facts mentioned justifiably awarded enhanced lump sum compensation for 1150 standing Orange trees on land at rate of Rs. 500/- per Orange tree rightly without adopting capitalizing method or using multiplier method after considering evidence of expert horticulturist as there was no dispute regarding number of Orange trees standing on land and compensation for irrigable land was already considered. As permission was sought by land owner to cut other trees for fuel and wood, other trees were not computed for to be valued. Since compensation for land was assessed considering it as perennially irrigated land sourced by water from well, separate compensation for 1150 standing orange trees could not have been computed by usual capitalizing by multiplier method. Lump sum compensation was granted as allowable in facts and circumstances of this case for assumption that damage was bound to result to standing Orange trees when possession of land was taken by Collector. Since wisdom of overall compensation awarded by reference Court appears assured just and fair returns to owners of acquired land, not further enhancement to it or reduction from it is necessary. Award of Reference Court is liable to be upheld.					           [Para 11,12]

heading: Urgency clause
First attempt failed
HeadNote.description: Urgency clause - Propriety of invocation of - Government trying to acquire land requisitioned 46 years before - First attempt failed - Second attempt made three years thereafter - Held time gap of three years was too long to justify invoking of urgency clause which resulted in depriving the respondents of their right to raise objection against acquisition of the premises.			(Para 13)

heading: Compensation
Challenge as to
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Challenge as to - Acquired land was adjacent to abadi land and has building potentiality - Evidence shows that claimant prepared layout of acquired land for making plots and selling them but could not do so due to acquisition proceedings - Comparable sale deeds of similar plots showing that said plots were sold at rate of Rs.1 per sq.ft. were duly proved - Compensation awarded @ Rs.1 per sq. ft., proper.        (Paras 6, 7)

heading: Market value
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Determination on basis of sale instance - Acquired land was a part of fully developed plots situated in settlement zone and in commercial area - Sale instance land and acquired land were similar in nature - Acquired land is a narrow strip of land having width of only 2.5 meter as against wider sale deed land, deduction of 50% to be made in price - Since acquired land was within set back area which could not be used for construction, further deduction is to be made - Sale instance is of one year back, annual increase of 10% to be made in price - Considering above, market value is fixed at Rs.1,000/- per sq. mtr. 
2009(5) ALL MR 1022 (S.C.) Foll. (Para 14)

heading: Compensation
Ref.	(Paras 3, 4)
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Value adopted for compensation for acquired plots of land will hold good for several plots of land if acquisition is made pursuant to same preliminary notification - Hence, held, there was no reason to award different amounts in respect of other lands acquired under the same notification. 

2011(1) ALL MR 293 - Ref.	(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Application under land scheme to allot alternative land - Land allotted twice was not acceptable to appellant and he did not deposit any amount, rather asked for cancellation of the same - He approached Chief Minister and obtained allotment in commercial area which was not permissible - C.M. was also not a competent Authority to grant alternative allotment of land - Held C.M. ought to have directed competent authority to consider the grievance and should not have passed the order himself. 

AIR 2010 SC 2620, AIR 1994 SC 2148 - Rel. on. (Para 15)

heading: Sale deed
HeadNote.description:
Determination of market value - Sale deed - Nature of plot in sale deed similar to that of the acquired land - Therefore, held, this transaction should be the best for determination of the market value of the acquired land.

2009(5) ALL MR 1022 (S.C.) - Ref. to. (Para 20)

heading: Enhancement of compensation granted by Reference Court
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation granted by Reference Court - No reference pending under S.30 of the Act before any reference Court - As such, held, the amount of compensation would have to be disbursed in accordance with such final adjudication. (Para 5)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Land in another case is just 20 metres away from land in present case - Evidence is corroborated by evidence of witness that both lands are close to one another and of same nature - Compensation in earlier case for similar land was awarded at Rs.21/- per sq. meter - Taking note of gap of time compensation awarded at rate of Rs.23/- per sq. meter in present case - Reference Court justified in relying upon award in previous case - Appellants unable to establish any dissimilarity in acquired land and land in previous case - Compensation awarded by Reference Court not liable to be interfered with. 	(Para 6)

heading: Objection to acquisition
HeadNote.description: Objection to acquisition - Time limit of 30 days - In a given case, Collector can always consider objections which are raised even after 30 days as there is no prohibition against Collector considering said objections. 	(Para 6)

heading: Acquisition of land
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - For construction and development of international airport - Challenge - Ground that an airport already exists and second airport is not needed - Also, that size of land acquired is in excess of requirement - Held, Project has already been approved by Civil Aviation Organization and Central Govt. - Requirement of second airport, suitability of land and area needed for construction are all subjects within domain of experts - Environmental aspects as also socio-economic impact of project have been duly considered - Disputed land held by petitioners is in middle of other lands already acquired - If it is not acquired, project itself may not be workable - Challenge of petitioners, not tenable. (Paras 12, 13, 14, 16, 22)

heading: Availability of
HeadNote.description: Additional benefits under S.23(1-A) - Availability of - Acquisition proceedings commenced on 5-3-1983 by issue of S.4 notification - Award passed on 1-3-84 - Land owners not filing appeal before High Court from order of Reference Court but filing application under O.41, R.33, CPC - Held, even in absence of appeal they were entitled to benefit under S.23(1-A) on the basis of their application under O.41, R.33, CPC. (1994)5 SCC 593, AIR 2010 SC 1308, AIR 2004 SC 1989 - Rel. on.	(Paras 16, 18, 21, 22)

heading: Compensation
Market value
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Market value - Determination - Court has to see whether acquired land has got building potentiality.

While determining the value of the property acquired one has to see whether the land has got the building potentiality to be used for the building purposes in the immediate or in near future.  (1995)2 SCC 305 - Rel.on. [Para 13]

In the instant case the acquired lands were near residential housing colonies, amount of compensation fixed by Reference Court @ Rs.1,75,000/- per acre was proper. As far as the question of grant of higher compensation than what is claimed by the claimants goes, the Reference Court has observed, and rightly so, that even before the representation before the Land Acquisition Officer, the claimants had stated that in event of their being not satisfied with the award, they reserve the right to go before the Civil Court for determination of just and reasonable compensation.(Paras 16, 23 to 26, 36, 38 to 40)

heading: Road widening
HeadNote.description: Road widening - Plaintiff had given undertaking to remove fencing when required for public purpose - Plaintiff failed to do so - Defendant Corporation removed fencing without acquiring land - Defendant is liable to pay damages for fencing material - Decree of First Appellate Court is liable to be upheld.	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Value of land of sale instance cited was Rs. 176/- per sq. yards - Land acquired was slightly away from nearly town but had potentiality for urban development, commercial, industrial and residential - Held reduced value from Rs.176 to Rs.120 was just and reasonable and contention that it ought to have been reduced by 60% can not be accepted. (Para 14)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Acquired land forming boundary of the railway property - Bound to be smoke and noise pollution - Deduction of 80% from purchase price of comparable sale deed made by Reference Court and further deduction made on account of distance of about 770 meters from comparable sale deed land - Held 80% deduction ought to be reduced to 50% and further deduction of 30% for distance of 770 meters would be reasonable - Sale price of Rs.2272/- reduced to Rs.796/- per sq. meter on the above two accounts. 			(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Compensation
Enhancement
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Enhancement - Challenge - SLAO initially awarded compensation of Rs.11,000/- per Hectare - Reference Court however enhanced it to Rs.22,000/- per Hectare considering sale instance of 1 Hectare land which was for Rs.30,000/- - Quality, fertility, potentiality and location of acquired land also considered - That apart, 7/12 extract which disclosed that claimant was taking crops of cotton, tur & jawar in acquired land which was sold in nearly located market, also taken into account - Impugned enhancement appears to be proper & adequate - No interference.		(Para 12)

heading: Compensation
Appeal
HeadNote.description: Compensation - 3 H 67 R land acquired for rehabilitation of villagers - Land acquisition Officer granting total compensation of Rs.2,85,159/- - Land was situated near State high-way, near the river, was of black soil with good irrigation potentiality and also NA potentiality - Appeal - Reference Court granting compensation at Rs.1,50,000/- per hectare - Respondents were very much emotionally attached as property was ancestral property and were satisfied with award of Reference Court - Held price determined by Reference Court was just and proper.  (Paras 15, 16)

heading: Compensation
Claim for compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Acquired lands were tenanted agricultural lands - Claim for compensation - Matter remanded to reference court in view of subsequent decisions in 2005(3) ALL MR 824 and 2011 ALL SCR 2723.  (Para 13)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Delayed payment of compensation - Liability to pay interest - Authority either has to pay compensation to claimant or deposit it in court in case of any doubt - Compliance of this would extricate authority from liability to pay interest under S.34.

In this case the compensation amount was partly paid at time of taking possession of land but remaining amount was paid after 5 years of passing of an award.  The reason for delay was that civil dispute was pending between family members of claimant.  In such case if payment could not be made to the claimant, the acquiring authority should have deposited amount in court within reasonable time to extricate liability to pay interest.  As the authority has failed to do so the petitioners are entitled to the interest as per mandate of S.34.  Held, that the said amount should be recovered from concerned officer at relevant time.					 [Para 5,6]

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - On basis of judgment and award of identical case - In that case, Reference Court granted compensation at rate of Rs.20,000/- per hectare - Said judgment and award attained finality - Facts and circumstances in both cases are similar and even notification u/S.4 also issued on same day - Compensation for acquired lands to be payable at same rate of Rs.20,000/- per hectare. 	(Para 5)

heading: Acquision of land for public purpose
HeadNote.description:
Acquision of land for public purpose - Portion of land excluded in final notification second notification not maintainable.

In the instant case, a bare perusal of the notifications issued under Sections 4(1) and 6 of the Land Acquisition Act would indicate that the land covered by Survey No.128/1 was a part of the said notification but since the same came to be excluded in the final notification under Section 28(4), the contentions raised for the appellants claimants that the said land stood acquired for a different purpose and, therefore, the purpose for which the land was sought to be acquired under Section 4 and 6 was unjustified, is not tenable.   [Para 13,15]

Even otherwise, if land already stands acquired by the Government and if the same stands vested in the Government there is no question of acquisition of such a land by issuing a second notification, for the Government cannot acquire its own land.   [Para 14]

heading: Dispensation of enquiry
HeadNote.description:
Dispensation of enquiry - Invocation of urgency clause - Acquisition for purpose of residential scheme for public at large invoking powers u/s.17 - Nothing has been produced to show that purpose of scheme could not have brooked delay of few months - And that conclusion of enquiry u/s.5A would have frustrated public purpose - Respondent authority failed to justify invocation of power of urgency and dispensation of enquiry - Direction to dispense with enquiry u/s.5A, improper hence quashed.

If the government seeks to invoke its power of urgency, it has to first form the opinion that the land for the stated public purpose is urgently needed. Such opinion has to be founded on the need for immediate possession of the land for carrying out the purpose for which land is sought to be compulsorily acquired. The use of power of urgency under Section 17(1) and (4) of the Act ipso facto does not result in elimination of enquiry under Section 5A and, therefore, if the government intends to eliminate enquiry, then it has to apply its mind on the aspect that urgency is of such nature that necessitates elimination of such enquiry. The satisfaction of the government on twin aspects viz; (i) need for immediate possession of the land for carrying out the stated purpose and (ii) urgency is such that necessitates dispensation of enquiry is a must and permits no departure for a valid exercise of power under Section 17(1) and (4).

Where the government invokes urgency power under Section 17(1) and (4) for the public purpose like 'planned development of city' or 'development of residential area' or 'Residential Scheme', the initial presumption in favour of the government does not arise and the burden lies on the government to prove that the use of power was justified and dispensation of enquiry was necessary. In the instant case, the respondents authority have miserably failed to show to the satisfaction of the Court that power of urgency and dispensation of enquiry under Section 5A has been exercised with justification. The action of authority dispensing with provisions of Section 5A shall not apply, if allowed to stand, it would amount to depriving a person of his property without authority of law.  [Para 18,19,20,22]

heading: Compensation
Challenge to
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Deductions made by Reference Court - Challenge to - Deduction of 45% on account of different dissimilarities considered to be just and appropriate - Held, the Reference Court was not justified to effect a deduction of 50% without specifying the deductions on account of each factor. 

2008 (17) SCC 436 - Rel. on. (Para 10)

heading: Natural Justice
Reference
HeadNote.description: Natural Justice - Reference - Reference Court framing fifteen issues - However, while discussing material on record, there is no specific finding given by Reference Court on each of the issues framed - Not giving such finding on each issues itself vitiated the impugned judgment - Held, the Reference Court is expected to scrutinize every piece of evidence adduced by the parties and arrive at specific finding on each of the issues. (Para 8)

heading: Sale deed plot
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Sale deed plot - Having regard to evidence led by parties, deduction made by Reference Court on account of development costs, on account of largeness of the acquired land, on account of nature and the location of the acquired land, vis-à-vis the sale deed plot, held, cannot be faulted. (Para 10)

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Sale deed plot and deduction - Sale deed plot having advantage of road on southern side which advantage the acquired land did not have - Held, it would be appropriate to make deduction of 10% on this court. (Para 11)

heading: Award under S.18
HeadNote.description:
Award under S.18 - Award becoming final before Land Acquisition Act came to be amended in 1984 - Application in 1989 to give benefit of amended provisions by enhancing solatium and interest allowed by High Court - Held award and decree passed by High Court in 1989 was without jurisdiction and nullity because award and decree having become final could not have been reopened for giving benefits under amended provisions in applications filed under Ss.151, 152 of Civil P.C. 
(1996) 5 SCC 501 Foll. (Para 21)

heading: Re-determination of compensation
Application for
HeadNote.description:
Re-determination of compensation - Application for - Filing of, beyond time limit of 3 months from date on which reference court disposed of O.P. - Rejection of, on ground of being beyond limitation, justified - Period of 3 months prescribed in Section 28-A, will start running from date of award of reference Court in O.P., and not from judgment of final appellate Court.

Under Section 28-A of the Act, the persons, who are aggrieved by the award of the Collector, but have not made an application to him under Section 18 of the Act, are entitled to move the Collector for re-determination of the compensation within three months from the date of the award of the Court. Section 3(d) of the Act defined "Court" as a Principal Civil Court of original jurisdiction, unless the appropriate Government has appointed a Special Judicial Officer within any specified local limits to perform the functions of the Court under the Act. Therefore, the only question to be decided in this writ petition is whether the time limit of three months starts running from the date of the award of the reference Court or from the date of the judgment of the Supreme Court in the SLPs filed by the petitioners and Ajjam Linganna. In the considered view of the Court, this aspect is no longer res integra in view of the judgments of the Supreme Court in (1996)1 SCC 85 and AIR 1997 SC 1793. In view of these authoritative pronouncements, the Court is of the considered opinion that in the instant case the time began to run to make an application for re-determination from 15.6.1994 i.e., the date on which the Court, which necessarily means the reference Court, disposed of O.P. No.471 of 1993. Therefore, the rejection of the petitioners' application on the ground that the same is beyond limitation cannot be found fault with.  (1996)1 SCC 85, AIR 1997 SC 1793 - Followed.   [Para 7,10]

heading: Application for redetermination of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Application for redetermination of compensation - Limitation of three months - Period is to be counted from date of award and not from date of knowledge by applicant.

Law of limitation may harshly affect a particular party but it has to be applied with all its rigour when the statute so prescribes. The Court has no power to extend the period of limitation on equitable grounds. The statutory provision may cause hardship or inconvenience to a particular party but the Court has no choice but to enforce it giving full effect to the same. The legal maxim "dura lex sed lex" which means "the law is hard but it is the law", stands attracted in such a situation. It has consistently been held that, "inconvenience is not" a decisive factor to be considered while interpreting a statute. "A result flowing from a statutory provision is never an evil. A Court has no power to ignore that provision to relieve what it considers a distress resulting from its operation.

2003(4) ALL MR 347 (S.C.) Rel. on. 						     [Para 13]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Land abutting two main roads - Rapid development in the vicinity - However High Court decreasing value of land by 1/3rd as it was little away from main road - Held 1/3rd deduction was not justified as land was developed by HUDA and 10% deduction of the value would be enough. 			(Paras 13, 15, 16)

heading: Interest on compensation

heading: Not provided for
HeadNote.description:
Computation of two years period - Exclusion of time taken to obtain certified copy of judgment or order in respect of stay order - Not provided for - In absence of any ambiguity or apparent omission doctrine of casus omissus cannot be invoked.

Section 11-A in terms does not provide for exclusion of the time taken to obtain a certified copy of the Judgment or order by which the stay order was either granted or vacated. Section 12 of the Limitation Act has no application to the making of an Award under the Land Acquisition Act. In the absence of any enabling provision either in Section 11-A of the Land Acquisition Act or in the Limitation Act, there is no room for borrowing the principles underlying Section 12 of the Limitation Act for computing the period or determining the validity of an Award by reference to Section 11-A of the Land Acquisition Act.		 [Para 15]

In the present case there is no ambiguity or any apparent omission in Section 11-A to justify application of the doctrine of casus omissus and by that route re-write 11-A providing for exclusion of time taken for obtaining a copy of the order which exclusion is not currently provided by the said provision. The omission of a provision under Section 11-A analogous to the proviso under Section 28A is obviously not unintended or inadvertent which is the very essence of the doctrine of casus omissus. 			 [Para 22]

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Compensation - Criteria to determine whether sale deed cited is comparable sale deed - Sale deed related to land measuring Acre 0.070 decimals and was sold for Rs.5,50,000/- per acre - Land in question was much larger in size and after giving discount High Court fixed value at Rs.3,00,000/- per acre - Held in the light of evidence on record it was just and proper compensation.

The following criteria provide a good indication of whether a sale deed may be comparable to the one in question : (1) it must be within a reasonable time of date of notification under Section 4(1) of the Act; (2) it should be a bonafide transaction; (3) it should be a sale of the land acquired or of the land adjacent to the one acquired; and (4) it should possess similar advantage. Although the land whose sale is evidenced in Exhibit 1 is not an excellent comparison in terms of area, the same indicates a sales transaction completed at around the same time as the acquisition of the said land. Moreover, Exhibit 1 also concerns a plot that is in geographical proximity to the acquired land. There being no other evidence on record, and since we are not inclined to remand the matter after such a long delay, Exhibit 1 must be relied on with necessary scrutiny and caution. Reliance could be placed on the said documentary evidence for determining and assessing the compensation of the acquired land after giving the necessary deduction. After giving some variations and discount, the High Court fixed the rate of the land at Rs.3,00,000/- per acre, which in the light of evidence on record was just and proper.  (1988)2 SCC 150 - Rel.on.  [Para 9,10,11]

Matter remanded back

heading: Re-determination of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Re-determination of compensation - Issue as to non-award of interest to landowners - Can be raised by an aggrieved person only by taking recourse to Art.226 of Constitution - As such dispute is not dispute which falls u/S.18 or 28-A(3) - Reference u/S.18 or 28A(3) cannot be considered to be an alternative statutory remedy available to landowner for getting question of non-award of interest u/S.28 or 34 decided by Civil Court.

	The dispute relating to non-award of the interest to the landowners, whether under Section 28 or Section 34 is not a dispute, which falls under Section 18 or/and 28A(3) of the Act. In other words, a reference under Section 18 can only be made by the Collector in respect of those issues, which are specified under Section 18. A dispute relating to non-award of interest payable to the landowners under Section 28 or/and Section 34 of the Act is not specified under Section 18 and hence it is not capable of being referred by the Collector to the Civil Court under Section 18 of the Act. It is also for the reason that payment of interest is statutory in character and being statutory, it is mandatory for payment once conditions specified under Sections 28 or/and 34 are fulfilled. It is true that once the interest is awarded by the Court under section 28 or by the Collector under Section 34 of the Act, it becomes the part of the award. However, it is hardly of any significance and has no bearing for deciding the question of remedy to challenge issue relating to the non-award of interest. Therefore, the dispute in relation to non-award of interest can be raised by an aggrieved person only by taking recourse to Article 226 of the Constitution in writ petition. In other words, reference under Section 18 or Section 28A(3) cannot be considered to be an alternative statutory remedy available to the landowner for getting the question of non-award of interest payable under Sections 28 or/and 34 of the Act decided by the Civil Court. 				 [Para 36,37,38,42,44,45]

heading: Land acquisition
Rejection
Appeal
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Prayer for quashing of acquisition proceedings - Rejection - Appeal - Appellants were paid compensation and possession was duly taken - Appellants also preferred reference on which higher compensation was awarded and matter attained finality upto Supreme Court - Writ petition filed thereafter challenging acquisition proceedings on ground that award was not valid - Same was rejected being barred by delay and laches and SLP also dismissed by permitting fresh challenge - Said findings do not suffer from any infirmity - Held, even if appellants permitted to lay fresh challenge they are required to overcome said legal bar of delay and laches which they failed to do - Therefore, appeal dismissed. Compensation

Acquisition of land - Compensation - Reference Court not granting any enhancement from sale deed year 1982-1992, the year of the notification under S.4 - Reference Court ignoring about increase in prices only because of absence of any evidence on actual development at the time of acquisition - Held, this view is erroneous since a proximate land holder is entitled to have increase in land prices taken into account irrespective of any actual development on the property since the land prices increased irrespective of such development.

heading: Notification under S.4
Declaration under S.6
HeadNote.description:
Notification under S.4 - Declaration under S.6 - Held, once S.4 notification is issued, necessary declaration under S.6 must be made as soon as possible for the reasons that the owner of the land would not be in a position to use the land as per his desire because of the uncertainty prevailing prior to declaration made under S.6 of the Act.

Once section 4 notification is issued, necessary declaration under Section 6 must be made as soon as possible for the reasons that the owner of the land would not be in a position to use the land as per his desire because of the uncertainty prevailing prior to declaration made under Section 6 of the Act. A prudent owner would not put up any construction on the land and normally no one would come forward to purchase the land also as there would be possibility of the land being acquired. Therefore, declaration under Section 6 is required to be made as soon as possible. So far as provisions of Section 11A of the Act are concerned, they expect the acquiring authorities to make the award within two years so that the land owner can get compensation after the award is made. He must get his compensation at an early date because his land is acquired, but in case of delay caused in paying the compensation, the land owner would be sufficiently compensated in terms of money for the reason that he would be getting interest on the amount of compensation payable to him as per the provisions of the Act. Thus, in fact, not much harm is caused to the land owner if some delay is caused. 			   [Para 16]

heading: Market value
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination of - Orchard land acquired for road improvement - Reference Court decided market value without considering sale instances - Also wrong assumption that land is not adjacent to road - No adequate reason given for determination of lower market value - Matter liable to be remanded to decide afresh. 2009 ALL SCR 2400, (1994)2 SCC 133 - Ref. to.	(Para 14)

heading: Compensation
Determination
Considerations
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination - Considerations - Market value arrived at after considering the escalation in the price and after deducting 40% towards development cost and another 40% on the ground that the acquired land was a paddy field and was not accessible by road - Valuation held proper.

In the present case, the Reference Court considered the location of the acquired land which had several facilities like road, church, market, bank, school etc. in the close proximity. The Reference Court also took into consideration the two sale deeds relied upon by the  respondent for the purpose of fixing the market rate of the acquired land. No doubt, the plots in the sale deeds were developed plots, whereas the acquired land was a paddy field. But, there was no illegality or perversity in the findings record by the Reference Court while fixing the market rate of the acquired land since the Reference Court has deducted 80% from the price of the sale deed plots on the ground that the sale deed plots were developed plots,  whereas the acquired land was a paddy field and below the ground level and did not have direct access to the main road. Thus, the deductions made by the Reference Court are proper and the Reference Court has correctly arrived at the market rate of the acquired land after making appropriate deductions on the basis of the sale deed plots and after taking into consideration the location of the  acquired land and facilities available near the acquired land. 	 [Para 8]

heading: Compensation
Enhancement
Proof
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Enhancement - Appellant claimed enhancement relying on valuation report and map drafted by expert - Proof - Valuation report not showing measurement of acquired house, foundation for calculation, test applied to determine rates, methods, parameters etc. - Contents of report not proved - Further, area of acquired house shown in map differ from area shown in award - Date of visit to acquired house and manner of preparing map also not mentioned by expert - Report and map suspicious - Enhancement cannot be allowed relying thereon. 2009 ALL SCR 1311 - Distinguished.	(Paras 16, 17, 18)

heading: Restoration of reference
HeadNote.description:
Restoration of reference - Rejection of application for - On ground that it is not maintainable - Reference has been decided on merit after holding that applicant and his counsel are absent and no evidence led to substantiate claim on merits - In such situation whether application is filed under O.9 R.9 or under O.9 R.13 or u/S.151 of C.P.C., does not make any difference - Rejection of application under O.9 R.9, not proper.

The Reference Court under Section 18 of the Land Acquisition Act has dismissed an application under Order IX, Rule 9 read with Section 151 of C.P.C for restoration of Land Acquisition Case No. 19 of 2001, on the ground that it is not maintainable, as the reference has been decided on merits by answering all the issues framed. The Court decided all the issues after holding that the applicant and his counsel are absent and no evidence has been led to substantiate the claim on merits. This dismissal of reference was on 13.08.2012. The petitioner who is the original applicant had two remedies, either to file Regular Civil Appeal under Section 54 of the Land Acquisition Act or to file an application under Order IX, Rule 13 of C.P.C to set aside the ex parte decree. The applicant has preferred an application under Order IX, Rule 9 read with Section 151 of C.P.C. for restoration of the Land Acquisition Reference case, proceeding on the footing that the reference need to be decided on merits after framing the application to lead evidence in support of the claim. In the absence of the applicant and his counsel before the Reference Court, which is an undisputed fact in the present case, according to the petitioner, the option with the Court was to dismiss the application in default and there was no occasion for the court to decide the case on merits. Therefore, presuming that the matter has been dismissed in the absence of the applicant and his counsel, the application under Order IX, Rule 9 of C.P.C is filed. The Apex Court has held that though an appeal would lie under Section 54 of the Land Acquisition Act against such an award, alternate remedy is also available. It further holds that whether the application is filed under Order IX Rule 9 of C.P.C or under Order 9 Rule 13 or under Section 151 C.P.C, it does not make any difference. In view of this, the trial Court has committed an error in holding that the application under Order IX Rule 9 of C.P.C read with Section 151 of C.P.C was not maintainable. The application should have been decided on its own merits and it should not have been dismissed on ground that it is not maintainable.

(1996) 5 SCC 701 Foll.        [Para 2,3,4,6]

heading: Reference to court
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Reference to court - Limitation - Time for making application - Whether six weeks or six months - Notice issued by Collector u/s.12(2) served on appellant on 22-2-1985 - After obtaining certified copy of award application filed on 8-4-1985 for making reference to Court - Held, application was not barred by time in absence of copy of award along with notice. 

The reason for providing six months from the date of the award for making an application seeking reference, where the applicant did not receive a notice under Section 12(2) of the Act, while providing only six weeks from the date of receipt of notice under Section 12(2) of the Act for making an application for reference where the applicant has received a notice under Section 12(2) of the Act is obvious. When a notice under Section 12(2) of the Act is received, the landowner or person interested is made aware of all relevant particulars of the award which enables him to decide whether he should seek reference or not. On the other hand, if he only comes to know that an award has been made, he would require further time to make enquiries or secure copies so that he can ascertain the relevant particulars of the award. What needs to be emphasised is that along with the notice issued under Section 12(2) of the Act, the land owner who is not present or is not represented before the Collector at the time of making of award should be supplied with a copy thereof so that he may effectively exercise his right under Section 18(1) to seek reference to the Court.   [Para 11]

In this case a careful reading of the averments contained in the application filed by the appellant under Section 18(1) shows that the notice issued by the Collector under Section 12(2) was served upon him on 22.2.1985. Thereafter, his advocate obtained certified copy of the award and filed application dated 8.4.1985 for making a reference to the Court. This implies that copy of the award had not been sent to the appellant along with the notice and without that he could not have effectively made an application for seeking reference. On behalf of the State Government, no evidence was produced before the Reference Court to show that copy of the award was sent to the appellant along with the notice. Unfortunately, this aspect has been totally ignored by the Reference Court which mechanically concluded that the application filed on 8.4.1985 was beyond the time specified in Section 18(2)(b). The learned Single Judge of the High Court also committed serious error by approving the view taken by the Reference Court, albeit without considering the fact that the notice issued by the Collector under Section 12(2) was not accompanied by a copy of the award which was essential for effective exercise of right vested in the appellant to seek reference under Section 18(1).  [Para 15]

Scheme for

HeadNote.description:
Maharashtra Project Affected Persons Rehabilitation Act (1999), Ss.10, 15, 16 - Maharashtra Resettlement of Project Displaced Persons Act (1976), Ss.2, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 20, 23 - Resettlement of project affected person - Predecessor of petitioner is project affected person having name in Sankalan Register - No representation is made by petitioner or his predecessor for allotment of land - 1st application in form of notice was made by petitioner after 15 years of acquisition of his land - Right to rehabilitation is subjected to availability of land - If petition is entertained, petitioner would have to deposit 65% of compensation amount granted in year 1997 - Further, State will have to acquire land to rehabilitate petitioner - Petitioners have signed petitions in English - Ground of illiteracy is not available - Petitions are delayed - Hence liable to be rejected.

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Notifications u/Ss.4 and 6 both dt.25.3.1981 by invoking urgency clause in S.17 - Possession taken on 20.8.1981 and land declared to be Protected Forest on 4.9.1990 - Land reacquired by notification dt.24.5.1995 by invoking urgency provisions for unspecified public purpose superseding earlier notification - Held, action of respondent State had denied appellant just and fair compensation for land from which he was dispossessed well over three decades ago - Acquisition of land set aside for non-compliance with S.11(9).
