heading: Land acquisition
Compensation enhanced
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Land owned by petitioner was part of land acquired by notification u/S.4 - Application u/S.18 rejected on ground of limitation - Court dealing with matter on merits also - Common award passed in relation to other lands forming part of same notification - Compensation enhanced - Petitioner entitled to make application under S.28A praying for compensation at par with that awarded to other land owners under same notification. 

 Where the reference made by the petitioner against the award passed on acquisition of agricultural land owned by him which was part of land acquired under a notification, was dismissed on ground of limitation but the court also dealt with the matter on merit, the petitioner is entitled to make an application under S.28A to consider his claim in terms with the award passed in References enhancing compensation pertaining to lands acquired by the same notification by which land belonging to the petitioner was also acquired.

When the Reference Court held that the Reference filed by the Petitioner was not filed within prescribed period of limitation, it should not have indulged in making any discussion on merits of the matter. In the circumstances, though the Reference Court might have dealt with the matter on merits also, the findings so recorded will have to be simply ignored and it has to be held that the Reference so made by the Petitioner, since was not made within the stipulated period was not liable to be adjudicated. In other words, the situation can be described as if no Reference under section 18 was made at all.

2008(5) ALL MR 264 Foll. 2007(2) ALL MR 472, 2002(4) ALL MR 585 (S.C.) Ref. to.   [Para 11,14,16]

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Entitlement to seek
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Entitlement to seek - Award passed on negotiations stating that land value has been fixed and appellant shall not be entitled for seeking any enhancement u/S.18 - However, supplementary negotiated award on structures and trees, does not contain any such stipulation - Same was passed unilaterally - Appellant filed writ petition within 6 months of said award, raising grievance regarding insufficiency of compensation - In view of facts and circumstances, held, appellant should be given opportunity to make request for reference u/S.18 for enhancement and other benefits. heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - On basis of post notification sale instance - Acquired land was falling in orchard zone and was agricultural and undeveloped land - It was situated at distance of 50 mts from Marcela-Savoiverem road, Village Panchayat and Primary Health Centre was at 300 mts distance - Land of sale instance sold @ ' 300/- per sq.mt - Though acquisition was in 2002, sale instance was of 2004 - However, that could not be discarded merely because it was post notification - Reference Court had deducted more than 20% towards sale transaction of 2004, more than 40% towards development and 10% being orchard zone - No fault found with findings of Reference Court awarding ' 90/- per sq.mt for acquired land. Determination of

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Impugned order quashed
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Without giving opportunity of hearing to owners - Is in breach of mandate of S.28A - Impugned order quashed - Matter remanded for reconsideration. 			(Para 3)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Claim for - Reference court awarded enhanced compensation of Rs.22,500/- per hectare to claimant for his dry crop land - However, appellant claiming further enhancement on basis of judgment of High court in other connected appeals in which land involved was similar to land of appellant - In those appeals compensation of Rs.65,000/- per hectare was awarded - Claimant also entitled to enhanced compensation of Rs.65,000/- per hectare. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Reference
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Limitation - Notice u/S.12(2) was not served on claimant - Period of limitation of six months is to be computed from date of Collector's award - Date of award is to be comprehended as date on which communication of passing of award to claimant takes place - Award was communicated on 16.05.1988 - Reference filed on 21.06.1988 is within limitation.

2012(3) ALL MR 434 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Resumption of land from allotee
HeadNote.description: Resumption of land from allotee - Land allotted in 1973 for manufacture of sheet glass by investing about Rs.4 crores and providing employment to as many as one thousand workmen - Without taking any steps to start factory respondent started selling acquired land by 2004-05, 118 sale deeds were executed - Purchasers of land had not made any diligent title search to find out title of respondent - Such persons cannot insist on impleadment in these proceedings and the respondent cannot complaint about want of 'Resumption Notice' and infact was liable to make over to the State all the profit that it has illegally and unjustifiably reaped by misutilization of lands allotted to it without setting up industrial unit. 	(Paras 19, 20, 21)

heading: Acquisition of land
Setting aside of
Challenge
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Setting aside of - Challenge - State initially invoked urgency clause u/S.17(4) but subsequently departed therefrom and allowed land owners to file their objections - Objections considered by Collector - Report of Collector duly considered by State Govt. and notification u/S.6 issued - Possession taken prior to passing of award - Compensation paid after taking over of possession - No illegality in acquisition of land - Impugned order, set aside.

Sections 17(1) and Section 17(2) vest power and jurisdiction in the State to take possession of the land even prior to the passing of the award. Section 17(4) enables the State to take such possession even by dispensing with the requirement of the opportunity contemplated under Section 5A of the Act. Sections 17(1) and 17(2) on the one hand and Section 17(4) operates in two different fields. It is extent of urgency or emergency that would determine the application of the respective clauses/sub-sections of Section 17 of the L.A. Act. In other words, even though the urgency clause under Section 17(1) and Section 17(2) may be invoked in a given case, the opportunity of filing objections under Section 5A of the L.A. Act need not be dispensed with and can still be afforded. However, if the provisions of Section 17(4) are invoked, the State would be empowered to dispense with the requirement of affording opportunity under Section 5A and take possession prior to making of the award. The dispensation of the opportunity contemplated by Section 5A by invoking Section 17(4) is not an invariable consequence of the invocation of Sections 17(1) or (2).      [Para 16]

What has happened in the present case is that even though the State had departed from its initial stand of invoking Section 17(4) of the Act and had given to the land-owners the opportunity contemplated by Section 5A, it had taken possession of the land prior to the passing of the award by invoking the provisions of Section 17(1) of the L.A. Act.     [Para 17]

In the present case compensation under Section 17(3A) was paid (on 18th April, 2006) after the date of taking over of possession (on 17th March, 2006), time and again, it has been held by the Court that the said fact by itself would not invalidate the acquisition. 

AIR 1964 SC 1217, 2004(5) ALL MR 1170 (S.C.), (2009) 10 SCC 689 Ref.to.  [Para 18]

heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Challenge, on ground of non-consideration of sale instances of lands having similar potentiality - Court considered sale instances of similar lands of same quality situated in different villages as except one, no other sale instance available from same village - It also considered evidence of expert land valuer who after considering quality, fertility and location of acquired land stated its market value in range of Rs.1 lakh per hectare - Determination of compensation of Rs. 90,000/- per hectare for acquired land, proper - Also mango trees standing on acquired land were 25 years old, each tree giving income of Rs.1,000/- per year - Compensation for four mango trees fixed at Rs.9,000/- per tree and for 22 berry trees at Rs.1000/- per tree - Total compensation of Rs.3,28,000/- granted by reference Court, proper. 	(Paras 14, 15, 16, 17)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Determination as to market value of acquired land - Land of area 11,000 sq.mtr was acquired in year 2000 for widening road - Claimants sought enhancement in compensation on basis of sale deed of year 1997 where area of 405 sq.mts was sold @ Rs.200/- per sq.mtr - Not considered by Reference Court on premise that acquired land was located in setback area and it being located within 40 mts of road widening land, lacks building potential and was tenanted agricultural land - By relying on judgment in Land Acquisition Case No.85/2003, Reference court enhanced compensation at Rs.40/- per.sq.mtr for bharad land and Rs.80/- per.sq.mtr for garden land - Not proper - Sale deed being in same vicinity and proximate in point of time to acquisition, was best evidence which ought to have been considered - Report of Govt. Valuer who valued structure in acquired land at Rs.16,19,800/- also not considered - Survey records did not show any tenant in respect of acquired lands - Considering vastness of area, allowing necessary deductions towards development cost and giving 10% escalation, market value of acquired land would be 159.97 per sq. mtr., rounded off to 160/- per sq.mt. - Claimants are also entitled to Rs.16,19,800/- towards value of structures in land. 2009(5) ALL MR 1022 (S.C.), (2005) 6 SCC 454, 2008 (2) GLR 499 Ref. to. 			(Paras 16, 17)

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - Appellants granted compensation @ Rs.235/- per sq. yd. - In all other cases covered by same notification compensation enhanced @ Rs.325/- per sq. yd. - Therefore, in the interest of justice compensation enhanced to said extent - However, appellant would not be entitled to any statutory benefit for period covered by delay in filing SLPs. 	(Paras 4, 6)

heading: Compensation
Determination
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination - Special Land Acquisition Officer awarded compensation @ Rs.2000/- per acre - Reference Court awarded Rs.6000/- per acre - Two sale instances for the similarly situated lands acquired for same project, produced on record, in which competent authority awarded Rs.24,000/- per acre - Reference Court however ignored the same on ground that it is not binding or quality of said land is high - Observation made by Reference Court is contrary to record - Hence, held not sustainable - Appellant, held entitled to compensation @ Rs.24,000/- per acre. 2012(4) ALL MR 470 (S.C.), 2001(4) ALL MR 550 (S.C.), 2007 ALL SCR 1608, AIR 1976 SC 2219 Ref. to. 	(Para 10)

heading: Condonation of delay
Application for
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - Application for - Delay of 884 days in filing appeal against award of Reference Court under Land Acquisition Act - Applicant claiming that they were not aware of making of award therefore, applied for certified copy only after 9 months of passing of award - However, award shows that it was passed in open Court in presence of advocates of applicants - There was no explanation for delay of more than 9 months in applying for certified copy of award - Further, statement of applicants that they are Govt. institutions and they have to take approval from Govt. before filing appeal is not sufficient to condone delay of 884 days - Explanation given by applicants for delay was quite casual, unverifiable and hardly constitutes sufficient cause - Delay cannot be condoned. 	(Paras 5, 7, 10, 18)

heading: Land acquisition
Grant of compensation
Duty of court
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Grant of compensation - Duty of court - Amount of compensation that a court can award, is no longer restricted to the amount claimed by applicant - Court has duty to award just and fair compensation taking into consideration true market value and other relevant factors, irrespective of claim made by the owner.

2012 ALL SCR 2429, (1985) SCC 737 Ref. to. 	(Para 7)

heading: Issue of title
HeadNote.description: Issue of title - Whether triable in Reference proceedings - Reading of S.4 notification shows what was sought to be acquired - It states "all lease hold and other outstanding interest" of claimants are likely to be needed for public purpose - Thus, ownership rights were not at all sought to be acquired - Being so, question of title cannot be decided in Reference proceedings - Subject matter of Reference depends upon subject matter of acquisition. 2007(6) Bom.C.R. 156 Rel. on. (Paras 10, 11, 12)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - For planned development of Delhi - Challenge, on ground that notification does not mention particular purpose of acquisition - It was not necessary to mention particular purpose - Once planned development of Delhi has been specified that to be read with zonal plan applicable in area in question - Zonal plan shows that acquired area was reserved for institutional purpose which includes educational institute - Notification not bad for not mentioning that land was acquired for purpose of school. (1973) 2 SCC 337 Disting. (1975) 4 SCC 285 Rel. on.  (Paras 10, 13, 14)

heading: Award of compensation
Entitlement to
HeadNote.description:
Award of compensation - Entitlement to - Respondent not owner of land but having leasehold rights - Prescribed form of lease does not stipulate period of licensing right - Same would be perpetual - Respondent losing the holding rights over the land on account of acquisition by Govt. - Therefore, entitled to compensation.

	Under the Andaman and Nicobar Islands Land Revenue and Reforms Regulation, 1966, the ownership of the land vests absolutely in the Government, except by a conveyance executed by the Chief Commissioner. In the instant case, it is an undisputed fact that the license has been granted under Section 146 (ii) of Regulation, 1966 under Form AG3. The said prescribed Form does not stipulate the period of licensing right. In the absence of stipulation of period, the contention urged on behalf of Respondent No.1 that it is a perpetual license in respect of the acquired land is a tenable contention, particularly having regard to the classes of tenants defined under Section 141 of the Regulation, 1966 extracted supra. Respondent No.1 has acquired interest in the land in dispute, in terms of the notifications under Sections 4(1), 4(2) read with Section 17(1) of the L.A. Act, wherein the parts and parcels of land along with building structures, the trees and crops have been clearly mentioned. Such an interest could only be extinguished in terms of Section 162 of the Regulation, 1966. That is to say that the right of Respondent No.1 could be extinguished only in terms of a notification to acquire the land. That was done by the Lieutenant Governor of Andaman and Nicobar Islands, who issued notifications to acquire the land, building structures including the standing trees and crops. The Award has been passed on a part of this land. The Award on the remaining 6 hectares of land was not passed by the Land Acquisition Collector, even though the entire land including the building structures, the trees and crops had been acquired for the aforesaid purpose of establishing industry. Not awarding compensation as provided under Section 11 of the L.A. Act amounts to deliberate omission in discharge of statutory duty by the Collector, despite the statutory right vesting in Respondent No.1 for award of compensation in lieu of losing the holding rights over the land on account of acquisition of the same by the Government. Therefore, Respondent No.1 rightly approached the High Court praying that the Writ of Mandamus be issued to the Review Petitioners-Appellants to pass an Award of compensation in its favour in respect of the remaining land.

2013 ALL SCR 799, 2004(5) ALL MR 79 (S.C.), AIR 1965 Mysore 222, AIR 1968 SC 1045 Disting. 		 [Para 11]

heading: Land acquisition
Determination of compensation
Comparative fail deed
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Determination of compensation - Comparative fail deed - Petitioners relying on two sale deeds dt.24/1/1974 to substantiate their claim for enhancement - However, failed to establish that land covered under said sale deeds having similar characteristics as land of petitioners - Courts below were justified in not relying on said sale deed - However, erred in ignoring to consider sale deed dt.19/3/1971 produced by respondents - Prima facie land of petitioners and land covered under sale deed dt.19/3/1971, are approximately having similar dimension and situated in same village - Therefore, compensation may be determined on basis of sale deed dt.19/3/1971 - Since acquisition took place in 1973, in view of escalation in price of lands compensation can be determined by adding 15% of value of consideration per year. heading: Land acquisition
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Notification u/S.17(3) of Karnataka Act - Challenge - On ground that no personal notice served to land owner due to which he lost opportunity to file his objection - Submission however made that objections were filed by land owner but not considered by Authorities - Same is contrary to pleadings in Writ Petition - That apart, notification u/S.16(2) also published in Gazette, which is a proof of possession being taken by Authorities - Panchnama of taking over of possession also produced - Land owner taking contradictory stands in matter of possession also - Attempt made by land owner that he is still in possession, is of no avail - Thus, publishing of impugned notification, held proper. 			(Paras 9, 10, 11)

heading: Compensation
Legality
HeadNote.description: Compensation - 2/3rd deduction made from total acquired land - Legality - Land was acquired for development of road - Acquired land had non agricultural potentials - But, it was an undeveloped piece of land - On account of development of said land such as for raising infrastructure and civic amenties, 2/3rd deduction required to be made - No illegality.	(Paras 6, 7, 8)

Compensation
Entitlement to receive
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Compensation - Entitlement to receive - Parties claiming that they were owners of land acquired and therefore entitled to compensation - However, documentary evidence on record showing that party no.2 had title over acquired property - Hence, party no.2 entitled to receive compensation. Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Rental compensation - Enhancement of - Petitioner claiming rental compensation for period subsequent to S.4 notification - Rental compensation had been awarded at 8% of market value of property as on S.4 notification - Petitioner ceased to be owner from date of S.4 notification itself - There is no question of paying rental compensation for period subsequent to S.4 notification - Compensation cannot be enhanced. HeadNote.description:
Lapsing of proceedings - Compensation neither paid to appellants nor deposited in court - Award predated the commencement of 2013 Act by well over five years - S.24(2) of 2013 Act comes into operation in favour of appellants and proceedings initiated under old Act stand lapsed.
2014(2) ALL MR 923 (S.C.), 2015(2) ALL MR 940 (S.C.), (2015) 8 SCC 544, (2015) 3 SCC 541 Rel. on. (Para 6)

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Determination of true market value - Applicants filed reference for grant of compensation for acquired land - Applicants relied upon certain documents of allotment of pieces of land by Goa Housing Board - However, said documents were neither marked as exhibits nor were considered by Reference Court - Further, acquired land was admeasured 342 sq.mtr., but in impugned award, compensation granted only for 290 sq.mtr. - Matter needs to be remanded to Reference Court for reconsideration. 			(Paras 6, 8)

heading: Land Acquisition
Determination of Compensation
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition - Determination of Compensation - Whether based on market value prevailing in year 1996 or 1989 - Consent agreements were entered into in year 1989 for handing over possession of land - Notification u/S.4 issued in year 1996 - However, declaration and consent awards were passed in year 1997 - Possession was taken after payment of 80% -90% of compensation to the incumbent - Additionally rent was also disbursed in lieu of occupation - Failure at the part of State Govt. to take steps for acquisition of land for seven years - Not proper - It would be totally unjust to ask land owners to abide by consent terms executed way back in year 1989 and hand over land to state Govt. at rate which prevailed in 1989 - As there was deprivation of possession and usufruct for 7 to 8 years, that could not be compensated in terms of payment of meager rent merely - Hence, determination of compensation based on market rate of year 1996 proper. 	(Paras 8, 9, 10)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Grant of statutory benefits - Period of stay before Reference Court, is not a relevant consideration for grant of statutory benefits - No such exclusion of period contemplated u/S.28 of LA Act - Only reference is the date of dispossession - Liability to pay interest starts to run from that date. 			(Paras 3, 4)

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - On basis of sale instances - SLAO has granted compensation initially at rate of Rs.12,000/- per hectare - Considering prevailing market price of surrounding lands at that time i.e. Rs.20,000/- to Rs.30,000/- per hectare, Reference Court enhanced compensation at rate of Rs.24,000/- per hectare - It appears to be just and fair. heading: Land acquisition
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Application for redetermination of compensation - Maintainability - On ground that reference had already been filed u/S.18 - However, same was dismissed on technical ground of non-payment of Court fees - Reference did not fructify nor entertained consequently not answered - Disentitlement to benefit u/S.28A would arise when reference u/S.18 is entertained and answered - Application u/S.28A maintainable. 2002(4) ALL MR 585 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Award of compensation
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Award of compensation - Challenge - Well and trees found on acquired land - SLAO however treated said land as partly bagayat and partly jirayat - No reason given for arriving at such conclusion - Held, in absence of reasoning, entire land is to be treated as bagayat land - Claimants entitled to market value @ Rs.1000/- per Aar. 	(Paras 7, 8, 9)

Validity
HeadNote.description: Reference - Rejection on ground of limitation - Validity - Alongwith notice u/S.12(2) of Act copy of award was not supplied to applicant - As applicant could not effectively make reference without copy of award - Applicant applied for certified copy of award and after receiving it filed reference which was beyond period of six weeks from receipt of notice u/S.12(2) - Reference cannot be said to be filed beyond period of limitation - Rejection of reference, not proper. 2012(3) ALL MR 434 (S.C.) Ref. to. 			(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Reference u/S.30
Determination
HeadNote.description: Reference u/S.30 - Whether, appealable u/S.54 of LA Act or u/S.96 of CPC - Determination - Reference u/S.30 is not related with determination of amount of compensation, but related with adjudication of title - Adjudication u/S.30 is therefore, not an "award" as contemplated u/S.54 - It can only be challenged by filing appeal u/S.96 of CPC. 1980 Mh.L.J 619, AIR 1970 Gujarat 37, 2006 (2) ALT 477, 1997(1) BLJR 1 Ref. to.  (2009) 16 SCC 1 Disting. 	(Para 12)

heading: De-acquisition of land
Notification as to
Legality
HeadNote.description: De-acquisition of land - Notification as to - Legality - While dealing with the same matter Supreme Court had held that power of re-conveyance could not be exercised after vesting of land with State Govt. under provisions of S.48 of LA Act - Ignoring said mandate, High Court in writ petition filed by land owner, directed State to decide representation of land owner - State thereafter issued notification for de-acquisition which is in gross violation of judgment of Supreme court - Hence, notification so issued held totally void and illegal - Same would confer no right to land owner. 	(Paras 5, 6, 7, 9)

heading: Reference application
Delay in filing
HeadNote.description: Reference application - Delay in filing - Award made on 18.1.1998 - Reference application filed on 17.10.2011 - Delay was due to fact that challenge to acquisition proceedings before different courts right up to Apex Court were pending till final order was passed by Apex Court on 15.9.2011 - Held, in the circumstances application should not have been rejected as it was filed immediately after pronouncement of judgment by Apex Court confirming acquisition proceedings. (Para 19)

heading: Value of land
Fixation of
HeadNote.description: Value of land - Fixation of - Is mainly based on factual position as revealed from the documents - Body language of witness or his conduct in court, not really relevant - Merely because witness was factually not correct on description, the evidence cannot be discarded. (Para 4)

heading: Land acquisition
Sustainability
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Claim for interest on compensation - Sustainability - Award passed on basis of agreement with land owner - Land owner accepted the agreed compensation amount without protest with a clear stipulation not to claim any additional amount - Compensation reflected in consent award deemed to have been taken into account all relevant factors including interest till date of agreement - Held, once land owner agrees for consent award and accepts compensation without protest, not only the remedy under the Act is lost but substantive cause of action also vanishes - Equitable considerations also cannot help because agreed amount was paid without delay - Therefore, claim not sustainable. 			(Paras 11, 12)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Constitution of India, Art.226 - Acquisition of land - Land in question notified u/S.4 of the State Act - However, S.6 declaration omit to include said land - Though after 2 years errata issued to correct said error, authority did not make any award or determine compensation - Proceeding lapsed by reason of failure of competent authority to make a proper award within time stipulated - High Court in exercise of power under Art.226, cannot make or direct to make an award - Direction issued by Division Bench so as to appoint Special officer for determination of compensation, also held erroneous.

It is true that the State enactment does not provide for a time limit within which the Collector must make and publish an award but that does not make any material difference in the light of Section 8 of the State enactment which applies the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 to the proceedings for their completion including making of an award and determination of the compensation after the declaration under Section 6 is published. Section 11-A of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, added to the statute in September 1984, provides that the award shall be made under Section 11 of the said Act within a period of two years of the declaration under Section 6 of the Act and if no award is made within the said period, the entire process for acquisition shall stand lapsed. In the case at hand the acquisition proceedings had started before the insertion of Section 11-A in the statute book. Proviso to Section 11-A would therefore apply and permit the making of an award within a period of two years from the date the Land Acquisition (Amendment) Act 1984 came into force. The said amendment came into force on 24th September, 1984. In terms of the proviso, therefore, the award in respect of the acquisition at hand could have been made till September 1986, by the latest. No such award was however made till September 1986 or at any time even thereafter till 2011, when the Collector did so, pursuant to the direction of the High Court. That award is on the face of it non-est in the eyes of law. The net effect of the above is that the entire process commencing with the publication of the Notification under Section 4 and declaration under Section 6 had lapsed and no award could be lawfully made or directed to be made by the High Court in exercise of its power under Article 226 of the Constitution of India. Inasmuch as learned Single Judge directed a decision to be taken by the competent authority it could only mean that the competent authority would be free to initiate the process of acquisition rather than taking the lapsed proceedings further by making an award beyond the statutory period. Inasmuch as the Division Bench directed compensation to be determined that too by appointing a special officer for that purpose, it fell in a palpable error.  [Para 9,10]

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - Land acquired was undeveloped land whereas sale instance was of developed land - Deduction to be effected - Deduction for internal roads, side gutters, railway line passing closer to acquired land than sale deed plot, relied on and land was communidade land - Sale instance related to year 2001 and compensation paid was @ of Rs.386/- per sq. metre - After considering deductions at aggregate of 65% and escalation at 10% per annum amount of compensation, held, works out to Rs.500/- per sq. meter. 			(Paras 13, 14, 15, 16, 17)

heading: Not justified
HeadNote.description:
Just and fair compensation - To be awarded to claimants irrespective of lesser demand made by them - Land of appellants and others acquired by same notification - Others were granted compensation at Rs.297/- per sq. yard - However, award to appellants limited at Rs.115/- per sq. yard on ground that they claimed compensation at said rate and paid court fee accordingly - Not justified - Court could direct appellants to pay difference of court fee.

	It transpires from the bare reading of the provision u/S.28A that even in the absence of exemplars and other evidence, higher compensation can be allowed for others whose land was acquired under the same Notification.

	The purpose and objective behind the aforesaid provision is salutary in nature. It is kept in mind that those land owners who are agriculturist in most of the cases, and whose land is acquired for public purpose should get fair compensation. Once a particular rate of compensation is judicially determined, which becomes a fair compensation, benefit thereof is to be given even to those who could not approach the court. It is with this aim the aforesaid provision is incorporated by the Legislature. Once we keep the aforesaid purpose in mind, the mere fact that the compensation which was claimed by some of the villagers was at lesser rate than the compensation which is ultimately determined to be fair compensation, should not be a ground to deny such persons appropriate and fair compensation on the ground that they claimed compensation at a lesser rate. In such cases, strict rule of pleadings are not be made applicable and rendering substantial justice to the parties has to be the paramount consideration. 

	In order to ensure that the land owners are given proper compensation, the Act provides for 'fair compensation'. Once such a fair compensation is determined judicially, all land owners whose land was taken away by the same Notification should become the beneficiary thereof. Not only it is an aspect of good governance, failing to do so would also amount to discrimination by giving different treatment to thepersons though identically situated. On technical grounds, like the one adopted by the High Court in the impugned judgment, this fair treatment cannot be denied to them.

	From the human rights perspective, persons belonging to the weaker sections are disadvantaged people who are unable to acquire and use their rights because of poverty, social or other constraints. They are not in a position to approach the courts even when their rights are violated; they are victimized or deprived of their legitimate due. Here lies the importance of access to justice for socially and economically disadvantaged people. When such people are denied the basic right of survival and access to justice, it further aggravates their poverty. Therefore, even in order to eliminate poverty, access to justice to the poor sections of the society becomes imperative. In the instant case, it is the poverty which compelled the appellants to restrict the claim to Rs.115/- per sq. yard, as they were not in a position to pay the court fee on a higher amount.

	It is the aforesaid weighty consideration which justify award of compensation to the appellants at the rate of Rs.297/- per square yards.

	Simply because the appellants had paid court fee on the claim at the rate of Rs.115/- square yards could not be the reason to deny the compensation at a higher rate. This could be taken care of by directing the appellants to pay the difference in court fee after calculating the same at the rate of Rs.297/- per square yards. 

2016 ALL SCR 778 Rel.on.	 [Para 6,7,12,13,16]

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Whether proper
HeadNote.description:
Enhancement of compensation - Grant of higher compensation than claimed by claimant - Whether proper - Considering judgment in case of Ambya Kalya Mhatre [2011(6) ALL MR 974 (S.C.)], held that if Reference Court finds that higher amount is the actual market value of acquired land, it can grant a higher compensation.

	In the instant case, the Reference Court assessed the evidence of the respondent applicant, the material brought on record by him vis-a-vis the various facilities and amenities available to it and last but not the least the Sale Deed in support of his case. Besides, the Reference Court also assessed the evidence of the valuer who had examined the Sale Deeds and on a consideration of the judgment in Ambya Kalya Mhatre [2011(6) ALL MR 974 (S.C.)], rightly came to a conclusion that the Reference Court could grant a higher compensation if the Court finds that the higher amount is the actual market value of the acquired land. The Reference Court for that matter considered the Sale instances dated 2/05/2008 and 12/05/2008 though in respect of small developed plots and that there was no evidence in rebuttal led by the respondents and on consideration of the fact that there was an escalation in the land prices by 10% each year held that the market value of the acquired land as on the date of Section 4 Notification was Rs.222/- per sq. mt. in respect of some survey holdings and Rs.189/- per sq. mt. in respect of the two survey holdings. The Reference Court for that matter had also considered the plea raised on behalf of the appellant that the lands were agricultural tenanted lands and being hit by Section 2 of the Goa Land Use (Regulation) Act, 1991. However, the Reference Court considered the judgment of the Apex Court in Goa Housing Board [2011 ALL SCR 2723], and made an appropriate deduction in respect of the land qua the issue of tenancy as also that in Vishnu Naik [2008(5) ALL MR 844], and after making 50% deduction from the market value of the lands which were the subject matters of the Sale instances arrived at the market value of the lands at Rs.189/- per sq. mt. and Rs.222/- per sq. mt. The Reference Court for that matter was equally seized of the fact that the two survey holdings were the large tracts as compared to the other survey holdings and made further deduction of 15% and fixed the market value at Rs.189/- per sq. mt. The findings thus rendered by the Reference Court therefore are not at all perverse much less illegal as to call for an interference in appeal. 2011(6) ALL MR 974 (S.C.) Rel. on. 2008(5) ALL MR 844, 2011 ALL SCR 2723 Ref. to. 		 [Para 22]

(Paras 3, 4, 5)

heading: Compensation
Award of
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Award of - Person entitled to compensation is also entitled to get interest on aggregate amount including solatium. - Splitting up compensation into different components for purpose of paying interest is not contemplated under S.34.

The compensation awarded would include not only the total sum arrived at as per sub-section (1) of S.23 but the remaining sub-sections thereof as well. It is thus clear from S.34 that the expression "awarded amount" would mean the amount of compensation worked out in accordance with the provisions contained in S.23, including all the sub-sections thereof.		 [Para 23]

What the legislature intended was to make the aggregate amount under Section 23 of the Act to reach the hands of the person as and when the award is passed, at any rate as soon as he is deprived of the possession of his land. Any delay in making payment of the said sum should enable the party to have interest on the said sum until he receives the payment. Splitting up the compensation into different components for the purpose of payment of interest under Section 34 was not in the contemplation of the legislature when that section was framed or enacted.	 [Para 24]

Compulsory nature of acquisition is to be distinguished from voluntary sale or transfer. In the latter, the landowner has the widest advantage in finding out a would-be buyer and in negotiating with him regarding the sale price. Even in such negotiations or haggling normally no landowner would bargain for any amount in consideration of his disinclination to part with the land. The mere fact that he is negotiating for sale of the land would show that he is willing to part with the land. The owner is free to settle terms of transfer and choose the buyer as also to appoint the point of time when he would be receiving consideration and parting with his title and possession over the land. But in the compulsory acquisition the landowner is deprived of the right and opportunity to negotiate and bargain for the sale price. It depends on what the Collector or the Court fixes as per the provisions of the Act. The solatium envisaged in sub-section (2) "in consideration of the compulsory nature of the acquisition" is thus not the same as damages on account of the disinclination to part with the land acquired.						 [Para 22]

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description:
Claim for enhanced compensation - Rejection by Reference Court - Challenge - Strip of land in middle of applicant's property acquired for construction of road, severing his property into two pieces - Sale instance relied by applicant for computing market rate of the land though relevant, ignored by Reference Court - Moreover, Reference court considered statement of expert that he would have to keep setback areas as also road widening areas on both sides as also severed portion - Yet, concluded that there was no material to prove that by reason of acquisition, remaining land was injuriously affected and denied severance charges - Therefore, award of Reference Court calls for interference - Applicant entitled to compensation on basis of enhanced market value and also severance charges to the extent of 20% of market rate fixed in his favour.

Reference Court was seized of the fact that the appellant had examined himself and an expert witness unlike the respondent who had examined none and moreover he had stated that the land was level and situated in the Settlement Zone. Reference Court was equally seized of the fact that the applicant had been unrebutted in his testimony that there was a scarcity of land available in Margao and prices of the land were rising and amenities like water, electricity etc. apart from important development were close to the acquired land. Reference Court had observed that the statement of the applicant was not at all disputed and still on examining the sale instance where the land was sold Rs.546/- per sq.mt. held that it did not bear any similarity to the acquired land and found favour with the contention on behalf of the respondents that it did not depict the true market rate of the land in the year 1990 and brushed it aside. Reference Court also did not consider the fact as borne out from the evidence that there was severance of the property and that he would suffer a loss when he undertook development. Reference Court ignored the sale instance on the specious premise that the vendors in that deed had transferred the undivided right in the land on which the buildings had been constructed by the confirming party in favour of the purchasers and chose to ignore the Deed as a reference for computing the market rate of the acquired land. It was completely lost on Reference Court that the parties had agreed to the price of the land and subsequent construction of the building had no bearing thereon and hence Reference Court was in error to ignore the sale instance.	 [Para 20]

Reference Court therefore ought to have considered the said sale instance in respect of the land sold in 1990 which was pursuant to an agreement of the previous year i.e. 1989 as the basis for computing the market value of the acquired land which it failed to do. For that matter Reference Court could also have looked into the award in respect of the land acquired much earlier where an award was made on 12/07/2001 where the market value of the acquired land was fixed Rs.267/- per sq.mt. in 1981 and acquired for the construction of multipurpose stadium at Fatorda in 1981. Reference Court ought to have relied on the said instance in particular in respect of an area of 1126 sq.mts. unlike the property of the applicant which was around 3000 sq.mts. and a portion admeasuring 227 sq.mts. had been acquired for the stated purpose. Therefore considering the sale instance of 1990 viz-a-viz the areas of the acquired land and after making necessary deductions towards development @30%, the market value is worked out at Rs.382/- per sq.mt. Further, giving 10% escalation the rate would work out to Rs.420/- per sq.mt. as on the date of the Section 4 Notification. 	 [Para 21]

Reference Court was conscious of the fact that the property of the applicant was severed but was unduly swayed by the statement of the appellant that he intended to do construction in the remaining portion of his property. For that matter, the Reference Court had considered the statement of the expert who had stated that he would have to keep setback areas as also the road widening areas on both the sides as also the severed portion and yet Reference Court in her wisdom hastily concluded that there was no material to prove that by reason of the acquisition, the remaining land was injuriously affected and denied the severance charges. This view of Reference Court calls for an interference in the face of the evidence led by the appellant and that of his expert and hence he is entitled to the severance charges to the extent of 20% of the market rate fixed in his favour.	 [Para 22]

Thus, the impugned Judgment and Award is modified to the extent that the applicant is held entitled to the compensation on the basis of the enhanced market value of the acquired land on the date of the Section 4 Notification Rs.420/- per sq.mt. He is also held entitled to the severance charges and all the other statutory benefits in terms of Section 23(1-A), 23(2) and 28 of the Act and the costs of the appeal.   [Para 23]

heading: Reference
Scope
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description:

It is well established that the reference Court gets jurisdiction only if the matter is referred to it under Section 18 or 30 of the Act by the Land Acquisition Officer and that Civil Court has got the jurisdiction and authority only to decide the objections referred to it. The reference Court cannot widen the scope of its jurisdiction or decide matters which are not referred to it. (1979)2 SCC 572, (1964)6 SCR 294, (2002)9 SCC 426 - Rel.on. 	 [Para 7]

In the instant case, there was no reference by the SLAO under Section 18 of the Act and the appellant-Samiti was not before the SLAO. Even the application allegedly filed on 12-10-1987 has rightly been characterized as suspicious as no mention has been made by the SLAO in the reference letter dated 12-10-1987. When such an objection was not referred to the Court, there was complete lack of jurisdiction. 			 [Para 11]

heading: Reference
Claimant is plaintiff
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Reference is an original proceeding to determine market value afresh - Claimant is plaintiff - Reference court cannot take into account the material relied upon by Special Land Acquisition Officer in the award unless it is produced and proved before the Court.

The claimant is a plaintiff and Reference is an original proceeding to determine market value afresh.  It is for the claimant to produce the material evidence for enhancement of the price of acquired land.  In the present matter, claimants have not produced any evidence as regards market value prevailing at the time of notification under Section 4(1) of the Act.  Similarly, the respondent/State has also not produced any evidence nor relied upon any material i.e. sale instances referred to by the Land Acquisition Officer in the award.  Suffice for our purpose to say that there was absolutely no evidence as regards the market value of the lands prevailing during the relevant period of the notification under Section 4 of the Act before the Reference Court.  It is enough to point out that in the light of the foregoing dicta of the Supreme Court, without more, the claimants were plaintiffs before the Reference court and References filed by them were the original proceedings to determine the market value of the lands and as the claimants failed to produce material evidence for enhancement of the price of the acquired lands, the Reference Court was not justified, at any rate, in awarding the enhanced compensation without any evidence before it.  As already pointed out from the judgment of the Apex Court, the Reference Court cannot take into account the material relied upon by the Special Land Acquisition Officer in the award unless it is produced and proved before the court. (1988)3 SCC 751 - Followed.  [Para 12,13]

heading: Approval by Commissioner
Word "approval"
HeadNote.description:
Approval by Commissioner - Is administrative in nature - He cannot sit in appeal over proposed award - Matter, however, referred to a larger Bench in view of conflicting view in 1998(2) SCC 573 and in Civil Appeal No.7695 of 1997, dt:13.11.1997.

Words and Phrases - Word "approval" - Connotation of.

What is provided under the proviso to Section 11(1) is that the proposed award made by the Collector must have the approval of the appropriate Government or such officer as the appropriate Government may authorise in that behalf. In our opinion, this power of granting or not granting previous approval cannot be equated with an appellate power. Black's Law Dictionary, 6th Edition, defines 'approval' to mean an act of confirming, ratifying, assenting, sanctioning or consenting to some act or thing done by another. In the context of an administrative act, the word 'approval' in our opinion, does not mean anything more than either confirming, ratifying, assenting, sanctioning or consenting. It will be doing violence to the Scheme of the Act if we have to construe and accept the argument of learned counsel for the respondents that the word approval found in the proviso to Section 11(1) of the Act under the Scheme of the Act amounts to an appellate power. On the contrary, we are of the opinion that this is only an administrative power which limits the jurisdiction of the authority to apply his mind to see whether the proposed award is acceptable to the Government or not. In that process for the purpose of forming an opinion to approve or not to approve the proposed award the Commissioner may satisfy himself as to the material relied upon by the Collector but he cannot reverse the finding as if he is appellate authority for the purpose of remanding the matter to the Collector as can be done by an appellate authority; much less can the Commissioner exercising the said power of prior approval, give directions to the statutory authority in what manner he should accept/appreciate the material on record in regard to the compensation payable. If such a power of issuing direction to the Collector by the Commissioner under the provision of law referred to hereinabove is to be accepted then it would mean that the Commissioner is empowered to exercise the said power to substitute his opinion to that of the Collector's opinion for the purpose of fixing the compensation which is opposed to the language of Section 11 of the Act. The Act has not conferred an appellate jurisdiction, on the Commissioner under Section 15(1) proviso of the Act. This conclusion is further supported by the scheme of the Act and Section 15A of the Act which is also introduced in the Act simultaneously with the proviso to Section 11(1) under Act 68 of 1984. By this amendment, the Act has given a power akin to the appellate power to the State Government to call for any records or proceedings of the Collector before any award is made, for the purpose of satisfying itself as to the legality or propriety of any finding or order passed or as to the irregularity of such proceedings and to pass such other order or issue such direction in relation thereto as it may think fit. Therefore it is not as if the acquiring authority namely the appropriate Government even if aggrieved by the fixation of compensation by the Collector it has no remedy.  It can very well exercise the power under Section 15A and pass such orders as it thinks fit, of course, after affording an opportunity to such person who is likely to be prejudicially affected by such order of the appropriate Government, therefore, it is clear that the statute when it intended to give appellate or revisional power against the finding of the Collector in the fixation of compensation it has provided such power separately in Section 15A of the Act. Therefore, if the Commissioner while considering the proposed award of the Collector under the proviso to Section 11(1) of the Act to grant or not to grant approval if he thinks that the order of the Collector cannot be approved, he can at the most on the administrative side bring it to the notice of the appropriate Government to exercise its power under Section 15A of the Act, but he cannot as in the present case on his own exercise the said power because that power under Section 15A is confined to the appropriate Government only.	 [Para 9]

heading: Compensation
Reduction
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Reduction - Challenge - Uniform rate of Rs.1,62000/- per hectare changed by High Court as Rs.50,000/- per hectare for irrigated and Rs.9,500/- per hectare for dry land - Compensation for orange trees, babul trees, fencing etc. set aside - Reliance placed on a judgment which was not related to acquisition in question - HC overlooked ample material produced by claimant - Documentary and oral evidence clearly establish that 85 to 90% of acquired land was irrigated on which different crops were grown - There were 325 orange trees, 40 babul trees, barbed fencing and a well - Besides, land in question was near to road and few Kms. away from Agricultural Produce Market - No rebuttal evidence produced by State - Only a Talathi was examined who had not personally visited acquired land - Order of HC, not sustainable - Finding that orange trees were not fruit bearing, also not justified - Said trees were 4 to 5 yrs. old and ripe for yielding fruits - Claimant entitled to compensation @ Rs.1,50,000/- per hectare for field - Rs.10,000/- for fencing etc. - Rs.600/- for each orange tree (pricing @ Rs.60 and taking 10 yrs. purchase as multiplier). heading: Reference
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Bringing legal representatives of deceased claimant on record - It is for the claimants to be diligent to bring legal representatives of the deceased claimant on record - It is not the duty of Land Acquisition Officer or the Collector to apply for bringing legal representatives of deceased on record.

It is always possible that the original claimants have left their places; have left the district and State and have settled somewhere else.  The Collector cannot keep track of all those subsequent developments and, therefore, looking to the role of the Collector under Sections 18 and 19, it has to be held that it is for the claimants or the applicants under Section 18 or the persons mentioned in sub-sections (a) and (b) of Section 20 to prosecute and pursue their claim.  They must be diligent and must take all the steps in prosecuting the reference which include bringing the legal representatives of the deceased claimant on record.  If some of the claimants or some of the persons mentioned in sub-sections (a) and (b) of Section 20 die during proceeding, then like all other civil cases, their representatives who are may be or other claimants must make an application to the Court for bringing the legal representatives of the deceased claimant on record.  In fact the Court issues notice to the claimants under the provisions of Land Acquisition Act as stated above then it is not only a notice requiring them to appear but it is also a notice that Civil Court has taken cognizance of the matter and the matter will be dealt with or decided by the Civil Court.  Therefore, even legally it is the duty of the claimants to take necessary steps in bringing the legal representatives on record.

In this background it has to be held that it is not the duty of the Land Acquisition Officer or the Collector to apply for bringing the legal representatives of the deceased claimant on record.  But it will be for the claimants to be deligent to bring legal representatives of the deceased claimant on record.   [Para 12,13]

heading: Reference
Bar of limitation
HeadNote.description: Reference - Bar of limitation - Notice of award received by claimant on 21.12.1987 - Said notice was however not accompanied with copy of award - Notice u/S.12(2) therefore, not effective - Certified copy of award received by claimant only on 3.2.1988 - Reference filed on 9.2.1988 not barred by limitation. 2012(3) ALL MR 434 (S.C.) heading: Enhancement of compensation
Method of averaging
HeadNote.description:
Enhancement of compensation - Three sale deeds of similar land executed in 1977, 1978, 1979 for Rs.1, 39, 130. Rs.1, 21, 600 and Rs.77, 500 respectively - Method of averaging - Held it is not desirable to take average of sale deeds, the transaction representing highest value should be preferred - Further appellants would be entitled to interest on solatium and additional market value. 

When there are several exemplars with reference to similar lands, it is the general rule that the highest of the exemplars, if it is satisfied, that it is a bona fide transaction has to be considered and accepted. When the land is being compulsorily taken away from a person, he is entitled to the highest value which similar land in the locality is shown to have fetched in a bona fide transaction entered into between a willing purchaser and a willing seller near about the time of the acquisition. In our view, it seems to be only fair that where sale deeds pertaining to different transactions are relied on behalf of the Government, the transaction representing the highest value should be preferred to the rest unless there are strong circumstances justifying a different course. It is not desirable to take an average of various sale deeds placed before the authority/court for fixing fair compensation. Held the appellants have made out a case for enhancement of compensation. Accordingly, the same is fixed at Rs.1,45,000/- per acre with all other statutory benefits including interest on solatium and additional market value.

2001(4) ALL MR 550 (S.C.), 2007(5) ALL MR 475 (S.C.) Rel. on.  [Para 15,18]

heading: Redetermination of compensation
Not permissible
HeadNote.description: Redetermination of compensation - Awarded by court in judgment u/S.54 of LA Act - Not permissible - Redetermination u/S.28A is available only in respect of award passed by Court under Part III of the Act comprising Ss.18 to 28A - Judgment of appellate court is not within purview of S.28A - However, if the State/authorities/claimants have approached the higher Courts for redetermination of quantum of compensation, as the case may be, the Collector, shall wait till a decision is finally rendered and thereafter award the compensation as per modified verdict of higher Courts. 	(Paras 3, 4, 5)

heading: Withdrawal from acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Withdrawal from acquisition - State Govt. cannot pick and choose some landowners and release their land from acquisition and deny same benefit to other landowners by creating artificial distinction - Classification on basis of nature of construction cannot be made.

Prior to October 26, 2007, the State Government did not have uniform policy concerning withdrawal from acquisition. As regards the guidelines provided in the letter dated June 26, 1991, this Court has already held that classification on the basis of nature of construction cannot be validly made and such policy is not based on intelligible differentia and a rational basis. What appears from the available material is that for release of the lands under the subject acquisition, no policy has been adhered to. This leads to an irresistible conclusion that no firm policy with regard to release of land from acquisition existed. It is true that any action or order contrary to law does not confer any right upon any person for similar treatment. It is equally true that a landowner whose land has been acquired for public purpose by following the prescribed procedure cannot claim as a matter of right for release of his/her land from acquisition but where the State Government exercises its power under Section 48 of the Act for withdrawal from acquisition in respect of a particular land, the landowners who are similarly situated have right of similar treatment by the State Government. Equality of citizens' rights is one of the fundamental pillars on which edifice of rule of law rests. Consequently, the Government has obligation of acting with substantial fairness and consistency in considering the representations of the landowners for withdrawal from acquisition whose lands have been acquired under the same acquisition proceedings. The State Government cannot pick and choose some landowners and release their land from acquisition and deny the same benefit to other landowners by creating artificial distinction. Passing different orders in exercise of its power under Section 48 of the Act in respect of persons similarly situated relating to same acquisition proceedings and for same public purpose is definitely violative of Article 14 of the Constitution and must be held to be discriminatory. The action of State Government in treating the present appellants differently although they are situated similar to the landowners whose lands have been released can not be countenanced and has to be declared bad in law.   [Para 24]

heading: Acquisition of land
Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Determination of compensation - Landholder aggrieved by award filing application for reference to civil court - Collector is bound to make reference - He cannot decide refernce on merit and refuse to make reference.

The scheme envisaged in Part III of the Land Acquisition Act as regards the reference to the Court and procedure therefor, does not vest in the Collector with any power to determine the objection raised by the landholders as regards the Award passed as that is the function which is left to the civil Court.  The Collector merely has to scrutinise the written applications made by the landholders and can only take a decision as to whether it has been made within the stipulated time as provided in the proviso to Section 18(2) of the said Act, and in case the Collector rejects an application for making reference to the Court, it is then the aggrieved landholder can, under Sub-section (3) of Section 18 of the said Act, prefer a revision to the High Court.  The State Government commits error by misconstruing S.18(3) and vesting power in the Collector to determine the reference made by landholder on merits which is not at all contemplated under S.18 of the Act.				 [Para 6]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Classification of lands on basis of land revenue assessment is just and proper.

As regards classification of the lands the land assessment is fixed after taking into consideration various aspects, such as, quality of soil, the condition of the land, topography and location of the lands. There is no dispute that applying modern methods of cultivation and by constructing bunds etc., the lands can be improved, but still the basic difference between the lands having fertile soil and the lands having ordinary or poor soil, cannot be ignored. If soil is very fertile in case of irrigated land, then there is possibility of more income, whereas in case the land is not so fertile, then even with the irrigation facility, such land would not give much income and at least to obtain more income, fertilizers and manures would be required to be used which would increase the cost of cultivation, if the soil is not fertile. Hence, it is apparent that all the lands cannot be treated alike and difference will have to be maintained on the basis of fertility of the lands. Hence, other things being equal, the land revenue assessment is the only criteria on the basis of which superiority or otherwise of the land can be judged. Therefore, classification done by the S.L.A.O. on the basis of land revenue assessment appears to be just and proper.  [Para 12]

Also, the market value of the land can be determined on the basis of following parameters.

(i)	Price paid for the same land or portion of it in recent years, after making all necessary allowances for lapse of time, advantage of situation and other possible differences between lands sold and the lands to be acquired.

(ii)	Price paid for similar lands in the vicinity in recent years after making all proper allowances for lapse of time, advantage of situation etc. and

(iii)	Net annual income from the land, which may be capitalised at a certain number of years, number of years dependent upon the nature of property, the state of money market and other circumstances of the case.  [Para 13]

HeadNote.description:

heading: Methods of valuation
Sale instances
Rel.on.			 [Para 22,24]
HeadNote.description:
Determination of market value - Methods of valuation - Sale instances - Refusal to take into consideration large number of relevant sale deeds - Refusal must be based on cogent and appropriate reasons.

For determination of the amount of compensation in terms of Section 23 of the Act, the methods of valuation which can be adopted for ascertaining market value are - (1) opinion of experts; (2) the price paid within a reasonable time in bona fide transactions of purchase of the lands acquired or the lands adjacent to the lands acquired and possessing similar advantages; and (3) number of years purchase of the actual or immediately prospective profits of the lands acquired. While adopting the second method, the transactions which are relevant, thus, are required to be taken into consideration. The Collector, the Reference Judge or the High Court without assigning appropriate reasons would not be entitled to discard one deed of sale and rely upon the other. It must be done on some legal principle, rationality and cogent reasons. Some other factors which are relevant for determination of the amount of compensation are - the nature and quality of land, whether irrigated or unirrigated, facilities for irrigation, presence of fruit bearing trees, location of the land, closeness to any road or highway, evenness of the land, existence of any building or structure and a host of other factors bearing on the valuation of the land. (1997)6 SCC 41 - Rel.on.			 [Para 22,24]

heading: Land acquisition
Determination
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - For project of infopark at Ernakulam - Special Tahsildar Cochin Refineries Ltd. whether empowered to act as Collector for project of infopark - Determination - As per S.3(c) of LA Act, Special Tahsildar can act as Collector only after issuance of specific notification by State appointing Special Tahsildar to act as Collector - State claiming that it has issued notification in 1989 appointing Special Tahsildar, Cochin Refineries to act as Collector for all acquisitions of land in Ernakulam district and Collector also by G.O. of 2005 appointed Special Tahsildar to act as Collector for project of infopark - By notification of 1989, State has empowered Special Tahsildar to act as Collector only in respect of land for which notification u/S.4(1) was already issued and not in respect of any fresh notification - Further, u/S.3(c) only appropriate Govt. and not District Collector has power to appoint any other officer as Collector - State has not issued any fresh notification u/S.3(c) appointing Special Tahsildar as Collector for project of infopark - Special Tahsildar Cochin Refineries not empowered to act as Collector for project of infopark. heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Mathematical formula by averaging prices of instance sales without any regard to location of lands cannot be a correct approach.

Such a mathematical formula completely disregards the location of the land which is acquired vis-a-vis the instance sale, the difference in the area acquired and the area of the sale instance and several other relevant factors in this regard. The area which was acquired was 1130 acres and 4 marlas, only a small portion of which abutted on the National Highway No. 8. Even if one was to disregard the quality of the land i.e. irrigated, semi irrigated or barren, one cannot be oblivious of the fact that the market value of land which abuts on the National Highway would be much more than the land which is away from it. A price of the land which is land-locked and which is further away from the National Highway cannot be the same as that which abuts on the National Highway. The formula which had been applied by the High Court, however, seems to indicate that the price of the entire land irrespective of the location of different parcels of land is the same. The formula which was applied by the learned single Judge of the High Court is obviously incorrect.  [Para 8]

heading: Public purpose
HeadNote.description: Public purpose - Land required for Siddhivinayak Temple Trust, Prabhadevi, Mumbai - Acquisition of plot adjacent to plot belonging to the Trust to enable thousands of visitors everyday to take darshan of Lord Ganesha - Held, acquisition was "for the public purpose" and in "interest of public" and cannot be interfered with at the instance of tenant of plot who was claiming of compensation - Mere allegation of mala fide acquisition by tenant is not sufficient to set aside acquisition when no objection was raised by owner of plot. Determination
Impugned order quashed

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Determination of market value of land - Land situated in fully developed area - Therefore, valuers of both sides relied on sale instances of built up area i.e. a flat - Same sale instances considered by both valuers - After necessary deductions on gross rate of flat, both valuers arrived at market value of land near about same i.e. Rs.3,700/- per sq.mtr. except deductions of some expenses considered by Govt. valuer - However, considering advantages of acquired land i.e. shape, locality, having facility of school, hospital etc. and distance between railway station and highway, claimant's valuer added 70% of Rs.3,700/- and held that market value should be Rs.6,300/- per sq. mtr. - Same is little bit on higher side - Instead 70% it should be 30% - Thus, valuation comes to Rs.4,810/- per sq.mtr. - Considering fact that land is situated in developed area next to railway station, claimant held entitled to compensation @ Rs.5000/- per sq.mtr. 	(Paras 38, 39, 40, 41, 42, 43)

heading: Valid
HeadNote.description:
Notifications under Ss. 4, 6 not indicating exercise of urgency powers - Possession of land given to acquising body even before initiation of acquisition proceedings - Compensation accepted though under protest - All facts indicating trappings of urgency - Award even though passed beyond two years of declaration under S.6 - Valid - S.11-A inapplicable -Section 11-A is intended to benefit land owner and to ensure that award is made within a period of two years from date of 6 declaration - Limitation prescribed by Section 11-A would however have no application to cases wherein landlord has delivered possession, either to the State or to the acquiring body, even before drawing of award and more so when such delivery of possession is by mutual consent during private negotiations - In such cases, acquisition can not be said to have lapsed by mere expiry of period of two years since declaration u/s 6.

In instant case Declaration under S.6 of the Land Acquisition Act was published in local newspapers but there was no information available as to whether it was sent for publication in Official Gazette and if so, whether it was published and on what date.  Therefore, the date on which the Notification under S.6 was published in local newspapers had to be taken as the date for commencement of limitation under S.11-A and the award was passed beyond the period of two years from that date, however, possession of the land was taken by the acquiring body from the claimant and this was before initiation of acquisition proceedings.  Thus, although urgency clause u/s 17(1) was not applied, in order to enable the respondents to take possession of the land immediately after notices u/s 9 and before declaration of the award, fact remains that petitioner was divested of the possession even before declaration u/s 6.  It is also admitted position that after award the petitioner has accepted the compensation, may be under protest regarding the quantum, upon service of notice u/s 12(2) of the Act.  All these admitted facts clearly indicate that the acquisition proceedings have all the requirements and trappings of urgency acquisition.  Although notice u/s 4 or declaration u/s 6 did not make a reference to Section 17(1), omission can be seen for obvious reasons.  The exercise of powers u/s 17(1) was not necessary in view of the fact that the land owners had delivered the possession to acquiring body by private negotiations in anticipation of the acquisition proceedings.  Even in the matters where the possession is taken at any stage, before the notice u/s 9(3) and (4) of the Land Acquisition Act, the limitation prescribed by Section 11-A would not apply, more so when the facts and circumstances clearly indicate that land owners were divested of the possession in favour of the acquiring body in view of urgency of the purpose.  [Para 5,6,8]

It is open for the petitioner to seek reference under S.18 or to claim rental compensation or enhanced compensation under S.28-A.	 [Para 12]
