heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description:
Determination of market value - Sale instances of a smaller plot of land, proximate to the situation and proximate to the time - Are relevant to find out the market value of large tract of land where other relevant evidence is not available - For want of definite evidence regarding sale of similar situated plots, the sale deeds produced by the claimants can be co-related to find out the index of the market value.

Sale instances of a smaller plot of land, proximate to the situation and proximate to the time, are relevant to find out the market value of large tract of land where other relevant evidence is not available. Against the backdrop of the aforesaid legal position, adverting to the evidence on record, it is seen that the acquired land is a large tract of land; it admeasures 85, 856 sq.metres. The acquired land is quite interior from the main road.  Though, there is conflicting evidence about the acquired land having access through a tar road, from the evidence, it is amply clear that the acquired land does not have direct motorable road from the main road. In so far as the civil amenities are concerned, the evidence suggests that the amenities like transport, water, electricity, temple, mosque and church etc. are at a distance of half a kilometre to one kilometre . The Dabolim Railway Station is also about 0.7 kms. In so far as the nine Sale Deeds which have been produced by the claimants are concerned, these relate to small plots of land of about 225 to 355 sq. metres. Those plots of lands at the time of sale were fully developed and abutting the main road. The plots that have been sold by these Sale Deeds are at a distance of about 0.8 kms from the acquired land. Strictly speaking, the sale instances produced by the claimants cannot be said to be comparable to the acquired land but asking the claimants to produce the sale instance of similarly situated large tract of land was asking the impossible. For want of definite evidence regarding sale of similar situated plots, the Sale Deeds produced by the claimants can be co-related to find out the index of the market value.  The broad factors that need to be kept in mind are that the Sale Deeds relate to developed small plots of land adjacent to the main road; the acquired land on the other hand is interior and one has to travel almost 1/2 km. to 3/4 kms. inside the main road to reach the acquired land. The acquired land is totally undeveloped though it is close to the already existing Sancoale Industrial Estate. The small plots of which the Sale Deeds were produced were sold for a price between Rs.100/- to Rs.132/- per sq.metre.  Where the Sale Deed of a developed plot is treated a comparable sale instance, 40% deduction needs to be made to find out the market value of undeveloped land. Then it cannot be overlooked that besides that the acquired land is undeveloped, there is difference in the location as well. As already indicated above, the Sale Deeds relate to the sale of plot of land which abut the main road whereas the acquired plot of land is situated in the area interior at a distance of more than half a kilometre from the main road.  This aspect also has to be borne in mind to arrive at the index of market value. AIR 1988 SC 1652 and 1998(1) G.L.T. 324 - Referred to.						 [Para 12,13]

heading: Land acquisition proceeding
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition proceeding - For purpose of State Highway - Provisions of State Act would be applicable - Central Act would stand excluded. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Compensation
Determination
Validity
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination - On basis of sale instances of small land - Validity - Court determined market value of large extent of land i.e. 15-18 bighas of land on basis of sale instance of land as no other comparable sale instance was available in same village - If no other comparable sales are available in same village, it is always open to Court to consider sales in adjoining villages during relevant period - Also, vendor in said sale instance is claimant in acquisition proceedings - Such sale could not be considered as comparable sale for fixing market value - Moreso when there are other methods for fixing compensation - Determination of compensation on basis of sale instance of small land, improper. 	(Para 14)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination of - Acquired land in close proximity to developed commercial and residential area within municipal limits - Sale instances produced related to smaller plots situated nearby - Rate of compensation must be subjected to deductions towards developmental costs - Compensation awarded by High Court at the rate of Rs.9 lakhs per acre raised to Rs.12 lakhs per acre - Land owners will also be entitled to statutory benefits under Ss.23(1A) and 23(2) on compensation awarded plus interest @ 15% p.a. under proviso to S.28.
2011 ALL SCR 1742, 2005(5) ALL MR 449 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Paras 16, 17)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Claim for - Compensation was awarded after considering all aspects like location of village, distance of land from city, quality of land etc. - Claimant failed to show that Court failed to consider any material piece of evidence - Court has not committed any error in determining market value of land - Claimant not entitled to enhancement of compensation. 	(Paras 15, 18, 20, 21, 23)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Imposition of 60% deduction on market value - Without making detailed discussion, justifying deduction - Matter remitted for fresh consideration on justifiability of imposition of 60% deduction on market value. 	(Paras 2, 5)

heading: Acquisition of land
Notification under S.4
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Notification under S.4 - Acquisition for public purpose - Notification duly published in two local papers and Official Gazette - No objection raised by appellant within 30 days under S.5-A - Neither S.4 or 5-A contemplates a personal notice - Hence S.45 was not attracted.

The provisions of Section 45 of the Act will not be attracted in cases where there is no obligation cast upon the authorities to issue notice to the persons interested once it is clear that neither Section 4 nor Section 5-A of the Act contemplates any personal notice to the person interested other than the objectors for the purpose of conducting inquiry under Section 5-A of the Act.  Therefore, the question of applicability of Section 45 in the case of the appellant-company would not arise at all as the appellant-company had note filed any objection under Section 5-A to the acquisition proceedings conseqeunt to the issuance of notification under Section 4 of the Act.	 [Para 16]

heading: Notification u/S.4
Quashing of
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Notification u/S.4 - Quashing of - Challenge - Notification issued for acquisition of land for purpose of expansion and systematic development of Surajkund Tourist complex i.e. for public purpose - Earlier proceedings in respect of same land were dropped in light of orders passed in M.C. Mehta's case in year 1996 restraining construction in the area - However, after modification in said order in 1998, State took fresh decision to acquire the land for public purpose - High Court erred in holding that State has not acted bonafide - Quashing of land acquisition applying doctrine of promissory estoppel and legitimate expectation, held erroneous. (Para 15)

heading: Land acquisition
Appeal by State
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Appeal by State - Against award of reference court - Compensation amount involved in matter very paltry - Such matters should not be brought in appeal - It not only deprives claimants of meager compensation but also consumes valuable judicial time - State directed to formulate policy, that land acquisition matters in which the stakes do not exceed some specified limit, say of Rs.25,000/- or even some higher limit, are not to be filed or even if filed are to be withdrawn. 	(Paras 6, 7, 18, 21)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Market value of land - Lok Adalat settlement whether can be relied upon.

In the instant case before the High Court a contention was raised that in a Lok Adalat Settlement, the market value of similarly situated land was fixed at Rs.22,000/- per bigha at the instance of the Union of India, pursuant whereto a Division Bench passed a decree on the said basis. However, the Supreme Court found that on what basis the aforementioned settlement in the Lok Adalat was arrived at is not known. Details of the land with regard to location, nature, advantages and dis-advantages pertaining thereto are absent. In absence of any detailed particulars showing the similarity of the land and/or the respective advantages and dis-advantages pertaining thereto, the said settlement had rightly not been made the basis for determining the market value of the land.   [Para 5,14]

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Dismissal on ground of bar of limitation - Period for filing reference is 6 months which can be curtailed to 6 weeks if claimant or his advocate was present at time of judgment - If claimant or his advocate not present on date of award, period of limitation of 6 weeks starts to run after service of notice u/S.12(2) - In absence of pleading regarding date of service of notice u/S.12(2) or regarding presence of claimant at time of award, period of limitation will not start running - In the instant case neither pleading nor evidence to show that claimant or his advocate were present at time of award or that notice u/S.12(2) was served on particular date - It was also not pleaded that claimants have not filed reference within 6 weeks from date of award - Award was passed on 30.11.1990 and reference was submitted on 30.01.1991 - Reference cannot be said to be barred by limitation - Dismissal of reference, improper. 	(Paras 12, 13, 14)

heading: Land acquisition
Sale instances
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Sale instances - No fixed criteria as to what would be the suitable addition or subtraction from the value of the relied upon transaction. 

In determining compensation for acquired land, price paid in a bona fide transaction of sale by a willing seller to a willing buyer is adopted subject to such transaction being adjacent to acquired land, proximate to the date of acquisition and possessing similar advantages. Of course, there are other well known methods of valuation like opinion of experts and yield method. In absence of any evidence of a similar transaction, it is permissible to take into account transaction of nearest land around the date of notification under Section 4 of the Act by making a suitable allowance. There can be no fixed criteria as to what would be the suitable addition or subtraction from the value of the relied upon transaction.    [Para 10]

heading: Land acquisition
Validity
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Allotment of alternative housing sites as special category of displaced person - Issuance of direction, for by High Court to State Govt. and Tamil Nadu Housing Board - Validity - Land was acquired for project of Railways of Mass Rapid Transport System - No scheme was framed in relation to said Railway project for providing alternative housing sites to project affected persons - In absence of such scheme order of High Court issuing directions to State Govt. and Tamil Nadu Housing Board for providing alternative land or housing site, improper. 1988 ALLMR ONLINE 492 (S.C.), 1990 ALLMR ONLINE 1210 (S.C.) Disting. 			(Paras 9, 12, 13, 15, 16)

Material issues

heading: Interest on solatium
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Interest on solatium - Claim for - interest on solatium would be payable if reference court has either not referred to it or has not rejected it expressly or by necessary implication - Claim for interest on solatium was not rejected by reference court - It was expressly kept open by High Court and liberty was given to institute proceedings before sub court after matter was resolved by larger bench as issue was ending before larger bench - Claimant entitled for payment of interest on solatium. 2007(5) ALL MR 475 (S.C.) headline: Land Acquisition Act (1894), S.23 – Compensation – Permission to withdraw 50% of enhanced amount of compensation as awarded by Reference Court without security – Validity.

heading: Compensation
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Permission to withdraw 50% of enhanced amount of compensation as awarded by Reference Court without security - Validity - Appellant claiming that permission to withdraw amount be granted to claimant only on furnishing of security - Lands of claimants acquired in 1996 and Reference court enhanced amount of compensation after period of approximately 17 years - Original claimants are not in position to furnish any security, while withdrawing amount of compensation - Considering interest of both parties and also fact that appellant is ready and willing to deposit entire enhanced amount of compensation awarded by Reference court together with interest and cost - Claimants are permitted to withdraw 25% of enhanced amount of compensation together with proportionate interest and cost without furnishing any security and balance 75% of enhanced amount of compensation together with proportionate cost and interest, permitted to be invested in fixed deposit in any nationalized bank.

heading: Notification u/S.6
Legality
HeadNote.description: Notification u/S.6 - Legality - Proposed acquisition was initiated for purposes of road access having width beyond four meters and in any case length of more than 200 meters - In view of Govt. Circular dated 7th April, 2003, approval of Town and Country Planning authority was required for such acquisition - Conditional approval was granted that right of way of road is to be maintained at minimum six meters - However, S.5A report shows that, at site it is impossible to have road having right of way of minimum six meters - At highest, what is possible at site, is road having width of hardly three meters and even laying road of three meters width, stair-cases to petitioners' two houses will have to be demolished - Circular also requires that at least 10 households to be benefited in respect of three meters wide road and length of less than 200 meters - Although as per S.5A report, about 13 households will be benefited by proposed road, material on record speaks otherwise - SLA Officer has purported to consider house of five objectors who are victims and not beneficiaries of proposed acquisition - Proposed acquisition is in totally breach of Govt. heading: Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation for fruit bearing trees - Determination of - There were jambhul, guava, mango, ber, coconut and chiku trees on acquired land - Evidence of claimant’s Govt. approved valuer shows that he produced relevant documents of inspection report, valuation report, being primary evidence, admissible in evidence - Further as per S. 45 of Act (1872) evidence of valuer being an opinion of third person on point of valuation of fruit bearing trees, is admissible in evidence - No other evidence produced by respondent-Government to lend support to valuation of trees finalized by SLAO - Market value of fruit bearing trees would be preferred @ 80% of valuation made by claimant’s valuer - As per report of claimant’s valuer market value of acquired trees comes to Rs. 11,68,925.64/- - 80% of said valuation accrued to Rs. 9,35,140.51/- - Claimant entitled to compensation for fruit bearing trees to tune of Rs. 9,35,140.51/-. 2011(6) Bom.C.R. 735 Rel. on. Re-determination of compensation

Maintainability

heading: Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Market value of land - Enhancement of - High Court determined market value of land at Rs.90/- per sq. yard - High Court considered sale deeds of 1981 under which properties were purchased by land owners and not sale deeds which were relied on by Reference Court as they were subsequent to notification of land acquisition - High Court has added 12% appreciation per year from 1981 to 1992 i.e. date of acquisition and arrived at market value of Rs.78/- per sq. yard - Additional value of Rs.12/- per sq. yard was added as escalation by taking note that there was steep increase in prices in Punjab - High Court while arriving at market value of property considered location of property, potentiality of property and appreciation of value - High Court properly determined market value of property - Market value need not be enhanced. Market value
Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Market value - Enhancement of - Appellants claiming that market value of land be fixed at Rs.15,402/- per acre - Appellants submitted that for acquisition of land in same village by notification dtd.19.12.1981 reference court awarded compensation of Rs.15,402/- per acre and State has accepted said amount of compensation - Land in question was acquired vide notification dtd.16.05.1981 - While determining market value, previous instances of acquisition in proximity for location and potential of land acquisition along with cumulative increase is relevant consideration - Time gap between two notification is only 7 months - No material changes pointed out during period between 16.05.1981 and 19.12.1981 - Appellants also entitled for compensation/market value at Rs.15,402/- per acre. heading: Land Acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - Total 9 hectares and 98 ares of land of claimant is acquired and compensation of Rs.1,00,000/- per hectare was granted for 7H 98 Ares deducting 2H of land on which orange trees were cultivated - Claimant on basis of sale deed of 1994 and 1996 which shows market price as Rs.50,000/- and Rs.75,000/- per hectare claiming further enhancement in compensation awarded for land - Land was acquired in 1997 i.e. just one year after sale deeds in question on which claimant is relying for enhancement - Considering material on record compensation of Rs.1,00,000/- awarded is proper - Claimant not entitled for enhancement - Claim regarding compensation for 100 mango trees is also not tenable as there was no evidence on record to establish existence of 100 mango trees when acquisition proceedings were initiated - However, land and trees are to be valued separately while determining compensation - Therefore, claimant entitled for compensation at Rs.1,00,000/ - per hectare for 2H of land for which no compensation was awarded as orange trees were cultivated on it. heading: Compensation
Claim for enhancement
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Claim for enhancement - Sale exemplar produced by claimant was in respect of small plot which was sold at rate of Rs.137.76 per sq. ft. - Such sale of small area as compared to acquisition of 9000 square meters can be taken into consideration after suitable deduction is made on account of development cost - Such land not cultivable - Further, State taken possession of part of land in 1984 and another part in 1992 - Land was in small town and was taken for construction of Govt. quarters and road - In view of facts, deduction of 50% would be proper, as sale deed was executed after 11 yrs. of possession of rocky land and moorum soil was taken - Thus, claimant entitled to compensation of Rs.70 per square feet which was market value assessed by Reference Court as well - And also others statutory benefits on compensation amount from date of award till realization. HeadNote.description: Compensation - Claim for enhancement - Sale exemplar produced by claimant was in respect of small plot which was sold at rate of Rs.137.76 per sq. ft. - Such sale of small area as compared to acquisition of 9000 square meters can be taken into consideration after suitable deduction is made on account of development cost - Such land not cultivable - Further, State taken possession of part of land in 1984 and another part in 1992 - Land was in small town and was taken for construction of Govt. quarters and road - In view of facts, deduction of 50% would be proper, as sale deed was executed after 11 yrs. of possession of rocky land and moorum soil was taken - Thus, claimant entitled to compensation of Rs.70 per square feet which was market value assessed by Reference Court as well - And also others statutory benefits on compensation amount from date of award till realization. heading: Award of compensation
HeadNote.description: Award of compensation - Benefits accruing from S.23(1)(A) - Claimants would not be entitled to the benefits accruing from S.23(1)(A) wherever the Awards u/s.11 are prior to the cut off date. 2005(1) ALL MR 459 - Rel. on.	(Paras 5, 7)

heading: Release of land
Prayer for
HeadNote.description:
Release of land - Prayer for - Rejection, on ground that possession of property had already been taken pursuant to award and same had been handed over to the authority (HUDA) - However, Rojnama not produced to show that physical possession had been taken - Nor any pleadings made in that regard - Held, unless property is taken possession of in accordance with law, no question of handing over property to HUDA, arises - Symbolic possession, will not serve the purpose - Matter remanded back to High Powered Committee.

2012(1) ALL MR 905 (S.C.) Rel. on. 	(Paras 13, 14)

heading: Delay
HeadNote.description:
Application for reference to court - Delay - Collector as a statutory authority and not as a court - Delay cannot be condoned by invoking S.5 of Limitation Act (1963).

1996(1) Mah.L.J.609(SC) Rel. AIR 1994 Bom 317 (FB) held no longer good law. (Para 6)

heading: Additional compensation
Starting point
HeadNote.description:
Additional compensation - Starting point - Possession of land taken prior to S.4 notification - Owner is entitled to compensation from date of notification and not from date of taking over possession.1995(2) SCC 142 Rel.On. 1995(6) SCC 355 and 1995(5) SCC 683 Overruled.

It is clear from Section 23(1 A) that the starting point for the purposes of calculating the amount to be awarded therender,at the rate of 12 per centum per annum on the market value, is the date of publication of the Section 4 notification. The terminal point for the purpose is either the date of the award or the date of taking possession, whichever is earlier. In the present case, possession of the land having been taken prior to the publication of the Section 4 notification, that terminal is not available. The only available terminal is the date of the award. The High Court, therefore, was in no error in holding that the appellants were entitled to the-additional compensation under Section 23(1A) for the period from date of notification to date of award. There is no room here for any construction other than that given above. It is only where a provision is ambiguous that a construction that leads to a result that is more just can be adopted. Having regard to its clear terms. Section 23(1A) must receive the only construction it can bear. The law has been correctly laid down in the decision in Special Tahsildar (LA) , P.W.D. Schemes v. M. A. Jabbar (1995 (2) SCC 142) and that it has not been correctly laid down in Asstt.Commr., Gadag Sub-Division v. Mathapathi Basavannewwa (1995(6) SCC 355) and, for that matter in State of H.P. v. Dharam Das (1995(5) SCC 683). [Para 5,6]

HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for public purpose - Land acquired for particular public purpose can be utilized for any other public purpose - Land acquired for civil aviation construction work - Land vesting in National Air Port Authority under S.13(1)(G) of National Air Ports' Authority Act 1985 - There is no illegality - No case made out for interference. (2011) 2 SCC 54 - Rel. on.		(Para 19)

heading: Enhanced compensation
Application for
HeadNote.description: Enhanced compensation - Application for - Refusal on ground that Land Acquisition Officer (LAO) had verified 66 sale deeds from neighbourhood within one year - Appellant had filed two sale deeds of his own lands in the vicinity sold a year before publication of notification under S.4 - LAO refusing to accept it on a surmise that lands must have been sold at inflated price based on prior knowledge of proposed acquisition of land - However, LAO unable to produce proof to support surmise - Held, evidence of vital nature of two sale deeds could not have been rejected on basis of such surmises and conjectures. 	(Para 10)

heading: Challenge
HeadNote.description:
Issuance of notification u/s.6 - Challenge - Respondent issued notification of acquisition for widening of road - Objection by petitioner that his land is not part of road already upheld by Land Acquisition Officer (LAO) under S.5A - Report of LAO in fact pointed out that disputed land is a drain - Said report not considered by respondent - No reasons disclosed for overruling report of LAO - Non application of mind - Notification u/s.6 liable to be quashed. 
2014(3) ALL MR 475 (S.C.) Ref. to.	(Paras 8, 9 )

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Reference applications under S.28(2) - Limitation - Decision under S.28(A)(2) is on par with offer under S.11 - Hence reference in S.18 to award will have to be read as a reference to award under S.28(A)(2) - Period of limitation provided in S.18 will apply - Starting point cannot be postponed till date on which copy of award is received by claimants.

There is no difference between an Award under Sub Section 2 of Section 28 (A) and an Award under Sub Section 11 to which Section 12 is applicable. It must be noted here that even Sub Section 1 of Section 11 contemplates an inquiry by the Collector into the objections of any person interested. Thus, the submission that the Award under Sub-Section 2 of Section 28(A) is not an offer will have to be rejected. It is an Award on par with an Award under Section 11 of the said Act.  [Para 9]

As provided in Sub Section (3) of Section 28(A), the provisions of Sections 18 to 28 are applicable to a Reference Application made under Sub Section 3 of Section 28(A) as far as the same may apply. As the Award under Sub-Section 2 of Section 28A is on par with an Award under Section 11, the reference in Section 18 to the Award will have to be also read as a reference to an Award under Sub-Section 2 of Section 28(A). Therefore, the period of limitation provided in Section 18 will apply to an Application for Reference under Sub-Section (3) of Section 28.  [Para 10]

Thus, it follows that the requirement of Sub Section 2 of Section 12 of the said Act of immediately issuing notice of the Award will also apply to an Award under Sub Section 2 of Section 28A. Therefore, as far as the limitation for filing Application under Sub-Section 3 of Section 28A is concerned, the period of limitation will be six weeks from the date of receipt of the notice from the Collector under Sub Section 2 of Section 12 or six months from the date of Collector's Award, whichever period shall expire earlier. It cannot be postponed till the date on which a copy of the award is received by the claimants.  [Para 11,14]

heading: Notification for acquisition
Publication
HeadNote.description:
Notification for acquisition - Publication - Assumption that because declaration under S.6 was published in official gazette notification under S.2 also must have been published in gazette - Is erroneous.

W.A.No. 1 of 2005 (Gauhoti) Reserved.

W.P. (C) No. 114 of 2000 Dt.7-1-2003 (Gauhoti) Approved. The question whether the notification issued under Section 4(1) was published in the Official Gazette is a question of fact and such question cannot be decided on assumptions and conjectures or inferences. Whenever the acquisition of land is challenged on the ground that the notification has not been published as per the mandate of the statute. In the absence of such evidence, the Court cannot decide challenge to the acquisition proceedings by assuming that the particular notification had been published as per the requirement of law. 					 [Para 13]

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - Land acquired admeasuring 572.50 Sq. mtr. - Market rate in ready reckoner Rs.5400/- per sq. mtr. - Special Land Acquisition Officer (SLAO) awarded compensation @ 2970 per sq.mtr., did not consider valuation report - Claimant claiming encroachment of 3.75 Sq. mtr. while land was in possession of respondent - SLAO deducing 3.75 Sq. mtr. from land claiming market price of Rs.6480 per sq.mtr. - Acquiring body getting tenants vacated from land - Report of expert based on information given by claimant - His valuation report completely flawed, did not verify report of joint inventory - Claimant not discharging onus to show advantageous factors of land to merit higher compensation - Not a single instance of sale of land in vicinity produced - Claimant not proving acquired land was not encroached where possession was handed over to the extent of 3.75 Sq. mtr. - Held, he cannot obtain value for encroached land - In the facts of the case SLAO had given reasonable value by way of compensation.
AIR 1998 SC 1652 Ref. to. 	(Para 38)

heading: Application for reference
Maintainability
HeadNote.description:
Application for reference - Maintainability - Award of compensation u/s.11 allegedly accepted without protest - Held, nothing in S.18 suggests that express protest is a condition precedent for filing a reference u/s.18 - Claimant however filed said reference immediately after passing of award - Conduct of claimant amounts to non-acceptance of award - Reference u/s.18, maintainable. 

Section 18 of the Land Acquisition Act contemplates an objection to be raised by the person interested to the amount of compensation made payable by an Award under section 11 of the Act. There is nothing in Section 18 to suggest that acceptance of compensation under express protest is a condition precedent for filing a reference application under section 18. The only requirement is that the claimant should not have accepted the Award under section 11. In the present case, on the next day after the declaration of Award under section 11 of the said Act, an application under section 18(1) of the said Act was filed raising an objection to the amount of compensation offered. This fact shows that the appellant did not accept the award. The conduct of the appellant of immediately filing an application for reference shows that the award under section 11 was not accepted by him. The compensation offered by the Award was in fact accepted without recording any formal protest. Mere failure to record a formal protest while accepting compensation, will not amount to acceptance of the award in every case.
2006(2) ALL MR 348, Held, Not good law in view of 2009 (5) ALL MR 492 (SC) and 2007 ALL SCR 652.                 [Para 12]

heading: Grant of solatium
HeadNote.description:
Grant of solatium - Award of civil court pending at the time when Amendment Act came in to force or passed thereafter - Amended S.23(2) would get attracted - Further, in this regard authority in K.S. Paripoornan (II) does not run counter to the authority in Raghubir Singh's case - It rather clarifies the principle laid down in Raghubir Singh's case.

 The larger Bench decision, in Raghubir Singh's case was only concerned with the grant of solatium in respect of the award passed between two dates, namely, April 30, 1982 and September 24, 1984. The issue before the Constitution Bench was not relatable to any award as such passed after the amended date.

 In K.S. Paripoornan (II) (supra), the three-Judge Bench appreciated the law laid down in Raghubir Singh's case and referred to Section 30(2) of the Land Acquisition (Amendment) Act, 1984 (68 of 1984) which was a transitory provision.

 On a perusal of the principle stated in Raghubir Singh case and what has been clarified in K.S. Paripoornan (II) case, it is not found that the three-Judge Bench decision runs counter to the authority in the Constitution Bench. It also does not give a different interpretation to Section 30(2) that what has been stated by the Constitution Bench. In fact, K.S. Paripoornan (II) clearly postulates about the awards that have been passed by the court after the Act has come into force which is in consonance with the ratio laid down in Raghubir Singh's case. The three-Judge Bench has only observed that the restricted interpretation placed by the Constitution Bench in Raghubir Singh (supra) should not convey that Section 23(2) would not apply to the awards of the civil court pending at the time when the Act came into force or thereafter. Thus, the controversy with which the three- Judge Bench was dealing with was absolutely different and the view expressed by it is absolutely in accord with the principles laid down in Raghubir Singh's case. Additionally, it is also in consonance with the provisions contained in Section 23(2) of the Act. 

(1989) 2 SCC 754 Foll.

(1995) 1 SCC 367 Approved.   [Para 9,10,11]

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination of - Land acquired for setting up industry for respondent no. 3 - Most of vacant land would be utilised by respondent no. 3 for its own financial benefit - Deduction of 10% amount from base price fixed by Supreme Court.

Reference Court committed error by deducting 50% of value assessed, towards development charges. High Court enhanced amount of compensation but committed error in fixing base price by applying doctrine of reasonable cut to average price. Land likely to be used towards roads sewage and other such facilities would be minimum as most of vacant land would be utilized by respondent no. 3 for its own financial benefit. Respondent no. 3 would be a great beneficiary at cost of depriving appellant land owner of his sole livelihood of agriculture. Therefore it is neither desirable nor proper to deduct more than 10% of amount from base price fixed by this Court. Appeal by land owner is liable to be allowed and appeal filed by Respondent no. 3 Corporation is liable to be dismissed.  1969(1) Mh. L.J. (SC) 45, 2008(6) ALL MR 491 (S.C.), 2008 ALL SCR 247 Relied on. 	 [Para 19,20,21,22,24]

heading: Proof
HeadNote.description: Release of land from acquisition - Taking over possession by State - Proof - Lands acquired for Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) - Subject lands are vacant lands - Possession receipts produced on record showing that ex-parte possession taken - However, roznama does not indicate any date fixed by authority concerned to go to spot and acquire possession of lands - Nothing on record to show that Land Acquisition Officer himself or any other person had gone to spot either with or without prior intimation to NIT for taking over possession - No panchnama prepared containing signatures of two independent witnesses - In absence of such evidence ex-parte possession receipts indicate mere paper possession of lands and not actual possession - Respondent failed to discharge burden of establishing taking over actual possession of lands - Lands do not vest in Government - Petitioners entitled to release of lands from acquisition. HeadNote.description: Public purpose - Acquisition of land for Expressway - Construction of Expressway on BOT basis - Land was not to vest in construction company - Company was only to implement project on BOT basis - After operating period was over assets were to be transferred to State Government - Hence, this cannot be said to be a colourable exercise of power - Acquisition of land was, therefore, for public purpose and not just useful to the public. HeadNote.description: Compensation - Property in dispute was sub-divided and was developed before acquisition - Sale instance available of very same land - Higher compensation awarded by Reference Court - Judgment of Reference Court is liable to be sustained. 1996(2) SCC 152 - Followed.	(Para 7)

HeadNote.description: Compensation - Escalation of - Land abutting National Highway have no high potentiality - 10% escalation in price is reasonable. 2002(3) SCC 688, 2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 1028 - Followed.	(Para 14)

HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - 11 acres 32 Guntas of land acquired at the rate of Rs.3800/- per acre - In reference award market value was assessed at Rs.15,000/- per acre for dry land and Rs.21,500/- for irrigated land - District Judge in appeal after condoning delay of 1717 days granting Rs.24000/- per acre as prayed for - In appeal before High Court no specific amount was demanded and only Rs.25/- was paid as court fee - High Court refused to enhance amount awarded in first appeal - Spl. leave petition filed with a delay of 154 days contending that High Court was found to enhance amount though no specific amount was demanded - Held, mere making a reference that High Court had awarded higher amount in respect of another land is not enough and more so when exemplar was not referred to in first appeal. Comparative sale instance
HeadNote.description: Market value - Comparative sale instance - Land acquired for setting up industrial township - Sale-deed of adjancent land - Not purposefully overvalued to ensure higher compensation claim - Such sale instance cannot be ignored or discarded.	(Para 17)

Not relied on

(Para 18)

heading: Revision
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Revision - Maintainability - Reference is rejected as revision applicant failed to adduce evidence - Order in Reference liable to be interfered with - Revision is maintainable in view of 2004(1) ALL MR 651. (Para 8)

heading: Reference
Rejection of
HeadNote.description: Reference - Rejection of - Ground that no documentary evidence filed by revision applicant - Order of rejection is not Award - Rejection of Reference on technicalities is not sustainable. (Para 10)

heading: Right of citizen to file objections to acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Right of citizen to file objections to acquisition of land - Is a valuable right.

Section 5-A confers an important right in favour of a person whose land is sought to be acquired. When the government proceeds for compulsory acquisition of particular property for public purpose, the only right that the owner or the person interested in the property has, is to submit his objections within the prescribed time under Section 5-A of the Act and persuade the State authorities to drop the acquisition of that particular land by setting forth the reasons such as the unsuitability of the land for the stated public purpose; the grave hardship that may be caused to him by such expropriation, availability of alternative land for achieving public purpose etc. Moreover, right conferred on the owner or person interested to file objections to the proposed acquisition is not only an important and valuable right but also makes the provision for compulsory acquisition just and in conformity with the fundamental principles of natural justice.  [Para 30]

heading: Dispensing with enquiry under S.5-A
HeadNote.description:
Dispensing with enquiry under S.5-A - Due application of mind - Government must establish its stand that urgency was of such a nature that it necessitated dispensing with enquiry under S.5-A.

Upon challenge being made to the use of power under Section 17, the government must produce appropriate material before the court that the opinion for dispensing with the enquiry under Section 5-A has been formed by the government after due application of mind on the material placed before it. It is true that power conferred upon the government under Section 17 is administrative and its opinion is entitled to due weight, but in a case where the opinion is formed regarding the urgency based on considerations not germane to the purpose, the judicial review of such administrative decision may become necessary. As to in what circumstances the power of emergency can be invoked are specified in Section 17(2) but circumstances necessitating invocation of urgency under Section 17(1) are not stated in the provision itself. Generally speaking, the development of an area (for residential purposes) or a planned development of city, takes many years if not decades and, therefore, there is no reason why summary enquiry as contemplated under Section 5-A may not be held and objections of land owners/persons interested may not be considered. In many cases on general assumption, likely delay in completion of enquiry under Section 5-A is set up as a reason for invocation of extraordinary power in dispensing with the enquiry little realizing that an important and valuable right of the person interested in the land is being taken away and with some effort enquiry could always be completed expeditiously. The special provision has been made in Section 17 to eliminate enquiry under Section 5-A in deserving and cases of real urgency. The government has to apply its mind on the aspect that urgency is of such nature that necessitates dispensation of enquiry under Section 5-A.  [Para 30]

The Government must, therefore, do a balancing act and resort to the special power of urgency under Section 17 in the matters of acquisition of land for the public purpose viz.; 'planned development of city' or 'for development of residential area' in exceptional situation. Use of the power by the government under Section 17 for 'planned development of the city' or 'the development of residential area' or for 'housing' must not be as a rule but by way of an exception. Such exceptional situation may be for the public purpose viz., rehabilitation of natural calamity affected persons; rehabilitation of persons uprooted due to commissioning of dam or housing for lower strata of the society urgently; rehabilitation of persons affected by time bound projects, etc.. The list is only illustrative and not exhaustive. In any case, sans real urgency and need for immediate possession of the land for carrying out the stated purpose, heavy onus lies on the government to justify exercise of such power. It must, therefore, be held that the use of the power of urgency and dispensation of enquiry under Section 5-A by the government in a routine manner for the 'planned development of city' or 'development of residential area' and thereby depriving the owner or person interested a very valuable right under Section 5-A may not meet the statutory test nor could be readily sustained.  [Para 31]

heading: Dispensation of S.5-A enquiry
HeadNote.description: Dispensation of S.5-A enquiry - Development Authority wanted subject land because their land bank had no land left - If profit making and sustenance of Development Authority was the motive, surely urgency was not of such nature that it could brook no delay whatsoever - In such a case dispensation of S.5-A enquiry by involving S.17 cannot be justified. (Para 32)

heading: Dispensation of S.5-A enquiry
HeadNote.description: Dispensation of S.5-A enquiry - Land already taken possession and 60% of infrastructure work done by spending Rs.5,28,00,000/- - Barring appellants others accepted compensation for their land - Held it was too late in the day to undo what has been done though dispensation of enquiry was not justified.	(Para 32)

heading: Release of land
HeadNote.description: Release of land - Land acquired by dispensing with S.5-A enquiry - Govt. failing to justify dispensation of enquiry - Government directed to consider application for release if made within three months from receipt of such application.	(Para 33)

heading: Compensation
Large tract acquired
Rel.on. [Para 11]
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Large tract acquired - Relevance of sale instances produced for small plots.

When a large tract of land is acquired and sale instances produced for small plots as exemplar, the best course for the court to arrive at a reasonable and fair valuation is to deduct a reasonable percentage from the valuation shown in the exemplar land and on the basis thereof to arrive at a just and fair valuation.  (2006)3 SCC 205, (1988)2 SCC 150, (2005)12 SCC 59, (2003)10 SCC 167, (2003)1 SCC 354, (2001)7 SCC 650, (2009)15 SCC 769 - Rel.on. [Para 11]

heading: Compensation
Development charges
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Development charges - Computation of between 20 to 75% depending upon facts of the case.

Whatever could be deducted towards development charges for developing a particular plot of land could range between 20 per cent to 75 per cent. This is a very wide bracket, no doubt, but an appropriate deduction befitting the situation, location and the nature of the land justifying the deduction made could be arrived at upon estimation of all the aforesaid factors. If the land is already developed and could be used as a commercial/residential plot, what should be deducted would be in the lower side whereas if development is to be made, like filling up of the land, providing of roads, sewage and other civic amenities, etc., the range of the deduction could be higher.   [Para 18]

In this case land is agricultural land and therefore would require extensive development to be utilised as a residential site. Therefore, relying on the Exhibits which are found as a reliable yardstick for determining the valuation in the present case, we determine the market value of the land at Rs.50/- per square yard as on the date of the notification and direct that 1/3rd of the awarded amount shall be deducted from the aforesaid valuation towards development charges. The respondents shall also be entitled to the statutory benefits as provided for under Sections 23(1), 28 and 34 of the Act.  2006(4) ALL MR (S.C.) 68 - Rel.on.  [Para 19,21]

HeadNote.description: Enhancement in rate of solatium and interest - Not available to claimants whose cases were finalized prior to 30.04.1982.	(Para 17)

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description:
Appeal - Order of Collector refusing to make reference under S.18(1) - Is not appealable.

The Land Acquisition Collector is not a Court, nor his award or order, an award of the Court. While the proceedings of a court resulting in an award of the court are judicial proceedings, neither the proceedings of the Collector under section 11 of the Act resulting in an award of the Collector, nor the proceedings relating to an application seeking reference, are judicial proceedings. Section 54 does not provide for appeals against the awards or orders of Land Acquisition Collector. Hence the assumption of the High Court that an order of the Collector refusing to refer a claim for increase in compensation to the civil court under section 18(1) of the Act, is an 'award of the court' appealable under section 54 of the Act, is wholly erroneous.   [Para 5]

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Condonation of delay by invoking S.5 of Limitation Act is not permissible. (1996)9 SCC 414 - Rel.on. (Para 7)

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Limitation of six months - Starting date is date of knowledge of award and not from date of award itself.

Clause (b) of the proviso to section 18 requires a person interested who has not accepted the award, to make an application to the Collector requiring him to refer the matter for determination of the court, within six weeks of the receipt of the notice from the Collector under section 12(2) or within six months from the date of the Collector's award whichever period first expires, if he or his representative was not present before the Collector at the time of making of the award. The words 'date of the collector's award' occurring in proviso (b) to section 18 requires to be read as referring to the date of knowledge of the essential contents of the award, and not the actual date of the Collector's award. When a person interested makes an application for reference seeking the benefit of six months period from the date of knowledge, the initial onus is on him to prove that he (or his representative) was not present when the award was made, that he did not receive any notice under Section 12(2) of the Act, and that he did not have the knowledge of the contents of the award during a period of six months prior to the filing the application for reference. This onus is discharged by asserting these facts on oath. He is not expected to prove the negative. Once the initial onus is discharged by the claimant/person interested, it is for the Land Acquisition Collector to establish that the person interested was present either in person or through his representative when the award was made, or that he had received a notice under Section 12(2) of the Act, or that he had knowledge of the contents of the award.   [Para 8,11,13]

heading: Compulsory acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Compulsory acquisition of land - State must exercise this power with great care and circumspection - Moreso when provisions of S.17 are invoked. 

Although in exercise of the power of eminent domain, the State can acquire the private property for public purpose, it must be remembered that compulsory acquisition of the property belonging to a private individual is a serious matter and has grave repercussions on his Constitutional right of not being deprived of his property without the sanction of law - Article 300A and the legal rights. Therefore, the State must exercise this power with great care and circumspection. At times, compulsory acquisition of land is likely to make the owner landless. The degree of care required to be taken by the State is greater when the power of compulsory acquisition of private land is exercised by invoking the provisions like the one contained in Section 17 of the Act because that results in depriving the owner of his property without being afforded an opportunity of hearing.  [Para 14]

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Invoking S.17 and dispensing with opportunity to raise objections - Idea of establishing electric sub-station was mooted prior to August, 2004 - For next three years officers of DTL and DDA exchanged letters on issue of allotment of land - On 28.7.2008 Govt. made suggestion of invoking S.17 by citing Commonwealth Games which were to be held in 2010 - Even after this it took more than one year to issue preliminary notification - Held pre-notification and post-notification delay falsified claim of urgency and elimination of opportunity of hearing and hence notification was liable to be quashed. 

A recapitulation of the facts would show that the idea of establishing 400/220 KV sub-station was mooted prior to August, 2004. For next almost three years, the officers of the DTL and the DDA exchanged letters on the issue of allotment of land. On 28.7.2008 Secretary (Power), Government of NCT of Delhi-cum-CMD, DTL made a suggestion for the acquisition of land by invoking Section 17 of the Act. This became a tool in the hands of the concerned authorities and the Lieutenant Governor mechanically approved the proposal contained in the file without trying to find out as to why the urgency provisions were being invoked after a time gap of five years. If the sub-station was to be established on emergency basis, the authorities of the DTL would not have waited for five years for the invoking of urgency provisions enshrined in the Act. They would have immediately approached the Government of NCT of Delhi and made a request that land be acquired by invoking Section 17 of the Act. However, the fact of the matter is that the concerned officers / functionaries of the DTL, the DDA and the Government of NCT of Delhi leisurely dealt with the matter for over five years. Even after some sign of emergency was indicated in letter dated 9.9.2008 of the Joint Secretary (Power), who made a mention of the Commonwealth Games scheduled to be organised in October, 2010, it took more than one year and two months to the competent authority to issue the preliminary notification. Therefore, it is difficult to approve the view taken by the High Court on the sustainability of the appellants' challenge to the acquisition of their land.  [Para 22]

(Para 12)

HeadNote.description: Reference - Reference Court is not a Court of original jurisdiction and it derives jurisdiction only in terms of the order of reference. 2009 ALL SCR 1415 - Rel. on.(Paras 8, 19)

heading: Reference
Right of audience
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Notice to persons interested in objection - Right of audience - CIDCO appointed as a New Town Development Authority under S.113(3-A) of MRTP Act of 1966 - CIDCO acting as an agent of State Government, held, cannot claim right of audience on the ground that it is a person interested.

A person can be said to be a person interested provided that he is the person claiming an interest in the compensation to be made on account of acquisition. Thus, the person who claims to be entitled to compensation or a share in the compensation can only be a person who can be said to be claiming interest in the compensation. Here the CIDCO is not claiming interest in the compensation. In fact, the CIDCO has no concern with the payment of compensation. Therefore, the CIDCO cannot claim right of audience on the ground that it is a "person interested". (2004)13 SCC 125 - Ref. to. [Para 14]
