Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Reference - Impleading of party as an opponent - Challenge to - Land acquired by State Government under S.113-A of Maharashtra Regional Town Planning Act for the New Bombay Project - CIDCO appointed as a New Town Development Authority to act as an agent of State Government, for setting up New Township - Land acquired at the expenses of State Government - CIDCO not being a local authority under S.50(1), held, could not have been impleaded as an opponent in the reference - Order impleading the CIDCO being completely illegal, quashed and set aside. (Paras 14, 15)

heading: Land acquisition
Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Determination of compensation - There cannot be any straight jacket formula to determine compensation payable to the claimants - Question of acquisition of larger piece of land has no relevance - Matters must be examined and evidence must be understood by the court in its correct perspective and while keeping the ground realities in acquisition matters in mind. 2007(5) ALL MR 711 (F.B.) - Rel. on.			(Para 7)

heading: Determination of compensation
Additional benefit
HeadNote.description:
Determination of compensation - Additional benefit - Additional benefit is admissible in law and payable to claimants for the period commencing from the date of publication of notification under S.4 of the Act till possession or date of award whichever is earlier.

The additional benefit is admissible in law and payable to the claimants for the period commencing from the date of publication of notification Under Section 4 of the Act till possession or date of award whichever is earlier. The most important expression in the provision of Section 23(1-A) wherever the additional benefit is to be given till the date of possession is "possession". The word "possession" has been explained differently in different contexts.

The possession is a legal right and it must arise legally. For possession to be accepted in law, the Court should be satisfied that possession has been acquired by the concerned party by due process of law and is not result of an unlawful act. Now let us examine the legislative scheme in relation to taking over of possession by the Government or its agencies under the provisions of the Act. The provisions of the Act contemplate only two methods for acquiring possession in accordance with law. Firstly, the Government acting through the Collector and after issuance of the notification under Section 4 and declaration under Section 6 of the Act is required to serve notice to all interested persons under Section 9(1) of the Act informing that the Government intends to take possession of the land and interested persons may make their claim for compensation in such land to him. The Collector thereupon shall conduct an enquiry as contemplated under Section 11 of the Act and make his award determining the market value of the acquired land. It is only after this procedure is completed that the Collector is entitled to take possession as per the provisions of Section 16 of the Act and then alone the land shall vest absolutely in the Government free from all encumbrances. Secondly, the legislature has vested special powers in the Appropriate Government to direct the Collector to take immediate possession under different circumstances by invoking the urgency clause. The Collector is empowered to take possession for immediate public purpose by serving fifteen days' notice even where no award has been made in terms of Section 11 of the Act. The Collector is even empowered to take possession by giving 48 hours notice but for possession in terms of sub-sections (1) and (2), the statute casts an obligation upon the said authority to pay compensation to the claimant. This compensation could be in relation to damage to any crop, structure, water supply, etc. and in any case before taking possession of the land the Collector, in terms of Section 17(3-A)(a) of the Act has to tender payment of 80 per cent of the compensation for such land as estimated by him to persons whose lands are acquired. The law requires that the compensation should be paid to the claimants unless and until the Collector is prevented by circumstances postulated under Section 31 of the Act. Even if that be so, still the Collector would be required to deposit the compensation in the Court as commanded under Section 31 of the Act. In other words, the Government is entitled to take immediate possession of the land but only and upon making payment of 80 per cent of the proposed market value of the land in question. There is no other way by which the Government or any other instrumentality of the Government can take possession of the land under the provisions of the Act. The Legislature has emphasized the need for payment of compensation prior to taking physical possession of the property in either case. The Court cannot ignore the fact that these are cases of compulsory acquisition and compliance to the statutory provisions would be mandatory. The State cannot take benefit of any of the provisions of the statute without satisfying the requirements or conditions precedent to such invocation. This onus is clearly upon the State to show that they have taken the possession of the land in accordance with the provisions of the Act and the term possession is "lawful possession". When the Act in no uncertain terms provides the methodology which is to be adopted by the authorities of the State in taking possession then it is mandatory for these authorities to take possession only in accordance with the provisions and no other way. Possession must be taken by a duly authorized person and in accordance with law. There is no necessity for the authorities of the State to create a mechanism of taking possession which is not in conformity with the statutory requirements. The State cannot defend against the provisions of law.  2004(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 435 - Ref. to.					       [Para 10,12]

heading: Acquisition proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition proceedings - S.10 of Coal Bearing Act vests the land in government immediately after government declares acquisition - It is, therefore, obvious that the owner is divested of his land though compensation thereof is not determined at all - S.9(1) Notification, therefore, cannot be equated with award under S.11 of Land Acquisition Act.

Section 10 vests the land in government immediately after the government declares the acquisition. It is, therefore, obvious that the owner is divested of his land though compensation thereof is not determined at all. The determination for the first time takes place via Section 14 and it may take place in a given case even after taking of possession under Section 12 as Coal Bearing Act does not prohibit it. The contention that Section 9(1) Notification, therefore, should be equated with award under Section 11 of Land Acquisition Act is without substance. In fact such an analogy can not be resorted to because of express provisions of Coal Bearing Act which contemplate determination of compensation for the first time by the Special Tribunal vide its Section 14. If the market value or compensation determined is in view of the agreement between parties, it is apparent that there need not be any recourse to Section 14 of Coal Bearing Act. The question crops up only when there is no such agreement and the amount offered by acquiring body is disputed by the land owner. Thus, an independent or impartial agency for the first time determines the compensation under Section 14 in said scheme.   [Para 12]

heading: Acquisition of land
Procedure
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Procedure - Scope and applicability of Land Acquisition Act - It cannot be held that entire process of land acquisition in Coal Bearing Act ends without determining the amount of market value payable to land owner - Held, the land acquisition proceedings in Coal Bearing Act continue till compensation amount is worked out as per Sec.14.

It cannot be held that entire process of land acquisition in Coal Bearing Act ends without determining the amount of market value payable to landowner. The determination of market value via Section 14 is part and parcel of acquisition proceedings and though land is vested in Central Government, the proceedings for its determination continue even thereafter before the Special Tribunal. Though authority under the Rules framed under Coal Bearing Act invite claims, it is not obligatory for them to work out compensation amount before publication of Section 9(1) notification or before vesting. This is unlike Section 11 of Land Acquisition Act where award is published only after the compensation amount is determined after inquiry & considering the claims of owners. A award declared under Section 14(5) by Special Tribunal is the first stage at which the market value & compensation is statutorily determinable under the Coal Bearing Act, 1957. Section 14 is the first provision which uses the word "award" & its sub-section (5) mandates Special Tribunal to determine just compensation after hearing the dispute before it. The date of notification under Section 9(1) of Coal Bearing Act mentioned in Circular dated 12.5.1989, therefore, cannot be a cut off date for the purpose of deciding the grant of escalation amount of 12%. Final declaration of acquisition and vesting of land without consequential statutory determination of compensation therefor can not be the end of any statutory land acquisition. The land acquisition proceedings in Coal Bearing Act can not end only because landowners are divested of their lands and remain pending till statutory determination of compensation payable to them.

Held, acquisition proceedings continue till the compensation amount is worked out after holding statutory inquiry as per Section 14 thereof. As claims for compensation as per Rule 5-A of Coal Bearing Rules are to be filed after vesting itself, determination of compensation is also possible only after Section 9 notification & hence date of Section 9 notification can not be relevant at all & date of award of special tribunal under Section 14(5) of Coal Bearing Act has to be the crucial date.

Even if notification under Section 9(1) is published before 30.4.1982 but proceedings for determination of compensation under Section 14 of Coal Bearing Act are pending before the Special Tribunal on said date or are decided by Special Tribunal after said date, the land owner is eligible to claim benefit of escalation amount of 12% per annum in terms of para 3 of Circular dated 12.5.1989.  AIR 2002 SC 3499 - Ref. to.   [Para 13,14]

heading: Market value
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Prices fetched for small plots cannot form safe basis for valuation of large tracts of land.

Where a large area is the subject matter of acquisition, rate at which small plots are sold cannot be said to be a safe criteria.

It cannot, however, be laid down as an absolute proposition that the rates fixed for the small plots cannot be the basis for fixation of the rate. For example, where there is no other material it may in appropriate cases be open to the adjudicating Court to make comparison of the prices paid for small plots of land. However, in such cases necessary deductions/adjustments have to be made while determining the prices.  					 [Para 7,8,9]

heading: Market value
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Determination - Some amount of guess work is unavoidable while determining potentiality.

Section 23 of the Act enumerates the matters to be considered in determining compensation. The first criterion to be taken into consideration is the market value of the land on the date of the publication of the notification under Section 4(1). Similarly, Section 24 of the Act enumerates the matters which the Court shall not take into consideration in determining the compensation. A safeguard is provided in Section 25 of the Act that the amount of compensation to be awarded by the Court shall not be less than the amount awarded by the Collector under Section 11. Value of the potentiality is to be determined on such materials as are available and without indulgence in any fits of imagination. Impracticability of determining the potential value is writ large in almost all cases. There is bound to be some amount of guess work involved while determining the potentiality.   [Para 10]

heading: Market value
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Value of the land is not to be estimated as its value to the purchaser.

While considering the market value, disinclination of the vendor to part with his land and the urgent necessity of the purchaser to buy it must be disregarded alike; neither must be considered as acting under any compulsion. The value of the land is not to be estimated as its value to the purchaser. But similarly this does not mean that the fact that some particular purchaser might desire the land more than others is to be disregarded. The wish of a particular purchaser, though not his compulsion may always be taken into consideration for what it is worth.   [Para 10]

heading: Market value
Determination
Comparable sales
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Determination - Comparable sales - When relevant.

The element of speculation is reduced to minimum if the underlying principles of fixation of market value with reference to comparable sales are made:

(i)	when sale is within a reasonable time of the date of notification under Section 4(1);

(ii)	it should be a bona fide transaction;

(iii)	it should be of the land acquired or of the land adjacent to the land acquired; and

(iv)	it should possess similar advantages.

It is only when these factors are present, can it merit a consideration as a comparable case.  2003(2) ALL MR 717 (S.C.) - Rel. on.					 [Para 11,12]

heading: Market value
Development charges
HeadNote.description: Market value - Development charges - Deduction to be made towards development charges cannot be proved in any strait-jacket formula - It would depend upon the facts of each case.	(Para 14)

heading: Finality of award
HeadNote.description:
Finality of award - Means there would be no appeal.

The finality of the awards is, however, subject to review by the Reference Court under Section 18 read with Section 31(2) or Section 30 of the Act. Except for the finality of these three factual matters, there is nothing in the Act making the award final as regards its legality. Moreover, the use of the word "final" in the statute only means that there would be no appeal.						   [Para 29]

heading: Acquisition of land
Proceedings for
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Proceedings for - Are administrative in nature and not quasi-judicial.

For the purposes of Land Acquisition Act, proceedings are carried on by an officer appointed by the Government known as Land Acquisition Collector. The proceeding under the Land Acquisition Collector is of an administrative nature and not of a judicial or quasi judicial character. When a Government intends to occupy a land in any locality it has to issue a notification under Section 4 in the official gazette as also newspaper and give a public notice which entitles anyone on behalf of the Government to enter into the land for the purposes of digging, taking level, set out boundaries etc. The notification puts forward the intention of the Government to acquire the land, in terms whereof the government officials become entitled to investigate and ascertain whether the land is suitable for the purpose for which the land is sought to be acquired. The section also makes it mandatory for the officer or person authorised by the Government to give a notice of seven days signifying his intention to enter into any building or enclosed court or garden in any locality. This is a mandatory provision of the process of land acquisition.  						 [Para 30]

heading: Declaration under
HeadNote.description: Declaration under - Within one year of S.4 notification - Is a mandatory requirement for acquisition.	(Para 31)

heading: Public notice about intention to acquire possession of land
HeadNote.description: Public notice about intention to acquire possession of land - One in the locality of acquisition and other to occupants or persons interested in land - It is a mandatory provision.			(Para 33)

heading: Except right of reference on three factual matters of area, value of land and apportionment of compensation, Act does not provide for appeal from the award of collector.	(Para 37)
HeadNote.description: Except right of reference on three factual matters of area, value of land and apportionment of compensation, Act does not provide for appeal from the award of collector.	(Para 37)

heading: Remedy under
HeadNote.description: Remedy under - Even a person who has not filed any application for enhancement of compensation can receive a just amount of compensation under S.28-A.	(Para 39)

heading: Applicability
HeadNote.description:
Applicability - When can S.18 be invoked.

For the purpose of invoking Section 18 of the Act, the person interested is required :

(i)	not to accept the award;

(ii)	that the matter may be referred to the Collector for determination by the court by way of a written application inter alia pointing out his objection with regard to : (a) amount of compensation, (b) person to whom it is payable, or (c) apportionment thereof amongst the persons interested.

Reference, thus, may be made by the Collector on receipt of the application in writing keeping in view the objections of the land owners or land holders in regard to one or all the matters.  			 [Para 42,43]

heading: Right to receive compensation
HeadNote.description: Right to receive compensation - S.31 enables person interested to accept award under protest - It is, however, circumscribed by conditions laid down in provisos appended to sub-section (2) of S.18 as also S.31(2) - They are imperative in character.			(Paras 45, 46)

heading: Reference within a period of six months from date of award
HeadNote.description: Reference within a period of six months from date of award - Compliance thereof is mandatory - It is impermissible to direct references to be made after a long period particularly when provisions of Section 5 of Limitation Act, 1963 cannot be said to have any application. 1996(9) SCC 414, 2005(8) SCC 709 - Rel. on.	(Paras 47, 48)

heading: Reference under
Person interested
HeadNote.description: Reference under - Person interested - In land acquisition proceedings, the question of a body of the persons being represented by Association does not arise - Statute provides for filing of claim applications as also filing of objections by land holders and not by and/or on behalf of Association and that too an independent body corporate.			 (Paras 57, 59)

heading: Limitation
HeadNote.description: Limitation - Date of knowledge of award either actual or constructive is relevant - Onus would be on landholder to show that he did not have any knowledge of the contents of award. 2005(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 965 - Rel. on.	(Para 66)

heading: Notice under S.9
HeadNote.description: Notice under S.9 - Raising objection to awards and receiving payment under protest - Raising of such objection in response to notice under Section 9 cannot have same effect as if an application has been filed for reference under Section 18.	(Para 77)

heading: Application for reference
HeadNote.description: Application for reference - Protest in regard to making of award need not be specified expressly - When an application for reference is filed, protest to award is implicit. (1994)4 SCC 67 - Rel. on.			(Para 82)

heading: Application for reference
HeadNote.description: Application for reference - Made long time after expiry of six months - No case for exercising extraordinary jurisdiction under Art.142 of Constitution is made out.			(Paras 86)

heading: Application for reference
HeadNote.description: Application for reference - In writ proceedings L.A.O assuring petitioners that a reference shall be made - He is collector within meaning of S.3(c) of LA Act and was bound by his promise - Though made only orally.	(Paras 94, 95)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Notification under S.4 issued and declaration under S.6 published dispensing with enquiry under S.5-A by invoking S.17 - Notifications challenged in H.C. - Directions issued to Authorities to hear petitioners - H.C. also directing publication of declaration afresh - Statutory period of 3 years for publication of notification also extended on basis of concession made by petitioners - Statutory right can be waived though fundamental right cannot be waived - Petitioners cannot challenge notification under S.6 on ground that it was barred by time. (Para 10)

heading: Market value
Determination of
Proof
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Determination of - Contemporary sale of land in locality - Proof - Mere production of sale - deed is not sufficient - Vendor, Vendee, attesting witnesses are to be examined - Expert's report prepared 10 years after S.4 Notification - Changes during intervening period not taken into consideration - Not safe to rely on the Report.

Mere production of certified copy or the original Sale Deed is not sufficient to prove the sale instance. It should also be proved that the sale transaction is genuine and the price is not inflated. Such proof must be offered either by the vendor or vendee or in their absence by attesting witness. In the absence of such important material,  to sale instances produced in a case  cannot be said to have been proved. After proving the documents the comparability of the land covered under the sale deed with the acquired land should also be proved and established. In other words it should also be proved whether the land acquired could fetch a price of that which is proved by documentary evidence. For these two aspects the examination of relevant witnesses are made mandatory.  1994(2) Mah LR 830 and 1995(2) Mah LR 829 held not good law in view of 1993(3) SCC 240. The Expert's Report 10 year after S.4 Notification cannot also be accepted when the changes under gone  in respect of the land is not borne out from the report, except his claim that he is a valuer for Government for assessing the market value of the land and when his Report is not based on any relevant material.  It can be seen from his evidence that he has not taken or examined any sale instance of any area around the acquired land for arriving to his conclusion. For this reason it will not be safe to rely upon the evidence of the Valuer or his Report for fixing the market price of the land.  [Para 7]

heading: Severance charges
Grant of
HeadNote.description: Severance charges - Grant of - Major part of land acquired - Utility of remaining part, a small strip of land reduced to zero - Access to it also blocked - Awarding of severance charge held valid. (Para 9)

heading: Compensation
Fixation of
Sale deed
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Fixation of - Sale deed - Deed not available to original claimant - Deed not to be considered for such fixation - But as land situated abutting Highway - Had potential for development for residential/commercial purposes - Compensation increased to Rs.10 per sq.m. from Rs.5 per sq.m.

heading: Interest
HeadNote.description: Interest - Effect of delay in issuance of notification - Notification u/s.4 issued in 1988 though  possession taken in 1965 - Being deprived of his land - Claimant entitled to interest - Claimant's suit for damages having become time-barred - In light of 1995(6) SCC 233, claimant's remedy restricted U/Ss.28,4 of the Act.

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Grant of benefit u/S.23-1A - Acquisition is an act of the State and in exercise of its powers, the State can take possession of the land but only in accordance with law - If the compensation is neither offered nor paid, the possession by the State may not be unlawful but certainly would not satisfy the basic and legal ingredients of possession contemplated under the provisions of the Act so as to bring an end to the grant of benefit u/s.23-1A of the Act for any further period.	(Para 10)

heading: Compensation to land owners
HeadNote.description: Compensation to land owners - Owners must be given compensation which they deserve, keeping in view the potential, location, fertility and user of the land at the time of acquisition.	(Para 12)

heading: Notification under
Requirements
HeadNote.description: Notification under - Requirements - Government/Collector has to publish the notification in the official gazette, publish notification in two newspapers, one in local language and lastly issue public notice to be given at convenient place in the said locality - In other words, these requirements are mandatory in given facts and circumstances of the case - Default in either of them may vitiate and render the acquisition proceedings bad in law. AIR 1992 SC 131, AIR 1985 SC 1622 and AIR 2002 SC 3309 - Rel. on.	(Para 13)

heading: Land acquisition proceedings
Irregularity
Effect of
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition proceedings - Irregularity - Effect of - Every irregularity would not vitiate the acquisition proceedings as bad in law but its total non-compliance to the mandatory provisions may adversely affect the acquisition proceedings.

Section 23 of the Act requires the compensation payable on account of market value of the land acquired on the date of publication of the notification under sub-section (1) of Section 4 of the Act. This does not exclude either specifically or by implication any of the three methods indicated in the section. In other words, it is the composite compliance to the provisions of Section 4(1) of the Act which would be the complete stage for taking further proceedings in the acquisition of acquired land. Every irregularity would not vitiate the acquisition proceedings as bad in law but its total non-compliance to the mandatory provisions may adversely affect the acquisition proceedings. Despite the fact that publication in the newspaper as well as display of notices at convenient places in the locality is a mandatory condition but the material date for determining the market value of the land would and should be the date on which the notification is published in the official gazette. For this, two reasons can be stated. One that the sale deeds or transfers executed by any party after publication of the notification in the official gazette is not binding on the State and is inconsequential. In other words, Section 4 puts a kind of embargo upon transfer of the properties which are subject matter of acquisition proceedings. Secondly, publication in the official gazette is accepted in law as notice to all and there is a presumption in favour of the notification and its contents. There would be more than three dates which may be pleaded to be relevant for determination of the market value. Firstly the date of notification, secondly when the notification was published in the official gazette, thirdly the date/s on which the notification was published in two newspapers circulated in the locality and finally the date/s on which the Collector would issue the substance of the notifications by publishing notice at convenient places in the locality. If the arguments advanced on behalf of the claimants is taken to its logical end, there will always be a dispute of fact as to which is the relevant date and whether which date satisfies the prerequisite of compliance to Section 4 of the Act.				 [Para 14]

heading: Limitation under S.18
foll. [Para 8,9,11]
HeadNote.description:
Limitation under S.18 - Is inflexible, uncondonable and is capable of rigid interpretation.

In an application under Section 18(1) of the Act, the applicant is expected to raise a challenge to the awarded compensation by the Collector in his award under Section 11 of the Act and in terms of Section 18(2) of the Act, the application shall state the grounds on which the objection to the Award is being taken. In other words, application under Section 18 is not a mere formality but is exercise of a substantive legal right in the manner specified in the provisions.  The expression "shall" has been cautiously used by the Legislature which indicates its intent that the application should state grounds on which objection or exception to the Award is being taken. It is expected of the Applicant to be aware of what was the value of his land at the time of issuance of the Notification under Section 4 of the Act as that date alone is relevant for determining compensation payable to the Claimants. He is at liberty to raise all factual and legal objections. This is a reference by the Collector to the Court of competent jurisdiction and proceedings of reference are expected to be carried out in accordance with law. Proviso to Section 18(2) spells out a limitation within which the application contemplated under Section 18 of the Act is to be filed. The period of limitation depending on the facts of a given case would be six weeks to six months. Six months being the outer case limit, in either of the events, where the Applicant was present before the Collector at the time when the Award was made or where he was served with a notice under sub-section (2) of Section 12 of the Act. This specific period of limitation is mandatory and is not flexible either in its term or by any enunciated principles of necessary implication. AIR 1961 SC 1500, 2006 Mh.L.J. 206, (1995)3 SCC 330 - foll. [Para 8,9,11]

heading: Award made by Collector
HeadNote.description: Award made by Collector - Is final in absolute terms vis-a-vis Govt. - Court can only enhance it to the extent of the amount claimed in reference under S.18 - Award so made by Court would then become a decree within meaning of S.2(2) and S.2(9) of Civil P.C..	(Para 14)

heading: Amendment of
HeadNote.description:
Reference petition under S.18 - Amendment of - Could not be granted particularly when period of limitation prescribed under S.18(2) is over.

A Petition under Section 18, if filed within time, will be referred to Court and would be incapable of being altered or amended with the aid of procedural provisions provided under the Code. The provisions of the Code are procedural in nature, while the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act are statutory and binding. The Land Acquisition Act is a special enactment intended to prescribe procedure and is a Code in itself particularly in relation to the proceedings taken under Part-II of the Act and the Collector upon making a Reference under Section 18 of the Act, loses its control and jurisdiction over such proceedings.  The law of amendment which will enable a party to amend the Memorandum of Appeal could normally relate to certain circumstances, like potential, location of the acquired land or reference to certain transactions which for bona fide reasons and despite due diligence could not be placed before the Court. In law, it would be difficult to hold that a Reference Petition which has been filed before the Collector within time can be amended in relation to quantum and can be altered after the prescribed period of limitation is over. Section 18(2) of the Act prohibits certain dealings and proceedings after expiry of the prescribed period and what cannot be achieved directly can also not be achieved indirectly by adopting recourse to the procedural law.  Thus provisions of Order 6, Rule 17 read with Order 41, Rule 33 of the Code of Civil Procedure cannot be resorted to amend the application filed by the claimants under section 18 of the Land Acquisition Act in so far as it relates to enhancement of the amount of compensation claimed. However, the provisions of amendment under the Code can be invoked in amending the memorandum of appeal or a petition before the reference court in so far as it relates to other matters pertaining to pleading and/or evidence, e.g. location, potential of the acquired land, sale instances which would benefit the applicants to justify the amount claimed under Section 18 and which could not be brought before the Court by them despite due diligence. In other words, amendment of memorandum of appeal should be understood in distinction to amendment of an application filed before the Collector under Section 18 of the Act.  [Para 33,34,44]

heading: Application under S.18
HeadNote.description: Application under S.18 - Is not mere formality, but is an admission of facts and grounds stated therein by the party concerned - Withdrawal of admission as a rule is impermissible except certain extra ordinary exceptions permissible under law. 		(Paras 34, 48)

heading: Collector
Powers
HeadNote.description: Collector - Powers - Function of collector under Ss.18, 19 is not merely ministerial and cannot be effected without application of mind.	(Para 35)

heading: Collector
HeadNote.description:
Collector - Exercising powers under provisions of Act - Is not "Court" within meaning of the Act and under legal parlance - Thus provisions of CPC are not applicable to proceedings before Collector - However once matter comes within realm of Court, CPC is held applicable - Petition barred by time - Provisions of CPC cannot be utilized for defeating bar which emerges from specific provisions of Act - Further merely because subsequently law is amended and/or judgment is pronounced which may give some benefit by itself - Would not be sufficient ground for permitting an amendment which at the face of it is impermissible in law.

The Collector while exercising powers under this Act is not a "Court" within the meaning of the provisions of the Act and for that matter even under legal parlance. Once an application is presented before the Collector and it conforms to the requirement of Sections 18 and 19 of the Act, even then the Collector has power to reject the reference if it is barred by time as the Collector or the Court for that matter have no power to extend the period prescribed under Section 18(2) of the Act.  The Collector while exercising such powers does not have the trapping of a Court and to that extent provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure per se would not be applicable to the proceedings before the Collector. Admittedly, once the matter comes within the realm of the Court, the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure would be applicable with the aid of Section 53 of the Act again and only to the extent they are not in conflict with the provisions of the Act. If a petition has become barred by time, then the provisions of the Code cannot be utilized for the purposes of defeating the bar which emerges from the specific provisions of the Act. Merely because subsequently a law is amended and/or a judgment is pronounced which may give some benefit by itself would not be a sufficient ground for permitting an amendment which at the face of it is impermissible in law.  [Para 35]

heading: Applications seeking amendment as well for leading additional evidence
HeadNote.description:
Applications seeking amendment as well for leading additional evidence - Applications so filed by claimants suffering from defect of delay, laches and even lacked bonafides - Dismissed.

The claimants are expected to act vigilantly and raise their appropriate claim for acquisition of their lands. However, even if the Claimants, despite exercise of due diligence, are not able to make an appropriate claim for determination of market value of the land as on the date of issuance of section 4 notification, in response to notice under section 9 of the Act, still after amendment of the provisions of section 25 of the Act, they can raise the claim for a higher amount in an application under section 18 of the Act. These provisions require the applicants to submit their objections and grounds, interalia, for inadequacy of the compensation awarded to the claimants and claim such other amount as they deem fit and proper. The legislative intent appears to be that there should be appropriate and expeditious disposal of land references. The scheme of the Act does not contemplate amendment of section 18 petition at a subsequent stage. In view of the legislative protection provided, there is hardly any prejudice being caused to an applicant-claimant if amendment to Petition is denied as it is the duty of every interested person to act diligently and in accordance with law.  On the contrary, if Petition under Section 18 is permitted to be amended at a late stage, it is likely to result in prejudice to the State or the acquiring authority. They will hardly be in a position to defend prayer for enhancement and the matter would have to be remanded to the court of reference which again would result in delay of conclusion of proceedings and lastly such an approach does not appear to be permissible under the provisions of the Act. 					        [Para 40,41]

heading: Compensation
Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Enhancement of - Reliance placed upon report of expert valuer and letters issued by CIDCO in relation to sale of plots from same vicinity - According to claimants as CIDCO had sold land at much higher price they are entitled to compensation at rate of Rs.500/- per sq. mtr. - Compensation granted by reference Court in judgment under appeal no way unreasonable or unfair - Claimant held entitled to full claim for compensation claimed by them.	(Paras 52, 56, 57)

heading: Acquisition proceedings
Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Acquisition proceedings - Challenge to - Procedure as contemplated in S.5-A of the Act, not followed - Held, consequent notification under S.6 could not have been published without following mandatory procedure as contemplated under S.5-A of the Act - Thus, acquisition proceedings are vitiated and are liable to be quashed.			(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Right to make objections - Right having regard to Article 330-A of Constitution of India, held, akin to fundamental right - No person can be deprived of his property save by authority of law.	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Compensation
Comparable sales
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Comparable sales - Where large area is subject matter of acquisition, rate at which small plot is sold cannot be a safe criteria - However, if there is no other material prices paid for small plots may be taken into consideration and necessary deductions/adjustments effected.			(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Compensation
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination - Factors to be kept in view.

Section 23 of the Act enumerates the matters to be considered in determining compensation. The first criterion to be taken into consideration is the market value of the land on the date of the publication of the notification under Section 4(1). Similarly, Section 24 of the Act enumerates the matters which the Court shall not take into consideration in determining the compensation. A safeguard is provided in Section 25 of the Act that the amount of compensation to be awarded by the Court shall not be less than the amount awarded by the Collector under Section 11. Value of the potentiality is to be determined on such materials as are available and without indulgence in any fits of imagination. Impracticability of determining the potential value is writ large in almost all cases. There is bound to be some amount of guess work involved while determining the potentiality.  [Para 17]

heading: Compensation
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination - Methods to eliminate element of speculation in determining market value with reference to comparable sales.

It can be broadly stated that the element of speculation is reduced to minimum if the underlying principles of fixation of market value with reference to comparable sales are made:

(i)	when sale is within a reasonable time of the date of notification under Section 4(1);

(ii)	it should be a bona fide transaction;

(iii)	it should be of the land acquired or of the land adjacent to the land acquired; and

(iv)	it should possess similar advantages.

It is only when these factors are present, it can merit a consideration as a comparable case. AIR 1959 SC 429 - Ref. (Paras 18, 19)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Deduction to be made towards development charges - Factors to be considered.

The deduction to be made towards development charges cannot be proved in any strait-jacket formula. It would depend upon the facts of each case.

In respect of agricultural land or undeveloped land which has potential value for housing or commercial purposes, normally 1/3rd amount of compensation has to be deducted out of the amount of compensation payable on the acquired land subject to certain variations depending on its nature, location, extent of expenditure involved for development and the area required for roads and other civic amenities to develop the land so as to make the plots for residential or commercial purposes. A land may be plain or uneven, the soil of the land may be soft or hard bearing on the foundation for the purpose of making construction; may be the land is situated in the midst of a developed area all around but that land may have a hillock or may be low-lying or may be having deep ditches. So the amount of expenses that may be incurred in developing the area also varies. A claimant who claims that his land is fully developed and nothing more is required to be done for developmental purposes, must show on the basis of evidence that it is such a land and it is so located. In the absence of such evidence, merely saying that the area adjoining his land is a developed area, is not enough particularly when the extent of the acquired land is large and even if a small portion of the land is abutting the main road in the developed area, does not give the land the character of a developed area. In 84 acres of land acquired even if one portion on one side abuts the main road, the remaining large area where planned development is required, needs laying of internal roads, drainage, sewer, water, electricity lines, providing civil amenities etc. However, in cases of some land where there are certain advantages by virtue of the developed area around, it may help in reducing the percentage of cut to be applied, as the developmental charges required may be less on that account. There may be various factual factors which may have to be taken into consideration while applying the cut in payment of compensation towards developmental charges, maybe in some cases it is more than 1/3rd and in some cases less than 1/3rd. It must be remembered that there is difference between a developed area and an area having potential value, which is yet to be developed. The fact that an area is developed or adjacent to a developed area will not ipso facto make every land situated in the area also developed to be valued as a building site or plot, particularly, when vast tracts are acquired, as in this case, for development purpose. 2003(1) ALL MR 755 (S.C.), 2004(10) SCC 745, 2004(12) SCC 425 Ref. to.		 [Para 21,22]

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Award
Validity
HeadNote.description:
Enhancement of compensation - Award - Validity - Acquired land having tremendous scope of development and having various infrastructrual facilities - Cross-objection upheld by increasing the amount of compensation - However development charge at the rate of 10% deducted since the land was already levelled and well thrashed.

Where the purpose of acquisition of land is for development of a township the fact must be borne in mind that this township is a necessary supplement to the industrial growth in and around the area thereby enhancing its value more than an ordinary residential area would fetch.  Therefore assessing the market value of these lands has to be in consonance with the industrial growth of whole track as such.  Taking into account the magnitude of growth of development the disadvantage of the land merely on the ground of distance from a landmark would disappear particularly where various infrastructural facilities are available to the acquired land.  As regards the deduction of development charges which is to be deducted to the tune of 10-20% taking into account that the land is levelled and well thrashed and the cost of development would be negligible development charge at the rate of 10% is to be deducted.  [Para 7,8]

heading: Limitation
Computation
HeadNote.description:
Reference to the Court - Limitation - Computation - 42 days must be computed from the date of the receipt of the copy of award and not the notice of the award.

In the instant case the question of limitation was a mixed question of law and facts because it was specifically required to be averred in the lower Court and the issue was required to be raised so as to give opportunity to the claimant to meet the issue squarely.  Moreover, only after the receipt of the copy of the award the claimant came to know about the reasons that the compensation was granted at the said meagre rate and therefore he had to make up his mind to file reference u/s.18 after going through the copy of the award received.  Thus the claim cannot be said to be barred by limitation.  [Para 9]

heading: Quashing of notification
Validity
HeadNote.description: Quashing of notification - Validity - Notification issued for residential complex, construction of roads, bus depot and also for green belt to avoid pollution - Land notified for acquisition almost 28 years ago - Construction made over land without acquisition of same and despite interim order is in operation regarding not to change nature of land - Further inquiry was dispensed by invoking urgency u/S.17 of LA Act, which is illegal - Quashing of notification, proper. 	(Paras 11, 12, 17)

heading: Compensation
Comparable sale instances
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of market value - Comparable sale instances - Instance of acquisition by State Govt. within a distance of about 500 meters for similar purpose of setting up sheep breeding farm - Held High Court was justified in taking this as reasonable comparable instance of sale and fixing market value of acquired land based thereon.	(Para 12)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description: Compensation for trees on acquired land - Determination - Claim for better valuation ought to have been looked into by reference court - Reference Court, held, fell into an error in taking a restrictive view of its own jurisdiction in the matter.		(Para 14)

heading: Acquisition of land in industrial area
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land in industrial area - Authority who has to carry out planned development of industrial estate, is in the best position to judge as to which land can be exempted from acquisition without jeopardizing development schemes - It is not possible for Court to sit in appeal over exercise of such satisfaction by authority vested with the task of implementing development plan.	(Para 11)

heading: Exemption from acquisition
HeadNote.description: Exemption from acquisition - Three units though did not qualify for exemption were granted exemption - They were not parties before court nor any relief was claimed against them - Even assuming that the exemption granted to the said three units was erroneous and illegal, Article 14 does not mandate that the appellants should be granted similar illegal and unjustified relief - Constitution of India, Art.14.			(Para 12)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Not only land but also structure on land can be acquired - As to whether in a given case land should he exempted only for the reason that some construction had been carried out is a matter of policy, and not of law - Courts cannot interfere with the satisfaction of the concerned authorities in this respect.			(Para 13)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Land with fruit bearing trees - Trees sufficiently grown up and bearing fruits - Deduction of cultivation expenses of 50% not necessary in such a case - Claimant, however, though entitled to much more on yield basis claiming only an amount of Rs.5 lacs by not deducting cultivation expenses - Held Reference Court and High Court were justified awarding the same amount. 			(Para 11)

heading: Market value
Determination of
Yield basis
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination of - Land with fruit growing trees - Yield basis - Multiplier of 15 reduced to 10 as more proper and appropriate.	(Para 15)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Determination of market value - Post notification sale deed - Sale deed cannot be simply brushed aside as a post notification sale deed - Most reliable way to determine the market value is to rely on instances made shortly before or after the S.4 notification. 2004 A.I.R. SCW 66 - Followed.	(Paras 20 & 21)

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
Severance
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Compensation - Severance - Claimants entitled to compensation for severance. AIR (29)1942 Bom 105 ; AIR 1981 P & H. 57 - Rel.on.			(Para 22)

heading: Acquisition of Land
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of Land - Compensation - Fixation of market value - Land on Bombay Pune National Highway - Lands grouped into three groups based on distance between land and national highway - Market value enhanced from that fixed by SLAO.			(Para 8)

heading: Acquisition of land
Who can challenge
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Who can challenge - It is only a person, who has an interest in the land who can challenge acquisition. When a challenge is made, to an acquisition, at a belated stage, then even if the Court is inclined to allow such a belated challenge, it must first satisfy itself that the person challenging acquisition has title to the land. Constitution of India, Art.226.	(Para 16)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Merely because the properties vest in the Custodian as evacuee properties does not mean that the same cannot be acquired for some other public purpose - The moment the property is acquired for another public purpose the compensation payable under the Land Acquisition Act would be paid to the Custodian who would distribute it under the provisions of the various Acts. (Para 21)

heading: Interest
Cannot be awarded
HeadNote.description:
Interest - Possession taken before issuance of notification under S.4(1) - Interest for period anterior to publication of notification under S.4(1) - Cannot be awarded - Possession taken prior to issuance of S.4(1) notification is de hors the Act - Land owner is entitled to rent/damages for period Govt. retains possession of property. AIR 1995 SC 762 Rel. on. AIR 1995 SC 2492 Overruled.

In order to decide the question whether the provisions of S.34 of the Act regarding payment of interest would be applicable to a case where possession has been taken over prior to issuance of Notification under S.4(1) of the Act it is necessary to have a look at the Scheme of the Land Acquisition Act. Acquisition means taking not by voluntary agreement but by authority of an Act of Parliament and by virtue of the compulsory powers thereby conferred. In case of acquisition the property is taken by the State permanently and the title to the property vests in the State. The Land Acquisition Act makes complete provision for acquiring title over the land, taking possession thereof and for payment of compensation to the land owner. [Para 11]

The scheme of the Act does not contemplate taking over of possession prior to the issuance of Notification under S.4(1) of the Act and if possession is taken prior to the said Notification it will be dehors the Act. It is for this reason that both Ss.11(1) and 23(1) enjoin the determination of the market value of the land on the date of publication of Notification under S.4(1) of the Act for the purpose of determining the amount of compensation to be awarded for the land acquired under the Act. These provisions show in unmistakable terms that publication of Notification under S.4(1) is the sine qua non for any proceedings under the Act.  [Para 11]

The expression "the Collector shall pay the amount awarded with interest thereon at the rate of nine per centum per annum from the time of so taking possession until it shall have been so paid or deposited" should not be read in isolation divorced from its context. The words "such possession" and "so taking possession" are important and have to be given meaning in the light of other provisions of the Act. "Such compensation" would mean the compensation determined in accordance with other provisions of the Act, namely, Ss.11 and 15 of the Act which by virtue of S.23(1) mean market value of the land on the date of Notification under S.4(1) and other amounts like statutory sum under sub-section (1-A) and solatium under sub-section (2) of S.23. The heading of Part II of the Act is acquisition and there is a sub-heading "Taking Possession" which contains Ss.16 and 17 of the Act. The words "so taking possession" would therefore mean taking possession in accordance with S.16 or 17 of the Act. These are the only two sections in the Act which specifically deal with the subject of taking possession of the acquired land. Clearly the stage for taking possession under the aforesaid provisions would be reached only after publication of the Notification under Ss.4(1) and 9(1) of the Act. If possession is taken prior to the issuance of the Notification under S.4(1) it would not be in accordance with S.16 or 17 and will be without any authority of law and consequently cannot be recognised for the purposes of the Act. For the parity of reasons the words "from the date on which he took possession of the land" occurring in S.28 of the Act would also mean lawful taking of possession in accordance with S.16 or 17 of the Act. The words "so taking possession" can under no circumstances mean such dispossession of the owner of the land which has been done prior to publication of Notification under S.4(1) of the Act which is dehors the provisions of the Act.  [Para 12]

In a case where the land owner is dispossessed prior to the issuance of preliminary Notification under S.4(1) of the Act the Government merely takes possession of the land but the title thereof continues to vest with the land owner. It is fully open for the land owner to recover the possession of his land by taking appropriate legal proceedings. He is therefore only entitled to get rent or damages for use and occupation for the period the Government retains possession of the property. Where possession is taken prior to the issuance of the preliminary Notification, in our opinion, it will be just and equitable that the Collector may also determine the rent or damages for use of the property to which the land owner is entitled while determining the compensation amount payable to the land owner for the acquisition of the property. The provision of S.48 of the Act lends support to such a course of action. For delayed payment of such amount appropriate interest at prevailing bank rate may be awarded. [Para 18]

heading: Expression "such possession" and "so taking possession"
HeadNote.description: Expression "such possession" and "so taking possession" - Means taking possession in accordance with Ss.16, 17 of Act.	(Para 12)

heading: Land acquisition proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition proceedings - Respondents issuing notice under S.9 without complying with provisions of S.6 - Said notice issued consequent to issuance of notification under S.4 - Writ Petition seeking setting aside of Land acquisition proceedings - Held, merely because no further steps were taken by respondents consequent to notification under S.4, it cannot be said that any right had accrued in favour of petitioner.

Where the petitioner contended that once the notification under S.4 was issued in relation to the property in question, the respondents could not have proceeded to issue notice under S.9 without issuing necessary declaration under S.6 prior to insurance of notice u/s.9, it was held that it for the concerned authorities to decide whether they should proceed with particular land acquisition proceedings consequent to the issuance of notification under S.4 and interested persons relation to the land which is a subject matter of notification under S.4 cannot acquire any right of insistence on proceeding with the land acquisition proceedings merely on account of issuance of notification under S.4. In fact, the interested persons in relating to the properties which are concerned under such notification do not acquire any right as such consequent to the notification issued under S.4 of the said Act. Being so, merely because no further steps were taken by the respondents consequent to the notification issued u/s.4, it cannot be said that any right had accrued in favour of the petitioner either to insist on respondents to proceed with the said land acquisition proceedings pursuant to the said notification or to countered that the earlier proceedings stood lapsed.	 [Para 7]

heading: Objection to award
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Objection to award - Limitation - When starts.

A mere perusal of section 18 discloses that there are three situations for which period of limitation has been provided for making an application for reference. Firstly, if the person making the application was present or represented before the Collector at the time when he made his award, the application must be filed within six weeks from the date of the Collector's award. Second and third situations are envisaged by Section 18(2)(b). The second situation envisaged is where a notice is received by the applicant under Section 12 sub-section (2) of the Act. In such a case, the period of limitation prescribed is six weeks from the date of the receipt of the notice or within six months from the date of the Collector's award whichever period shall first expire.  [Para 8,10]

heading: Notice under
HeadNote.description:
Notice under - No particular form is prescribed by the Act or the Rules.

Notice under Section 12(2) of the Act is a clear intimation of making of the award requiring the owner or person interested to receive the compensation awarded under Section11 of the Act. It is not necessary that the notice should contain all the details of the award including the consideration by the Land Acquisition Collector and its manner of determination of the compensation. No particular form is prescribed by the Act or the Rules.   [Para 11]

heading: Nil award
HeadNote.description: Nil award - Special Land Acquisition officer rejecting claim for compensation - This does amount to making of an award, commonly descried as nil award.	(Para 14)

heading: Application for reference
Delay in applying
HeadNote.description: Application for reference - Delay in applying - Land Acquisition Officer making a reference or the court considering a reference has no power of condonation of delay in making an application under S.18.			(Para 14)

heading: Order of reference
Scope
HeadNote.description:
Order of reference - Scope - Land Acquisition Judge cannot entertain application of pro interesse suo or in nature thereof. Civil P.C. (1908), O.1, R.10(2).

The Act is a complete code by itself.  It provides for remedies not only to those whose lands have been acquired but also those who claim the awarded amount or any apportionment thereof. A Land Acquisition Judge derives its jurisdiction from the order of reference.  It is bound thereby.  Its jurisdiction is to determine adequacy or otherwise of the amount of compensation paid under the award made by the Collector.  It is not within its domain to entertain any application of pro interesse suo or in the nature thereof.  [Para 19]

heading: Reference proceedings
HeadNote.description: Reference proceedings - Rejected on ground that applicant is not a party interested within meaning of S.3(b) - Second application not maintainable despite subsequent event. Civil P.C. (1908), O.1, R.10(2).	(Para 20)

heading: Compensation for damages
Entitlement to
HeadNote.description: Withdrawal of acquisition proceedings - Compensation for damages - Entitlement to - Claimant deprived of his right to property for 18 yrs and after notification no steps taken for acquisition - Contention of Govt. that as possession of land continued with claimant he was not entitled to compensation - Held, contention unsustainable and claimant entitled to compensation.	(Para 7)

heading: Compensation for damages
Quantum of
HeadNote.description: Withdrawal of acquisition proceedings - Compensation for damages - Quantum of - Land of Toka tenure - As land of Toka tenure its value to be 50%.	(Para 9)

heading: Compensation for damages
Quantum of
HeadNote.description: Withdrawal of acquisition proceedings - Compensation for damages - Quantum of - Claimant though made no demand for developing land he was entitled to compensation for being deprived of making use of land - No road abutting land and land of Toka tenure - Municipal Corporation had offered Rs.30 per sq. yd. for such land - Value fixed at Rs.30 per sq. yd. - Also as acquisition withdrawn after 18 yrs and compensation decided only after claimant twice petitioned High Court - Govt. directed to pay costs of Rs. 3,000/-.	(Paras 9,11)

heading: Market Value
Determination of
Average method
HeadNote.description: Market Value - Determination of - Average method - Not proper. (Para 4)

heading: Market Value
Determination of
Comparable Sales Method
HeadNote.description:
Market Value - Determination of - Comparable Sales Method - Compensation arrived at on basis of that method - Held reasonable and just.

The best evidence for determining the market value of the acquired land could be an authentic transaction of sale relating to the very acquired land or a portion thereof or any other land which could be favourably compared with the acquired land.  Comparable Sales Method is the most favoured method and such sale deeds must have taken place at a time proximate to the date of publication of preliminary Notification under Section 4(1) of the Act; land sold under the sale must be similar to the acquired land and the land sold under the sale must be in the vicinity of the acquired land, besides the said sales being genuine.  The location, size, shape, tenure, user or potentiality of land under comparable sale have to be taken into account while determining the compensation.  The same principles would apply in respect of Awards of the Courts.

Where the earlier awards based on sale deeds had been passed 4 to 5 years prior to the acquisition of the land in the case under consideration and besides that, in the said Awards, the land acquired was in the heart of city and could, in no manner, be said to be comparable with the acquired land, which is at a distance of about 2 Kms. from city, those awards could not be relied upon for determining the market value of the acquired land under consideration.  However the awards of the lands which were situated at about 1 to 3 Kms. from city and which were acquired for the same purpose for which the land under consideration was acquired, could be relied upon for determining the market value of the acquired land.  Though the trial Court had adopted method of average, but the said method was adopted by the Court in order to re-assure itself that the price which was arrived at on the basis of comparable Award could be fully justified.  The trial Court had come to the conclusion that the rate of the acquired land could be fixed at Rs.35/- per sq. metre based upon comparable Award which was not only in proximity with reference to the time of Notification, but also with reference to the distance.  However, in view of the fact that close to the acquired land modern facilities like electricity, school etc. were available.  The enhancement of rate by Rs.5/- by Reference Court was proper.  [Para 8,11,15]

Held further that compensation awarded in instant case by the Reference Court in relation to construction of fencing, well, trees, as well as compensation on the ground of severance was reasonable, and just.  [Para 16,19]

The claimant was however not entitled to compensation under S.23(1A) of the Act.  [Para 20]

heading: Market Value
Determination
Guess work
HeadNote.description: Market Value - Determination - Guess work - Instance of sale 3 years subsequent to S.4 notification - Reliance on such sale instance for enhancement of compensation is not justified - Sale instance that can be relied should be within reasonable time from date of notification - Period of 3 years is not reasonable. (Paras 5,7,9)

heading: Compensation
Grant of solatium
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Grant of solatium - Cut off date for implementing amended provision was 30-4-1983 - Award made by authority on 29-1-1982 - Solatium cannot be granted - Order granting is illegal. (Para 8)

heading: Declaration made that land is required for public purpose
HeadNote.description:
Declaration made that land is required for public purpose - Conclusive proof of public purpose - Malafide intention on part of authority has to be proved by strong evidence.

Once there is the declaration under Section 6 of the Land Acquisition Act, that the land is required for public purposes, the petitioners land lords will have to make out very strong case to show that the acquisition is with mala fide intentions or the acquisition is excessive acquisition. The declaration under Section 6  is conclusive proof with respect to requirement of the land for public purposes. The petitioners have failed to dislodge this presumption either on the ground of mala fide or on the ground of excessive acquisition.  [Para 30]

In the instant case, what has happened is that the agency which was constructing Bachat Bhavan, is changed. Obviously, the State Government, through Collector, and other Departments of the State Government, were constructing the building of Bachat Bhavan which consisted of auditorium, art gallery, etc. Then it was decided that the entire project be handed over to the Municipal Corporation and accordingly the entire project was handed over to the Municipal Corporation. But the funds provided for construction came from the incentive granted to the Municipal Corporation as per the scheme under "Small Savings". Particular portion of the incentive which was to be given to the Municipal Corporation, as per the rules, was given to the Municipal Corporation and that was used for the construction of "Shri Sant Eknath Rangmandeer". So, "Shri Sant Eknath Rangmandeer" has come up from the cash incentive received in the scheme under the "Small Savings" and, therefore, it continues to be Bachat Bhavan. It is not any different project undertaken by the Municipal Corporation. In such circumstances, if the two plots of the petitioners are being acquired for providing compound to Bachat Bhavan, which is subsequently known as "Shri Sant Eknath Rangmandeer", it cannot be said that the purpose is changed. The purpose continues to be the same that of providing open space around Bachat Bhavan @ Shri Sant Eknath Rangmandeer.  [Para 33,34]

Further, who actually constructed Bachat Bhavan is immaterial. Whether the State has constructed Bachat Bhavan or the Municipal Corporation has constructed Bachat Bhavan, the purpose for acquisition of the two plots is providing additional open space for Bachat Bhavan and that is continued. So, it cannot be said that, in this case, the purpose for acquisition is changed prior to passing of award under Section 11 of the Land Acquisition Act and, therefore, the acquisition becomes void.  [Para 36]

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Declaration made within one year from date of S.4(1) notification - It is valid even if it is published after more than one year for such notification.

There are three steps in this regard. First is the notification under Section 4(1) of the Act which states that the particular land is needed or is likely needed for public purpose and, therefore, there is the proposal of acquisition of the land. Thereafter the objections are called from the interested persons and the objections are considered as per the provisions of Section 5A of the Act and then there is the declaration regarding public purpose for acquisition of the land as per the provisions of Sub-Section 1 of Section 6 of the Act. All these steps are to be complied with and thereafter publication of the declaration is to be made as per the provisions of Sub-Section 2 of Section 6 of the Act. The notification under Sub-Section 2 of section 6 of the Act serves only as evidence of declaration and it also has to be taken into consideration for the purpose of provisions of Section 11A of the Act to find out whether the final award under Section 11 of the Land Acquisition Act is made within a period of two years from the date of publication of declaration.  [Para 46]

The wording used in Sub-Section 1 and Sub-Section 2 of Section 6 of the Act, to the effect "last of any such notification" is meant to make up leeway for the authorities, so that, the maximum time can be made available for the authorities to make a declaration under Sub-Section 1 of Section 6, after the publication of notification under Section 4(1); and similarly, maximum time could be available to the authorities to pass the final award under Section 11, by remaining within the limits of Section 11A. Because of the provision of Sub-Section 2 of Section 6, that last of such notification would be considered for the proceedings thereafter taken in the acquisition of the land. If the Legislature intended that Sub-Section 2 of Section 6 should regulate the provisions of Sub-Section 1 of Section 6 with respect to declaration of the public purpose, then, in ordinary course, the wording would have been, "first of such publication of declaration would be relevant". The intention of the Legislature appears to be to give maximum time to the authorities to take the appropriate decisions. In both Sub-Sections 1 and 2 of Section 6, the last notification is considered relevant, and from this point of view, the argument advanced by the learned Assistant Government Pleader appears correct. Thus, if the declaration is made within a period of one year from the publication of notification under Section 4(1) of the Act, then merely because that declaration is published after the expiry of the period of one year, from the date of notification under Section 4(1) the acquisition will not be void and it cannot be quashed.  [Para 47,49]

heading: Withdrawal from acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Withdrawal from acquisition - Land adjacent to school building reserved for extension of school in Town Development Plan in 1973 - It remained so reserved in revised Development Plan of 1989 - Government issuing notifications under S.4 and 6 at the instance of the society running the school for acquisition of land - Land Acquisition Officer recommending withdrawal from acquisition to Commissioner on basis of resolution passed by Zilla Parishad to the effect that it did not require land for extension of school - Land belonged to State Government and was not transferred to Zilla Parishad by notification published in official gazette - Commissioner without hearing the society who was the sole beneficiary vis-a-vis land sought to be acquired withdrawing from acquision - Held, interest of society as a sole beneficiary in land acquisition was independent in the sense that it had no concern with the ownership of the school building and hence its locus standi to question withdrawal from acquision cannot be challenged.	(Paras 26, 28)

2002(1) ALL MR 560 Followed.

heading: Public interest
HeadNote.description: Public interest - Acquision of land for registered society running a school - It cannot be contended that acquision of land is not for public purpose. (Para 27)

heading: Withdrawal from acquision
HeadNote.description: Withdrawal from acquision - Order cannot be passed without giving hearing to the beneficiary of land - Order is justiciable and reasons given in support are subject to judicial review - Order cannot be passed based on mere recommendation of Special Land Acquisition Officer without application of mind by the Commissioner.		(Para 32)

heading: Compensation
Determination
Comparable sales
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination - Comparable sales - Certified copy of registered agreement is admissible without examining parties to the transaction.

It is not the law that a certified copy of a registered agreement for sale is inadmissible in evidence unless the parties to the document are examined to prove it. That would be contrary to what Section 77 read with Sections 74(2) and 76 of the Evidence Act, 1872 and more specifically Section 51A of the Land Acquisition Act provide. As far as the provisions of the Evidence Act are concerned, a certified copy of the registered sale deed is admissible in evidence and does not need to be proved by calling a witness.	 [Para 5]

Section 51 A is to the same effect. In Land Acquisition Officer and Mandal Revenue Officer v. V. Narasaiah, it was held that by virtue of Section 51-A, a certified copy of a document registered under the Registration Act, 1908 including a copy under Section 57 of the Act may be accepted as evidence of the transaction recorded in such documents. It is open to the Court to accept the certified copy as reliable evidence and without examining parties to the documents. This does not however preclude the Court from rejecting the transaction itself as being malafide or sham provided such a challenge is laid before the Court. 2001(2) ALL MR 517 (S.C.) Rel.on. [Para 6]

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - Court shall take into consideration market value - Payment of any further sum on account of potential value not permitted.	(Para 11)

heading: Reference to court
Limitation
HeadNote.description:
Reference to court - Limitation - Only communication received from Land Acquisition Officer was a letter asking for succession certificate - After furnishing succession certificate bill for compensation was handed over to petitioner - Knowledge of contents of award can be taken to have become known to him when bill was handed over to him or when he received compensation - Application made within six months from either of these dates is not barred by time.

AIR 1963 SC 1604 Rel.On.	(Para 11,12)

heading: Reference to court
HeadNote.description: Reference to court - Petitioner asking for enhanced compensation on the very date he received the compensation - Petitioner could not be said to have received compensation without any protest.	(Para 13)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Scope
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Application for reference to civil court - Scope - Held, Application U/S. 18 cannot be rejected on ground other than that application was beyond limitation period or that it was not in relation to claim for enhancement of compensation awarded for acquisition of land or that application was not by an interested person - Collector cannot decide as to whether applicant had sufficient evidence in support of his claim for enhancement or not - Rejection of application on ground that applicant failed to produce material in respect of justification for enhancement - Rejection illegal and unsustainable.	(Para 5)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Rejection of application
Held, rejection improper
Rel on.
HeadNote.description:
General Clauses Act, S.3(16) - Enhancement of compensation - Application for reference to civil court - Rejection of application - Application rejected for failure to pay requisite court fee within limitation period for filing of application U/S. 18 - Held, rejection improper - Statutes pertaining to court fees are intended to get revenue for State and not to harass parties with sole object to delay their valuable right or to use same as weapon of technicality to avoid adjudication of their claim on merits - Collector to exercise discretion with object and purpose of offering opportunity to parties to make good deficiency in court fees - Application U/s. 18 is a document U/S. 5 r/w S.40 of the Court Fees Act - Obligatory upon Collector to bring to notice of applicant fact of deficiency in court fee and to give just opportunity and reasonable time to pay deficit fee - Application can be rejected only in case of failure to pay within period granted - Insufficient court fee does not render application U/S. 18 inherently invalid.	(Paras 11, 12, 13)

AIR 1967 Bom. 224 - Rel on.

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Rejection of application
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Application for reference to civil court - Rejection of application - Rejection on ground that on reference valuable time of court would be wasted - Held, application cannot be rejected on such ground - Rejection unsustainable.	(Para 14)

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Possession of land taken before issue of notification under S.4 - Compensation - Interest on compensation has to be paid from date of possession and not from date of notification. (Para 7)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Grant of special compensation - Land owners are entitled to special compensation from date of possession and not from date of notification - Interest is not payable on solatium. (Paras 16,17)

heading: Reference proceedings under
