heading: Acquisition in cases of urgency
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition in cases of urgency - Misuse of provision and deprivation of Constitutional rights of individual - Need to be prevented.

Even though ownership of property has ceased to be conceived of as a Fundamental Right, it continues to receive Constitutional protection. It is also the regrettable reality that Governments are increasingly relying on rulings of Apex Court to the effect that even if the public purpose providing the predication for the compulsory acquisition of a citizen's land has proved to be an illusion or misconception, another purpose can conveniently be discovered or devised by the State for retention by it of the expropriated land. It is necessasry insulate genuinely urgent projects from lapsing and not to annihilate the constitutional rights of the individual from the might of the State even though it transgresses essence of the statute. It has become alarmingly commonplace for lands to be expropriated under the banner of urgency or even under normal procedure, only to be followed by a withdrawal or retraction from this exercise enabling a favoured few to harvest the ill-begotten windfall.        [Para 1]

heading:
Importance of right conferred u/S.5A.

The importance of Section 5A cannot be overemphasised. It is conceived from natural justice and has matured into manhood in the maxim of audi alteram partem, i.e. every person likely to be adversely affected by a decision must be granted a meaningful opportunity of being heard. This right cannot be taken away by a side wind, So stringent is this right that it mandates that the person who heard and considered the Objections can alone decide them; and not even his successor is competent to do so even on the basis of the materials collected by his predecessor. Furthermore, the decision on the Objections should be available in a self contained, speaking and reasoned order; reasons cannot be added to it later as that would be akin to putting old wine in new bottles.

2014(6) ALL MR 451 (S.C.) Rel. on.       [Para 6]

heading: Word 'vest'
HeadNote.description:
Word 'vest' - Connotations.

The word 'vest' has two connotations - the first and primary one relates to possession of land; and the second, an adjunctory one, pertains additionally to the title of that land. But this distinction has not been drawn in India since Apex Court has held in several cases that 'vesting' covers and encompasses the possession as well as the title of the land.        [Para 8]

heading: Salient concomitants of the Section
HeadNote.description:
Salient concomitants of the Section - Enumerated.

The salient concomitants of Section 17(1) deserve enumeration. Firstly, the Section is attracted even though an Award has not been made which, it appears to us, clearly indicates that the completion of this exercise has not been obliterated or dispensed with but has been merely deferred. An unambiguous and unequivocal statement could have been made excluding the requirement of publishing an Award. Secondly, it is available only on the expiration of fifteen days from the issuance of the Section 9 notice. This hiatus of fifteen days must be honoured as its purpose appears to be to enable the affected or aggrieved parties to seek appropriate remedy before they are divested of the possession and the title over their land. The Government shall perforce have to invite and then consider Objections preferred under Section 5A, which procedure as painstakingly and steadfastly observed by this Court constitutes the Constitutional right to property of every citizen; inasmuch as Section 17(4) enables the obliteration of this valuable right, this Court has repeatedly restated that valid and pressing reasons must be present to justify the invocation of these provisions by the Government. Thirdly, possession of the land can be taken only if it is needed for public purpose, which term stands defined in the preceding Section 3(f). A conjoint reading of Sections 17 and 3(f) makes it apparent to us that urgency provisions cannot be pressed into service or resorted to if the acquisition of land is for Companies; however we must be quick to add that this question does not arise before us. Fourthly, possession of such lands would vest in the Government only when the foregoing factors have been formally and strictly complied with. This Section enables the curtailment of a citizen's Constitutional right to property and can be resorted to only if the provisions and preconditions are punctiliously and meticulously adhered to, lest the vesting be struck down and set aside by the Court in its writ jurisdiction.      [Para 12]

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Payment of eighty per cent of compensation before taking possession - Provision is mandatory.

Section 17(3A) came to be introduced into the statute by Act 68 of 1984. It requires the Collector to tender payment of eighty per cent of the compensation estimated by him, obviously and pointedly, to the person interested in compensation for such land, unless the Collector is precluded or prevented from making such payments because of exigencies enumerated in Section 31 of the L.A. Act. In other words, the Collector cannot by way of first recourse deposit the estimated compensation even in the Court to which the filing of a Reference under Section 18 is provided. The use of the word "shall" indicates that the provisions are prima facie mandatory in nature unless the statute or the language employed in the Section indicates otherwise. The language of sub-Section (3A), inasmuch as it commences with the words "Before taking possession of any land.....", makes it incontrovertibly clear that what follows are the prerequisities thereto. It is beyond cavil, therefore, that the statute has ordained a precise and particular methodology which must be adhered to as a precursor to divesting the owner of land of its possession and title. It is axiomatic that if a statute prescribes the manner in which an action is to be performed, it must be carried out strictly in consonance thereto or not at all.      [Para 14]

heading: Estimated compensation and actual compensation
HeadNote.description:
Estimated compensation and actual compensation - Difference between.

The use of the word "estimated" in the Section delineates the distinction from "actual" compensation; an estimate always remains a rough or approximate calculation only [Black's Law Dictionary], or an approximate judgment and /or a price specified as that which is likely to be charged. It would do violence to the statute and fly in the face of common sense if an estimate is treated per se as a conclusive calculation.      [Para 14]

The tender of the estimated compensation is the precondition, the sine qua non, enabling the Government to take possession of land under the foregoing subsections; and must be followed by the exercise of computation of compensation in a procedure corresponding to that in Section 11.      [Para 14]

heading: Invocation of urgency clause
HeadNote.description:
Invocation of urgency clause - Logical, cogent and well reasoned noting must precede before any action is taken.

The L.A. Act postulates that the urgency clause can be pressed into service at two stages. Firstly, ordinarily possession can be taken fifteen days after the publication of the Section 9 notice. The decision to procure possession on an urgency basis can be taken by the Government either at the very inception of the proceedings or at any time preceding or contemporaneous to the date of the issuance of the Section 9 notice. In both these contingencies the valuable right of the landowner to file Objections and resist the acquisition by virtue of Section 5A remains unimpaired. Secondly, the Government can invoke sub-Section (4) and dispense with the valuable Section 5A right; in which event, logical, cogent and well-reasoned notings must be simultaneously articulated in writing for taking this momentous and monumental decision.      [Para 15]

heading: Acquisition of land
Challenge to
Civil suit for
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Challenge to - Civil suit for - Main relief sought by appellants is denotification of acquisition - It has attained finality pursuant to proceedings initiated under the Act - Suit filed is not maintainable in view of AIR 1995 SC 1955, 1997 (11) SCC 250.

In the instant case there is no dispute that procedure as prescribed under Land Acquisition Act have been duly complied with by Respondents. In fact, whilst disposing of the writ petition challenging acquisition, Court did not find favour with contentions of Appellants that notification under S. 6 of said Act was visited. Claim of damages put forward by Appellants is not on ground that Collector had refused to adjudicate upon claim put forward by Appellants. It is not contention of Appellants that at time when such claims could be raised in terms of provisions of Land Acquisition Act, such damages were not foreseen at that time. In case Appellants were aggrieved with compensation which was offered in Award of Land Acquisition Officer under S. 11 of said Act, it was incumbent upon them to seek reference in terms of Act within time prescribed therein and not file suit for these reliefs. Claim for compensation in suit are matters which come within purview of said Act which Appellants could have raised interims of provisions of Land Acquisition Act and as such there is no question of filing suit to claim such reliefs. When Act provides a complete mechanism and create specific forum for determination of amount payable as compensation, jurisdiction of Civil Court is impliedly ousted. When jurisdiction has been conferred upon Courts as provided under said Land Acquisition Act, such jurisdiction is exclusive. Act creates special jurisdiction and provides special remedy to claim compensation and as such it would not be reasonable to hold, when Legislature having provided special remedy under Land Acquisition Act , that such remedy is optional for parties either to apply for reference under S. 18 or to institute as suit in ordinary Court. Hence in order that Court can exercise its jurisdiction to determine compensation, such jurisdiction can be exercised only on basis of reference under S. 18 of said Act made by Collector and not by suit. Finding that reliefs sought by Appellants were not maintainable in Civil Suit, held proper.

AIR 1995 SC 1955, 1997 (11) SCC 250 Rel. on. 				     [Para 10]

heading: Land acquisition proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition proceedings - Importance of effective opportunity of hearing, stressed.

The execution authorities entrusted with the lack of acquiring private land for any specified public purpose have time and again exhibited total lack of seriousness in performance of their duties. They must observe following principles in discharge of statutory duties :-

(i) The rule of audi alteram partem engrained in the scheme of Section 5A of the Act ensures that before depriving any person of his land by compulsory acquisition, an effective opportunity must be given to him to contest the decision taken by the State Government / competent authority to acquire the particular parcel of land.

(ii) Any person interested in the land, which has been notified under Section 4(1) of the Act, can file objections under Section 5A(1) and show that the purpose specified in the notification is really not a public purpose or that in the guise of acquiring the land for a public purpose the appropriate Government wants to confer benefit upon private persons or that the decision of the appropriate Government is arbitrary or is vitiated due to mala fides.

(iii) In response to the notice issued by the Land Acquisition Collector under Section 5A(2) of the Act, the objector can make all possible endeavours to convince the Land Acquisition Collector that the acquisition is not for a public purpose specified in the notification issued under Section 4(1); that his land is not suitable for the particular purpose; that other more suitable parcels of land are available, which can be utilized for execution of the particular project or scheme.

(iv) The Land Acquisition Collector is duty bound to objectively consider the arguments advanced by the objector and make recommendations, duly supported by brief reasons, as to why the particular piece of land should or should not be acquired and whether the plea put forward by the objector merits acceptance. In other words, the recommendations made by the Land Acquisition Collector should reflect objective application of mind to the entire record including the objections filed by the interested persons.

(v)The Land Acquisition Collector is required to submit his report and the recommendations to the State Government along with the record of proceedings to enable the latter to take final call on the desirability, propriety and justification for the acquisition of the particular parcel(s) of land.

(vi) The declaration under Section 6(1) of the Act can be issued only if the appropriate Government, on an objective application of mind to the objections filed by the interested persons including the landowners and the report of the Land Acquisition Collector, is satisfied that the land is needed for the particular purpose specified in the notification issued under Section 4(1) of the Act.

heading: Public purpose
HeadNote.description:
Public purpose - Meaning of.

It cannot be said that only development of infrastructure, railways or irrigation, water supply, drainage, road etc. are primary public purposes. Public purpose includes a purpose involving general interest of community as opposed to the interest of an individual directly or indirectly involved. Individual interest must give way to public interest as far as public purpose in respect of acquisition of land is concerned.

Prima facie, State is the first Judge to determine whether there exists public purpose or not. But the decision of the State is not beyond judicial scrutiny. The Courts have the jurisdiction and it is their duty to determine the matter whenever a question is raised whether a requisition order is or is not for a public purpose While determining the question whether a requisition order is or is not for a public purpose, the facts and circumstances in each case are to be closely examined in order to determine whether a public purpose has been established. The requirement of land for residential and commercial purposes and for development of the Sector involves in it an element of general interest of the community and whatever furthers the general interest must be regarded as a 'public purpose' as opposed to the particular interest of individuals. 

2006(6) ALL MR 97 (S.C.), 2009 ALL SCR 731 Rel.on. 		     [Para 9,11,12]

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Land once released from acquisition, it can be re-acquired - No bar against subsequent acquisition or issuance of successive notification.

As regards contention that the land once released cannot be subsequently reacquired, there is no bar to the subsequent acquisition of the land nor is there a bar for issuance of successive notification for acquisition of the land. It would not be right to contend that because the land was already released, it cannot be acquired by subsequent notification. If it is to be held that land already released cannot be reacquired, an anomalous situation may arise that the land cannot be acquired for all time to come even if it is genuinely required. It is not in dispute that the earlier notification is issued by the State for the development of the land for residential and commercial purposes which is same purpose for subsequent acquisition as well. When the State felt that the land sought to be acquired cannot be adjusted in the development of the Plan, there is no bar for issuance of notification for acquisition of the land.	     [Para 15]

heading: Re-determination of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Re-determination of compensation - On basis of enhanced compensation allowed to others - Held, entitlement u/S.28A is only in matters of enhancement allowed to others by Reference Court u/S.18 i.e. under Part III of Act - S.28A is not referable to appellate decree by High Court under Part IV of Act of 1894.

Section 28-A of the Land Acquisition Act stipulates that wherein an award under this Part (Part III), the Court allows to the applicant any amount of compensation in excess of the amount awarded by the Collector under section 11, the persons interested in all the other land covered by the same notification under section 4, sub-section (1) and who are also aggrieved by the award of the Collector may, notwithstanding that they had not made an application to the Collector under section 18, may by written application to the Collector within three months from the date of the award of the Court require that the amount of compensation payable to them may be re-determined on the basis of the amount of compensation awarded by the Court. Entitlement of claimant who has not presented reference application challenging the award of the Collector to claim re-determination of amount of compensation is on the strength of award passed by the reference Court on an application tendered by another claimant covered by same section 4 notification. Re-determination of amount of compensation payable under section 28-A is in reference to award under Part III. The term 'award' shall necessarily mean an award of the Court or an award of the Land Acquisition Officer. Entitlement of claimant to claim redetermination of amount of compensation in the event he does not present application for reference to the Court, is only in the matters of enhancement of amount of compensation by the Court in reference application under section 18 of the Act presented by a claimant covered by same section 4 notification. Re-determination of amount of compensation, as contemplated under section 28A of the Land Acquisition Act, is on the basis of award passed under Part III of the Act and, shall not be referble to an appellate decree by the High Court under Part VI of the Act.	 [Para 3,5]

heading: Land acquisition
Grant of interest
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Grant of interest - Relevant date, where possession is taken before issuance of notification u/S.4 - Even if possession is handed over before publication of award, such possession does not amount to acquisition of land under L.A. Act - Claimants are entitled to interest from date of notification u/S.4 only.	(Para 33)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Legality
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Legality - Suit lands acquired for purpose of primary school and playground - Suit lands being non agricultural lands were situated in centre of city having all necessary amenities and facilities - Every possibility of increasing prices of lands in surrounding area due to faster development and potentiality of lands - Bazar Mulya Takta and ready rackoner produced on record showing price of suit lands in range of Rs.1400/- per sq. meter and Rs.2745/- per sq. meter which were squarely applicable - However, Land Acquisition officer awarded compensation at rate of Rs.1345/- per Sq. meter for first 1000 sq. meters and Rs.807/- for remaining area - No reason was given for such distinction - Hence, Trial Court enhanced compensation at rate of Rs.1400/- per Sq. meter, proper. 			(Paras 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 25)

heading: Acquisition of land
Making of award
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Making of award - Limitation of two years from date of publication under S.6 - Proceeding stayed by court - Such period of stay can be excluded.

In view of Explanation to S.11A, in computing the period of two years, for making the award, from the date of declaration made under S.6, the period during which any action or proceeding to be taken in pursuance of the declaration is stayed by the order of the court such time has to be excluded. In the instant case, the proceedings were stayed for 364 days and the award which was passed was beyond the period of limitation even after excluding this period and as such the award was of no avail.  [Para 11]

heading: Award of compensation
Writ petition against
HeadNote.description: Award of compensation - Deduction of 10% of amount towards royalty from compensation - Writ petition against - Amount deducted on basis of G.R. dtd. 11.01.2017 - Award was passed on 31.03.2016 - Nowhere in G.R. it was stated that it is applicable retrospectively - Further, in case of compulsory acquisition there is no question of deducting any amount towards royalty or premium - Deduction of 10% of amount of compensation towards royalty, improper. 1996 (1) SCC 305 Rel. on. 	(Para 10)

heading: Interest
HeadNote.description: Interest - On delayed payment of compensation - Award u/S.28A, re-determining amount of compensation was passed on 31.03.2016 - Compensation paid to claimant on 5.12.2016 - There was delay on part of authority in making payment of compensation immediately - Claimant entitled to interest for period of delay. 	(Para 11)

heading: Manual of Land Acquisition for State of Maharashtra (1918), Para 328
HeadNote.description:
Manual of Land Acquisition for State of Maharashtra (1918), Para 328 - Govt. Resolutions dtd. 10.10.73 and 19.8.74 - Acquisition of Non-agricultural land for VRCE - Surplus lands surrended to Govt. by VRCE - Govt. planning to allot such lands to construct building for central and its own Departments - Application by owner for release of such lands - Order of Revenue Minister to restore lands in favour of land owner is contrary to Govt. resolutions and is without jurisdiction.

Once the land is acquired and the possession of the acquired land is taken over by the government and Award is passed, the acquired land completely vests in the Government without any encumbrance in view of S. 16.  In the instant case, after issuance of the Notification under sections 4 and 6 of the Land Acquisition Act, the possession of the disputed land was taken over by the Collector in exercise of his power under section 11 of the said Act and consequently the disputed land had vested absolutely in the Government free from all encumbrances.  [Para 10]

Para of the Manual of the Land Acquisition of the State of Maharashtra deals with the disposal of the surplus land.  It says that where any acquired land becomes available for disposal by the State Government, it need not necessarily be restored to the person from whom it was originally acquired unless the person concerned is a landless person or is in receipt of income not exceeding Rs.1000/- p.m. from other sources, in which case the land could be restored to such landless person.  It further says that such excess land, if not granted to the original occupants, should be disposed in accordance with the Standing Orders of the Government regarding disposal of the Government waste lands but on payment of price etc..  This particular paragraph further makes it clear that the surplus land referred to is only the agricultural land and it did not apply to the nonagricultural land or the land having nonagricultural potentiality.  [Para 11]

From the Govt. Resolution it was a clear policy of the Government that the lands which were nonagricultural lands at the time of its acquisition or which gained nonagricultural potentiality after acquisition, were not covered by the Government Resolution dtd.10.10.73.  The land owner's predecessor who held the land at the time of acquisition, himself had made an application for conversion of the said land for nonagricultural purpose.  It is apparently clear that subsequent thereto the land having been included in the City of Nagpur, it was shown in the Development Plan of Nagpur City and shown having been reserved for being used for the public offices as also for commercial use.  It was, therefore, apparently clear from the record that the land had nonagricultural potentiality from the date of its acquisition.  It was also clear that the land was not capable  of being used for agriculture as it was a vacant land within the meaning of Land Ceiling Act, 1976 and also because it was included in the agglomeration of City of Nagpur.  [Para 13]

No doubt the Revenue Minister had to pass an order on review petition in terms of mandate issued by the High Court to decide matter on basis of earlier writ petitions but it was incumbent on the Hon'ble Revenue Minister to consider the Government Resolution itself and also the fact whether the disputed land did have or not the nonagricultural potentiality before deciding to restore the same.  He, however, committed total error, irregularity and non-application of mind in ordering restoration which was obviously in violation of the Government Policy.  Order was, therefore, without jurisdiction which was not available in view of the government Resolution.  The order could not be sustained.  [Para 17,18,19]

heading: Acquisition for public purpose
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition for public purpose - Not practical to attempt a comprehensive definition of "public purpose" - Left to Government to say what is public purpose - Declaration of the Government is final except where there is a colourable exercise of power - Court not to go behind the public purpose nor seek specification in the notification under S.4 of L.A.Act - In case of vagueness court will accept specification in counter - affidavit or where it is evident from the record - "for public trust Saibaba Sansthan" specified in Notification held sufficient - Disclosure in counter affidavit in High Court that land needed for joining two temples - No mala fides if Government first negotiates for private sale.

Case law discussed (Paras 7,8,9)

HeadNote.description: 'Comparable Sales' method of valuation - Sale transaction few months after S.4(1) Notification - Vendor had purchased that land few months prior to S.4(1) Notification and he developed it and then sold it - Acquired land undeveloped and in vicinity - Held, sale transaction after S.4(1) - Notification was not appropriate comparable instance - Appropriate comparable instance was transaction prior to S.4(1) Notification. Sale deed price

Compensation - Determination - Sale deed price - Grant of 10% rise per year on compounding basis can be granted.

heading: Withdrawal from acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Withdrawal from acquisition - Beneficiary has a right to be heard - This right is not limited to acquisition for companies under Part VII of the Act.

Section 48 does not in terms exclude the principles of natural justice. However, the section has been construed to exclude the owner's right to be heard before the acquisition is withdrawn. This is because the owner's grievances are redressable under Section 48(2). But as far as the beneficiary of the acquisition is concerned there is no similar statutory provision. In contrast with the owner's position the beneficiary of the acquisition may by withdrawal from the acquisition suffer substantial loss without redress particularly when it may have deposited compensation money towards the cost of the acquisition and the steps for acquisition under the Act have substantially been proceeded with. An opportunity of being heard may allow the beneficiary not only to counter the basis for withdrawal, but also, if the circumstances permitted, to cure any defect or shortcoming and fill any lacuna.			 [Para 32]

heading: Withdrawal from acquisition
HeadNote.description: Withdrawal from acquisition - Decision to withdraw is justiciable - Declaration of public purpose under S.6 - Public purpose aspect can no longer be questioned.			(Paras 43,47)

heading: Withdrawal from acquisition
HeadNote.description: Withdrawal from acquisition - State Government cannot justify its decision on ground not stated in its order.	(Para 48)

heading: Acquisition for public purpose
HeadNote.description: Acquisition for public purpose - No form of the prior approval required under Section 3(f)(vi) of the Act has been specified in the Act itself - What the section in terms requires is the prior approval to the acquisition for the purpose specified - Lack of compliance with Art 166 of Constitution does not render it a nullity.	(Para 54)

heading: Acquisition for registered society or co-operative society
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition for registered society or co-operative society - Tentative conclusion that land is required for public purpose and approval under S.3 - Can be based on material already on record.

Section 4(1) r.w. Section 3 (f) (vi) of the Act indicates that there are two separate functions to be performed by the State Government. Under Section 4 (1) it must prima facie come to the conclusion that the land proposed to be acquired is required for a public purpose and under Section 3(f)(vi) such tentative conclusion must be coupled with specific approval to acquire the land for the purposes specified for the benefit of the registered society or co-operative society, as the case may be. The Act does not specify the material on which either the tentative conclusion to Section 4(1) or approval under Section 3(f)(vi) are to be based. There is no prohibition on the State Government acting on the basis of material already on record provided the material is sufficient, relevant and genuine.				 [Para 68]

heading: Interest
Not tenable
HeadNote.description: Interest - Reference Court granted interest at rate of 9% p.a. for period of one year by resorting S.28 - On basis of interpretation of S.34 made by Full Bench in 2016(4) ALL MR 513 (F.B.) - Challenge by contending that view so taken by Full Bench would have no bearing upon grant of interest u/S.28 - Not tenable - Both these provisions are pari materia - Intent and language expressed and used in both these Sections are identical except difference of stage at which interest is to be granted - Therefore, interpretation accorded to S.34 would also have its equal application while understanding import of S.28. 2016(4) ALL MR 513 (F.B.), AIR 1964 SC 1878 Rel. on.  (Paras 4, 5)

heading: Interest
HeadNote.description: Interest - Distinction and interpretation between S.28 and S.34 - Both these provisions are pari materia - They are identical in every sense except for stage at which interest is to be granted - S.34 is about interest to be granted at rate of 9% for period of one year by Collector at stage of S.11 Award, while S.28 is on interest to be granted by Civil Court while deciding application referred to it by Collector u/S.18 - Except this, there is no variation or difference in intent and language expressed and used in both these Sections. (Para 5)

heading: Market value
Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Market value - Enhancement of - Acquired lands were Jirayat (dry) lands - Claimants produced three sale deeds for determining market value of acquired lands - Two of those sale deeds were executed after issuance of notification u/S.4 - Cannot be considered for determining market value - Sale instance of land considered by Reference Court was sold at Rs.14,900/- per acre and was having water facility - Valuation of dry lands have to be calculated at half price of lands having water facility from Well - Market price of dry land would be Rs.7,450/- per acre - Market value determined by Reference Court for acquired lands at Rs. 8,000/- per acre - Is just and proper - Need no enhancement. 		(Paras 15, 16, 17)

heading: Land acquisition
Validity
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Classification of land as Jirayat (dry) land - Validity - Claimants claiming that acquired lands are Bagayati-irrigated lands - No cogent and reliable evidence on record to show that acquired lands were Bagayat-irrigated lands - Wells from acquired lands except from one land were not under acquisition - Also mere existence of Wells in rest of portion not under acquisition of acquired lands, is not sufficient to hold that acquired lands were Bagayat-irrigated lands - Classification of acquired lands as Jirayat (dry) lands, proper. 	(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Acquisition of land
Comparable sale deeds
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Determination of market value - Comparable sale deeds - Their genuineness must be established by examining witnesses.

The claimant is entitled to just and reasonable compensation and Section 23 mandates to determine the market value of the lands on the basis of prevailing prices as on the date of publication of the Notification under Section 6(1) of the said Act. The reasonable method for ascertaining and determining the value of the property is the bonafide sales of the acquired lands and in its absence bonafide sales of the lands situated and located in the neighbourhood of the acquired land possessing  similar potentiality or fertility or other advantageous features. The sale instances, however, relied upon must be comparable to the acquired land in certain features such as it must be within a reasonable time of the date of Notification, it should be a bona-fide transaction, it should be a sale of the land acquired or land adjacent to the land acquired and are possessing similar advantages and disadvantages. It is however necessary to establish the bona-fide and genuineness of such sale instances by examining either the vendors or vendees and if they are not available the attesting witnesses who have personal knowledge of the transactions. The original Sale deed or certified copy thereof must be tendered as evidence but that does not dispense with the proof of genuineness and bonafide of such transaction. (1991) 4 SCC 195, (1995) 5 SCC 303 Relied on. Decision of Single Judge dt. 30th Oct 1991 and 3rd March 1992 in L.A.R. No.21 of 1976 and 6 of 1977 (Bom) Reversed.  [Para 18,20]

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Previous judgments or awards - Cannot be relied on in absence of evidence to find out how for they would be comparable to acquired land. (Para 25)

HeadNote.description: Award made before 30-4-1982 - Advantage or benefit of amended provisions could not be claimed. (Para 30)

HeadNote.description: Award of rate of interest - Equity cannot be invoked for enhancement. (Para 31)

heading: S.6 notification issued beyond period of three years
HeadNote.description:
S.6 notification issued beyond period of three years - It is null and void.

AIR 1995 SC 2398 Rel.on. (Para 8)

heading: Vidarbha Irrigation Development Corporation Act (1997), Ss.19(2)(a), 26, 15(3)
HeadNote.description: Vidarbha Irrigation Development Corporation Act (1997), Ss.19(2)(a), 26, 15(3) - Leave to file appeal - Against award of Reference Court - Sought by Corporation on ground that it is an 'acquiring body' u/S.19(2)(a) of Vidarbha Act - Corporation can acquire property for performance of any of its functions - But it does not enable Corporation to compulsorily acquire land under LA Act - As per S.26 of Vidarbha Act power to compulsorily acquire lands under LA Act is with State Govt. - Corporation is not acquiring body - Further, provisions of Ss.3(1), 15(3), 19(2) (a) and 26 of Vidarbha Act shows that Corporation is not local authority within meaning of S.3(31) of General Clauses Act and S.3(aa) of LA Act - It has no direct right to participate in proceedings before Collector or Reference Court - Also, Corporation has not explained why it has not taken any steps to seek permission to participate in proceedings before Reference Court - Moreover, State Govt. has already decided not to file appeal against award of Reference Court - Leave to file appeal, cannot be granted to Corporation. AIR 1963 SC 1890 Rel. on. 			(Paras 16, 17, 20)

heading: Local authority
Definition of
HeadNote.description:
Local authority - Definition of - Does not include Corporation.

	Section 3(aa) of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 does not define "local authority" but it widens the ambit of expression "local authority" by providing that "local authority" will include the town planning authority (by whatever name called) set up under any law for the time being in force. For all purposes, the definition of "local authority" as per Section 3(31) of the General Clauses Act, 1897 will have to be considered for the purposes of the proceedings under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894.

	The statutory body or authority to be termed as 'local authority' has to satisfy the principal test laid down in judgment in AIR 1963 SC 1890, AIR 1981 SC 951, that the body or authority should be entrusted by the statute with such Governmental functions and duties as are usually entrusted to municipal bodies, such as those connected with providing amenities to the inhabitants of the locality, like health and education services, water and sewerage, town planning and development, roads, markets, transportation, social welfare services, etc. The body or authority may be entrusted with the performance of civic duties and functions which would otherwise be Governmental duties and functions. Another important test laid down is that the body or authority should have the power to raise funds for furtherance of their activities and the fulfilment of their projects by levying the taxes, rates, charges or fees. It is laid down that only because the Corporation is furnished with funds by the Government for commencing itsbusiness, it would not make the funds of the Corporation "local funds".

	In the instant case, the Corporation which is established for mobilization of resources for completion of some irrigation projects does not fulfill the above tests. The Corporation is not "local authority" as it cannot be said to be "local authority" as per Section 3(31) of the General Clauses Act, 1897 or a town planning authority as required by S. 3(aa) of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894.

AIR 1963 SC 1890, AIR 1981 SC 951 Rel. on. 		 [Para 14,15]

heading: Term 'person interested'
HeadNote.description: Term 'person interested' - Includes body or corporation only if it is 'local authority' or 'company' as per S.3(aa) or 3(e). 			(Para 13)

heading: Right of appeal
Is statutory right
HeadNote.description: Right of appeal - Against award of Reference Court - Is statutory right - However, it cannot be availed by any person who was not party to proceedings before Reference Court. 	(Para 18)

heading: Acquisition of land for public purpose
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for public purpose - Land acquired for constructing hotel - Certain restrictions imposed in agreement - In terms of agreement Hotel required to create sports and other recreational facilities/amenities within specified time - Such facilities could be enjoyed by hotel residents and other residents of general public - Acquisition of land is under S. 40(1)(b) and not under S. 40(1)(a)or S. 40(1)(aa).	(Para 12)

heading: Acquisition of land for hotel
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for hotel - Right of public access/road to the beach categorically saved in terms of agreement - Held, claim in relation to access was well founded.	(Para 18)

heading: Acquisition of land for construction of hotel
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for construction of hotel - Condition imposed that sports and other recreational facilities should be created within specified time for use of hotel residents and for general public - Hotel not creating any facilities for public purposes - Lands used by hotel for its own purposes - Govt. is entitled to resume lands for breach of agreement - Notice had to be issued for resumption in terms of agreement. (Para 21)

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description: Scope - Notification under S.4 published - Interested person receiving notice inviting him to file objections, if any - Interested person remaining present with objections - Not intimating Spl. Land Acquisition Officer that he wanted to adduce any evidence or wanted to say anything - Cannot be said that requirement under S.5A relating to hearing is not complied with - Not necessary for Land Acquisition Officer to give any further date for hearing (Paras 6,7)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Right of State cannot be curtailed by Development Plan - Particular site earmarked under Development Plan for constructing S.T. Bus Stand - State can instead acquire another site

The right of the State to acquire lands under the Land Acquisition Act as per the provisions of the Act cannot be curtailed by the Development Plan and it is not as if no other land excepting that which may be earmarked for a particular public purpose in the development plan can be acquired if all requirements of the law and the Land Acquisition Act are complied with. Once it is established that the lands are being acquired for a public purpose then the suitability and the extent of lands required for the purpose normally has to be left to the State.  [Para 8]

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description:
Determination of market value - Sale deed relating to small piece of land - It cannot be relied on in determining value of big piece of land.

AIR 1991 SC 2027 Followed. (Para 3)

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description:
Determination of market value - Sale deed cannot be relied on unless vendor or vendee is examined.

(1995) 2 SCC  305  Followed. (Para 3)

heading: Valuation report
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Valuation report - Absence of evidence of expertise of valuer - Neither evidence of valuer nor valuation report can be taken into account. (Para 4)

heading: Valuation report
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Valuation report - No explanation or clarification made by valuer as to how valuation taken five years after S.4(1) notification would be relevant - Neither evidence of valuer nor valuation report can be taken into account. (Para 4)

heading: Award made by Land Acquisition Officer on 30-6-1983
HeadNote.description:
Award made by Land Acquisition Officer on 30-6-1983 - Value of trees separately granted by him - Value of trees also ought to be included in market value of land for calculating benefit under S.23(1A) and S.23(2) of amended provisions of Act.

1989 Goa LT 337 Relied on. (Para 6)

heading: 'Comparable Sales' method of valuation
HeadNote.description:
'Comparable Sales' method of valuation - Mere production and reliance upon sale deeds or copies thereof cannot provide useful guidelines - Necessary evidence must be placed before Court for ascertaining comparability thereof.

To accept any sale transaction as and by way comparable to the acquired land, certain factors will have to be placed before the Court for judging its comparability vis-a-vis the acquired plot. It should be in close proximity of the date of S.4(1) Notification. The similar or dissimilar factors between the two plots of land also make considerable difference. The transaction has to be proved as genuine and bonafide between the willing buyer and the willing seller and that the sale in question is not got up or manipulated. Mere production and reliance upon Sale Deeds or copies thereof will not provide any useful guidelines and necessary evidence has to be placed before the Court for ascertaining the comparability thereof.  [Para 9]

heading: Valuation report
HeadNote.description: Valuation report - No evidence as to expertise and experience of valuer and report lacking objectivity as also professional skill - Also report prepared much after S.4(1) Notification - Evidence of valuer and his report cannot be accepted. (Para 17)

heading: Average method
HeadNote.description:
Average method - Not permissible and acceptable - It does not provide useful guideline for arriving at market value.

The average method has been disapproved and deprecated by the apex Court in various decisions. The average method even otherwise cannot be considered either rational or logical as such, for the simple reason that the property being the subject matter of various sale instances may differ in variety of ways in its potentiality and may not possess similar advantages or disadvantages. Therefore such method apart from the fact that the same is not permissible and acceptable even otherwise will not provide as a useful guideline in arriving at the market value of the property.

AIR 1994 SC 1160  Followed.  [Para 19]

heading: Possession of land taken on 30-3-1984
HeadNote.description: Possession of land taken on 30-3-1984 - Claimants would be entitled to get benefits under amended provisions of S.23(1A). (Para 23)

heading: Land acquisition
Opportunity of hearing
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Opportunity of hearing - Landholder represented by Advocate before land Acquisition Officer - Advocate exhausting opportunity by making submissions - Cannot be said that landholder was not offered personal hearing.

AIR 1976 SC 2095 Rel. on. (Para 4)

heading: Notification under
Publication of
HeadNote.description: Notification under - Publication of - Period of one year is to be computed from date of publication of Notification under S.4 in gazette. (Para 7)

heading: Notifications under mentioning particular area of land to be acquired
HeadNote.description: Notifications under mentioning particular area of land to be acquired - Land in excess of that area cannot be acquired. (Para 9)

heading: Enquiry under
HeadNote.description:
Enquiry under - Landholder given opportunity of hearing - Recommendation by land Acquisition Officer to drop acquisition rejected by Government - Fresh opportunity of hearing need not be given to landholder before acquiring the land.

Once an inquiry under Section 5-A has been completed by giving due opportunity as per law to these whose land is sought to be acquired , there is no second opportunity or a successive opportunities or inquiries contemplated under the Land Acquisition Act, and the Government can proceed to acquire the land rejecting the recommendations made by the Land Acquisition Officer that proceedings for acquisition may be dropped.

AIR 1968 SC 1459 Foll.  [Para 4,5,6]

heading: Land acquisition
Propriety
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Propriety - Comparative utility or availability of land - High Court will not examine under Art.226 of the Constitution.

Under Article 226 the High Court can not sit as appellate authority and examine the propriety of the acquisition proceedings, unless and until the case for mala-fides, either in law or in fact has been made out by the petitioner.  The Court cannot consider the comparative utility of the lands and or comparative availability of the land.  It is the domain of the State Government to decide which land is to be acquired and the extent of land to be acquired.  [Para 8]

heading: Acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition - Plea that landholder will become landless after acquisition of his land- Cannot be accepted when partition is effected to evade acquisition.

Being aware of the acquisition proceedings likely to be taken to acquire the land, the so called partition has been effected and the land likely to be acquired has been shown in the name of the petitioner only, the said submission that because of the acquisition of the stand, the petitioner will become landless and therefore acquisition is not proper cannot be accepted.  When the partition has been effected to evade the acquisition a person becomes landless, would not be a valid ground in law to evade the acquisition proceedings because the Government is empowered to proceed to acquire the land compulsorily according to law.  [Para 10]

heading: Land acquisition
Objection
Refusal to
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Objection - Refusal to - Challenge - On ground that refusal was without reasons - Petitioner's lands acquired for construction of bridge - Objections raised that petitioner would be deprived of residential accommodation and family business due to proposed acquisition - Acquiring Department stated that as bridge and road width could not be reduced considering State Highway, road alignment could not be shifted or changed - If it was changed, parallel bridge would get narrowed down and lead to bottleneck - Objections of petitioner had been duly considered and rejected with reasons - Challenge, not tenable. 2014(4) ALL MR 780, 2014(6) ALL MR 97 Disting. 	(Para 10)

heading: Notification u/S.6
Whether, time barred
HeadNote.description: Notification u/S.6 - Whether, time barred - Declaration of notification u/S.6 was made on 29.01.2013 while published in official gazette on 13.02.2014 - Contention raised that as notification had been issued after 1 year and 12 days, it was time barred - However, proviso II of S.6 (1) provides time limit of one year only for declaration and not for publication - Therefore, notification, held, not time barred. 2011 ALL SCR 1163 Ref. to. 	(Para 12)

Compensation
Valuation of
Building

Valuation of

Valuation

HeadNote.description:
Land Acquisition Reference - Is not by way of an appeal against award of S.L.A.O.

The land acquisition reference is not an appeal against the Award of the S.L.A.O. Only the material produced and provided before the Court can be relied upon. If the material produced before the S.L.A.O. is not produced and proved in the Reference Court it cannot be relied upon.  [Para 7]

heading: Valuation
HeadNote.description:
Valuation - Principles and methodology.

The exercise of valuation has to be undertaken in a common sense manner as a prudent man of the world of business. Thus adopting the common sense approach of a willing purchaser and a willing vendor, the market value of the acquired property is to be calculated. The rental method of valuation is not appropriate in this case as instances of sale are available in the same locality having similar features.  [Para 7]

The S. L. O. has calculated the value of the building at Rs. 48,00,240/-. It has also come in evidence that the life of the building is 80 years. The acquired building was constructed in the year 1940. So by the time f acquisition it had already exhausted 50 per cent of its age. The building is also fully tenanted. These are relevant actors or determining the value o the building on the relevant date.  [Para 8]

heading: Public purpose
HeadNote.description:
Public purpose - Making available lands and other infrastructural facilities to attract huge investments into state - Land under acquisition is for public purpose.

Land acquisition - Public purpose - What is. (Para 1)

heading: "urgency"
validity. (Paras 3,5,7)
HeadNote.description:
"urgency" - S.4 notification describing land as "Likely to be needed" for public purpose - No material before Government to have subjective satisfaction with regard to urgency of acquisition - Consequences of following S.5A enquiry procedure not disclosed - Held, invoking emergency provisions was not justified - Statutory right of affected party to file objections cannot be mechanically taken away.  1996(1)S.C.C. 9 and AIR 1988 SC 1439 foll. 1993(2) SCC 84 Disting.

Land acquisition-Invoking emergency provisions dispensing with enquiry and hearing of objections - validity. (Paras 3,5,7)

heading: Uttar Pradesh Avas Evam Vikas Parishad Adhiniyam (1966), S.55
HeadNote.description: Uttar Pradesh Avas Evam Vikas Parishad Adhiniyam (1966), S.55 - Delay in issue of notification corresponding to S.6 declaration under Land Acquisition Act - Acquisition initiated under State Act would not lapse - Land Acquisition Act stands incorporated in State Acts. (Para 59)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Punjab Town Improvement Act (1922), S.59 - Uttar Pradesh Avas Evam Vikas Parishad Adhiniyam (1966), S.55 - Acquisition of land under State Acts - Compensation - Different principles cannot be applied for land acquired under State Acts and Contract Act. (Para 54)

heading: Foll.
HeadNote.description: Interest on amount payable under S.23(1-A) - Claimant is entitled to interest on the amount of compensation worked out in accordance with S.23(1), (1-A) and (2).			(Paras 29, 64) 2001(7) SCC 211 - Foll.

heading: Application for
HeadNote.description:
Redetermination of compensation on basis of award of the court - Application for - Can be made by a person who sought reference under S.18 but whose application was rejected on ground of delay - Expression "had not made an application to the collector under S.18" in S.28-A - Cannot be construed literally.

It is no doubt true that the object of Section 28-A of the Act is to confer a right of making a reference on a person, who might have not made a reference earlier under Section 18 and, therefore, ordinarily when a person makes a reference under Section 18 but that was dismissed on the ground of delay, he would not get the right of Section 28-A of the Land Acquisition Act when some other person makes a reference and the reference is answered.  But the Parliament having enacted Section 28-A, as a beneficial provision, it would cause great injustice if a literal interpretation is given to the expression "had not made an application to the Collector under Section 18" in Section 28-A of the Act.  The aforesaid expression would mean that if the land-owner has made an application for reference under Section 18 and that reference is entertained and answered.  In other words, it may not be permissible for a land owner to make a reference and get it answered and then subsequently make another application when some other person gets the reference answered and obtains a higher amount.  When an application under Section 18 is not entertained on the ground of limitation, the same not fructifying into any reference, then that would not tantamount to an effective application and consequently the rights of such applicant emanating from some other reference being answered to move an application under Section 28-A cannot be denied.  Hence the dismissal of an application seeking reference under Section 18 on the ground of delay would tantamount to not filing an application within the meaning of Section 28-A of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894.  [Para 4]

heading: Redetermination of compensation
Application for
HeadNote.description:
Redetermination of compensation - Application for - Receipt of compensation with or without protest pursuant to the award is of no consequence for the purpose of fresh application under S.28-A.

If a person has not filed an application under Section 18 of the Act to make a reference, then irrespective of the fact whether he has received the compensation awarded by the Collector with or without protest, he would be a person aggrieved within the meaning of Section 28-A and would be entitled to make an application when some other land owner's application for reference is answered by the reference Court.  It is apparent on the plain language of the provisions of Section 28-A of the Act.  Otherwise, it would amount to adding one more condition, not contemplated or stipulated by the Legislature itself to deny the benefit of substantial right conferred upon the owner.  [Para 6]

heading: Redetermination of compensation
HeadNote.description: Redetermination of compensation - Whether can be made on basis of successive court awards - Question not answered as it was neither referred under order of reference nor did it arise in the case - Correctness of Pradeep Kumar's case (1995 (2) SCC 736) not gone into and decided.	(Para 7)

heading: Market value
Determination of
Capitalisation method
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination of - Capitalisation method - Evidence not forthcoming for adoption of - Taking price fixed under old comparable sale transactions as base value and grant of 10% plus per annum for every subsequent year is neither excessive nor unreasonable. 			(Paras 12,14)

heading: Market value
Determination
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination - Potential value of land under acquisition same as in other connected cases - Supreme Court fixing value in earlier instances at Rs.5 per sq.ft. - Value of land would be Rs.8/- by giving 10% appreciation per year - Value of Rs.7/- fixed by reference Court without any cross-appeals or objections by claimants - Is reasonable and cannot be interfered with. 	(Para 15)

heading: Acquisition of land
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Determination of market value - Compensation computed at rate of Rs.3.5 or 4.0 per meter - Enhancement of compensation - Earlier D.B. Judgment computing compensation at Rs.15/- per meter in respect of similar lands covered by same notification - Computation of compensation at Rs.15/- per meter is valid.	(Paras 9,13)

heading: Acquisition of Land
Solatium and interest
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of Land - Claimants right to get additional amount - Solatium and interest - Explained.

The amount at the rate of 12% per annum as per Section 23(1-A) of the Act has to be calculated from the date of publication of the Notification under Section 4(1) of the Act i.e. 3rd February, 1970 till 23rd March, 1973 with regard to the lands surrendered on that date.  Similarly, it has to be calculated at the rate of 12% p.a. under Section 23(1-A) from 3rd February, 1970 till 17th April, 1973.  Claimant could not contend that the amount should be computed till 22nd September, 1983 being the date of the Award.  A bare reading of Section 23(1-A) of the said Act itself makes it abundantly clear that the interest has to be awarded from the date of publication of the notification under Section 4(1) of the said Act till the date of handing over possession or the date of Award, whichever is earlier. [Para 10,13]

heading: Acquisition proceedings
Setting aside of
HeadNote.description: Acquisition proceedings - Setting aside of - Ground that proceedings have lapsed as award was not passed within 2 years from date of declaration u/S.6 - Award could not be passed as there was stay of proceedings - Plea of landowner that stay was granted in cases of other similar situated landowners and not in their case - When stay is granted in case arising from same acquisition proceedings, it would operate in respect of other lands also - Authorities justified in not proceeding with acquisition proceeding - Further, such period of stay has to be excluded while computing period of two years - Acquisition proceedings cannot be said to have lapsed - Order setting aside acquisition proceedings, improper. 2018(4) ALL MR 948 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Words "stay of action or proceedings"
HeadNote.description: Words "stay of action or proceedings" - Means any interim effective order passed by Court which may come in way of authorities to proceed further. 			(Para 7)

heading: Notice under
HeadNote.description:
Notice under - Is a statutory notice and cannot be liberally construed and service thereof presumed lightly - Internal communication between Survey officer and Talathi cannot have any semblance of notice under S.12(2).

The purpose of sub-section (2) of S.12 is to intimate the persons interested about the award meaning thereby, the essential contents of the award which have become final by virtue of filing of the award in Collector's Office i.e. the true area and the value of the land and the apportionment of the compensation among the persons interested. Though  no form is prescribed for a notice under sub-section (2) of section 12 of the Act, it is clear that a notice under sub-section (2) of section 12 has to contain the above information. A notice which does not contain such information cannot be regarded as a notice under sub-section (2) of section 12 of the Act. Moreover, such a notice has to be issued by the Collector. Unless the law permits the Collector to delegate this power to somebody else, no one else can issue the same.  [Para 6]

A Letter addressed by the Assistant Survey Officer to the patel Talathi informing him about the visit of the Land Acquisition officer for the purpose of payment of compensation can have no semblance whatsoever of a notice contemplated by sub-section (2) of Section 12 of the Act.  [Para 7]

heading: Notice by affixation
HeadNote.description:
Notice by affixation - Not a normal mode of service.

Law is well settled that the mere fact that the serving officer does not find the person to be served with the notice at his address is not sufficient to establish that he cannot be found. It must be shown not only that the serving officer went to the place at a reasonable time when he would be expected to be present, but also that if he was not found, proper and reasonable attempts were made to find him either at that address or elsewhere. It is only if after such reasonable attempts the person concerned cannot be found that it can be said that "he cannot be found" and service can be effected by the substituted mode of affixture.

AIR 1960 Bom.499 Rel.on.    [Para 8]

heading: Compensation
Belting method
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Belting method - Compact block of land acquired for a specific purpose - It was not to be sub-divided into smaller plots where value of plots near the road would have higher value while those further away would fetch a lesser value - In such a case belting method cannot be applied.			(Para 8)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
Potentiality of land
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - Potentiality of land - If potentiality is already taken note of while fixing price no question of giving any additional percentage towards potentiality arises.(Para 12)

heading: Compensation
Computation of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Computation of - Acquisition of compact block of land - Large plots always fetch less than small plots - Hence no question of appreciation on account of largeness arises.	(Para 13)

heading: Interest
From when payable
HeadNote.description: Interest - From when payable - Is payable under Ss.28 and 34 only from date compensation becomes payable - Normally from date of award.	(Para 19)

heading: Interest
HeadNote.description: Interest - Possession taken by invoking urgency clause even before institution of acquisition proceedings - In such cases interest would become payable right from the date of possession by virtue of S.17.(Para 19)

heading: Acquisition of land
Assessment of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Assessment of compensation - Potentiality of the lands, irrigation facilities, quality of soil, its texture and its fertility - Cannot be overlooked while considering and/or while assessing the compensation as contemplated under the Land Acquisition Act.

1975 Mh.L.J. 468, AIR 1990 SC 2192 and 2001(2) Mh.L.J. 386 - Referred to. (Para 10)

heading: Acquisition of land
Assessment of compensation
Sale instances
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Assessment of compensation - Sale instances - No sale instances available for relevant land or related area - Sale instances and material placed on record by land owners, cannot be discarded though sale instances were not of relevant or immediate period from the date of notification in question.

In the present case, various sale instances have been taken into consideration by the learned Judge, while enhancing the compensation. Whereas the land acquisition officer admittedly based its award on the basis of two sale instances, placed on the record.  Out of those two sale instances one sale instance was rejected by the Land Acquisition Officer, himself. The learned Advocate appearing for the respondents pointed out that the remaining one sale instance was not comparable with the land under acquisition, as admittedly the same was of land under Group C. There were no comparable sales in the village Banayat, for the purpose of land under acquisition of Group A and B. The Land Acquisition Officer, therefore, took those sale instances of Group C, into consideration while awarding the compensation, having Rs.2/- per hector as the rate of assessment.  The learned Advocate appearing for the respondents pointed from the award itself, the rate of assessment per hector of the respective lands, which shows that the rate of assessment per hector of the lands in question are 3 to 3.13. Therefore, considering these rates of assessment itself, on the face of record, the land acquisition officer had awarded less compensation. The law is settled that the parties or person or land owners are entitled for the maximum compensation for its lands, subject to other condition must be on higher side. The learned Judge, therefore, rightly relied on the sale instances and material placed on the record by the land owners, as referred in para no.23 of the impugned judgment. Those sale instances even though were not of relevant or immediate period from the date of notification in question, still those sale deeds cannot be overlooked by the Land Acquisition Officer, especially when there is no dispute that no sale instances were available of the village Banayat and, specially of Group A and B, as observed above. The learned Advocate appearing for the respondents therefore, relied on Chinda Vithal Sonone (Supra) (Bom. High Court), wherein after considering the material on record as well as the existing provisions of the law, read with Sections 23 and 24 of the Act, and based on the earlier decisions, our High Court, has expressed in Assistant Development Officer, Trombay Vs. Tayaballi Bohori (supra), permitted to take into consideration such sale instances.  In the facts and circumstances of the case like this, where admittedly there were no sale instances available for the relevant land or related area, in such circumstances, the sale instances available on the record cannot be discarded. For proper assessment it is necessary to look into those sale instances and material on the record, to award compensation to the land owners.  In the present case, admittedly, those sale instances were placed on the record along with the evidence of three witnesses in support of the same, therefore, those sale instances as well as material cannot be overlooked. 1933(35) BLR 763 - Rel on.  [Para 12]

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Question of apportionment expressly referred - Record of rights showing name of a person as "holder" and claimant as a person having "other rights" - Order of L.A.O. showing that he did not accept claimant as exclusive owner but kept question open - Therefore held, question of title has not been referred under S.18.

In a reference under section 18 the Court is entitled to consider only those objections which are referred to the Court and nothing else.  [Para 4]

The reference in instant case expressly refers to the question of apportionment.  Even the application for reference refers to the question of apportionment.  However the claimant submitted that the question of considering of his title to the acquired property does not arise in the present reference.  After reciting the entries in the revenue records, the Special Land Acquisition Officer (S.L.A.O.) has observed in his order that the claimant's claim of exclusive ownership cannot be accepted as in the record of rights produced by him, his name appears as person having "Other rights" and in the record of rights name of another person appears as "Holder".  Thus, read in context, it cannot be said that the S.L.A.O. accepted the claimant's title in the award.  This is further clear when in the operative part of the order the S.L.A.O. declared certain sum as due to the claimant and "heirs of deceased holder".  Had the S.L.A.O. accepted the claimant's title to the exclusion of all others, he would not have passed the award in the above terms.  It is true that the proportion of appointment between the holder and the claimant were not specified.  However, the S.L.A.O. informed the claimant that the compensation would be payable to him "on production of document in proof of your title to the land under reference...."  This therefore clearly establishes that the S.L.A.O. did not accept the claimant to be the true owner, much less the exclusive owner of the said property.  The question of title has been kept expressly open by the S.L.A.O..  He has also not rejected the claimant's claim to property.  Therefore, it is not necessary at this stage for the Court to decide the question of title for the same has in fact not been referred to the Court under this reference under section 18.  [Para 6,8,9,11,12,13,15]

heading: Land Acquisition
Valuation
HeadNote.description:
Land Acquisition - Valuation - Court can take into consideration sale transactions after S.4 notification - Difference of 10 years between S.4 notification and agreement of sale - Agreement cannot be taken as reliable instance of sale.

If there are no other distinguishing features in the post section 4 notification, transaction sought to be relied upon and the circumstances have not affected the prices/valuation thereof there is no reason why it cannot be looked into for the purpose of determining the value of the acquired property.					         [Para 23,27]

heading: Land Acquisition
Valuation
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Land Acquisition - Valuation - Determination - Comparable sale instances should be within reasonable period.

The comparable sale instances should be within a reasonable period.  Now, naturally, what is a reasonable period has not been and indeed cannot be specified as a universal inflexible rule.  It must depend on the facts of each case.	 [Para 26]

heading: Reference under
HeadNote.description:
Reference under - Reference under two sections operate in different fields - Remedy of reference under S.18 is available only to a 'person interested - S.30 remedy is available to person gaining title to land after passing of award - Thus viewed Ss.18 and 30 do not overlap.

The scheme of the Act reveals that the remedy of reference u/S. 18 is intended to be available only to a 'person interested'. A person present either personally or through representative or on whom a notice is served u/S. 12(2) is obliged, subject to his specifying the test as to locus, to apply to the Collector within the time prescribed u/S. 18(2) to make a reference to the Court. The basis of title on which the reference would be sought for u/S. 18 would obviously be a pre-existing title by reference to the date of the award. So is Section 29, which speaks of 'persons interested'. Finality to the award spoken of by Section 12(1) of the Act is between the Collector on one hand and the 'persons interested' on the other hand and attaches to the issues relating to (i) the true area, i.e. measurement of the land, (ii) the value of the land, i.e. the quantum of compensation, and (iii) apportionment of the compensation among the 'persons interested'. The 'persons interested' would be bound by the award without regard to the fact whether they have respectively appeared before the Collector or not. The finality to the award spoken of by Section 29 is as between the 'persons interested' inter se and is confined to the issue as to the correctness of the apportionment. Section 30 is not confined in its operation only to 'persons interested'. It would, therefore, be available for being invoked by the 'persons interested' if they were neither present nor represented in proceedings before the Collector, nor were served with notice u/S. 12(2) of the Act or when they claim on the basis of a title coming into existence post award. The definition of 'persons interested' speaks of 'an interest in compensation to be made'. An interest coming into existence post award gives rise to a claim in compensation which has already been determined. Such a person can also have recourse to Section 30. In any case, the dispute for which Section 30 can be invoked shall remain confined only (i) as to the apportionment of the amount of compensation or any part thereof, or (ii) as to the persons to whom the amount of compensation (already determined) or any part thereof is payable. The State claiming on the basis of a pre-existing right would not be a 'person interested', as already pointed out hereinabove and on account of his right being pre-existing, the State, in such a case, would not be entitled to invoke either Section 18 or Section 30 seeking determination of its alleged pre-existing right. A right accrued or devolved post award may be determined in a reference u/S. 30 depending on Collector's discretion to show indulgence, without any bar as to limitation. Alternatively, such a right may be left open by the Collector to be adjudicated upon in any independent legal proceedings. This view is just, sound, and logical as a title post award could not have been canvassed up to the date of the award and should also not be left without remedy by denying access to Section 30. Viewed from this angle, Sections 18 and 30 would not overlap and would have fields to operate independent of each other.	 [Para 30]

heading: Land owned by the State
HeadNote.description:
Land owned by the State - No question of acquisition of such land can arise.

It would be absurdity to comprehend the provisions of Land Acquisition Act being applicable to such land wherein the ownership or the entirety of rights already vests in the State. In other words, the land owned by the State on which there are no private rights or encumbrances is beyond the purview of the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act.  [Para 31]

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Dispute as to pre-existing right of Government in land acquired - Cannot be subject matter of reference either under S.18 or 30 - Award passed in favour of person cannot be called in question by the state seeking a reference on the premise that land did not belong to the person from whom it was purportedly acquired.

The State is not a "person interested" as defined in Section 3(2) of the Act.It is not a party to the proceedings before the Collector in the sense, which the expression 'parties to the litigation' carries. The Collector holds the proceedings and makes an award as a representative of the State Government. Land or an interest in land pre-owned by State cannot be subject-matter of acquisition by State. The question of deciding the ownership of State or holding of any interest by the State Government in proceedings before the Collector cannot arise in proceedings before the Collector (as defined in Section 3(c) of the Act). If it was a government land there was no question of initiating the proceedings for acquisition at all. The Government would not acquire the land, which already vests in it. A dispute as to pre-existing right or interest of the State Government in the property sought to be acquired is not a dispute capable of being adjudicated upon or referred to the Civil Court for determination either under Section 18 or Section 30 of the Act. The reference made by the Collector to the Court was wholly without jurisdiction and the Civil Court ought to have refused to entertain the reference and ought to have rejected the same. All the proceedings under Section 30 of the Act beginning from the reference and adjudication thereon by the Civil Court suffer from lack of inherent jurisdiction and are therefore a nullity liable to be declared so.	 [Para 40]

However, the quashing of the proceedings under Section 30 of the Land Acquisition Act would not debar the State from pursuing such other legal remedy before such other forum as may be available to the State Government.	 [Para 41]

heading: Application for
Locus standi
HeadNote.description: Withdrawal of acquisition proceedings - Application for - Locus standi - Applicant purchased land after passing of award by Acquisition officer - Land vested with Govt. on passing of award and prior to purchase by Applicant - Applicant had no locus to make application - Application not maintainable. (Para 10)

heading: Withdrawal from acquisition
Application for
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Withdrawal from acquisition - Application for - Maintainability - As possession of land already taken pursuant to acquisition - Application not maintainable. (Para 14)

heading: Acquisition in 1949
HeadNote.description: Challenge to acquisition by alleged successors and return of lands to original occupants - Contention that purpose for which acquisition was made had frustrated - Acquisition in 1949 - Owner and occupant tenants accepting compensation in 1950 - Tenants not seeking restoration during lifetime - Petitioner's claim is frivolous & abuse of process of the Court.	(Para 4)

heading: Land acquired in 1948 for the purpose of T.B.Sanatorium
HeadNote.description:
Land acquired in 1948 for the purpose of T.B.Sanatorium - Not used for that purpose - Govt. taking back possession and allotting the land to different entities for other public purposes - Land put to use by such entities about 20 to 30 years before the date of petition - Challenge on ground of diversion of acquired land from one public purpose to other public purpose - Not maintainable.

(1976) 1 SCC 800 Rel. on.	 [Para 5]

heading: Suit ultimately withdrawn
HeadNote.description: Govt. of Maharashtra resolution dated 10/10/1973 - Restoration of unused land - Land owner claiming restoration on the ground that acquired land was not used for the purpose for which it was acquired - Suit ultimately withdrawn - Claim for restoration by alleged successors of Mirashi tenants for the same reason - Claim is not maintainable.		(Para 5)

heading: Govt. of Maharashtra resolution dated 10/10/1973
HeadNote.description:
Govt. of Maharashtra resolution dated 10/10/1973 - Claim for restoration not tenable since the validity or legality of the G.R. is questionable.

(1997) 5 SCC 432 Relied on.	 [Para 5]

heading: Acquisition of land
Parties
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Land Acquired for administrative department of Mantralaya - Application filed by landholders for reference under S.18 against award - Parties - It is not necessary to join officers of department as parties to reference application - It is also not necessary to join officers of concerned department at regional and district levels as parties - Collector sufficiently represents department and also State - Moreover this aspect does not come within purview of jurisdiction of Collector while dealing with reference application.			 (Para 5)

heading: Acquisition of land
Order is illegal
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Determination of compensation and making of award - Landholder making application for reference to civil court seeking enhancement of compensation - Collector going into merits of matter and holding that award is proper and refusing to make reference - Order is illegal - Collector acting under S.18 is not adjudicating authority to pronounce finally upon the merits of reference - The Collector not only exceeds his jurisdiction but also encroaches upon jurisdiction of civil court.	(Paras 6, 7)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Claim for - Claimant was awarded compensation of Rs.40,000/- per hector for acquired land - Sale instances on basis of which claimant claiming enhanced compensation shows market value of land in area near acquired land to tune of Rs.35,000/- to 50,000/- per hector - Grant of compensation of Rs.40,000/- per hector to claimant, proper. 		(Para 9)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
