Though, a decree-holder may have the right to appropriate the payments made by the judgment-debtor, it could only be as provided in the decree if there is provision in that behalf in the decree or, as contemplated by Order XXI Rule 1 of the Code. The Code or the general rules do not contemplate payment of further interest by a judgment-debtor on the portion of the principal he has already paid. His obligation is only to pay interest on the balance principal remaining unpaid as adjudged either by the Court of first instance or in the Court of appeal. On the pretext that the amount adjudged by the appellate Court is the real amount due, the decree-holder cannot claim interest on that part of the principal already paid to him, out of what is paid he can adjust the interest and costs first and the balance towards the principal, if there is a shortfall in deposit. But, beyond that, the decree-holder cannot seek to re-open the entire transaction and proceed to re-calculate the interest on the whole amount and seek a re-appropriation as a whole in the light of the appellate decree.						 [Para 49]

heading:
S.28 applied to further enhancement of compensation by appellate Court.

Under Section 54 of the Act, a person, still not satisfied with the decree of enhancement in his favour on the reference under Section 18 of the Act, has a right to file an appeal to the High Court and from the decision of the High Court in such an appeal, an appeal to the Supreme Court. If one were to go by the definition of "Court" occurring in Section 3(d) of the Act, Section 28 providing for payment of interest on excess compensation may not apply to an appeal under Section 54 of the Act on the excess, if any, awarded by the High Court or in subsequent appeal by the Supreme Court. But when in an appeal under Section 54 of the Act, the appellate Court further enhances the compensation, it awards the compensation that the reference Court ought to have awarded and so understood, Section 28 of the Act may be applied at the appellate stage. If the expression "Court" used in Section 28 of the Act is understood in the generic sense (on the basis that the context otherwise requires it), the result would be the same. The other provision relevant to be noted is Section 53 of the Act which makes the Code of Civil Procedure applicable to all proceedings before the Court under the Act save insofar as the provisions of the Code are found to be inconsistent with anything contained in the Act. Section 54 also does not keep out the Code, but makes the appeal under it subject to the provisions of the Code applicable to appeals from original decrees.						 [Para 31]
HeadNote.description:
S.28 applied to further enhancement of compensation by appellate Court.

Under Section 54 of the Act, a person, still not satisfied with the decree of enhancement in his favour on the reference under Section 18 of the Act, has a right to file an appeal to the High Court and from the decision of the High Court in such an appeal, an appeal to the Supreme Court. If one were to go by the definition of "Court" occurring in Section 3(d) of the Act, Section 28 providing for payment of interest on excess compensation may not apply to an appeal under Section 54 of the Act on the excess, if any, awarded by the High Court or in subsequent appeal by the Supreme Court. But when in an appeal under Section 54 of the Act, the appellate Court further enhances the compensation, it awards the compensation that the reference Court ought to have awarded and so understood, Section 28 of the Act may be applied at the appellate stage. If the expression "Court" used in Section 28 of the Act is understood in the generic sense (on the basis that the context otherwise requires it), the result would be the same. The other provision relevant to be noted is Section 53 of the Act which makes the Code of Civil Procedure applicable to all proceedings before the Court under the Act save insofar as the provisions of the Code are found to be inconsistent with anything contained in the Act. Section 54 also does not keep out the Code, but makes the appeal under it subject to the provisions of the Code applicable to appeals from original decrees.						 [Para 31]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Award of, by reference/appellate court - Part of amount awarded deposited pursuant to an interim order of appellate Court - Manner of appropriation, if amount withdrawn by claimant, stated.

In such a case, the amount would be received by the decree-holder on the strength of the interim order and the appropriation will be subject to the decision in the appeal or the further appeal and the direction, if any, contained therein. In such a case, if the appeal is disposed of in his favour, the decree-holder would be entitled to appropriate the amount already received by him pursuant to the interim order first towards interest then towards costs and the balance towards principal as on date of the withdrawal of the amount and claim interest on the balance amount of enhanced compensation by levying execution. But on that part appropriated towards the principal, the interest would cease from the date on which the amount is received by the awardee. Of course, if while passing the interim order, the Court had indicated as to how the deposited amount is to be appropriated, that direction will prevail and the appropriation could only be done on the basis of that direction.  [Para 52]

heading: Interest
HeadNote.description:
Interest - On compensation awarded by reference Court - Payable only on excess amount of compensation awarded by reference Court over and above amount awarded under S.11 - By virtue of Section 28, such interest, payable from date of taking possession at rate of 9% p.a. for first year and thereafter at 15% p.a. till deposit of excess is made. Civil P.C. (1908), O.24 Rr.1, 3.

Under Section 28 of the Act, the Court which has awarded compensation in excess of the sum which the Collector did award as compensation, may direct that the Collector shall pay interest on such excess at the rate of nine per cent per annum from the date on which he took possession of the land to the date of payment of such excess into Court. The proviso enjoins the Court to direct that where such excess or any part thereof is paid into Court after the expiry of a period of one year from the date on which possession is taken, interest at the rate of fifteen per cent per annum, shall be payable from the date of expiry of the said period of one year on the amount of such excess or part thereof which has not been paid into Court after the date of such expiry. Two aspects require to be noted. One is that the interest is payable only on the excess amount of compensation awarded by the reference Court and the second is that interest on the enhanced amount awarded is payable from the date of taking possession at the rate of 9% per annum for the first year after taking possession and thereafter at 15% per mum till the deposit of the excess is made.  [Para 30]

heading: Interest on solatium
HeadNote.description:
Interest on solatium - Claim for, if negatived either expressly or by necessary implication by decree, necessarily to be rejected by executing Court - Execution Court cannot go behind decree - But if award/decree does not refer said question or where claim had not been made and rejected, it would be open to execution court to apply ratio of Sunder's case, 2001(4) ALL MR 550 (S.C.) to say that compensation awarded includes solatium and in such event interest awarded on amount can be directed to be deposited in execution.

It is well settled that an execution Court cannot go behind the decree. If, therefore, the claim for interest on solatium had been made and the same has been negatived either expressly or by necessary implication by the judgment or decree of the reference Court or of the appellate Court, the execution Court will have necessarily to reject the claim for interest on solatium based on Sunder's case on the ground that the execution Court cannot go behind the decree. But if the award of the reference Court or that of the appellate Court does not specifically refer to the question of interest on solatium or in cases where claim had not been made and rejected either expressly or impliedly by the reference Court or the appellate Court, and merely interest on compensation is awarded, then it would be open to the execution Court to apply the ratio of Sunder's case and say that the compensation awarded includes solatium and in such an event interest on the amount could be directed to be deposited in execution. Otherwise, not.  [Para 54]

Such interest on solatium can be claimed only in pending executions and not in closed executions and the execution court will be entitled to permit its recovery from the date of the judgment in Sunder (September 19, 2001) and not for any prior period.  [Para 54]

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Acquisition of large tract of land - Exemplar for small plot of land can be looked into by making adequate discount, if no other relevant or material evidence is available.		(Para 5)

heading: Compulsory acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Compulsory acquisition of land - Determination of market value - Development Authority filing appeal and claimants filing cross-appeals before High Court - Apex Court not deciding matter on merits finally though case was pending for over fifteen years because cross-appeals were pending before High Court and it being the Court of first appeal ought to decide them after considering the evidence before it.	(Para 7)

heading: Delay in challenging notification under S.17(1)(iv)
HeadNote.description: Delay in challenging notification under S.17(1)(iv) - Acquisition on 7.3.1962 culminated in award on 30.6.1962 - Payment of full price made on 16.6.1980 - It cannot help appellant because acquisition proceedings were complete in 1962 i.e. much before payment of full price by appellant - Challenge to such acquisition could not have been allowed. (Para 47)

heading: Compensation
Determination
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination - Sale of adjoining developed land @ ' 10 per sq. ft. - On deduction of 1/3 towards development charges market value comes to ' 6.25 per sq.ft. - Valuation fixed at ' 6 per sq.ft is just and proper - In other instances of sales lands covered are land of better quality, and better location with better connectivity - Besides, these are small pieces of land compared to a large tract of land acquired in the present case - Hence, valuation of those lands cannot be relied upon.	(Para 8)

heading: Interest
HeadNote.description: Interest - Claimants are entitled to receive interest on solatium under section 23(2) and additional compensation under Section 23(1-A) - However, such interest can be claimed only from date of judgment and not period prior to the same. 2001(4) ALL MR 550 (S.C.)1 and 2006(4) ALL MR 68 (S.C.) - Rel.on	(Para 11)

heading: Publication of notification
Meaning of
HeadNote.description:
Publication of notification - Expression "in two daily newspapers circulating in that locality" - Meaning of - Authorities should ensure that notification is published in the newspapers having reasonably wide circulation.

The purpose of requiring newspaper publication is to give as wide a publicity to the notification as possible, as the State Gazettes do not have a wide circulation and causing public notice of the substance of the notification at convenient places in the locality would give notice only in specific pockets in the locality. Legislature therefore provided for publication in two newspapers (of which at least one being in the regional language) to have a wider reach. Having regard to the object and purpose of the provision, it is evident that publication should be in newspapers which have a reasonably good circulation in the locality. If the publication is to be made in obscure newspapers having only token or insignificant circulation, either to cut the cost of publication or by way of political or official patronage, that will defeat the very purpose of providing for publication in newspapers. [Para 17]

If there is failure to publish in two daily newspapers or if the publication is in two newspapers that have no circulation at all in the locality, without anything more, the notification under section 4(1) of the Act and the consequential acquisition proceedings will be vitiated, on the ground of non-compliance with an essential condition of section 4(1) of the Act. If the two newspapers carrying the publication of the notification have reasonably wide circulation in the locality, (apart from the publication of the notification in the Gazette and causing public notice of the substance of the notification to be given at convenient places in the locality), then the requirements of section 4(1) are complied with and all persons concerned in the locality shall be deemed to have notice of the notification. (For this purpose, the publication need not be in newspapers having the widest or largest circulation, but it is sufficient if the publication is in newspapers having reasonably wide circulation). In that event, neither the notification under section 4(1), nor the consequential acquisition proceedings would be open to challenge, on the ground of violation of Section 4 of the Act. If the newspapers in which the notification is published were circulating in the locality, but did not have a reasonably wide circulation in the locality, then neither the notification under section 4(1) nor the consequential acquisition proceedings, will become vitiated automatically. If the person aggrieved, apart from demonstrating that the two newspapers did not have reasonably wide circulation in the locality, also asserts that as a consequence, he did not have notice of the proposed acquisition that was provided for in Section 4(1) of the Act, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, the acquisition to the extent of the land of such person will be vitiated. But if such assertion is rebutted by the acquiring authority by placing evidence to show that the person concerned had in fact notice (as for example where he participated in the enquiry under section 5-A of the Act), the acquisition will not be vitiated on the ground of violation of section 4-A of the Act. If the person challenging the acquisition is able to establish that the notifications were deliberately and with malafides, published in newspapers having negligible circulation, to avoid notice to the persons concerned, then section 4(1) will be violated.   [Para 20]

heading: Land Acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition - Acquiring Authority need not prove actual notice of proposal to acquire - Such notice can also be by way of implied notice or constructive notice.(Para 21)

heading: Notice of proposal to acquire land
HeadNote.description:
Notice of proposal to acquire land - Difference between actual, implied and constructive notice.

When notice is directly served upon a party in a formal manner or when it is received personally by him, there is actual notice. If from the facts it can be inferred that a party knew about the subject matter of the notice, knowledge is imputed by implied notice. For example, if the purpose of the notice is to require a party to appear before an authority on a particular date, even though such a notice is not personally served on him, if the person appears before the authority on that date or participates in the subsequent proceedings, then the person can be said to have implied notice. Notice arising by presumption of law from the existence of certain specified facts and circumstances is constructive or deemed notice. For example, any person purchasing or obtaining a transfer of an immovable property is deemed to have notice of all transactions relating to such property effected by registered instruments till the date of his acquisition. Or, where the statute provides for publication of the notification relating to a proposed acquisition of lands in the Gazette and newspapers and by causing public notice of the substance of the notification at convenient places in the locality, but does not provide for actual direct notice, then such provision provides for constructive notice; and on fulfillment of those requirements, all persons interested in the lands proposed for acquisition are deemed to have notice of the proposal regarding acquisition.   [Para 21]

heading: Notice of proposal to acquire land
HeadNote.description: Notice of proposal to acquire land - Respondents 1 to 4 had no interest in land - They had not chosen to get their names entered in revenue records though their father had died 20 years before - They admitted that purchasers of some land from them and their tenant had notice of acquisition - They cannot claim to have suffered for want of publication in newspapers having wider circulation.(Para 25)

heading: Opportunity of hearing
HeadNote.description: Opportunity of hearing - 30-09-2012 was fixed for filing objection - 30-09-2012 being holiday objection filed was received on 01-10-2012 but petitioner's representative did not ask for personal hearing though it was made available to him on that day - His objections in writing were taken on record - Held, objection that opportunity of hearing was not given could not be sustained. 	(Para 5)

heading: Mistake in notifications
HeadNote.description: Mistake in notifications - Wrong survey number stated in S.4(1) notification - Corrected by corrigendum issued subsequently - Correct number was, however, stated in personal notice - Declaration under S.6 was published well within time but same mistake of survey number was repeated - Corrigendum issued to correct this second mistake will relate back to the date of S.6 notification.			(Para 9)

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
Quantum
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Compensation - Quantum - Determination - Application for reference against - Has to be within period of limitation - Claimants in receipt of notice u/s.12 had knowledge of contents of award - Period of limitation would begin from date of service of said notice - Reference filed beyond prescribed period of 6 weeks was thus beyond period of limitation - Said reference was hence not maintainable.

Section 12(2) of the said Act speaks of notice of the award and not a copy of the award to the interested persons, while the objection under section 18 could be in relation to measurement of land, the amount of compensation, the persons to whom it is payable and the apportionment of the compensation.  In other words, if notice issued under section 12(2) in relation to the award passed under section 11 contains information regarding identity and the area of land acquired, the rate of the compensation awarded and the share of the addressee of the notice in the compensation awarded then it could be sufficient compliance of the provisions of section 12(2) of the said Act which would enable the interested person to file objections, if any, under section 18 in case he is dissatisfied on account of any of the factors mentioned in the said provision of law.  For this reason, he need not have copy of the award itself.  Once reference is made, he can even elaborate his grounds of objections before the Reference Court and the Reference Court can allow amendment by resorting to the provisions of Order VI, Rule 17, CPC.

In the instant case, the award, in fact, was ready on 11-04-1985 and a copy thereof was available with the claimants.  As the same was not signed because the concerned S.L.O. was transferred, it was required to be signed by the second S.L.O. and that is what was done on 17-06-1986 for the purpose of its declaration under section 11 of the said Act.  The above facts thus reveal the knowledge of the contents of the award to the claimants even on the date of the receipt of the notice under section 12 of the said Act itself.  The application filed under section 18 of the said Act was, therefore, clearly beyond the period of six weeks from the date of service of notice under section 12.  [Para 11,18,19]

heading: Land acquisition
Objections
Consideration
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Objections - Consideration - Personal notice given to petitioner for acquisition of his land - Petitioner did not file objections within 30 days - Written objections filed much after expiry of such period - Persons filing objections beyond 30 days cannot insist personal hearing as of right - No specific bar for authorities to take into consideration such objections in case the objections contain any material worth considering - Refusal to consider such objections would not create any right in favour of objector nor it would vitiate the acquisition proceedings.	(Para 6)

heading: Accrual of right
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition-Ceiling on land - Accrual of right - Maharashtra Resettlement of Project Displaced Persons Act, 1976 prescribing limit of 8 acres of land which was required to be excluded from acquisition proceeding- Rehabilitation Act repealed Resettlement Act and prescribed limit of 4 acres of land - As no acquisition proceedings initiated during time when Resettlement Act was in force, no right accrued in favour of petitioner for exclusion of any particular area of land from acquisition proceedings when same had not fallen below ceiling limit of 4 acres.			(Paras 7, 8, 9)

heading: Relevant date
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Relevant date - Government abandoning earlier notification by issuing fresh notification - Compensation would be payable with reference to publication of second preliminary notification.	(Para 10)

heading: Expression "loacal authority" and "person interested"
HeadNote.description:
Expression "loacal authority" and "person interested" - Delhi Development Authority is "local authority" and "person interested" - Hence it was entitled to participate in land acquisition proceedings - Failure to issue notice to DDA was fatal to award passed - It was entitled to notice and opportunity to lead evidence before Reference Court.

The DDA falls within the definition of the expressions "local authority" [Section 3(aa)] and "person interested" [Section 3(b)] of the Act; and it was entitled to participate in the proceedings held before the Land Acquisition Collector. The failure of the Land Acquisition Collector to issue notice to the DDA and give an opportunity to it to adduce evidence for the purpose of determining the amount of compensation payable to the land owners was fatal to the award passed by him. The DDA was entitled to notice and opportunity to adduce evidence before the Reference Court could enhance market value of the acquired land entitling the respondents to claim higher compensation and, as no notice or opportunity was given to the DDA by the Reference Court, the judgments rendered by it are liable to be treated as nullity. The High Court also committed serious error by further enhancing the amount of compensation payable to the contesting respondents without requiring them to implead the DDA as party respondent so as to enable it to contest their prayer for grant of higher compensation.   [Para 27]

heading: Interest on additional compensation
HeadNote.description: Interest on additional compensation - Interest claimed first time in first appeal - Additional compensation for trees and structures on land awarded by Reference Court - Claim for interest on additional compensation never made before Reference Court - Claim of interest under S.28 refers to statutory benefit - Hence, it is permitted to raise it for first time in this appeal.	(Para 3)

heading: Followed.			(Paras 19, 24)
HeadNote.description: Interest on additional compensation - Land in dispute is forest land declared as wild life sanctuary - 12% additional compensation granted for forest and fruit bearing trees and structures - Appellants are claiming interest on additional compensation - Additional amount is awarded by Reference Court in excess of sum awarded by Collector - Additional amount granted is as per provisions under S.28 - Respondent is liable to pay interest for period from date of taking possession till making of excess payment. 2007 ALL SCR 943 - Followed.			(Paras 19, 24)

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Rejection merely on ground of failure of petitioner to adduce evidence - Is improper. 2004(1) ALL MR 651 Foll. 			(Para 9)

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Acquiring body not made party respondent - Judgment of Supreme Court, making it incumbent upon claimants to add acquiring body as party to the reference has been delivered, subsequently after filing this reference - Court below should have given fair opportunity to the petitioner to file application for impleading the acquiring body as a party to the reference - Claim of petitioner should not have been discarded/rejected, merely on technicalities of not adding acquiring body as a party to the reference.	(Para 11)

heading: Notification under
Effect
HeadNote.description:
Notification under - Effect - Person purchasing land after issuance of notification - Cannot challenge notification on any ground what so ever.

A person who purchases land subsequent to the issuance of a Section 4 notification with respect to it, is not competent to challenge the validity of the acquisition proceedings on any ground whatsoever, for the reason that the sale deed executed in his favour does not confer upon him, any title and at the most he can claim compensation on the basis of his vendor's title.  [Para 10]

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Possession of land taken - Application for release of land is not maintainable.
AIR 2005 SC 3581, 2010 ALL SCR 1863 Rel. on.  (Para 13)

heading: Purchase of land subsequent to issuance of S.4 notification
HeadNote.description:
Purchase of land subsequent to issuance of S.4 notification - Purchaser cannot challenge validity of acquisition proceedings.

AIR 1996 SC 540, AIR 1996 SC 1170, (1996) 11 SCC 698, (2008) 9 SCC 177 Rel. on.		(Para 9)

heading: Acquisition challenged by one
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition challenged by one - Others cannot take benefit of the same.

The relief obtained by some persons, by approaching the Court immediately after the cause of action has arisen, cannot be the basis for other persons who have belatedly filed their petition, to take the benefit of earlier relief provided, for the reason that, such persons cannot be permitted to take impetus of an order passed by the court, at the behest of another more diligent person. 

AIR 1997 SC 2366, AIR 2010 SC 2430 Rel. on.	 [Para 10]

In the event that the person interested has not filed objections in response to a notice issued under Section 5-A, and has not challenged the acquisition proceedings, the quashing of the declaration issued under Section 6 in some other case, would not enure any benefit to such person. More so, where the possession of land has already been taken, and such land stands vested in the State, free from all encumbrances as provided under Sections 16 and 17(2) of the Act, prior to the date of decision of the Court quashing the declaration in toto, no benefit can be taken by him. Where a party has not filed objections to the notice issued under Section 5-A, the declaration qua such persons is generally neither quashed, nor does it stand vitiated qua him, by any error of law warranting interference. There is also another view with respect to this matter, which is that, in case the said land has been acquired for a Scheme, which does not fall within the ambit of "public purpose" then, in such a case, it would not be a case of acquisition under the Act, instead, it would amount to colourable exercise of power.

AIR 1997 SC 2564 Rel. on.	 [Para 15]

heading: Vesting of land in the State
HeadNote.description:
Vesting of land in the State - Land owner becomes persona non grata - He has a right only to receive compensation and he cannot claim any right of restitution. 

Once the land is acquired and it vests in the State, free from all encumbrances, it is not the concern of the land owner, whether the land is being used for the purpose for which it was acquired or for any other purpose. He becomes persona non-grata once the land vests in the State. He has a right to only receive compensation for the same, unless the acquisition proceeding is itself challenged. The State neither has the requisite power to reconvey the land to the person-interested, nor can such person claim any right of restitution on any ground, whatsoever, unless there is some statutory amendment to this effect.

(2004) 4 SCC 460, (2011) 9 SCC 354 Rel. on.	 [Para 22]

heading: Sale of acquired land by tenure holder
HeadNote.description: Sale of acquired land by tenure holder - Sale is null and void.	(Para 40)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - Award of land in same village available - Reference Court discarded other 2 awards of land in different village, far away from acquired land - Decision of Reference Court is liable to be upheld. 	(Para 16)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Acquired land is fast developing industrial township - Available sale instance is 3 1/2 years old - Escalation should be 10% per annum - Land is rocky with paddy and cashew field area - No evidence as to what extent area acquired can be classified - Deduction of 10% is liable to be effected - Market value of land is liable to be fixed after total 30% deduction - Order accordingly. (2008)17 SCC 436, 2000(4) ALL MR (S.C.) 590 - Rel. on. 			(Paras 16, 17, 18, 20)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - Acquired land is in far interior of village than land in sale instance - It has no motorable access - 20% deduction is liable to be effected - Order accordingly.			(Para 26)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Principle of belting area - Site of new town of acquired land almost at same elevation as Mussoorie and having immense potential value - High Court presuming that total land in Mussoorie is sloppy and hilly - Held, on mere presumption it was not open to High Court to apply principle of belting area. 	(Paras 10, 11)

heading: Reference under S.18
HeadNote.description:
Reference under S.18 - Claimant is entitled to additional compensation @ 12% p.a. from date of publication of notification under S.4 and interest at 15% as compensation was paid after expiry of one year.
2007(5) ALL MR 475 (S.C.), 2012(6) ALL MR 473 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			(Paras 16, 17, 18)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Original owners sold part of their property to respondent no. 1 to 6 - Portion sold is not part of acquired survey number - Compensation not awarded to respondent nos. 1 to 6 - Judgment liable to be upheld. 	(Para 6)

heading: Compensation
Apportionment of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Apportionment of - No evidence produced by appellants to establish that they are the only descendents of original owners - Further respondents no. 7 to 44 have their residential houses in portion of acquired property - Apportionment of compensation to appellants and respondents no. 7 to 44 is just. 	(Para 6)

heading: Reference application
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Reference application - Limitation - Case of respondent that petitioner received notice u/s.12(2) on 4-3-1992 hence reference presented on 24-4-1992 is time barred - Copy of Roznama produced by respondent not sufficient to support its case - Held, in absence of evidence, oral version of petitioner is to be believed that notice u/s.12(2) was received on 11-3-1992 - Reference application filed within limitation. 	(Para 6)

heading: Compensation
Enhancement
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Enhancement - Land Acquisition Officer granted compensation at the rate of Rs.40,000/- per hectare - Acquired land was situated in a village having population of 10,000 and at a distance of just 3 kms. from a junior college - The land was irrigated, fertile and also having a well - Sale instances of adjoining lands show that at relevant time market price of land was Rs.1,00,000/- per hectare - In view of overwhelming evidence, rate of compensation enhanced to Rs.1,00,000/- per hectare. 	(Para 8)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Court must take judicial notice of steady increase in market value of lands.	(Para 16)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Mere reliance on sale deeds of smaller residential area for determination of market value of larger agricultural area, will not render determination illegal until and unless it is shown that determination was not proper.		(Para 19)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - High Court treated land acquired as homestead land when it was actually agricultural land for which annual revenue rent was payable - It also wrongly relied on evidence of officer who was not posted in the area and by relying on official record denied standing crops on the land - Judgment of High Court set aside and order of reference court restored.			(Paras 21, 22, 23)

heading: Compensation
Two sale instances
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Acquisition of land for Govt. Polytechnic Institute - Two sale instances - Claimants were purchasers and sellers in those two instances - These two sales had taken place only two months before had was notified - Apparently claimant was wife of person who was on selection committee of Polytechnic Institute - Held two sale instances could not be relied on as they were slam, collusive and not bona fide.	(Para 14)

heading: Additional evidence about shown and collusive sale instances
HeadNote.description: Additional evidence about shown and collusive sale instances - Claimants had prior knowledge of impending acquisition proceedings and sale instances were executed with intention to raise price of land proposed to be acquired - Held High Court ought to have allowed application to produce additional evidence in support.	(Para 15)

heading: Compensation
Deduction
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Deduction - Is to be applied on account of carrying out of developmental activities like providing roads, electricity, water etc. - It can also be applied where sale instances relate to smaller pieces of land and on account of wastage of land - No uniform rule applicable to all cases can be laid down.	(Para 18)

heading: Compensation
Deduction
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Deduction - Class of cases where no deduction can be allowed also cannot be defined stricto sensu.

The cases where the acquired land itself is fully developed and has all essential amenities, before acquisition, for the purpose for which it is acquired requiring no additional expenditure for its development, falls under the purview of cases of 'no deduction'. Furthermore, where the evidence led by the parties is of such instances where the compensation paid is comparable, i.e. exemplar lands have all the features comparable to the proposed acquired land, including that of size, is another category of cases where principle of 'no deduction' may be applied. These may be the cases where least or no deduction could be made. Such cases are exceptional and/or rare as normally the lands which are proposed to be acquired for development purposes would be agricultural lands and/or semi or haphazardly developed lands at the time of issuance of notification under Section 4(1) of the Act, which is the relevant time to be taken into consideration for all purposes and intents for determining the market value of the land in question.   [Para 19]

heading: Compensation
Exemplar sale instances
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Exemplar sale instances - Non-examination of vendor and vendee - Sale instances cannot be rejected on this ground. (1997)10 SCC 128 stood overruled by (2004)8 SCC 270.	(Para 16)

heading: Compensation
Exemplar sale instances
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Exemplar sale instances - Sale instances of smaller land - Applicability of principle of deduction.

The acquired land has to be more or less developed land as its developed surrounding areas, with all amenities and facilities and is fit to be used for the purpose for which it is acquired without any further expenditure, before such land could be considered for no deduction. Similarly the sale instances even of smaller plots could be considered for determining the market value of a larger chunk of land with some deduction unless, there was comparability in potential, utilisation, amenities and infrastructure with hardly any distinction. On such principles each case would have to be considered on its own merits.   [Para 20]

heading: Compensation
Valuation of land
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Valuation of land - Some guesswork is irrevitable.

The compensation payable to the claimants has to be computed in terms of Sections 23 and 24 of the Act. The market value of the land has to be determined at the date of the publication of the notification under Section 4(1) of the Act, after taking into consideration what is stated under Sections 23(1), 23(1A), 23(2) and excluding the considerations stated under Section 24 of the Act. More often than not, it is not possible to fix the compensation with exactitude or arithmetic accuracy. Depending on the facts and circumstances of the case, the Court may have to take recourse to some guesswork while determining the fair market value of the land and the consequential amount of compensation that is required to be paid to the persons interested in the acquired land.   [Para 26]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Calculation, guesstimate and conjecture - Meaning of.

'Guess' as understood in its common parlance is an estimate without any specific information while 'calculations' are always made with reference to specific data. 'Guesstimate' is an estimate based on a mixture of guesswork and calculations and it is a process in itself. At the same time 'guess' cannot be treated synonymous to 'conjecture'. 'Guess' by itself may be a statement or result based on unknown factors while 'conjecture' is made with a very slight amount of knowledge, which is just sufficient to incline the scale of probability. 'Guesstimate' is with higher certainty than mere 'guess' or a 'conjecture' per se. The concept of 'guesswork' is not unknown to various fields of law. It has been applied in cases relating to insurance, taxation, compensation under the Motor Vehicles Act as well as under the Labour Laws. All that is required from a Court is that such guesswork has to be used with greater element of caution and within the determinants of law declared by the Legislature or by the Courts from time to time.  (1976)3 SCC 772, 2010 ALL SCR 2152, 2007(12) SCR 703 - Ref. to.  [Para 27,28]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Methods of compensation.

Under the Act, as settled by various judgments of this Court, there are different methods of computation of compensation payable to the claimants, for example it can be based upon comparable sale instances, awards and judgments relating to the similar or comparable lands, method of averages, yearly yields with reference to the revenue earned by the land etc. Whatever method of determining the compensation is applied by the court, its result should always be reasonable, just and fair as that is the purpose sought to be achieved under the scheme of the Act.   [Para 32]

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination of - Some guesswork may be necessary - But in case of no evidence Court will not be in a position to award compensation merely on basis of imagination, conjecture etc..

The guesswork has to be used for determination of compensation with greater element of caution and the principle of guesstimation will have no application to the case of 'no evidence'. This principle is only intended to bridge the gap between the calculated compensation and the actual compensation that the claimants may be entitled to receive as per the facts of a given case to meet the ends of justice. It will be appropriate for us to state certain principles controlling the application of 'guesstimate:

(a)	Wherever the evidence produced by the parties is not sufficient to determine the compensation with exactitude, this principle can be resorted to.

(b)	Discretion of the court in applying guesswork to the facts of a given case is not unfettered but has to be reasonable and should have a connection to the data on record produced by the parties by way of evidence. Further, this entire exercise has to be within the limitations specified under Sections 23 and 24 of the Act and cannot be made in detriment thereto.   [Para 32,33]

heading: Compensation
Deduction
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Deduction - Land acquired situated on reasonably good location surrounded by development activity, civic amenities - Held 10% deduction from market value of acquired land would meet ends of justice.	  (Paras 42, 43, 44)

heading: Application for reference
HeadNote.description: Application for reference - Filing of copy of award and award statement is not necessary - Court fee can be deposited even before the Reference Court and while making reference to Court LAO can always pass a conditional order and forward it to Civil Court. 	(Para 6)

heading: Application for reference
HeadNote.description: Application for reference - Purported rejection of reference was not on merits but shown as disposed of on account of failure to comply with objections - Applicant was, however never served with communication of rejection of reference - Reference application restored to file. 	(Paras 6, 11)

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Compensation - Claimant alone is entitled to maintain application for enhancement of compensation. 	(Para 4)

heading: Impleadment of third party applicants
HeadNote.description: Impleadment of third party applicants - Controversies arising between parties inter se are not capable of determination by Court dealing with determination of S.18 application.			(Paras 5, 7)

heading: Judicial review of
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for public purpose - Declaration u/s. 6 of the Act - Judicial review of - Jurisdiction of the court is limited in this regard - However, in case of total non-compliance or substantial non-compliance of S.5-A, power of judicial review can be exercised.

heading: Declaration u/s.6
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for public purpose - Declaration u/s.6 - Alleged non-application of mind on the part of the State - Held, when ultimate order is itself in question, it is for the State to satisfy the court about validity thereof - Counter affidavit filed in this regard on behalf of a Collector, cannot be held to be sufficient compliance of requirements of law - In such situation production of record by the State is necessary.(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Amendment of pleadings
Question of limitation
HeadNote.description: Amendment of pleadings - Question of limitation - Ordinarily, amendment of pleadings relates back to the date of filing of the proceedings - However, held, the proposition cannot be extended to the question of limitation, because despite grant of leave to amend proceedings, the Court is duty bound the consider whether the claim is within the prescribed period of limitation, just as the original claim.	(Para 7)

heading: Acquisition of land
Award of compensation
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Award of compensation - There cannot be separate determination of compensation for land as well as for fruit-bearing trees situate on the land. 1995 Supp. (2) SCC 637 - Ref. to.			(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Sympathy and sentiment by itself should not be a ground to accept method of calculation of market value arrived at by S.L.A.O. when Law does not recognise such course - Statutory Scheme under S.23 of the Act will have to be read as a whole in its context, which is certainly unambiguous. (2004)2 SCC 286 and (1994)4 SCC 595 - Ref. to.			(Para 17)

heading: Ready Reckoner
HeadNote.description:
Determination of market value - Ready Reckoner - Can serve simply as guidelines - Necessary evidence about market value would be the development, the sale instances, its potentiality, the loss suffered by the claimants and benefits to the acquiring body.

The Ready Reckoner is for all purposes to generate revenue for the Government at the time of application of stamp duty and registration of the documents. It can serve simply as guidelines but it cannot be used to be a rule as a whole in derrogation to the statutory scheme contemplated under Section 23 of the Land Acquisition Act. It is again an important aspect that the Ready Reckoner fixed by the Government varies from time to time. It will not be taking into consideration the importance of the property, its location and particular user of the claimants. The necessary evidence about the market value would be the development, the sale instances its potentiality, the loss suffered by the claimants and benefits to the acquiring body. AIR 1969 S.C. 429 - Ref. to.						 [Para 14]

heading: Right to file objections
HeadNote.description:
Right to file objections - Hearing to person whose land is sought to be acquired - Must be effective one and not mere formality. 

Section 5-A of the Act 1894 confers a valuable right in favour of a person whose lands are sought to be acquired. It is trite that hearing given to a person must be an effective one and not a mere formality. Formation of opinion as regard the public purpose as also suitability thereof must be preceded by application of mind having due regard to the relevant factors and rejection of irrelevant ones. The State in its decision making process must not commit any misdirection in law. It is also not in dispute that Section 5-A of the Act, 1894 confers a valuable important right and having regard to the provisions, contained in Article 300A of the Constitution of India has been held to be akin to a fundamental right. Thus, the limited right given to an owner/person interested under Section 5-A of the Act, 1894 to object to the acquisition proceedings is not an empty formality and is a substantive right, which can be taken away only for good and valid reason and within the limitations prescribed under Section 17(4) of the Act, 1894.     [Para 10]

heading: Hearing of objections to acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Hearing of objections to acquisition of land - Officer who hears the case must himself decide it. 

The very person/officer, who accords the hearing to the objector must also submit the report/ take decision on the objection and in case his successor decides the case without giving a fresh hearing, the order would stand vitiated having been passed in violation of the principles of natural justice.    [Para 15]

heading: Acquisition proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition proceedings - Land Acquisition Collector in his report not recommending acquisition of land - Despite such report Government without assigning any reasons for not accepting Collector's recommendation issuing notification under S.6 by holding that land was required for public purpose - Acquisition proceedings are vitiated in law and as such set aside.

AIR 2014 SC 1212, 2013 ALL SCR 2381 Rel. on. 	(Paras 9, 11)

heading: Constitution of India, Art.141
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.141 - Scope and applicability of S.11-A of Land Acquisition Act - Provisions of S.11-A not applicable to acquisition proceedings under M.R.T.P. Act - Decision of Apex Court under Art.141 of Constitution on issue of applicability of S.11-A to the acquisition proceedings under M.R.T.P. Act in Sant Joginder Singh's case reported in 1995 Suppl (2) SCC 475 - Decision, held, direct decision and binding on the High Court. 1995 Suppl (2) SCC 475 - Rel. on.			(Para 20)

heading: Market value
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Oral evidence that public transport, water pipeline, electricity, telephone lines are available - Acquired land is fit for construction of buildings - Evidence is corroborated by Government approved valuer - Acquired land is land with building potentiality, situated within settlement zone - Land has advantage of necessary facilities and amenities - Sale deeds produced are of developed and converted land - Land acquired is undeveloped and unconverted hence deduction in price of plots of sale deeds must be made to arrive at market value - Deduction of 40% made by Reference Court is just and reasonable.

2010 (1) SCC 444 Ref. 	 [Para 18,21]

heading: Market value
HeadNote.description: Market value - There is gap of 1 year in publication of notification and date of sale deeds - Annual increase of at least 10% in price of land must be considered. 			(Para 22)

heading: Market value
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Land of applicant though is adjacent to road, it is in settlement zone - Land is fit for construction and has potential for development - Deduction of 35% made by Reference Court - Ground that acquired land is abutting existing road and within setback area, hence could not be utilized for construction - Deduction made on such ground is not liable to be upheld.

2009(5) ALL MR 1022 (S.C.) Ref. 			 [Para 24,25]

heading: Market value
HeadNote.description: Market value - Portion of land is severed because of old and new course of nallah - Portion has become unapproachable and useless - No compensation is liable to be awarded for that severed portion. 			(Paras 28, 29)

heading: Interest
HeadNote.description: Interest - Evidence on record shows that possession of acquired land was taken in May 1981 - Notification was published in 1994 - Applicants are entitled to interest - Order of Reference Court liable to be upheld. 	(Para 30)

heading: Compensation
Market value
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Market value - Deduction on account of cost of development can vary between 30% to 65% - Acquired land was small strip of land while comparative sale deed related to developed plot fit for construction - Hence, High Court found it appropriate to deduct 30% towards development cost. 2005(2) ALL MR 486 - Foll.	(Para 7)

heading: Compensation
Market value
Determination
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Market value - Determination - Acquired land was little below the road level - That by itself cannot justify deduction of 15% for purpose of filling land - Also, because acquired land was acquired after about 3 1/2 years from comparative sale there shall be enhancement in market value.	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination of - Long strip of land measuring more that 2/3 rd of acre lying alongside and adjoining Highway - Determination of market value of acquired land with reference to value of comparable land cannot be faulted.

A long strip of land measuring more than two-third of an acre lying alongside and adjoining the Highway cannot be treated as a land without value or without any potential for development, merely on the ground that the law relating to Highways prohibited construction on either side of the Highway, upto a depth of 40 meters from the centre of the Highway. All that was required to create or realize potential of such land was to annex or merge the said strip of land with the land to its rear. In that event, the strip of land will become the 'access' to the rear-side land from the main road and will also become the frontage of the aggregate land, thereby enhancing the potential and value of the rear-side land, as also creating a potential for its own use. The contention that a land adjoining the Highway should be treated as having no development potential (and therefore as land without much value except as ordinary agricultural land), while considering the lands to its rear which are farther away from the road, or other adjoining lands of the same extent, but having more depth (so as to extend beyond the 40 meters margin) as having potential for development, is illogical and cannot be accepted.   [Para 3,5]

heading: Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Determination of compensation - Solatium, additional amount and interest have no bearing in deciding market value - They are distinct from determination of market value.

It is well-settled that the solatium, additional amount and interest have no bearing on the determination of the market value under first clause of section 23(1) of the Act. The reason for grant of the additional statutory benefits are clearly different. The additional benefit under section 23(1-A) is to mitigate the hardship to the owner on account of deprivation of enjoyment of the land because of the delay in making the award and offering payment. The solatium under section 23(2) is in consideration of the compulsory nature of acquisition. Interest under section 28 of the Act is paid for delay in paying the compensation from the date on which possession is taken. They are distinct from the determination of market value. The fact that the landowner would also be entitled to statutory benefits cannot be taken into account, when determining the market value of the acquired land for purpose of compensation.   [Para 6]

heading: Conclusive evidence
Means conclusive proof
HeadNote.description: Conclusive evidence - Means conclusive proof - There is no difference between effect of two expressions, the aim of both being to give finality to establishment of the existence of a fact from the proof of another.	(Para 19)

heading: Constitutionality
HeadNote.description: Constitutionality - Act being a pre-constitution law is protected from operation of Art.31(2) by the provisions of Art.31(5)(a) and Art.19(1)(f) is not attracted to such a case.	(Paras 21, 22, 23)

heading: Definition of "public purpose"
HeadNote.description: Definition of "public purpose" - Is inclusive and not compendious one - Public purpose is bound to vary with the times and prevailing conditions in a given locality.			(Paras 24, 31)

heading:
Object of the Act.

The object of the law is to empower Government to acquire land only for a public purpose or for a company, and where it is for a company the acquisition is subject to the provisions of Part VII. The acquisition for a company contemplated by Part VII is confined only to cases where the Government is satisfied that the purpose of obtaining the land is erection of dwelling houses for workmen employed by the company or for the provision of amenities directly connected therewith or for the construction of some work which is likely to prove directly useful to the public.  [Para 25]
HeadNote.description:
Object of the Act.

The object of the law is to empower Government to acquire land only for a public purpose or for a company, and where it is for a company the acquisition is subject to the provisions of Part VII. The acquisition for a company contemplated by Part VII is confined only to cases where the Government is satisfied that the purpose of obtaining the land is erection of dwelling houses for workmen employed by the company or for the provision of amenities directly connected therewith or for the construction of some work which is likely to prove directly useful to the public.  [Para 25]

heading: Declaration of public purpose by the Government
HeadNote.description: Declaration of public purpose by the Government - Is final except if there is colourable exercise of power - To such a declaration protection of S.6(3) will not extend.	(Paras 26-29, 36, 40)

heading: Public purpose
HeadNote.description: Public purpose - Justiciability of declaration relating to - Restriction placed by S.6(3) on the powers of Apex Court under Art.32 - of the Constitution must operate - Declaration, however, must be relatable to a public purpose as distinct from a purely private purpose.	(Paras 39, 40)

heading: Notificiation under
HeadNote.description: Notificiation under - Need not set out the fact that the Government had decided to pay a part of the expenses of acquisition or even to state the extent to which the Government is prepared to make a part contribution to the cost of acquisition.			(Para 43)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Colourable exercise of power - Absence of provisions in the Budget as to cost of acquisition and final sanction for a small amount of Rs.100 - Held, these are not circumstances which would suffice to show that declaration was colourable.			(Paras 43, 44)

heading: Meaning of
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition Of Land For Public Purpose - Compensation wholly or partly out of public revenues - Meaning of - Word "part" does not necessarily mean a substantial part in each and every case.

Per majority (Subba Rao, J. dissenting):- Whether taken contribution meets the requirements of the law would depend upon the facts of every case. Indeed the fact that the State's contribution is nominal may well indicate, in particular circumstances, that the action of the State was a colourable exercise of power. 'Part' does not necessarily mean a substantial part and that it will be open to the Court in every case which comes up before it to examine whether the contribution made by the State satisfies the requirement of the law. In this case we are satisfied that it satisfies the requirement of law. Held, on the facts of the case that the decision of the Government to contribute Rs.100/- towards the cost of acquisition of the land which was worth Rs.4,50,000/- satisfied the requirement of Proviso to S.6(1) and the notification cannot be challenged as a colourable exercise of the power. 	 [Para 52]

Per Subba Rao, J. (Dissenting) :- Unless the Government agrees to contribute a substantial part of the compensation, depending upon the circumstances of each case, the condition imposed by the proviso on the exercise by the appropriate Government of its jurisdiction is not complied with. In the instant case it is impossible to say that a sum of Rs.100 out of an estimated, compensation which may go even beyond Rs.4,00,000 is in any sense of the term a substantial part of the said compensation. The Government has clearly broken the condition and therefore, it has no jurisdiction to issue the declaration under S.6 of the Act.  [Para 64]

The underlying object of the section is apparent: it is to provide for a safeguard against abuse of power. A substantial contribution from public coffers is ordinarily a guarantee that the acquisition is for a public purpose. But it is argued that the terms of the section are satisfied if the appropriate Government contributes a nominal sum, say a pie, even though that total compensation payable may run into lakhs. This interpretation would lead to extraordinary results. The Government may acquire the land of A for B for a declared public purpose, contributing a pie towards the estimated compensation of, say Rs.1,00,000. If that, was the intention of the Legislature, it would not have imposed a condition of payment of part of the compensation, for that provision would not serve the purpose for which it must have been intended. Therefore, a reasonable meaning should be given to the expression 'wholly or partly'. The proviso says that the compensation shall be paid by the company or, wholly or partly, out of public revenues. A contrast between these two modes of payment suggests the idea that in one case the compensation must come out of the company's coffers and in the other case the whole or some reasonable part of it should come from public revenues. This idea excludes the assumption that practically no compensation need come out of public revenues. The juxtaposition of the words "wholly or partly " and the disjunctive between them emphasize the same idea. What is substantial part of a compensation depends upon the facts of each case, the estimate of the compensation and other relevant circumstances. While a court will not go meticulously into the question to strike a balance between a part and a whole, it will certainly be in a position to ascertain broadly whether in a particular case the amount contributed by the Government towards compensation is so illusory that it cannot conceivably be a substantial part of the consideration. 	 [Para 64]

heading: Acquisition of land for public purpose
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for public purpose - Fixation of priorities amongst utilities of different kinds - No question of discrimination would, arise merely by reason of fact that Government has declared that establishment of a particular industry is a public purpose.	(Para 59)

heading: Notifications under
HeadNote.description: Notifications under - Prior publication of notification under S.4(1) is not a condition precedent to publication of notification under S.6 - If S.5-A is not in the way there is no irregularity in publishing notifications under Ss.4 and 6 on the same day.	(Para 60)

heading: Acquisition of land in Aurangabad
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land in Aurangabad - Aurangabad city a place of tourist importance and industrially developing - Potential value of land must be kept in view in determining compensation to be paid.	(Paras 11, 13)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Market value of large tracts to be acquired - Valuation in respect of sale of smaller plots cannot be taken as a real basis.

When large tracts are acquired the transaction in respect of small properties do not offer a proper guideline. Therefore, the valuation in transactions in regard to smaller property is not taken as a real basis for determining the compensation for larger tracts of property. For determining the market value of a large property on the basis of a sale transaction for smaller property a deduction should be given.  [Para 13]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Acquisition proceedings commenced on 6-3-1965 - Award passed on 9-7-80 i.e. before 30-4-82, the date from which Amending Act of 1984 was made applicable to pending and subsequent proceedings - Hence, claimants are not entitled to benefit of S.23(1-A). (1994)5 SCC 593, 2010 ALL SCR 2263 - Foll.		(Para 8)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Large chunk of undeveloped agricultural land - Acquisition for residential purpose - Evidence by way of sale deeds to support case not produced - Witnesses only referring to potentiality of land by showing its location, proximity to main road and industries operating in nearby areas - LAD, Reference Court, High Court fixing rates respectively at Rs.16.52, Rs.22 and Rs.50/- per square yard - High Court also referring to rate of one adjacent land at Rs.63/- per sq. yard - Held, after having opined that Rs.63/- was fair value of land it ought not have reduced it to Rs.50/- per sq.yard.(Para 21)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Fixation of fair market value - Court cannot adopt sale price of adjacent land acquired 10 years subsequent to acquisition in question and then go on reducing value by 10% every year to determine fair market value of land in question.(Paras 23, 24)

heading: Fair market value
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Fair market value - Determination - Discretion by court to be exercised within permissible parameters based on evidence before court.

One can never come to any exact figure of price of lands because in the very nature of things, the prices are bound to vary from land to land and further they also depend upon the individual buyer-to-buyer, seller-to-seller and the reasons which led to such sale and purchase. However, Courts in such cases always exercise their discretion within the permissible parameters after appreciating the entire evidence brought on record and applying the relevant legal principles.    [Para 26]

heading: Apportionment of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Apportionment of compensation - Applicant sought impleadment directly before reference court - No application made before Land Acquisition Officer for making reference under S.18 or S.30 - Direct impleadment before reference court for the purpose of apportionment, not permissible.

2007 ALL SCR 46, (2002) 9 SCC 426, 2003(3) ALL MR 758 (S.C.) Rel. on.	(Paras 31, 32)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of market value - Adjacent land's value fixed at Rs. 17.10 per square meter - Held, market value of land in question which was acquired under same notification be fixed at the same rate. Decision in F.A. Nos.312 and 315/1999 (Bom) Dt.15.04.2011 - Followed. 2009 ALL SCR 1790 - Ref. to.	(Para 11)

heading: Land acquisition
Notification
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Notification - Determination of date of publication - Giving of public notice, will have to be construed to be date of publication of notification. (Para 8)

heading: Land acquisition
Notification
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Notification - Modes of publication, stated.

Sub-section (1) of Section 4 provides three modes, (1) by publication in the official gazette; (2) by publication in two daily newspapers circulating in that locality of which at least one has to be in the regional language; and (3) by publication of the substance of such notification at convenient places in the said locality.

heading: Land acquisition
Setting aside of
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Declaration of notification u/s.6 - Setting aside of - Declaration u/s.6 has to be made within a period of one year from date of publication of notification u/s.4 of Act - Notification u/s.4 was issued on 16.9.2011 - Declaration u/s.6 was made on 26.9.2012 i.e. after period of one year from date of notification u/s.4 of Act - Declaration u/s.6 liable to be set aside.	(Paras 8, 9, 12, 16, 18)

heading: Condonation of delay
HeadNote.description: Condonation of delay - None appears for claimant respondents - No reply to application for condonation of delay is filed - Delay in filing appeals by acquiring body is liable to be condoned.	(Para 2)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Appellant was not party before Reference Court - Matters liable to be remanded for denovo consideration by impleading appellant as party - Award passed in reference is liable to be set aside. 1995(2) SCC 326, 2010(3) Mh.L.J. 581 Relied on. 			(Para 4)

heading: Redetermination of compensation
HeadNote.description: Redetermination of compensation - 3 months limitation period to file application under S.28A after passing award - Limitation put to end belated claims - Passing of award was communicated and compensation was paid to petitioner - Petitioner neither sought reference under S.18 nor applied under S.28A within specified time - Petitioner was not vigilant enough and slept over his rights - Petition liable to be dismissed. 	(Para 16)

heading: Determination of compensation
Comparable sale instances
HeadNote.description: Determination of compensation - Comparable sale instances - Three sale instances relied upon by claimant - In first two sale instances plot was sold at Rs.55/- per square meter in year 1982 and if 15% increased per year added value of acquired plot for year 1987 would be Rs.70-75/- per square meter - Also in third sale instance plot fetched price of Rs.85/- per square meter which was one year prior to date of notification an increase of 15% price would be Rs.100/- per sq. meter - Compensation awarded @ Rs.120/- per square meter, held justified. 	(Paras 7, 8)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Claim for compensation on ground of severance - Nothing on record to show that land remained with claimant was small fragment - Even as per deposition of claimant after acquisition land remained with him was about 50,000 sq. ft. cannot be treated as fragment - In absence of any evidence to show that land remanded rendered useless after acquisition, particularly of its smallness - Claim for enhanced compensation cannot be made on ground of severance. 	(Para 9)

heading: Act being ex-proprietary legislation its provisions are required to be strictly construed
HeadNote.description: Act being ex-proprietary legislation its provisions are required to be strictly construed - Proceedings under S.5A are based on principle of eminent domain - S.5A provides minimum safeguard to a person whose lands are sought to be acquired. (Para 10)

heading: Opportunity of hearing and report of Collector
HeadNote.description: Opportunity of hearing and report of Collector - Not an empty formality - Declaration under S.6 can be made only after appropriate Govt. is satisfied on consideration of report. (Para 11)

heading: Formation of opinion that land is needed for public purpose
HeadNote.description:
Formation of opinion that land is needed for public purpose - Is based on consideration of objections of owner of land, report by collector and his recommendations - Hence hearing and report assume importance.

The appropriate Government while issuing declaration under Section 6 of the LA Act is required to apply its mind not only to the objections filed by the owner of the land in question, but also to the report which is submitted by the Collector upon making such further inquiry thereon as he thinks necessary and also the recommendations made by him in that behalf. Sub-section (3) of Section 6 of the LA Act makes a declaration under Section 6 conclusive evidence that the land is needed for a public purpose. Formation of opinion by the appropriate Government as regards the public purpose must be preceded by application of mind as regards consideration of relevant factors and rejection of irrelevant ones. It is, therefore, that the hearing contemplated under Section 5A and the report made by the Land Acquisition Officer and his recommendations assume importance. It is implicit in this provision that before making declaration under Section 6 of the LA Act, the State Government must have the benefit of a report containing recommendations of the Collector submitted under Section 5A(2) of the LA Act. The recommendations must indicate objective application of mind.

(1973) 2 SCC 337, (1998) 6 SCC 1, (1980) 2 SCC 471.  [Para 11]

heading: Proceedings under
Opportunity of hearing
HeadNote.description: Proceedings under - Opportunity of hearing - Owner of land requesting second adjournment as his counsel was out of station - L.A. officer ought to have adjourned proceedings after putting him to terms because hearing his representative was mandatory. (Para 19)

heading: Computation of
HeadNote.description:
Publication of declaration under S.6 - Period of one year - Computation of - Period had to be computed from the last of the date of publication of notification or the giving of public notice in locality - Notification was published in Marathi news papers on 30.3.2010 and on 7.12.10 on the notice board in the locality - Held declaration under S.6 issued on 1.12.2011 was within period of one year.

2011 ALL SCR 2145 - Disting.  (Paras 14, 15)

heading: Urgency clause
HeadNote.description: Urgency clause - Acquisition of land for approach road to dumping ground - Dumping ground was in continuous use for several decades - For continuing its use acquisition of land in question was immediately needed - Any disruption of facility was treble to cause serious consequences on conditions of sanitation in municipal council area - Held recourse to urgency clause was warranted.  (Para 19)

heading: Appeal
HeadNote.description:
Appeal - Error apparent on face of award - Reference Court awarding Rs.45/- per sq.yard - Price of 1 Bigha comprising 2225 sq.yds, would be 1,01,250 and not Rs.1,10,250 - Other grounds raised by appellant were also required to be considered - Held, summary disposed of appeal was not justified.

Under section 54 of the LA Act, a party aggrieved by the award of the Reference Court is entitled to file an appeal against the award of the Reference Court as of right. Such appeals which mostly relate to the correctness of the quantum of compensation or apportionment, raise both questions of facts as well as questions of law. The provisions of Order 41 of the Code are made applicable to such appeals. The High Court, should therefore, if it wants to dismiss an appeal summarily without issuing notice, assign brief reasons, though not required to render a 'brief judgment'. Subject to the requirements and limitations placed by the statute providing for the appeals, appeals may be disposed of summarily, where so provided. 'Summary decision' refers to a decision which is short and quick and not elaborate. But it does not mean 'non-reasoned dismissal', as any order appealable in law has to be reasoned. A dismissal in limine refers to dismissal at the outset. Summary dismissal or dismissal in limine does not refer to a dismissal without assigning reasons.   [Para 9]

In this case the Land Acquisition Collector has awarded Rs.10,250 per bigha. The Reference Court awarded Rs.1,10,250 per bigha. The Reference Court stated that one bigha is equivalent to 2250 sq.yds. and it was awarding Rs.45/- per sq.yd. On that basis, that is at the rate of Rs.45 per sq.yd. the price of a bigha comprising 2225 sq.yds. would be Rs.1,01,250 and not Rs.1,10,250. Thus even without a detailed examination, there is an error apparent on the face of the award of the Reference Court. The other grounds raised by the appellant also deserved examination and consideration, particularly having regard to the fact that several other appeals relating to the same notification, against similar fixation of market value by the Reference Court were already admitted by the High Court and pending consideration. [Para 10]

heading: Unit of measurement
Word 'Bigha'
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Unit of measurement - Word 'Bigha' - Does not have a same meaning in all parts of country - Description by standard units of measurement will be desirable.	(Para 11)

heading: Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Suit to recover interest on amount of compensation - Maintainability - Compensation for acquired land awarded in year 1993 - But having doubt that lands allotted to tenants were not demarcated, the same refused to be disbursed - Being satisfied with document produced by plaintiff in this regard, cheque of amount of compensation handed over to plaintiff in year 2002 - Plaintiff accepted the cheque under protest - This being position, said suit clearly maintainable u/s.9 CPC.            (Para 13)

heading: Payment of interest
HeadNote.description: Payment of interest - Liability of State Government - Land Acquisition Officer after deciding not to release compensation in favour of plaintiff kept the amount under revenue deposit and not in Reference Court - State Government liable to pay interest u/s.34 - In terms of S.31(2) Land Acquisition Officer in such cases should deposit the said amount in Reference Court so as to avoid liability of State Government.           (Para 16)

heading: Notification under
HeadNote.description:
Notification under - Purchase, transfer of land after notification is void and would not be binding on the Government.

A purchaser, subsequent to the issuance of a Section 4 Notification in respect of the land, cannot challenge the acquisition proceedings, and can only claim compensation as the sale transaction in such a situation is Void qua the Government. Any such encumbrance created by the owner, or any transfer of the land in question, that is made after the issuance of such a notification, would be deemed to be void and would not be binding on the Government.

The word "void" is used in the sense of incapable of ratification. A thing which is found non-est and not required to be set aside though, it is sometimes convenient to do so. There would be no need for an order to quash it. It would be automatically null and void without more ado. The continuation orders would be nullities too, because no one can continue a nullity.

2010 ALL SCR 2441, 2012 ALL SCR 2654, AIR 1996 SC 906, (2002) 9 SCC 28 Rel. on. 	  [Para 7,11]

heading: Land acquired for industrial development
HeadNote.description:
Land acquired for industrial development - Respondent society wanted land for residential houses - Such a demand cannot be accepted.

2009(1) ALL MR 459 (S.C.), (2005) 10 SCC 162 Rel. on. 	(Para 22)

heading: Sale deeds executed after publication of notification under
HeadNote.description: Sale deeds executed after publication of notification under - Government though treating them as void - Government cannot at the same time think of regularising such orders - Right to administer cannot include right to maladminister.	(Para 32)

heading: Adequacy of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Adequacy of compensation - Burden of proof is on the owner to prove that award does not correctly determine the amount payable.

In a reference under Section 18 of the Land Acquisition Act on the question of adequacy of compensation determined by the Collector, the burden to prove that the Collector's award does not correctly determine the amount of compensation payable to the landowner is upon the owner concerned. It is for the claimant to prove that the amount awarded by the Collector needs enhancement, and if so, to what extent. The claimant can do so by adducing evidence, whether oral or documentary which the Reference Court would evaluate having regard to the provisions of Sections 23 and 24 of the Land Acquisition Act while determining the compensation payable to the owners. To that extent the claimant is in the position of a plaintiff before the Court. 					       [Para 7]

heading: Compensation
Inadequacy of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Inadequacy of - Owner not producing evidence to prove that compensation awarded by Collector was inadequate - Reference court cannot act as appellate court and enhance compensation by reappreciating material collected and relied on by the Collector. 			(Paras 10, 11, 12)

heading: Acquisition under urgency clause
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition under urgency clause - Acquired land formed part of large area - In phase wise development, area forming part of acquired land may not be developed for years - No illegality.

In the instant case the acquisition was made by applying "Urgency" clause under S.17(4) of Land Acquisition Act (1894). The lands in question were required not only for the purpose of industrial use, but also for residential use. Even in residential area developed by the third Respondent, various amenities are required to be provided. Thus, it appears that acquired lands formed a part of large area acquired by the respondent Maharashtra Industrial Development Corporation for development as an Industrial Area. Said respondent always carries out phasewise development, when the acquisition is of a very large area.
