Considering the method of phasewise development, one particular area forming part of acquired lands may not be developed for years and that is the reason why even assuming that lands held by predecessor of petitioners have not been used for public purpose, there is no illegality. Also various amenities are required to be provided in the industrial as well as residential area and therefore, allotment of portions of land to private parties for setting up of various activities cannot be rendered illegal. 		    [Para 10]

heading: Acquisition proceeding
HeadNote.description: Acquisition proceeding - Initiated in year 1961 and completed in year 1963 - Owner of land did not challenge said acquisition - He even accepted compensation during his life time - Challenge to said acquisition by LRs. of owner of land raised after lapse of 50 years in year 2012 - Not permissible. 			(Para 11)

heading: Reference
Claim of compensation
HeadNote.description: Reference - Claim of compensation - Appellants claimed compensation at Rs.1,00,000/- per acre but paid the Court fee only at Rs.80,000/- per acre for the lands in question - The prayer of the appellants, held, was to fix the market value of the acquired land at Rs.80,000/- per acre.			(Para 7)

heading: Determination of
Comparable lands
HeadNote.description: Market value of acquired land - Determination of - Comparable lands - Lands situated at a distance of 2 to 3 kilometers from the acquired lands - Could not be said to be comparable lands with that of acquired lands.	(Para 12)

heading: Sugarcane growing land
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Veracity of contents of document - Sugarcane growing land - Certificate issued by a government officer giving particulars of the yield - Held, without the author of the said certificate being produced for testing the veracity of the certificate and the contents thereof, it is not safe to rely on such certificate.			(Paras 15 to 17)

heading: Market value
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination of - Capitalisation method of valuation - No valid document from which it can safely be deduced as to what the exact market price of the land in question could be - Adoption of capitalisation method of valuation, held, justified.	(Para 18)

heading: Land taken over without acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Land taken over without acquisition - Writ petition seeking direction to acquire land and pay compensation - High Court directing petitioner to file application under S.18 - Held High Court was not justified in dismissing writ petition because petitioner could not have filed application when his land was not acquired at all. Constitution of India, Art.226.

An application under section 18 of the Act cannot be filed in regard to a land which was not acquired at all. The remedy of a land holder whose land is taken without acquisition is either to file a civil suit for recovery of possession and/or for compensation, or approach the High Court by filing a writ petition if the action can be shown to be arbitrary, irrational, unreasonable, biased, malafide or without the authority of law, and seek a direction that the land should be acquire in a manner known to law. The appellant has chosen to follow the second course. The High Court was not therefore, justified in dismissing the writ petition on the ground that the remedy was under section 18 of the Act.   [Para 5]

heading: Challenge to
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition by invoking Ss.17(1) and (4) - Challenge to - High Court should not literally apply abstract rules of burden of proof - It is too much to expect from rustic villagers to obtain records from Government and then present skillfully drafted petitions for enforcement of their legal/constitutional rights. (1977)1 SCC 133, (2010)11 SCC 242 - Rel.on.			(Para 19)

heading: Acquisition of private property for public purpose
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of private property for public purpose - Principles involved and procedure to be adopted stated.

From the analysis of the relevant statutory provisions and interpretation thereof by this Court in different cases, the following principles can be culled out:

(i)	Eminent domain is a right inherent in every sovereign to take and appropriate property belonging to citizens for public use. To put it differently, the sovereign is entitled to reassert its dominion over any portion of the soil of the State including private property without its owner's consent provided that such assertion is on account of public exigency and for public good.

(ii)	The legislations which provide for compulsory acquisition of private property by the State fall in the category of expropriatory legislation and such legislation must be construed strictly.

(iii)	Though, in exercise of the power of eminent domain, the Government can acquire the private property for public tpurpose, it must be remembered that compulsory taking of one's property is a serious matter. If he property belongs to economically disadvantaged segment of the society or people suffering from other handicaps, then the Court is not only entitled but is duty bound to scrutinize the action/decision of the State with greater vigilance, care and circumspection keeping in view the fact that the land owner is likely to become landless and deprived of the only source of his livelihood and/or shelter.

(iv)	The property of a citizen cannot be acquired by the State and/or its agencies/instrumentalities without complying with the mandate of Sections 4, 5-A and 6 of the Act. A public purpose, however, laudable it may be does not entitle the State to invoke the urgency provisions because the same have the effect of depriving the owner of his right to property without being heard. Only in a case of real urgency, the State can invoke the urgency provisions and dispense with the requirement of hearing the land owner or other interested persons.

(v)	Section 17(1) read with Section 17(4) confers extraordinary power upon the State to acquire private property without complying with the mandate of Section 5-A. These provisions can be invoked only when the purpose of acquisition cannot brook the delay of even few weeks or months. Therefore, before excluding the application of Section 5-A, the concerned authority must be fully satisfied that time of few weeks or months likely to be taken in conducting inquiry under Section 5-A will, in all probability, frustrate the public purpose for which land is proposed to be acquired.

(vi)	The satisfaction of the Government on the issue of urgency is subjective but is a condition precedent to the exercise of power under Section 17(1) and the same can be challenged on the ground that the purpose for which the private property is sought to be acquired is not a public purpose at all or that the exercise of power is vitiated due to mala fides or that the concerned authorities did not apply mind to the relevant factors and the records.

(vii)	The exercise of power by the Government under Section 17(1) does not necessarily result in exclusion of Section 5-A of the Act in terms of which any person interested in land can file objection and is entitled to be heard in support of his objection. The use of word "may" in sub-section (4) of Section 17 makes it clear that it merely enables the Government to direct that the provisions of Section 5-A would not apply to the cases covered under sub-section (1) or (2) of Section 17. In other words, invoking of Section 17(4) is not a necessary concomitant of the exercise of power under Section 17(1).

(viii)	The acquisition of land for residential, commercial, industrial or institutional purposes can be treated as an acquisition for public purposes within the meaning of Section 4 but that, by itself, does not justify the exercise of power by the Government under Sections 17(1) and/or 17(4). The Court can take judicial notice of the fact that planning, execution and implementation of the schemes relating to development of residential, commercial, industrial or institutional areas usually take few years. Therefore, the private property cannot be acquired for such purpose by invoking the urgency provision contained in Section 17(1). In any case, exclusion of the rule of audi alteram partem embodied in Section 5-A (1) and (2) is not at all warranted in such matters.

(ix)	If land is acquired for the benefit of private persons, the Court should view the invoking of Sections 17(1) and/or 17(4) with suspicion and carefully scrutinize the relevant record before adjudicating upon the legality of such acquisition.   [Para 53]

heading: Acquisition of land for industrial development
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land for industrial development - Acquisition found to be primarily meant to cater private interest in the name of industrial development - Even if it is treated as public purpose there was no urgency to justify exercise of power under Ss.17(1) and (4).

The objective of industrial development of an area cannot be achieved by pressing some buttons on computer screen. It needs lot of deliberations and planning keeping in view various scientific and technical parameters and environmental concerns. The private entrepreneurs, who are desirous of making investment in the State, take their own time in setting up the industrial units. Usually, the State Government and its agencies/instrumentalities would give them two to three years' to put up their factories, establishments etc. Therefore, time required for ensuring compliance of the provisions contained in Section 5-A cannot, by any stretch of imagination, be portrayed as delay which will frustrate the purpose of acquisition. In this context, it is apposite to note that the time limit for filing objection under Section 5-A(1) is only 30 days from the date of publication of the notification under Section 4(1). Of course, in terms of sub-section (2), the Collector is required to give opportunity of hearing to the objector and submit report to the Government after making such further inquiry, as he thinks necessary. This procedure is likely to consume some time, but as has been well said, "Principles of natural justice are to some minds burdensome but this price-a small price indeed-has to be paid if we desire a society governed by the rule of law."   [Para 55]

In this case, the Development Authority sent proposal some time in 2006. The authorities up to the level of the Commissioner completed the exercise of survey and preparation of documents by the end of December, 2006 but it took one year and almost three months to the State Government to issue notification under Section 4 read with Sections 17(1) and 17(4). If this much time was consumed between the receipt of proposal for the acquisition of land and issue of notification, it is not possible to accept the argument that four to five weeks within which the objections could be filed under sub-section (1) of Section 5-A and the time spent by the Collector in making inquiry under sub-section (2) of Section 5-A would have defeated the object of acquisition.   [Para 56]

heading: Time limit for issue of notifications under
HeadNote.description: Time limit for issue of notifications under - Time limit of one year specified in cl.(ii) of the proviso to S.6(1) is the outer limits for issue of declaration.	(Para 58)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Found to be unjustified and violative of Art.14 of the Constitution - Contention that Court may not annul impugned acquisition because villagers in other villages have not challenged acquisition of their land - Cannot be entertained because it is possible that they have not approached due to sheer poverty, ignorance and similar handicaps in availing legal remedies.	(Para 61)

heading: Taking possession of acquired land
HeadNote.description:
Taking possession of acquired land - Appellant in physical possession of land and cultivating the same - Entries in record of cultivation cited in support - He was not served with notice of taking possession - No independent witness to fact of taking possession of land on which crop was standing - Record by revenue authorities showing delivery of possession to HSIIDC is self serving record without any legal sanctity - Held High Court was not justified in summarily dismissing writ petition on the premise that possession of acquired land had been taken and same vested in Government.

(1976) 1SCC 700, 2011 ALL SCR 1357 Rel. on. (Paras 16, 19, 20)

heading: Acquisition of land
Opportunity of hearing
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Opportunity of hearing - Objective application of mind to objections raised against acquisition of land is necessary. 

The rules of natural justice have been ingrained in the scheme of Section 5A with a view to ensure that before any person is deprived of his land by way of compulsory acquisition, he must get an opportunity to oppose the decision of the State Government and/or its agencies/instrumentalities to acquire the particular parcel of land. At the hearing, the objector can make an effort to convince the Land Acquisition Collector to make recommendation against the acquisition of his land. He can also point out that land proposed to be acquired is not suitable for the purpose specified in the notification issued under Section 4(1). Not only this, he can produce evidence to show that another piece of land is available and the same can be utilized for execution of the particular project or scheme. Though, it is neither possible nor desirable to make a list of the grounds on which the landowner can persuade the Collector to make recommendations against the proposed acquisition of land, but what is important is that the Collector should give a fair opportunity of hearing to the objector and objectively consider his plea against the acquisition of land. Only thereafter, he should make recommendations supported by brief reasons as to why the particular piece of land should or should not be acquired and whether or not the plea put forward by the objector merits acceptance. In other words, the recommendations made by the Collector must reflect objective application of mind to the objections filed by the landowners and other interested persons.  [Para 25]

heading: Casual approach in massive acquisition of agricultural land in rural areas criticised
HeadNote.description: Casual approach in massive acquisition of agricultural land in rural areas criticised - Before acquiring private land State and/or its agencies/instrumentalities should, as far as possible, use land belonging to State for specified public purposes - If acquisition of private land becomes absolutely necessary, then too, concerned authorities must strictly comply with relevant statutory provisions and rules of natural justice. (Para 26)

heading: Land acquisition
Declaration as to
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Declaration as to - It is the issuance and not the publication that is material event - Issuance of declaration within prescribed one year is valid.(Para 16)

heading: Acquisition of land
Personal hearing
Plea of breach
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Personal hearing - Plea of breach - Maintainability - Petitioners constituting themselves into an association and represented by one person - Notice therefore sent to said representative who remained present on site but failed to ask for personal hearing - Spl. Land Acquisition Officer not obliged to grant personal hearing - Considerations of objections raised was sufficient compliance.	(Para 17)

heading: Acquisition of land
Declaration as to
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Declaration as to - Petitioners representing against same but failing to question same - Cannot raise said issue after passing of award.	(Para 17)

heading: Acquisition of land
Awards
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Awards - Correction of by Spl. Land Acquisition Officer - Is within his powers - Such correction carried out twice would not vitiate the award.	(Para 18)

heading: Award u/S.11
HeadNote.description: Award u/S.11 - It must be made by Collector within period of 2 years from date of publication of declaration - If award is not made within such period, entire proceedings shall lapse - This explanation is not applicable here as there was no order of stay by Court to pass Award. 	(Para 13)

heading: Award u/S.11
HeadNote.description:
Award u/S.11 - Period of 2 years for completing Award cannot be extended merely because corrigendum to Notification u/S.6 was published during said period - It cannot be construed to be publication of notification u/S.6.
2007(3) ALL MR 326 (S.C.) Ref. to. (Paras 14, 15, 16)

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Section is a beneficient provision intended to remove inequality and give advantage to inarticulate and poor landowners who have not applied for reference under S.18.

S.28-A represents the Legislature's determination to ensure that the goal of equality enshrined in the Preamble of the Constitution and Articles 38, 39 and 46 thereof is translated into reality, at least in the matter of payment of compensation to those who are deprived of their land for the benefit of the State, its instrumentalities/agencies and even private persons. Section 28-A also represents statutory embodiment of the doctrine of equality in matters relating to the acquisition of land. The Act which was enacted in 1894 and was amended after 90 years has the potential of depriving a large segment of the society i.e. the 'agriculturist' of their only source of livelihood. The scheme of Section 28-A provide some solace to this segment of the society by ensuring that such of the land owners whose land was acquired under the same notification but who could not, on account of poverty, ignorance and other disabilities join others in seeking reference under Section 18 get an opportunity to claim compensation at par with others. This section is aimed at removing inequality in the payment of compensation in lieu of acquisition of land under the same notification. To put it differently, this section gives a chance to the land owner, who may not have applied under Section 18 for determination of market value by the Court to seek re-determination of the amount of compensation, if any other similarly situated land owner succeeds in persuading the Reference Court to fix higher market value of the acquired land.  This opportunity can be availed by filing application in prescribed time.  (1995)2 SCC 736 - Rel. on.  [Para 9]

heading: Award under S.28-A(2)
HeadNote.description:
Award under S.28-A(2) - Land owner who is not satisfied with award can make application to Collector under S.28-A(3) for making reference to Court.

If sub-section (3) of Section 28-A is interpreted keeping in view the object sought to be achieved by enacting the provision for removing inequality in the matter of payment of compensation, it must be held that a person who is not satisfied with an award made under Section 28-A(2) can make an application to the Collector under Section 28-A(3) for making a reference to the Court as defined in Section 3(d) of the Act and this right cannot be frustrated merely because as a result of re-determination made under Section 28-A(2) read with Section 28-A(1) the applicant becomes entitled to receive compensation at par with other land owners. There is nothing in the plain language of Section 28-A(3) from which it can be inferred that a person who has not accepted the award made under Section 28-A(2) is precluded from making an application to the Collector with the request to refer the matter to the Court. Of course, the Court to which reference is made under Section 28-A(3) will have to bear in mind that a person who has not sought reference under Section 18 cannot get compensation higher than the one payable to those who had sought reference under that section.  [Para 11]

heading: Urgency provisions under S.5A invoked without paying compensation stipulated under S.17(3A)
HeadNote.description:
Urgency provisions under S.5A invoked without paying compensation stipulated under S.17(3A) - Expropriatory legislation is required to be construed strictly. 

Even though the holding of property is no longer a fundamental right guaranteed under Part III of the Constitution of India, it has been given constitutional protection under Article 300A which came to be inserted into the Constitution by the Constitution (Forty-fourth Amendment) Act, 1978 which omitted Article 19(1)(f), viz., "to acquire, hold and dispose of property". The Constitution now guarantees that no person shall be deprived of his property save by authority of law. If the Union or the State Government is desirous of depriving any person of his property it can only do so by authority of law. That authority, as is facially evident, inter alia, is the necessity to tender the payment of 80 per cent of the compensation estimated by the Collector in the event that Section 17 is to be pressed into service, with the objective of denying the landowners remonstration rights by filing Objections in consonance with Section 5A of the L.A. Act. Expropriatory legislation, such as the L.A. Act, must compulsorily be construed strictly. The Appellant State cannot be permitted to invoke one part of Section 17 while discarding another. Sections 17(3A) and 17(3B), which were inserted by the Act 68 of 1964 with effect from 24.9.1994, cannot be rendered nugatory. 		      [Para 6]

heading: Acquisition proceedings
Quashing of
HeadNote.description: Acquisition proceedings - Quashing of - Quashing of entire proceeding has to be explicitly expressed - Quashing at the instance of one or two landowners does not have effect of nullifying the entire acquisition.	(Para 9)

heading: Apportionment of compensation
Proof of title
HeadNote.description: Code of Communidade, Arts.549, 551, 208 - Apportionment of compensation - Proof of title - Appellant produced no document except Matriz Certificate - Pleaded that relevant record at the office of Administrator of Comunidade is not legible being very old and wet due to rains - No such plea raised in pleadings which appears to be afterthought - Appellant did not even produce copies of such old and illegible record - Adverse inference is to be drawn that appellant has no title document hence could not produce them - Matriz record also does not confer any title on appellant as the same does not tally with boundaries of disputed land. (Paras 15 to 17)

heading: Acquisition proceedings
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition proceedings - Sub-section (2) envisages rule of audi alteram partem - Opportunity of hearing is mandatory.

The sub-section (2) of Section 5-A envisages the rule of audi alteram partem and makes it sine qua non to the acquisition proceedings under the Act. It mandates the LAO to first provide an opportunity of hearing to the objector(s) in respect of their objections to the acquisition of lands notified under Section 4(1) of the Act. The LAO or the Collector may also conduct a further enquiry in this regard, if he deems it necessary, and thereafter decide upon the objections raised by such objector(s) and submit his recommendations to the State Government in the form of a report, on the basis of which the State Government is to formulate its opinion in respect of acquisition of lands notified under Section 4(1) of the Act and issue appropriate notification under Section 6 of the Act. The purpose is to afford an opportunity of making representation to the aggrieved person before any order, which may adversely affect his interest in any immovable property, may be passed by the LAO and subsequent notification be issued by the State Government. non-adherence to the principles envisaged under the Act at the stage of making recommendations, not only defeats the purpose and object of the provisions of Section 5-A(2) but also introduces illegality into the opinion formulated by the State Government after considering the report so submitted by the LAO and therefore, by necessary implication, permeates the notification issued under Section 6 of the Act with such illegality.	 [Para 23,28]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Base price of lands acquired arrived at following quantification of compensation of adjacent lands - Deduction towards development cost was improper.

In the instant case the single judge of High Court while enhancing the compensation has followed the quantification of compensation of the adjacent lands at the rate of Rs.22/- per sq. yard previously determined by the High Court for lands acquired by the State in the year 1973 and 1977. The said rate pertains to the lands later named as Sectors 13 and 14, which are situated across the lands in lis herein. The Single Judge, after keeping the base price at Rs.22/- per sq. yard has enhanced the compensation at the rate of 15% per annum for the lands acquired vide notifications dated 04.06.1980, 13.03.1981, 22.06.1982 and 05.07.1982 later named as Sectors 6, 3, 9 and 7, respectively. However while doing so, he has deducted 1/3rd of the said price towards costs borne by the State in development of such lands as commercial and residential areas. Held that, the High Court ought not to have made any deduction towards development cost.

2004(5) ALL MR 213 (S.C.) Foll.         [Para 16,17]

heading: Scope and extent of solatium
HeadNote.description:
Scope and extent of solatium - Interest on solatium amount should be granted - Interest rate on solatium amount would be escalated from expiry of one year as mentioned in S.34 - As well as interest should also be paid on solatium during preceding period.

2001(4) ALL MR 550 (S.C.) Rel. on. 	 (Para 20)

heading: Market Value
HeadNote.description: Market Value - Determination , with reference to potential of land - Notification u/s.4 issued on 1.2.1990 - Land use Act restricting the use of land for agriculture only, came into force on 2.11.1990 - Relevant date for compensation is date of notification - Since on that date Land use Act was not in force, restriction imposed thereby will not be taken into account - Land in question can be valued as having potential for non-agricultural use.  (Para 7)

heading: Market Value
Determination
HeadNote.description: Market Value - Determination - Fact that land could not be sold by tenant without sanction of Malmatdar, would not depress its value nor affect its potential for development. (Para 8)

heading: Compensation
Enhancement
Legality
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Enhancement - Appellant granted compensation of Rs.17/- per sq. m. as against adjoining landholder to whom compensation of Rs.78/- per sq. m. was granted - Ground that land which is subject to tenancy, fetches lesser price - Legality - Held, said principle applies only when land is acquired subject to tenancy - In instant case rights of landlord as well as rights of tenant have been acquired - Compensation rate will be no lesser than what was awarded to neighbour - Total amount  will be apportioned 50-50 between landlord and tenant. 

(1996) 3 SCC 594 Disting.  (Paras 10, 11)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Provisions of Act have become outdated and need to be replaced as early as possible by a rational enactment in tune with Art.300A of the constitution. 			(Para 12)

heading: Suitability of alternative land suggested
HeadNote.description: Suitability of alternative land suggested - Government not finding it suitable - It's decision not vitiated by any error of law, nor it was irrational or founded on extraneous reasons - Court in judicial review will not substitute it's opinion. 			(Para 23, 24)

heading: Definition of "company"
HeadNote.description: Definition of "company" - Has undergone complete change and Government company stands expressly excluded from expression "company". 	(Para 29)

heading: Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description: Determination of compensation - To be fixed by referring to evidence regarding fair and just compensation near about the proximate date or on the date itself of the publication of S.4 notification - Post notification transaction may not be a sound criterion to determine and assess value of acquired land.		(Paras 12, 14)

heading: Compensation
Determination
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination - Cited sale deed was in respect of small plot of land located out side municipal limits - Land acquired a large tract of land falling within municipal limits and having excellent prospects of being used as residential site - High Court taking into consideration that acquired land was a large tract of land reduced compensation of Rs.17/- per sq. ft. granted by Reference Court to Rs.9/- per sq. ft. - Held, Rs.11/- per sq.ft. which was the value fetched by small plot would be reasonable price and High Court was not justified in scaling down rate of compensation to Rs.9/- per sq. ft..			(Paras 23, 24, 25)

heading: Acquisition of land
LAO inspected site
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Land purchased by petitioners was acquired for purpose of playground - All objections raised by petitioner were dealt with by Land Acquisition Officer - LAO came to conclusion that objections are devoid of merit - No material unknown to petitioners was considered by LAO - Petitioners were given personal hearing - Statement of petitioners is recorded by LAO - Checklist and survey report was sent - LAO inspected site - There is compliance of S.5A and no violation of principles of natural justice.

2009(5) ALL MR 287, 2005 (7) SCC 627 Ref. to. (Para 19)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Land purchased by petitioners for house construction - Land acquired for purpose of playground for village student community - Public purpose is involved in acquisition - There is no colourable exercise of powers done with malafide purpose.  (Para 20)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Land purchased by petitioners for house construction - Land acquired for purpose of playground for village student community - Petitioners purchased land for Rs. 25,00,000/- - Petitioners spent further some amount on conversion of sanad - Director of Sports and Youth Affairs in checklist valued land at Rs.3,25,000/- - Petitioners have right to ask for reference and claim appropriate compensation.

2010 ALL MR (Supp) 693, 2009 (4) ALL MR 194 Ref. to. (Para 21)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Land purchased by petitioners acquired for purpose of playground - Public notice regarding this land was issued by advocate in news paper - Though petitioners stated that notice was not issued by them it is not said that they were not aware of notice - Petitioners at time of purchasing said property knew that it is proposed to be acquired - Despite that petitioners obtained conversion sanad - Petitioners purchased property and further issued legal notice to respondent in name of vendor - Contention that petitioners purchased property even when they knew that it is being used as football ground - It seems that petitioners did not approach court with clean hands - Petition liable to be dismissed. (Para 22)

heading: Consequence of breach
HeadNote.description: Period for making award - Period prescribed is mandatory - Consequence of breach - Entire proceedings get lapsed. (Para 12)

heading: Computation of period of two years
HeadNote.description: Computation of period of two years - Commences from date of publication of declaration - Declaration if published before commencement of Amendment Act, period commences from commencement of Amendment Act - Only period excludible is period during which proceedings remain stayed under order of Court and no other - Provisions of Limitation Act, 1963 and particularly S.12 cannot be read into it. (Para 12)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Land abutting National Highway - About 15 k.m. from Bangalore City Corporation - Held High Court was right in awarding Rs.75/- per sq. feet for concerned land.	(Para 6)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Deduction for development charges - Land abutting national highway acquired for widening the highway - No further question of any development - No evidence was led supporting proposed development - Held High Court was not justified in reducing Rs.25/- per sq. ft. from Rs.75/- per feet - Claimant, hence, would be entitled to the rate of Rs.75/- plus all statutory benefits like solatium, interest, under S.23(1-A) and under S.34.	(Para 8)

heading: Land acquisition
Payment of compensation
Cannot be appreciated
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Payment of compensation - Stand of the Authority that it had deposited compensation with Land Acquisition Officers and it was for the owner to collect money - Cannot be appreciated - No question of 'come and get' the compensation while compulsorily acquiring land - Approach required under law is "go and give".	(Para 8)

heading: Acquisition proceeding therefor
HeadNote.description:
Establishment of "Forest Garden" - Acquisition proceeding therefor - Held, before starting any acquisition proceeding for acquiring land for the establishment of a "Forest Garden" the Corporation was required to decide certain aspects - Aspects to be decided, indicated.

Before starting any acquisition proceeding for acquiring land for the establishment of a 'Forest Garden' the Corporation was required to decide as to : -

(a)	Whether there was any need at all to establish a 'Forest Garden' ? AND if such need at all was there, Whether one or more than one such gardens were needed?

(b)	Where should such Forest Garden(s) be located ?

(c)	What should be the total area of such a Forest Garden(s) ?

(d)	Whether is it possible to establish such 'Forest Garden' at a place/land which is already available with Corporation ?

(e)	If no such place/lands are available, as aforesaid, what are the ways and means of getting such place/land i. e. can the Corporation get it from State Government or Central Government as 'Forest Department' ?

(f)	Is it necessary for this purpose to acquire land ?

(g)	Whether the financial condition of the Corporation permits incurring of such an expenditure, firstly for acquisition of the land to establish such a 'Forest Garden(s)', and secondly the total expenditure that would go in for actual establishment of the 'Forest Garden(s)' at the acquired site, including the recurring expenditure for its maintenance etc.?

Court however hastened to add that these aspects are only illustrative and that this is not an exhaustive list of various aspects to be considered by the Corporation.  1997(5) SCC 421 & 1997(7) SCC 44 - Ref. to.  [Para 11]

heading: Compulsory acquisition
HeadNote.description: Compulsory acquisition - Issuance of Order as contemplated by S.7 - It is the source for the authority of collector to take steps for actual compulsory acquisition of lands under the Act - Requirement of 'taking an order for the acquisition of the land' as contemplated by S.7, held is a substantive requirement of the law and not a mere formal or procedural requirement of law.			(Para 47)

heading: Requirement of 'taking an order for the acquisition of the land' as contemplated by S.7 of the Act
HeadNote.description:
Requirement of 'taking an order for the acquisition of the land' as contemplated by S.7 of the Act - Requirement is a substantive and not just procedural requirement of law - Also, the requirement of law has to be treated as mandatory and not directory.

Land Acquisition Act does not provide for any consequences that should follow in case the Collector does not "take order for acquisition of the land", as contemplated by section 7 of the said Act. A close reading of section 7 of the said Act in fact contemplates only issuance of a direction to the Collector "to take order for acquisition of the land". Thus, it contemplated "only a direction" to take such an order. It does not even contemplate that the Collector has to take such an order and only thereupon the Collector can proceed further with the acquisition proceedings. It is also true that there is no specific and explicit provision in the said Act that requires, much less mandatorily the Collector 'to take an order' as contemplated by Section 7 of the said Act, before taking further steps towards the acquisition proceedings.  However, the object and purpose of section 7 is obviously that the Collector must be authorised and/or empowered to take further steps, contemplated by provisions of section 8 onwards, for the purpose of acquisition of the land that are declared to be needed for the public purpose under section 6 of the said Act. In the light of our aforesaid conclusion that requirement for the collector to take such an order is the substantive (and not just a procedural requirement) of the said Act, such a requirement for the collect to take order as contemplated by Section 7 of the said Act will have to be read into the Act to make the entire scheme of the said Act complete and meaningful. Absence of such an order as contemplated by the Section 7 of the said Act will amount to a missing link in the chain of requirements/steps that are to be taken for the compulsory acquisition of lands under the said Act. The true compliance with the letter and spirit of the provisions of Section 7 of the said Act is not in just directing the collector to take order for acquisition of land but in the collector factually and actually taking such an order, as issuance of such an order alone will clothe the collector with jurisdiction and/or authority and/or power to proceed further with the compulsory acquisition of the lands under the said Act.

The appropriate Govt. is possessed of powers to take decision to acquire land or not. The power in some cases is delegated to Commissioner. What is more important is that the power to decide whether particular land is to be acquired or not is not with the Collector. Therefore, section 7 directs to Collector to take order from the appropriate Govt. or Commissioner. Therefore, where Collector approaches the Govt. or Commissioner to take order for acquisition of land, the appropriate Govt. or Commissioner has to take decision as to whether land is to be acquired by compulsory acquisition. This decision is original decision in whole acquisition proceeding. On performance of this procedure, two effects follows- (1) that Government has decided to acquire land compulsorily thereby incurring liability to pay compensation at market rate; (2) the Collector is clothed with jurisdiction and power to acquire land, as provided by section 8 onwards. Therefore, such important provision cannot be said to procedural one or directory in nature, as contended by respondent. Therefore, post facto approval with retrospective effect will not protect the present acquisition proceedings.  AIR 2006 SC 289 and AIR 1957 SC 912 - Ref. to.  [Para 50,51,54]

heading: Compulsory acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Compulsory acquisition of land - Order contemplated under S.7 - Held, order for acquisition of land must be granted/issued with proper application of mind and by giving reasons in support thereof.

a)	The requirement of the Collector "to take order for acquisition of the land" as contemplated by the provisions of Section 7 of the said Act is a substantive requirement of the said Act and is not just a procedural requirement.

b)	The aforesaid requirement is mandatory in nature and is not just directory.

c)	It is not open to the Collector to comply with such a requirement by way of ratification i.e. by obtaining a post facto sanction with retrospective effect from the appropriate government or from the officer authorised by it in this behalf, or as the case may be, the Commissioner.

d)	Such order for acquisition of land must be granted/ issued with proper application of mind and by giving reasons in support thereof.

e)	The previous approval granted by the appropriate government or its authorized officer under the first proviso to Section 11(1) of the said Act does not amount to and cannot be considered as sufficient compliance with this requirement.				 [Para 65]

heading: Compliance with S.5-A
HeadNote.description: Compliance with S.5-A - It is mandatory to satisfy the principles of natural justice. (1995)3 SCC 752, (1976)3 SCC 719 and (1975)4 SCC 298 - Ref. on.	(Para 68)

heading: Land Acquisition proceedings
Writ Petition
Inordinate delay
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition proceedings - Writ Petition - Inordinate delay - Held, if writ petition is filed with gross and an inordinate delay, the same will be dismissed on that ground itself, whether it questions sustainability of the land acquisition proceedings or any other action under any other law. 2008(4) SCC 695 and 2000(2) BCR 678 - Ref. to.			(Paras 94, 95)

heading: Notification for
Acquisition of land
Public purpose
HeadNote.description:
Notification for - Acquisition of land - Public purpose - Land Acquisition Officer not expected to write a judgment like a Judicial Officer - It is not possible to take one or two lines from the notifications for coming to the conclusion that the purpose mentioned in the notifications did not existed and there is no public purpose involved - Simply because name of the scheme is not mentioned in the notification, cannot be treated as a ground that there is no public purpose involved.

Simply because in the notification under Sections 4 & 6 of the Act, there is a reference about the acquisition of the land for Government school playground and though the Government school is not functioning in the area, it cannot be said that there is no public purpose as no such public school is functioning in the village. It is required to be noted that on the basis of the recommendations of the Sports Authority of State of Goa, the Director of Sports and Youth Affairs, ultimately decided to acquire the land in question for the purpose of Government Village Playground. It cannot be said that there is no public purpose involved in such acquisition. Simply because some private club might have some playground, it would not mean that there is no public purpose involved in acquiring the land in question. It is for the State Government to consider whether any additional ground is required to be acquired so that all the village people can take benefit by using the said playground. In the present case, the Land Acquisition Officer has considered whatever objections raised before him and he is not expected to write a judgment like a Judicial Officer. It is not possible to take out one or two lines from the notifications for coming to the conclusion that the purpose mentioned in the notifications did not exist and there is no public purpose involved. Considering the affidavit-in-reply and the submissions of the Advocate General, held, that on the basis of the recommendations of the Director of Sports, ultimately it was decided to acquire the land for establishing football ground under the said Scheme. Simply because name of the scheme is not mentioned in the notification, cannot be treated as a ground that there is no public purpose involved.  [Para 17]

heading: Selection of land for public purpose
HeadNote.description: Selection of land for public purpose - Interference by writ court in selection process - Selection process within domain of Land Acquisition Officer - Court cannot interfere in selection process in a petition under Art.226 of the Constitution of India, especially when affidavit-in-reply clearly points out as to how the land in question is most suitable land as compared to other lands. (1996)11 SCC 501 and (1975)4 SCC 298 - Ref. to.			(Paras 19, 49)

heading: Land acquisition proceedings
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition proceedings - Allegations about mala fide - Allegation too vague to be given any weightage - Person against whom allegations made, not joined as a party in present writ petition - Held, if the villagers of people ultimately submitted any representation through their leader or M.L.A. or M.P. of their area, and on the basis of the said representation, if any recommendation is made by the said M.L.A. or M.P., it cannot be said that the said recommendation is made with any ulterior motive.	(Para 46)

heading: Compensation
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Market value of land - Determination - Acquisition of small and compact extent of land - Valuation at single uniform rate is proper.

The question whether the acquired lands have to be valued uniformly at the same rate, or whether different areas in the acquired lands have to be valued at different rates, depends upon the extent of the land acquired, the location, proximity to an access road/Main Road/Highway or to a City/Town/Village, and other relevant circumstances.

When a small and compact extent of land is acquired and the entire area is similarly situated, it will be appropriate to value the acquired land at a single uniform rate. [Para 6]

In the instant case the acquisition relates to a comparatively small extent of village land measuring about 38 bighas of compact contiguous land. The High Court was of the view that the size and situation did not warrant any belting and all lands deserved the same rate of compensation. The Authority has not placed any material to show that any area was less advantageously situated. Therefore the view of the High Court that compensation should be awarded at an uniform rate does not call for interference.   [Para 7]

However, where a very large tract of land on the outskirts of a town is acquired, one end of the acquired lands adjoining the town boundary, the other end being two to three kilometres away, obviously, the rate that is adopted for the land which is further away from the town. In such a situation, what is know as a belting method is adopted and the belt or strip adjacent to the town boundary will be given the highest price, the remotest belt will be awarded the lowest rate, the belts/strips of lands falling in between, will be awarded gradually reducing rates from the highest to the lowest.   [Para 6]

heading: Interest
Grant of
HeadNote.description:
Interest - Grant of - Ss.34 and 28 do not duplicate award of interest but together cover entire amount of compensation awarded.

In regard to the compensation that is offered by the Land Acquisition Collector, the interest is payable under section 34 of the Act. In regard to the increase in such compensation, which is awarded by the Reference Court or any appellate court, such interest is awarded under section 28 of the Act. Sections 34 and 28 of the Act do not duplicate the award of interest, but together cover the entire amount of compensation awarded. The award of interest on the enhances amount under section 28 of the Act is the normal rule. The refusal of interest should be by assigned special or specific reasons. The contention of the Authority that the High Court ought not to have awarded interest under section 28 is therefore untenable.   [Para 13]

heading: Land acquisition compensation
Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition compensation - Enhancement of - Acquisition of land in question was for non-agricultural purpose/Industrial/Commercial purpose - Absence of evidence on record to show specific appreciation or non-agricultural improvement in vicinity of acquired lands - Inflation at flat rate of 7.5% allowed - Rate of Rs.37,000 per hectare sanctioned by lower court increased to Rs.67,300/-.	(Para 15)

heading: Expression "land"
HeadNote.description: Expression "land" - Acquired structure consisting of ground floor and mezzanine floor - Structure of the mezzanine floor, held, could be considered as the acquired land. 	(Para 9)

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Fact that acquired property is situated in prime locality of metro city and it is easily accessible to the members of public - This fact was duly considered for enhancement of total compensation of Rs.76,05,898/- to Rs.1,99,56,182.48. 	(Paras 9, 10)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Application for
Calculation improper
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Application for - Appellant sought enhancement on basis that his land is abutting Ward No.6 where prevailing market rate is Rs.2000/- per sq.m. - However, he failed to bring any comparative material on record - Hence rate of Ward No.6 could not be directly applied to appellant - Sale instance of back years of nearby area showed market rate @ Rs.660/- per sq.m. - By allowing a flat 10% increase, Reference Court awarded compensation @ Rs.990/- per sq.m. - Calculation improper - To calculate increase in market value, appropriate method is to apply cumulative rate and not flat rate - So applying, appellant entitled to compensation @ Rs.1064/- per sq.m. 2008(6) ALL MR 491 (S.C.) Rel. on.  (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Compensation - Calculation of increase in market value - On basis of sale instances of back years - Appropriate method is to apply cumulative rate and not flat rate. 2008(6) ALL MR 491 (S.C.) Rel.on.  (Paras 6, 8)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Claimant can amend his claim application so as to enhance compensation claimed in an application for reference under S.18.

The claimant whose land is acquired can be allowed to amend his claim application so as to enhance the compensation claimed in an application for reference under section 18 of the Act. It is for the Court to determine the market value of the land once a reference has been made to it. The determination of the market value of the land is adjudicative process which the Court must complete irrespective of participation by the claimant in the enquiry. If that is the mandate of law and this is the obligation on the Court, then, all such materials as are placed before the Court to enable it to determine the market value, must be permitted to be produced. Production of materials and additional facts/figures, data is something which is part of a procedure evolved by the Court. There are procedural provisions by which the proceedings are governed. Ultimately, the procedural provisions are hand-maids of Justice. They can never be held to be mandatory. Therefore, it will have to be held that the provisions, namely, sections 18, 19 to 21 read with section 53 of the Act enable the claimant to apply for amendment to the reference. Merely because an application for amendment is made does not necessarily mean that it has to be granted. Ultimately, whether application will be allowed or not depends on facts and circumstances in each case and no general rule can be laid down.  It would not be just and proper to hold that the reference before the Civil Court cannot be amended.  The proceedings before the Reference Court are "civil proceedings". There is no reason for restricting expression "Civil proceedings" only to those proceedings which arise out of civil suit or proceedings which are tried as civil suits.  [Para 32,18,20]

The power to allow amendments of pleadings is also conferred so as to enable the Court to determine the real question in controversy between the parties. All amendments shall be made as may be necessary for the purpose of determining the real question and controversy between the parties. If such is the power, then, to hold that it is unavailable while deciding a reference under section 18 would be contrary to the object of determining the compensation to be awarded for compulsory acquisition of the land for public purpose. Justice and fair play demands that this procedural provision which assists the Court in determining the matter must be held to be a necessary aid or else the determination may not be fair.  [Para 21]

The word "pleadings" is defined to mean plaint or written statement. Thus, when the nature of the proceedings before the Reference Court are such as placing the applicant in the position of plaintiff and his application a plaint so also the burden cast upon him in law, then, one can safely hold that what are filed before the Reference Court are pleadings. Once the object and purpose is to award compensation at the market value for a land acquired for public purpose, then, it would not be proper to hold that the Court while determining the matter referred under section 18 of the Act does not have any power to allow the amendment of the pleadings. Of course, the ambit and scope of this discretionary power does not mean all amendments prayed for should be granted straightaway. The discretion must be exercised judiciously. 2008(6) ALL MR 65, Decision in F.A. No.226/1994, Dt.:-11-11-2008 - Overruled.  [Para 29]

heading: Application for reference
HeadNote.description:
Application for reference - Amendment to claim enhanced compensation - Can be allowed before Reference Court as well as in appeal before High Court against decision of Reference Court - Amendment to be granted keeping in mind general principles laid down under O.6, R.17, CPC.

There is no inconsistency in the provisions of Order 6, Rule 17 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 and section 18 of the Act. It is now a fairly settled principle that Appeal is in continuation of the suit. In these circumstances, there is no reason why the amendment should not be allowed so as to enhance the claim made under reference application at appellate stage. Thus, amendment can also be granted at the appellate stage, however subject to the restraint prescribed under Order 6, Rule 17 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908. Whether amendment in particular case can be granted or not depends on facts and circumstances of each individual case. For example, the amendment so as to enhance the claim under reference application if rejected by Reference Court and the said order if allowed to become final, then similar amendment may not be allowed at appellate stage. Even the delay and latches on the part of applicant in applying for amendment can be considered in proper perspective.  [Para 22]

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Challenge - Compensation was enhanced by relying on judgment wherein land adjacent to acquired land was awarded compensation at rate of Rs.10/- per sq. ft. - Said judgment was passed five years ago of proceeding of acquired land - Hence, it cannot be said that compensation awarded was on higher side. 	(Para 11)

heading: Reference
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Reference - Limitation - Respondent was not present when award was made on 30.03.1989 nor he was aware about contents of award - Notices u/S.12(2) were issued upon respondent on 28.07.1989 and 25.10.1989, but no copy of award was supplied - Respondent therefore applied for certified copy of award after period of six month from award and received same on 26.06.1992 and immediately thereafter, filed reference on 29.06.1992 - Held, limitation would actually commence from knowledge of actual contents of award - Reference proceedings not barred by limitation. 2010 ALL SCR 778, 2012(3) ALL MR 434 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 7, 8, 9, 10)

Award of
Power regarding
HeadNote.description: Interest - Award of - Power regarding - Provisions u/s.34 and u/s.28 - Object of both Sections is to compensate claimant who does not receive compensation before dispossession besides being eligible therefor - Difference is that power to grant interest u/s.28 vests in Court whereas that u/s.34 vests in Collector. 	(Para 17)

HeadNote.description: Relevancy - Once award passed under sub-section (2) of S.28A is made, it replaces award u/s.11 for all purposes.	(Para 14)

heading: Compensation
Payment of
Norms regarding
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Payment of - Norms regarding - Scheme of the Act contemplates that compensation must be offered to persons interested, before taking over possession.	(Para 15)

heading: Interest
Award of
Not illegal
HeadNote.description: Interest - Award of - Compensation awarded under sub-section (2) of S.28A by Collector - Collector invoking provision of S.34 granted interest at rates of 9% p.a. and 15% p.a. for subsequent years - Not illegal - Collector can always invoke S.34 while making award under sub sec.(2) of S.28A - Merely because reference was made by Collector to wrong section namely 28, exercise of power does not become bad.		(Paras 18, 20)

heading: Interest
Grant of
Relevant date
HeadNote.description: Interest - Grant of - Relevant date - Delay of two years and nine months in payment of compensation - No reason given by respondent authorities for such delay - S.34 will be applicable - Interest has to be paid by respondent till date of deposit of compensation.	(Para 22)

heading: Tenability
HeadNote.description: Award of compensation under sub-section (2) of S.28A - Plea by respondent/Acquiring Authority that it was not made party to reference u/s.18 which was subject matter of petition under sub-section (2) of S.28A - Tenability - Before making award under sub-section (2) of S.28A respondent was given hearing - It's not case that respondent was not aware of award - Further, appeal by State against award passed u/s.18 still pending - Moreover, petitioner had also offered to submit bank guarantee for amount withdrawn by him - Plea raised by respondent Acquiring Authority - Is not tenable.	(Para 22)

heading: Land acquisition
Publication of declaration
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Publication of declaration - After issuance of notice u/S.9(1) - Such Publication is not valid.

	All the steps contemplated by section 6 are required to be taken in accordance with the scheme of the said Act. Every action taken under the said Act has to be in accordance with the provisions of the said Act and not otherwise. In the present case, as stated earlier, after the notice under sub-section (1) of section 9 was issued on 12th January 2006, the publication at Tahsildar's Office and at the village chavdi is allegedly shown to have been made on 15th January 2006 and 24th January 2006 respectively. The Award is made on 24th January 2008 and that is how significantly,the date of the last publication appears to have been shown as 24th January 2006. Such publication is not at all valid. 	 [Para 11]

heading: Lapse of acquisition
Award not valid
HeadNote.description: Lapse of acquisition - For failure to pass award within stipulated time - Successive publication of declaration for bringing award within limitation - Such publication needs to be ignored - Award passed after stipulated period of two years from date of first declaration - Award not valid - Acquisition liable to be lapsed. 			(Para 12)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Appeal filed after inordinate delay of 10 years 2 months and 29 days - Sufficient grounds to condone delay not cited - Held, High Court was justified in not condoning delay. (Paras 16, 17)

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - No rule of law that in every case escalation should be at rate of 10% in market price - But, rule is that higher the gap between two notifications, higher the escalation.	(Para 14)

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - Challenge - On ground that only 5% increase granted in reference on purchase price awarded to other land acquired under same project - Considering gap between two notifications which is hardly of one year, escalation at rate of 5% is adequate - As regards compensation for various trees which were being newly planted and thus, were not fruit bearing trees, amount of Rs.1,72,700/- was validly awarded - Rs.51,900/- also awarded towards well - No interference warranted especially when enhancement granted more than four times of amount awarded by SLAO. 2004(5) ALL MR 1028 (S.C.), 2009(2) ALL MR 972 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			(Paras 14, 16, 17)

heading: Land acquisition
Additional compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Additional compensation - Award not made on or before 30-4-1982 - Claimant would be entitled to additional compensation under S.23(1-A).	(Para 5)

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
Question of parity
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Compensation - Question of parity - Lands identically circumstanced in same village - Supreme Court in 2004(5) ALL MR 1028 (S.C.) granting compensation at Rs.76,550/- per bigha - This rate was in respect of Notification dt.:-17-11-1980 and notification in present case was published on 22-3-1978 - Apex Court scaling down compensation by 10% and not by 20% in view of fact that lands were found to be already developed into plots - Hence, compensation at Rs.69,550/- plus benefit under S.23(1-A) r.w. S.30(1)(b) allowed.(Para 9)

HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land for construction of missing link in proposed road - Authorities, however, intending to acquire excess land for commercial purpose - Drawing kept for inspection showing that part of land was meant for commercial purpose but there was no indication at all in S.4 or S.6 notification - Held, when purpose mentioned in notifications was construction of road, authorities cannot acquire more land than what was required for road construction - Such acquisition for hidden purpose of commercial exploitation was bad in law and needed to be set aside.
2013 ALL SCR 1689 Rel. on. (Paras 25, 26, 27)

HeadNote.description: Public purpose - Acquisition for residential purpose - Land was intended to be acquired for adjusting oustees whose land was acquired for construction of road - 55 acres of land was sought to be given to those from whom 74 acres of land was taken i.e. for far greater area than what was required even as per stated public purpose - Further there was nearly vacant barren agricultural land which could have been acquired - Held, it is not for the court to decide how much land and which land should be acquired and as such appellants were allowed to make representation to authorities which shall be pragmatically considered by authorities. Filing of
Limitation
HeadNote.description: Reference - Filing of - Limitation - Respondents were not present when award was passed - Notice under S.12(2) was not served on them - Reference filed within 6 months from date of knowledge of award - Reference filed is well within limitation. AIR 2010 SC 1532, 2005(4) Mh.L.J. 1171 - Rel. on. 	(Paras 20 to 23)

Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Enhancement of - Claimant failed to produce cogent evidence for enhancement - Also failed to justify enhancement in deposition - Evidence of valuer and valuation report based on previous judgments considered - Claimant not liable to enhancement of compensation. heading: Market value
Determination of
Comparative sale instance
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination of - Comparative sale instance - Cannot be discarded merely on account of smallness of area of plot. (Para 14)

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
Determination of
Comparative sale instances
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Compensation - Determination of - Comparative sale instances - Land of sale deed was similar in nature and very close to acquired land - By considering that sale deed plot was developed, 30% deduction towards development charges proper, which brought down market value to Rs.112/- per sq.mtr. - Since there was gap of about 7 months between sale deed and date of publication of S.4 notification, increase of 5% due to annual escalation of land rate, proper - That brought market value at Rs.117.60/- per Sq. mtr. - By rounding this, claimant entitle to compensation of Rs.120/- per sq. mtr. (Para 14)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Plaintiff inherited business after death of his father - Premises of business belonging to defendant no. 5 - Plaintiff's father was aware of acquisition is clear from letter sent to Collector - Plaintiff's father in said letter has claimed relief against defendant no. 5 - Letter was sent by Acquisition officer to inform that compensation is paid to defendant no. 5 - Award was not challenged despite many available opportunities - All procedural steps were duly taken regarding acquisition - Personal notice was not issued as interest of plaintiff was not known - Relief of injunction from evicting him claimed by plaintiff till compensation is paid - Civil Court has no jurisdiction to grant said relief - Order of Trial Court liable to be upheld.

1997 (4) SC 5, AIR 1995 SC 1955 - Rel. on.  (Paras 15 to 18)

heading: Personal notice
HeadNote.description: Personal notice - Collector to issue notice to all interested persons regarding filing of claim and quantum of compensation - Plaintiff running grocery shop in premises owned by defendant no. 5 - Plaintiff despite having knowledge of acquisition did not file any objection - Interest of plaintiff was not known - Omission to issue notice was not wilful and fraudulent - Further failure to issue notice gives raise to cause of action to challenge award - Here award was not challenged by plaintiff - Contention that personal notice not issued is liable to be rejected. (Para 16)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Plaintiff inherited business after death of his father - Premises of business belonging to defendant no. 5 - Plaintiff has not averred that his late father was tenant in shop - Plaintiff, after his father, is mere occupier in premises - Licensee does not have judicial possession and interest in land or building standing thereon - Plaintiff not entitled to share in compensation awarded for value of land or to relocation at other place - Plaintiff reveals that his business in suit premises continues even after acquisition - Plaintiff not entitled for compensation for loss of business also.

AIR 1976 HP 16 - Ref. to.  (Paras 21, 22)

heading: Market value
Determination of
Not satisfactory
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Determination of - Reliance on auction sale transactions - Not satisfactory - May be relied on where open auction sale is the only comparable transaction available - Court may exercise caution and rely upon such auction sale by providing appropriate deduction or cut to off-set competitive hike in value.

The market value is determined with reference to the open market sale of comparable land in the neighbourhood, by a willing seller to a willing buyer, on or before the date of preliminary notification, as that would give a fair indication of the market value. A 'willing seller' refers to a person who is not acting under any pressure to sell the property, that is, where the sale is not a distress sale. A willing seller is a person who knowing the advantages and disadvantages of his property, sells the property after ascertaining the prevailing market prices at the fair and reasonable value. Similarly, a willing purchaser refers to a person who is not under any pressure or compulsion to purchase the property, and who, having the choice of different properties, voluntarily decides to buy a particular property by assessing its advantages and disadvantages and the prevailing market value thereof. Of course, unless there are indications to hold otherwise, all sale transactions under registered sale deeds will be assumed to be normal sales by willing sellers to willing purchasers. Where however there is evidence or indications that the sale was not at prevailing fair market value, it has to be ignored. But auction sales stand on a different footing. When purchasers start bidding for a property in an auction, an element of competition enters into the auction. Human ego, and desire to do better and excel other competitors, leads to competitive bidding, each trying to outbid the others. Thus in a well advertised open auction sale, where a large number of bidders participate, there is always a tendency for the price of the auctioned property to go up considerably. On the other hand, where the auction sale is by banks or financial institutions, courts, etc. to recover dues, there is an element of distress, a cloud regarding title, and a chance of litigation, which have the effect of dampening the enthusiasm of bidders and making them cautious, thereby depressing the price. There is therefore every likelihood of auction price being either higher or lower than the real market price, depending upon the nature of sale. As a result, courts are wary of relying upon auction sale transactions when other regular traditional sale transactions are available while determining the market value of the acquired land.  2007(7) SCC 609 - Ref.   [Para 6]

But where an open auction sale is the only comparable sale transaction available (on account of proximity in situation and proximity in time to the acquired land), the court may have to, with caution, rely upon the price disclosed by such auction sales, by providing an appropriate deduction or cut to off-set the competitive-hike in value.   [Para 7]

Determination of

Determination of

Entitlement to interest

Not acceptable
