heading: Vesting of land in Government
HeadNote.description:
Vesting of land in Government - Occurs only after taking possession in the manner provided by Act - Concept of deemed vesting, from date of notification u/S.4(1) in cases where possession continues with original land owner or where possession not taken in the manner provided - Not acceptable.

Taking over the possession of the land by the Collector, is the necessary ingredient or an instance of vesting of title in the Government under the provisions of the said Act and it is, therefore, of a great significance. The proceedings commenced for acquisition of land upon issuing notification under Section 4(1) of the said Act can be dropped in terms of Section 48 therein, before the land vests in the Government. Once the land vests in the Government, it is not even possible to withdraw it from acquisition. For vesting of title, the manner of taking possession has to be strictly adhered to. The concept of deemed vesting of land in the Government, cannot be imported upon publication of notification under Section 4(1) of the said Act, if the possession of the land taken by the Collector dehors the provisions of the Act, continues with him upon issuance of such notification. The possession taken over in the acquisition proceedings dehors the provisions of the Act will not confer or vest the title over it in the Government merely because notification under Section 4(1) of the said Act is issued and the proceedings for acquisition of the land have commenced.  [Para 13]

heading: Interest u/S.34
HeadNote.description:
Interest u/S.34 - Not payable on enhanced amount covered by S.28.

The interest payable under Section 34 is not the compensation paid to the owner for depriving him of his right to possession of the land, but that is given to him for deprivation of the use of money representing the compensation of the land acquired. It is payable where possession is taken but the compensation determined under Section 11 or in terms of clause (a) of sub-section (3-A) of Section 17 of the said Act, has not been paid or deposited on the date when it became due and payable. It is not payable on account of enhancement of compensation which is covered by Section 28 of the said Act. AIR 1964 SC 1878 Rel. on. 	     [Para 27]

heading: Interest u/S.34
HeadNote.description:
Interest u/S.34 - No overlapping with beneficial provision u/S. 23(1-A).

Section 34 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, operates only from the date on which the compensation determined becomes due and payable. As against this, the additional component under Section 23(1-A) becomes payable on the date of publication of the notification under Section 4(1) of the said Act, or from the date of taking possession of the land, whichever event occurs earlier.

In view of above, there is no question of overlapping the benefits available to the claimants under Section 23(1-A) or Section 34 of the said Act. The terminal point under Section 23(1-A) is either the date of the award or taking of possession, whereas the starting point of interest under Section 34 of the said Act is the passing of the award or taking of possession; both terminating on the date of payment or deposit in Court pursuant to the award passed under Section 11 of the said Act. 

There is no overlapping of the benefits under Section- 23(1-A) and Section 34 of the said Act. The terminal points under Section 23(1-A) are the starting points under Section 34 of the said Act and both the provisions operate in different fields.

2002(1) ALL MR 262 (S.C.) Rel. on.  [Para 29,30,32]

heading: Possession of land
HeadNote.description: Possession of land - Prior to notification u/S.4(1) - Would be illegal, being de hors the provisions of Act u/Ss.16 and 17 - Claimant can seek recovery of possession with rent or damages for period of illegal possession. 2004(5) ALL MR 435 (S.C.) Rel. on. 			(Para 31)

heading: Interest u/S.34
HeadNote.description: Interest u/S.34 - Payable date, when possession taken over even prior to notification u/S.4(1) - Held, in such a case, interest will be payable from date of award u/S.11 - Only in a case where possession taken over under urgency clause of S.17, payable date would be date of possession - Neither R.L. Jain's Case 2004(5) ALL MR 435 (S.C), nor Bhaskar Wagh's Case 2008(6) ALL MR 555, nor Karigowda's Case 2010 ALL SCR 2152 lay down a law that in aforesaid situation interest would be payable from date of notification u/S.4(1). 2012(4) ALL MR 779 Approved. 2009(3) ALL MR 779 Held, Not Good Law. 2004(5) ALL MR 435 (S.C) Ref. to. (Paras 24, 25, 32, 33)

heading: Land acquisition
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Interest on award of compensation - Reference Court awarded interest from date possession of acquired land - Not proper - In view of judgment of Full Bench in 2016(4) ALL MR 513 (F.B.), interest would have to be granted from date of passing of award. 2016(4) ALL MR 513 (F.B.) Rel. on. (Para 9)

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - For trees standing on acquired land - Challenge, on ground that it is on higher side - Govt. approved Valuer made valuation of trees much more than amount determined by Reference Court - Enhancement was granted only 20% of compensation awarded by L.A. Officer which is very meagre - Challenge, not tenable.  (Para 8)

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
Legality
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - Legality - Amount enhanced on basis of sale deed executed 2 years before issuance of notification - As per sale deed, 2 acres land situated in same survey where acquired land was situated, was sold for sum of Rs.1,75,000/- - Acquired land was adjoining National Highway and situated within radius of 10 km from sugar factory and had great potential value - There was good transport facility from acquired land to market place and agricultural produce was easily carried by claimants from their respective lands to market area - Considering aforesaid facts, no error committed by Reference Court in granting compensation @ Rs.2,00,000/- per hectare to claimants. 	(Para 7)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Setting aside of award - On ground of same being passed beyond limitation - Claimant challenged validity of notification in first round of litigation and in second round of litigation he challenged rejection of representation - Award passed during pendency of first round of litigation and possession taken during pendency of second round of litigation - Claimant did not raise ground of limitation in first as well as second round of litigation - Challenge raised same after 8 years barred by O.2 R.2 of CPC as well as doctrine of delay and laches - Hence, award, cannot be set aside. (Paras 10, 11)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Delay in passing award, whether attracts S.11A - Land acquired by invoking urgency clause u/S.17, dispensing with requirement of filing objection u/S.5A - Action on the part of Govt. upheld by Supreme Court in first round of litigation - Held, once possession is taken u/S.17(1), S.11A is attracted - Therefore, acquisition proceedings would not lapse on failure to make award within period prescribed therein. (1993) 4 SCC 369, (1995) 6 SCC 31 Rel. on. (Para 12)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Claim for rental compensation - Jurisdiction of Civil Court, whether barred - Held, claim for rental compensation not relatable to LA Act - Claim made on basis of Govt. Resolutions dt.1.12.1972, 17.11.1973, 2.8.1997 and 3.10.2004 - Dispute in respect of payment of rental compensation pursuant to said GRs. does not arise under LA Act - Therefore, jurisdiction of Civil Court not barred to entertain the claim.	(Paras 7, 8, 12)

heading: Land acquisition
Reduction of compensation
Validity
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Reduction of compensation - Validity - Compensation reduced from Rs.2,500/- per cent to Rs.1,670/- per cent - Land acquired for providing house sites to people - Acquired land is having capacity for higher potential as it is in midst of railway track and national highway - Nearby land to extent of 8 cent was sold at rate of Rs.4,893/- per cent - Considering sale deed of nearby land compensation awarded by Reference Court at Rs.2,500/- per cent along with 30% solatium and 12% additional amount from date of notification, proper - Order reducing compensation to Rs.1,670/- per cent, liable to be set aside. 	(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Term 'public purpose'
HeadNote.description:
Term 'public purpose' - Includes purpose in which general interest of society as opposed to particular interest of individual, is directly and vitally concerned.

	Public purpose is not capable of precise definition. Each case has to be considered in the light of the purpose for which acquisition is sought for. It is to serve thegeneral interest of the community as opposed to the particular interest of the individual. Public purpose broadly speaking would include the purpose in which the general interest of the society as opposed to the particular interest of the individual is directly and vitally concerned. Generally the executive would be the best judge to determine whether or not the impugned purpose is a public purpose. Yet it is not beyond the purview of judicial scrutiny. The interest of a section of the society may be public purpose when it is benefited by the acquisition. The acquisition must indicate that it was towards thewelfare of people and not to benefit a private individual orgroup of individuals joined collectively. Therefore, acquisition for anything which is not for a public purpose cannot be done compulsorily. 	 [Para 11]

heading: Public purpose
Existence of
Proof
HeadNote.description:
Public purpose - Existence of - Proof - Held, it is not necessary to establish dire or desperate need.

While exercising the power under Sub-Section(1) of Section 48, the declaration under Section 6 of the Land Acquisition Act by the State Government binds the State. In view of Sub-Section(3) of Section 6, while exercising the power Sub-Section(1) of Section 48, the State Government cannot go into the issue whether public purpose was in existence on the day on which the declaration was issued under Section 6. However, the State Government can examine in a given case whether with the passage of time, the public purpose continues to exist. It is not the finding recorded that due to the events which have happened after the declaration under Section 6 of the Land Acquisition Act was made, the public purpose has ceased to exist. [Para 18]

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Order releasing land from acquisition - Is subject to judicial review - State Govt. is under obligation to record reasons - It is also necessary to give opportunity of being heard to beneficiaries of acquisition.			(Paras 22, 23)

heading: Reference
Legality
HeadNote.description: Reference - Rejection, on ground of bar of limitation - Legality - Reference application to be filed within 6 weeks of notice u/S.12(2) of LA Act - Said notice received by applicant on 4.2.1988 - Relying on entries of Roznama, Reference court concluded that application was filed on 19.8.1988 therefore barred by limitation - Communication sent to said court by SLAO not looked into which showed that application was filed on 11.3.1988 - Application not barred. (Para 7)

heading: Compensation
Enhancement
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Enhancement - Reliance placed on sale instance from same survey number - It showed sale of one hectare of land for Rs.82,500/- - Said sale was of April 1983 i.e. prior to notification u/S.4 which was issued in Dec.1983 - On this count, claimant entitled to compensation to the tune of Rs.90,000/- per hectare. 	(Paras 8, 9)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Challenge on strength of decree of Civil Court declaring that acquisition proceedings in respect of subject land is null and void due to oral partition between parties - Held, Civil Court has no jurisdiction to give a declaration that award passed by Land Acquisition Officer is null and void - For challenging award, writ petition u/Art.226 of Constitution has to be filed in High Court - Hence, decree of Civil Court is void. AIR 1985 SC 1403 Ref. to. 	(Para 5)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Maharashtra Resettlement of Project Displaced Persons Act (1976) - Acquisition of land - For rehabilitation of displaced person of Panshet Dam - Whether provision of Resettlement Act applicable - Held, land was acquired, notification u/S.4 issued, inquiry held u/S.5 of LA Act and after giving hearing to petitioner, award was passed - As all procedure prescribed under LA Act is followed, provisions of Resettlement Act not applicable. 1984 Mh.L.J. 752 Ref. to. 	(Para 4)

heading: Acquisition of land
Grant of compensation
Requirement
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Grant of compensation - Deduction for development charges - Requirement - Acquired land is to be used for raising a school building and to provide playgrounds therewith - In peculiar facts of the case, there would hardly be any requirement for development charges - Therefore, deduction of amount, not justified.	(Para 6)

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Seeking enhancement of market value - Exemplar land, on basis of which appellants desired determination of market price, was sold @ Rs.161/- per meter - Market price however sought to be determined @ 200/- per sq. meter - Area of exemplar land was rather small in comparison to acquired land - Giving land value more than exemplar land, held not justified.	(Para 7)

heading: Adverse possession
Claim of title
Maintainability
HeadNote.description:
Adverse possession - Claim of title - Maintainability - Suit land was acquired by notifications in 1984 and 1986 - However, actual possession remained with original owner who sold it to plaintiff in 1994 - Plaintiff filed suit for declaration of title in year 2001 on basis of her possession for 7 yrs. plus previous possession of original owner totaling more than 12 yrs. - Plaintiff's claim of title on basis of adverse possession, held, not maintainable - Firstly because, purchase of land by her after notification of acquisition, is void - Secondly, possession of original owner cannot be counted while computing 12 yrs. period of adverse possession - Thirdly, even if plaintiff claims actual possession, paper possession was already taken by Authorities by drawing panchanama which is a valid mode - Fourthly, plaintiff's possession cannot be said to be open and peaceful in view of her own assertion that defendants had come to suit property in 2001 and demolished the structure on suit land.

2016 ALL SCR 320 Foll.

2007 ALL SCR 1582, (2013) 6 ADJ 119 Ref. to. 	(Paras 18, 22)

heading: Notification of acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Notification of acquisition - Subsequent sale of land would be void and non est in the eyes of law.

(2015) 10 SCALE 27, (1996) 3 SCC 124, (1996) 10 SCC 721, (1995) 5 SCC 335, (1995) 5 SCC 528, (2008) 9 SCC 177, (2009) 10 SCC 689 Rel. on. 	(Para 18)

heading: Mode
HeadNote.description:
Possession of land by acquiring authority - Mode - Taking only paper possession of land by drawing Mahazar or Panchanama - Is a valid mode of taking possession.

(1996) 2 SCC 634, (1998) 4 SCC 387 Ref. to. 	(Para 18)

heading: Land acquisition
Re-determination of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Re-determination of compensation - Power of trial court - During pendency of reference u/S.18 before Trial Court, Act of 1894 was amended - Amending Act giving certain additional benefits to claimants which were extended to even those claimants to whom compensation was not paid before 30.04.1982 - Land acquisition Award was passed on 25.10.1982 and amount of compensation was also paid much after cut-off date of 30.04.1982 - Amended provisions were applicable to claimants - Trial Court can act suo moto to give benefits of this award to claimants - Order of trial Court reviewing its own order and granting additional benefits to claimants thereby enhancing amount of compensation, proper - Moreso because, by said order trial court has only corrected its own award. 2006(5) Bom.C.R. 739 Disting., (1991) 1 SCC 262 Rel. on.	(Paras 11, 13, 24)

heading: Land acquisition
Entitlement to
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Additional compensation provided by S.23(1-A) - Entitlement to - Cut-off date for entitlement to benefit of S.23(1-A) is 30.04.82 i.e. date when Bill was introduced in Parliament - Benefit of additional compensation u/S.23(1-A) is to be given if proceedings for acquisition were pending but no award was passed by Collector till 30.04.82 - But if award was passed by Collector before 30.04.82 benefit u/S.23(1-A) not available to claimants. 	(Para 19)

heading: Land acquisition
Interest on compensation
Entitlement to
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Interest on compensation - Entitlement to - If possession of land was taken prior to 30.04.1982 and compensation was not paid or deposited in Court till 30.04.1982 then only claimants would be entitled to enhanced rate of interest as provided by amended S.34 - If compensation is paid or deposited prior to 30.04.1982 claimant is not entitled to interest at increased rate. 	(Paras 21, 23)

heading: Quashing of acquisition
Prayer for
HeadNote.description: Quashing of acquisition - Prayer for - Suit land is part of larger area of land acquired falling in many adjoining villages - Compensation already disbursed to the extent of 76% and substantial part of land has also been developed - Therefore, relief of quashing of acquisition, cannot be granted - However, land owners held entitled to relief of payment of additional compensation and allotment of land. 2015 ALL SCR 2333 Foll. (2011) 11 ADJ (1) Ref. to.	(Paras 12, 15)

heading: Quashing of acquisition
Prayer for
Grant of
Considerations
HeadNote.description: Quashing of acquisition - Prayer for - Grant of - Considerations - Prompt petitions by an individual is not the only consideration for grant of said relief - When land is part of large area of acquired land, overall development on substantial part of land should be considered.	(Para 15)

heading: Lapse of acquisition
Declaration as to
HeadNote.description: Lapse of acquisition - Declaration as to - Sought on ground that award not made within 2 yrs. of declaration u/S.6 - Declaration u/S.6 made on 23/12/2012 - Draft award prepared on 12/6/2013 and sent to Govt. for approval - Approval granted on 31/7/2013 - Though after approval of Govt., the Authority not required to again sign the award, in instant case Authority also singed award - Yet same was within period of limitation i.e. on 12/10/2013 - Authority i.e. SLAO thereafter issued communication to petitioner on 20/6/2014 that award is passed on 12/6/2013, which was received by petitioner on 25/6/2014 - Even if contention of petitioner is accepted that knowledge of award being passed would be relevant date, petitioner had constructive knowledge of award on 20/6/2014 - Same being within period of limitation, acquisition proceedings cannot be lapsed. AIR 1961 SC 1500 (1) Ref. to.  (Paras 17, 18)

heading: Land acquisition
Award of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Award of compensation - Presence of parties interested, whether necessary - Held, Act nowhere contemplates that preparing and signing of award should be only in presence of parties interested - Nor any consequence is provided if notice of award not given to interested person - Rather, as per S.12(2) award shall be filed in Collector Office and same shall be final and conclusive evidence. (Para 12)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - Acquired land had all basic amenities like water, sewer, electricity and telephone lines - However, acquired land was not situated very near to urban area - Considering circumstance of case and sale deed of adjoining area which is proximate to date of notification - Compensation granted at Rs.72 lakhs per acre, proper. 	(Paras 14, 16)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Deduction towards development charges - Acquired land has all basic facilities such as water, electricity, sewer, telephone, etc. - However, as land is situated at some distance from town needs some further development to make it suitable for acquisition purpose - Deduction at rate of 10% towards development of acquired land, proper.

	In the present case, the acquired land has all basic facilities such as water, electricity,sewer, telephone etc.these are, however, not enough to meet the purpose of acquisition. To make such land suitable for the acquisition purpose i.e. for the construction of Mini Secretariat at Nuh, some further development is sine qua non. For calculating the percentage of development charges, various factors need to be taken into consideration such as location of land, facilities available in nearby area, size of the land, purpose of acquisition etc. The present acquired land of Firozpur Namak village which is located at some distance from the Nuh Town needs to be developed in proper manner like construction of better and wide roads etc., to make it suitable for the acquisition purposes. Therefore, deduction at rate of 10% towards development of acquired land, proper. 	 [Para 18,19]

heading: Land acquisition
Additional compensation
Provided by S.23(1-A)
Entitlement to benefit
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Additional compensation - Provided by S.23(1-A) - Entitlement to benefit - Cut-off date for entitlement to benefit of S.23(1-A) is 30.04.82 i.e. date when Bill was introduced in Parliament - Benefit of additional compensation u/S. 23(1-A) is to be given if proceedings for acquisition were pending but no award was passed by Collector till 30.04.82 - But if award was passed by Collector before 30.04.82 benefit u/S.23(1-A) not available to claimants. 	(Paras 16, 19)

heading: Interest on compensation
Entitlement to
HeadNote.description: Interest on compensation - As per amended S.34 - Entitlement to - If possession of land was taken prior to 30.04.1982 and compensation was not paid or deposited in Court till 30.04.1982 then only claimants would be entitled to enhanced rate of interest as provided by amended S.34 - If compensation is paid or deposited prior to 30.04.1982 claimant is not entitled to interest at increased rate. 	(Para 23)

heading: Legality
Release order quashed
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition for public purpose - Transfer of title of notified land in favour of a builder for purpose of colonization - Legality - Held, release of land under notification to such builder, tantamounts to acquisition for private purpose - Same amounts to transfer of resources of poor for benefit of rich and hence, violation of fundamental right of equality and right to property and life - Release order quashed - Builder held not entitled to recover consideration paid to the owners but will be entitled to reimbursement as prescribed.

There could be no objection to acquisition of land for a compelling public purpose nor to regulate development of colonies, but entertaining an application for releasing of land in favour of the builder who comes into picture after acquisition notification and release of land to such builder tantamounts to acquisition for a private purpose. It amounts to transfer of resources of poor for the benefit of the rich. It amounts to permitting profiteering at the cost of livelihood and existence of a farmer. This is against the philosophy of the Constitution and in violation of guaranteed fundamental rights of equality and right to property and to life. What cannot be done directly cannot be done indirectly also. This apart, if State is to be party to directly or indirectly select beneficiary of State largess - which in present fact situation the State certainly is - objectivity and transparency are essential elements of exercise of public power which are required to be followed. It is patent that the State has enabled the builder to enter the field after initiation of acquisition to seek colonization on the land covered by acquisition. In absence of State's action, it was not possible for the builder to enter into the transactions in question which was followed by withdrawal from acquisition. But for assurance from some quarters, the builder could not have made investment nor land owners could have executed the transactions in question. Such fraudulent and clandestine exercise of power by the State is not permitted by law.	 [Para 14,15,27]

heading: Notification u/S.4
HeadNote.description: Notification u/S.4 - Transfer of title thereafter for release of land to a person who is not owner on date of notification - Is an abuse of power u/S.48 - Such transferee cannot claim any right other than compensation.	(Para 21)

heading: Power to release land from acquisition
HeadNote.description: Power to release land from acquisition - Has to be exercised consistent with the doctrine of public trust and not arbitrarily.			(Para 19)

heading: Land acquisition
For Housing Society
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - For Housing Society - Peaceful possession free from encumbrances handed over to society - All rights thus would stand vested with society free from encumbrances and transferred to its members - No requirement of execution of deed of conveyance by Govt. under TP Act - S.44A of LA Act would not be attracted since after land stood vested with society and regulated under Delhi Co-operative Societies Act 2003 and Rules 2007 framed thereunder. 	(Paras 33, 47)

heading: Karnataka Land Acquisition Rules (1965), R.10(b)
HeadNote.description: Karnataka Land Acquisition Rules (1965), R.10(b) - Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013), S.24 - Land acquisition under KIAD Act - Applicability of new LA Act - Whether proceedings can be lapsed as per new LA Act for non-compliance with S.11A of old LA Act - Held, once proceedings initiated under KIAD Act, S.11A of old Act would not be applicable - Therefore, S.24(2) of new Act would also not be applicable.			(Paras 25, 26)

heading: Karnataka Land Acquisition Rules (1965), R.10(b)
HeadNote.description: Karnataka Land Acquisition Rules (1965), R.10(b) - Right to Fair Compensation and Transparency in Land Acquisition, Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act (2013), S.24 - Land acquisition under KIAD Act - Prayer for lapse of proceedings on ground that no award passed within time stipulated u/S.11A of the old LA Act - Appellant authorities contending that compensation was fixed on basis of consent agreement arrived at in meeting held on 9th Sep., 2005, therefore no award required to be passed under KIAD Act - Appellants even deposited said amount in civil court as same could not have been disbursed to respondents due to dispute among them as to apportionment of compensation - Respondents denying to have given any such consent - Entire move on the part of appellants for fixing compensation was bona fide - Only accidental slip on their part was that they failed to produce Form D i.e. format in which said mutual consent should be arrived at as per R.10(b) of KLA Rules - They also failed to show that notice of meeting was served on respondents - In such view of the matter order of Single Judge rejecting prayer for lapse of proceedings and permitting appellants to proceed with fixing of market value as on the date of final Notification held, proper.			(Paras 10, 18, 19, 20, 27)

heading: Market value of land
HeadNote.description: Market value of land - Land was acquired for non-residential purpose and surrounding lands were also being used for non-residential purpose - Submission made that market price of land should be calculated at commercial rate - However, acquired land was used for agriculture purpose - Therefore, compensation cannot be granted at commercial rate. 2010 ALL SCR 2152, (1995) 5 SCC 203 Ref. to. 	(Paras 13, 14, 15)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Not proper
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Claimed, on basis of sale instance - Map produced on record nowhere shows that land purchased in said sale deed was adjacent to acquired land - Also, comparatively much smaller in size - Thus, can't be considered as comparable sale instance - Reference Court referred earlier judgements pertaining to land acquired from same area and survey numbers of those lands are found reflected in map - In said cases compensation awarded at rate of Rs.30,000/- for dry crop land and Rs.45,000/- for irrigated land - Acquired land is big one admeasuring 3 H 8 R and total orange trees cultivated therein were only 277 - Considering that only portion of field was under irrigated crop of orange trees and in absence of any evidence relating to laying down pipeline in field, Reference Court reduced amount of compensation - Not proper - Compensation should be calculated at rate of Rs.30,000/- for non-irrigated land and Rs.45,000/- for irrigated land - Direction issued accordingly.			(Paras 6, 8, 9, 10)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Towards cost of pipeline - In view of S.3(a), expression 'land' includes benefits arising out of land and things attached to earth or permanently fastened to anything attached to earth - Pipeline being permanently fastened to earth, price of said pipeline is included in benefits arising out of land - No separate amount can be awarded towards construction of pipeline. 		(Para 11)

heading: Market value
Determination of
Comparable sale method
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination of - Comparable sale method - Claimant produced two sale deeds in support of his claim for compensation - First sale deed was executed after publication of notification u/S.4 of LA Act - Land in said sale deed was also located at distance of 2 Km. from land under acquisition - Record does not show that land in second sale deed was identical in characteristic and potential with land under acquisition - Further, transaction in second sale deed was executed between real brothers due to acute need of money - Such sale instances cannot be comparable sale instances to determine market value of land. 	(Paras 9, 10, 11, 12)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Towards trees, well and other improvements carried out by claimant in acquired land - Claim for enhancement of - Evidence of valuer who valued land of claimant was cryptic and scanty in nature - Further, no report of expert from Horticulture department to evaluate cost of fruit bearing trees - Reference Court adopted superficial approach while granting enhanced compensation in favour of claimant - However, no objection raised by State against order of Reference Court - Order of Reference Court cannot be interfered with - Claimant not entitled to further enhancement in compensation.			(Paras 15, 17, 18, 19)

heading: Market value
Determination
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination - Claimants claiming compensation at Rs.1,00,000/- per acre, produced sale instances of lands situated in adjoining village - Lands in said sale instances were dry lands and situated in interior part of village - Acquired land was located near Highway and was also irrigated - One of lands in said sale instances fetched price as high as Rs.1,34,891/- per acre - Compensation of Rs.60,000/- per acre awarded by Reference Court without considering these facts, improper - Claimants entitled to compensation of Rs.1,00,000/- per acre. 		(Paras 10, 12, 14)

heading: Grant of
HeadNote.description: Compensation for orange trees - Grant of - Reference Court granted compensation of Rs.7,000/- per orange tree after considering evidence of Retired Professor of Horticulture and valuation report on record - Professor of Horticulture made detailed analysis of fruit bearing trees and other trees and applied proper yardstick for their valuation - Nothing much has been elicited in his cross-examination - Further, State could not point out any discrepancies in findings of Reference Court - Grant of compensation of Rs.7,000/- per orange tree, proper. 	(Para 16)

heading: 'Land'
Inclusive definition u/S.3(a)
HeadNote.description: 'Land' - Inclusive definition u/S.3(a) - Issue as to whether a part of building would be covered by definition - Held, portion of building cannot survive without building and building cannot stand without land - Hence building (and its portion) would also be a part of land. 			(Paras 29, 30)

heading: Permissibility
Plea not tenable
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of a portion of building - Without acquiring underlying land - Permissibility - Plea raised that acquisition of land being dominant purpose of Act, land has to be necessarily acquired - Plea not tenable - Purpose of Act is to make additions for public purpose and to award compensation to owners/ interested persons - Acquisition made for public purpose in instant case - Further, if flats can be sold without land, they can be acquired also - Land beneath building need not be acquired. 	(Para 33)

heading: Acquisition of building
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of building - Without acquiring underlying land - Building owned by private persons but underlying land belonging to State - Held, in case of its own ownership, State need not acquire land. (1907-08) 12 CWN 569, AIR 1916 Pat. 330(1), AIR 1934 All. 260, AIR 1939 All. 34 Overruled. AIR 1968 SC 1045, AIR 1955 SC 298 Rel.on.	(Paras 34, 41, 42, 43, 44, 49)

heading: Not tenable
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of a portion of building - Without acquiring underlying land - Contention that such an acquisition would amount to overreach of State's power to eminent domain - Not tenable - Article 300A interdicts taking of property for public purpose without compensating owner - In adjudication of compensation as per S.23, State is not depriving respondents - There is acquisition by fair procedure along with reasonable compensation - No question of eminent domain being misused or violation of Art.300A of Constitution. 	(Para 52)

heading: Land acquisition
Interest on compensation
Not tenable
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Interest on compensation - Reference Court granted interest at rate of 9% p.a. for period of one year by resorting S.28, on basis of interpretation of S.34 made by Full Bench in 2016(4) ALL MR 513 (F.B.) - Challenge by contending that view so taken by Full Bench would have no bearing upon grant of interest u/S.28 - Not tenable - Both these provisions are pari materia - Intent and language expressed and used in both these Sections are identical except difference of stage at which interest is to be granted - Therefore, interpretation accorded to S.34 would also have its equal application while understanding import of S.28. 2016(4) ALL MR 513 (F.B.), AIR 1964 SC 1878 Rel. on. 	(Paras 4, 5)

heading: Land acquisition
Interest on compensation

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
Opinion of expert
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Compensation - Determination of market value - Opinion of expert - Consideration.

Evidence Act (1872) S.45.

In determination of market value of acquired land the prices paid for the properties of similar character in the neighbourhood, can be the best piece of evidence for the purpose of determination of market value.  However, that is not the only method to determine the market value.  There may not be any single sale transaction in that village around the time of issuance of notification under section 4 of the said Act. In such cases, the claimant would be definitely entitled to adduce other evidence to establish the market value which the claimant is entitled to claim on acquisition of the property. 				 [Para 9]

In the instant case, in regard to experts evidence it is apparent on the face of his testimony that he claims to be B.Sc. (Agri) and his subjects at B.Sc. course were Agronomy, Soil Chemistry and Crop Cultivation. Considering the subjects which he had studied at the graduation level, in no circumstances, he can be considered as an 'expert' in the field of valuation of the property.  His expertise may be in the field of soil chemistry or in crop cultivation.  That by itself is not sufficient for a person to claim expertise in the matter of valuation of the property.  That apart, the witness nowhere assisted the claimants in establishing the market value of the property. 				 [Para 10]

heading: Acquisition of land
Objection to
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Objection to - It is for the persons interested to object to the acquisition within 30 days of publication of notification u/s.4, by making such objection in writing to the Collector.

It is for the persons interested to object to the acquisition within 30 days of the publication of the notification under section 4, by making such objection in writing to the Collector. In the instant case, the petitioners filed objections on 12-8-2002. The petitioners were given an individual notice on 26-8-2002 fixing the hearing on 16-9-2002.  The petitioners in Writ Petition No.5604 of 2002 sought further time for filing objections. Time was given upto 26-9-2002. The petitioners filed additional objections on 26-9-2002. The Land Acquisition Officer completed hearing on 26-9-2002, in respect of these petitioners and in respect of other petitioners who had not filed objections and who had not sought time on 18-9-2002 completed the hearing process. The mere fact that the petitioners herein have filed additional objections on 14-10-2002 and 13-11-2002, would therefore be of no consequence as they are after the hearing was completed on 26-9-2002. The petitioners were given individual notices of hearing. When they sought additional time, that time was given to them. In these circumstances, the first contention as urged on behalf of the petitioners herein that no notice of hearing was given to them or that they were not heard as required by Section 5-A, has to be rejected.   [Para 8]

heading: Expression "public purpose"
What is
HeadNote.description: Expression "public purpose" - What is - Acquisition of land for a garbage treatment plant and/or land fill sites - Would come under the expression "public purpose". AIR 1963 SC 151 and AIR 1963 SC 1890 - Followed.	(Para 9)

heading: Acquisition of land for a garbage treatment plant and/or land fill sites
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land for a garbage treatment plant and/or land fill sites - Inspection of the site and whether it would conform to the requirements and satisfy the environmental issues - Can only be done if the officers of Development Authority can enter upon the land after the issue of notification u/s.4 of the Act - There is no requirement on Development Authority or Municipal Authority to take authorisation before a notification u/s.4(1) of the Act was issued.

The question which the court had to answer is whether for the purpose of identification of landfill sites or for garbage treatment plant permission of Pollution Control Board had to be taken as is sought to be contended on behalf of the petitioners herein. Site selection is set out in Schedule III.  Amongst various other requirements, it is provided that in areas falling under the jurisdiction of the development authorities, it shall be the responsibility of such development authorities to identify the land fill sites and hand over the sites to the concerned municipal authority for development, operation and maintenance. Elsewhere this responsibility shall lie with the concerned municipal authority. The requirement is that the site must be selected taking into consideration and/or examination of environmental issues.  That necessarily has to be done before a notification under Section 4 of the Land Acquisition Act is issued. If the land belongs to private owners, a public body or its officers cannot or could not enter on the land without the permission of the said authorities. It is only when the notification is issued under Section 4(1) of the Act, is it then lawful, by virtue of sub-section (2) for any officer either generally or specially authorised to enter upon and survey the land, dig or bore in the sub-soil, and to do all other acts necessary to ascertain whether the land is adapted for such purpose.  If we bear this aspect in mind, the contention as urged on behalf of the petitioners that the permission is required even before the notification under Section 4 of the land Acquisition Act is issued, will have to be negatived.  The inspection of the site and whether it would conform to the requirements and satisfy the environmental issues, can only be done if the officer of Respondent No.1 or officers of the Development Authority can enter upon the land after the issue of the notification under Section 4(1) of the Land Acquisition Act. A reading of Rule 4 of the Solid Waste Rules would also make it clear that the application in Form-I is for grant of authorisation for setting up waste processing and disposal facility including the landfills. The definition of landfill, which includes not only the disposal of residual solid wastes but also putting up of a facility. In other words, something that is already done on the land, and consequently the authorisation contemplated by Form I, can also contemplate a case where the land is not yet taken in possession by Respondent No.7. Therefore there was no requirement on the Development Authority or the Municipal Authority to take authorisation before a notification under Section 4(1) of the Land Acquisition Act was issued.   [Para 10]

heading: Development authority
HeadNote.description:
Maharashtra District Planning Committees (Constitution and Functions) Act (1998) - Municipal Solid Wastes (Management and Handling) Rules (2000), Rule 4 - Acquisition of land for a garbage treatment plant and/or landfill sites - Development authority - Wherever there is a notified planning Authority for an area that would be the Development Authority - If there is no planning Authority, it would be the Municipal Authority - The M.P.C.B. which is the authority set up for granting permission and monitoring landfill sites and garbage treatment plant under the provisions of the Environment Act, intimated by its communication that in so far as village from where the Land is to be acquired, the development authority is the Collector.

A perusal of the Solid Waste Rules would indicate, that the Planning Authorities are the Development Authorities or the Municipalities. In the instant case, the land does not fall within the limits of Municipality.  The lands are within the local area of a village. The expression "Development Authority" therefore will have to be seen in the context of the authority which is seized with the planned development of the area within its jurisdiction.  It must be noted that Parliament would be aware of the fact, that there are Town Planning Acts in every State which provide for development plan for a town as also for a region which can include a village. Wherever there is a notified Planning Authority for an area that would be the Development Authority.  If there is no Planning Authority, it would be the Municipal Authority. The M.P.C.B. which is the authority set up for granting permission and monitoring landfill sites and garbage treatment plant under the provisions of the Environment Act, intimated by its communication that in so far as village from where the land is to be acquired, the development authority is the Collector.	 [Para 12]

heading: Acquisition of land
Not necessary
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Issuance of notice to persons interested - Not necessary - Such notice is required to be given to objectors.

Section 5-A nowhere provides that a notice has to be issued by the Land Acquisition Officer to the "persons interested" in the land which has been notified under Section 4(1).  Section 5-A however requires that opportunity of personal hearing shall be given to the objector.  Apparent that what is required is that after Notification under Section 4(1) if objections are filed, personal hearing should necessarily be given to the objectors and without giving such hearing, no report can be made by the Land Acquisition Officer.  It would thus be seen that the notice mentioned in Rule 5-A in the Manual of Land Acquisition for State of Maharashtra is nothing but a notice to the objector.  In the present case, after the publication of Notification under Section 4(1), none of the petitioners preferred any objection and as such they were not entitled to any notice under 5-A.  Their grievance is, therefore, unfounded and has to be rejected.  [Para 10]

The declaration under Section 6(1) dated 16-4-1987 was made within one year from 24-4-1986, on which date the public notice of the notification under Section 4(1) was displayed at the office of Gram Panchayat.  Thus, there is no delay in making of the declaration under Section 6(1).  As such no fault can be found with the declaration.  [Para 14,15]

heading: Acquisition of land
Market value
Determination of
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Market value - Determination of - Sale instances of comparable lands - Method of determination of market rate on basis of sale instances of comparable lands is the proper method.

Method of determination of market rate on the basis of sale instances of comparable lands is the proper method.  The reference Court also adopted that method for determination of market rate.  However, grievance from both the sides is that the evidence about sale instances has not been considered properly.  One of the contention raised on behalf of the claimant is that the reference Court without considering the sale instances and without recording any reasons discarded that evidence observing that the prices shown are exorbitant.  On behalf of acquiring body also contention is raised that sale instances brought on record are not considered.  In view of these rival contentions the evidence adduced before the reference Court oral as well as documentary requires consideration.  The claimants produced on record certified copies of sale deeds at Exhs.25 to 29.  Out of 5 sale instances, sale transaction under Exhs.27 to 29 are of the lands located in Beed Taraf Bobde area and other two are from different locality known as Taraf Pingale.  On behalf of the acquiring body as many as twenty certified copies of the sale deeds were produced on record.  Out of the said twenty sale transactions the transactions under Exhs.33 to 38 are for the year 1999 and remaining sale instances are for the years 2000 and 2001.  The market rates as well as the sale instances within proximate time of the date of notification under Section 4 of the Act are relevant.  The sale instances for the years 2000 and 2001 need no consideration when the sale instances for the year 1999 which are within proximate time of date of notification under Section 4 are available on record.  So far as the sale instances brought on record by claimants, the reference Court in paragraph 10 of the judgment observed that sale transactions under Sale deeds at Exhs.25 to 27 are prior to the date of notification under Section 4(1) of the Act.  The sale deeds at Exhs.28 and 29 are observed to be the sale instances after the date of notification under Section 4 of the Act.  The date of notification under Section 4 in the present case is 2/12/1999 and sale deeds at Exhs.28 and 29 are dated 10/2/2000 and 30/12/2000.  Sale deed at Exh.25 is dated 15/10/1998 and transactions under Exhs.26 and 27 are dated 19/5/99 and 30/9/99.  So these sale transactions are prior to the notification under Section 4 and also within the proximate time.  In respect of sale transactions of which the acquiring body placed reliance, it has been rightly observed that the transactions under sale deeds Exhs.33 to 38 are the transactions in the proximate time of date of notification and relevant.  It is for the Court to examine those sale transactions to ascertain as to whether those can be said to be comparable sale instances for the purpose of determination of market rate. On perusal of sale deed Exh.25 we noticed that the property under this sale deed bearing survey no.173 is located in Pingale Taraf area.  It is a sale transaction of a house property.  So this sale transaction which is a transaction of plot alongwith a house structure cannot be said to be a comparable sale instance of the land acquired.

Other 2 sale deeds are post-notification sale deeds, though they are from Taraf Bobade area.  No doubt it is not an absolute rule that the sale transactions of the lands situated at long distance cannot be treated to be comparable sale instances.  Even post-notification transaction also can be taken into consideration with some allowances of deductions because of time factor.  However, it must be shown that the said lands are the comparable lands and are having same advantage and other amenities.  However, no such evidence is laid before the reference Court though sale deeds are produced on record by claimant.  The documents by themselves do not assist the claimant to prove the market rate of the lands at the time of date of notification under Section 4 of the Act, in absence of evidence of similarity in quality and similar amenities.  Though acquiring body produced on record 20 certified copies of sale instances only the sale transactions under Exhs.33 to 38 are within the proximate time of date of notification.  No evidence is laid on behalf of the acquiring body also to show that these sale transactions are also of comparable lands.  AIR 1996 SC 531 and 1996(2) SCC 583 - Ref. to.   [Para 12,15]

heading: Acquisition of land
Market value
Reference Court
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Market value - Reference Court - Determination of market value binding on acquiring body as well as on the reference Court - Reference Court may enhance the same on basis of material placed before it by claimant, but cannot reduce it.

In the present case, the evidence laid before the Reference Court oral as well as documentary including the sale instance was found not sufficient to determine the market price at the time of acquisition of the land.  The SLAO accepting the potentiality of the land had granted compensation on square meter basis however, without there being any deduction towards development charges.  He has determined the market rate at Rs.107/- per Sq.Mt., considering the location of the land.  It appears that he has collected some information of sale instances and on that basis as well as market rate determined in another land acquisition proceeding SLAO determined the market rate.  Learned Advocate Shri. A. S. Bajaj submitted that the material collected by the S.L.A.O. cannot be considered by reference Court unless that was brought on record before the Reference Court.  This contention raised by Shri. Bajaj needs to be considered at this stage.  The award is a public document.  Same is produced before reference Court while challenging the market rate as unreasonable or inadequate.  No doubt, the reference Court needs to record finding on the issue of market rate on the basis of material available before it.  For the purpose of acertaining the reasonableness of the market rate whether it is reasonable and adequate, the award needs to be placed before the Court.  The mandate under Section 25 imposes restriction not to grant compensation less than awarded by SLAO.  In view of provisions under Section 25 the market rate determined is binding on the acquiring body as well as on the reference Court though reference Court may enhance the same on the basis of material placed before him by the claimant but cannot reduce it.  In view of these facts, contention raised on behalf of acquiring body that the material referred in the award cannot be considered is devoid of any merit.  						 [Para 21]

HeadNote.description: Apportionment of compensation - Legality - Father purchased acquired land in name of his eldest son out of love and affection when he was 13 years old - Hence, at that time it was benami transaction - Son had attained majority, retained land with him so also his name remained entered throughout in revenue record and then died before father - Father did not transfer said property either in his name or in name of his other children during life time or after death of son - When father executed Will, he neither mentioned about such benami purchase nor disposed of same because till then son had become full owner of suit property - Therefore, inference of lapse of legacy drawn by Reference Court as son died before father, is improper - After death of son, his widow and children being legal representatives entitled to receive amount of compensation. heading: Notification under S.4
Test of urgency
Pre-notification delay
HeadNote.description:
Notification under S.4 - Test of urgency - Pre-notification delay - Not necessarily indicative of absence of urgency - Failure to issue declaration under S.6 simultaneously, or soon thereafter too is not necessarily indicative of absence of urgency.

(1)	Urgency in completing a project cannot be equated to urgency which makes it necessary to even skip enquiry under section 5-A of the Act.

(2)	The question of subjective satisfaction of an authority in forming the opinion that enquiry under section 5-A should be done away with is one of facts, to be determined with reference to totality of circumstances.

(3)	Pre-notification delay is not necessarily indicative of absence of urgency.

(4)	Failure to issue declaration under section 6 simultaneously, or soon thereafter too is not necessarily indicative of absence of urgency.

(5)	Skipping enquiry under section 5-A should not be routinely resorted to or allowed by courts, since it is the only opportunity afforded to owner of property to raise his objections to compulsory acquisition.

When an authority is required or permitted to form requisite opinion, at least one sentence indicating why it formed such opinion to dispense with the enquiry under Section 5-A of the Act, would be reasonably expected.  Such an expression is missing from the impugned notification.  Since the original record of the proceedings was made available for perusal of the Court, as also petitioners' counsel, Court after going through the same, could not find any specific proposal having been placed before the Commissioner indicating urgency of such magnitude as to dispense with enquiry under Section 5-A of the Act.  It may, therefore, be reasonable to infer that the Commissioner's subjective satisfaction does not pass the muster.  1998(6) SCC 1 and A.I.R. 1997 SC 1284 - Ref. to.	 [Para 33,35]

HeadNote.description:
Valuation of land - Fixing market value of acquired land - Considerations to be kept in mind.

While fixing the market value of the acquired land, the Land Acquisition Officer is required to keep in mind the following factors:- (i) existing geographical situation of the land; (ii) existing use of the land; (iii) already available advantages, like proximity to National or State Highway or road and/or developed area and (iv) market value of other land situated in the same locality/village/area or adjacent or very near to the acquired land. Thus, the market value is determined with reference to the open market sale of comparable land in the neighbourhood, by a willing seller to a willing buyer, on or before the date of preliminary notification, as that would give a fair indication of the market value.            [Para 10,11]

heading: Valuation of land
Valuation of land
HeadNote.description:
Valuation of land - Determination of market value of land - Averaging price paid under sale transactions - When permissible.

Where the lands acquired are of different type and different locations, averaging is not permissible. But where there are several sales of similar lands, more or less, at the same time, whose prices have marginal variation, averaging thereof is permissible. For the purpose of fixation of fair and reasonable market value of any type of land, abnormally high value or abnormally low value sales should be carefully discarded. If the number of sale deeds of the same locality and the same period with short intervals are available, the average price of the available number of sale deeds shall be considered as a fair and reasonable market price.      [Para 20]

heading: Valuation of land
HeadNote.description:
Valuation of land - Determination of market value - Freehold vis-a-vis leasehold deeds - Are conceptually different.

If a property subject to a lease and in the possession of a lessee is offered for sale by the owner to a prospective private purchaser, the purchaser being aware that on purchase he will get only title and not possession and that the sale in his favour will be subject to encumbrance namely, the lease, he will offer a price taking note of the encumbrances. Naturally, such a price would be less than the price of a property without any encumbrance. But when a land is acquired free from encumbrances, the market value of the same will certainly be higher.      [Para 23]

heading: Valuation of land
HeadNote.description:
Valuation of land - Competition involved in auction sales - Makes it unsafe guide for value determination.

While considering the competition involved in auction sales of commercial/residential plots and observing that the element of competition in auction sales make them unsafe guides for determining the market value of the acquired lands. The general rule that the sale prices of the comparable sales should be relied upon for calculating the market value will not apply when the sale transactions relied upon are auction sales.          [Para 26,28]

heading: Valuation of land
HeadNote.description: Valuation of land - Market value of acquired land - Deduction towards development cost - Involved in laying roads, erection of electricity lines, drains, other facilities and development around the area - One third deduction is normal rule. (Para 34)

heading: Interest
HeadNote.description:
Interest - Award of interest is mandatory under S.34 - Award of interest under S.28 is discretionary.

Award of interest under Section 34 is mandatory in as much the word used in the Section is 'shall'. The scheme of the Act and the express provisions thereof establish that the interest payable under Section 34 is statutory. The claim for interest under Section 28 of the Act proceeds on the basis that due compensation not having been paid, the claimant should be allowed interest on the enhanced compensation amount. The award of interest under Section 28 is discretionary power vested in the Court and it has to be exercised in a judicious manner and not arbitrarily. The use of the word "may" in Section 28 does not confer any arbitrary discretion on the Court to disallow interest for no valid or proper reasons. Normally, Court awards interest if it enhances the compensation in excess of the amount awarded by the Collector, unless there are exceptional circumstances.      [Para 45]

Section 28 empowers the courts, if it was enhancing the compensation awarded by the Collector, to award interest on the sum in excess of what the Collector had awarded as compensation. Both in terms of Section 34 and Section 28, interest at 9% per annum is payable for the first year of taking possession and 15% per annum thereafter, if the amount of compensation was not paid or deposited within a period of one year or deposited thereafter.      [Para 44]

heading: Costs
HeadNote.description:
Costs - When litigant succeeds in fact and fails in part, court may order payment of proportionate costs.

The language of Section 27(1) is clear and very wide and it gives power to the courts to order costs to be paid by what persons and in what proportions they are to be paid. In making order for costs under Section 27(1), the court may have regard to the provisions of Section 35 C.P.C. Analysing sub-section (2) of Section 27, it appears to consist of three parts, viz., (i) When the award of the Collector is not upheld, the costs shall ordinarily be paid by the collector as directed by the Court; (ii) the court is not bound to do so in every case. If the court forms opinion that the claim of the claimant is extravagant or that he was so negligent in putting his case before the Collector, then the court may make a different order as regards costs and (iii) the court may in such cases direct, that some deduction be made from the costs of the claimant or that he should pay a part of the Collector's costs. Ordinarily, when a litigant succeeds in part and fails in part, the equitable order made is that he should receive proportionate costs.          [Para 54,55]

heading: Art.30(4)(f)
Comparison method
HeadNote.description:
Goa, Daman and Diu Agricultural Tenancy Act (1964) - Code of Communidate (Legislative Diploma No.2070) - Art.30(4)(f) - Determination of market value - Comparison method - Land held by Communidade - In case of a land held by a Communidade, the restriction on transfer will be one of the negative factors, which will have to be considered while fixing the market value - Taking into consideration the said negative factor, some deduction will have to be made depending upon the facts of a particular case while fixing the market value on the basis of a comparable sale instance of a free-hold land.

When a land is described as a free-hold land, it has reference to the tenure of the land. The characteristic of a freehold tenure is that there is inheritability and transferability as a matter of right. In case of a land held by a Communidade, there is no defect in the title or ownership of the Communidade, but the restriction is on transferring the land held by the Communidade by way of sale, lease or exchange. Restriction is that such a transfer by way of sale cannot be made without prior sanction. There is no complete prohibition against effecting such transfer. In case of an insolvency of Communidade, there is a power to sell land of Communidade. However, there is a general power vesting in a Communidade by virtue of Article 30 of the Code to transfer its land by sale, lease or exchange with the sanction.

While assessing the market value for the purpose of Section 23 of the said Act of 1894 by comparison method, the test adopted is what a prudent and genuine buyer will offer as a price of the acquired land. In case of a land, which is not freehold in the sense that a transfer thereof cannot be effected without sanction of the authorities, a willing bona fide buyer may not offer the same price, which he may offer in respect of a comparable freehold land as the buyer will be conscious of the fact that there are restrictions on transferability or that the authority empowered to sanction sale may impose some conditions. Therefore, he may offer to some extent a lesser price to the land having such restrictions. However, it cannot be said that the sale instance of a freehold land which is otherwise comparable to the acquired land cannot afford a basis to determine the market value of a land, which is having restrictions on transfer.

In case of a land held by a Communidade, the restriction on transfer will be one of the negative factors, which will have to be considered while fixing the market value. Taking into consideration the said negative factor, some deduction will have to be made depending upon the facts of a particular case while fixing the market value on the basis of a comparable sale instance of a free-hold land.  AIR 1979 SC 869 and 2005(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 449 - Ref. to. 		 [Para 13,15]

heading: Taking possession of land
HeadNote.description:
Taking possession of land - What amounts to.

Law on the issue can be summarized to the effect that no strait-jacket formula can be laid down for taking the possession of the land for the purpose of Sections 16 and 17 of the 1894 Act. It would depend upon the facts of an individual case. In case the land is fallow and barren and does not have any structure or crop on it, symbolic possession may meet the requirement of law. However, this would not be the position in case crop is standing on the land or a kachha or pacca structure has been raised on such land. In that case, actual physical possession is required to be taken. There may be a case where the acquiring authority is in possession of the land, as the same has already been requisitioned under any law or the property is in possession of a tenant, in such a case symbolic possession qua the tenure holder would be sufficient. In the instant case, in view of the fact that land in dispute is an agricultural land and has 167 dwelling houses, law in fact requires taking over the actual physical possession.  [Para 124,125]

heading: Acquisition of land
Taking possession of
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Taking possession of - Land acquired by Development Authority - State Authority preparing panchanama on the spot showing delivery of possession by land owner to Development Authority - Passing of award within two years from date of such possession - Proceedings do not stand lapsed. heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Taking possession of land - What constitutes.

The principles can be stated thus :-

i)	No hard and fast rule can be laid down as to what act would constitute taking of possession of the acquired land.

ii)	If the acquired land is vacant, the act of the concerned State authority to go to the spot and prepare a panchanama will ordinarily be treated as sufficient to constitute taking of possession.

iii)	If crop is standing on the acquired land or building/structure exists, mere going on the spot by the concerned authority will, by itself, be not sufficient for taking possession. Ordinarily, in such cases, the concerned authority will have to give notice to the occupier of the building/structure or the person who has cultivated the land and take possession in the presence of independent witnesses and get their signatures on the panchanama. Of course, refusal of the owner of the land or building/structure may not lead to an inference that the possession of the acquired land has not been taken.

iv)	If the acquisition is of a large tract of land, it may not be possible for the acquiring/designated authority to take physical possession of each and every parcel of the land and it will be sufficient that symbolic possession is taken by preparing appropriate document in the presence of independent witnesses and getting their signatures on such document.

v)	If beneficiary of the acquisition is an agency/instrumentality of the State and 80% of the total compensation is deposited in terms of Section 17(3A) and substantial portion of the acquired land has been utilised in furtherance of the particular public purpose, then the Court may reasonably presume that possession of the acquired land has been taken.  					 [Para 34]

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Land acquisition - Determination of market value - Purpose for which the land was acquired cannot from the basis for determining the market price in view of the bar under S.24 (Fifthly) of the Act - Reference Court was required to decide applications for higher compensation strictly within the ambit of Ss.23 and 24 of the Act.

The determination of market price is governed by the provisions of Section 23 of the Land Acquisition Act and the factors stated therein are required to be taken into consideration.  At the same time, the developments that have taken place, when the reference was being decided, cannot be considered.  The purpose for which the land was acquired cannot form a basis for determining the market price in view of the bar under section 24 (Fifthly) of the Land Acquisition Act.  The Reference Court was required to decide the applications for higher compensation strictly within the ambit of sections 23 and 24 of the Land Acquisition Act and it did not have the power to innovate a reasonable method by taking into consideration the developments that were noticed on the date of inspection.  The method invented by the Reference Court in determining the market price is not only speculative in nature but, in fact, it suffers from conjectures and surmises.  It is evident that the Reference Court treated itself as a Writ Court.  When the parties had placed on record evidence of comparative sale instances the Reference Court ought to have considered the said evidence and set out reasons for not considering the same.  The methodology adopted by the Reference Court could not be sustained when the comparable sale instances were placed on record.  If these sale instances could not be called as comparable sale instances, the Reference Court was required to record reasons therefor.  AIR 1996 SC 1565 and 1996(3) SCC 124 - Referred to.  [Para 19]

heading: Public purpose
HeadNote.description:
Public purpose - No document produced to show that appellant had prepared housing scheme and the same had been approved by state Government before issuing S.4(1) notification - Held Division Bench of High Court was correct in holding that acquisition was not for a public purpose.

In this case no housing scheme was framed by the appellant which is sine qua non for treating the acquisition of land for a cooperative society as an acquisition for public purpose within the meaning of Section 3(f). Not only this, the appellant executed agreement for facilitating the acquisition of land in lieu of payment of a sum of rupees more than 5 crores. The Estate Agent engaged by the appellant had promised that it will get the notifications issued under Sections 4(1) and 6(1) within four months and three months respectively. The huge amount which the appellant had agreed to pay to the Estate Agent had no co-relation with the services provided by it. Rather, the amount was charged by the Estate Agent for manipulating the State apparatus and facilitating the acquisition of land and sanction of layout etc. without any obstruction. Such an agreement is clearly violative of Section 23 of the Contract Act. Held High Court did not commit any error by relying upon the judgment in 1st H.M.T case (1995) 2 SCC 677 for declaring that the acquisition was not for a public purpose.  [Para 29]

heading: Withdrawal from acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Withdrawal from acquisition - Can be done only by issuing notification in Official Gazette.

Although, the plain language of Section 48(1) does not give any indication of the manner or mode in which the power/discretion to withdraw from the acquisition of any land is required to be exercised, having regard to the scheme of Parts II and VII of the 1894 Act, which postulates publication of notification under Section 4(1), declaration under Section 6 and agreement under Section 42 in the official gazette as a condition for valid acquisition of the land for any public purpose or for a company, it is reasonable to take the view that withdrawal from the acquisition, which may adversely affect the public purpose for which, or the company on whose behalf the acquisition is proposed, can be done only by issuing a notification in the official gazette. The exercise of power by the government under Section 48(1) of the Act must be made known to the public at large so that those interested in accomplishment of the public purpose for which the land is acquired or the concerned company may question such withdrawal by making representation to the higher authorities or by seeking court's intervention. If the decision of the Government to withdraw from the acquisition of land is kept secret and is not published in the official gazette, there is every likelihood that unscrupulous land owners, their agents and wheeler-dealers may pull strings in the power corridors and clandestinely get the land released from acquisition and thereby defeat the public purpose for which the land is acquired. Similarly, the company on whose behalf the land is acquired may suffer incalculable harm by unpublished decision of the Government to withdraw from the acquisition.   [Para 27]
