Whether tenable
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Challenge to acquisition proceedings - Whether tenable - Land acquired for construction of railway line - Neither petitioner-landowner nor his predecessor in title were put to notice with regard to acquisition - Perusal of award shows that possession of land was not actually taken immediately upon declaration of award - Petitioner stood dispossessed immediately prior to date when he first wrote letter to respondent regarding grant of compensation and measurement of acquired land - Therefore, it would not be necessary to examine as to whether acquisition proceedings stood lapsed or not - Purpose for which land was taken was of immense public interest and development - Therefore, instead of setting aside entire process of acquisition, direction issued to pay compensation to petitioner. (2005) 13 SCC 477 Ref. to. 			(Paras 21, 22, 23, 28, 29)

heading: Market value
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Market value - Determination of - Reference Court determined market value of acquired land at Rs.700/- per sq. mtr. by considering sale instances of house property - Whereas acquired land was open land - Sale instances of house property is not a comparable sale instance - Highest rate of sale instance available on record on relevant date was Rs.473/- per sq. mtr. - Acquired land was in vicinity of Govt. Offices, Hospital, S.T. depot, District Court, School, College, etc. - After deducting 33% value, market price of acquired land comes to Rs. 317/- per sq. mtr. - Market value of acquired land modified to Rs.317/- per sq. mtr. from Rs.700/- per sq. mtr.			(Paras 22, 23, 24, 28)

heading: Interest on compensation
HeadNote.description: Interest on compensation - When possession taken prior to date of notification u/S.4 - Scheme of Act does not contemplate taking of possession prior to issuance of notification u/S.4 - Interest therefore cannot be awarded for such period - Interest at 9% payable for period of one year from date of notification u/S.4 and at 15% from date of award till date of realization of compensation amount. 2012(4) ALL MR 779 Rel. on. 			(Paras 25, 26, 28)

heading: Enhancement of compensation
Claim for
HeadNote.description: Enhancement of compensation - Claim for - Reference Court enhanced compensation from Rs.2,22,900/- per hectare to Rs.60,00,000/- per hectare, Considering potentiality of land - Claimants seeking further enhancement on ground that they have purchased land at Rs.12,54,658/- per hectare and have also entered into agreement of sale at rates ranging from Rs.160/- to Rs.210/- per sq.ft. - Acquired land was claimed to be purchased by claimant two years prior to acquisition - Enhancement of five times in value of land within span of two years, does not appear probable - Further, sale deed on basis of which claimants become owners of acquired land was not produced by them on record, though it was best piece of evidence for seeking enhancement - In absence of sale deed being brought on record, price mentioned in it cannot be considered for determining amount of compensation - Agreements of sale entered into by claimants with third party were for small portion of acquired land - Witnesses stated that said agreements were cancelled due to failure to get sanction from authority for conversion of land from agricultural to non-agricultural - Further, record showing that market rate of land in locality ranges from Rs.60/- per sq.ft. onwards - Considering material on record amount of compensation is to be determined at Rs.40/- per sq. ft. - As there was no evidence to show that land was developed land, deduction of 65% is to be made while determining amount of compensation - Claimants entitled to compensation of Rs.22,54,000/- for acquired land. 			(Paras 13, 14, 15, 16, 17 18)

heading: Land acquisition
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Enhancement of compensation - Sale deed on basis of which claimants become owners of acquired land shortly prior to its acquisition would be best piece of evidence available for seeking enhancement in amount of compensation.	(Para 12)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Land acquired situated in one village - Reliance on award passed in respect of land in adjacent village - Close poximity between two villages - Can be made basis for determining market value in absence of comparative sale in village of acquisition.	(Para 7)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Rate of price increase - Lands situate in rural areas - No evidence of any out-of-ordinary developments or increases in prices in the area - Escalation of 7.5% per annum would be sufficient and appropriate increase to be adopted.			(Paras 11, 14)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination of market value - Recent trend to determine the market value of acquired lands with reference to future sale transactions or acquisitions is unsafe.

One of the fundamental principles of valuation is that the transactions subsequent to the acquisition should be ignored for determining the market value of acquired lands, as the very acquisition and the consequential development would accelerate the overall development of the surrounding areas resulting in a sudden or steep spurt in the prices. Even if it becomes inevitable, there should be greater caution in applying the prices fetched for transactions in future.   [Para 13]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Benefit of annual increase in price - To be calculated cumulatively and not at a flat rate - Year of relied upon transaction to be excluded.	(Paras 15, 17)

heading: Interest on compensation
HeadNote.description: Interest on compensation - Amount awarded for the purpose of calculating interest - Will include not only market value but also the additional amount under S.23(1A) and solatium under S.23(2).	(Para 19)

heading: Reference
Enhancement of compensation
HeadNote.description: Reference - Enhancement of compensation - Reference court by way of enhancement granted compensation of Rs.40/- per sq.ft. - Compensation enhanced by considering post notification sale instances though sale instances prior to issuance of notification were available on record - Sale instances prior to notification shows average rate of land per square foot was Rs.24/- - However, there was rising trend in land prices after notification - Entire acquired land converted for residential use and civic amenities were available but at some distance from acquired land - Reasonable compensation at rate of Rs.28/- per sq.ft. would be proper - Compensation modified from Rs.40/- per sq.ft. to Rs.28/- per sq.ft. 		(Paras 11, 12, 13)

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Setting aside of notification u/Ss.4 and 6 - Ground that there is no justification for invocation of urgency clause and dispensing with enquiry u/S.5A - ITBP required 72 to 75 acres land urgently to establish Battalion headquarter due to increase in counter insurgency operations, law and order duties and disaster management operations - Some time is bound to be consumed in identifying such land - Merely because some time taken in identifying land and issuing S.4 notification, High Court is not justified in observing that there is no urgency - There is development on 90 to 95% of acquired land and it has also been put to use by ITBP - Also out of 28.1398 hectares of acquired land only owners of near about 3 hectares of land raised objection to notification - Order setting aside notification u/Ss.4 and 6, improper. (Paras 6.2, 6.3, 6.4, 6.5)

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
Claim for non-payment
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Compensation - Claim for non-payment - Record showing that ITBP for whom land was acquired had deposited 80% of estimated amount of compensation - Notices were also served on landowners to withdraw compensation but they refused to take it - Final award directing adjudgment of compensation including solatium was also published but still compensation was not accepted - Not open to petitioners that compensation was not paid. (Paras 7, 8)

heading: Interest on solatium
Not permissible
HeadNote.description: Interest on solatium - Not permissible - (1996 2 SCC 71 Foll. Judgment in L.A.R. No.33/78 dt. 21.12.95 Reversed. (Para 4)

heading: Scope
HeadNote.description:
Scope - Section as amended has no retrospective operation.

Section 28 deals with payment interest to a Claimant on excess compensation. There is nothing in the language of Section 28 to suggest that from the date of possession till coming into force of the Act, the Claimant would be entitled to such rate of interest as was payable prior to the enforcement of the amendment  [Para 9]

heading: Interest payable
HeadNote.description: Interest payable - Calculation of Amount of compensation paid under the award is deductible from market value.  (Para 12)

heading: Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Determination of compensation - Based on market value - Market value of comparable sale instances to be identified by having regard to proximity from time angle and proximity from situation angle.

Section 23 of the Act specifies the matters required to be considered in determining the compensation; the principal among which is the determination of the market value of the land on the date of the publication of the notification under sub-section (1) of Section 4.

One of the principles for determination of the amount of compensation for acquisition of land would be the willingness of an informed buyer to offer the price therefor. It is beyond any cavil that the price of the land which a willing and informed buyer would offer would be different in the cases where the owner is in possession and enjoyment of the property and in the cases where he is not.

Market value is ordinarily the price the property may fetch in the open market if sold by a willing seller unaffected by the special needs of a particular purchase. Where definite material is not forthcoming either in the shape of sales of similar lands in the neighbourhood at or about the date of notification under Section 4(1) or otherwise, other sale instances as well as other evidences have to be considered.

The amount of compensation cannot be ascertained with mathematical accuracy. A comparable instance has to be identified having regard to the proximity from time angle as well as proximity from situation angle. For determining the market value of the land under acquisition, suitable adjustment has to be made having regard to various positive and negative factors vis-a-vis the land under acquisition by placing the two in juxtaposition. The positive and negative factors are as under:

Whereas a smaller plot may be within the reach of many, a large block of land will have to be developed preparing a layout plan, carving out roads, leaving open spaces, plotting out smaller plots, waiting for purchasers and the hazards of an entrepreneur. Such development charges may range between 20% and 50% of the total price.

heading: Compensation
Market value
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Market value - Acquisition of Land in likely submergence area of a dam - Land would not have any potential value - Development in the area had stopped - Comparable sale deed related to small piece of land situated far away - It was sold at Rs.270/- per sq. meter - Hence compensation at Rs.160/- for large plots and Rs.175/- for small plots would subserve ends of justice.	(Paras 31, 32)

heading: Acquisition of Land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of Land - Determination of market value for awarding compensation - Comparable instance of sale - Out of second and third instances of sale third instance more relevant - Price of land involved in third instance could be adopted as basis for determining market value - It cannot be worked out by averaging value of lands in second and third instances.	(Para 26)

heading: Acquisition of Land
Comparable instance
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of Land - Determination of market value - Comparable instance - Attribution of plus points to acquired Lands on counts of situation, location, frontage and level - Factors of location and level cannot be considered - Closeness to Rly. Station is no doubt matter of convenience but not of comfort - In circumstances acquired land is entitled to get 7 & 1/2% allowance on factor of situation of land - In addition it will be given 12 & 1/2% rise in price excluding emergency period.	(Paras 27,28,30,31)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
Comparable sale instances
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination of - Comparable sale instances - Of similar lands in the neighbourhood at or about date of Notification - Is the best evidence for determining market value of acquired land.

Comparable sales instances of similar lands in the neighbourhood at or about the date of Notification under Section 4(1) of the Act are considered to be the best evidence for determining the market value of the acquired land to arrive at a fair estimate of the amount of compensation payable to a land owner. Nevertheless, while ascertaining compensation, it is the duty of the Court to see that the compensation so determined is just and fair not only to the individual whose property has been acquired but also to the public which is to pay for it.   [Para 13]

Held the exemplars relied upon by the High Court were relevant for determining the market value of the acquired lands. It was moreso as, unless some glaring infirmity is shown in the assessment of evidence by the High Court, Supreme Court would ordinarily be slow in interfering with the approach of the High Court in that behalf.   [Para 17]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Deduction towards development charges - Factors to be taken into consideration - Held having regard to location of land and other relevant factors 30% deduction towards development charges would meet ends of justice.

It is well settled that it is not in every case that deduction towards development charges has to be made when a big chunk of land is acquired for housing colonies etc. Where the acquired land falls in the midst of an already developed land with amenities of roads, electricity etc. deduction on this account may not be warranted. At the same time, where all civic and other amenities are to be provided to make it suitable for building purposes or under the local building regulations setting apart of some portion of the lands for providing common facilities is mandatory, an appropriate deduction may be justified.

In the light of the afore-noted parameters, in the instant case having regard to the relevant facts and circumstances of the case, including the location of the acquired land, a deduction of 30% towards development charges from the market value of land as arrived by the High Court, would meet the ends of justice.   [Para 19,21]

heading: Land acquisition appeal
Delay in filing
Condonation of
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition appeal - Delay in filing - Condonation of - In matters of compensation for land acquisition, approach of Court has to be pragmatic and liberal on aspect of condonation of delay - For purpose of balancing equities, applicants can be denied interest for period for which they did not approach Court - Such course would enable applicants to receive similar compensation as that received by adjoining land owners whose lands were acquired under same notification and granted enhanced compensation - State would also not be burdened by amount of interest as no interest would be payable for period of delay - Delay liable to be condoned. 			(Para 6)

heading: Compensation
Enhancement of
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Enhancement of - Claim by legal representative after death of claimant - Is maintainable. 			(Para 7)

heading: Market value
Determination
Rel.on.						 [Para 9,10]
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Determination - Norms required to be applied - Non-consideration of sale instances - But land-owner not prejudiced on that account - No interference needed.

It is now a well settled principle of law that the determination of the market value of the land acquired, indisputably would depend upon a large number of factors, including the nature and quality thereof. The norms which are required to be applied for determination of the market value of the agricultural land and homestead land may be different. In given cases location of land and in particular, closeness thereof from any road or high-way would play an important role for determination of the market value wherefor belting system may in appropriate cases have to be resorted to. The position of the land, particularly in rainy season, existence of any building etc. also plays an important role. A host of other factors including development in and around the acquired land and/or the potentiality of the development will have a bearing on determination of the value of the land. Determination of the market value of the land may also depend upon the facts and circumstances of each case, amongst them, however, would be the price of land, amount of consideration mentioned in a deed of sale executed in respect of similarly situated land near about the date of issuance of Notification under Section 4(1) of the Act; in the absence of any such exemplars the market value can be determined on yield basis or in case of an orchard on the basis of number of fruit bearing trees. 2005(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 449, (2004)13 SCC 643, (2005)12 SCC 59 - Rel.on.						 [Para 9,10]

heading: Market value
Determination of
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Determination of - Positive and negative factors to be considered by Court in fixing market value.

    Positive factors   Negative factors   (i) Smallness of size (i) Largeness of area   (ii) Proximity to a road (ii) Situation in the interior at a distance from the road   (iii)   Frontage on a road  (iii)  Narrow strip of land with very small frontage compared to depth   (iv) Nearness to developed area (iv) Lower level requiring the					depressed					portion to be					filled up   (v) Regular shape (v) Remoteness from developed locality   (vi)   Level vis-a-vis land under acquisition  (vi)  Some special disadvantage-	ous factors					which would					deter a						purchaser   (vii)   Special value for an owner of an adjoin- ing property to whom it may have some very special advantage. (vii)         [Para 10]

heading: Compensation
Determination
Agricultural land
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination - Agricultural land - Absence of sale instance - State should bring on record requisite information about land sought to be acquired.

In absence of any example of sale being available, the reference court was required to take recourse to other methods of valuation. We do not find that enough materials had been brought on record to establish the yield of the lands sought to be acquired, which are admittedly agricultural in nature. In all fairness, the State should have brought on record the requisite information, viz., the nature of the crop, the annual average yield, availability of irrigation facilities, etc. so as to enable the reference court to arrive at a correct decision in regard to grant of compensation under the Act.  The potentiality of a land for the purpose of development as also for building purposes would depend upon a large number of factors. For the said purpose, the court may not only have to bear in mind the purpose for which the lands were sought to be acquired but also the subsequent events to some extent. In a case of this nature the court may proceed on the presumption that such a vast tract of land, viz., 96 villages were sought to be acquired at the same time for construction of New Bombay. Development in the entire area was not possible at one point of time. Development of the area must have taken place in phases. Not the price of the land may skyrocket depending upon the development as also future potentiality. [Para 13,16]

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Wahal, one of the 96 villages near about 9 Kms from Panvel sought to be acquired for construction of New Bombay - It had a gram panchayat and electricity had not reached it as yet - Held, by taking recourse to belting system compensation at Rs.10 per sq. meter would subserve ends of justice.	(Paras 19, 21, 25)

heading: Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description:
Determination of compensation - Issues involved.

A holder of a land has a statutory right to ask the Collector by a written application that the matter be referred for determination to the court in regard to amount of compensation in terms of Section 18 of the Act while taking objection to the amount of compensation awarded by the Collector. The owner of the land may raise various contentions including the measurement of the land, the amount of compensation, the persons to whom it is payable, etc. For the purpose of getting the amount of compensation determined, the applicant may furthermore raise contentions as regards classification of land, non-grant of compensation under different heads, non-grant and/or inadequate grant of compensation under different Heads, etc.. The Reference Judge, thus, has a duty to consider all such objections. For the said purpose, opportunities must be given to the applicants to establish that the findings arrived at by the Collector in his award in respect of grant of compensation were based on a wrong classification of land and/or ignoring the relevant materials therefor.   [Para 17,18]

heading: Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description: Determination of compensation - Cannot be based on surmises and conjectures - It would be necessary in every case to place a correct report before Reference Court, the true state of affairs regarding the number of trees, their age, yield, in particular when capitalization method is to be adopted to determine market value of acquired land - No rule in absolute terms can be laid down.		(Paras 23, 24, 25, 26)

heading: Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description: Determination of compensation - Valuation of agricultural land on the one hand and valuation of orchard and forest on the other would stand on different footings - In the former case reference to exemplars will have to be applied, in the latter multiplier will have to be adopted. 2008 ALL SCR 51, 2005(5) ALL MR (S.C.) 293 - Rel. on.			(Para 32)

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Cannot be determined both on the basis of sale instance as also on capitalization method keeping in view the fact that it had fruit bearing trees.	(Para 33)

heading: Determination of compensation
HeadNote.description: Determination of compensation - A large number of factors have to be taken into consideration, namely, nature and quality of land, whether irrigated or unirrigated, facilities for irrigation like existence of well etc., presence of fruit bearing trees, the location of the land, closeness to any road or highway, the evenness thereof whether there exists any building or structure. 2008 ALL SCR 369 - Rel. on.	(Para 35)

heading: Contention not tenable
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition for Housing Society - Quashing by writ court - Locus standi of Society to file writ appeal - Contention raised that unless possession taken over by Govt. and award passed in favour of land owners, Society would have no right in acquired land and no locus to file writ appeal - Contention not tenable - Once the land is sought to be acquired in favour of Society and notifications issued u/Ss.4(1) and 6(1), Society acquires right to challenge the quashing of said acquisition. 			(Paras 24, 25)

heading: Land acquisition for Housing Society
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition for Housing Society - Whether involved a public purpose - Neither any scheme formulated nor any approval granted by State Govt. in terms of S.3(f)(vi) - Society had hired services of a company to act as middleman between Society and State Govt. and to get the land acquired in favour of Society - State Govt. exercised its eminent power of notifying acquisition merely at instance of such middleman, without considering irregularities in the affairs of Society and in blatant violation of provisions of law - Held, no "public purpose" can be said to be involved - Upholding such acquisitions would be akin to approving such type of agreements which are opposed to public policy - Concept of hiring middlemen to get lands of poor agriculturists acquired, is abhorrent and not sustainable. (1995) 2 SCC 677 Rel. on. 2012 ALL SCR 745, 2013(7) ALL MR 853 (S.C.) Ref. to.  (Paras 33, 34, 36, 37)

heading: Land acquisition
Not tenable
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Quashing of notification on ground of being "void ab initio" - Entitlement of land owners to seek relief who approached the court belatedly - Contention that claim of such land owners liable to be rejected on ground of delay - Not tenable - Once the proceedings are held void ab initio, original owners cannot be shut out from the Court - They are entitled to challenge the acquisition at any point of time even in collateral proceedings. 	(Para 42)

heading: Land acquisition for Housing Society
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition for Housing Society - Quashing of notification on ground of malafide - Subsequent sale of land to private parties by middleman - Whether such private purchasers deserve any protection - Land owners are poor agriculturists - Some of them had executed power of attorney in favour of middleman only for its sale to Housing Society - After quashing of notification, middleman sold land to his own family members and some other private parties - Held, such sale is void ab initio being fraudulent - Private purchasers not entitled to any relief - Land directed to be restored to original land owners. 			(Paras 43, 44)

heading: Release from acquisition
HeadNote.description: Release from acquisition - Not permissible after taking over possession - Test as to whether possession was complete - Documents on record show that notice was served to all co-owners, two of whom were present on prescribed date - Fact that SLAO took over possession on that date, clear from panchanama - Effecting mutation entries firstly in name of State Govt. and then in name of Development Authority, clearly establish that possession was complete - S.48 no more applicable - Subsequent direction of Revenue Minister for release of land u/S.48, without any jurisdiction - Liable to be set aside. 1975 ALLMR ONLINE 225 (S.C.) Ref.to.		(Paras 44, 45, 46, 54)

heading: Release from acquisition
Enforceability
HeadNote.description: Release from acquisition - Order of Revenue Minister - Enforceability - Concerned Minister only made a noting for release of land - Due to upcoming elections, Code of Conduct was in force and therefore, order of release never communicated to land owners - A mere noting does not partake nature of a legal order - It has no binding effect and it cannot create any right of release in favour of land owners - Besides, there cannot be a release without notification to that effect having been issued - Order of Revenue Minister, not enforceable. 1960 ALLMR ONLINE 323 (S.C.), 1987 ALLMR ONLINE 342 (S.C.), 1993 ALLMR ONLINE 204 (S.C.), 2008 ALL SCR 2649, 2010(1) ALL MR 911 (S.C.) Ref.to. 	(Paras 49, 50, 51)

heading: Award of compensation
Writ petition against
HeadNote.description: Award of compensation - Writ petition against - Award passed on 17.10.2014 - Petition filed on 26.10.2016, after lapse of more than 2 years - No explanation offered for such delay - More than 90% of compensation is already disbursed to affected persons and more than 60% work on project is over - Work was to be completed in October 2018, but has got delayed due to several litigations being filed in that regard - No case made out for invoking writ jurisdiction under Art.226. 	(Para 14)

heading: Calculation of compensation
HeadNote.description: Calculation of compensation - In case award is passed after New Act came into force - Compensation has to be calculated as per new Act of 2014 and not as per old Act. 			(Para 16)

heading: Acquisition proceedings
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Acquisition proceedings - Challenge - On count that objection u/S.5A of LA Act were calculated by one person and report submitted by another person - Land acquired for construction of ring road - Petitioner owner raised objection regarding alignment of ring road - After considering objections, Requisition Collector submitted report u/S.5A, which was not accepted twicely by administrator and was decided to be re-submitted after site inspection - While submitting report, specific noting made that every objection u/S.5A made to Collector in writing has been considered - Every effort made by authorities concerned to try and save properties of affected persons and after exhaustion of all remedies - Report finally re-submitted to administrator which was finally approved - Hence, challenge, not tenable.	(Para 11)

heading: Competent authority
Not acceptable
HeadNote.description: Competent authority - For issuing notification u/S.4 and declaration u/S.6 - Notification and declaration issued in name of administrator Diu, Daman and Dandra Nagar Haveli - Challenge by contending that appropriate Govt. in relation to acquisition for Union purpose would be Central Govt. - Not acceptable - Art.239(1) of Constitution and notifications dated 14th April, 1989 and 15th Dec, 2014, give power to administrator not only to issue notification u/S.4 and declaration u/S.6, but also power to undertake or sanction acquisition proceedings. 	(Para 9)

heading: Compensation
Determination of
Lime orchard
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of - Lime orchard - No special circumstances regarding nature, standard and condition of orchard - Multiplier of 10 to be applied in determining value by income capitalisation method.	(Para 7)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Acquisition of lime orchard - No specific documentary evidence in respect of actual income - Government experts valuing annual income from each tree as Rs.150-200/- - Average thereof viz. Rs.175/- can be accepted as annual income per tree - By deducting Rs.35/- towards cost of cultivation net income would be Rs.140/- per tree.	(Para 10)

HeadNote.sub_clause: Ss.3A and 3B (as inserted West Bengal Act 7 of 1997) and S.23
heading: Beel land requisitioned
HeadNote.description:
Beel land requisitioned - Such lands developed into residential plots can be treated as Sali plots for determining market value.

It is possible that Beel lands when developed into residential plots, by draining, filling and levelling the land, will cease to be Beel in nature. But it is also possible that the plots sold under sale deeds comparable were really Beel plots without any actual development. In the instant case there is no evidence to show that these plots were drained, filled, levelled and made into plots similar to Sali plots. The sale deeds refer to these plots as Beel plots. There is no dispute that at the relevant point of time the Sali plots were considered to be more valuable than Beel plots. Therefore it cannot be said that the value of these Beel plots should be treated on par with the value of Sali plots and that should form the basis for determining the market value of Sali Plot which were acquired. But the value of these Beel plots can be a clear indicator for determining the value of one acquired Beel plot.	 [Para 10,11]

heading: Compensation
Market value
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Market value - Determination - Exemplar sale transaction and preliminary notification for acquisition was in same year - No provision be made for appreciation in value.

When the relied upon sale transaction and the preliminary notification are in the same year, no provision is made for any appreciation in value. Therefore, unless the difference is more than one year, normally no addition should be made towards appreciation in value, unless there is special evidence to show some specific increase within a short period. 2008(6) ALL MR 491 (S.C.) Rel. on.	 [Para 13]

heading: Compensation
Market Value
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Market Value - Determination - Frontage advantage or facing particular direction - Considerations.

In the instant case the valuer has made one more addition to the basic value on account of frontage advantage of the acquired plots, that is 25%, 20% and 30% respectively for plot nos.62, 42 and 272 for having a frontage on a wider road thereby giving the advantage of a better FAR (floor area ratio) when undertaking construction. Addition of percentages for advantageous frontage, that too twice was unwarranted. Advantage of a better frontage is considered to be a plus factor while assessing the value of two similar properties, particularly in any commercial or residential area, when one has a better frontage than the other. However where the value of large tracts of undeveloped agricultural land situated on the periphery of a city in an area which is yet to be developed is being determined with reference to a value of nearby small residential plot, the question of adding any percentage for the advantage of frontage to the acquired lands, does not arise.					 [Para 14]

Also, the Expert Valuer has added 5% for plot No.62 for the advantage of being an east facing plot and 7% for plot no.42 for the advantage of being an east & east/south facing plots. When a large tract of land is made into several plots, most of the plots will cease to be east facing. Further, addition in value for facing a particular direction cannot be accepted.						 [Para 15]

heading: Compensation
Market value
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Market value - Determination - Small and large plots - From value of small plots i.e. retail price, wholesale price of land is to be estimated.

The prices fetched for small plots cannot form safe basis for valuation of large tracts of land and cannot be directly adopted in valuation of large tracts of land as the two are not comparable properties - the former reflects the 'retail' price of land and the latter the 'wholesale' price. However, if it is shown that the large extent to be valued does admit of and is ripe for use for building purposes; that building lots that could be laid out on the land would be good selling propositions and that valuation on the basis of the method of a hypothetical layout could with justification be adopted, then in valuing such small laid out sites the valuation indicated by sale of comparable small sites in the area at or about the time of the notification would be relevant. In such a case, necessary deductions for the extent of land required for the formation of roads and other civic amenities; expenses of development of the sites by laying out roads, drains, sewers, water and electricity lines, and the interest on the outlays for the period of deferment of the realization of the price; the profits on the venture etc., are to be made. From the value of small plots which represents what may be called the 'retail' price of land, the 'wholesale' price of land is to be estimated.			 [Para 17]

heading: Compensation
Market value
Determination
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Market value - Determination - relevant date is date of notification under S.4(1).

The market value has to be determined with reference to the date of publication of the notification under section 4(1) of LA Act. Though the lands were requisitioned in the year 1978 and possession was taken in pursuance of such requisition in 1978-79 and 80% of estimated value was given as advance under section 8B in pursuance of notification under section 4(1a) of WB Requisition Act, the said acquisition notification was not followed by an award and the acquisition notification was allowed to lapse. What is therefore relevant is the date of notification under section 4(1) of LA Act in pursuance of which the acquisition was completed.			 [Para 20]

Thus, the relevant date for determination of compensation would be the date of publication of the preliminary notification under section 4(1) of the LA Act. However in anticipation of acquisition the appellant/the Land Acquisition Officer had made any payment to the land owner they will be entitled to credit therefor with interest at 15% per annum from the date of payment to date of publication of preliminary notification. In section 23(1), the words "the date of publication of the notification under section 4(1)" would refer to the date of publication of the notification in the gazette.				      [Para 20,25]

heading: Meaning and construction
HeadNote.description:
Date of publication of notification - Meaning and construction - Under Ss.4 and 6 date of publication would mean the last date, out of dates of notifications in official gazette, in two daily newspapers and in convenient place of locality - However, under S.23 expression would mean date of notification in official gazette - Similar construction of the expression in all contexts would lead to disastrous results.

Also, One of the principles in regard to determination of market value under section 23(1) is that the rise in market value after the publication of the notification under section 4(1) of the Act should not be taken into account for the purpose of determination of market value. If the deeming definition of 'publication of the notification' in the amended section 4(1) is imported as the meaning of the said words in the first clause of section 23(1), it will lead to anomalous results. Owners of the lands which are the subject matter of the notification and neighbouring lands will come to know about the proposed acquisition, on the date of publication in the gazette or in the newspapers. If the giving of public notice of the substance of the notification is delayed by two or three months, there may be several sale transactions in regard to nearby lands in that period, showing a spurt or hike in value in view of the development contemplated on account of the acquisition itself.			 [Para 24]

heading: Power of eliminating enquiry
HeadNote.description: Power of eliminating enquiry - Acquisition of land for public purpose by itself shall not justify the exercise of power of eliminating enquiry under S.5 - A in terms of S.17 (1) and S.17 (4) of the Act - Held, the court should take judicial notice of the fact that certain public purpose such as development of residential, commercial, industrial or institutional areas by their intrinsic nature and character contemplates planning, execution and implementation of the schemes which generally takes time of few years. (1996) 2 SCC 549 and (1984) 4 SCC 308 - Ref. to.	(Para 9)

heading: Pre-notification delay
HeadNote.description: Pre-notification delay - Delay, by itself, does not create urgency for acquisition but accelerates urgency only in case it already exists in the nature of the public purpose.	(Para 13)

heading: Land acquisition
Non-payment of compensation
Justifiability
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Non-payment of compensation - Justifiability - Sale of acquired land subsequent to S.6 notification - Plea that due to dispute between original owner and the subsequent purchaser, compensation could neither be tendered nor paid - Held, such subsequent sale being illegal by virtue of S.4 of Delhi Act, said plea is of no avail - Moreover, authorities were not in dilemma at all as to who should be paid - Therefore, non payment of compensation not justified. (2008) 9 SCC 177 Ref. to.	(Para 23)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Determination of market value of land - Large chunk of land acquired for the purpose of establishment of rehabilitation centre - Sale deeds relied on by land owners pertain to very small plots, whereas acquired land is quite large - It is not safe to rely on one or two isolated sale deeds of high value of very small plots - Held, it would be just and proper to take out average value of these plots for determining market value of acquired land.  (1998) 2 SCC 385 Ref. to. (Paras 30, 31, 35)

heading: Land acquisition
Permissibility
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Determination of market value of land - Deduction towards development charges - Permissibility - Acquired land is not fully developed and is required for construction of rehabilitation centre - Held, it would be just, fair and proper to deduct 40% of amount towards development charges out of average value worked out. (1998) 2 SCC 385 Ref. to. (Para 31)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Fixation of market value of land - Notification u/S.4 issued in 1982 - Claimant agreed to purchase suit land prior to 1980 - Sale deed executed on 21/12/1981 - Development also started on suit land prior to issuance of S.4 notification - Representation was also made to Government for releasing certain portion of land which is already developed and Government also considered it - Hence, for fixing market value of acquired land instead of relying on valuation report and/or other sale instances best sale instance is of acquired land itself. (1996) 2 SCC 152, 1979 Mh.L.J. 494 Rel. on. 	(Para 24)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Whether market value of land can be fixed on basis of belting system or not - Land acquired for bus stand and depot - Before acquisition, land owners had submitted their plans for development of entire property for residential and commercial activities - Entire land is near developed area - In view of such facts market value cannot be fixed on basis of belting system. 2013 ALL SCR 2076, 2011 ALL SCR 1526, (1998) 2 SCC 385 Ref. to. 	(Para 31)

heading: Land acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Fixation of market value of land - Land situated in the heart of the city having all facilities - Same is abutting to road also - In view of judgment of Apex Court in matter of Bhupalsingh [2015 ALL SCR 2304] future potentiality can be considered - Therefore, increase of 20% taken into consideration - Claimant purchased land by sale deed dt.21/12/1981 @ 42.86 per sq.mtr. and notification u/S.4 issued on 30/8/1982 - Therefore, for 8 months increase comes to Rs.5.40 per sq. mtr. - Thus, market value of acquired land comes to 48.26 per sq. mtr. - However, considering law laid down in Apex Court judgment in Valliayammal 's case [2011(5) ALL MR 933 (S.C.)], 1/3 required to be deducted towards development charges - Thus, market value comes to 32.17 per sq. mtr. 2011(5) ALL MR 933 (S.C.), (2015) 5 SCC 801 Rel. on. 	(Para 35)

heading: Land Acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition - Determination of market value - Held, determination of market value of the land with building potentialities is an intricate exercise which calls for collection and collation of economic criteria - Though at times some guess work is permissible, what is impermissible are feats of imagination. AIR 1988 SC 1862 and 2001(4) ALL MR 874 (S.C.) - Ref. to. 	(Para 6)

heading: Sale instance
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Sale instance - Held, if at all any sale or award instance was to be considered as a guide for the purpose of fixing the market value of the acquired land, it ought to have been proximate to the date of notification and in the vicinity of the acquired land. 2005(2) ALL MR 258 - Ref. to. 	(Para 7)

heading: Acquisition of land
Compensation
Burden of proof
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Compensation - Burden of proof - Burden of proof that the amount awarded by Land Acquisition Officer is not adequate is always on the claimant by producing relevant and material evidence to establish that the acquired land was capable of fetching higher market value than the amount awarded by L.A.O. or that L.A.O. had produced a wrong premise - Burden does not shift to the Government. AIR 1997 SC 1779 - Rel. on.	(Para 17)

heading: Solatium
HeadNote.description: Solatium - Entitlement of owner of the land - Held, solatium is available only in cases where the land has actually been acquired - If the land is released from acquisition, claimant not entitled to solatium, as he is put in position of "no acquisition".			(Paras 12, 13)

heading: Reduction of damages
HeadNote.description: Reduction of damages - Land reserved by notification u/S.31(1) of Town Planning Act on 31/8/76 - It is equivalent to notification u/S.4 of LA Act - Determination of compensation u/S.48(2)(3), S.23(1A) - It is mandatory u/ S.23 to award amount @ of 12% per annum on market value for period commencing from date of publication of notification u/S.4 - Reducing rate from 12% to 10% not sustainable. 1999 (1) LAC 86 Ref.to.	(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Determination of compensation
Award issued u/S.48(2)
HeadNote.description: Determination of compensation - Land reserved by notification u/S.31(1) of Town Planning Act on 31/8/76 - It is equivalent to notification u/S.4 of LA Act - Award issued u/S.48(2) - Notification was under S.126(4) of Town Planning Act issued for acquisition which is equivalent to notification u/S.6 of LA Act - Award issued u/S.48(2) of LA Act - Authority has considered market value of land on date of notification u/S.4 - Price of land was higher on 6/7/86 i.e. date of notification u/S.6 - Contention that date of notification u/S.6 should have been considered while deciding compensation is liable to be rejected. 	(Para 17)

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Acquired land situated in close vicinity of various residential colonies, educational institutions, hospitals etc. and is on junction of two important roads - Therefore, it can safely be concluded that the land is semi-urban and has huge potential for being developed as housing sites - Held, High court should have added 10% Per annum escalation in the price specified in the sale deeds relied upon for fixing market value of the acquired land. (2005) 9 SCC 594 - Ref. to.	(Para 23)

heading: Determination of market value
HeadNote.description: Determination of market value - Court cannot be oblivious of the fact that the land owners have been deprived of the only source of livelihood, the cost of living has gone up manifold and the purchasing power of rupee has substantially declined. (2004) 2 SCC 283 - Ref. to. 	(Para 25)

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description:
Reference - Strict rules of pleadings, as well as consequence of non-filing of written statement as envisaged under O.8 CPC - Would not be applicable to proceedings u/S.18.

The objections under section 18 and the statement under section 19 cannot be treated as a plaint or suit. As a consequence thereof strict rules of pleading as well as the consequences of non filing of the written statement as envisaged under Order VIII CPC would not be applicable to proceedings under section 18 of the Act.. In such proceedings, wherein objections are restricted to the quantum of compensation, burden is on the claimant to prove that the compensation awarded by the Collector is not reasonable and that the land possessed higher value. The beneficiary of the acquisition, though not entitled to seek a reference, has right to adduce evidence, which is restricted to and relevant for the purpose of determining the amount of compensation. Eventually, it is for the reference court to decide the value of the land as on the date of Section 4 notification. (Para 21)

heading: Notice under
HeadNote.description: Notice under - Beneficiary of acquisition had statutory right to participate in proceedings before Reference Court - And lead evidence to defend the award or to rebut evidence adduced by claimants - Hence, issuance of notice to him by Reference Court, is mandatory. (Para 22)

heading: Reference
HeadNote.description: Reference - Claimants allowed beneficiary of acquisition to participate in proceedings - And to adduce evidence without demur - Indicates that there was no element of surprise - Claimants cannot subsequently complain that said beneficiary was not entitled to adduce evidence in absence of written statement. (Para 22)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description: Compensation - Determination of market value - Genuine agreement for sale pertaining to very same land, executed three years prior to publication of S.4 Notification - Cannot be discarded solely on ground that it does not create interest in property as envisaged u/S.54 of TP Act - No direct or substantive evidence to indicate that as on date of agreement, claimants were aware that beneficiary of acquisition was interested in said land or that acquisition process was likely to be initiated at his instance - Thus, Reference Court not justified in drawing such presumption and discarding the said agreement, which reflected true value of land at time of acquisition - In view of facts, relying upon sale deeds in respect of neighbouring land by Reference Court, was not proper. (Paras 29, 30, 31)

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
Market value
Determination of
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Compensation - Market value - Determination of - Annual increase in value of land at flat rate of 12% - Reference Court as well as High Court while determining value of land, considered sale deed which is more than 9 years before acquisition notification - Land owners claiming that increase in land value should be on cumulative basis - Assuming that land owners are right in submitting that increase should have been on cumulative basis - No reason to interfere with annual increase in land at 12%. 	(Para 6)

heading: Land acquisition
Compensation
Challenge
HeadNote.description: Land acquisition - Compensation - Deduction of 15% towards development charges - Challenge - Acquired land at relevant time was agricultural land - Further, considering that sale deed relied on was of big chunk of land and location of acquired land and that land was acquired for spinning mill - Deduction of 15% towards development charges, proper.	(Para 6)

heading: Writ petition against
Maintainability
HeadNote.description: Award of Reference Court - Enhancing amount of compensation - Writ petition against - Maintainability - Locus of petitioner, seriously disputed - Dispute also arose as to whether petitioner can be said to be ‘person interested’ within definition of S.3(b) of LA Act - Thus, disputed questions of facts and contentious issues involved - Therefore, High Court ought not to have entertained writ petition u/Art.226 and ought not to have set aside judgment and award passed by Reference Court - Remedy available to petitioner is to prefer appeal before High Court with application for leave to appeal. (Paras 8, 9)

headline: Land acquisition – Compensation determined for lands acquired subsequently, cannot be said to be comparable at all.

heading: Land Acquisition
Compensation
Enhancement
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition - For purpose of planned development of industries in area - Compensation - Enhancement - Notification u/S.4 issued and also possession of land taken over in 1976 and award passed in 1978 - In case relied upon notification u/S.4 was issued in year 1991 and possession of land taken over in year 1992 and award was passed in 1993 - Thus case relied upon cannot be said to be comparable at all because of time gap of approximately 15 years between dates of acquisition - Moreover, in First appeal in case relied upon, High Court enhanced compensation by inadvertently tagging First appeals without noticing difference with regard to acquisition of years 1977 and 1991 - Review applications preferred in aforesaid first appeals which are reported to be pending - In view of said obvious mistake, claimants in present case cannot claim enhancement of compensation relying upon decision in case with regard to acquisition of year 1991.			(Para 13)

headline: Land acquisition – Compensation determined for lands acquired subsequently, cannot be said to be comparable at all.

heading: Land Acquisition
Compensation
Enhancement
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition - For purpose of planned development of industries in area - Compensation - Enhancement - Compensation determined for lands acquired subsequently, cannot be said to be comparable at all - Even otherwise in year 1976 when lands in question were acquired, there was no development at all - However, subsequently, after 1980 development had taken place and even the development plan was sanctioned at time when comparable land was acquired in year 1983 - Compensation for lands in question cannot be determined on basis of case relied upon where acquisition proceedings commenced in year 1983 and compensation was determined - Plea that by adopting formula of deducting 10% depreciation each year and after deducting 10% depreciation for 07 years, enhanced compensation may be determined, held, not tenable.	(Paras 14, 15)

heading: Market value
Determination
Improper
HeadNote.description:
Market value - Determination - Subject land admeasuring 5.34 HR is a barren land situated in deserted village - Determination of market value on basis of sale instance of a small residential plot of 158.85 Sq. m. belonging to an established village - Improper - Not a case that no other material was available - Award in respect of adjoining lands (acquired by same notification) were already passed - That could have been best guide - Market value fixed at same rate - Award of Reference court set aside.
	(2003) 4 SCC 481 Rel. on. (Paras 22, 31, 32, 33, 35)

HeadNote.sub_clause: Ss.28(2) and 23(1-A) (as amended by Act 68 of 1984)
heading: Acquisition of Land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of Land - Entitlement to Additional compensation amount - Would be available only to claimants who had applied and in respect of whom proceedings were pending prior to 30-04-1982.

If it is not open to the Courts to award compensation under section 23(1-A) where the award was made before 30-04-1982 or who had applied under section 18 or where dispute was referred under Section 30 of the Land Acquisition Act to get the additional compensation, merely because an additional right has been conferred on the claimant to apply under section 28(A), would not result in such claimant being entitled to benefits which otherwise were not available to claimants where awards were passed before 30-04-1982.  The Section would have to be read to mean that under Section 28(A) also, those claimants would be entitled to the benefit under Section 23(1-A) which were available to the claimants in respect of whom proceedings were pending before the Collector on 30-04-1982. 2002(2) ALL MR 630 (S.C.) & 1991 SCC 277 Rel. foll.  [Para 4]

heading: Acquisition of Land
Award of compensation
Redetermination of amount
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of Land - Award of compensation - Redetermination of amount - Party not making any claim after notice u/s. 9 - May be allowed to make claim by reference Court u/s. 25 for sufficient reason.

A perusal of sub-section (3) of section 28(A), would show that any person who has not accepted the award under sub-section (2) may, by written application to the Collector require that the matter be referred by the Collector for determination of the Court and the provisions of sections 18 to 28 shall so far as may be, apply to such reference as they apply to a reference under section 18.  In other words the provisions of sections 18 to 28 are also made applicable while considering the reference under section 28(A).  What this would mean is that the provisions of section 25(4) and (5) as they stood before the amendment, would also be applicable in those cases where the amended provisions of the Act are not applicable.  That would mean that under section 25, the Reference Court for sufficient reason can allow party to make a claim, even if the claim had not been made.  It will also mean that it will be open to the party to make a higher claim, if the claim had been restricted and for the Reference Court to consider whether it should be allowed.  It would not be possible to construe the power under section 25 to only those cases where no claim had been made.  To give effect to the provisions, it would cover both situations, where either claimant had not made a claim or had made a lesser claim.  In such cases the reference Court for sufficient cause can allow the party to make the claim.  It is, therefore, clear that there was discretion in the reference court even prior to the amendment to allow a party to make claim if not made in reply to a notice served under Section 9 or to permit a higher claim than that made in a reply to the notice under Section 9 of the Act.  [Para 5]

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description:
Acquisition of land - Process of acquisition has been duly complied with - Possession already taken in due process of law - Title of land has vested upon respondent - Not a case where possession was taken for temporary occupation, which would otherwise entitle party for compensation - Hence provisions of S.36(2) would not be applicable - Therefore dismissal of suit as not maintainable held, proper.

AIR 2008 (NOC) 2831 (A&P), AIR 2005 (NOC) 459 (Madras) Disting. 	 [Para 11]

heading: Notification under S.4(1)
HeadNote.description:
Notification under S.4(1) - Subsequent  declaration under S.6(1) within three years quashed by court - Fresh notification under S.6(1) though made beyond period of three years from date of S.4(1) notification is not invalid.

AIR 1980 Mad 251 (FB) Rel. on. (Para 5)

heading: Acquisition of land for Mysore Urban Development Authority (MUDA)
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land for Mysore Urban Development Authority (MUDA) - Withdrawal at the instance of land owners - Objected to by MUDA - State Govt. issuing another notification cancelling earlier notification - While doing so land owners not heard - Both notifications quashed and matter remanded to State Govt. to decide afresh after hearing both the landowners and MUDA.	(Paras 10, 11, 14)

heading: Compensation
HeadNote.description:
Compensation - Determination of market value - For determination of market value of the land acquired in terms of the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act, it depends upon large number of factors, first being the nature and quality of the land i.e. whether agricultural land or non-agricultural land has to be considered.

For determination of the market value of the land acquired in terms of the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act, it depends upon large number of factors, first being the nature and quality of the land i.e. whether agricultural land or non agricultural land. Apart from nature and quality of the land, in the event of agricultural lands are acquired, the other factors relevant therefore are also required to be considered, namely, as to whether they are irrigated or non irrigated lands, the extent of facilities available for irrigation, location of the land, closeness thereof from any road or high way. On these factors the market value of the land always depends.  2007(5) ALL MR 711 - Rel. on.			 [Para 11]

heading: Reference under S.18
HeadNote.description:
Reference under S.18 - Only issue raised was about enhancement of compensation awarded - Court can decide only this issue - Determination of inter se apportionment under S.30, would be wholly without jurisdiction.

The reference court derives jurisdiction from the reference made. References under Section 18 and Section 30 are conceptually different from each other. The decree in terms of Section 18 is different from the one in terms of Section 30. Remedy available in terms of Section 55 of the Act is against a decree. The question whether reference court can deal with the question covered by Section 30 of the Act in a reference made under Section 18 of the Act and vice versa has been the subject matter of judicial determination. In (Rai) Pramatha Nath Mullick Bahadur Vs. Secry. of State (AIR 1930 PC 64) it was held that the jurisdiction of the courts under the Act is a special one and strictly limited to the terms of Sections 18, 20 and 21. It only arises when a specific objection has been taken to the Collector's Award and it is confined to a consideration of that objection. Therefore, it is certain that when the only objection taken is to the amount of compensation that alone is the matter referred and the Court has no jurisdiction to determine or consider anything beyond it. (2003)5 SCC 561 and (2002)9 SCC 426 Rel. on.  [Para 12]

Every tribunal of limited jurisdiction is not only entitled but bound to determine whether the matter in which it is asked to exercise its jurisdiction comes within the limits of its special jurisdiction and whether the jurisdiction of such tribunal is dependent on the existence of certain facts or circumstances. Its obvious duty is to see that these facts and circumstances exist to invest it with jurisdiction, and where a tribunal derives its jurisdiction from the statute that creates it and that statute also defines the conditions under which the tribunal can function, it goes without saying that before that tribunal assumes jurisdiction in a matter, it must be satisfied that the conditions requisite for its acquiring seisin of that matter have in fact arisen. (1855)6 M.I.A. 134 (PC), (1979)2 SCC 572 and AIR 1965 SC 304 - Rel. on.		 [Para 14]

heading: Public purpose
Determination
Judicial review
Scope
HeadNote.description:
Public purpose - Determination - Discretion of State, exercise of - Judicial review - Scope - Primarily it is for State to decide whether there exists public purpose or not - Decision of State though not beyond judicial scrutiny, a writ court shall not interfere unless such power exercised mala fide or for collateral purposes or purported action, de hors the Act, irrational or otherwise unreasonable or so-called purpose is 'no public purpose' at all and fraud on statute is apparent - A writ court, while exercising powers under Articles 32, 226 or 136 of Constitution, cannot substitute its own judgment for judgment of Government as to what constitutes 'public purpose'.

The State of Andhra Pradesh in the background of 'World Tourism Organization Report' and 'Vision 2020 Document' took a policy decision for the development of the City of Hyderabad. For the said purpose, it decided to establish an Integrated Project which would make Hyderabad a major Business-cum-Leisure Tourism Infrastructure Centre for the State. The project is both structurally as well as financially integrated. It is to be implemented through Andhra Pradesh Infrastructure and Investment Corporation (APIIC) which has taken all steps to make Hyderabad a world-class business destination. APIIC is an instrumentality of State and works as 'Nodal Agency' developing the project which would facilitate socio-economic progress of the State by generating revenues, weeding out unemployment and bringing new avenues and opportunities for public at large. Development of infrastructure is legal and legitimate 'public purpose' for exercising power of eminent domain. Simply because a Company has been chosen for fulfillment of such public purpose does not mean that the larger public interest has been sacrificed, ignored or disregarded. It will also not make exercise of power bad, mala fide or for collateral purpose vitiating the proceedings.   [Para 166,168]

It is clearly established in this case that the Infrastructure Development Project conceived by the State and executed under the auspices of its instrumentality (APIIC) is one covered by the Act. The Joint Venture Mechanism for implementing the policy, executing the project and achieving lawful public purpose for realizing the goal of larger public good would neither destroy the object nor vitiate the exercise of power of public purpose for development of infrastructure. The concept of joint venture to tap resources of private sector for infrastructural development for fulfillment of public purpose has been recognized in foreign countries as also in India in several decisions of this Court.   [Para 170]

The entire amount of compensation is to be paid by State agency (APIIC) which also works as nodal agency for execution of the project. It is primarily for the State to decide whether there exists public purpose or not. Undoubtedly, the decision of the State is not beyond judicial scrutiny. In appropriate cases, where such power is exercised mala fide or for collateral purposes or the purported action is de hors the Act, irrational or otherwise unreasonable or the so-called purpose is 'no public purpose' at all and fraud on statute is apparent, a writ-court can undoubtedly interfere. But except in such cases, the declaration of the Government is not subject to judicial review. In other words, a writ court, while exercising powers under Articles 32, 226 or 136 of the Constitution, cannot substitute its own judgment for the judgment of the Government as to what constitutes 'public purpose'.   [Para 171]

heading: Constitution of India, Art.226
HeadNote.description: Constitution of India, Art.226 - Lapse of acquisition proceedings - Alleged non-payment of amount of compensation - Possession of land taken in 2008 however, amount of compensation was not paid to petitioner - Respondent stated that said amount was deposited in Personal Ledger Account (PLA) of Special Land Acquisition officer (SLAO) and it was obligation of petitioner to collect the same - Held, mere deposit of amount in account of SLAO does not amount to payment of compensation to petitioner - Therefore, S.24(2) of Act 2013 squarely applicable - Acquisition proceedings deemed to have lapsed. 2016 ALL SCR 1948 Rel. on. (Paras 2, 3, 11)

heading: Challenge to land acquisition proceedings
HeadNote.description: Challenge to land acquisition proceedings - Defence of locus of applicant - Contention that defence of locus not raised in replies - Held, failure to raise a defence in replies, can bar a party from raising contention on related facts - Defence based on implications of law on admitted facts not barred. AIR 1982 P & H 519 (FB) Not good law in view of (1996)6 SCC 407.	(Para 13)

heading: Determination
HeadNote.description:
Market value of acquired land - Determination - Averaging of various sale instances produced by acquiring authority to reduce compensation payable - Not proper.

(1967) MH.L.J. 45 (SC), 1994 5 SCC 734, (2010)13 SCC 710 Rel. on. (Para 12)

heading: Lapse of compulsory acquisition
HeadNote.description:
Lapse of compulsory acquisition - On account of non payment of compensation - Compensation amount originally awarded in year 1995 to the appellant was deposited in Govt. Treasury and not in Reference Court - Only the enhanced amount was deposited in Reference Court - It was only after commencement of 2013 Act, that originally awarded amount was deposited in Reference Court just to get over the provisions of S.24(2) - Held, such a belated deposit cannot be treated as "deemed payment" - Acquisition proceedings lapsed so far as appellant is concerned.

2014(2) ALL MR 923 (S.C.) Rel. on.

(2014) 6 SCC 564, (2014) 6 SCC 586, 2015(2) ALL MR 940 (S.C.), 2014(6) ALL MR 414 (S.C.) Ref. to. 	(Paras 21, 22)

heading: Land Acquisition
HeadNote.description: Land Acquisition - Compensation under new Act - Possession of land taken in year 1997 - No compensation paid till 1.1.2014 when new Act came into force - It was paid only in 2016 in accordance with old Act - Held, such subsequent payment would have no adverse effect on right of petitioners to claim compensation in accordance with new Act, 2013 - Payment of compensation directed accordingly. 2014(2) ALL MR 923 (S.C.) Rel. on. (Paras 5, 6, 7, 9)

heading: Expression "compensation has not been paid" in S.24(2) of 2013 Act
HeadNote.description:
Expression "compensation has not been paid" in S.24(2) of 2013 Act - Meaning and effect on subject acquisition - Land acquisition more than five years prior to commencement of 2013 Act - Persons interested not consenting to receive compensation - Compensation money deposited in government treasury - Cannot be treated as equivalent to compensation paid to land owners / persons interested - Held, in such a case land acquisition proceedings shall be deemed to have lapsed under S.24(2) of the 2013 Act. 

For the purposes of Section 24(2), the compensation shall be regarded as "paid" if the compensation has been offered to the person interested and such compensation has been deposited in the court where reference under Section 18 can be made on happening of any of the contingencies contemplated under Section 31(2) of the 1894 Act. In other words, the compensation may be said to have been "paid" within the meaning of Section 24(2) when the Collector (or for that matter Land Acquisition Officer) has discharged his obligation and deposited the amount of compensation in court and made that amount available to the interested person to be dealt with as provided in Sections 32 and 33. 1894 Act being an expropriatory legislation has to be strictly followed. The procedure, mode and manner for payment of compensation are prescribed in Part V (Sections 31-34) of the 1894 Act. The Collector, with regard to the payment of compensation, can only act in the manner so provided. It is settled proposition of law that where a power is given to do a certain thing in a certain way, the thing must be done in that way or not at all. Other methods of performance are necessarily forbidden.

The deposit of compensation amount in the government treasury is of no avail and cannot be held to be equivalent to compensation paid to the landowners/persons interested. The subject land acquisition proceedings shall be deemed to have lapsed under Section 24(2) of the 2013 Act.  [Para 17,18,20]

heading: Acquisition of land
HeadNote.description: Acquisition of land - Appellant in possession of land throughout the proceedings as land was protected by status quo order of courts - Physical possession was never taken by LAO after award was passed - Averment that possession was taken, was false and could not be accepted - Held, as neither physical possession was taken nor compensation awarded was paid to appellant, acquisition proceedings of the land would be deemed to have lapsed.			(Paras 15, 16)

heading: Compensation under new Act
HeadNote.description:
Compensation under new Act - In respect of certain land notified under old Act - Provisions of sub-section (2) of S.24 carve out an exception - Condition precedent for seeking compensation under new Act is making of Award 5 yrs or more prior to the commencement of new Act. 

Provisions of Section 24 (2), to which the Proviso is appended, would apply only to the Awards that are made five years of more, prior to the commencement of the Act of 2013. The Award was made on 09.07.2009 and the Act of 2013 came into force on 01.01.2014. The Award was not made five years or more, prior to the commencement of the Act on 01.01.2014. Since, the Proviso appears to have been appended to sub-section (2) of Section 24 of the Act of 2013, the petitioners would not be entitled to seek compensation under the provisions of the new Act.

Also, it is clear from the provisions of Section 24(1)(b) that where the Award is made under Section 11 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, then such proceedings shall continue under the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 as if the Act was not repealed. The provisions of sub-section 2 of Section 24 carve out an exception to the provisions of Section 24(1)(b) of the Act of 2013 and create a class of acquisitions in respect of the Awards, which have been made five years or more, prior to the commencement of the Act of 2013 under the Land Acquisition Act, 1894, but where the physical possession of the land is not taken or the compensation has not been paid, for the purpose of lapsing. The Proviso, being applicable to the provisions of sub-section 2 of Section 24, the condition precedent for seeking compensation under the Act of 2013 would be the making of the Award five years or more prior to the commencement of the Act of 2013.        [Para 6]

heading: Lapse of acquisition of land

Petition for

heading: Benefit of S. 24
HeadNote.description:
Benefit of S. 24 - Claim for by purchaser of land after issuance of notification u/S. 4 of Act of 1894 - Sale effected after issuance of notification u/S. 4 is void - Such purchaser cannot invoke provisions of S. 24 and is not entitled to benefit of S. 24. 
	S. 24 (2) provides that in case the award has been passed five years or more prior to the commencement of the Act, but the physical possession of the land has not been taken, or the compensation has not been paid, the said proceedings shall be deemed to have lapsed. It is not the case set up that compensation had not been paid to purchasers/owners. The only case set up is that physical possession has not been taken and proceedings of taking over possession have been questioned to take advantage of provisions under S. 24(2) of the Act of 2013. Whereas, averment in the writ petition itself indicates that possession had been taken over in the year 2000 and that unauthorized colonies have come up in the area. Thus, it is clear that possession, if any, is illegal, and in fact, the actual physical possession had been taken, and re-entering in possession in an unauthorized manner can confer no right. There is nothing to doubt that actual physical possession had been taken in 2000. Thus, S. 24(2) is not attracted in the case. 
	Even otherwise, proviso to S. 24(2) does not recognize a purchaser after S. 4 notification inasmuch as it provides that where an award has been made, and the compensation in respect of a majority of land holdings has not been deposited in the account of the beneficiaries, then, all beneficiaries specified in the notification for acquisition issued under the Act of 1894, shall be entitled to compensation under the provisions of the Act of 2013. The proviso makes it clear that in case of compensation concerning the majority of landholding has not been deposited, then recorded owner(s) at the time of issuance of notification under S. 4 of the Act of 1894 shall have the right to receive the compensation. Purchasers after S. 4 notification have not been given the right to receive the higher compensation under the provisions contained in the act of 2013. Such a person who has purchased after S. 4 notification, as sale deed is void under the Act of 1894, cannot claim rehabilitation and resettlement as per policy envisaged under the Act of 2013, as his land has not been acquired, but he has purchased a property which has already been acquired by the State Government, he cannot claim even higher compensation, as per proviso to S. 24(2) under the Act of 2013. The transaction of sale, effected after S. 4 notification, is void, is ineffective to transfer the land, such incumbents cannot invoke the provisions of S. 24. It would be unfair and profoundly unjust and against the policy of the law to permit such a person to claim resettlement or claim the land back as envisaged under the Act of 2013. When he has not been deprived of his livelihood but is a purchaser under a void transaction. (2017) 6 SCC 751 Overruled, (1975) 2 SCC 232; (1988) 2 SCC 602 Foll. (Paras 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21)
